abstract: Readers suggest that U.S. gains and goals, including rights for women, could be jeopardized if a hasty withdrawal is made.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Bittersweet Juice WRLD Team-Up, and 13 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by 24kGoldn, Beach Bunny, Kali Uchis and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Dia Chelsea to Reopen in April
abstract: The pioneering institution, which has revitalized its gallery and program spaces, will showcase work by Lucy Raven in the spring.
lead_paragraph: After a two-year renovation and expansion in three adjacent industrial buildings on West 22nd Street in New York, Dia Chelsea will reopen in April with new, internally connected spaces and a cohesive look to its facade. Admission will be permanently free.

headline: Overlooked No More: Barbara Waxman Fiduccia, Reproductive Rights Advocate
abstract: A sexual health educator and counselor in Los Angeles, she challenged a dominant culture that viewed people with disabilities as asexual beings.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

headline: Covid Survivors With Long-Term Symptoms Need Urgent Attention, Experts Say
abstract: In a two-day meeting sponsored by the N.I.H., officials acknowledged an insufficient understanding of the issues and warned of a growing public health problem.
lead_paragraph: There is an urgent need to address long-term symptoms of the coronavirus, leading public health officials said this week, warning that hundreds of thousands of Americans and millions of people worldwide might experience lingering problems that could impede their ability to work and function normally.

headline: Pelosi voices optimism on stimulus after McConnell agrees to compromise on a year-end spending bill.
abstract: Speaker Nancy Pelosi flashed fresh optimism on Friday that the House and Senate could soon reach a bipartisan deal on an elusive pandemic stimulus plan after she and Senator Mitch McConnell, the Senate majority leader, agreed to try to find an agreement that could be merged with an enormous year-end spending package.
lead_paragraph: Speaker Nancy Pelosi flashed fresh optimism on Friday that the House and Senate could soon reach a bipartisan deal on an elusive pandemic stimulus plan after she and Senator Mitch McConnell, the Senate majority leader, agreed to try to find an agreement that could be merged with an enormous year-end spending package.

headline: The Man Guiding Italy’s Oldest Opera House Through the Pandemic
abstract: After warring with powerful unions in Paris, Stéphane Lissner has moved to Naples to run the Teatro di San Carlo.
lead_paragraph: NAPLES, Italy — Six years ago, Stéphane Lissner left Milan after a decade managing Italy’s most famous opera house, the Teatro alla Scala, to run the Paris Opera.

headline: ‘What Can I Feel? The Most Important Is That We Are Alive’
abstract: A village on the frontline of the war between Azerbaijan and Armenia welcomes peace — after more than two decades.
lead_paragraph: CIRAQLI, Azerbaijan — The fate of the people of Ciraqli, in a rural corner of the southern Caucasus, had long been forgotten by the outside world since a war between Azerbaijan and Armenia halted in a cease-fire in 1994. But the conflict never ended for the villagers.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: The Weekender: Legendary singers reflect on their most memorable performances. Also in this edition: the ghosts of segregation, how music programs are surviving the pandemic and more.
lead_paragraph: The Weekender: Legendary singers reflect on their most memorable performances. Also in this edition: the ghosts of segregation, how music programs are surviving the pandemic and more.

headline: The State of the Virus This Week
abstract: A look at the news from the team tracking the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: A look at the news from the team tracking the coronavirus.

headline: Reopening Schools Before a Children’s Vaccine
abstract: Experts say we may not need to wait.
lead_paragraph: The first coronavirus vaccines for adults are nearly here, but children’s vaccines will take a lot longer. Pfizer and Moderna’s pediatric trials are just getting started for children older than 12.

headline: Why ‘Wonder Woman’ at Home Matters
abstract: The Netflix model is winning, and the entertainment industry may be changed forever.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: Frank Carney, Co-Founder of Pizza Hut, Dies at 82
abstract: When he was 19, Mr. Carney and his brother Dan borrowed $600 from their mother to start their business in Wichita, Kan. Before long it became the world’s largest pizza chain.
lead_paragraph: Frank Carney, who founded Pizza Hut with his brother Dan and helped build it into the world’s largest pizza chain, died on Wednesday at an assisted living facility in Wichita, Kan. He was 82.

headline: Powerfully Flavored Pasta
abstract: Mark Bittman’s puttanesca is as easy and satisfying as anything you’ll make all month.
lead_paragraph: Hello and welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes, the newsletter for busy people who still want something good to eat.

headline: House Passes Landmark Bill Decriminalizing Marijuana
abstract: The House passed sweeping legislation that would decriminalize marijuana and expunge nonviolent marijuana-related convictions. The measure is all but doomed in the Republican-led Senate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House on Friday passed sweeping legislation that would decriminalize marijuana and expunge nonviolent marijuana-related convictions, as Democrats sought to roll back and compensate for decades of drug policies that have disproportionately affected low-income communities of color.

headline: Drilling and the Pandemic
abstract: A reader faults the president’s priorities in the midst of a health crisis. Also: The problem with electric vehicles.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Share Your Post-Pandemic Firsts
abstract: What will you do when the pandemic finally wanes? The Times would love to hear from you.
lead_paragraph: With the number of coronavirus cases, and deaths, setting records almost daily, news that a vaccine could be ready before the end of 2020 was a ray of hope — the first suggestion that there might be an “after time” to the pandemic, as well as the fondly remembered “before time.”

headline: Park With Covid Memorial Is Rising on Site of Former Toxic Dump
abstract: Hundreds of trees will be planted in a grove at the new Skyway Park — one for every resident of Jersey City who has died of the virus.
lead_paragraph: JERSEY CITY, N.J. — Of all the toxic dumps in New Jersey, perhaps none was more infamous than PJP Landfill.

headline: Doctors Are Skeptical of Pricey Drug Given Emergency Approval for Covid
abstract: Baricitinib, an arthritis drug made by Eli Lilly, may reduce recovery time by a day, but costs about $1,500 and comes with side effects.
lead_paragraph: In mid-November, an arthritis drug with a tricky name hit a pandemic milestone — then slipped back into relative obscurity.

headline: What Hearing Loss Feels Like in ‘Sound of Metal’
abstract: The director Darius Marder and the sound designer Nicolas Becker went to great lengths to put viewers inside the head of a musician going deaf.
lead_paragraph: Creating an audioscape for a movie about a musician losing his hearing is more complicated than it may seem. The filmmakers behind the new drama “Sound of Metal” wanted to take audiences into the experience of its lead character, Ruben (Riz Ahmed), a punk-metal drummer who is forced to look at his life differently as he goes deaf.

headline: ‘The Mandalorian’ Season 2, Episode 6: Things Fall Apart
abstract: A familiar face appears in search of some armor. Grogu tries on an uncomfortable but adorable new accessory.
lead_paragraph: This season’s shortest episode of “The Mandalorian” turned out to be the most consequential so far. In 30 breathless minutes — mostly made up of one long action sequence — “The Tragedy” offers a sudden and rapid acceleration this year’s main story line. By the end of the half-hour, Din Djarin has lost almost everything, including his ship and his tiny friend Grogu. In their stead he gains two new allies and a critical assignment. For the sake of the galaxy and to mend his own broken heart, he must get the Child back.

headline: Love Letter: No Limitations on an Interabled Couple’s Love
abstract: Plus: Is pandemic ghosting the new normal?
lead_paragraph: When Charisma Jamison and Cole Sydnor first met at the Sheltering Arms Physical Rehabilitation Centers in Richmond, Va., Ms. Jamison noticed Mr. Sydnor working out and thought he was good looking. Mr. Sydnor, who is a quadriplegic, is paralyzed from the shoulders down with limited function in his arms and wrists.

headline: You Might Be Grounded, But Your Frequent Flier Miles Don’t Have to Be
abstract: Not many of us are jet-setting around the world this year. Take those loyalty points and put them to good use.
lead_paragraph: This may not have been the year in which you used many of your frequent flier miles or loyalty points, but that doesn’t mean you can’t put them to good use while they idle in your accounts.

headline: Here is what went viral this week.
abstract: Stories about Elliot Page, BTS and a rare “Christmas Star” dominated social media this week.
lead_paragraph: Here at Daily Distortions, we try to debunk false and misleading information that has gone viral. We also want to give you a sense of how popular that misinformation is, in the context of what is being discussed on social media. With the help of NewsWhip, a firm that compiles social media performance data, we made a list of the 10 most-engaged stories of the week in the United States. (NewsWhip tracks the number of reactions, shares and comments each URL receives on Facebook, along with shares on Pinterest and by a group of influential users on Twitter.)

headline: Prominent New York Priest Is Investigated Over Sexual Assault Accusation
abstract: The Manhattan district attorney’s office said it was investigating the Rev. George William Rutler after a security guard said he attacked her at his church.
lead_paragraph: A nationally prominent Catholic priest is under criminal investigation after a security guard assigned to his church accused him of sexually assaulting her on Election Day, the Manhattan district attorney’s office said on Friday.

headline: David Sedaris on a Career-Spanning Collection
abstract: Sedaris talks about “The Best of Me” and his life as an essayist.
lead_paragraph: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen

headline: A ‘Season of Hope,’ Says Pence of Possible Vaccine Approval
abstract: Vice President Mike Pence visited the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Friday, offering an upbeat assessment of the coronavirus pandemic with the likely approval of the first coronavirus vaccine coming as soon as next week.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Mike Pence visited the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Friday, offering an upbeat assessment of the coronavirus pandemic with the likely approval of the first coronavirus vaccine coming as soon as next week.

headline: Read the Complaint
abstract: Two former workers claimed in court documents unsealed on Friday that the tour boat operator and private ferry company pumped unfiltered bathroom waste into the Hudson River.
lead_paragraph: Two former workers claimed in court documents unsealed on Friday that the tour boat operator and private ferry company pumped unfiltered bathroom waste into the Hudson River.

headline: Big Ferry Company Dumped Sewage Into Hudson for Years, Whistle-Blowers Say
abstract: Two former workers claim New York Waterway fouled the river with unfiltered waste from boats’ toilets. The firm denies the allegations.
lead_paragraph: WEEHAWKEN, N.J. — The dirtiest work happened while most of New Jersey slept, on boats docked across from Manhattan’s shimmering, half-lit skyscrapers.

headline: What’s the Deal With Russell Westbrook?
abstract: Despite being a regular All-Star and former M.V.P., Westbrook is headed to his third team in three years. His value appears to be a matter of opinion.
lead_paragraph: Russell Westbrook is a Most Valuable Player Award winner. He is regularly an All-Star (nine times in 12 seasons) and will almost assuredly be a first-ballot Hall of Famer when his career ends. He has led the league in scoring twice and once scored 43 points in an N.B.A. finals game. He just turned 32 last month and if all goes well, he should have several All-Star seasons left in him.

headline: Black Man Is Beaten on Camera, Thrusting French Police Into Spotlight
abstract: A music producer believes he’d be in jail unjustly if not for a video showing how officers assaulted him. Instead, the police are now in the eye of a political storm. And so is he.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Without the video, Michel Zecler believes his case would have been reduced, at most, to a brief news item.

headline: 4 Festive Dishes to Make You Happy to Be Home
abstract: This is the holiday season for staying in with lazy-day recipes that feel like cooking self-care and taste like celebration.
lead_paragraph: Some of the very best dishes are those that take a long time — time you never used to have. These comforting but festive holiday recipes don’t require much prep time or hands-on attention, but they do need you to be around the house. You just have to wait while the dishes fill your home with the aromas you want this time of year.

headline: For Boris Johnson, a Week to Exorcise the Demons of 2020
abstract: With the vaccine rollout and a potential Brexit deal looming, his government has a chance to wash away its reputation for chaos and mismanagement.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain’s approval of a coronavirus vaccine this week, beating every other Western country, would be a political gift for any leader. But perhaps none needs it as much as Prime Minister Boris Johnson.

headline: A New Way to Invest for the Vengeful and the High-Minded
abstract: Big investment managers are buying up companies that help with so-called direct indexing, which offers clients a way to boot individual companies from their portfolios. It has tax benefits, too.
lead_paragraph: Imagine a 401(k) where there’s no investment menu of stock funds. Instead, you get to make one that aligns with your values.

headline: California Monolith Is Removed and Replaced With a Cross
abstract: A group of young men chanting “Christ is king!” drove five hours to dismantle the third shiny metal structure to mysteriously appear in the last few weeks, leaving a wooden cross in its place.
lead_paragraph: How the third monolith to crop up in the past month arrived atop Pine Mountain in Atascadero, Calif., where it was discovered by a hiker on Wednesday, remains a mystery.

headline: 50 Years On, the Feminist Press Is Radical and Relevant
abstract: A mission to unearth forgotten female writers became a full-fledged publishing house. It has risen and fallen with the tides of feminism. And it’s not going away.
lead_paragraph: — Gloria Steinem

headline: Manitoba Premier Slams Virus Skeptics, Urges Safety for Holidays
abstract: Brian Pallister, the premier of the Canadian province of Manitoba, pleaded with residents not to ignore science and avoid gathering over the holidays as coronavirus cases rise.
lead_paragraph: Brian Pallister, the premier of the Canadian province of Manitoba, pleaded with residents not to ignore science and avoid gathering over the holidays as coronavirus cases rise.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week
abstract: Late-night hosts enjoyed this bit of comparatively lighter fare this week before returning to Trump. Here are some highlights.
lead_paragraph: Late-night hosts enjoyed this bit of comparatively lighter fare this week before returning to Trump. Here are some highlights.

headline: Irina Antonova, Grande Dame of Russian Museum World, Dies at 98
abstract: During her decades-long reign at Moscow’s main fine arts museum, she provided a window on the outside world for the Soviet people. She died of complications of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Irina A. Antonova, a commanding art historian who led the Pushkin State Museum of Fine Arts in Moscow for more than a half-century, used it to bring outside culture to isolated Soviet citizens and turned it into a major cultural institution, died on Nov. 30 in that city. She was 98.

headline: Radio Disney, Launching Pad for Young Stars, Will Shut Down Next Year
abstract: Since 1996, the network has been a go-to music destination for preteens and helped jump-start the careers of future superstars. Disney said it was ending it to focus on streaming and TV.
lead_paragraph: Radio Disney, the nationwide radio network that entertained young listeners for more than two decades and helped jump-start the music careers of Disney Channel stars like Miley Cyrus, the Jonas Brothers and Selena Gomez, is set to end operations early next year, Disney’s television division announced on Thursday.

headline: Behind the Cover: Tree Communication
abstract: A look at how trees appear to be communicating through intricate underground networks.

headline: Considering a Post-Pandemic Future
abstract: What are you looking forward to?
lead_paragraph: Welcome. Yesterday I noticed a colleague tweeting about the things he’s been missing during the pandemic that surprise him: his daily commute on the subway, making small talk with strangers. Of course we’re all missing things these days: people, traditions, normalcy. Of course we miss hugs, live theater, sporting events, dinner parties, going to the movies. It’s not surprising that filmmakers miss Cannes — many of us longed to attend a glittering film festival on the Riviera long before the pandemic, and we’re not even in the movie business.

headline: Flea Theater to Shut Down Programs for Emerging Artists
abstract: Actors, directors and playwrights who fought for changes at the Flea say they feel betrayed. The theater said it is eliminating their roles, but is promising future residencies that pay.
lead_paragraph: Months after promising radical changes in how it treats actors and other affiliated artists, the Flea Theater has announced that it would do just that, but not in the way those artists expected. As part of plans to “embark on a new mission,” the theater, a notable Off Off Broadway company, said Thursday it would close its most prominent programs for emerging actors, directors and writers, in effect eliminating dozens of positions.

headline: House Votes to Decriminalize Marijuana
abstract: The U.S. House of Representatives on Friday passed legislation that would decriminalize marijuana and expunge nonviolent marijuana-related convictions. The measure is aimed at rolling back drug policies that have disproportionately affected low-income communities of color.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. House of Representatives on Friday passed legislation that would decriminalize marijuana and expunge nonviolent marijuana-related convictions. The measure is aimed at rolling back drug policies that have disproportionately affected low-income communities of color.

headline: What the Church Meant for James Baldwin
abstract: Although he ultimately rejected Pentecostalism, the writer captured its pathos and ability to bear witness to Blackness in America in his first novel.
lead_paragraph: This essay is part of T’s Book Club, a series of articles and events dedicated to classic works of American literature. Click here to R.S.V.P. to a virtual conversation, led by Ayana Mathis, about “Go Tell It on the Mountain” on Dec. 17.

headline: 20 Top Food & Drink Gift Ideas for 2020
abstract: Trying to find a good present? We’ve curated the best food and drink gifts to help you check everyone off your list.
lead_paragraph: Trying to find a good present? We’ve curated the best food and drink gifts to help you check everyone off your list.

abstract: Trying to find a good present? We’ve curated the best home and design gifts to help you check everyone off your list.

abstract: Trying to find a good present? We’ve curated the best cooking gifts to help you check everyone off your list.

lead_paragraph: Trying to find a good present? We’ve curated the best entertainment gifts to help you check everyone off your list.

headline: 20 Top Hard to Please Gift Ideas for 2020
abstract: Trying to find a good present? We’ve curated the best gifts for all the hard-to-please people in your life.
lead_paragraph: Trying to find a good present? We’ve curated the best gifts for all the hard-to-please people in your life.

lead_paragraph: Trying to find a good present? We’ve curated the best tech gifts to help you check everyone off your list.

headline: Trump Orders All American Troops Out of Somalia
abstract: While the number of forces — about 700 — is small, it is a continuation of President Trump’s efforts to withdraw the United States from what he has described as endless wars.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump, pressing his end-of-term troop withdrawals from conflicts around the world, will pull American forces out of Somalia, where they have been trying to push back advances by Islamist insurgents in the Horn of Africa.

headline: The 10 Best Crime Novels of 2020
abstract: Lars Kepler’s “The Rabbit Hunter,” Susan Furlong’s “Shattered Justice” and more.
lead_paragraph: No fluffy bunny scenes in THE RABBIT HUNTER (Knopf, 512 pp., $27.95), just a sanguinary psycho-killer suspense story by Lars Kepler, a popular Swedish husband-and-wife writing team. There is, indeed, the sweet voice of a child chanting a nursery rhyme before each death. (“Ten little rabbits, all dressed in white / Tried to get to heaven on the end of a kite.”) But that’s more a grace note than a plot point in a story that hops from sophisticated political terrorism to graphic gore.

headline: Fernando Solanas, Argentine Filmmaker and Politician, Dies at 84
abstract: He helped propel a new wave of politically charged moviemaking and served as a lawmaker. He died of complications of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Outdoor Yoga and Fighting Poverty
abstract: How Michael Kors, Wes Moore and Anne Pasternak are giving back during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: With the New York charity circuit on hiatus, here is how some philanthropists and society figures are spending their time and resources during the coronavirus crisis.

headline: The Hartford Courant’s newsroom is closing down.
abstract: Citing the coronavirus pandemic’s economic fallout, the Connecticut daily’s parent company tells staff members they will work remotely into 2021.
lead_paragraph: The Hartford Courant, the Connecticut newspaper that has been in print since 1764, when it chronicled the locals’ dissatisfaction with British rule, is the latest daily that will try to cover the news without a newsroom.

headline: Naomi Long Madgett, Champion of Black Poets, Is Dead at 97
abstract: The longtime poet laureate of Detroit, she was as well known for publishing the work of others as she was for her own verse.
lead_paragraph: Naomi Long Madgett was 17 when her first book of poetry was published, and just 26 when her work appeared in an anthology co-edited by Langston Hughes, an early mentor, that covered 200 years of Black poetry — a new name among the greats.

headline: Becoming a Part of the Story
abstract: How our day at the food pantry hit close to home. Plus, your questions about vaccine distribution, answered.
lead_paragraph: Hey, hey everybody — Happy Friday. Our team is on the hunt for new things to watch this weekend, having ripped through “The Queen’s Gambit” and “The Undoing” during our days off for Thanksgiving, so email us any recommendations you’ve got!

headline: Supreme Court to Hear Case on Trump’s Medicaid Work Requirements
abstract: The case, which could become moot if the Biden administration eliminates the requirements, will be scheduled to be heard early next year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday agreed to decide whether the Trump administration may impose work requirements on Medicaid recipients, an issue that could become moot if the Biden administration eliminates the requirements.

headline: What to Watch: Modern Takes on Noir
abstract: A troubled private eye. A dangerous woman. A twisty plot with a conspiracy that goes all the way to the top. Check out five modern takes on film noir.
lead_paragraph: A troubled private eye. A dangerous woman. A twisty plot with a conspiracy that goes all the way to the top. Check out five modern takes on film noir.

headline: Jobs, C.D.C., Hanukkah: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: The Window on New Movie Releases Finally Shatters
abstract: Warner Bros. has embraced a digital future. The rest of the industry would do well to pay mind.
lead_paragraph: The windows are now smashed, and that’s a good thing, broken glass notwithstanding.

headline: A Trump Immigration Policy Is Leaving Families Hungry
abstract: The “public charge” rule was supposed to ensure that green cards go only to self-sufficient immigrants, but in the pandemic, it is driving up hunger and leaving Joe Biden with a quandary.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The cars began filing into the parking lot shortly after 6 a.m., snaking around police officers who directed traffic to masked volunteers standing ready with boxes of frozen pizza, tortillas and brown bags of canned food.

headline: Further Slowdown in Job Creation Sets Off Economic Alarms
abstract: November’s hiring of 245,000, the fifth straight monthly easing in new employment, reinforces calls for action on a fresh relief package.
lead_paragraph: The American job engine has slowed significantly, stranding millions who have yet to find work after being idled by the pandemic, and offering fresh evidence that the recovery is faltering.

headline: Walter E. Williams, 84, Dies; Conservative Economist on Black Issues
abstract: Skeptical of antipoverty programs, he was a scholar who reached a wide public through a newspaper column and books, and as a fill-in for Rush Limbaugh.
lead_paragraph: Walter E. Williams, a prominent conservative economist, author and political commentator who expressed profoundly skeptical views of government efforts to aid his fellow African-Americans and other minority groups, died on Tuesday on the campus of George Mason University in Virginia, where he had taught for 40 years. He was 84.

headline: A $900 Billion Plan Would Help the Economy, but Not Fix It
abstract: While a compromise package gaining steam in Congress would provide urgent help to the economy, some people and businesses would be left out in the cold.
lead_paragraph: The economic recovery, slowing for months, is in danger of going into reverse. That’s why a growing list of economists, business lobbyists and other advocacy groups are urging lawmakers to rally around the $908 billion aid package currently gaining bipartisan support in Congress.

headline: Sculpture Vanishes From German Mountain, Then Is Replaced
abstract: The authorities are stumped by what happened to the wooden phallus, a popular Instagram stop for hikers. Along with all the monoliths, it has been quite a month for mysterious public art.
lead_paragraph: The police are investigating the disappearance of a seven-foot-tall wooden phallus that was removed from its post atop Grünten mountain in southern Bavaria last weekend, then just as mysteriously replaced on Thursday by a replica, evidently a bit larger than its predecessor.

headline: Cliff Joseph, Artist, Activist and Therapist, Dies at 98
abstract: After agitating for the inclusion of Black artists in New York museums, he helped introduce a multicultural perspective to the field of art therapy.
lead_paragraph: Cliff Joseph, an artist raised in Harlem who in the 1960s and ’70s led protests against major New York museums to advocate for the inclusion of Black artists, and who later pioneered the practice of multiculturalism in the field of art therapy, died on Nov. 8 in a hospital in Chicago. He was 98.

headline: As Virus Spreads, C.D.C. Draws Up an Urgent Battle Plan
abstract: The multipronged advice, for individuals and state and local officials, may augur a national strategy in the months to come, experts said.
lead_paragraph: With coronavirus infections soaring across the nation, federal health officials on Friday urged Americans in the most forceful language yet to take steps to protect themselves — starting with consistent, proper use of masks — and pressed local governments to adopt 10 public health measures deemed necessary to contain the pandemic.

headline: Stimulus Prospects Grow as Leaders Agree to Try for Year-End Deal
abstract: Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, have agreed to try to reach a deal that could be included in a must-pass spending measure.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The prospects for an elusive bipartisan stimulus deal appeared to brighten on Friday as Speaker Nancy Pelosi projected fresh optimism that the House and Senate could come to terms and President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. prodded lawmakers to “act and act now” on a measure he insisted was within reach.

headline: Responding to Terrorism in France
abstract: President Emmanuel Macron and others there have been angered by outside criticism.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of two horrific incidents of Islamist terrorism in France, President Emmanuel Macron and many of his countrymen have reacted angrily to criticism from abroad suggesting that French policies, and especially the French version of state-enforced secularism, somehow contributed to the lethal radicalization of a sliver of the country’s large Muslim population.

headline: Judge Orders Government to Fully Reinstate DACA Program
abstract: Up to 300,000 additional undocumented immigrants could be allowed to apply for protection from deportation under a new court ruling. President Trump had sought to cancel the program.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Friday ordered the Trump administration to fully restore an Obama-era program designed to shield young, undocumented immigrants from deportation, dealing what could be a final blow to President Trump’s long-fought effort to end the protections.

headline: A Gathering Political Storm Hits Georgia, With Trump on the Way
abstract: With two crucial Senate seats up for grabs, Mike Pence and Barack Obama joined the fray in support of their party’s candidates, and President Trump is headed there on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Some of the biggest names in national politics jumped into the fiercely contested runoffs for two Georgia Senate seats on Friday, even as a second recount showed that Joseph R. Biden Jr. had maintained his lead in the state and Republicans braced for a visit by President Trump, who has railed against his loss there with baseless claims of fraud.

headline: Flaws in Census Count Imperil Trump Plan to Exclude Undocumented Immigrants
abstract: More problems arise as the Census Bureau rushes to compile information needed for apportionment before President Trump leaves office.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Census Bureau experts have uncovered serious flaws in a section of the 2020 head count that potentially affect the enumeration of millions, according to people familiar with the census operations, delaying still further the completion of state-by-state population totals that the White House has demanded before President Trump leaves office next month.

headline: The Virus Is Devastating the U.S., and Leaving an Uneven Toll
abstract: The United States saw the most new coronavirus cases of the pandemic on Friday, with deaths and hospitalizations also rising. Underlying conditions largely determine who survives.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The United States is winding up a particularly devastating week, one of the very worst since the coronavirus pandemic began nine months ago.

headline: Vaccines End the Pandemic’s Political Harmony
abstract: Erin O’Toole, the Conservative leader, is using the government’s vaccine plans to begin his first big political attack on Prime Minister Justin Trudeau.
lead_paragraph: This week people in Britain learned that a coronavirus vaccine will soon be on its way — at least for the first batch of people. In Canada, however, vaccines were the focus of political squabbling.

headline: As Deadline Lapses, Trump Administration Continues TikTok Talks
abstract: The White House did not extend a Dec. 4 deadline for the Chinese internet company ByteDance to sell TikTok.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration will allow a Friday deadline for TikTok’s Chinese parent company to sell the viral video app to lapse, said a person with knowledge of the decision. But the government will continue to work on a deal that would put a larger slice of TikTok’s ownership in American hands, the person said.

headline: Diabolical
abstract: Get sucked into this Brendan Emmett Quigley construction, if you dare!
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — We are lucky to get a lot of puzzles out of Brendan Emmett Quigley, but he hasn’t had a Saturday grid for The New York Times since 2012 — I imagine that today’s construction was deemed a soupçon too difficult for a Friday. For some reason I picture the entire thing swirling into creation around one particular factoid, but you may have a very different take depending on where your interests lie, which is how a toothsome themeless should be.

headline: Japan’s Journey to an Asteroid Ends With a Hunt in Australia’s Outback
abstract: The Hayabusa2 mission cements Japan’s role in exploring the solar system, but finding its asteroid cargo presented one last challenge.
lead_paragraph: This past weekend, Japan’s space agency concluded a six-year, 3.25 billion-mile journey of discovery that aims to shed light on the earliest eons of the solar system and possibly provide clues about the origins of life on Earth.

headline: Quotation of the Day: The Outcry Over Sex Testing Grows Louder
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, December 5, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “They treat us as if we are cheats. We deserve to be respected as athletes, as champions.”

headline: Corrections: Dec. 5, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Dec. 5, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about contenders for energy and climate positions in the Biden administration misstated the name of the organization that Heather McTeer Toney leads. It is Moms Clean Air Force, not Mom’s Clean Air Task Force.

headline: How to Make a Chess Set
abstract: Inspired by ‘The Queen’s Gambit,’ demand for chess sets is soaring. So why not make your own?
lead_paragraph: Thanks to the success of the Netflix show “The Queen’s Gambit,” chess sets are flying off the shelves. If you can’t find one, or just want another pandemic crafting project, why not make your own at home?

headline: Joe From Scranton Didn’t Win Back the Working Class
abstract: An economic analysis of the counties that Joe Biden won and lost shows how the two parties are continuing to realign.
lead_paragraph: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

headline: If It’s Fiction, Can It Be an Invasion of Privacy?
abstract: Emmanuel Carrère’s latest novel, “Yoga,” has stoked debate in France after the author’s ex-wife, Hélène Devynck, accused him of writing about her without her consent.
lead_paragraph: When nonfiction writers face backlash for their depictions of loved ones, the disputes tend to center on how far their indiscretions have stretched. But what happens when someone no longer wants to appear in an ex-partner’s work, period?

headline: Republicans Pushed to Restrict Voting. Millions of Americans Pushed Back.
abstract: Almost 160 million people voted this year, as new options made necessary by the pandemic removed many of the traditional barriers to casting ballots. Will it change the way America conducts elections?
lead_paragraph: Nearly 160 million Americans voted in the 2020 elections, by far the most in history and a level of turnout not seen in over a century, representing an extraordinary milestone of civic engagement in a year marked by a devastating pandemic, record unemployment and political unrest.

headline: Cynthia Lummis, a Bull-Coaxing Conservative, Heads to the Senate
abstract: A right-wing rancher with a libertarian streak, Ms. Lummis, who served four terms in the House, is the first woman to represent Wyoming in the Senate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The bull Romeo stood in the middle of 2,000-acre pasture near Cheyenne, Wyo., suffering from foot rot. Even though Cynthia Lummis lacked a horse, it was her job, as the ranch owner, to get this moody and aggressive animal into a trailer and to the vet.

headline: One of the First Virus Hot Spots in the U.S. Is Under Siege Again
abstract: New Rochelle, N.Y., was a model for how to contain and control the coronavirus’s spread. But the city’s success may be fleeting.
lead_paragraph: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y. — There are lines again at Glen Island Park, the drive-through coronavirus testing center that state officials set up when the coronavirus was discovered in this city in March.

headline: Two Retiring Senators, Two Divergent Views on How to Save the Senate
abstract: Senators Lamar Alexander, a Republican, and Tom Udall, a Democrat, agree the institution needs fixing but differ on what the solution is.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The two senators are friends from opposite parties, both proven legislators with glittery political pedigrees who are leaving Congress on their own terms at the end of this year.

headline: Candice Bergen, Woman Who’s Had It All
abstract: The wryest of Hollywood royals recalls life with Daddy’s dummy, marriage to Louis Malle and a comedic career for the ages.
lead_paragraph: There may be some things more fun than hanging out with Candice Bergen and talking about Michael Caine, Sean Connery, Steve McQueen, Jack Nicholson, Princess Diana, Princess Grace, John Belushi, Donald Trump, Charles Manson, getting fat, getting old, getting wrinkled and not giving a damn.

headline: The Swiss Cheese Model of Pandemic Defense
abstract: It’s not edible, but it can save lives. The virologist Ian Mackay explains how.
lead_paragraph: Lately, in the ongoing conversation about how to defeat the coronavirus, experts have made reference to the “Swiss cheese model” of pandemic defense.

headline: Police Drones Are Starting to Think for Themselves
abstract: In one Southern California city, flying drones with artificial intelligence are aiding investigations while presenting new civil rights questions.
lead_paragraph: CHULA VISTA, Calif. — When the Chula Vista police receive a 911 call, they can dispatch a flying drone with the press of a button.

headline: Festive Holiday Gifts for Newlyweds
abstract: Event planners and culinary professionals share some suggestions to help couples celebrate the season in style.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic has given new meaning to being home for the holidays this year. Most newlyweds will have to celebrate their first Christmas, Kwanzaa, Hanukkah or New Year’s Eve in more intimate settings because of social-distancing requirements, but they can still do it in style.

headline: The ‘Mexican Beverly Hills’
abstract: How a former white enclave became an aspirational suburb for Latinos in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: I was having dinner at some fancy beach-side eatery in early March when someone said they had just moved to Downey, a Southeast Los Angeles suburb 12 miles south of downtown.

headline: After Perilous Atlantic Journey, Migrants Await Their Fate in Canary Island Hotels
abstract: The Spanish government has put migrants up in hotels as the islands struggle to cope with a rise in arrivals from Africa, but tensions are fraying with locals who fear they’ll scare off tourists.
lead_paragraph: PUERTO RICO, Spain — After braving the Atlantic on a rickety and overcrowded fishing boat for six days, a group of young Senegalese has spent the past three weeks in a three-star hotel in the Canary Islands, overlooking a spectacular beach lapped by pristine waters.

headline: A Race Against Time to Rescue a Reef From Climate Change
abstract: In an unusual experiment, a coral reef in Mexico is now insured against hurricanes. A team of locals known as “the Brigade” rushed to repair the devastated corals, piece by piece.
lead_paragraph: When Hurricane Delta hit Puerto Morelos, Mexico, in October, a team known as the Brigade waited anxiously for the sea to quiet. The group, an assortment of tour guides, diving instructors, park rangers, fishermen and researchers, needed to get in the water as soon as possible. The coral reef that protects their town — an undersea forest of living limestone branches that blunted the storm’s destructive power — had taken a beating.

headline: Greek Orthodox Church Faces Criticism as Virus Hits Its Ranks
abstract: Church leaders have backed government restrictions, but defiance by hard-liners and a commitment to the sacrament of communion, taken with a shared spoon, may undercut good intentions.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — The coronavirus has dealt a double blow to the powerful Greek Orthodox Church, with the disease spreading through its ranks while the clergy fends off criticism that it has been stoking the pandemic.

headline: A Poet’s View of the Year: Longing for Our Own Lives
abstract: For the novelist and poet Linda Bostrom Knausgard, 2020 was a period of reflection, and a constant reminder that time is fleeting.
lead_paragraph: This is an article from Turning Points, a special section that explores what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead.

headline: ‘Natural Immunity’ From Covid Is Not Safer Than a Vaccine
abstract: What if you’ve already had Covid-19 — do you still need a vaccine? Experts tackle questions about vaccine immunity.
lead_paragraph: On the heels of last month’s news of stunning results from Pfizer’s and Moderna’s experimental Covid-19 vaccines, Senator Rand Paul tweeted a provocative comparison.

headline: Mystery Couple Found in a Roll of Film From Nearly 70 Years Ago
abstract: Internet sleuths have been captivated by the photos, which were recently developed and document a couple’s trip to the Swiss-Italian border with a dachshund.
lead_paragraph: For nearly 70 years, a partially finished roll of film that documented a couple’s escapades in Switzerland and Italy was hidden away in a brass container, forgotten as it changed hands.

headline: Can Your Apartment Building Ban Overnight Guests?
abstract: A patchwork of laws governs how buildings can restrict visitors. But one thing is clear: Those laws matter more than a building’s stated rules.
lead_paragraph: Q: During the pandemic, a number of people in my Manhattan co-op have left the city for second homes. Concerned that shareholders were letting visitors stay in the empty apartments, the board enacted a new rule: Shareholders must now request authorization for any overnight guest. I understand the concern, but this rule seems to overstep the board’s authority. Do I need to ask permission if I want an overnight guest to stay with me? As a single woman, I am not comfortable with this invasion of my privacy.

headline: East Village Fire Damages 128-Year-Old Church
abstract: The fire tore through a vacant building early Saturday morning and then spread to Middle Collegiate Church on Second Avenue. Four firefighters had minor injuries.
lead_paragraph: A fire in a vacant building in the East Village early Saturday morning spread to a 128-year-old church that houses the New York Liberty Bell, destroying its Gothic-style sanctuary and blowing out the Tiffany stained-glass windows that adorned the stone facade, fire and church officials said.

headline: The Rise and Fall of Carl Lentz, the Celebrity Pastor of Hillsong Church
abstract: A charismatic pastor helped build a megachurch favored by star athletes and entertainers — until some temptations became too much to resist.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2017, the singer Justin Bieber abruptly canceled the remainder of a concert tour that had taken him across six continents in 16 months. Mr. Bieber cited fatigue; his fans fretted. But on the tabloid website TMZ, a more hopeful narrative quickly emerged. The 23-year-old singer left the tour because he “rededicated his life to Christ” thanks to a pastor named Carl Lentz, leader of the New York City branch of the global megachurch Hillsong. The pastor and the pop star were inseparable, the gossip site reported. Two days later, the site reported that Mr. Bieber saw Mr. Lentz “as a 2nd father.”

headline: As Refugees, Their Options Were Limited. Others Saw a Profit.
abstract: Even after decades in Thailand, Kayan women who fled Myanmar make their living from their traditional neck rings. But that’s changing.
lead_paragraph: HUAY PU KENG, Thailand — In front of nearly every bamboo home in the village of Huay Pu Keng are stalls selling trinkets related to the neck rings that women from the Kayan ethnic group traditionally wear.

headline: Make This French Onion Galette
abstract: Make Sue Li’s recipe, or any of the most popular recipes of the week.
lead_paragraph: This weekend make Sue Li’s caramelized onion galette (above), inspired by the flavors of French onion soup, Dorie Greenspan’s lemon meringue cookies or Ali Slagle’s three-cup vegetables. Find more of NYT Cooking’s most popular recipes of the week in the collection below.

headline: With 3 Billion Packages to Go, Online Shopping Faces Tough Holiday Test
abstract: The season is adding pressure on retailers, strained by a pandemic surge in e-commerce and limited by shippers, to deliver gifts on time.
lead_paragraph: E-commerce became a lifeline for consumers and companies during the pandemic. But this holiday season, online shopping will strain the industry as never before: An estimated three billion packages will course through the nation’s shipping infrastructure — about 800 million more than delivered last year.

headline: Historic Church Damaged in East Village Fire
abstract: The fire started in a vacant building early Saturday and spread to the 128-year-old Middle Collegiate Church next door, causing significant damage.
lead_paragraph: The fire started in a vacant building early Saturday and spread to the 128-year-old Middle Collegiate Church next door, causing significant damage.

headline: The Elderly vs. Essential Workers: Who Should Get the Coronavirus Vaccine First?
abstract: The C.D.C. will soon decide which group to recommend next, and the debate over the trade-offs is growing heated. Ultimately, states will determine whom to include.
lead_paragraph: With the coronavirus pandemic surging and initial vaccine supplies limited, the United States faces a hard choice: Should the country’s immunization program focus in the early months on the elderly and people with serious medical conditions, who are dying of the virus at the highest rates, or on essential workers, an expansive category encompassing Americans who have borne the greatest risk of infection?

headline: A King Above and Beyond Politics
abstract: Why are the people of Thailand rising up against royal power now?
lead_paragraph: Several thousand people dressed in yellow or pink, colors associated with the royal family of Thailand, gathered along the road to the Grand Palace in Bangkok on Saturday to celebrate the birthday of King Bhumibol Adulyadej, who died in 2016.

headline: I’m Autistic. I Didn’t Know Until I Was 27.
abstract: Autism spectrum disorder is inseparable from who I am. I wish only that it hadn’t taken so long to find out.
lead_paragraph: For my entire life, I have found it very difficult just to exist.

headline: J.K. Rowling’s New Non-Potter Children’s Book
abstract: If “The Ickabog” — about a land of plenty that due to a monstrous lie becomes a land of fear — sounds familiar, it’s pure coincidence. Really.
lead_paragraph: THE ICKABOGBy J.K. RowlingWith illustrations by the winners of The Ickabog Illustration Competition

headline: How Did Ancient Cultures Experience Reading?
abstract: The first book in David Bowles’s new graphic novel series, “Rise of the Halfling King,” shows kids how a hieroglyphic script might have captivated the Mayans.
lead_paragraph: RISE OF THE HALFLING KINGTales of the Feathered Serpent, Vol. 1Written by David BowlesIllustrated by Charlene Bowles

headline: Report Points to Microwave ‘Attack’ as Likely Source of Mystery Illnesses That Hit Diplomats and Spies
abstract: A government-commissioned report provides the most definitive explanation yet for “Havana syndrome,” which struck scores of American employees, first in Cuba and then in China, Russia and other countries.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The most probable cause of a series of mysterious afflictions that sickened American spies and diplomats abroad in the past several years was radiofrequency energy, a type of radiation that includes microwaves, the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine has concluded in a report.

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon create some shade with an acerbic acrostic.
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — This excerpt is a bit of a departure, and not just because its clues come with a colorful visual aid (which I hope solvers see online). It’s about a famously brilliant early film actress and inventor, but half of it is a cutting quote of hers that surprised me, in our comfy old acrostic. I know some of the story — leading movie roles in the 1930s to 1950s, as well as knowledge of radio frequencies that led to important military technology (and even modern Wi-Fi). The book this passage is from, “Hedy’s Folly,” by Richard Rhodes, fleshes all of this out.

headline: Reaching Out to Trump’s Base
abstract: Readers react to a writer’s discouragement after trying to reach across the political divide.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Trump’s Final Days of Rage and Denial
abstract: The last act of the Trump presidency has taken on the stormy elements of a drama more common to history or literature than a modern White House.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Over the past week, President Trump posted or reposted about 145 messages on Twitter lashing out at the results of an election he lost. He mentioned the coronavirus pandemic now reaching its darkest hours four times — and even then just to assert that he was right about the outbreak and the experts were wrong.

headline: 2020 Through the Eyes of Dogs
abstract: We asked the photographer William Wegman what he (and his famous canine muses) thought of this year.
lead_paragraph: This is an article from Turning Points, a special section that explores what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead.

headline: The Sacklers’ Last Poison Pill
abstract: A trapdoor in the Justice Department deal with the family’s company might enable them to escape a full accounting of their part in the opioid epidemic.
lead_paragraph: The opioid crisis remains one of America’s deadliest public health disasters. Victims demand answers about how it happened and who was responsible.

headline: How the Pfizer-BioNTech Vaccine Works
abstract: Two shots can prime the immune system to fight the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Two shots can prime the immune system to fight the coronavirus.

headline: How Moderna’s Vaccine Works
abstract: Two shots can prime the immune system to fight the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Two shots can prime the immune system to fight the coronavirus.

headline: They Offered Us Comfort and Normalcy. Now They Need Our Help.
abstract: The city’s mom-and-pop establishments need help now.
lead_paragraph: It’s never been easy to run a small business in New York City. The city’s entrepreneurs have long faced dizzying odds: high rents and high taxes, byzantine restrictions from City Hall and fierce competition from corporate big-box stores as well as the bodega next door.

headline: Venezuela Votes in an Election the Opposition Calls a Charade
abstract: A victory by the party of President Nicolás Maduro is likely to further weaken Juan Guaidó, the opposition leader who launched a bold but ultimately failed bid backed by the U.S. to take power.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — In the years since the Venezuelan crisis began, Yajaira Paz, 35, has lost nearly everything to its fallout: her mother, dead from a heart problem she could not afford to treat; her brothers, to migration; her faith in democracy, to the nation’s crippled institutions.

headline: Death Came for the Dakotas
abstract: In terms of the coronavirus, they’re a theater of American disgrace.
lead_paragraph: Under normal circumstances, I would have flown to one or both of the Dakotas to write this column, but the whole point is that these aren’t normal circumstances. And I don’t have a death wish.

headline: The Decency Agenda
abstract: Joe Biden promised to be a president for all Americans. Here’s a way to start.
lead_paragraph: Joe Biden won the presidency because, at a moment when so many Americans were exhausted by the chaos and nastiness of the Trump era, he promised stability, decency and healing. At the heart of his candidacy was the vow to be “a president for all Americans” as he labored “to restore the soul of the nation.”

headline: Europe’s Deadly Second Wave
abstract: Summer vacations led to fall lockdowns. How did the world’s richest club of nations let it happen again?
lead_paragraph: By early June, Europe was emerging from the depths of its fight against the coronavirus, just as the U.S. and others were fighting record caseloads. Europeans, desperate for a break, headed off for their sacred summer vacations — and paid dearly for it.

headline: And Play Like a Girl She Did
abstract: Vanderbilt’s Sarah Fuller is the first woman to play Power 5 football. She’s been a long time coming.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — When Sarah Fuller stepped onto the field at the University of Missouri on Nov. 28, she wasn’t wearing the jersey she normally wears as a goalkeeper for Vanderbilt University’s women’s soccer team. On that Saturday after Thanksgiving, she was wearing full pads and a Commodores football jersey. Her helmet was emblazoned with the words “Play Like a Girl.”

headline: The World According to Vivienne Westwood
abstract: For the fashion designer and punk icon, 2020 has been a time for reflection on art, politics and new ways to save the planet.
lead_paragraph: This is an article from Turning Points, a special section that explores what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead.

headline: Why Do So Many Americans Think the Election Was Stolen?
abstract: Looking for the reasons behind a seemingly unreasonable belief.
lead_paragraph: There have been few surprises this past month in how Donald Trump has dealt with the reality of his electoral defeat.

headline: William Aronwald, Target of a Botched Mob Hit, Dies at 79
abstract: He was a prominent prosecutor in the 1970s. A blunder by hit men left his father dead.
lead_paragraph: William I. Aronwald died on Oct. 29. If not for the ineptitude of a couple of mob hit men, he might never have made it out of the 1980s.

headline: At Rally for Georgia Senators, Trump Focuses on His Own Grievances
abstract: The president falsely claimed the election was rigged and that he had won. Earlier, he urged Georgia’s governor to call a special legislative session to overturn Joe Biden’s win in the state.
lead_paragraph: VALDOSTA, Ga. — One month before a pair of Georgia runoffs that will determine the Senate majority, President Trump used a rally for the Republican senators on Saturday to complain about his own loss last month, insisting he would still prevail and, with notably less ardor, encouraging voters here to re-elect the two lawmakers.

headline: In Somalia, U.S. Troop Withdrawal Is Seen as Badly Timed
abstract: Somali presidential elections are scheduled in just a few months, war is erupting in neighboring Ethiopia, and Shabab militants are still strong. The timing, Somalis say, could not be worse.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Somalis fear a U.S. decision to withdraw troops from their country will be seen as a victory for the Qaeda-linked militants who have wreaked havoc there for years, and sow the potential for further chaos at an especially delicate moment for Somalia and the region.

headline: As Premier League Gates Reopen, a Soothing Soundtrack Returns
abstract: The return of a few thousand fans to Premier League stadiums was a reminder that it’s not only their roars that we’ve missed.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The stillness spoke volumes. There were 12 minutes left to play, but the game was over. Manchester United’s players were swarming around Marcus Rashford, scorer of his team’s third goal, the one that had settled matters. West Ham’s were staring blankly at the turf, unsure of quite how things had slipped away from them.

headline: Louisiana Runoff Election Results: Fifth Congressional District
abstract: See full results and maps from the Louisiana congressional runoff election.
lead_paragraph: See full results and maps from the Louisiana congressional runoff election.

headline: Suhaila Siddiq, Afghanistan’s First Female General, Is Dead
abstract: Also a renowned surgeon, she rose through the ranks of the Afghan Army and practiced medicine during the Soviet invasion and the Afghan civil war and under the Taliban’s rule.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Suhaila Siddiq, the first woman to hold the rank of lieutenant general in Afghanistan and a renowned surgeon who became a feminist role model in a largely patriarchal society, died here on Dec. 4 at the same hospital where she had treated the wounded through decades of war in her country. She was thought to be 81 or 82.

headline: Get Out of Here!
abstract: Wait, no, not yet — come do this Tony Orbach Sunday special.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — I defy anyone to not try to come up with examples of this theme for the rest of the day, once they’ve gotten to the bottom of this nifty grid by Tony Orbach, who has been a master of Sunday Times crosswords since 2006. It’s as natural as going out to breathe fresh air.

headline: Fred Sasakamoose, One of the First Indigenous N.H.L. Players, Dies at 86
abstract: He played only 11 games in hockey’s top league, but he inspired generations of athletes from Canada’s First Nations. He died after suffering complications of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Fred Sasakamoose began skating on blades his grandfather had tied to his moccasins. His hockey stick was a willow branch. A disk of cow manure served as the puck. The rink was a frozen lake.

headline: Warren Berlinger, Film and Television Character Actor, Dies at 83
abstract: Mr. Berlinger, who had dozens of roles in a career that spanned more than six decades, appeared in “Happy Days” and “The Cannonball Run.”
lead_paragraph: Warren Berlinger, whose career as a character actor spanned more than six decades and featured myriad roles in film and television dramas and comedies, died on Wednesday at the Henry Mayo Newhall Hospital in Santa Clarita, Calif. He was 83.

headline: ‘They’re Playing With Our Lives’: What Happens Next for DACA’s ‘Dreamers’
abstract: A judge ordered the Trump administration to reinstate protections for young immigrants brought to the country as children. But their status remains precarious.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Despite being a college graduate, Maria Fernanda Madrigal Delgado had no choice in 2011 but to clean buildings and flip burgers in fast-food joints for cash because she was not eligible to work in the United States. She had grown up undocumented in Southern California after being brought to the country as a child from Costa Rica.

headline: She Couldn’t Open for Outdoor Dining. The Film Crew Next Door Could.
abstract: Restaurant owners say Los Angeles County is unfairly enforcing its ban on outdoor dining, but health officials say rules for film crews are much more strict.
lead_paragraph: For more than a week, tensions have flared between Los Angeles restaurant owners and politicians over the county’s ban on outdoor dining, which health officials say is necessary to slow the surging pandemic — and restaurateurs say is destroying their livelihoods.

headline: More Than 90,000 Without Power After New England Winter Storm
abstract: Around 85,000 customers in Maine alone still don’t have electricity after a nor’easter brought high winds and heavy snow.
lead_paragraph: A winter storm that battered parts of New England over the weekend brought high winds and heavy snow that left more than 90,000 utility customers still without power as of Sunday evening.

headline: Celebrate the Holidays with Cheese Pancakes and a Performance by Taylor Mac
abstract: This week, learn to fold paper airplanes, watch a new ballet or bake Emily Dickinson a birthday cake.
lead_paragraph: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.

headline: Do It Yourself Home Repairs
abstract: With a few tools and a little know-how, these five home repairs are relatively easy to complete.
lead_paragraph: As the pandemic forces us to spend our days hunkered down, our homes face far more strain than usual. Faucets bear the brunt of increased hand-washing, toilets get flushed with greater regularity and appliances experience more frequent use. If you have children at home, it’s also possible that your living room now suffers as much abuse as a gym.

headline: Traveling? Be Prepared to Quarantine
abstract: If you’re thinking of traveling in the coming weeks, here’s what to think about first.
lead_paragraph: Though the number of air travelers topped one million on the Sunday after Thanksgiving, many Americans opted not to travel for the holiday. (The equivalent number a year ago, 2019’s biggest travel day, was more than 2.8 million). But even as coronavirus cases continue to surge, the winter holidays and breaks from school may have more people contemplating taking some time away from home in the coming weeks.

headline: For Holiday Baking: One Cookie, Three Ways
abstract: Baking experts show how to transform simple sugar cookies into dazzling treats.
lead_paragraph: It’s time to break out the cookie cutters. Despite a forecast of canceled parties and virtual family gatherings, baking traditions go on. In fact, a scaled-down holiday season offers the perfect opportunity to try your hand at new decorating techniques.

headline: Geek Out Over Christmas Films
abstract: Enjoy famous holiday movies communally again at virtual conventions and digital museum exhibits.
lead_paragraph: Theaters would normally be packed this time of year with folks assembled to watch revered holiday films like “It’s a Wonderful Life,” Frank Capra’s 1946 heart-tugger usually returns to big screens over the holidays, including an annual weeks-long run at the IFC Center in New York.

headline: Top a Present With a Newsprint Bow
abstract: With some artful folding and a few snips of the scissors, a newspaper can become fanciful gift-toppers (and they’re recyclable).
lead_paragraph: As much as unwrapping a present is part of the delight of receiving a gift, wrapping one can be an enjoyable part of the gift-giving experience. No matter what holiday you are celebrating, these handmade gift-topper ideas — from a fancy bow to a quick-snipped holly leaf — are relaxing and meditative undertakings.

headline: Quotation of the Day: After Perilous Crossing, Migrants Await Fate in Canary Islands Hotels
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, December 6, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “Winter is our main tourism season, and when you come as a tourist, you don’t want to be next to a building that is filled with migrants.”

headline: Corrections: Dec. 6, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Dec. 6, 2020.
lead_paragraph: Because of a transcription error, an article last Sunday about cannabis farms facing a devastating wildfire season misidentified the location of Sweet Creek Farm. It is in Guerneville, Calif., not Greenville.

headline: ‘S.N.L.’ Parodies Rudy Giuliani and Melissa Carone’s Disastrous Hearing
abstract: Cecily Strong took center stage in a “Saturday Night Live” sketch playing a real-life figure who had already reminded viewers of one of her best-known characters.
lead_paragraph: The emergence of a new public figure in the political sphere is a precious moment for fans of “Saturday Night Live,” one that often sets off a guessing game of which cast member (or, lately, which celebrity guest star) will be playing that person by the weekend. Who would make the best Brett Kavanaugh? The perfect Robert Mueller? The ideal Dr. Anthony Fauci?

headline: Rachel Maddow and Michael Yarvitz Tell the Full Sordid Story of Spiro Agnew
abstract: “Bag Man” reports on who knew what and when about Agnew’s years of corruption.
lead_paragraph: BAG MANThe Wild Crimes, Audacious Cover-Up, and Spectacular Downfall of a Brazen Crook in the White HouseBy Rachel Maddow and Michael Yarvitz

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $1 Million
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: How Joe Biden’s Digital Team Tamed the MAGA Internet
abstract: The campaign’s empathetic digital strategy held up surprisingly well against President Trump’s passionate digital following.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: China Peddles Falsehoods to Obscure Origin of Covid Pandemic
abstract: To push the idea that the virus didn’t come from China, the government has misrepresented experts’ remarks and given dubious theories the veneer of science.
lead_paragraph: The mild-mannered German scientist never anticipated becoming a Chinese propaganda star.

headline: Some Colleges Plan to Bring Back More Students in the Spring
abstract: College officials say they have learned important lessons about managing the pandemic on their campuses. Not everyone is so confident.
lead_paragraph: It was a tough fall semester for many American colleges and universities, with declining enrollment, canceled classes and sporting events, widespread Zoom fatigue and enough coronavirus-infected students nationwide to fill three and a half Rose Bowls.

headline: ‘Existential Peril’: Mass Transit Faces Huge Service Cuts Across U.S.
abstract: Reeling from the pandemic, transit agencies are grappling with drastic reductions in ridership and pleading for help from Washington.
lead_paragraph: In Boston, transit officials warned of ending weekend service on the commuter rail and shutting down the city’s ferries. In Washington, weekend and late-night metro service would be eliminated and 19 of the system’s 91 stations would close. In Atlanta, 70 of the city’s 110 bus routes have already been suspended, a move that could become permanent.

headline: Bergamo’s Pandemic Survivors Carry Scars Unseen and Incalculable
abstract: Plagued by guilt, anger and regrets, those still alive in the hardest hit place in Italy, and perhaps the world, grapple to understand how the virus has changed them.
lead_paragraph: NEMBRO, Italy — Every Monday night in the northern Italian town that had perhaps the highest coronavirus death rate in all of Europe, a psychologist specializing in post-traumatic stress leads group therapy sessions in the local church.

headline: Jupiter and Saturn Head for Closest Visible Alignment in 800 Years
abstract: On Dec. 21, Jupiter and Saturn will appear to be no more than a dime’s width apart in the night sky. The last time that could be seen was in 1226.
lead_paragraph: For months, Saturn and Jupiter have appeared to be courting, as the giant celestial bodies have gradually drawn nearer in the night sky.

headline: Coronavirus Surge, Georgia, Candice Bergen: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: The Week in Business: The Future of Chicken, and More Stimulus Chatter
abstract: A big step for lab-grown meat. A smaller step toward stimulus talks. And a sprint to stop vaccine misinformation.
lead_paragraph: It’s officially the holiday season, and you’d better get your online shopping done early — the overworked United States Postal Service slapped temporary shipping limits on retailers like Gap and Nike, a sign that delivery systems are bursting at their seams. Here’s what else you need to know about business and tech for the week ahead.

headline: ‘I Asked the Driver to Take Me to a Place That Was Seven Blocks Away’
abstract: A short cab ride, a new place in the West Village and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Events to Shake, or Gently Rattle, the World in 2021
abstract: Planning your calendar for next year? Here are a few events to look out for.
lead_paragraph: This is an article from Turning Points, a special section that explores what critical moments from this year may mean for the year ahead.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘The Social Life of Forests’
abstract: Trees appear to communicate and cooperate through subterranean networks of fungi. What are they sharing with one another?
lead_paragraph: Foresters once regarded trees as solitary individuals: They competed for space and resources, but were otherwise indifferent to one another.

headline: Studying ‘The Nutcracker,’ Students Listen, Touch, Move Like Snow
abstract: Music students who are blind and visually impaired are offered a five-week course. “For me this class is about being dance,” its teacher says.
lead_paragraph: On a November afternoon, seven young students twirled, hopped and lifted their chests to the sky, as Waltz of the Snowflakes from “The Nutcracker” played through their computer speakers. Gathered for a weekly Zoom class, they had arrived at a part of the lesson that one of their teachers, Jenny Seham, called “freestyle snow dancing”: a moment to channel, through improvised movement, the wonder of Tchaikovsky’s music and the freedom of swirling snow.

headline: Christmas tree sales are booming as pandemic-weary Americans seek solace.
abstract: Before this year, Wesley Yang had never celebrated with a real Christmas tree. Growing up, his family deemed it an inconvenience. But stuck at home this season, Mr. Yang and his roommate decided to do something different to mark the end of a tragic year, spending $90 on a tree and lugging it up three floors to their Los Angeles apartment.
lead_paragraph: Before this year, Wesley Yang had never celebrated with a real Christmas tree. Growing up, his family deemed it an inconvenience. But stuck at home this season, Mr. Yang and his roommate decided to do something different to mark the end of a tragic year, spending $90 on a tree and lugging it up three floors to their Los Angeles apartment.

headline: A Covid memorial will rise from a former toxic waste site in New Jersey.
abstract: Of all the toxic dumps in New Jersey, perhaps none was more infamous than PJP Landfill, which sat at the edge of the Hackensack River in Jersey City and was polluted by hazardous chemicals. For more than a decade there, underground fires erupted spontaneously, belching acrid smoke so thick it could snarl traffic on an adjacent bridge, the Pulaski Skyway, a key link for commuters heading to and from New York City.
lead_paragraph: Of all the toxic dumps in New Jersey, perhaps none was more infamous than PJP Landfill, which sat at the edge of the Hackensack River in Jersey City and was polluted by hazardous chemicals. For more than a decade there, underground fires erupted spontaneously, belching acrid smoke so thick it could snarl traffic on an adjacent bridge, the Pulaski Skyway, a key link for commuters heading to and from New York City.

headline: Trump called Georgia’s governor to urge him to help overturn Biden’s win in the state.
abstract: VALDOSTA, Ga. — Before President Trump arrived on Saturday to rally for two Republican Senate candidates, the president made no attempt to disguise his central priority as it relates to Georgia: overturning his loss in the state. He began the day with a telephone call with Gov. Brian Kemp, ostensibly to offer his condolences about the death in a car accident of a young man who was close to Mr. Kemp’s family.
lead_paragraph: VALDOSTA, Ga. — Before President Trump arrived on Saturday to rally for two Republican Senate candidates, the president made no attempt to disguise his central priority as it relates to Georgia: overturning his loss in the state. He began the day with a telephone call with Gov. Brian Kemp, ostensibly to offer his condolences about the death in a car accident of a young man who was close to Mr. Kemp’s family.

headline: China peddles falsehoods to push the idea that the virus came from somewhere else.
abstract: Facing global anger over their initial mishandling of the outbreak, the Chinese authorities are now trying to rewrite the narrative of the pandemic by pushing theories that the virus originated outside China.
lead_paragraph: Facing global anger over their initial mishandling of the outbreak, the Chinese authorities are now trying to rewrite the narrative of the pandemic by pushing theories that the virus originated outside China.

headline: A Polarizing Documentary Spurs Debate Over a Violent Time in Quebec
abstract: Fifty years after separatist violence prompted the government to send soldiers to Montreal, Quebec is grappling with how to remember the 1970 “October crisis.”
lead_paragraph: MONTREAL— Félix Rose was 7 years old when he realized that the gentle father he idolized had a secret past. “Your daddy killed someone,” his cousin told him during a family celebration, he recalled recently.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Spend today making Melissa Clark’s desserts and teatime delights for a holiday cookie box.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. We’ll get to dinner soon enough, but I think today might be largely spent making desserts and teatime delights for a holiday cookie box, in keeping with the teachings of Melissa Clark. Make some combination of vanilla bean spritz cookies, cornmeal lime shortbread fans, toasted almond snowballs, black and white brownies and fudgy bourbon balls. You don’t have to eat them all. As Melissa will show you, here’s how to pack them for the mail.

headline: ‘Like a Cattle Yard’: How Justice Is Delivered in Australia’s Bush Courts
abstract: In some remote Aboriginal communities, judges and lawyers arrive by plane and handle dozens of cases in a single day. Critics say language barriers and the rapid pace infringe on human rights.
lead_paragraph: WADEYE, Australia — After an hourlong flight over the ocher sands of northern Australia, the judge stepped off the plane and made her way to the makeshift courthouse, a single white-walled room next to a new $20 million police station ensconced in barbed wire.

headline: Residents of nursing homes could receive vaccine by the end of December, official says.
abstract: Trump administration officials on Sunday laid out an ambitious timetable for the rollout of the first coronavirus vaccine in the United States, rebuking President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s criticism that there was “no detailed plan that we’ve seen” for getting people immunized.
lead_paragraph: Trump administration officials on Sunday laid out an ambitious timetable for the rollout of the first coronavirus vaccine in the United States, rebuking President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s criticism that there was “no detailed plan that we’ve seen” for getting people immunized.

headline: Winter Storm Blankets New England
abstract: Heavy snow and high winds created dangerous road conditions and left more than 250,000 customers without power in New England. The storm is expected to wind down in the region by Sunday evening.
lead_paragraph: Heavy snow and high winds created dangerous road conditions and left more than 250,000 customers without power in New England. The storm is expected to wind down in the region by Sunday evening.

headline: The Moment to Rethink U.S.-Saudi Ties
abstract: A reader suggests that President-elect Joe Biden should take a cleareyed look at what the kingdom is, and is not. Also: A pandemic haircut.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Should Congress Bring Back Earmarks?
abstract: Readers discuss an editorial that argued that a revival of pork could help polarized lawmakers embrace negotiation and compromise.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Roald Dahl’s Family Apologizes for His Anti-Semitism
abstract: The author, who died in 1990, made several disparaging comments about Jews during his lifetime. “Those prejudiced remarks are incomprehensible to us,” the family said in a statement online.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The family of Roald Dahl has apologized for “the lasting and understanding hurt” caused by anti-Semitic comments the author made during his lifetime.

headline: In Last-Ditch Bid for Brexit Deal, Leaders’ Theatrics Show the Stakes
abstract: Boris Johnson and the European Union’s president are preparing their domestic audiences for either a landmark accord requiring compromise or a breakdown that will disrupt cross-channel trade.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It can be hard, in the climactic days of a high-stakes negotiation, to separate theatrics from substance — and so it was on Saturday evening, when Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain and the president of the European Commission, Ursula von der Leyen, hung up after an hourlong phone call.

headline: New York City prepares to reopen elementary schools amid surge.
abstract: About 190,000 students in New York City are set to return to classrooms this week, starting with elementary school students on Monday, following a monthslong roller coaster of changes to the most closely watched school reopening effort in the country. Students with complex disabilities will be able to return to school buildings on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: About 190,000 students in New York City are set to return to classrooms this week, starting with elementary school students on Monday, following a monthslong roller coaster of changes to the most closely watched school reopening effort in the country. Students with complex disabilities will be able to return to school buildings on Wednesday.

headline: How to Help Kids Create an ‘Our Street Herald’
