abstract: Start the presses: Winter at home is a great time for children to publish their own newspaper from the kitchen table.
lead_paragraph: In this era of working from home and schooling from home and exercising from home and making sourdough from home, the question will soon present itself: What else is there to do from home?

headline: How to Find — and Spread — Joy
abstract: Even during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: “I made a big batch of chocolate chip cookies for Election Day and delivered them to friends. I so enjoyed seeing my friends and hearing their voices ‘in person’ (socially distanced and masked, of course). Happiness for my friends and also for me.”

headline: Pamela Tiffin, Movie Star Who Shone Brightly but Briefly, Dies at 78
abstract: Billy Wilder called her “the greatest film discovery since Audrey Hepburn,” and she made an immediate splash in two 1961 movies, when she was only 19.
lead_paragraph: Pamela Tiffin, the bouffant-haired brunette model turned actress who leapt to movie stardom at 19 in a Tennessee Williams drama and a Billy Wilder comedy, then ran away to make Italian movies and retired from acting before her 32nd birthday, died on Wednesday at a hospital in Manhattan. She was 78.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: China tries to rewrite the narrative of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Facing global anger over their initial mishandling of the coronavirus outbreak, the Chinese authorities are trying to rewrite the narrative of the pandemic by pushing false theories that the virus originated outside China.

headline: In Georgia Debate, Kelly Loeffler Won’t Say Trump Lost
abstract: Republicans fear that President Trump’s grievances about the results might persuade his supporters to sit out Georgia’s two runoff elections, including Ms. Loeffler’s race, that will determine control of the Senate.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — In a televised debate on Sunday night, Senator Kelly Loeffler, a Georgia Republican, declined to say that President Trump had lost the election, arguing instead that the president had “every legal recourse available” to pursue his baseless assertion that the vote in Georgia was rigged against him.

headline: Who Wrote ‘Citizen Kane’? It’s No Mystery
abstract: The Netflix drama “Mank” suggests that Herman J. Mankiewicz, credited along with Orson Welles, primarily wrote the script. But that has long been debunked by scholars.
lead_paragraph: “Mank,” the new drama from David Fincher, revives an old charge against Orson Welles. Was Welles, who with “Citizen Kane” (1941) created what is often cited as the greatest movie ever made on his first try, actually standing on the shoulders of another genius?

headline: How ‘Wolves’ and ‘Heroes’ Are Saving Pandemic Theater
abstract: Serious new plays are always in danger of disappearing — never more so than now. But inventive virtual productions, such as “The Wolves” and “Heroes of the Fourth Turning,” offer hope.
lead_paragraph: It’s all well and good that some theaters are making money during the pandemic by producing what can only be called quasi-theater: magic shows, murder mysteries, a hundred variations on “A Christmas Carol.” I won’t congratulate them here; let their income be its own reward. With luck, they may keep the spark of performance alive to light another night.

headline: Greek Orthodox Church faces criticism, and other news around the world.
abstract: The coronavirus has dealt a double blow to the powerful Greek Orthodox Church, with the disease spreading through its ranks even as the clergy fends off criticism that it has been stoking the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus has dealt a double blow to the powerful Greek Orthodox Church, with the disease spreading through its ranks even as the clergy fends off criticism that it has been stoking the pandemic.

headline: Giuliani has tested positive for the coronavirus, Trump says.
abstract: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former New York City mayor and President Trump’s personal and campaign lawyer, has tested positive for the coronavirus, Mr. Trump announced on Twitter on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former New York City mayor and President Trump’s personal and campaign lawyer, has tested positive for the coronavirus, Mr. Trump announced on Twitter on Sunday.

headline: As Pandemic Threatens Britain’s Mental Health, These ‘Fishermen’ Fight Back
abstract: A charity called the Bearded Fishermen has begun a nightly suicide-prevention patrol around a town in England, looking for people in crisis.
lead_paragraph: GAINSBOROUGH, England — The group of seven volunteers in high-visibility vests, equipped with GPS trackers and radios, gathered in the parking lot of a nature preserve on the outskirts of town.

headline: After Centuries of Obscurity, Wilmington Is Having a Moment
abstract: Joe Biden’s hometown, known chiefly for its dull, corporate vibe, has become the center of the political universe. Residents are thrilled.
lead_paragraph: WILMINGTON, Del. — The hometown of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. has long wrestled with its image problem. Namely, it does not have one.

headline: In Brooklyn Bridge Park, Artwork Confronts Climate Change
abstract: “Waters of a Lower Register,” by the artist Allison Janae Hamilton, came about when Creative Time had to rethink a year marked by a pandemic, frequent hurricanes and racial injustice.
lead_paragraph: Those who wander the circuitous paths of Pier 3 in Brooklyn Bridge Park may be drawn to the western edge of the pier by the lapping of water. But the sounds may not be coming from the East River, which borders the site.

headline: After Defying Virus Rules, Bar Manager Drives Car Into Sheriff’s Deputy
abstract: The manager of Mac’s Public House on Staten Island hit the deputy while fleeing from arrest after authorities confronted him, the sheriff said.
lead_paragraph: The manager of a Staten Island bar who has repeatedly and flamboyantly defied New York’s coronavirus restrictions hit a sheriff’s deputy with his Jeep early Sunday as he unsuccessfully tried to escape arrest, the sheriff’s office said.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Dec. 7, 2020
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.

headline: Errol Spence Jr.’s Win Sets Up a Dream Pairing. That’s All It May Be.
abstract: Spence retained his two world welterweight titles by beating Danny Garcia on Saturday. Does that mean he’ll face Terence Crawford, the W.B.O. champion, next? No, this is boxing.
lead_paragraph: After turning his high-stakes bout with Danny Garcia into a 12-round boxing clinic, Errol Spence Jr., the undefeated welterweight, held a news conference that included reporters gathered at AT&T Stadium in Arlington, Texas, and others tuning in via Zoom.

headline: Biden Picks Xavier Becerra to Lead Health and Human Services
abstract: The selection of Mr. Becerra, the California attorney general, is a surprise. If confirmed, he will face a daunting challenge in leading the department at a critical moment in the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. has selected Xavier Becerra, the Democratic attorney general of California, as his nominee for secretary of health and human services, tapping a former congressman who would be the first Latino to run the department as it battles the surging coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Beeps and Boops
abstract: Barb Lin opens our solving week.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Barb Lin starts off our solving week, and her puzzle left me feeling a bit sentimental for trips past. As she mentions in her notes below, I look forward to the day when we can travel safely.

headline: Barr Is Said to Be Weighing Whether to Leave Before Trump’s Term Ends
abstract: The attorney general’s future came into doubt after he acknowledged that the Justice Department had not found evidence of widespread voter fraud in the president’s election loss.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General William P. Barr is considering stepping down before President Trump’s term ends next month, according to three people familiar with his thinking. One said Mr. Barr could announce his departure before the end of the year.

headline: Biden has selected Xavier Becerra as his nominee for secretary of health and human services.
abstract: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. has selected Xavier Becerra, a former congressman who is now the Democratic attorney general of California, as his nominee for secretary of health and human services, ending a politically delicate search that brought complaints from the Congressional Hispanic Caucus about a lack of Latinos in the incoming cabinet.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. has selected Xavier Becerra, a former congressman who is now the Democratic attorney general of California, as his nominee for secretary of health and human services, ending a politically delicate search that brought complaints from the Congressional Hispanic Caucus about a lack of Latinos in the incoming cabinet.

headline: What We Learned From Week 13 of the N.F.L. Season
abstract: The Jets had an epic collapse, the Giants shocked the Seahawks and the Browns clinched their first winning season since 2007.
lead_paragraph: Despite starting a backup quarterback, the Giants stunned the Seahawks in Seattle. The Indianapolis Colts survived a close game against the Houston Texans, the Cleveland Browns hung on for a win over the Tennessee Titans and the New Orleans Saints and the Kansas City Chiefs won yet again. But none of Sunday’s games could match the excitement of a wild matchup between the Las Vegas Raiders and the Jets in which Gang Green managed to snatch defeat from the jaws of victory.

headline: Romania’s Leader Is Tested by a Close Election
abstract: Prime Minister Ludovic Orban will need to maintain his alliance with a smaller party to stay in power after a surprisingly tight race.
lead_paragraph: BUCHAREST, Romania — Amid record low turnout, voters in Romania on Sunday dealt a setback to the country’s prime minister, Ludovic Orban, in a surprisingly tight race that threatened his grip on power.

headline: Behind Baker Mayfield, the Browns and Their Playoff Hopes Mature
abstract: With a five-touchdown outburst against a formidable A.F.C. contender, Cleveland and its stabilizing star showed a trait the franchise had lacked for almost two decades: playoff poise.
lead_paragraph: The Cleveland Browns’ postseason drought grew from a crabby and cranky toddler into an exasperating adolescent. After its tumultuous teens, it seems ready to say goodbye.

headline: David L. Lander, Squiggy on ‘Laverne & Shirley,’ Dies at 73
abstract: He appeared in more than 100 movies and TV projects, but was best known for his seven-year run on the popular 1970s sitcom.
lead_paragraph: David L. Lander, the comic actor who for eight seasons made entrance laughter inevitable as Squiggy on the ABC series “Laverne & Shirley,” died on Friday in Los Angeles. He was 73.

headline: Anti-Vaccine Doctor Has Been Invited to Testify Before Senate Committee
abstract: The selection of Dr. Jane M. Orient as federal health officials are trying to promote a vaccine to end the coronavirus pandemic prompted harsh criticism from Senator Chuck Schumer, Democrat of New York.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A doctor who is skeptical of coronavirus vaccines and promotes the anti-malaria drug hydroxychloroquine as a Covid-19 treatment will be the lead witness at a Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee hearing on Tuesday, prompting criticism from Democrats who say Republicans should not give a platform to someone who spreads conspiracy theories.

headline: How Black People Learned Not to Trust
abstract: Concerns about vaccination are unfortunate, but they have historical roots.
lead_paragraph: It would appear that the people in America hit hardest by Covid-19 — Black people — are also the group most leery about the prospects of a vaccine.

headline: A Powerful Reporter Got Away With Sexual Misconduct for Decades. His Paper, and His Union, Looked the Other Way.
abstract: Michael Fuoco was a bigfoot reporter with a fiery personality and a reputation for harassing young women. No one seemed to want to rein him in.
lead_paragraph: As the American news business shrank and struggled over the past decade, a new wave of labor activism caught fire. A younger generation of labor leaders rose up and offered a powerful and progressive vision: They would be transparent, sensitive to issues of racism and sexism and truly accountable to workers.

headline: Trump Officials Push Ambitious Vaccine Timeline as California Locks Down
abstract: As cases surge and hospital beds fill up, federal officials said a vaccine could be distributed to as many as 24 million people by mid-January.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration’s top health officials outlined an ambitious timetable on Sunday for distributing the first coronavirus vaccinations to as many as 24 million people by mid-January, even as the accelerating toll of the pandemic filled more hospital beds across the United States and prompted new shutdown orders in much of California.

headline: Giants Outmuscle Seahawks in Season’s Biggest Upset
abstract: Facing Seattle on the road without their starting quarterback, the Giants picked up their fourth straight win behind a stout defense, a lot of running and no trickery.
lead_paragraph: At the midpoint of the Giants’ 2020 season, they had lost seven of their eight games, with four of those defeats by four or fewer points.

headline: Australia Gears Up for the Great Koala Count, Using Drones, Droppings and Dogs
abstract: The marsupials are not easy to find, or count accurately, so officials will deploy new methods.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — One would think that koalas are easy to find and count. They’re large. They’re fluffy. They’re mostly immobile since they tend to sleep for about 20 hours a day.

headline: Coronavirus, Brexit, Havana Syndrome: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: The loss, guilt and anger after an outbreak.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: California Men Declare Themselves Makers of Pine Mountain Monolith
abstract: Four artist-fabricators say they made the mysterious manifestation in stainless steel that sprang up in Atascadero. Meanwhile, two others rise.
lead_paragraph: For the first time, someone has taken credit for erecting one of the monoliths that have popped up in the last few weeks, riveting the world.

headline: Chick-fil-A Accuses Poultry Suppliers of Price Fixing
abstract: The fast-food chain has named Tyson Foods, Perdue Farms and other producers in a lawsuit, which carries the latest allegations of price fixing in the industry.
lead_paragraph: Chick-fil-A, the company that says it invented the chicken sandwich, has accused more than a dozen poultry suppliers in a federal lawsuit of inflating prices on billions of dollars of chicken that it bought.

headline: Quotation of the Day: In Debate, Loeffler Won’t Acknowledge Trump Lost Election
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, December 7, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “The president’s statements are false. They are misinformation. They are stoking anger and fear among his supporters — and hell, I voted for him.”

headline: Corrections: Dec. 7, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Monday, Dec. 7, 2020.
lead_paragraph: A refer on Sunday to the Book Review misstated that the 100 Notable Books of 2020 were selected by Times critics. They were selected by Times editors.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: A Bee Gees Documentary and ‘Couples Therapy’
abstract: “The Bee Gees: How Can You Mend A Broken Heart” debuts on HBO. And a pandemic-focused “Couples Therapy” special airs on Showtime.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Dec. 7-12. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Word + Quiz: arrant
abstract: This word has appeared in two articles on NYTimes.com in the past two years.

headline: Another Month on a Warming Planet: Record-Hot November
abstract: European scientists reported that November’s global temperatures were the highest ever, surpassing the previous record, set in 2016 and 2019.
lead_paragraph: Last month was the hottest November on record, European researchers said Monday, as the relentlessly warming climate proved too much even for any possible effects of cooler ocean temperatures in the tropical Pacific Ocean.

headline: Remembering Rafer Johnson in a Long Year of Lost Sports Legends
abstract: The death of the Olympic track star hit our columnist particularly hard because of the connection to him from his early years and the toll of other titans who died this year.
lead_paragraph: Death stalks us always. It is a bitter truth we tend to shove from our thoughts in typical times. But during a pandemic, we cannot. It is before our eyes daily, in the news, in our communities, sometimes in our homes.

headline: 5 Highlights of New York Mayor’s Race, as Spike Lee Weighs In
abstract: Ray McGuire grabbed attention with a campaign launch video, as New Yorkers get to know the candidates who have not run for office before.
lead_paragraph: With more than a dozen candidates running for mayor of New York City, it can be difficult to stand out. A powerful ad can help — especially if it features Spike Lee.

headline: An N.B.A. Veteran Turns Wisdom Into Wins, On and Off the Court
abstract: At 36, Andre Iguodala is on the back end of his N.B.A. career, as an elder statesman with the Miami Heat, but he’s hitting his stride in the tech world.
lead_paragraph: Andre Iguodala’s family members were reluctant card game participants.

headline: The Suburbs Helped Elect Biden. Can They Give Democrats the Senate, Too?
abstract: Some Atlanta suburbs that used to be “blood red” went blue in November. But Democrats need strong turnout in January, not just disaffected Republicans seeking to give Trump one final defeat.
lead_paragraph: DECATUR, Ga. — President Trump bet his re-election on a very specific vision of the American suburb: a 2020 edition of Mayfield from “Leave It to Beaver” in which residents are white, resent minorities, and prioritize their economic well-being over all other concerns.

headline: I Achieved My Wildest Dreams. Then Depression Hit.
abstract: I’d spent my life training for the Olympics, but I wasn’t prepared for what came next.
lead_paragraph: I’d spent my life training for the Olympics, but I wasn’t prepared for what came next.

headline: In His Autobiography, the College Basketball Giant John Thompson Is Plainspoken and Profound
abstract: The longtime Georgetown coach, who died in August at 78, writes about his upbringing and his remarkable career in “I Came as a Shadow.”
lead_paragraph: “I’m six feet 10 inches tall,” the longtime Georgetown basketball coach John Thompson writes in his posthumously published autobiography. “I have a large mouth, a big head and a deep voice. I naturally make a big noise. Not only am I Black, but I have dark skin. My feet are big, my body is big. Sometimes I’m loud, but I’m loud because I’m composed of big things.”

headline: What Habits Have You Started or Left Behind in 2020?
abstract: What new routines have you established during the pandemic? What habits and pastimes have you given up or modified?
lead_paragraph: What are your daily and weekly routines — activities that you repeat without even thinking? Consider what you typically do from the moment you wake up in the morning until the time you fall asleep at night. What purpose do these routines serve in your life?

headline: Lifestyles of the ‘More Famous Than Rich’
abstract: This entrepreneur is taking on power and money in Hollywood with a new business model for celebrities — including the ones who’ve been forgotten or canceled.
lead_paragraph: Steven Galanis is helping celebrities get into the gig economy. He launched his company, Cameo, three years ago as a marketplace for the famous (and not-so-famous) to sell personalized shout-outs.

headline: It’s Time to Scare People About Covid
abstract: Our public messaging about the virus should explain the real costs — in graphic terms — of catching the virus.
lead_paragraph: I still remember exactly where I was sitting decades ago, during the short film shown in class: For a few painful minutes, we watched a woman talking mechanically, raspily through a hole in her throat, pausing occasionally to gasp for air.

headline: I Achieved My Wildest Dreams. Then Depression Hit.
abstract: I’d spent my life training for the Olympics, but I wasn’t prepared for what came next.
lead_paragraph: What if athletes and coaches were trained to look for depression just as vigilantly as they’d be watching for a hamstring pull? In the Op-Ed video above, Alexi Pappas, who lives in Los Angeles, argues that we should view mental health and physical health as equally important and as treatable as a torn ACL. She would know. She’s a record-setting runner who raced at the 2016 Olympics in Rio but came crashing down after she experienced clinical depression soon after.

headline: Trump Needed the ‘Boneheads’ More Than He Knew
abstract: Populists cast themselves in opposition to technocratic expertise — but they ultimately rely upon it.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s public feuding with his own senior appointees is a signature aspect of his tumultuous presidency. The Fed chairman, Jerome Powell, and his colleagues are “boneheads”; a former national security adviser (John Bolton) is a “wacko”; and his former secretary of state (Rex Tillerson) is “dumb as a rock.”

headline: When a Family Is Fractured
abstract: For most people, estrangements and family rifts are a source of chronic stress that threatens “mental, social and physical well-being.”
lead_paragraph: Show me a family that has not been fractured — temporarily or permanently — by a fury-filled rift between two or more members and I might believe in miracles. Just about everyone I know seems to have experienced such a distressing event, often with painful psychological and sometimes physical effects that carried over to relatives who had nothing to do with the precipitating dispute.

headline: ‘A Suitable Boy’ Finally Finds Its Perfect Match: Mira Nair
abstract: The filmmaker’s acclaimed and controversial adaptation of the landmark novel, the BBC’s first prime-time drama with an almost entirely Indian cast, comes to American TV this week.
lead_paragraph: When “A Suitable Boy” was published in 1993, the 1,349-page tome about post-Independence India, written by Vikram Seth, became one of the longest English-language novels in print. Superlative reviews around the world ensured its place in the door-stopping canon of modern literary classics.

headline: Brexit: What Were We Thinking?!
abstract: Don’t blame working-class people for voting to leave the European Union. Blame the party that betrayed them.
lead_paragraph: This is an article from Turning Points, a special section that explores what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead.

headline: The Places That Had the Biggest Swings Toward and Against Trump
abstract: Education was a key dividing line, but other things mattered, too.
lead_paragraph: With most of the slow-to-report votes tallied, we finally have a clearer picture of last month’s presidential results. Despite the high polarization in the country that carried over to the reaction to the results — with 70 percent to 80 percent of Republicans still saying they disbelieve that Joe Biden won — in some respects the vote itself was less polarized than in 2016.

headline: How New York City Plans to Keep Children Safe as Schools Reopen
abstract: There will likely be more closures of individual school buildings as the amount of testing increases.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, New York City will reopen some of its public schools in the teeth of a worsening coronavirus outbreak.

headline: Scandal Dogs AstraZeneca’s Vaccine Partner in China
abstract: The British-Swedish drugmaker has joined with a huge Asian company to produce a Covid-19 vaccine in China, where shady reputations are common in the pharmaceutical industry.
lead_paragraph: As a government regulator sidled into a car, the Chinese pharmaceutical executive handed over a paper bag stuffed with $44,000 in cash.

headline: Biden Says No More Coddling Dictators. OK, Here’s Where to Start.
abstract: The United States has been far too lenient with Egypt’s brutal dictator.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Joe Biden has pledged to put democracy back on the agenda after four years of President Trump’s unapologetic coddling of dictators. Mr. Biden has promised to host a gathering of the world’s democracies to demonstrate his commitment to democratic values both abroad and at home. But will Mr. Biden go beyond rhetoric and gestures to making concrete policy?

headline: Finding Community Even in a Pandemic
abstract: A former priest settles in nicely at Stonewall House, an L.G.B.T.Q.-friendly senior housing development in Fort Greene.
lead_paragraph: Bill Meehan moved into Stonewall House, an affordable, L.G.B.T.Q.-friendly senior housing development in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, early this year, when it was not exactly an ideal time to get to know one’s neighbors.

headline: A Rare Pandemic Silver Lining: Mental Health Start-Ups
abstract: Using teletherapy, metrics and matching algorithms, entrepreneurs are focusing on addressing aspects of the mental health care system that they view as broken.
lead_paragraph: Ariela Safira was on a mission. Shaken by the attempted suicide of a friend during her freshman year at Stanford University in 2013, Ms. Safira sought to understand the opaque mental health care system. She soon learned of the shortage of qualified therapists and, even where they are more plentiful, of the hurdles to obtaining care. Although a computer science and math major, she eventually enrolled in a clinical psychology graduate program at Columbia University.

headline: ‘This Is Insanity’: Start-Ups End Year in a Deal Frenzy
abstract: Investors are tripping over one another to give hot start-ups money. DoorDash and Airbnb are going public. The good times are baaack.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Hopin, a virtual events start-up in London, had seven employees and was valued at $38 million at the beginning of the year. Johnny Boufarhat, the company’s chief executive, wasn’t planning on raising more money.

headline: Fishing by Lantern on an Island in Kenya
abstract: On Lake Victoria, attracting baitfish with lanterns extends as far back as anyone can remember. But overfishing may jeopardize the tradition.
lead_paragraph: As the sun sets over the waters of Lake Victoria, the soft sound of the lapping waves is drowned out by the hum of motors. Squinting, I can see them on the horizon, the tiny boats splitting the oranges and blues of the twilight sky.

headline: An Autistic Man Is Killed, Exposing Israel’s Festering Police Brutality Problem
abstract: The police killing of a disabled Palestinian fueled nationwide protests. But the authorities have failed to rein in the use of excessive force, which has a long history.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The school for the mentally disabled in Jerusalem’s Old City made a point of preparing its Palestinian students for interactions with the Israeli police.

headline: ‘It Makes Me Angry’: These Are the Jobless in a City Filled With Wealth
abstract: Pandemic job losses have disproportionately hurt low-paid service workers who tend to be poor and people of color. In this New York neighborhood, hope is slipping away.
lead_paragraph: More than one in four workers in the West Farms neighborhood is out of work.

headline: Best Songs of 2020
abstract: Tracks responding to real-time events and a spectrum of moods captured the hodgepodge feelings of life in lockdown.
lead_paragraph: No short list can sum up the plenitude of remarkable songs that appear every year, from commercial bangers to standout album tracks to one-time digital apparitions. So don’t treat this as a ranking. Enjoy it as a playlist.

headline: Three Years After Family Separation, Her Son Is Back. But Her Life Is Not.
abstract: Many of the migrant families separated under the Trump administration’s most controversial immigration policy have been reunited. But some are still struggling.
lead_paragraph: When Leticia Peren bid her 15-year-old son, Yovany, good night in a Texas Border Patrol station three years ago, he was still small enough that she, standing less than five feet tall, reached down a little when she placed her hand on his shoulder and urged him to rest.

headline: Want Vaccines Fast? Suspend Intellectual Property Rights
abstract: Otherwise, there won’t be enough shots to go around, even in rich countries.
lead_paragraph: As some reports would have it, this is the beginning of the end. Three coronavirus vaccines have posted excellent results, with more expected to come.

headline: How the Virus Swept Through a Corner of Queens
abstract: During the spring, as the first wave of the coronavirus caused havoc, five neighborhoods were the hardest-hit place in the country.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Amazon and Stan in Australia in December
abstract: Our streaming picks for December, including ‘The Prom,’ ‘Ma Rainey’s Black Bottom,’ and ‘Your Honor.’
lead_paragraph: Every month, streaming services in Australia add a new batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for December.

headline: A Bronx neighborhood reels with 26 percent unemployment.
abstract: More than one in four workers in the West Farms neighborhood of the Bronx are out of work.
lead_paragraph: More than one in four workers in the West Farms neighborhood of the Bronx are out of work.

headline: How Much Do You Know About Eritrea?
abstract: Can you find Eritrea on a map? What else do you know about this African country with about five million people.
lead_paragraph: Can you find Eritrea on a map? What else do you know about this African country with about five million people.

headline: Dutch Panel for Looted Art Claims Must Change Course, Report Finds
abstract: A review commissioned by the Dutch culture minister found that the country’s art restitution panel showed too little empathy to victims of Nazi aggression and sided too often with museums.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — For years, the Netherlands was heralded as a leader in the effort to remedy the injustice of Nazi looting during World War II. It was praised for taking action to research stolen art and return it to its rightful owners.

headline: Police in Indonesia Kill 6 Followers of Hard-Line Cleric
abstract: The authorities said the men, adherents of the Muslim cleric Rizieq Shihab, were shot and killed after they attacked officers in an unmarked car that had been following them.
lead_paragraph: Six followers of the divisive Indonesian cleric Rizieq Shihab were shot and killed by the police on the outskirts of Jakarta early Monday after what the authorities described as an attack on officers who were tailing the men as part of an investigation.

headline: China’s ‘King of Vaccines,’ a partner to AstraZeneca, is plagued by scandal.
abstract: As a government regulator sidled into a car, the Chinese pharmaceutical executive handed over a paper bag stuffed with cash.
lead_paragraph: As a government regulator sidled into a car, the Chinese pharmaceutical executive handed over a paper bag stuffed with cash.

headline: ‘It Has All Gone Too Far’
abstract: Why one Republican election official in Georgia is speaking out against President Trump’s baseless claims of voting fraud.
lead_paragraph: The state of the 2020 U.S. election is, still, not a settled matter in Georgia. For weeks, conservatives have been filing lawsuits in state and federal courts in an effort to decertify results that gave a victory to Joe Biden. On Twitter, President Trump has been making unsubstantiated claims that the state has been “scammed.”

headline: The Bronx vs. Manhattan
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic Party’s biggest problem today is its struggle to win over working-class voters.

headline: ‘Fishermen’ help fight mental health problems in Britain during the pandemic.
abstract: The past few weeks have been busy for the Bearded Fishermen, a mental health charity in England. With the country just emerging from a second lockdown, the group has seen a measurable uptick in calls for support and an increasing need for its crisis services as the community grapples with the fallout of the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The past few weeks have been busy for the Bearded Fishermen, a mental health charity in England. With the country just emerging from a second lockdown, the group has seen a measurable uptick in calls for support and an increasing need for its crisis services as the community grapples with the fallout of the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Bob Dylan Sells His Songwriting Catalog in Blockbuster Deal
abstract: Universal Music purchased his entire songwriting catalog of more than 600 songs in what may be the biggest acquisition ever of a single act’s publishing rights.
lead_paragraph: Bob Dylan’s memoir “Chronicles: Volume One” opens in 1962 with the signing of his first music publishing deal — a contract for the copyrights of the budding songwriter’s work. The terms of that agreement, brokered by Lou Levy of Leeds Music Publishing, met young Dylan’s approval.

headline: Trump’s Pressure Campaign in Georgia
abstract: Trump turns up the heat on the governor, but the governor isn't playing ball: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: Trump’s Act V continues to play out in Georgia, while Biden names another key member of his health policy team. It’s Monday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

headline: Is Goldman Sachs Going to Florida?
abstract: The Wall Street stalwart may shift some operations to the Sunshine State. It wouldn’t be alone in doing so.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs is one of Wall Street’s best-known firms, its identity indelibly tied to New York. Yet it may move at least some parts of a major division to Florida, with costs and the pandemic in mind.

headline: Visa and Mastercard to Investigate Financial Ties to Pornhub
abstract: The payment companies said they would investigate financial links after The New York Times reported that videos on Pornhub depict child abuse.
lead_paragraph: Visa and Mastercard said they would investigate their financial links to MindGeek, the parent company of the adult website Pornhub, after the New York Times columnist Nicholas Kristof reported that the website included videos of child abuse and nonconsensual sexual violence.

headline: Paul Sarbanes, 87, Dies; Maryland Senator Fought Accounting Fraud
abstract: Early in his career, he introduced the first article of impeachment against Richard Nixon. Decades later, he co-wrote legislation in response to corporate scandals.
lead_paragraph: Former Senator Paul S. Sarbanes of Maryland, a publicity-shy Democratic lawmaker who wrote landmark legislation to curb fraudulent accounting practices that led to huge investor losses and major corporate bankruptcies in 2001 and 2002, died on Sunday in Baltimore. He was 87.

headline: DoorDash and Airbnb plan to go public, and other news in the week ahead.
abstract: DoorDash plans to make its stock market debut on Wednesday, followed by Airbnb on Thursday. Both have raised their valuation targets significantly, part of a frenzy of tech deal making that some say resembles the dot-com mania.
lead_paragraph: DoorDash plans to make its stock market debut on Wednesday, followed by Airbnb on Thursday. Both have raised their valuation targets significantly, part of a frenzy of tech deal making that some say resembles the dot-com mania.

headline: Online sales pile up, but a logjam for shipping all that stuff is looming.
abstract: If there was ever a year to get your holiday shopping done early, this is it. The pandemic surge has experts predicting three billion packages will course through the nation’s shipping infrastructure during the holiday season — about 800 million more than were delivered last year, Michael Corkery and Sapna Maheshwari report in The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: If there was ever a year to get your holiday shopping done early, this is it. The pandemic surge has experts predicting three billion packages will course through the nation’s shipping infrastructure during the holiday season — about 800 million more than were delivered last year, Michael Corkery and Sapna Maheshwari report in The New York Times.

headline: Federal pandemic aid package ‘leaves a ton on the table.’
abstract: The $908 billion bipartisan aid package that is gaining support in Congress will not solve all of the nation’s economic problems, but economists say that the federal government should pass it anyway.
lead_paragraph: The $908 billion bipartisan aid package that is gaining support in Congress will not solve all of the nation’s economic problems, but economists say that the federal government should pass it anyway.

headline: After Grand Theft Auto and Minecraft, Balenciaga: The Video Game?
abstract: The fashion house has created a game to showcase its latest collection, and everyone can play.
lead_paragraph: The year is 2031. Cities are concrete jungles crossed by flying buses that can twist in space and populated by avatars in oversize puffers and shredded jeans that resemble antique draperies over windows to interior worlds. They gesture toward posters promoting a secret rave in a watery wood that leads to a red rock desert where a woman in silver armor pulls a sword from a stone.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘Pantyhose and Trash Bags: How Music Programs Are Surviving in the Pandemic’
abstract: In this lesson, students will learn about innovations embraced by student music groups that address concerns about spreading the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “Pantyhose and Trash Bags: How Music Programs Are Surviving in the Pandemic” by Aishvarya Kavi

headline: Georgia Republicans push back as Trump calls for a special legislative session.
abstract: Officials in Georgia pushed back on Sunday against President Trump as he continued repeating baseless allegations questioning the integrity of the election and called for a special session of the State Legislature with the aim of overturning his loss.
lead_paragraph: Officials in Georgia pushed back on Sunday against President Trump as he continued repeating baseless allegations questioning the integrity of the election and called for a special session of the State Legislature with the aim of overturning his loss.

headline: A Michigan pastor draws fire for telling worshipers to ‘get it, get it over with.’
abstract: A Michigan pastor is under fire for telling his congregation to catch the coronavirus and “get it over with.”
lead_paragraph: A Michigan pastor is under fire for telling his congregation to catch the coronavirus and “get it over with.”

headline: California Lockdowns Go Into Effect
abstract: Monday: Southern California, the San Joaquin Valley and the Bay Area are now under stay-at-home orders. Also: Los Angeles’s outdoor dining ban.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Being Boba Fett: Temuera Morrison Discusses ‘The Mandalorian’
abstract: Morrison, a veteran of the “Star Wars” film franchise, talks about his role as the fearsome bounty hunter on the Disney+ series “The Mandalorian.”
lead_paragraph: It’s been nearly 40 years since moviegoers saw Boba Fett, the fearsome bounty hunter of the original “Star Wars” saga, take an ill-fated tumble into the Great Pit of Carkoon, where he was presumed to have been devoured by the Sarlacc.

headline: What You Get for $1.6 Million in California
abstract: A midcentury-modern house in Lafayette, a remodeled 1967 home in Calabasas and a Victorian landmark in Nevada City.
lead_paragraph: A midcentury-modern house in Lafayette, a remodeled 1967 home in Calabasas and a Victorian landmark in Nevada City.

headline: $1.6 Million Homes in California
abstract: A midcentury-modern house in Lafayette, a remodeled 1967 home in Calabasas and a Victorian landmark in Nevada City.
lead_paragraph: This house was designed by Donald Olsen, an architect whose midcentury residences brought the hilly landscapes of Northern California indoors. The seller has made some updates, but worked to preserve the integrity of Mr. Olsen’s design.

headline: After a Hard Year, Holiday Commercials Get Real
abstract: Tear-jerker scenes and reminders of the coronavirus pandemic are part of a not-so-cheery seasonal ad blitz.
lead_paragraph: For television viewers, the holiday season means commercials filled with rosy-cheeked Santas, computer-generated polar bears and brand-new cars festooned with big red bows.

headline: In Poland, Protests Over Abortion Ban Could Revolutionize Politics
abstract: The government’s conservative social policies, closely tied to the Catholic Church, have met with a backlash from women hoping to change a political culture that developed after Communism fell.
lead_paragraph: Women have been at the heart of a protest movement that has grown and battled on Poland’s streets since October, sparked by a court decision to ban most abortions. But this was never just a one-issue protest. Something deeper is going on, and it has been building for years.

headline: ‘Mank’ and Politics: What Really Happened in 1934 California
abstract: In the Netflix drama, Hollywood gets involved in the race for governor. But while that’s based in fact, history didn’t exactly go down that way.
lead_paragraph: David Fincher’s new Netflix drama “Mank” explores how Herman J. Mankiewicz came to co-write the celebrated screenplay for “Citizen Kane.” Why did he stick with it despite enormous pressure to drop the project? In the film’s telling, one of his primary motivations is the author Upton Sinclair’s race for governor of California in 1934, and how it was sabotaged by the MGM producer Irving Thalberg and the media baron William Randolph Hearst.

headline: New York Philharmonic Musicians Agree to Years of Pandemic Pay Cuts
abstract: Anticipating a long road to financial recovery, the orchestra has decided on cuts that will gradually lessen.
lead_paragraph: The New York Philharmonic, battered by a pandemic that will keep its concert hall dark for at least 15 months, announced on Monday that its musicians had agreed to a four-year contract that includes substantial salary cuts.

headline: In Australia’s Deadly Year for Shark Attacks, a Surfer Lives to Tell the Tale
abstract: After being bitten by a great white in South Australia, the victim managed to paddle ashore and walk nearly 1,000 feet for help. He said the attack “was like being hit by a truck.”
lead_paragraph: A surfer who was mauled by a great white shark in remote waters in Australia managed to swim ashore and walk nearly 1,000 feet to seek help, a “remarkable” feat, according to one of the paramedics who treated him.

headline: Steaks Grown From Human Cells Spark Interest and Outrage
abstract: An artist project offering an absurdist take on the lab-grown meat industry triggers a debate and backlash in London.
lead_paragraph: The installation of steak grown from human cells at the Design Museum in London was intended to criticize the meat industry’s rising use of living cells from animals. It ended up triggering a roiling debate about bioethics and the pitfalls of artistic critique.

headline: Recipes You Won’t Soon Forget
abstract: Buttermilk marble cake, seafood pancakes, lemon-caper pork chops: You may remember what you cook in this time for many years to come.
lead_paragraph: It’s funny, the kitchen rhythms I’ve fallen into during the pandemic, and the dishes I’ll forever associate with this time. So many seafood pancakes. So many ham and Swiss sandwiches. So much hollandaise sauce — with scallops and bo ssam, no less. All those bricks of tofu cubed and fried or planked and baked. A year ago, I barely ever cooked tofu at all.

headline: A Kugel That’s Savory and Sweet (and Crispy, Too)
abstract: Yerushalmi kugel, a specialty of Jerusalem, is bound with caramel, seasoned with black pepper and filled with springy egg noodles.
lead_paragraph: I grew up in a family of savory kugel makers, whether my grandmother and her schmaltzy potatoes, Great-Aunt Martha with her crisp-edged egg noodle iteration or my mother and her elaborate, ever-changing vegetable combinations that veered into casserole territory.

headline: Metropolitan Opera to Lock Out Stagehands as Contract Talks Stall
abstract: After reaching a bargaining impasse, the shuttered opera company said it would lock out the workers needed to build sets for next season’s productions.
lead_paragraph: In one of the most serious labor disputes to erupt in the culture world since the coronavirus pandemic halted performances around the globe, the Metropolitan Opera said on Monday that it planned to lock out its stagehands at midnight after the union representing the workers balked at the company’s demands for pay cuts.

headline: How You Can Help Count and Conserve Native Bees
abstract: Honeybees and their problems get the most attention, but scientists are using tactics learned from bird conservation to protect American bees.
lead_paragraph: In the last 20 years, the rusty patched bumblebee population declined by 87 percent because of habitat loss, use of pesticides and disease. This fuzzy bee, native to the continental United States, gets its name from the rusty patch on its back.

headline: Trump Administration Declines to Tighten Soot Rules, Despite Link to Covid Deaths
abstract: Health experts say the E.P.A. decision defies scientific research showing that particulate pollution contributes to tens of thousands of premature deaths annually.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration on Monday declined to tighten controls on industrial soot emissions, disregarding an emerging scientific link between dirty air and Covid-19 death rates.

headline: Deciding Who Gets the Vaccine First
abstract: Readers discuss how those who have had the virus, the elderly and inmates should be regarded in terms of priority.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Trump supporters protest Michigan’s election results outside its secretary of state’s home.
abstract: Supporters of President Trump on Saturday night took their anger over the results of the election from the steps of the state Capitol to a quiet neighborhood in Detroit, Mich., where Secretary of State Jocelyn Benson lives.
lead_paragraph: Supporters of President Trump on Saturday night took their anger over the results of the election from the steps of the state Capitol to a quiet neighborhood in Detroit, Mich., where Secretary of State Jocelyn Benson lives.

headline: A Costly Quip Angers Chinese Moviegoers, and a Film Is Yanked
abstract: “Monster Hunter” disappeared from theaters in China after online critics labeled a snippet of dialogue — a pun about knees — racist and called for a boycott.
lead_paragraph: In a film scene that has roiled a segment of the Chinese moviegoing public, two American soldiers share a strange bit of banter.

headline: The Most Tender Short Ribs, the Most Satisfying Soup
abstract: Left with some spare short ribs, J. Kenji López-Alt made them sing in a Taiwanese beef noodle soup.
lead_paragraph: Hmm, I thought to myself as I did an emoji-quality chin scratch by the light of the refrigerator door late one night last year. Hmm.

headline: The Scandal in Literary Awards
abstract: Readers discuss the problem of conflicts of interest among panel members and the persistence of a patriarchy that allows for sexual harassment.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Gabriela Hearst Unveiled as Chloé’s New Artistic Director
abstract: The Uruguayan-born, New York-based designer will continue as creative director at her namesake brand alongside her new role.
lead_paragraph: And so a new era begins at Chloé. Less than a week after the departure of Natacha Ramsay-Levi following a four year tenure, the French fashion house announced Gabriela Hearst as its new artistic director, effective immediately.

headline: How to Return to Campus Safely: Test, Then Test Again
abstract: Some colleges are using lessons from the fall to bring back more students in spring
lead_paragraph: The fall semester has been hell for most colleges — canceled classes, dorm closures, outbreaks and deaths. No one wants a repeat.

headline: Xavier Becerra Brings Environmental Justice to Forefront
abstract: Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s choice to run the Department of Health and Human Services is the first state attorney general to create an environmental justice bureau.
lead_paragraph: Martha Romero felt that she had to send her daughters to safety.

headline: As His Term Ends, Trump Faces More Questions on Payments to His Hotel
abstract: A civil case being pursued by the attorney general for the District of Columbia has brought renewed attention to what limits there should be on a president’s ability to profit from the office.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was a month before Donald J. Trump’s inauguration, and one of his aides had a delicate question: Wasn’t there going to be a backlash when it became known that the inauguration had spent donors’ money at Mr. Trump’s hotel in Washington, even though other places would cost much less or even be free?

headline: Bad Bunny’s New Album Is Billboard’s First All-Spanish No. 1
abstract: The Puerto Rican pop star’s latest LP, “El Último Tour del Mundo,” debuted at the top of the Billboard 200 chart. Miley Cyrus is No. 2.
lead_paragraph: Bad Bunny, the Puerto Rican singer, rapper and streaming megastar, has set an industry milestone with his latest album, “El Último Tour del Mundo”: It is the first LP entirely in Spanish to top the Billboard 200 album chart.

headline: Coronavirus Apps Show Promise but Prove a Tough Sell
abstract: Technology to alert people exposed to the virus could slow transmission, pilot studies show, but only if people and states sign up. So far, most haven’t.
lead_paragraph: Last spring, Apple and Google launched an ambitious effort to harness technology in the fight against Covid-19, building a powerful smartphone tool that would alert people of possible exposure to the coronavirus.

headline: Pat Patterson, a Wrestling Star Who Came Out, Dies at 79
abstract: He delighted his fans, especially in villain roles. When he announced in 2014 that he was gay, they remained loyal.
lead_paragraph: Pat Patterson, the first major wrestling star to announce that he was gay, died on Wednesday in Miami Beach. He was 79.

headline: Among Sparkling Wines, the Other Half Lives Pretty Well
abstract: Consumers focus on Champagne, but in the bubbly universe many stars offer distinctive and delicious versions of their own.
lead_paragraph: The Wine School assignment over the last month was simple: Drink sparkling wines in three different styles from three different regions — the Loire Valley of France, Trento in Italy and the Penedès in Spain.

headline: Can Body Cameras Improve Policing?
abstract: Body cameras are brimming with possibility, but they’re not a magic remedy for misconduct.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: Montepulciano d’Abruzzo: Highly Popular but Little Known
abstract: It’s made of Italy’s second-most widely planted red grape, and the wines are priced to go. How come they don’t get more respect?
lead_paragraph: It’s time to dig in. In the Northeast, the cold and dark of winter are arriving, made even chillier by the unrelenting Covid-19 pandemic. The holidays, at least, will be festive in 2020’s own peculiar way.

headline: Covid-19 Dealt a Blow to Working Women. Can We Emerge Stronger?
abstract: As we adapt to a new normal at the office, let’s put some outmoded norms to rest.
lead_paragraph: This is an article from Turning Points, a special section that explores what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead.

headline: The Crossword Stumper
abstract: A look at one of the entries that fooled solvers in last week’s puzzles.
lead_paragraph: L.G.B.T. stands for lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender. The abbreviation appeared in Will Nediger’s puzzle on Wednesday, Nov 2. at 10-Across, and it has so far made 21 appearances in the New York Times Crossword.

headline: What Were the Jets Thinking?
abstract: The Jets looked to have their first win of the season sewn up. But a decision to send an all-out blitz against the Raiders on the final play handed Las Vegas the game-winning touchdown.
lead_paragraph: The dumbest N.F.L. play call ever? Some people think it came on Sunday, and it seems to have cost the Jets’ defensive coordinator, Gregg Williams, his job.

headline: Is American Dietetics a White-Bread World? These Dietitians Think So
abstract: A new generation of practitioners says the profession pays inadequate attention to different kinds of diets, body types and lives.
lead_paragraph: Long before she decided to help others eat better by becoming a dietitian, Jessica Wilson learned that the profession was unlikely to offer much to people like her.

headline: Top Georgia election official debunks ‘ridiculous’ claims about election fraud.
abstract: The office of Georgia’s secretary of state dedicated part of a news conference to what was called “Disinformation Monday.”
lead_paragraph: Late on Nov. 3, election workers in Fulton County, Georgia, heard that they would be allowed to go home for the night. So they packed uncounted ballots into suitcases and prepared to lock up for the evening.

headline: After Botched Covid Response, U.K. Tackles Giant Vaccine Rollout
abstract: Britain left hospitals short of masks and gowns, and stumbled on testing and tracing, so can it vaccinate tens of millions of people in a matter of months? Experts think it can.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In Bristol, a sports stadium is being converted into a temporary clinic to provide inoculations, as is a racecourse outside London. Village halls, libraries and parking lots across the country are also being quickly turned into makeshift vaccination centers, with the government enlisting military planners for advice.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: People across Australia celebrate a return to (almost) normal.
lead_paragraph: People across Australia celebrated “Freedom Day,” when months of tough coronavirus restrictions eased in the lead-up to Christmas and summer in the Southern Hemisphere.

headline: No, Kelly Loeffler didn’t wear a wire during a debate.
abstract: The false claim about the Georgia Republican was shared by some liberals on Twitter.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, Senator Kelly Loeffler, a Republican in one of the runoff elections in Georgia next month, fielded questions and sparred with her Democratic opponent, the Rev. Raphael Warnock, in a televised debate.

headline: ‘Take Five’ Is Impeccable. ‘Time Outtakes’ Shows How Dave Brubeck Made It.
abstract: An album of previously unheard recordings from the “Time Out” sessions in 1959 reveals the making of a masterpiece.
lead_paragraph: Listening to the alternate takes and behind-the-scenes recordings of any classic album will unravel some of its timelessness. But there’s something especially startling about hearing what went into the making of “Time Out,” the Dave Brubeck Quartet’s masterpiece, and maybe the ultimate example of a live art form being carved down and mapped out into an impeccably finished product.

headline: Dolly Parton and the Women Who Love Her
abstract: Sarah Smarsh talks about “She Come by It Natural,” her book about Parton and the lives of her fans.
lead_paragraph: Dolly Parton’s no stranger to attention, and she’s been in the news a lot lately.

headline: The Kremlin Is Offering Russians Free Vaccines, but Will They Take Them?
abstract: Distrust of the government is so widespread that 59 percent of Russians say they have no intention of getting a shot.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Aleksei Zakharov, a Moscow economics professor, got the Russian coronavirus vaccine injected into his upper arm over the weekend.

headline: Are Cities a Safe Place to Live During a Pandemic?
abstract: Dense urban centers were vilified when the pandemic struck, rekindling the age-old town vs. country debate. We asked seven experts if the backlash was warranted.
lead_paragraph: In the spring, as thousands of people were sickened by the coronavirus, the bodies began to pile up in one of the country’s densest urban centers: New York City.

headline: When You Can’t Go Home for the Holidays
abstract: A family holds tight to tradition in the face of the hardest year.
lead_paragraph: In my family, going home for Christmas means driving from Texas to Alabama with my husband and two young daughters.

headline: A Fake ‘War on Christmas’ and the Real Battle Against Covid
abstract: There are two culture wars, but only one with deadly consequences.
lead_paragraph: It’s the Christmas season, when the air is usually filled with the sound of carols, the jingling of cash registers and the cries of the religious right and its political bedmates complaining that a cashier who says, “happy holidays,” or an insufficiently Christmas-specific Starbucks cup constitutes an attack on their beliefs. In other words, it’s getting to be “war on Christmas” time.

headline: Why Are Pandas Covering Themselves With Horse Manure?
abstract: Researchers in China spent a decade studying this question.
lead_paragraph: Last Wednesday, Aleah Bowie, a wildlife ecologist and animal behavior expert, received an interview request by email that made her do a serious double take.

headline: Top Georgia Election Official Debunks ‘Ridiculous’ Claims About Election Fraud
abstract: The office of Georgia’s secretary of state dedicated part of a news conference to what was called “Disinformation Monday.”
lead_paragraph: The office of Georgia’s secretary of state dedicated part of a news conference to what was called “Disinformation Monday.”

headline: Pressure on California hospitals is still mounting fast, Newsom says.
abstract: Hospitals across California have continued to fill rapidly to dangerous levels as state and local officials try to dampen the explosive spread of the coronavirus in the state, Gov. Gavin Newsom said on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Hospitals across California have continued to fill rapidly to dangerous levels as state and local officials try to dampen the explosive spread of the coronavirus in the state, Gov. Gavin Newsom said on Monday.

headline: Christmas Trees — an Elusive Bit of Happiness for Canadians
abstract: There’s been a run on Christmas trees as Canadians, trapped inside because of the pandemic, try, in record numbers, to shoehorn joy into their lives.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Scott Lunau was steering apple pickers onto his farm in mid-November when a customer asked if it was too early to cut down a Christmas tree. He scrambled out to the barn to find the wrapping machine and netting needed to tie up a tree like a package, ready for a roof rack.

headline: A Referee Pursues Her Calling in the Men’s Game
abstract: Last season, Crystal Hogan was the only woman officiating games in the top level of college basketball. The question is: Why?
lead_paragraph: COMPTON, Calif. — There are nearly 900 officials working in the top tier of men’s college basketball, keeping order at thousands of games. They wear black-and-white striped shirts and try to keep a low profile.

headline: Glamour Portraits for the Nurses of Mount Sinai
abstract: The designer Rebecca Moses turns a quarantine art project into a gift of thanks and tribute.
lead_paragraph: “There’s nothing fashionable — ever — about being in a hospital,” said Linda Valentino, the vice president and chief nursing officer at Mount Sinai Health System.

headline: Uber, After Years of Trying, Is Handing Off Its Self-Driving Car Project
abstract: Company executives once said having cars that can drive on their own would be a salvation for their business. But the effort turned into a legal and financial headache.
lead_paragraph: Uber, which spent hundreds of millions of dollars on a self-driving car project that executives once believed was a key to becoming profitable, is handing the autonomous vehicle effort over to a Silicon Valley start-up, the companies said on Monday.

headline: Trump administration officials passed when Pfizer offered months ago to sell the U.S. more vaccine doses.
abstract: Before Pfizer’s coronavirus vaccine was proved highly successful in clinical trials last month, the company offered the Trump administration the chance to lock in supplies beyond the 100 million doses the pharmaceutical maker agreed to sell the government as part of a $1.95 billion deal months ago.
lead_paragraph: Before Pfizer’s coronavirus vaccine was proved highly successful in clinical trials last month, the company offered the Trump administration the chance to lock in supplies beyond the 100 million doses the pharmaceutical maker agreed to sell the government as part of a $1.95 billion deal months ago.

headline: Tanning Beds and Sunbathing May Raise Endometriosis Risk
abstract: Living in areas that are sunnier, however, lowered the risk.
lead_paragraph: Women who use tanning beds or who sunbathe are at increased risk for endometriosis, according to new research.

headline: Birth Defects Tied to Higher Cancer Risk
abstract: Major birth defects are associated with an increased risk for cancer in childhood. New research suggests the risk persists into adulthood.
lead_paragraph: People born with birth defects have a higher risk for cancer throughout life, researchers report.

headline: As Brexit Deadline Looms, Boris Johnson Takes Personal Control of Talks
abstract: With negotiators at impasse, the prime minister hopes he and European leaders can hammer out a trade deal to replace the one that expires on Dec. 31.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — With time running out and the gaps still wide, Prime Minister Boris Johnson took personal control of the Brexit negotiations on Monday, declaring that he would travel to Brussels later this week for a last-ditch effort to strike a trade agreement between Britain and the European Union.

headline: MSNBC Names Rashida Jones as President, Succeeding Phil Griffin
abstract: Ms. Jones, currently a senior vice president at the network, will become the highest-ranking Black woman in the TV news industry.
lead_paragraph: MSNBC was already preparing for one momentous presidential transition next year. Now the 24-hour cable channel and home to liberal stars like Rachel Maddow is about to take on a second.

headline: Chris Young Heads Home, and the Mets Keep Waiting
abstract: The Mets were in the hunt for one of the top general manager candidates in the game, but the ability to stay in Texas was something Steven Cohen could never match.
lead_paragraph: All the billions in the world, apparently, cannot change one stubborn truth about modern baseball: everything takes time. The Mets will have a general manager someday, and the new owner, Steven A. Cohen, will surely find players to take a small slice of his fortune. But for now, the industry is adjusting its batting gloves, stepping off the rubber and checking the defensive-alignment card tucked inside its cap. So we wait.

headline: Elizabeth J. McCormack, Innovative Educator, Dies at 98
abstract: A former nun, she transformed Manhattanville College as its president before becoming a philanthropic adviser to major foundations and the Rockefellers.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth J. McCormack, a former Roman Catholic nun who was the catalyst for sweeping changes at Manhattanville College in the 1960s and ’70s, and who later advised major foundations on philanthropic strategies, died on Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 98.

headline: Romania’s Leader Quits After His Party’s Unexpected Election Loss
abstract: Prime Minister Ludovic Orban expressed confidence that his National Liberal Party would win Sunday’s parliamentary election, but by Monday, he was handing in his resignation.
lead_paragraph: BUCHAREST, Romania — It was supposed to be a moment of victory for Romania’s prime minister, Ludovic Orban, but after his party suffered an unexpected loss in parliamentary elections on Sunday, Mr. Orban resigned from office Monday evening.

headline: This Austrian Cake Sparkles at the Party
abstract: Punch cakes from the Vienna Cookie Company are inspired by punschkrapferl, a liquor-soaked petit four.
lead_paragraph: Move over, macaron. These celebratory little Viennese cakes beg for bubbly alongside. They’re new from Heidi Riegler’s Vienna Cookie Company in Baldwin, N.Y. Called punschkrapferl or punch cakes, they’re the Austrian take on petits fours, with liquor-soaked cake sandwiching fillings of jam and chocolate, glazed on the outside and blinged with a bit of gold leaf. They come in a rainbow of flavors— cherry, orange and spiced rum — seven in each silver tin.

headline: California, Vaccines, Georgia: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: France Infection Rate Above Target for Holiday Season
abstract: Jérôme Salomon, a French health official, said on Monday that new daily infections were no longer decreasing and remain particularly high among people older than 75.
lead_paragraph: Jérôme Salomon, a French health official, said on Monday that new daily infections were no longer decreasing and remain particularly high among people older than 75.

headline: Catch These 15 Titles Before They Leave Netflix in December
abstract: The year’s end means a ton of licenses are expiring. Stream these movies and bingeable TV series while you can.
lead_paragraph: The end of the year means the end of licensing contracts for the streaming services, so this month’s Netflix offload is a bit of a blood bath — including not only the customary assortment of beloved movies for young and old, but also a handful of the streamer’s most binge-able and rewatchable TV series. (Dates reflect the final day of a title’s availability.)

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: Who should get a shot first? Second? Third?
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus vaccination campaign is expected to begin in the United States within the next month, and the debate about when different groups of Americans should receive doses is heating up. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has recommended that health care workers and the oldest, most vulnerable people should be first in line. Who should go next?

headline: Trading Box Office for Streaming, but Stars Still Want Their Money
abstract: If studios are no longer trying to maximize ticket sales, what will that mean for often lucrative pay packages tied to a film’s performance in theaters?
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Last month, Warner Bros. quietly approached Hollywood’s two biggest talent agencies, William Morris Endeavor and Creative Artists. The studio wanted to release the much-anticipated “Wonder Woman 1984” simultaneously in theaters and on the streaming service HBO Max on Christmas Day. And they wanted to get the film’s star, Gal Gadot, and director, Patty Jenkins, on board with the plan.

headline: Arctic Seismic Work Will Not Hurt Polar Bears, Government Says
abstract: The announcement removes a major hurdle to approving a plan to hunt for oil in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska, part of a push to allow drilling there by the Trump administration.
lead_paragraph: The United States Fish and Wildlife Service said on Monday that a seismic survey planned for the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska this winter would have “no more than a negligible impact” on the numbers of polar bears in the region.

headline: Supreme Court Hears Holocaust Survivors’ Cases Against Hungary and Germany
abstract: The justices struggled to decide whether a 1976 law that bars most suits against other nations allows Jewish victims to sue over the theft of their property.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court, wary in the past of cases concerning conduct by and against foreigners that took place abroad, heard arguments on Monday over whether American courts have a role in deciding whether Hungary and Germany must pay for property said to have been stolen from Jews before and during World War II.

headline: Dick Allen, 78, Dies; Baseball Slugger Withstood Bigotry
abstract: One of the game’s best and most honored players in the 1960s and into the ’70s, he nevertheless felt racism’s sting early in his career in Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: Dick Allen, who was among baseball’s leading sluggers of the 1960s and early ’70s, playing mostly with the Phillies and Chicago White Sox, but who found himself a target of Philadelphia fans in his early years with the club, an outgrowth of racial animosity, died on Monday in Wampum, Pa. He was 78.

headline: Indoor Dining May Be Banned Again, Threatening Many N.Y.C. Restaurants
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced a new restrictions model that could end indoor dining in the city as early as next week.
lead_paragraph: Since the pandemic forced most New York City businesses to shut down nine months ago, the restaurant industry has warned that it was facing a crisis.

headline: Florida’s fired virus data manager says the police seized her computer.
abstract: Police officers seized the computer, cellphone and hard drives of Rebekah D. Jones, an outspoken critic of Florida’s handling of coronavirus data,  Ms. Jones said.
lead_paragraph: Police officers seized the computer, cellphone and hard drives of Rebekah D. Jones, an outspoken critic of Florida’s handling of coronavirus data,  Ms. Jones said.

headline: Georgia Recertifies Election Results, Affirming Biden’s Victory
abstract: The move was the latest blow to President Trump’s attempts to subvert the election results. But battles over the process of voting in Georgia are likely to continue.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Georgia election officials on Monday recertified the results of the state’s presidential race after another recount reaffirmed Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory over President Trump, the third time that results showed that Mr. Trump had lost the state.

headline: Republicans Can’t Handle the Truth
abstract: You shouldn’t be surprised that they’re still backing Trump.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s continuing attempts to overturn an election he lost decisively more than a month ago is, like so much of what he’s done in office, shocking but not surprising. Who imagined that he would go quietly?

headline: On Iran, Biden Can Bide His Time
abstract: The new administration should not be stampeded into returning to the nuclear deal.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Joe Biden has made it clear that his preferred method for dealing with Iran is to find a way back to the nuclear deal the Obama administration concluded in 2015, while bargaining for an extension to some of its key provisions.

headline: The Stimulus Compromise Is $908 Billion Better Than Nothing
abstract: The Senate’s plan is flawed. Doing nothing would be much worse.
lead_paragraph: Americans urgently need Congress to deliver a fresh round of economic aid. Millions of people who lost jobs in the spring are reaching the end of their unemployment benefits. Many have fallen behind on rent or mortgage payments. Many do not have enough to eat.

headline: Elevating Fringe Theories, Ron Johnson Questions Virus Science
abstract: The Wisconsin Republican has transformed his Senate panel into a forum for amplifying dubious theories and questionable treatments pushed by President Trump.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In choosing a slate of doctors to testify about coronavirus treatments before his committee on Tuesday, Senator Ron Johnson has assembled a cast of witnesses who question much of the public health consensus about the virus.

headline: Republicans Make Clear Their Georgia Senate Strategy: Attack Warnock
abstract: For the crucial Senate runoffs, the G.O.P. is focusing its attacks on the Rev. Raphael Warnock, portraying him as radical, a claim he has rejected but one that worked for Republicans in down-ballot races last month.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Senator David Perdue of Georgia didn’t show up for a debate on Sunday night, he ensured two outcomes: Jon Ossoff, Mr. Perdue’s Democratic opponent, would enjoy free airtime unencumbered by attacks from his rival, and the other Senate debate that night would draw far more attention.

headline: Sorry, Gen. Lloyd Austin. A Recently Retired General Should Not Be Secretary of Defense.
abstract: After a tumultuous four years, we need civilian leadership and a return to normalcy.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Joe Biden is expected to nominate a retired Army general, Lloyd Austin, for secretary of defense.

headline: Most of California Locks Down Again as Coronavirus Strains Hospitals
abstract: As the United States surpassed 15 million cases, California’s situation despite its earlier restrictions was a cautionary tale.
lead_paragraph: MORAGA, Calif. — Most of California was on lockdown on Monday as two vast regions, Southern California and the heavily agricultural San Joaquin Valley, reached a serious enough shortage of hospital beds to trigger new restrictions set by the state to slow the spread of the coronavirus.

headline: Chocolate Crackers and Yule Logs for the Holidays
abstract: Hide these festive treats from La Maison du Chocolat and Charbonnel et Walker in the stockings.
lead_paragraph: Christmas traditions rendered in chocolate make for snackable treats and stocking stuffers. This year at La Maison du Chocolat, the holiday theme is the Christmas cracker, the party toy most popular in England that snaps open to reveal little goodies. A 10-inch oblong solid dark chocolate version is tied at each end and festively encrusted with nuts, like a mendiant. Another option would be bite-size milk chocolate praline Yule logs dusted with sugar from Charbonnel et Walker of London.

headline: Panettone, Fresh From Italy
abstract: Olivieri, a bakery in northern Italy, ships its feather-light breads to America.
lead_paragraph: Back in 1882, when Olivieri, a bakery in Arzignano, Italy, near Vicenza in the Veneto region, started producing panettone you can be sure that it did not make an apricot and salted caramel flavor. But Nicola Olivieri, a sixth-generation baker in the baking family, is doing just that, along with other flavors, for his luxurious feather-light domes: chocolate-hazelnut gianduja, three-chocolate and the classic with candied fruit. They’re as good as it gets with panettone.

headline: This Cookbook Raises Money for the Ballet
abstract: The American Ballet Theater’s dancers and staff have created a community cookbook of cherished recipes.
lead_paragraph: Even the dancers and other staff from the American Ballet Theater have been spending time cooking during the pandemic. The result is a digital cookbook with 65 recipes, including delectables like tarte au citron from Emily Hayes in the corps de ballet, and pirouette pumpkin muffins from Kara Medoff Barnett, the executive director. Among the savories is adagio braised short ribs from the principal dancer Hee Seo. The illustrations with ballet motifs are by the dancer Javier Rivet. Proceeds from sales of the cookbook benefit the ballet company.

headline: Biden Plans to Tap Lloyd Austin, Former Iraq Commander, as Defense Secretary
abstract: The retired four-star Army general would make history as the first African-American to lead the Pentagon.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. is expected to nominate retired Gen. Lloyd J. Austin III, a former commander of the American military effort in Iraq, to be the next secretary of defense, according to two people with knowledge of the selection.

headline: My, What a Sneaky Little Flour
abstract: Those looking to add more fiber to their diet have a flour in their corner: Flourish, made with a high-fiber strain of wheat.
lead_paragraph: It’s nothing like spinach in the mashed potatoes. Adding a boost of fiber to home-baked goods, even sugary holiday treats, is easy with a new all-purpose flour. Flourish — made from a strain of white wheat, with a naturally high fiber content, grown by farmers in various locations and processed by Bay State Milling — provides 24 grams of fiber in a cup, compared with an average 3.4 grams for regular all-purpose. The good news is that Flourish performs like regular unbleached all-purpose flour in pie crust, the essential test, and in poundcake. The downside is that it’s expensive.

headline: Christchurch Inquiry Says New Zealand Couldn’t Have Prevented Mosque Attacks
abstract: But the Royal Commission, the country’s highest-level investigation, faulted lax gun regulations and the country’s “fragile” intelligence agencies.
lead_paragraph: WELLINGTON, New Zealand — He was a socially anxious loner who was radicalized partly by extremist content on YouTube. But even as he traveled abroad extensively to places linked to far-right violence; amassed weapons, ammunition, tactical gear and unprescribed steroids; and was treated in a hospital after a firearms accident in his living room, he never came to the attention of the New Zealand authorities.

headline: No One Expects Civility From Republicans
abstract: What’s worse: making Sarah Sanders leave a restaurant, or terrorizing election officials?
lead_paragraph: Perhaps you remember the terrible ordeal suffered by the White House press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders at the Red Hen in 2018. She was awaiting her entree at the Virginia farm-to-table restaurant when the co-owner, appalled by Sanders’s defense of Donald Trump’s administration, asked her to leave. This happened three days after the homeland security secretary at the time, Kirstjen Nielsen, was yelled at for the administration’s family separation policy as she tried to dine at a Mexican restaurant in Washington.

headline: Reserve a Cookie Box From Some Culinary Darlings
abstract: Nina Compton, Alice Waters and Enrique Olvera are among the chefs contributing to the Resy Cookie Box.
lead_paragraph: This cookie assortment — from Resy, the restaurant reservation platform, and Ovenly, the Brooklyn-based baker — has a dozen cookies made from recipes by chefs like Missy Robbins, Alice Waters, Enrique Olvera, Jeremy Fox and Nina Compton. The selection, available through this month, includes a winter spiced sweet potato cookie, lemon fennel shortbread, chocolate chip rye, criollo oatmeal, and white chocolate almond cherry. American Express Gold Card has added a copy of Ovenly’s cookbook to each order; along with Resy, it will make a donation to José Andrés’s World Central Kitchen.

headline: Israeli Soccer Team, Infamous for Anti-Arab Fans, Has New Co-Owner: a Sheikh
abstract: The barrier-shattering deal puts an Emirati royal at the helm of Beitar Jerusalem, the only Israeli team that has never fielded an Arab player and whose most extreme fans chant racist slurs.
