headline: Trump Administration Is Planting Loyalists in Biden Transition Meetings
abstract: Supporters of the president are monitoring many of the conversations between Biden teams and civil servants, chilling the flow of information.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Loyalists to President Trump have blocked transition meetings at some government agencies and are sitting in on discussions at other agencies between career civil servants and President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s transition teams, sometimes chilling conversations, several federal officials said.

headline: House Passes Defense Bill Overwhelmingly, Defying Trump’s Veto Threat
abstract: The $741 billion measure passed with a veto-proof majority, setting up a potential showdown with President Trump in the final weeks of his term.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House overwhelmingly passed a $741 billion defense policy bill on Tuesday that would require that Confederate names be stripped from American military bases, defying President Trump’s veto threat and moving lawmakers one step closer to a potential showdown in his final weeks in office.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: Britons became the first people in the world to receive a fully tested vaccine.
lead_paragraph: At 6:31 a.m. today in Britain, Margaret Keenan, a 90-year-old former jewelry shop assistant, pulled up the sleeve of her “Merry Christmas” T-shirt and was injected with a coronavirus vaccine — kicking off the world’s first campaign to deliver a fully tested vaccine against Covid-19.

headline: Biden’s Pentagon Pick Reignites Debate Over Civilian Control of Military
abstract: Congress would need to approve a waiver for Lloyd J. Austin III, a recently retired general, to serve in the civilian post, four years after President Trump’s first defense secretary received one.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s intention to nominate a retired Army general as secretary of defense has run into bipartisan resistance on Capitol Hill, where there are growing concerns about another former commander leading the Pentagon in a nation that has a long tradition of civilian control of the military.

headline: Pandemic Fatigue, Meet Pandemic Anger
abstract: If shaming people for flouting Covid-19 safety guidance doesn’t work, what are we supposed to do with all of our frustration?
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.

headline: DoorDash to price its public offering at $102 a share, valuing it at $39 billion.
abstract: DoorDash had already raised its price range amid demand from potential shareholders as it prepares to begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
lead_paragraph: DoorDash, the country’s largest food delivery company, said on Tuesday it would price its shares at $102 each, raising roughly $3.4 billion in its initial public offering and valuing the company at around $39 billion.

headline: Biden Promises 100 Million Vaccine Shots in 100 Days, but Shortage Worries Rise
abstract: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s promise to shift the course of the pandemic in his first 100 days in office could run into vaccine production and procurement problems he will inherit.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr., setting ambitious goals to change the course of the coronavirus pandemic, vowed on Tuesday to get “at least 100 million Covid vaccine shots into the arms of the American people” during his first 100 days in office, and said he would make it a “national priority” to get children back to school during that time.

headline: Apps Are Helping to Gut the Restaurant Industry
abstract: High fees are cutting already thin margins to the bone.
lead_paragraph: The sudden onset of the pandemic in March sent the restaurant industry into a death spiral. Working in a notoriously low-margin business, many couldn’t withstand weeks of limited or no indoor dining. As a result, about one in six restaurants nationwide has closed permanently, and as of September nearly three million restaurant workers had lost their jobs.

headline: Stop the Coronavirus Outbreak at Brooklyn’s Federal Jail
abstract: New York’s congressional representatives can make sure that prisoners are treated humanely.
lead_paragraph: Last week, at least 55 inmates at the Metropolitan Detention Center in Brooklyn tested positive for the coronavirus, according to Federal Bureau of Prisons data.

headline: Special End of Year 2020 News Quiz
abstract: See what you remember about this extraordinary year by taking our special 2020 news quiz.
lead_paragraph: See what you remember about this extraordinary year by taking our special 2020 news quiz.

headline: The Nation Reached ‘Safe Harbor.’ Here’s What That Means.
abstract: President Trump’s efforts to overturn the presidential election are nearing the end of the line.
lead_paragraph: Joseph R. Biden Jr. has already won the presidential election, but on Tuesday he moved one step closer to the White House.

headline: As Trump Rails Against Loss, His Supporters Become More Threatening
abstract: The president’s baseless claims of voting fraud have prompted outrage among his loyalists and led to behavior that Democrats and even some Republicans say has become dangerous.
lead_paragraph: With a key deadline passing Tuesday that all but ends his legal challenges to the election, President Trump’s frenzied campaign to overturn the results has reached an inflection point: Certified slates of electors to the Electoral College are now protected by law, and any chance that a state might appoint a different slate that is favorable to Mr. Trump is essentially gone.

headline: In Farewell Speech, Udall Says Senate Has Become ‘Graveyard for Progress’
abstract: Senator Tom Udall, a retiring New Mexico Democrat, used his parting speech as a call to kill the legislative filibuster, arguing that it had caused paralysis and prevented action on big issues.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Tom Udall urged his colleagues on Tuesday to kill the legislative filibuster that he said had helped turn the Senate into a “graveyard for progress,” using his farewell speech to point up a state of dysfunction in Congress that had become painfully obvious to most everyone listening to him.

headline: Two Presidents, Two Messages, One Killer Virus
abstract: In split-screen assessments of the coronavirus pandemic, President Trump focused on the “medical miracle” of vaccines and President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. warned of a “very dark winter.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One president all but declared victory over the pandemic, hailing new vaccines as a “medical miracle” and congratulating himself for doing what “nobody has ever seen before.” The next president declared the pandemic deadlier than ever, calling it a “mass casualty” event that is leaving “a gaping hole” in America with more misery to come.

headline: Biden’s Choice for Pentagon Faces Questions on Ties to Contractors
abstract: Retired Gen. Lloyd J. Austin III serves on the board of Raytheon, one of the world’s largest weapons makers, and is a partner in an investment firm that buys military suppliers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Three weeks ago, a Navy ship off Hawaii launched a military contractor’s experimental missile to successfully intercept and destroy for the first time in space a decoy pretending to be an incoming nuclear weapon.

headline: Word + Quiz: potable
abstract: This word has appeared in 18 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: Terry McAuliffe, former Virginia governor, will begin a bid for his old job.
abstract: Terry McAuliffe, the former governor of Virginia, will enter the contest for his old job on Wednesday, according to a person familiar with his plans, joining an already crowded Democratic primary that is likely to serve as a harbinger of the party’s future.
lead_paragraph: Terry McAuliffe, the former governor of Virginia, will enter the contest for his old job on Wednesday, according to a person familiar with his plans, joining an already crowded Democratic primary that is likely to serve as a harbinger of the party’s future.

headline: White House Offers $916 Billion Stimulus Proposal, Cutting Jobless Benefits
abstract: The proposal by Steven Mnuchin, the Treasury secretary, was the administration’s first substantive engagement with Congress on a stimulus deal since the election.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jump-starting negotiations with days to spare, the White House on Tuesday offered Democrats a $916 billion pandemic stimulus proposal that would meet their demand to provide some relief to state and local governments and include liability protections for businesses that have been a top priority of Republicans.

headline: Biden Picks Marcia Fudge for HUD and Tom Vilsack for Agriculture Secretary
abstract: Ms. Fudge, a House member from Ohio, would be the second African-American Biden cabinet member chosen in two days. Mr. Vilsack would reprise his role from the Obama administration.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. has selected Representative Marcia L. Fudge, Democrat of Ohio, to serve as the secretary of housing and urban development, people familiar with the transition said on Tuesday, the second African-American he has chosen for his cabinet in two days.

headline: Trump appointee sidelines V.O.A. director before Biden takes office.
abstract: The acting director of Voice of America was reassigned on Tuesday, as part of what is most likely a broader bid to install loyalists for President Trump at the news outlet before the Biden administration takes over, two people familiar with the decision said.
lead_paragraph: The acting director of Voice of America was reassigned on Tuesday, as part of what is most likely a broader bid to install loyalists for President Trump at the news outlet before the Biden administration takes over, two people familiar with the decision said.

headline: Speaking Words of Wisdom
abstract: Owen Travis makes his New York Times Crossword debut, enabled and abetted by Jeff Chen.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — In Marcel Proust’s “In Search of Lost Time,” also translated as “Remembrance of Things Past,” the author bites into a madeleine and is transported, in his memory, to his childhood.

headline: Quotation of the Day: What’s in a Name? A Patient Adds Shakespearean Flair
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, December 9, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “It could make a difference to our lives from now on, couldn’t it?”

headline: New & Noteworthy, From Schopenhauer to the Pope
abstract: A selection of books published this week; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
lead_paragraph: LET US DREAM: The Path to a Better Future, by Pope Francis and Austen Ivereigh. (Simon & Schuster, $26.) The leader of the Roman Catholic Church asks what we can learn from the pandemic, and revisits three crises from his own life.

headline: A Year Like No Other: 2020 in Pictures
abstract: In a world where life changed seemingly overnight, photographers transformed how they worked, trading intimacy for distance. This is what they captured.
lead_paragraph: In a world where life changed seemingly overnight, photographers transformed how they worked, trading intimacy for distance. This is what they captured.

headline: Vaccines, Brexit, Obama: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Work-From-Home Scheme Targeting Latinas Netted $7 Million, U.S. Says
abstract: A federal lawsuit says that Moda Latina BZ, a Los Angeles County company, deceived consumers into thinking they could make up to $500 a week selling perfume, makeup and other items.
lead_paragraph: The federal government has sued a Los Angeles County telemarketing company that officials said had reaped $7 million by making false promises of work-from-home opportunities to female viewers of Spanish-language television stations, exploiting their economic insecurity — and later, their worries over the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Corrections: Dec. 9, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Dec. 9, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about a global update on the coronavirus pandemic misidentified the country where ski lifts were opening. It is Austria, not Australia.

headline: Late-Night Hosts Celebrate ‘V-Day’ in Britain
abstract: Stephen Colbert and others riffed on 90-year-old Margaret Keenan and 81-year-old William Shakespeare, the first recipients of Pfizer’s coronavirus vaccine in a mass inoculation program.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Word + Quiz: aerie
abstract: This word has appeared in 19 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: How to End This Pandemic, and Prepare for the Next One
abstract: A group of experts gathered to debate vaccines, inequality and repairing the nation’s battered institutions.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration will hold a hearing this week to determine whether to grant emergency authorization to a coronavirus vaccine developed by Pfizer and BioNTech. The vaccine, which the companies claim is 95 percent effective, is one of two that could be ready for injections in the United States before the end of this year. The other, by Moderna, will be considered by the regulator for emergency approval next week. In early trials, the vaccine appeared to prevent the development of Covid-19 in around 94 percent of recipients.

headline: Money and Tears
abstract: What is this image saying?

headline: This Eagles’ No-Win Quarterback Predicament Isn’t Like the Last One
abstract: Jalen Hurts, a rookie, was named the Week 14 starter over Carson Wentz, a franchise quarterback, but Philadelphia is in no way suited for a rebuild.
lead_paragraph: The Philadelphia Eagles were too cursed for too long to finally win a Super Bowl without a “Twilight Zone”-worthy twist. Fate granted the Eagles a championship but denied them the franchise quarterback they thought they were getting with it.

headline: Virtual Cycling and Real Cheating: Cracking Down on ‘Digital Doping’
abstract: A highly anticipated race on Wednesday, sponsored by the Zwift cycling app and the sport’s world governing body, will test new controls on cheating in virtual competitions.
lead_paragraph: The cat-and-mouse battle between athletes who cheat and those who try to find them has gone digital.

headline: He Broke Out of Quarantine for 8 Seconds, and Got a $3,550 Fine
abstract: Around the world, flouting coronavirus regulations can have expensive consequences.
lead_paragraph: One man left the house after an argument with his wife and walked 280 miles to cool off, breaching Italy’s national curfew.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘Hollywood’s Obituary, the Sequel. Now Streaming.’
abstract: In this lesson, students will learn about the challenges facing the movie industry and consider the future of Hollywood.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “Hollywood’s Obituary, the Sequel. Now Streaming.” by Brooks Barnes

headline: In Russia, vaccines are free. But public distrust is high.
abstract: Russia has made its coronavirus vaccine available for free in recent days to teachers, medical workers and social-service employees younger than 61 in Moscow. But a lack of trust is hobbling Russia’s rollout: the country’s scientists may well have made great strides in battling the pandemic, but many Russians are not ready to believe it.
lead_paragraph: Russia has made its coronavirus vaccine available for free in recent days to teachers, medical workers and social-service employees younger than 61 in Moscow. But a lack of trust is hobbling Russia’s rollout: the country’s scientists may well have made great strides in battling the pandemic, but many Russians are not ready to believe it.

headline: Children’s hospitals are pitching in to help with the flood of adult Covid-19 patients.
abstract: With a rising tide of Covid-19 patients threatening to overwhelm hospitals, public health officials across the United States are reaching for a safety valve that the Northeast used in the spring: borrowing beds in children’s hospitals to care for adults.
lead_paragraph: With a rising tide of Covid-19 patients threatening to overwhelm hospitals, public health officials across the United States are reaching for a safety valve that the Northeast used in the spring: borrowing beds in children’s hospitals to care for adults.

headline: She Accused the Mayor of Sexual Assault. Then the Town Turned on Her.
abstract: Assemblymen in Kusatsu, Japan, organized an election to recall their sole female colleague, saying she had damaged the town’s reputation with her allegations.
lead_paragraph: A Japanese councilor who accused a mayor of sexual assault has been voted out of office by residents after colleagues argued that she had damaged the town’s reputation.

headline: What Works of Art, Culture and Technology Flopped in 2020?
abstract: With so much content moving online because of the pandemic, there were bound to be some duds. What performances, movies, music, food and tech did you find boring, awkward or just plain bad this year?
lead_paragraph: This has not been an easy year for the arts. After the onset of the coronavirus pandemic, museums, movie theaters and restaurants shuttered. Concerts were canceled. Performances were postponed.

headline: This Borscht Is the Essence of the East Village
abstract: The Polish diner that used to feed me is gone, so I make this soup instead. It’s almost as good.
lead_paragraph: My very first solo apartment in Manhattan was a miniature studio on East 11th Street, nothing more than a quiet room with tall windows and a stove. But I felt so mature having it — a place I was entirely responsible for rather than slipping into the extra bedroom of a space where someone else’s name was on the lease and the electric bill. I was exuberant on the sunny day I moved in. Clicking the locks to the hollow echo inside; unpacking the crumpled newspaper-stuffed boxes of my things in quasi-monastic silence (there wasn’t even the vibrating hum of the half fridge, because Con Ed hadn’t arrived yet); and placing my jelly jar of writing pens just so on the ledge.

headline: When a Theater Critic Learned to Grade on a Curve
abstract: Nine months covering a devastated art form have changed one critic’s habits, and tastes.
lead_paragraph: Nothing much about the process of reviewing theater had yet changed by March 7, when I set out to see the musical “Six” on Broadway. My husband and I braved the subway from Brooklyn to a jammed Times Square, squeezed our way into the Brooks Atkinson Theater, hugged friends, took our seats and inhaled the atmosphere of joy and anxiety that perfumes every show about to open.

headline: Our Oceans, Our Future
abstract: To conquer the dual, interrelated crises of Covid-19 and climate change we have to start small, and dream big.
lead_paragraph: This is an article from Turning Points, a special section that explores what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead.

headline: To Lose Weight With Exercise, Aim for 300 Minutes a Week
abstract: Overweight men and women who exercised six days a week lost weight; those who worked out twice a week did not.
lead_paragraph: Can exercise help us shed pounds? An interesting new study involving overweight men and women found that working out can help us lose weight, in part by remodeling appetite hormones. But to benefit, the study suggests, we most likely have to exercise a lot — burning at least 3,000 calories a week. In the study, that meant working out six days a week for up to an hour, or around 300 minutes a week.

headline: The Best Graphic Novels of 2020
abstract: Our Graphic Content columnists pick their favorites from a year rich with visual storytelling.
lead_paragraph: As the assorted pressures of this year weighed down on your Graphic Content columnists, we periodically sought escape in our reading material — but many of our favorite comics titles for 2020 tackled serious matters head on: racism, police violence, the refugee crisis, colonialism, mental illness. There’s some humor to be found in the selections below, which are far-flung in time and space. But what’s most remarkable, in this excruciating year, is how these books — and the medium itself — seem capable of illuminating just about anything.

headline: Iran Is Moving Key Facility at Nuclear Site Underground, Satellite Images Show
abstract: In July, an explosion rocked a key Iranian nuclear facility. Iran called it sabotage and vowed to rebuild a destroyed building underground. Iran is now turning that promise into a reality, new satellite images show.
lead_paragraph: The mysterious July explosion that destroyed a centrifuge assembly hall at Iran’s main nuclear fuel enrichment facility in Natanz was deemed by the Iranian authorities to be enemy sabotage, and provoked a defiant response: The wrecked building would be rebuilt in “the heart of the mountains,” the head of Iran’s Atomic Energy Organization said.

headline: Why Some N.Y.C. Lawmakers Want to Rethink Ranked-Choice Voting
abstract: The new system was approved by voters in 2019, but critics, including at least one top mayoral candidate, fear that it may disenfranchise minority voters.
lead_paragraph: Next year was supposed to be when New York City would revolutionize how voters choose their mayor — not merely selecting one candidate, but picking as many as five and ranking them in order of preference.

headline: Watched ‘Mank’ but Never Seen ‘Citizen Kane’? Here’s a Primer
abstract: Why does the new Netflix film revisit a drama from 1941? To many, the older movie is still considered the greatest ever made.
lead_paragraph: Before its reputation as the greatest film of all time was cemented, and even before it was released, “Citizen Kane” (1941) was a lightning rod. Its first-time director, Orson Welles, already known for his innovations in theater and radio, had gone to Hollywood in his mid-20s riding a wave of anticipation. By making his debut feature a thinly veiled portrait of the newspaper tycoon William Randolph Hearst, he had chosen a target who could guarantee that the film would be shunned in the press. “Kane” hadn’t even opened when Louis B. Mayer, the production chief of M.G.M., hatched a plan to pay off R.K.O., the film’s studio, and have the negative destroyed.

headline: The Resentment That Never Sleeps
abstract: Rising anxiety over declining social status tells us a lot about how we got here and where we’re going.
lead_paragraph: More and more, politics determine which groups are favored and which are denigrated.

headline: ‘There’s No Place for Them to Go’: I.C.U. Beds Near Capacity Across U.S.
abstract: More than a third of Americans live in areas where hospitals are running critically short of intensive care beds.
lead_paragraph: More than a third of Americans live in areas where hospitals are running critically short of intensive care beds.

headline: California Towns Rebel Against Pandemic Restaurant Restrictions
abstract: Frustrated over an order to temporarily ban outdoor dining across Los Angeles County, many elected officials have fought back — with votes to form their own health departments.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Until late last month, outdoor dining — no masks required — was the closest thing to pre-pandemic normal for the 10 million residents of Los Angeles County. But amid a record-busting surge in hospitalizations and cases of the coronavirus, the county’s health department recently said outdoor dining must come to a complete halt for the first time since May.

headline: Social Inequities Explain Racial Gaps in Pandemic, Studies Find
abstract: Higher rates of infection and mortality among Black and Hispanic Americans are explained by exposure on the job and at home, experts said.
lead_paragraph: When Dr. Gbenga Ogedegbe began to research coronavirus infections among Black and Hispanic patients, he thought he knew what he would find. Infected Black and Hispanic patients would be more likely to be hospitalized, compared with white patients, and more likely to die.

headline: This Sport Is a ‘Way of Life.’ In a Pandemic, It’s Also High Risk.
abstract: A number of outbreaks connected to youth ice hockey have led many states in the Northeast to restrict it. Players and their parents are crestfallen.
lead_paragraph: WEST ORANGE, N.J. — On a recent Sunday at a cavernous ice skating complex in suburban New Jersey, locker rooms sat empty while hockey players slipped into their uniforms in the parking lot.

headline: How Bad Was Virus Aid Fraud? One Banker Was ‘Frustrated With Humanity’
abstract: The Paycheck Protection Program offered small businesses a few months of relief, but prosecutors will be running down fraud for years.
lead_paragraph: Chris Hurn wasn’t surprised scammers were trying to get government money. An enormous relief effort like the $523 billion Paycheck Protection Program is bound to attract grifters.

headline: Dispute Erupts Over Translation Rights to New Nobel Laureate
abstract: For 14 years, one publisher released Louise Glück’s poetry in Spanish. Then she won the Nobel Prize, and her agent made a change.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — After winning the Nobel Prize in Literature, Louise Glück has found herself at the heart of less-welcome publicity, because of a dispute over who should hold the Spanish-language rights to her work.

headline: Help! How Can I Help My Toddler Wear a Mask on a Plane?
abstract: Flying with a small child is difficult enough. Now try to get one to keep their mask on.
lead_paragraph: At some point this winter, my wife and I are hoping to take our daughter to visit her grandparents on the West Coast. We live in New Jersey and haven’t seen my folks in more than a year. Our daughter will turn 2 in January and has no experience wearing a mask yet. We follow public health policies to a T and respect the overall good they bring; however, I can’t help but worry about what might happen if my daughter refuses to keep it on for the duration of the flight. How strict are airlines being? What can I do to prepare? Howard

headline: When Culture Really Began to Reckon With White Privilege
abstract: Black artists didn’t wait around for institutional change. They are making it happen.
lead_paragraph: “Dear White American Theater.” So opened the scathing statement released on June 8 and signed by some of our most influential playwrights and directors who are Black, Indigenous and people of color. “We see you. We have always seen you,” the letter read a few lines later. “We have watched you pretend not to see us.”

headline: When Reading Had No End
abstract: Books were a refuge in 2020, although some stories were more of a consolation than others.
lead_paragraph: This was the worst year, and nothing made sense any longer, except when it was the best year, because time for reading seemed to expand like one of those endless summer afternoons when one was in the late stages of grade school. I despised 2020 while also, as a person of solitary disposition, found myself helplessly nodding in agreement with Emma Brockes, who wrote in The Guardian about this plague year: “Let’s face it: some aspect of it has also been the enactment and indulgence of our wildest dreams.” I sense I am like that character in John Bunyan’s “The Pilgrim’s Progress,” Mr. Facing Both-Ways.

headline: The Hall of Fame Kept Dick Allen Waiting. He Ran Out of Time.
abstract: The pandemic delayed a Golden Days committee vote that could have finally put Allen, who died on Monday, in Cooperstown.
lead_paragraph: They are some of the most hallowed names in baseball history, 10 of the most dominant offensive forces of the fully integrated major leagues, inner-circle Hall of Famers who slugged their way through an era better known for pitching:

headline: Amazon Halo Review: The Fitness Gadget We Don’t Deserve or Need
abstract: The retail giant claims that its health product is extremely precise at scanning body fat. I found otherwise.
lead_paragraph: Many of us are in the same boat these days. With the coronavirus killing more people by the day, we are increasingly stress-eating and drinking more alcohol. At the same time, with gyms shut down, we are sitting around more and glued to screens.

headline: Ronald Lauder Gives Major Arms and Armor Gift to the Met
abstract: The group of galleries will be named for the collector, whose 91-object gift is the museum’s most significant since 1942.
lead_paragraph: For more than 40 years, Ronald S. Lauder collected knights in shining armor. Now he has decided to be one.

headline: Even in Defeat, Trump Tightens Grip on State G.O.P. Lawmakers
abstract: In Pennsylvania, the president’s false claims of a rigged vote may inflame the party base for years to come. One lawmaker said that refusing to back up his assertions would “get my house bombed.”
lead_paragraph: Last week, allies of President Trump accused Republican leaders in Pennsylvania of being “cowards” and “liars” and of letting America down.

headline: Living In ... New Rochelle, N.Y.
abstract: An early pandemic hot spot, this Westchester city is seeing a new outbreak. But it still represents a refuge to some New Yorkers.
lead_paragraph: An early pandemic hot spot, this Westchester city is seeing a new outbreak. But it still represents a refuge to some New Yorkers.

headline: How Atlanta’s Politics Overtook the Suburbs, Too
abstract: Communities that defined themselves in opposition to the city have increasingly grown to resemble it.
lead_paragraph: The suburbs of Cobb County, Ga., boomed during white flight on the promise of isolation from Atlanta. Residents there dating to the 1960s did not want Atlanta problems, or Atlanta transit, or Atlanta people. As a local commissioner once infamously put it, he would stock piranha in the Chattahoochee River that separates Cobb from Atlanta if it were necessary to keep the city out.

headline: New Rochelle, N.Y.: A Waterfront Suburb With a Socioeconomic Mix
abstract: An early pandemic hot spot, this Westchester city is seeing a new outbreak. But it still represents a refuge to some New Yorkers.
lead_paragraph: “We have it in our power to begin the world over again,” wrote Thomas Paine, the political provocateur, in 1776.

headline: When Podcasts Bridged the Social Distance
abstract: The voices that piped into our ears carried more than stories — they brought in the outside world.
lead_paragraph: This spring, when so many of us became involuntary shut-ins, haunting our own homes like premature phantoms, routine mail delivery could feel oddly thrilling. We cheered the arrival of new packages not only for their contents but simply because they were new — tantalizing evidence of a wider world within reach.

headline: This Was the Year When Everything Became TV
abstract: As a global pandemic left us homebound, cousin Emily in Pittsburgh existed on the same plane as “Emily in Paris.”
lead_paragraph: The year is coming to a close, which means it’s time for critics like me to look back on the most memorable television of 2020. There was “I May Destroy You,” Michaela Coel’s tour de force on HBO. There was “Palm Springs” (on Hulu) and “Borat Subsequent Moviefilm” (on Amazon Prime) and that instant-classic TV-antihero drama, “Hamilton” (on Disney+). And then there were the offbeat streaming hits, like “Your Weekly Office Departmental Planning Meeting” and “Your Sophomore Year in College” and “Thanksgiving Dinner With Your Mom.”

headline: When Opera Entered the Chat
abstract: The pandemic urged a classical music critic to pull out his phone — and find unexpected community.
lead_paragraph: Since my livelihood depends on my sitting for many long, silent hours in darkened concert halls, it’s an unfortunate aspect of my character that I hate keeping my opinions to myself — even long enough to write them down for the next day’s paper.

headline: ‘Nothing to do with genes’: Racial gaps in pandemic stem from social inequities, studies find.
abstract: When Dr. Gbenga Ogedegbe began to research coronavirus infections among Black and Hispanic patients, he thought he knew what he would find. Infected Black and Hispanic patients would be more likely to be hospitalized, compared with white patients, and more likely to die.
lead_paragraph: When Dr. Gbenga Ogedegbe began to research coronavirus infections among Black and Hispanic patients, he thought he knew what he would find. Infected Black and Hispanic patients would be more likely to be hospitalized, compared with white patients, and more likely to die.

headline: Time Won’t Let Me Wait That Long
abstract: An encounter at a clock-repair shop offered a lesson about life in 2020.
lead_paragraph: A long time ago — 100 years, give or take — a farmer dropped his pocket watch in a field in Missouri.

headline: Dear Academy: Please Give Cher Another Oscar
abstract: “Moonstruck” sustained so many of us through the pandemic. We talked to Cher about why it endures.
lead_paragraph: “Moonstruck” sustained so many of us through the pandemic. We talked to Cher about why it endures.

headline: The Two Minute Geniuses of TikTok
abstract: Comedians like Sarah Cooper, Blaire Erskine and Jeff Wright turned the short clip into a mirror — and a send up — of our pandemic anxiety.
lead_paragraph: Comedians like Sarah Cooper, Blaire Erskine and Jeff Wright turned the short clip into a mirror — and a send up — of our pandemic anxiety.

headline: Viola Davis Wants to Be Honest With You
abstract: “When you’re creating a character, the most important thing you can do is observe life.”
lead_paragraph: “When you’re creating a character, the most important thing you can do is observe life.”

headline: We’re Not Used to Seeing Women Act This Way
abstract: A new class of artists are engaged in a risky performance of self — not as elegant but as klutzy, volatile and occasionally unstable.
lead_paragraph: A new class of artists are engaged in a risky performance of self — not as elegant but as klutzy, volatile and occasionally unstable.

headline: The Best Actors of 2020
abstract: In a year of tragedy and isolation, screens were more important than ever before. These film, TV and TikTok stars gave us more than just diversion.
lead_paragraph: In a year of tragedy and isolation, screens were more important than ever before. These film, TV and TikTok stars gave us more than just diversion.

headline: How a Bar Became a Symbol of Staten Island Virus Defiance
abstract: Local protesters have come out in support of Mac's Public House, which has flouted  coronavirus restrictions for weeks.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Some Los Angeles County officials who oppose restaurant restrictions are forming their own health departments.
abstract: Until late last month, outdoor dining — no masks required — was the closest thing to pre-pandemic normal for the 10 million residents of Los Angeles County. But amid a record-busting surge in hospitalizations and cases of the coronavirus, the county’s health department recently said outdoor dining must come to a complete halt for the first time since May.
lead_paragraph: Until late last month, outdoor dining — no masks required — was the closest thing to pre-pandemic normal for the 10 million residents of Los Angeles County. But amid a record-busting surge in hospitalizations and cases of the coronavirus, the county’s health department recently said outdoor dining must come to a complete halt for the first time since May.

headline: The Beginning of the End of the Pandemic
abstract: Britain has become the first country to start administering a fully tested coronavirus shot. We were on the ground as the vaccination effort got underway.
lead_paragraph: In Britain, news that the country had become the first to start administering a fully tested coronavirus vaccine was met with hope, excitement — and some trepidation.

headline: It May Feel Like Winter, but It’s Time to Shop for Seeds
abstract: The 2021 garden season officially begins this month, with the arrival of seed catalogs. Here’s what to expect after last year’s chaotic spring.
lead_paragraph: Resilience: It’s a vegetable-seed industry buzzword, and a mission — to breed genetically resilient varieties that stand up to pests, diseases and the rigors of a shifting climate.

headline: My Pandemic Cat Had a Secret
abstract: First of all, she wasn’t a kitten …
lead_paragraph: In early May, I received a text from a close friend who lives several blocks away: “Do you want a kitten?”

headline: 2020, in 12 Photographs
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: Dean Baquet, The Times’s executive editor, believes that 2020 will go down as a signature year in history, alongside years like 1968, 1945 and 1865. “It will long be remembered and studied as a time when more than 1.5 million people globally died during a pandemic, racial unrest gripped the world, and democracy itself faced extraordinary tests,” he writes.

headline: A cruise ship returns to Singapore early after a passenger tests positive.
abstract: Update: The passenger whose positive coronavirus test forced the cruise ship to dock did not actually have the virus, officials said. He has since tested negative several times.
lead_paragraph: Update: The passenger whose positive coronavirus test forced the cruise ship to dock did not actually have the virus, officials said. He has since tested negative several times.

headline: ‘Let Them All Talk’ Review: That Ship Has Sailed
abstract: Meryl Streep plays an author trying to reconnect with college friends in Steven Soderbergh’s film.
lead_paragraph: A Pulitzer Prize-winning author, her two college buddies and her nephew walk into a cruise ship’s bar …

headline: ‘Sing Me a Song’ Review: Technology vs. the Contemplative Life
abstract: The French filmmaker Thomas Balmès follows a Bhutanese boy as he becomes a man and finds a life outside the monastery where he grew up.
lead_paragraph: Following his 2014 film “Happiness,” which profiles Peyangki, a boy in a Bhutanese monastery, director Thomas Balmès returned to make the striking new documentary, “Sing Me a Song.” Here, Peyangki is 10 years older and living in what seems like a completely different world: one changed by the internet and television. Bhutan was the last nation to adopt these technologies, and Balmès’s all-seeing eye captures the profound impact they had on Peyangki and his hometown, Laya.

headline: ‘A Dog Called Money’ Review: Lyrical Encounters With PJ Harvey
abstract: In this documentary, the musician PJ Harvey travels to Kabul, Kosovo and Washington, D.C. to find inspiration.
lead_paragraph: While making her 2016 album “The Hope Six Demolition Project,” the musician PJ Harvey did something rare: She opened her recording process to public viewing. She and her team constructed a studio in London that allowed fans of the musician, or the merely curious, to look in on Harvey and her musical collaborators as they laid down tracks.

headline: We’ve Reached ‘Safe Harbor’
abstract: The Supreme Court shoots down a Republican challenge in Pennsylvania as states pass a critical deadline.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court shoots down a Republican challenge in Pennsylvania as states pass a critical deadline. It’s Wednesday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

headline: Priorities for a Post-Pandemic World
abstract: A panel of experts debate what post-Covid policy should focus on.
lead_paragraph: In early December, we convened a number of panels with experts to discuss the most pressing issues facing business, government and society. Starting today, we’re publishing a special series of articles about these gatherings, which we call the DealBook D.C. Policy Project. We will highlight a new debate every day over the next eight days, covering climate change, Big Tech, U.S.-China relations, police reform and more.

headline: Scientists are monitoring New York’s sewers, hoping to identify coronavirus clusters.
abstract: New York City’s sewers, whose lore has spawned films, children’s books and fantastical tales of alligator infestation, have now seized a role in the pandemic: Scientists are tracking outbreaks by monitoring the smelly, gray effluent that flows through underground pipes in hopes of identifying coronavirus clusters days before they appear through patient testing.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s sewers, whose lore has spawned films, children’s books and fantastical tales of alligator infestation, have now seized a role in the pandemic: Scientists are tracking outbreaks by monitoring the smelly, gray effluent that flows through underground pipes in hopes of identifying coronavirus clusters days before they appear through patient testing.

headline: Uber rids itself of another expensive project: flying cars.
abstract: Uber is handing its flying car project, Uber Elevate, to the air taxi start-up Joby Aviation, the two companies said on Tuesday. Uber will also invest $75 million in Joby’s effort to build a flying taxi, while agreeing to become partners with the start-up when the flying car reaches the market, reports Cade Metz for The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Uber is handing its flying car project, Uber Elevate, to the air taxi start-up Joby Aviation, the two companies said on Tuesday. Uber will also invest $75 million in Joby’s effort to build a flying taxi, while agreeing to become partners with the start-up when the flying car reaches the market, reports Cade Metz for The New York Times.

headline: No, I Am Not Getting Rid of My Thousands of CDs
abstract: Our chief classical music critic writes in praise of going to a shelf, pulling out a recording and sitting down to listen.
lead_paragraph: In the late 1970s, when I was living in Boston, the record store of choice for classical music fans was the Harvard Coop. It had an extensive catalog and informed salespeople eager to offer invariably strong opinions on which albums to buy. I’d often bump into friends and fellow musicians, all of us flipping through bins of LPs. After making a purchase I’d have to squeeze yet more shelf space out of my cramped apartment, but I was pleased at my growing home library.

headline: What TikTok Taught One Stand-Up Comic
abstract: Carmen Lynch told the same joke on “The Tonight Show” and an album. It didn’t take off until she made it the subject of a goofy video posted on the platform.
lead_paragraph: In January, the stand-up comic Carmen Lynch told a joke on “The Tonight Show” about dating a man turning 50. “The other day, he came up to me and said: ‘Please live with me’” she said, hands on heart. “I said: “Please live.”

headline: Iran Claims Arrests in Killing of Top Nuclear Scientist
abstract: A parliamentary adviser told a state-run news outlet that some people he accused of involvement in the assassination last month of the scientist, Mohsen Fakhrizadeh, had been arrested.
lead_paragraph: The Iranian authorities have detained a number of people accused of involvement in the assassination of the country’s top nuclear scientist last month near Tehran, a parliamentary adviser told an Iranian state-run broadcaster on Wednesday.

headline: Biden picks Marcia Fudge for housing secretary and Tom Vilsack for agriculture secretary.
abstract: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. has selected Representative Marcia L. Fudge of Ohio to serve as the secretary of housing and urban development in his administration and Tom Vilsack for agriculture secretary, people familiar with the transition said.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. has selected Representative Marcia L. Fudge of Ohio to serve as the secretary of housing and urban development in his administration and Tom Vilsack for agriculture secretary, people familiar with the transition said.

headline: The departing and incoming presidents on Tuesday offered vastly divergent assessments of the pandemic response.
abstract: One president all but declared victory over the pandemic, hailing new vaccines as a “medical miracle” and congratulating himself for doing what “nobody has ever seen before.” The next president declared the pandemic deadlier than ever, calling it a “mass casualty” event that is leaving “a gaping hole” in America with more misery to come.
lead_paragraph: One president all but declared victory over the pandemic, hailing new vaccines as a “medical miracle” and congratulating himself for doing what “nobody has ever seen before.” The next president declared the pandemic deadlier than ever, calling it a “mass casualty” event that is leaving “a gaping hole” in America with more misery to come.

headline: Dez Bryant’s Wild Ride: A Positive Test, a Glass of Wine, a Ravens Win
abstract: After testing positive for the coronavirus, receiver Dez Bryant missed Baltimore’s game against the Dallas Cowboys. But fans were still able to follow his emotional evening in real time.
lead_paragraph: It was quite an evening for Dez Bryant.

headline: Xavier Becerra’s Move to the Biden Administration
abstract: Wednesday: A closer look at the attorney general’s ascension. Also: “Best Of” lists in 2020.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Saying Goodbye to the Trips of a Lifetime
abstract: The Warriors dynasty allowed a reporter to spend some unexpected, and extremely welcome, time with his dad.
lead_paragraph: Marc Stein is away this week.

headline: What You Get for $400,000
abstract: A two-bedroom condominium in Savannah, Ga.; a Tudor Revival house in Cincinnati; and a Craftsman-influenced home in Charles Town, W.V.
lead_paragraph: A two-bedroom condominium in Savannah, Ga.; a Tudor Revival house in Cincinnati; and a Craftsman-influenced home in Charles Town, W.V.

headline: $400,000 Homes in Georgia, Ohio and West Virginia
abstract: A two-bedroom condominium in Savannah, a Tudor Revival house in Cincinnati and a Craftsman-influenced home in Charles Town.
lead_paragraph: This ground-floor apartment was once part of a private townhouse that (along with its neighbors) has been converted into a 10-unit condominium. It is in the heart of town, surrounded by staples, services and recreations. Step off the frilly, covered front porch (shared with the upstairs unit) and turn left, and you can see Forsyth Park a block and a half away. The National Historic Landmark District is just to the north, although the Victorian District, where this property is, is pretty venerable in its own right.

headline: Video Shows West Virginia Chemical Explosion
abstract: A large explosion at a West Virginia chemical plant flung debris more than a mile away late on Tuesday. At least four people were hospitalized and residents nearby were asked to shelter in place.
lead_paragraph: A large explosion at a West Virginia chemical plant flung debris more than a mile away late on Tuesday. At least four people were hospitalized and residents nearby were asked to shelter in place.

headline: New York’s $226 Billion Pension Fund Is Dropping Fossil Fuel Stocks
abstract: The fund will divest from many fossil fuels in the next five years and sell its shares in other companies that contribute to global warming by 2040.
lead_paragraph: New York State’s pension fund, one of the world’s largest and most influential investors, will drop many of its fossil fuel stocks in the next five years and sell its shares in other companies that contribute to global warming by 2040, the state comptroller said on Wednesday.

headline: Chinese Covid-19 Vaccine Gets Key Push, but Doubts Swirl
abstract: The announcement by the United Arab Emirates that it approved a Chinese vaccine was met with silence from China, and raised more questions.
lead_paragraph: The United Arab Emirates issued the first government approval of a Chinese coronavirus vaccine on Wednesday, citing preliminary data showing that it was 86 percent effective, a move that could bring Chinese vaccines a step closer to widespread use.

headline: A Little Castle in the Sea
abstract: This circular home on the southeastern shore of Grand Cayman, in the Cayman Islands, is on the market for $3.95 million.
lead_paragraph: This circular home on the southeastern shore of Grand Cayman, in the Cayman Islands, is on the market for $3.95 million.

headline: House Hunting in the Cayman Islands: A Compact Castle in the Caribbean
abstract: Sales and volume have fallen this year, though prices are looking up, as the popular islands anxiously wait for tourists to return.
lead_paragraph: Cayman Castle, a gated and walled villa with a dollop of medieval whimsy, juts into the Caribbean Sea from the southeastern coast of Grand Cayman, the largest of the three Cayman Islands.

headline: When youth hockey is suspended, it takes with it ‘a way of life.’
abstract: In New Jersey and in many suburban towns across the Northeast, youth hockey is an all-consuming ritual of the cold weather months. Players and their families devote nights and weekends and routinely drive hundreds of miles to compete in multiday tournaments.
lead_paragraph: In New Jersey and in many suburban towns across the Northeast, youth hockey is an all-consuming ritual of the cold weather months. Players and their families devote nights and weekends and routinely drive hundreds of miles to compete in multiday tournaments.

headline: New Trump Rule Aims to Limit Tough Clean Air Measures Under Biden
abstract: The E.P.A. rule, which changes the way cost-benefit analyses are used, would make it easier for fossil fuel companies to fight regulations in court.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration on Wednesday completed a rule that could weaken federal authority to issue clean air and climate change rules by changing the way the costs of pollution to human health and safety are tallied — and the way benefits of controlling that pollution are tabulated.

headline: Getting Everyone Vaccinated, With ‘Nudges’ and Charity Auctions
abstract: A Nobel laureate proposes selling a small proportion of early doses to the rich and famous, and rewarding reluctant recipients to accelerate herd immunity.
lead_paragraph: The good news is that safe and effective vaccines from Moderna and Pfizer appear to be on the way soon and that more are likely to follow.

headline: Top Mayoral Candidate’s Struggle: Should He Send His Sons Back to School?
abstract: If Scott Stringer wins the race next year, his experience as a parent is likely to inform how he guides New York’s public schools out of crisis.
lead_paragraph: When Mayor Bill de Blasio reopened elementary schools this week, many New York City parents who had been keeping their children home were offered a last chance to send them back into classrooms this school year.

headline: Will Art Lovers Open Their Wallets for Online Tours?
abstract: Two London museums have started charging to experience their shows on the internet.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Since the National Gallery’s blockbuster “Artemisia” exhibition opened in October, art lovers have had to jump through hoops to see it.

headline: Tone Is Hard to Grasp Online. Can Tone Indicators Help?
abstract: We all struggle to communicate on the internet. Now, young people are leading a sincere effort to clear things up.
lead_paragraph: Written language is an imperfect method for the messy, complex business of communication, where facial expressions, gestures and vocal tones transmit oceans of meaning and subtext — for those, at least, who can read them.

headline: The Best Sweet-Savory Kugel
abstract: A Yerushalmi kugel, which Melissa Clark learned to cook from the cookbook author Adeena Sussman, is sure to hit both notes.
lead_paragraph: Hannukah begins on Thursday, and for some of those celebrating, there’ll be kugel on the table for sure. Sweet or savory? How about both? Melissa Clark wrote for us this week about Yerushalmi kugel (above), a peppery sweet-savory kugel that’s a specialty of Jerusalem, and which she learned to cook from Adeena Sussman, author of “Sababa: Fresh, Sunny Flavors From My Israeli Kitchen.” Pair it with a roast chicken and a pile of greens, and that’s a blessing in itself.

headline: Just how full are U.S. intensive care units? New data paints an alarming picture.
abstract: At the five-hospital Tanner Health System west of Atlanta, the first emails about capacity land in the inboxes of Dr. Benjamin Camp, the chief medical officer, and Deborah Matthews, the chief nursing officer, at about 6:30 a.m. each day. Then the juggling starts.
lead_paragraph: At the five-hospital Tanner Health System west of Atlanta, the first emails about capacity land in the inboxes of Dr. Benjamin Camp, the chief medical officer, and Deborah Matthews, the chief nursing officer, at about 6:30 a.m. each day. Then the juggling starts.

headline: He broke out of quarantine for 8 seconds, and it cost him a $3,550 fine.
abstract: One man left the house after an argument with his wife and walked 280 miles to cool off, breaching Italy’s national curfew.
lead_paragraph: One man left the house after an argument with his wife and walked 280 miles to cool off, breaching Italy’s national curfew.

headline: Boris Johnson Fails to Break Brexit Deadlock in Brussels Talks
abstract: Hopes for a trade pact hinged on his meeting with Ursula von der Leyen, the president of the European Commission. But an agreement remains elusive.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain and the European Union on Wednesday failed to break the deadlock in critical negotiations about a post-Brexit trade deal and, with wide divisions remaining between them, set a new deadline for Sunday to reach a decision on the future of the talks.

headline: Lockdown Gardening in Britain Leads to Archaeological Discoveries
abstract: The finds this year, including a cache of gold coins from the reign of Henry VIII, come as Britain considers expanding the law to protect a broader range of artifacts from its centuries-old history.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Gardeners in Hampshire, a county in southeast England, were weeding their yard in April when they found 63 gold coins and one silver coin from King Henry VIII’s reign in the 16th century, with four of the coins inscribed with the initials of the king’s wives Catherine of Aragon, Anne Boleyn and Jane Seymour.

headline: More Men Reach for Sewing Machines
abstract: A long-neglected home art is reclaimed during the pandemic, including by some eager to break gender stereotypes.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in foster homes, Norris Dánta Ford, a fashion designer, cleverly used clothes to impress his future parents, dressing himself and his sister up in multiple outfits to show how stylish they were. Realizing the confidence that can come from clothes, Mr. Ford, 34, built a career as a stylist, working with celebrities including Prince and Matthew McConaughey, before realizing the creative potential in making his own garments. Now a men's wear pattern designer and online sewing teacher in Atlanta, he is at the forefront of a new and growing movement of men embracing home sewing.

headline: Carnegie Hall Stands By Its Chairman, Despite Tax Violations
abstract: Robert F. Smith has acknowledged his involvement in a 15-year scheme to hide more than $200 million in income and evade taxes, but he retains the support of the hall’s board.
lead_paragraph: When Robert F. Smith, the billionaire philanthropist, became the new chairman of Carnegie Hall in 2016, he seemed almost too good to be true.

headline: Explosion Like a ‘Bomb’ Kills One and Injures Two at West Virginia Chemical Plant
abstract: The explosion in Belle sent shrapnel flying across a river, and as a precaution, officials told residents to shelter in place, closed a highway and shut down nearby schools.
lead_paragraph: A large explosion at a West Virginia chemical plant killed one person and injured at least two others late Tuesday night, throwing debris more than a mile away and forcing a nearby highway and some schools to close, officials said.

headline: ‘On Social Media, There Are Thousands’: In Cuba, Internet Fuels Rare Protests
abstract: Artists gathered by the hundreds in Cuba’s largest protest in decades after seeing videos of police detentions that were filmed on cellphones and circulated online.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA — In another era, the detention of a young Cuban dissident may have gone completely unnoticed. But when the rapper Denis Solís was arrested by the police, he did something that has only recently become possible on the island: He filmed the encounter on his cellphone and streamed it live on Facebook.

headline: Pantone Picks Two Colors of the Year for 2021
abstract: It’s all about the messaging. Get ready for a brighter future.
lead_paragraph: There is general agreement on very little in this world, save, perhaps, for one thing: This year has been a mess, and the next one cannot come fast enough.

headline: U.S. Takes Tougher Tone With Turkey as Trump Exits
abstract: Officials said President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. must keep from alienating the government in Ankara even as the U.S. and European allies try to curb Turkey’s military ambitions with sanctions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — No longer restrained by President Trump’s affection for Turkey’s authoritarian leader, U.S. officials and Congress are using the waning days of his presidency to ready sanctions and strike a strident tone against the strategic but unreliable ally.

headline: How to Clean Your Office Chair
abstract: Your office chair can become a hotbed of germs and allergens. Here’s how to keep it like new.
lead_paragraph: Your office chair can become a hotbed of germs and allergens. Here’s how to keep it like new.

headline: Pandemic Closures Devastate Restaurant Industry’s Middle Class
abstract: A sous-chef’s search for job security shows how cooks, managers and servers at upscale dining establishments have been hit hard by the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: On the day in September when he was hired as a cook at Fulton Market Kitchen — a restaurant in Chicago featuring shrimp and grits and miso-glazed halibut — Jeff Danaher asked the chef about his plans for the winter.

headline: Twitch Cracks Down on Hate Speech and Harassment
abstract: The livestreaming site announced new guidelines after contending with claims that its streamers were too easily abused.
lead_paragraph: Twitch, the livestreaming platform popular among video game players, unveiled new guidelines on Wednesday aimed at cracking down on hateful conduct and sexual harassment on its site.

headline: Holidays in a Pandemic? Here’s What Happened in 1918
abstract: The festive season fell between two deadly waves of the deadly influenza outbreak. Families still gathered, often with empty chairs at the table.
lead_paragraph: Not long before Christmas, as the pandemic was taking a devastating toll in rural Iowa, Rebecca Tinti was visiting some neighbors who had fallen ill.

headline: You Should Have Listened, New York Tells Big Oil
abstract: The comptroller’s threat to pull billions from fossil fuel investments is a big victory for climate activists.
lead_paragraph: New York State’s comptroller, Thomas DiNapoli, announced on Wednesday that the state would begin divesting its $226 billion employee pension fund from gas and oil companies if they can’t come up with a legitimate business plan within four years that is aligned with the goals of the Paris climate accord. Those investments have historically added up to roughly $12 billion.

headline: Our Delivery System Is Breaking
abstract: With the holidays coming and the pandemic raging, we’re shopping online a ton. It’s chaos.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: YouTube is forbidding videos claiming widespread election fraud.
abstract: The company said that it was making the change because the deadline for recounts and audits of the election had passed.
lead_paragraph: YouTube on Wednesday announced changes to how it handles videos about the 2020 presidential election, saying it would remove new videos that mislead people by claiming that widespread fraud or errors influenced the outcome of the election.

headline: Report Provides a Preview of the ‘New Arctic’
abstract: Also this week, five climate reporters recommend books they’ve enjoyed.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Climate Fwd: newsletter. The New York Times climate team emails readers once a week with stories and insights about climate change. Sign up here to get it in your inbox. (And find the website version of this week’s letter here.)

headline: The Best Albums of 2020? Let’s Discuss
abstract: An absence of live music refocused attention on records, and work by Fiona Apple, Taylor Swift and Run the Jewels spoke loudly.
lead_paragraph: In the absence of live music this year, there was renewed focus on that old standby, the recorded album. It turns out that the album is an ideal format for the era of coronavirus quarantine — a longform project you can lose yourself in.

headline: She Was Stranded in Canada. A Stranger Drove Her 1,000 Miles to Alaska.
abstract: Lynn Marchessault was driving her children and pets from Georgia to Alaska when she got stuck in whiteout conditions in British Columbia. Gary Bath, a Canadian veteran, came to the rescue.
lead_paragraph: By her own admission, Lynn Marchessault was not prepared for the odyssey she embarked on last month.

headline: ‘Small Town, No Hospital’: Covid-19 Is Overwhelming Rural West Texas
abstract: As cases soar in Texas, hospitals are filling up from El Paso to Lubbock. The Big Bend region is especially vulnerable, with just one hospital for 12,000 square miles.
lead_paragraph: ALPINE, Texas — It is one of the fastest-growing coronavirus hot spots in the nation, but there are no long lines of cars piled up for drive-through testing and no rush of appointments to get swabbed at CVS.

headline: DoorDash Soars in First Day of Trading
abstract: The delivery company’s shares closed at $190 each, 86 percent above its initial public offering price of $102, in a sign of investor appetite.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Wall Street loves a pandemic winner.

headline: The Chicago Teachers Union Plays Hardball
abstract: An injunction could stop or delay the city’s reopening plans.
lead_paragraph: Chicago’s school reopening plan is hanging in limbo after the city’s teachers’ union filed an injunction that could delay a return to in-person learning.

headline: Futura, a King of Graffiti, Returns to His Roots
abstract: The artist has gone from painting subway cars to the runways of Comme des Garçons. After a hiatus, his two exhibitions are his first in his hometown in 30 years.
lead_paragraph: The week before he turned 65, Futura was contemplating his legacy. Considered one of the progenitors of graffiti art, and one of its most recognizable figures, he was sitting in Eric Firestone Gallery in NoHo, where “Futura 2020,” his first solo exhibition in New York in 30 years, is on view. Across the river, in Queens, his installation at the Noguchi Museum, a suite of hand-painted Akari lanterns, had opened the day before. Futura, who is rangy and was wearing a wool knit cap pulled to just above his eyes and a jacket from his recent collection with Comme des Garçons, was discussing the long arc of his career, one that has taken him from painting in unlit subway tunnels to working for the United States Postal Service to being a frequent presence in the global luxury fashion market.

headline: Terry McAuliffe Faces All-Black Democratic Primary in Virginia Governor’s Race
abstract: Mr. McAuliffe, who was governor from 2014 to 2018, says he wants to take “Virginia to the next level and to lift up all Virginians.”
lead_paragraph: Terry McAuliffe, the former governor of Virginia, on Wednesday entered the contest for his old job, simultaneously offering himself as both a trusted steward during an economic and public health crisis and someone prepared to fight against “the old way of doing things.”

headline: A Year of Radical Political Imagination
abstract: Mass protest movements changed the world’s attitude toward social justice.
lead_paragraph: This is an article from Turning Points, a special section that explores what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead.

headline: ‘Six’ Tries to Get Back Onstage. Again, and Again, and Again.
abstract: For nine months, the hit musical about the wives of Henry VIII has tried to keep the show going. But that’s not easy in a pandemic.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — At 3:15 p.m. on Dec. 5, a line of theater fans stretched outside the Lyric in London's West End, all desperate to see the return of “Six,” the hit musical about Henry VIII’s wives.

headline: Why Can’t Some Take Covid Seriously?
abstract: Readers call for unsparing news coverage of the illness’s severity.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Johns Hopkins Reveals That Its Founder Owned Slaves
abstract: The university and its medical system have long celebrated their founding benefactor as a staunch abolitionist. But newly surfaced documents tell a different story.
lead_paragraph: It’s a tale that has long been repeated at the university and medical center in Baltimore that bear his name: In 1807, the 12-year-old Johns Hopkins was summoned home from boarding school to work the fields of the family’s sprawling tobacco farm in Maryland after his father, following the directives of his Quaker faith, freed the family’s slaves.

headline: Guido Goldman, a U.S. Bridge to Germany, Dies at 83
abstract: A Kissinger protégé (and a pre-eminent textile art collector), his fingerprints can be found on many of the leading postwar institutions linking the two allies.
lead_paragraph: Guido Goldman, a renaissance man who used his vast wealth and extensive network of friendships in politics and the arts, from Henry A. Kissinger to Harry Belafonte, to help rebuild America’s relationship with Germany after World War II, died on Nov. 30 at his home in Concord, Mass. He was 83.

headline: Name One Good Thing About 2020
abstract: We invite readers to think of something positive about a dismal year.
lead_paragraph: Dear readers: Without discussing politics, name one good thing about 2020.

headline: For Canadians Held in China, Two Years of Isolation and Uncertainty
abstract: The fates of Michael Kovrig and Michael Spavor appear tied to a Chinese technology executive detained in Canada on a U.S. warrant. Some hope the new Biden administration could hasten their release.
lead_paragraph: For two years, the Canadian men have been held in separate prisons in northern China, largely cut off from the rest of the world. They have been accused of espionage, without evidence, and forced to go months without visits from diplomats. They have waited as their cases have meandered through China’s opaque legal system, despite calls around the world for their release.

headline: Menaced by Murder Hornets, Bees Decorate Their Hives With Feces
abstract: Asian honeybees have exhibited what scientists call a form of tool use to deter attacks by giant predatory wasps.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to the hunt, giant hornets in the genus Vespa do not mess around.

headline: Casey Goodson Died From Multiple Gunshot Wounds, Coroner Says
abstract: Mr. Goodson, of Columbus, Ohio, was shot several times in the torso, the coroner said. He was shot by a member of a fugitive task force who the authorities said was searching for someone else.
lead_paragraph: A man who was shot dead outside his home in Columbus, Ohio, by a sheriff’s deputy last week died from multiple gunshot wounds to his torso, according to the Franklin County Coroner’s Office, which said Wednesday that his death had been ruled a homicide.

headline: Planned Execution Stirs Debate Over Punishment for Young Offenders
abstract: Brandon Bernard was 18 when he took part in the grisly murders of two youth ministers. He is scheduled to be put to death on Thursday despite a drive among his supporters for clemency.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Brandon Bernard, then 18, joined a haphazard robbery plot in June 1999 that resulted in two grisly murders, a jury found in his federal trial.

headline: Canada Approves Vaccine and Could Start Shots Next Week
abstract: Canada approved the same coronavirus inoculation codeveloped by Pfizer that Britain authorized last week, and that American regulators will consider on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Canada on Wednesday become only the second Western country to approve a coronavirus vaccine, a week after Britain did so and a day before U.S. regulators will meet to consider taking that step, opening the possibility that Canadians will start being inoculated next week.

headline: With These Experiences for Kids, All the Living Room’s a Stage
abstract: Theatermakers are devising new, immersive ways to engage children, with a few sending boxes of props and set pieces to your home.
lead_paragraph: Back in March, when New York’s governor abruptly ordered Broadway theaters to shut their narrow lobby doors, many of us thought they would soon open again — in April or July, surely by January. I remember kidding a friend, via text, about it: “If not, I’ll just make the kids do ‘Hamlet.’” Careful what you joke about.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: The U.A.E. gives China’s vaccine a vote of confidence.
lead_paragraph: The United Arab Emirates said on Wednesday that it had approved a Chinese coronavirus vaccine after preliminary data showed that it was 86 percent effective. It is the first government to grant approval to the vaccine developed by Sinopharm, a state-owned vaccine maker.

headline: A Former General as Biden’s Defense Secretary
abstract: One reader urges civilian leadership of the Pentagon, while another praises the honesty of Gen. Lloyd Austin. Also: Empathy and the virus; postponed travel; the shelf life of movie theaters.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. and States Say Facebook Illegally Crushed Competition
abstract: Regulators are accusing the company of buying up rising rivals to cement its dominance over social media.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Trade Commission and more than 40 states accused Facebook on Wednesday of buying up its rivals to illegally squash competition, and they called for the deals to be unwound, escalating regulators’ battle against the biggest tech companies in a way that could remake the social media industry.

headline: France Takes On Islamist Extremism With New Bill
abstract: The French government says draft legislation aimed at combating the extremist ideology that has taken many lives on French soil in recent years is a “law of freedom” necessary for peaceful coexistence.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French government, determined to combat an ideology it views as “the enemy of the Republic,” on Wednesday unveiled draft legislation to combat radical Islamism, calling the measure “a law of freedom” essential to peaceful coexistence in French society.

headline: The U.K. says people with severe allergies should not take the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine while two reactions are under investigation.
abstract: Thousands of Britons received the first clinically authorized, fully tested coronavirus vaccine on Tuesday, with people reporting minimal side effects.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of Britons received the first clinically authorized, fully tested coronavirus vaccine on Tuesday, with people reporting minimal side effects.

headline: Britain’s Ports Are Jammed, and Brexit Is Around the Corner
abstract: Honda’s plant in England was forced to halt operations because its parts hadn’t arrived. Soon U.K. ports will face a mountain of customs declarations.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — With just 23 days until Britain’s exit from the European Union truly begins, the country got a taste of the havoc that trade disruption could bring. Honda shut down production on Wednesday at its biggest plant in Europe, where more than 3,000 people assemble Civics, showcasing the severity of the congestion and delays that have gripped Britain’s ports.

headline: Red Cross Visit to Guantánamo Limited by Virus Measures
abstract: Delegates from the International Committee of the Red Cross quarantined for two weeks but then encountered health protections that made it difficult to communicate with detainees.
lead_paragraph: This article was produced in partnership with the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting.

headline: Fleeing Ethiopians Tell of Ethnic Massacres in Tigray War
abstract: Tens of thousands have sought safety in Sudan, where they gave accounts to Times journalists of a devastating and complex conflict that threatens Ethiopia’s stability.
lead_paragraph: HAMDAYET, Sudan — The armed men who stopped Ashenafi Hailu along the dirt road dragged him by a noose so they could save bullets.

headline: Read Riley McCusker’s Lawsuit
abstract: The gymnast has accused her coach Maggie Haney of forcing her to train with injuries. Haney has denied those accusations.
lead_paragraph: The gymnast has accused her coach Maggie Haney of forcing her to train with injuries. Haney has denied those accusations.

headline: Suspension Reduced for Gymnastics Coach Accused of Emotional and Physical Abuse
abstract: An arbitrator hearing an appeal from Maggie Haney, who has coached an Olympian and other top athletes, decided some of the testimony against her was improperly used.
lead_paragraph: A top gymnastics coach accused of berating and mistreating athletes will be barred from the sport for five years instead of eight, after an arbitrator found some of the testimony that led to her suspension should not have been allowed.

headline: 5 Art Gallery Shows to See Right Now
abstract: Thornton Dial’s “Flying Tiger,” Thomas Eggerer’s protest painting, Harriet Korman’s brilliant canvases, Sheida Soleimani’s portraits of Iranian-U.S. relations, and Etel Adnan’s tapestries.
lead_paragraph: The great self-taught artist Thornton Dial (1928-2016) made his tough relief-like paintings out of nearly any detritus that came his way, including rope rugs, wire screen and scraps of wood and fabric. His roiling works convey the hardship and creativity of Black life in the South while also responding sardonically to modernist painting’s fixations with all-overness and flatness. There is a certain tension between what Mr. Dial used and how.

headline: The Hidden ‘Fourth Wave’ of the Pandemic
abstract: America hasn’t begun to face this year’s mental health crisis.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Winter’s Arrival, and the Promise of Spring
abstract: A mysterious bag of birdseed.
lead_paragraph: Welcome. Yesterday I received a parcel in the mail containing a four-pound bag of deluxe birdseed. No receipt, no note, a plain brown box containing only a sack of sunflower-and-safflower mix. I thought it must have originated with my friend Kate Wong, a science writer who’s recently taken up bird-watching. I thrill to her Instagram, where she chronicles her new at-home hobby, a hobby that finds meaning and delight in the changing seasons, in nine months and counting of limited human contact. But Kate didn’t send it.

headline: Childhood Without Other Children: A Generation Is Raised in Quarantine
abstract: Covid-19 has meant the youngest children can’t go to birthday parties or play dates. Parents are keeping them out of day care. What is the long-term effect of the pandemic on our next generation?
lead_paragraph: Alice McGraw, 2 years old, was walking with her parents in Lake Tahoe this summer when another family appeared, heading in their direction. The little girl stopped.

headline: Modern Love Podcast: With the Help of Strangers
abstract: Two women find allies to survive difficult times.
lead_paragraph: [New York Times subscribers are invited to join the hosts Daniel Jones and Miya Lee on Dec. 15 for an evening of performances and special guests, celebrating the new “Tiny Love Stories” book. RSVP here.]

headline: Earth Is Still Sailing Into Climate Chaos, Report Says, but Its Course Could Shift
abstract: The biggest polluters are continuing to pollute, raising the risks of global warming. There are, however, new signs of a pivot to a green economy.
lead_paragraph: The world as a whole is dangerously behind schedule in slowing catastrophic climate change, and its richest people will have to make big changes in their everyday lives in order to shift course, a major United Nations report warned Wednesday.

headline: TikTok ‘Ratatouille’ Musical to Be Presented as Benefit Performance
abstract: Cobbled together from songs and scenes inspired by the Disney-Pixar movie, the online performance will benefit the Actors Fund.
lead_paragraph: With Broadway houses and performance venues across the country closed because of the pandemic, musical theater lovers burned off pent-up creative energy on TikTok this year, creating songs, dances and even set designs for a hypothetical musical version of the 2007 Disney-Pixar movie “Ratatouille.”

headline: Lorraine Millar, Resilient in the Face of Tragedy, Dies at 95
abstract: Ms. Millar persevered through a series of deaths in her family, succeeding in multiple careers and finding joy in life. She died of Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Google Chief Apologizes for A.I. Researcher’s Dismissal
abstract: The researcher, one of the company’s best-known Black female employees, said she was fired last week.
lead_paragraph: Sundar Pichai, chief executive of Google’s parent company Alphabet, apologized for the departure of a prominent artificial intelligence researcher, whose exit has roiled the company’s work force and raised questions about its stated commitment to diversity and the responsible development of A.I. technology.

headline: N.Y. Attorney General Asks Courts to Take Action Against Facebook
abstract: Attorney General Letitia James of New York, who led the multistate investigation into Facebook, called for the courts on Wednesday to stop the company from its “anti-competitive” behavior to protect small businesses.
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Letitia James of New York, who led the multistate investigation into Facebook, called for the courts on Wednesday to stop the company from its “anti-competitive” behavior to protect small businesses.

headline: A ‘Godfather’ Guide: How Francis Ford Coppola’s Trilogy Has Evolved
abstract: The newly re-edited version of “Part III” is the latest in a string of editions of the sprawling Corleone tale. Here’s a primer.
lead_paragraph: The director Francis Ford Coppola is releasing his reimagined version of “Part III” of the “Godfather” saga this month, now called “Mario Puzo’s The Godfather, Coda: The Death of Michael Corleone.” It’s hardly the first time he’s returned to the iconic series. From the 1972 drama that started it all to sequels and restorations, Coppola and audiences alike couldn’t help but revisit the trials and tribulations of the Corleones as the years unfolded. Here’s a guide to the films and their different cuts:

headline: The 100-Year Dispute for Jim Thorpe’s Olympic Golds
