abstract: Thorpe was stripped of his medals in 1912, and named co-champion in 1982. Now, a movement has been renewed to award Thorpe his titles as his own.
lead_paragraph: It is almost universally viewed today as one of the great sports injustices: Jim Thorpe, the world’s greatest athlete at the time, was stripped of his Olympic decathlon and pentathlon gold medals from 1912 after it was discovered he had earned a few dollars playing baseball.

headline: ‘Heroes of the Future’: NASA Picks 18 Astronauts for Moon Mission Training
abstract: Among the group are astronauts who could be the first woman on the moon.
lead_paragraph: NASA on Wednesday introduced the group of astronauts it has chosen for upcoming missions to the moon.

headline: Jill Biden Is a Teacher. And She’s Not About to Change That.
abstract: In choosing to continue teaching at a community college, Dr. Biden is breaking with precedent and modernizing the persistently anachronistic first lady role.
lead_paragraph: — Katherine Jellison, history professor at Ohio University

headline: Big Ten Changes Rules to Let Ohio State Play for Conference Championship
abstract: The shift is yet another example of college football changing its rules on the fly during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The Big Ten, faced with the possibility of being shut out of the College Football Playoff — and the $6 million plus payday that comes with it — rewrote its rules on Wednesday so that Ohio State could be placed in its conference championship game despite playing just five games this season.

headline: Our 28 Best Christmas Cookies
abstract: We put together a list of our favorite holiday treats, including peanut butter blossoms, rugelach and frosted sugar cookies.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a year. Let’s bake some cookies. Make a single batch just for yourself or whip up several and (safely) share them with friends and family. Here are 28 of our most-loved Christmas cookie recipes.

headline: Legacy on the Line, Mnuchin Gambles by Ending Fed Programs
abstract: Steven Mnuchin, the Treasury secretary, has clawed back billions from the Federal Reserve, a move Democrats call political but he says is prudent.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In his third floor office in the Treasury Department, Steven Mnuchin, the Treasury secretary, keeps for posterity a stack of documents that he signed in March authorizing the Federal Reserve’s emergency lending programs as the pandemic roiled financial markets.

headline: U.S. says it will bring first dispute under new trade agreement with Canada, over milk.
abstract: The Trump administration announced Wednesday that it was filing a challenge to measures that Canada uses to protect its dairy market, the first enforcement action taken under a new trade agreement that the countries agreed to last year.
lead_paragraph: The Trump administration announced Wednesday that it was filing a challenge to measures that Canada uses to protect its dairy market, the first enforcement action taken under a new trade agreement that the countries agreed to last year.

headline: In wary communities, children are left without playmates and parents are concerned.
abstract: Alice McGraw, 2 years old, was walking with her parents in Lake Tahoe this summer when another family appeared, heading in their direction. The little girl stopped.
lead_paragraph: Alice McGraw, 2 years old, was walking with her parents in Lake Tahoe this summer when another family appeared, heading in their direction. The little girl stopped.

headline: Biden Picks Katherine Tai as Trade Representative
abstract: Ms. Tai, a chief trade lawyer in the House, has extensive experience with China and played a key role in hammering out the new North American Free Trade Agreement.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. is expected to select Katherine Tai, the chief trade lawyer for the House Ways and Means Committee, as the United States trade representative, a key post that will bear responsibility for enforcing America’s trade rules and negotiating new trading terms with China and other countries, according to people familiar with the plans.

headline: Disney to Reveal Plans to Turbocharge Streaming Offerings
abstract: Some big-budget movies will first go to theaters. Other offerings will debut online. All will ultimately strengthen Disney+.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A significant expansion of the “Star Wars” universe. Tom Hanks as Geppetto in a live-action “Pinocchio,” and Yara Shahidi as Tinker Bell in a live-action “Peter Pan & Wendy.” Footage from new Marvel projects. A star-studded prequel to “The Lion King.”

headline: ‘Is Austin on Your List?’: Biden’s Pentagon Pick Rose Despite Barriers to Diversity
abstract: With retired Gen. Lloyd J. Austin III’s nomination to be the first Black defense secretary, the Pentagon comes face to face with its record as a place where people of color struggle to climb.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Retired Gen. Lloyd J. Austin III, who is on the brink of becoming the first Black man to be secretary of defense, rose to the heights of an American military whose largely white leadership has not reflected the diversity of its rank and file.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: Many Americans live in areas where hospitals are running critically short of intensive care beds.
lead_paragraph: The federal government published detailed information on hospitalized Covid-19 patients for the first time. The data, seen in the map above, showed that many Americans live in areas where hospitals are running critically short of intensive care beds.

headline: Sara Leland, Ballerina of Passion and Abandon, Dies at 79
abstract: She was a favorite of George Balanchine at New York City Ballet and staged his ballets worldwide even during her performing career.
lead_paragraph: Sara Leland, a principal dancer with New York City Ballet who was entrusted with staging George Balanchine’s ballets worldwide even during her performing career, and who went on to become a beloved ballet master with the company, died on Nov. 28 in Westwood, N.J. She was 79.

headline: Facebook, Pfizer, Pantone: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Supreme Court Weighs President’s Power to Fire Head of Housing Agency
abstract: The case was brought by shareholders of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, who say the law that created the agency was unconstitutional and that they are owed billions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court heard arguments on Wednesday in a dispute between shareholders of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the government-sponsored mortgage finance giants, and the Treasury Department over $124 billion in payments the two lenders were required to make to the government.

headline: Watch SpaceX’s Starship Launch and Explode in Crash Landing
abstract: The company described the test of the next-generation spacecraft as “awesome” even though it ended in a fiery blast.
lead_paragraph: A test of a prototype of a rocket that Elon Musk has dreams of sending people to Mars in flew several miles high on Wednesday. But in attempting to land, it hit the ground too fast and exploded.

headline: Ray Perkins, Coach at Alabama and in the N.F.L., Dies at 79
abstract: With the Crimson Tide, he had a tough act to follow, Bear Bryant, but he enjoyed some success. He didn’t fare so well with the Giants and the Buccaneers.
lead_paragraph: Ray Perkins, who spent nearly four decades as a college and N.F.L. coach and was best known for succeeding Paul “Bear” Bryant at the University of Alabama, his alma mater, died on Wednesday at his home in Tuscaloosa, Ala. He was 79.

headline: The U.S. will initially hold back half the first vaccine supply.
abstract: A top federal vaccine official said Wednesday that 2.9 million doses of Pfizer’s Covid-19 vaccine will be shipped around the country in the first week after it is authorized by the Food and Drug Administration — half of the initial shipment from Pfizer.
lead_paragraph: A top federal vaccine official said Wednesday that 2.9 million doses of Pfizer’s Covid-19 vaccine will be shipped around the country in the first week after it is authorized by the Food and Drug Administration — half of the initial shipment from Pfizer.

headline: Arnie Robinson Jr., Olympic Long Jump Champion, Dies at 72
abstract: Mr. Robinson won the gold medal at the 1976 Summer Olympics in Montreal and a bronze medal in Munich in 1972.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: SpaceX Starship Explodes During Test Flight
abstract: During Wednesday’s test flight of the SpaceX Starship prototype, a rocket Elon Musk envisions ferrying humans to Mars, it launched into the sky but glided back to Earth before it exploded while attempting to land.
lead_paragraph: During Wednesday’s test flight of the SpaceX Starship prototype, a rocket Elon Musk envisions ferrying humans to Mars, it launched into the sky but glided back to Earth before it exploded while attempting to land.

headline: Spain’s Juan Carlos Makes a Big Tax Payment Amid New Financial Probe
abstract: The former king of Spain paid about $820,000, his lawyer said. He did not say why, but the news came amid the latest investigation into possible financial wrongdoing by Juan Carlos.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — King Juan Carlos, Spain’s former monarch, has paid about $820,000 in back taxes, his lawyer said on Wednesday, amid an investigation by prosecutors into whether he and other members of the royal family used bank accounts in other people’s names to hide assets from the tax authorities

headline: Canada Approves Pfizer-BioNTech Coronavirus Vaccine
abstract: After completing an independent review, Health Canada, the country’s drug regulator, announced on Wednesday that it had approved the coronavirus vaccine made by Pfizer and BioNTech and that shots could start being given as early as next week.
lead_paragraph: After completing an independent review, Health Canada, the country’s drug regulator, announced on Wednesday that it had approved the coronavirus vaccine made by Pfizer and BioNTech and that shots could start being given as early as next week.

headline: An Uplifting Update, on the Terrible World of Pornhub
abstract: Young heroes lead in confronting pornography companies that monetize rape and child abuse.
lead_paragraph: We all need uplift this terrible year, so here’s inspiring news about some young heroes and the good they’ve achieved on a wrenching topic.

headline: Can Israelis Put Two Landers on the Moon at Once?
abstract: Although the Beresheet lunar landing ended in a crash last year,  SpaceIL wants to try again with a more complex mission by 2024.
lead_paragraph: An Israeli nonprofit will try again to land a robotic spacecraft on the moon after its first attempt ended in a crash last year.

headline: General Electric will pay $200 million to settle claims it misled investors.
abstract: General Electric will pay $200 million to settle charges that it failed to disclose important information to investors in its power and insurance businesses, the Securities and Exchange Commission said Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: General Electric will pay $200 million to settle charges that it failed to disclose important information to investors in its power and insurance businesses, the Securities and Exchange Commission said Wednesday.

headline: Trump and Friends Got Coronavirus Care Many Others Couldn’t
abstract: Rudolph W. Giuliani became the latest in President Trump’s inner circle to boast about the treatment he received for Covid-19, as hospitals across the country ration care.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ben Carson, Chris Christie and Donald J. Trump are not the sturdiest candidates to conquer the coronavirus: older, in some cases overweight, male and not particularly fit. Yet all seem to have gotten through Covid-19, and all have gotten an antibody treatment in such short supply that some hospitals and states are doling it out by lottery.

headline: House Approves One-Week Funding Extension as Stimulus Talks Continue
abstract: Congress moved to buy an additional week for a deal on pandemic aid and a broader agreement to fund the government, but there was little sign of progress on the stimulus plan.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congressional leaders moved on Wednesday to buy more time to strike an elusive deal on an economic relief measure to address the ruin wrought by the pandemic, but with time running short, it was unclear whether a compromise would pass.

headline: The Coronavirus Vaccines Were Developed in Record Speed. Now, the Hard Part.
abstract: Don’t squander this opportunity, America.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration is expected to grant emergency use authorizations to the first two coronavirus vaccines in the next several days. The sheer speed with which doctors and scientists were able to reach this stage is a major achievement, and the early results for both vaccines are undeniably impressive. New vaccines normally take years to develop, and scientists initially worried.

headline: Militia Leader Is Convicted in Bombing of a Minnesota Mosque
abstract: Prosecutors said Michael Hari had helped to bomb the Dar Al Farooq Islamic Center in Bloomington in 2017 to try to terrorize Muslims and scare them into leaving the country.
lead_paragraph: A militia group leader who wanted to drive Muslims out of the United States was convicted on Wednesday of helping to bomb a Minnesota mosque in 2017, just as congregants began to gather for prayers, prosecutors said.

headline: ‘Welcome to Texas!’: Musk’s California Departure Stokes the States’ Rivalry
abstract: Several companies have followed the same path to Texas, which has aggressively advertised lower taxes and fewer regulations.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Long before Elon Musk, the Tesla magnate and billionaire Californian, announced that he was moving to Texas, Marie Bailey, a California transplant now living north of Dallas, fastened a customized license plate onto her very own Tesla, with a message that has become her ethos.

headline: Team of Rivals? Biden’s Cabinet Looks More Like a Team of Buddies
abstract: In making his picks for the new administration, the president-elect has put a premium on personal relationships.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. has worked with the former aide he wants to be secretary of state since their time at the Senate Foreign Relations Committee in the 1990s. His nominee for agriculture secretary endorsed his first presidential bid more than 30 years ago. And he knows his choice for Pentagon chief from the retired general’s time in Iraq, where Mr. Biden’s son Beau, a military lawyer, also served on the general’s staff.

headline: Airbnb prices I.P.O. at $68 a share, for a $47 billion valuation.
abstract: The move, which is the second time the home-rental company raised its offering price, would value Airbnb for as much as $42 billion.
lead_paragraph: Airbnb priced its initial public offering on Wednesday at $68 a share, selling 51.5 million shares for $3.5 billion and valuing the home rental company at $47 billion. It is the largest I.P.O. of the year.It was a far higher price than the company had originally set, indicating investor demand for the stock. Airbnb had initially put its price range at $44 to $50 a share, and on Monday it had raised that to $56 to $60 each.

headline: Hunter Biden Discloses He Is Focus of Federal Tax Inquiry
abstract: Mr. Biden said Justice Department prosecutors in Delaware had said they were examining his “tax affairs.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department is investigating the tax affairs of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s son Hunter, he disclosed in a statement on Wednesday.

headline: Senate Rejects Attempted Blockade of Weapons Sale to U.A.E.
abstract: The Senate endorsed the Trump administration’s last-minute push to sell a $23 billion arms package including armed drones and stealth fighter jets to the Emirati military.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Wednesday rejected efforts to block the sale of munitions worth $23 billion to the United Arab Emirates, overcoming concerns about sending weapons to Gulf Arab nations.

headline: 17 Republican Attorneys General Back Trump in Far-Fetched Election Lawsuit
abstract: The move is an attempt to bolster a baseless legal effort by Texas that seeks to delay certification of the presidential electors in four battleground states that Mr. Trump lost.
lead_paragraph: Despite dozens of judges and courts rejecting challenges to the election, Republican attorneys general in 17 states on Wednesday backed President Trump in his increasingly desperate and audacious legal campaign to reverse the results.

headline: Biden Asks Congress to Grant Waiver for ‘Cool Under Fire’ Defense Pick
abstract: Senior Democrats appear willing to exempt Lloyd J. Austin III, a retired four-star general, from a law meant to protect civilian control of the military.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr., on Wednesday praised Lloyd J. Austin III, his choice for secretary of defense, as “a leader of extraordinary courage, character, experience and accomplishment,” and asked Congress to grant the exemption the retired four-star Army general needs from a law that bars officers recently on active duty from serving in the top Pentagon post.

headline: The virus spreads at wildfire speed in tiny Rhode Island, surpassing rates of new cases elsewhere.
abstract: Rhode Island, the smallest U.S. state in area, now has the fastest spread of coronavirus, with more new cases per capita being reported than any other state, according to a New York Times database.
lead_paragraph: Rhode Island, the smallest U.S. state in area, now has the fastest spread of coronavirus, with more new cases per capita being reported than any other state, according to a New York Times database.

headline: Arizona Man Who Conspired to Threaten Journalists Gets 16 Months in Prison
abstract: Johnny Roman Garza, 21, working with a neo-Nazi group, researched home addresses for potential targets and put up a threatening poster at the home of a journalist, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: A 21-year-old Arizona man who pleaded guilty to helping a neo-Nazi group threaten and intimidate journalists was sentenced on Wednesday to 16 months in federal prison.

headline: What You Need to Know About Getting Tested for Coronavirus
abstract: Long lines, slow results and inconsistent advice have left many of us confused about when and how to get tested. We talked to the experts to answer your questions.
lead_paragraph: Testing is essential to controlling the coronavirus. Once people know they are infected, they can isolate, alert others of the risk and stop the spread.

headline: A Constant Celebration
abstract: Read the clues very carefully for this puzzle by Jack Murtagh.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — I am an unapologetic science geek, so you can always win me over with a tricky puzzle about science. I liked this one by Jack Murtagh. And while that may be a bit of a spoiler, there is definitely more to figure out here.

headline: Merkel, Facebook, Ethiopia: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: They’re Among the World’s Oldest Living Things. The Climate Crisis Is Killing Them.
abstract: California’s redwoods, sequoias and Joshua trees define the American West and nature’s resilience through the ages. Wildfires this year were their deadliest test.
lead_paragraph: California’s redwoods, sequoias and Joshua trees define the American West and nature’s resilience through the ages. Wildfires this year were their deadliest test.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Nowhere for the Sick to Go in Rural West Texas
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, December 10, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “There will be no place for us to go if we get sick — that’s the bottom line.”

headline: Corrections: Dec. 10, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Dec. 10, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about the sale of Bob Dylan’s song catalog to Universal misstated the number of songs that he owned the copyrights to but did not write. It was not only “The Weight,” as recorded by the Band, but several other tracks associated with that group as well.

headline: N.F.L. Week 14 Predictions: Our Picks Against the Spread
abstract: The Dolphins face their biggest test yet in the Chiefs and the Steelers, after an 11-0 start, are trying to avoid a losing streak.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. made its way through a few weeks of odd schedules caused by coronavirus delays, and appears set for its first “normal” week in a while. Or at least the league is starting out with that plan until any virus-related adjustments are needed.

headline: It’s Australia’s First Big Blaze of the Fire Season. How Bad Will the Summer Get?
abstract: Last year, the country suffered catastrophic wildfires. Now, it is watching as a scenic getaway burns. What the rest of the season brings may depend on heat waves, winds and dried-out grass.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — The first major blaze of Australia’s wildfire season has now blackened roughly half of Fraser Island, an idyllic getaway north of Brisbane renowned for its golden beaches and lush biodiversity.

headline: They Call Us Enemies of the Cuban People
abstract: The San Isidro movement is a small step toward a national conversation.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA — I have been on the news on Cuban television twice in my life. The first time, I was a happy 10-year-old boy, shaking hands with Fidel Castro. The second time was just a few days ago, when television reports described me as someone who is “openly hostile toward Cuba” — an enemy of my country.

headline: Trevor Noah: Trump Takes Another ‘L’ Trying to ‘Unlose’ the Election
abstract: “Not only did they shut this case down, but they shut it down in just 34 minutes,” Noah said of the Supreme Court. “They didn’t even pretend that they were going to consider it.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Word + Quiz: affectation
abstract: This word has appeared in 11 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: Cases Surge in South Korea, but Covid Vaccine Is Months Away
abstract: Health officials warned that the number of daily cases in the country could rise to record highs in coming days, and that the latest wave of infections was the most elusive.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — For most of the year, South Korea has kept its coronavirus numbers so low it was the envy of the world. Now, the country is grappling with the most elusive wave of infections it has seen, just as other nations prepare to roll out vaccinations.

headline: Stay-at-Home Holiday
abstract: What story does this image inspire for you?

headline: The New Abortion Rights Advocates Are on TikTok
abstract: Gen Z activists have been unapologetic and confrontational, a shift in tactics for a movement at a crossroads.
lead_paragraph: In a TikTok filmed in August outside of a women’s health center in Charlotte, N.C., the uncensored version of the mid-1990s novelty rap song “Short, Short Man,” by Gillette blares: “Eenie weenie teenie weenie shriveled little short, short man.”

headline: December Date for U.S. Women’s Open Brings New Challenges
abstract: Golf’s final major tournament is set to play in Houston with coronavirus-related challenges, an unprecedented two-course format, and one of women’s golf’s largest purses.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The PGA Tour does not have a 72-hole stroke play event this week, and several weekend college football games, including the marquee matchup between Michigan and Ohio State, have been canceled or postponed because of the coronavirus, leaving the best female golfers in the world well positioned to fill the TV viewing void.

headline: The Once and Future Handbag
abstract: Predictions that 2020 would bring the end of the bag have been greatly exaggerated.
lead_paragraph: In a case of truly unfortunate timing, the week before the Victoria and Albert Museum’s blockbuster show celebrating all things bag related — an exhibition over 18 months in the making, one of the largest ever in a museum, with loans from around the world — was to have opened on April 25, Britain shut down in response to the coronavirus. The show was postponed.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘No Papers, No Jobs: The New Street Vendors of Queens’
abstract: In this lesson, students will learn about the struggles that street vendors face in New York. Then they will make connections to history.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “No Papers, No Jobs: The New Street Vendors of Queens” by Juan Arredondo and David Gonzalez (also available in Spanish)

headline: The Salzburg Festival, Reduced This Year, Roars Back in 2021
abstract: Classical music’s most storied annual event announces plans to return to pre-pandemic scale next summer.
lead_paragraph: It was the great exception in a summer for the performing arts almost entirely scratched out by the pandemic. Its calendar reduced and its audiences distanced, but still defiantly ambitious, the Salzburg Festival, classical music’s most storied annual event, went forward in August with a robust schedule of opera, theater and concerts.

headline: We Know How to Curb the Pandemic. How Do We Make People Listen?
abstract: Could better public health messaging persuade more people to change their behavior?
lead_paragraph: At this point, we have all the scientific information we need in order to prevent the surgings of the coronavirus: Avoid gathering indoors with people from outside your household, keep physically apart from others, wear a mask, wash your hands often. Among those who can follow these precautions — a lot of people, as policymakers should recognize, can’t afford to — too many are still disregarding public health advice. A recent report by researchers from Northeastern University and elsewhere found that the number of Americans heeding most recommendations has dropped steadily since April. (Mask-wearing, which has increased, was an exception.)

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Plush Toy Nativity Scene Advent Calendars
abstract: It’s the most wonderful time of the year — until mom tries to hijack your Balthazar.
lead_paragraph: Michelle writes: My family has a plush Advent calendar that forms a Nativity scene. For years, my sister (20) and I (23) have alternated who gets to add the wise man Balthazar, the most special plush in the calendar. Now our mom wants to add Balthazar herself. She’s never participated before. Please stop her.

headline: Let Cassandra Campbell Tell You a Story. She’s a Pro.
abstract: The voice behind hundred of audiobooks speaks out about what inspires her.
lead_paragraph: SPEAKING VOLUMES Cassandra Campbell has narrated 900 audiobooks, so it comes as no surprise that she is a pleasure to interview by phone, with a voice that’s both soothing and commanding and with the range to make herself heard over the din of a sisterly squabble in the background (mine). Campbell’s recent projects include “Golem Girl” by Riva Lehrer, “True Story” by Kate Reed Petty and “Eat the Buddha” by Barbara Demick, but she is perhaps best known for her narration of “Where the Crawdads Sing,” which is now in its 27th month on the best-seller list for audio fiction.

headline: Watch This Disgusting Food Video Right Now. It Explains Everything.
abstract: A viral clip of a grotesque breakfast dish reveals more about the way we use social media — and how it uses us — than about American cuisine.
lead_paragraph: The video makes it all seem so easy, even fun, and yet with each successive step, your sense of dread only mounts. First, you take an enormous brick of vividly orange cheese, one with enough structural integrity to allow you to hack into it with a knife. A cartoon mouse bounces up to encourage you, and to remind you of the longstanding cultural ties between cheese and mice. The jaunty, royalty-free music chirps away in the background as you ably carve out a deep recess within the cheese block, making sure the bottom is smooth. Then you place the block on top of four overlapping tortillas and wrap the cheese, sort of like a Christmas present. Strips of bacon are then applied until it is fully encased, and you slide the block into an oven preheated to 350. A little cartoon cat pops up to remind you that ovens are hot. After half an hour, you take the block out of the oven and you tie a sturdy strip of tinfoil around it. Then, you take —

headline: Jerry Seinfeld Rarely Laughs While He’s Reading
abstract: “The written word is tough.”
lead_paragraph: “It’s pretty hard to laugh when you’re reading — the written word is tough,” says the comedian and author of “Is This Anything?” But he makes an exception for John Updike: “You know, describing the circles of water under someone’s toes when they get out of the pool. That makes me laugh more than anything, that he would zero in on that.”

headline: A Couple Explore the Towers of Long Island City. Which of These Apartments Would You Choose?
abstract: After discovering ‘New York’s greatest-kept secret’ in Queens, two former Manhattanites went looking for a comfortable home with plenty of sun and useful amenities. Here’s where they landed.
lead_paragraph: After discovering ‘New York’s greatest-kept secret’ in Queens, two former Manhattanites went looking for a comfortable home with plenty of sun and useful amenities. Here’s where they landed.

headline: Do You Think People Have Gotten Too Relaxed About Covid?
abstract: Coronavirus cases, hospitalizations and deaths are at record numbers across the nation. Do we need stronger public messaging to “scare” Americans?
lead_paragraph: The good news: After racing for months to develop a safe and effective vaccine that will provide immunity against the coronavirus, two companies, Pfizer and Moderna, announced in November that they had developed vaccines that are more than 94 percent effective. Pending approval from the Food and Drug Administration, these companies estimate that enough vaccine doses will be available to administer to 22.5 million Americans by January.

headline: Facing Friction, Entrepreneurs Readjust to Meet Needs
abstract: Small businesses are kept afloat while keeping health care workers fed. And with training, opportunities for new ventures arise.
lead_paragraph: For Tee Tran, the golden rule is not just an aspiration. It’s a way of life that he has tried to embody, particularly during the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: ‘Farewell Amor’ Review: Alone Together
abstract: Ekwa Msangi’s tender drama shows us that goodbyes haunt immigrants wherever they go.
lead_paragraph: Contrary to its title, “Farewell Amor” begins with a reunion. In a delicate opening set in an airport, Walter (Ntare Guma Mbaho Mwine), an Angolan refugee in New York, embraces his wife and teenage daughter, who’ve just arrived in America after a 17-year wait for visas.

headline: Poem: the times
abstract: Lucille Clifton brings a complexity to something we imagined we understood — and a relentless honesty.
lead_paragraph: Aracelis Girmay has written that Lucille Clifton’s works are “explicitly historical and of a palpable present moment.” Clifton brings a complexity to something we imagined we understood — and a relentless honesty. Here, she admits, of the child who has killed and the child who has died, “i catch myself relieved that they are/white.” And yet, by poem’s end, she remembers that “these too are your children this too is your child.” The line she draws is always at being complicatedly human. Is there more than this to ask of a poet? Selected by Reginald Dwayne Betts

headline: Movie Theaters Are Dying. Did Jason Kilar Deal the Final Blow?
abstract: The WarnerMedia C.E.O. was trying to drag Hollywood into the 21st century, but now he’s at odds with the theaters and filmmakers he needs on his side.
lead_paragraph: If you want to be the first to watch “Dune,” “Godzilla vs. Kong” or the new “Matrix” movie this year (yes, there’s a fourth one) — you won’t have to line up at a movie theater. That’s because Jason Kilar, the C.E.O. of WarnerMedia, announced last week that the full slate of Warner Bros. films will be simultaneously released in theaters and on the company’s streaming service, HBO Max.

headline: What Really Saved the Republic From Trump?
abstract: It wasn’t our constitutional system of checks and balances.
lead_paragraph: Americans are taught that the main function of the U.S. Constitution is the control of executive power: curtailing presidents who might seek to become tyrants. Other republics have lapsed into dictatorships (the Roman Republic, the Weimar Republic, the Republic of China and so on), but our elaborate constitutional system of checks and balances, engineered largely by James Madison, protects us from despotism.

headline: There’s Still a Loaded Weapon Lying Around in Our Election System
abstract: State legislatures are still a threat to appointing electors contrary to the will of their voters.
lead_paragraph: The 2020 election revealed longstanding fractures in the foundation of our system for conducting presidential elections. Before these lead to an earthquake in a subsequent presidential election, we need to shore up that foundation.

headline: Kids Are Watching Pornography. Here’s How to Talk About It.
abstract: I teach sex ed. In light of a recent report on exploitation of children on the site Pornhub, I have some talking points for parents.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times columnist Nicholas Kristof’s recent report on videos of child sexual abuse on the website Pornhub may have parents wondering if their own children are watching Pornhub, or other pornography websites. Others may be appalled by the possibility that their child may view videos of assault and rape, or ask for or send sexually explicit selfies that could end up on social media or a porn site.

headline: Remote School as the Gateway Drug to Social Media
abstract: For parents who did not expect their children to have devices or use social media so young, virtual learning was an unexpected push into the digital deep end.
lead_paragraph: Several weeks into the new school year, I was sitting in my home office when I heard a series of beeps emanating from my phone.

headline: Becerra Supports ‘Medicare for All,’ and Could Help States Get There
abstract: Waivers can expand health care offerings without need for congressional approval, but the challenge will be how to pay for them.
lead_paragraph: Xavier Becerra has long supported moving the United States to a “Medicare for all” system. As President-elect Joe Biden’s pick to run Health and Human Services, he may have opportunities to speed up such a transition.

headline: The Virus Has Stolen Your Face From Me
abstract: As a portrait artist, all I can do now is reconstruct the mysteries of who you are under the mask.
lead_paragraph: Today’s sightings: red paisley mask, pleated pink flowered mask, black VOTE mask, yellow smiley-face mask, Etsy bedazzled mask, Spiderman mask. Lots of surgical-blue paper masks. A few hard-shell N95s. One or two navy bandit gaiters. (Me, I’m under the grinning-wolf mask.) Most masks hide who we are and let us try on different identities, but these disguises give me clues to the wearer underneath.

headline: The Risk in Suspending Vaccine Patent Rules
abstract: The system that built a coronavirus vaccine in record time relies on robust intellectual property protections.
lead_paragraph: South Africa and India have petitioned the World Trade Organization to suspend some intellectual property protections from Covid-19 drugs, vaccines and diagnostic technologies. In support of the effort, Doctors Without Borders began a social media campaign urging governments to “put lives over profits,” warning of “pharma profiteering” and urging support for “#NoCovidMonopolies.” The W.T.O., which governs trade rules among its 164 member nations, considered the proposal at its Council for Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights meeting Thursday.

headline: How Can a Garment Be Cheaper Than a Sandwich?
abstract: Covid-19 has demonstrated just how dependent the global fashion industry is on the exploitation of cheap labor.
lead_paragraph: This is an article from Turning Points, a special section that explores what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead.

headline: How Foods May Affect Our Sleep
abstract: A growing body of research suggests that the foods you eat can affect how well you sleep, and your sleep patterns can affect your dietary choices.
lead_paragraph: This has not been a very good year for sleep.

headline: Crime Wave Hits Bodegas, Threatening a Lifeline in the Pandemic
abstract: Bodegas have seen a 63 percent rise in shootings and a threefold increase in burglaries. Six people have been killed in or just outside the stores.
lead_paragraph: It was shortly after 6 o’clock one night in late October when Hardik Parekh, the manager of a corner store in Queens, saw a man he recognized as a chronic shoplifter walk in. Not again, he thought.

headline: The Highly Unlikely Yet Totally Predictable Return of Uggs
abstract: How Ugg learned to play the high-fashion game.
lead_paragraph: It started with Rihanna, as these things so often do.

headline: ‘How Many Fact Checkers Do They Have?’
abstract: Inside the battle between Biden and Facebook.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: ‘It’s Hard to Prove’: Why Antitrust Suits Against Facebook Face Hurdles
abstract: The U.S. and state cases against the social network are far from a slam dunk because the standards of proof are formidable.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When the Federal Trade Commission and more than 40 states sued Facebook on Wednesday for illegally killing competition and demanded that the company be split apart, lawmakers and public interest groups applauded.

headline: States Try to Rescue Small Businesses as U.S. Aid Is Snarled
abstract: State governments are offering loans, grants and tax rebates, but budget constraints limit their impact.
lead_paragraph: With the economic recovery faltering and federal aid stalled in Washington, state governments are stepping in to try to help small businesses survive the pandemic winter.

headline: N.C.A.A. Crisis Shows How Biden’s Surgeon General Pick Navigated the Pandemic
abstract: Vivek Murthy was a central figure in the decision to cancel the N.C.A.A. basketball tournaments in March. He’s poised to have a major role in the Biden administration’s response to the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus had started to grip the United States, and the National Collegiate Athletic Association’s board convened an emergency conference call to consider the fate of the organization’s lifeblood: the annual basketball championships that generate hundreds of millions of dollars of the organization’s revenue.

headline: How We Followed a 1,500-Mile Migration Journey
abstract: Over several months, a team of Times journalists tracked the progress of a pregnant mother displaced by the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: South Korea faces its ‘biggest ever coronavirus crisis’ and other news around the world.
abstract: For most of the year, South Korea has kept its coronavirus numbers so low it was the envy of the world. Now, the country is grappling with the most elusive wave of infections it has seen, just as other nations prepare to roll out vaccinations.
lead_paragraph: For most of the year, South Korea has kept its coronavirus numbers so low it was the envy of the world. Now, the country is grappling with the most elusive wave of infections it has seen, just as other nations prepare to roll out vaccinations.

headline: ‘These Girls Are Being Cut and Married in Droves’
abstract: In Samburu County, economic and social strife from the pandemic is helping turn a generation of girls into commodities.
lead_paragraph: A deep, sonorous melody pierces the night sky when young Samburu warriors celebrate an impending marriage. These songs, which echo across the arid plains of rural northern Kenya, are beautiful. They also often herald danger for girls in the region’s pastoralist communities — and during the coronavirus pandemic, they’ve grown alarmingly more frequent.

headline: The Newest Challenge for Europe’s Parks: A Surge of New Nature Lovers
abstract: Lockdown-weary city dwellers across the continent are visiting parks and other protected areas for the first time, overwhelming staff and generating pleas for more support.
lead_paragraph: Lockdown-weary Europeans have sought out nature in record-breaking numbers this year, putting sudden and substantial pressure on national parks and other natural areas across the continent.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience virtually.
lead_paragraph: In normal times, Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater would now be encamped at New York City Center for the month, inspiring awe and bringing joy. This year, everything is virtual: a mix of archival and newly filmed video, supplemented with conversations, available free on the company’s website, YouTube channel and Facebook page.

headline: As Trump Disputes Election Results, Republicans Target Voting by Mail
abstract: Nearly half of voters cast absentee ballots in the election, a huge increase. If Republicans have their way, that might not last.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s barrage of losses in court cases trying to undermine the election has not stopped Republicans from turning to battles they might be able to win — attempts to limit or undermine the future use of the vote-by-mail ballots that so infuriated Mr. Trump.

headline: An Unwelcome Silent Night: Germany Without Christmas Markets
abstract: Across the country, city and town squares stand empty of the usual huts, sounds, scents and lights, as the coronavirus has forced the country to skip its beloved annual Christmas markets.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Germany this December doesn’t feel right.

headline: U.S. sets record for daily deaths as hospitals nationwide near or exceed capacity.
abstract: The onslaught has been relentless.
lead_paragraph: The onslaught has been relentless.

headline: The Partial Return to School in New York City
abstract: Elementary schools have reopened, with mandatory weekly testing, but many parents decided not to send their children back.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: For Germans, Christmas markets are a beloved fixture. Maybe next year.
abstract: No groups of friends gripping mugs of steaming red wine spiced with cinnamon and cloves crowding Rothenburg’s medieval market square, or beneath Cologne’s towering cathedral. No brass brands playing carols before Berlin’s Charlottenburg Palace. No stars shining from the eaves of Seiffen’s wooden huts.
lead_paragraph: No groups of friends gripping mugs of steaming red wine spiced with cinnamon and cloves crowding Rothenburg’s medieval market square, or beneath Cologne’s towering cathedral. No brass brands playing carols before Berlin’s Charlottenburg Palace. No stars shining from the eaves of Seiffen’s wooden huts.

headline: How Washington and Silicon Valley Agree to Disagree on Taming Big Tech
abstract: A group of experts gathered to debate privacy, competition and what to do — if anything — about tech giants’ growing power.
lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley’s most successful companies have moved fast and amassed millions — and in some cases, billions — of users, while governments have slowly caught on to how these new digital businesses worked. Now, policymakers better understand the power that tech platforms gained by offering free services, which users pay for with data, and how these affect markets and society.

headline: Smarter Traffic Lights, Calmer Commuters
abstract: Advances in technology may come to a corner near you, easing traffic and possibly helping the environment.
lead_paragraph: How often have you cursed out a traffic light that took forever to change? Or the lights on a long stretch of road made you stop at every cross street, just when you felt you might actually make it to work on time? Take heart: Less painful commutes may be ahead, with advanced electronic control systems that apply artificial intelligence to the task of keeping traffic moving.

headline: Housing Fights to Be Heard in the Mayoral Race
abstract: A coalition of housing groups releases a blueprint that includes rezoning affluent neighborhoods, legalizing basement apartments and turning hotels into affordable housing.
lead_paragraph: In a New York mayoral race already transformed by the pandemic and mounting racial justice issues, a coalition of more than 80 wide-ranging organizations has released a report to remind the crowded field: Don’t forget about housing.

headline: Why Did the U.S. Turn Down Vaccine Doses?
abstract: The Trump administration rejected the opportunity to secure a bigger stockpile months ago. How did that happen?
lead_paragraph: From the start of the pandemic, the Trump administration said it was committed to ordering and stockpiling enough potential vaccine doses to end the outbreak in the United States as quickly as possible.

headline: E.U. Reaches Deal on Major Budget and Stimulus Package
abstract: Leaders meeting Thursday worked out a compromise with Hungary and Poland, who had vetoed the bloc’s budget and stimulus plans over threats that they could lose access to funds.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European Union leaders reached a landmark budget agreement Thursday after weeks of fraught negotiations, unblocking $2.2 trillion in funds crucial to some of the bloc’s weakest economies that have been decimated by the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Masks, Distancing — and Tests
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: Reducing the spread of Covid-19 over the next several months — while vaccines are being distributed — has the potential to save more than 100,000 American lives, as I explained earlier this week. So how can we reduce the spread?

headline: Holidays in a pandemic? Here’s what happened in 1918.
abstract: The influenza pandemic of 1918-19, in which millions of Americans were sickened and 675,000 died, seemed to roll across the United States in waves, much like the coronavirus today. The winter holidays in 1918 were marked by grievous loss, and came during a relative lull after the deadliest wave, in the fall. Another, smaller surge would peak shortly after New Year’s Day.
lead_paragraph: The influenza pandemic of 1918-19, in which millions of Americans were sickened and 675,000 died, seemed to roll across the United States in waves, much like the coronavirus today. The winter holidays in 1918 were marked by grievous loss, and came during a relative lull after the deadliest wave, in the fall. Another, smaller surge would peak shortly after New Year’s Day.

headline: ‘Wild Mountain Thyme’ Review: Finding Love Down on the Farm
abstract: John Patrick Shanley adapts his play “Outside Mullingar” into a movie. (Don’t worry about the accents.)
lead_paragraph: Whenever a movie has its performers speak in a regional dialect, the world entire suddenly teems with accent experts. “Wild Mountain Thyme,” written and directed by John Patrick Shanley (adapted from his play “Outside Mullingar”) is set in Ireland. And it started getting pushback in that country when its trailer dropped in November. Film people on social media made sport with the speaking styles of its American, English and Irish cast too.

headline: ‘The Weasels’ Tale’ Review: House Hunting
abstract: Argentine showbiz stars in a remote mansion battle with two real estate hustlers in Juan José Campanella’s crowd-pleasing comedy.
lead_paragraph: Schemers meet their match in “The Weasels’ Tale,” Juan José Campanella’s crowd-pleasing Argentine comedy. A former diva, Mara (grande dame Graciela Borges), shares a rambling remote mansion with her milquetoast husband, Pedro (Luis Brandoni), and two suave parasites she used to make movies with: a director, Norberto (Oscar Martínez), and a screenwriter, Martín (Marcos Mundstock). They pass the time trading reminiscences and barbs, until a slick city couple, Bárbara (Clara Lago) and Francisco (Nicolás Francella), show up and angle to buy the property.

headline: ‘Through the Night’ Review: Tucking In Children When Their Parents Can’t
abstract: A new documentary looks at a 24-hour day care center a couple runs in their home.
lead_paragraph: The lean and powerful documentary “Through The Night” centers on Dee’s Tots Childcare, a day care center in New Rochelle, N.Y., that provides 24-hour service for local families. Deloris and Patrick Hogan run the center out of their home seven days a week. In family fashion, the kids call Patrick Pop Pop, and everyone calls Deloris Nunu.

headline: ‘Funny Boy’ Review: Coming Out During Civil War
abstract: Deepa Mehta’s sprawling coming-of-age drama follows a boy who realizes he is gay in a country that criminalizes homosexuality.
lead_paragraph: Set against the backdrop of the Sri Lankan civil war, “Funny Boy” centers on a protagonist who is effectively fighting on two fronts.

headline: ‘The Prom’ Review: Showbiz Sanctimony, and All That Zazz
abstract: Ryan Murphy takes on the Broadway hit “The Prom,” with help from Meryl Streep, Nicole Kidman and Keegan-Michael Key.
lead_paragraph: Early in Ryan Murphy’s “The Prom,” a Broadway flack starts reading the reviews of a newly opened show about Eleanor Roosevelt, “Eleanor!” The gang’s all here, including the self-adoring stars, Dee Dee Allen (Meryl Streep) and Barry Glickman (James Corden). The drinks and laughs are flowing, and everyone is as lit as their bedazzled outfits. And then the flack starts reading the notice from The New York Times (hiss, boo). “This is not a review you want when you have crappy advance sales,” he bleats. “This is going to close us.”

headline: Antitrust Suits and a Hail Mary
abstract: Facebook is hit with separate antitrust suits, while Republican state attorneys general file a legal Hail Mary to delay the election certification. It’s Thursday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
lead_paragraph: Facebook is hit with separate antitrust suits, while Republican state attorneys general file a legal Hail Mary to delay the election certification. It’s Thursday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

headline: ‘Assassins’ Review: Duped Into an International Murder Plot
abstract: A documentary tries to explain how two women were able to cause the death of the North Korean leader’s half brother.
lead_paragraph: The two women who smeared a nerve agent on the face of Kim Jong-nam, the half brother of the North Korean dictator Kim Jong-un, causing his death, have left a light pop-cultural footprint in the United States. This is especially so given that one of them was wearing a shirt reading “LOL” during the act. Anyone that meme-ready deserves at least one movie.

headline: How ‘The Queen’s Gambit’ Is Inspiring Women to Take Up Chess
abstract: Fans of the Netflix series, including teenagers and the actress Beth Behrs, are flocking to the game because “women can be rock stars” in chess.
lead_paragraph: The actress Beth Behrs has a new obsession — chess — and the Netflix series “The Queen’s Gambit” is to blame. Her obsession even got her into trouble on the set of the CBS show “The Neighborhood,” where she plays Gemma Johnson.

headline: Watch live: Steven Mnuchin testifies about management of stimulus funds.
abstract: Steven Mnuchin, the Treasury secretary, is testifying on Thursday before the Congressional Oversight Commission, a bipartisan panel tasked with overseeing how pandemic aid is distributed, about his management of stimulus funds.
lead_paragraph: Steven Mnuchin, the Treasury secretary, is testifying on Thursday before the Congressional Oversight Commission, a bipartisan panel tasked with overseeing how pandemic aid is distributed, about his management of stimulus funds.

headline: Who Wants to Undo Facebook?
abstract: The F.T.C. and more than 40 states seek to break up the tech giant.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission and more than 40 states sued Facebook yesterday, saying its acquisitions of Instagram and WhatsApp unfairly eliminated competition. They called for Facebook to be split apart and restricted in making future deals, “some of the most severe penalties regulators can demand,” write The Times’s Cecilia Kang and Mike Isaac.

headline: U.S. corporations say they’ll hire one million Black workers in the next decade.
abstract: Jarred by the death of George Floyd and the issues of racial injustice raised in its wake, the chief executives of three dozen companies are starting an initiative to provide a million jobs for Black workers in the next decade.
lead_paragraph: Jarred by the death of George Floyd and the issues of racial injustice raised in its wake, the chief executives of three dozen companies are starting an initiative to provide a million jobs for Black workers in the next decade.

headline: Biden puts a premium on personal relationships in his cabinet picks.
abstract: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. has worked with the former aide he wants to be secretary of state since their time at the Senate Foreign Relations Committee in the 1990s. His nominee for agriculture secretary endorsed his first presidential bid more than 30 years ago. And he knows his choice for Pentagon chief from the retired general’s time in Iraq, where Mr. Biden’s son Beau, a military lawyer, also served on the general’s staff.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. has worked with the former aide he wants to be secretary of state since their time at the Senate Foreign Relations Committee in the 1990s. His nominee for agriculture secretary endorsed his first presidential bid more than 30 years ago. And he knows his choice for Pentagon chief from the retired general’s time in Iraq, where Mr. Biden’s son Beau, a military lawyer, also served on the general’s staff.

headline: Bloomberg’s gun control group calls for a raft of executive actions from Biden.
abstract: Everytown for Gun Safety, the gun control organization backed by former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York, called on the Biden administration on Thursday to swiftly enact executive orders that would regulate the tracking of homemade firearms, require background checks for virtually all gun sales and mandate dealers notify the F.B.I. when they complete gun sales before completing a background check.
lead_paragraph: Everytown for Gun Safety, the gun control organization backed by former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York, called on the Biden administration on Thursday to swiftly enact executive orders that would regulate the tracking of homemade firearms, require background checks for virtually all gun sales and mandate dealers notify the F.B.I. when they complete gun sales before completing a background check.

headline: Minneapolis City Council Votes to Remove $8 Million From Police Budget
abstract: The move comes as the city grapples with efforts to overhaul the department after the police killing of George Floyd.
lead_paragraph: Months after their pledge to dismantle the Police Department fell apart, members of the Minneapolis City Council voted early Thursday to divert nearly $8 million from the proposed policing budget to other city services, a move heralded by some as an important step toward transforming public safety in a city where law enforcement has long been accused of racism.

headline: A man whose positive test forced a cruise ship to return early is actually negative, Singaporean officials say.
abstract: An 83-year-old passenger who initially tested positive for the coronavirus on a “cruise to nowhere” from Singapore this week, forcing thousands of passengers and crew members to return to port a day early, did not have the virus after all, officials said on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: An 83-year-old passenger who initially tested positive for the coronavirus on a “cruise to nowhere” from Singapore this week, forcing thousands of passengers and crew members to return to port a day early, did not have the virus after all, officials said on Thursday.

headline: To Deter Iranian Attacks on U.S. Troops, Pentagon Orders B-52 Flights to Middle East
abstract: It was the second time in three weeks that Air Force bombers had conducted long-range flights near Iranian air space on short notice.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two American B-52 bombers flew a show-of-force mission in the Persian Gulf on Thursday that military officials said was intended to deter Iran and its proxies from carrying out attacks against United States troops in the Middle East amid rising tensions between the two countries.

headline: Afghan Journalist Is Killed in Latest Attack on Media Figures
abstract: ISIS gunmen attacked Malalai Maiwand, a well-known TV and radio journalist, in Jalalabad. Her death is one of a string of high-profile targeted killings in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: JALALABAD, Afghanistan — An Afghan journalist was killed on her way to work on Thursday, marking the third fatal attack on a well-known media personality in just over a month and sowing fear in a community that came of age reporting on a country at war for decades.

headline: Why We’re Talking About the California-Texas Rivalry, Again
abstract: Thursday: What the two states’ “frenemy” relationship says about the economy. Also: An update on the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Chinese Embassy retweets Trump’s false claims of election fraud, then backtracks.
abstract: The Twitter account of the Chinese Embassy in the United States on Wednesday shared a post by President Trump falsely claiming that the Democrats “cheated” in the election and that the results should be overturned — only to undo the retweet hours later and claim that its account had been hacked.
lead_paragraph: The Twitter account of the Chinese Embassy in the United States on Wednesday shared a post by President Trump falsely claiming that the Democrats “cheated” in the election and that the results should be overturned — only to undo the retweet hours later and claim that its account had been hacked.

headline: How Do I Tell My Relatives to Stop Buying Me Christmas Gifts?
abstract: I’m tired of tossing useless presents, especially since I put so much time into shopping for my family.
lead_paragraph: How can I ask my brother and sister-in-law not to give me a gift for Christmas? She does the shopping for their family, and while I know it’s the thought that counts, her presents are never to my taste or things I can use. (Some also appear to be regifts.) So, I donate them to charity shops or throw them away. This seems like a waste of their money, and I’m tired of recycling their gifts. I always spend a great deal of time choosing gifts that I think each member of their large extended family will like. But I feel less joy in it every year. Any thoughts?

headline: The Work Diary of Mira Mariah, Tattoo and ‘Girl Culture’ Expert
abstract: She built a cult following as Instagram’s @girlknewyork by designing tattoos for people who want to look and feel cool.
lead_paragraph: In an ideal world, Mira Mariah would always be celebrating.

headline: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
abstract: Cozy knits, handcrafted furnishings from Mexico City — and more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we’re sharing things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. You can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: This week’s properties are in Boerum Hill, Jackson Heights and on the Upper East Side.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are in Boerum Hill, Jackson Heights and on the Upper East Side.

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
abstract: This weeks properties are a four-bedroom in Stockton, N.J., and a six-bedroom in Nissequogue, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: This weeks properties are a four-bedroom in Stockton, N.J., and a six-bedroom in Nissequogue, N.Y.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
abstract: This weeks properties are a four-bedroom in Stockton, N.J., and a six-bedroom in Nissequogue, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn, Queens and Manhattan
abstract: This week’s properties are in Boerum Hill, Jackson Heights and on the Upper East Side.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: Taylor Swift Announces Second Surprise Quarantine Album, ‘Evermore’
abstract: The “sister record” to her Grammy-nominated “Folklore” again features Aaron Dessner, Jack Antonoff and Justin Vernon, along with new collaborators.
lead_paragraph: Five months after the surprise arrival of “Folklore,” an album entirely written and recorded in quarantine, Taylor Swift is doing it again: “Evermore,” the singer and songwriter’s ninth studio album, will arrive on Friday.

headline: Italy Charges Egyptian Security Agents in Student’s Killing
abstract: Prosecutors brought formal indictments against four officials from the North African country over the abduction and murder of Giulio Regeni in 2016.
lead_paragraph: Italy announced on Thursday that four officials with the Egyptian National Security Agency had been charged in connection with the abduction and murder of an Italian doctoral student in Cairo in 2016.

headline: As Trump disputes election results, Republicans target voting by mail.
abstract: Republicans are shifting their focus from legal challenges to overturn election results in battleground states to efforts that would limit or undermine the future use of the vote-by-mail ballots that so infuriated President Trump.
lead_paragraph: Republicans are shifting their focus from legal challenges to overturn election results in battleground states to efforts that would limit or undermine the future use of the vote-by-mail ballots that so infuriated President Trump.

headline: Executed Nigerian Farmers Were Caught Between Boko Haram and the Army
abstract: More than 70 agricultural workers were killed by militants, who accused them of telling the authorities that the extremist group was in the area.
lead_paragraph: ZABARMARI, Nigeria — For years, the farmers had an agreement with Boko Haram militants: They could tend their fields in peace, as long as they did not report the fighters’ presence to the Nigerian Army.

headline: Gifts From Cyberspace
abstract: Searching for a last-minute gift … that may take months to arrive? This holiday gift guide might give you a few ideas.
lead_paragraph: Searching for a last-minute gift … that may take months to arrive? This holiday gift guide might give you a few ideas.

headline: The Olive Garden Is Open, but Marilyn Hagerty Isn’t Eating There
abstract: At 94, the author of a North Dakota restaurant review that became an internet sensation is still at work. In the pandemic, though, she’s had to make a few changes.
lead_paragraph: North Dakota’s most famous restaurant critic has been eating at home lately. It’s not that there’s nowhere to go in and around Grand Forks, where she lives and writes. Her governor, Doug Burgum, has allowed restaurants and bars to stay open even though the state has had the third-highest death rate from Covid-19 over the past week.

headline: Lebanon Prime Minister Charged With Negligence in Beirut Blast
abstract: An investigating judge named the caretaker prime minister, Hassan Diab, a suspect, a significant step toward holding the top levels of power accountable in the August explosion that killed 200.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Lebanese judge investigating the massive explosion in the port of Beirut has charged the acting prime minister, Hassan Diab, and three former ministers with negligence in the August blast that killed nearly 200 people, the state-run National News Agency reported on Thursday.

headline: Biden’s pick for surgeon general had a crucial role in the N.C.A.A.’s pandemic response.
abstract: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s choice for surgeon general, Dr. Vivek H. Murthy, had a central role in the National Collegiate Athletic Association’s decision in March to cancel this year’s national basketball tournaments — one of the earliest and most culturally significant signs that the virus would upend ordinary life in America.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s choice for surgeon general, Dr. Vivek H. Murthy, had a central role in the National Collegiate Athletic Association’s decision in March to cancel this year’s national basketball tournaments — one of the earliest and most culturally significant signs that the virus would upend ordinary life in America.

headline: Dionne Warwick Has Entered the Chat
abstract: The Grammy-winning singer isn’t afraid to pick a fight on Twitter. But it’s all in good fun.
lead_paragraph: Dionne Warwick has had a Twitter account for years, but recently her followers thought she might have been hacked.

headline: What’s in Our Queue? ‘Sound of Metal’
abstract: I'm a pop culture reporter and The Times's award-season columnist. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and playing.
lead_paragraph: I'm a pop culture reporter and The Times's award-season columnist. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and playing.

headline: Time Running Out for Brexit Deal, ​E.U. Seeks to Avoid Jan. 1 Chaos
abstract: The measures, which require British agreement, would cover air and road travel, freight and fishing for six months, to prevent immediate chaos should the transition period end without a trade pact.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — With little progress in negotiations with Britain over its future relationship with the European Union, the European Commission published some contingency measures on Thursday to help prepare for a possible no-deal Brexit.

headline: E.U.’s Top Drug Regulator Says It’s ‘Fully Functional’ After Cyberattack
abstract: The agency’s leader said the breach would not delay delivery of a coronavirus vaccine to member nations.
lead_paragraph: The European Union’s top drug regulator, whose approval is necessary for countries of the bloc to begin rolling out the coronavirus vaccine, has begun an investigation after it was hit by a cyberattack, the head of the agency said on Thursday.

headline: ‘Small Axe’ Review: The Agonies and Ecstasies of Black British Lives
abstract: Steve McQueen’s anthology of five films is a revelatory look at Afro-Caribbean neighborhoods in Britain from the 1960s to the ’80s.
lead_paragraph: When the British filmmaker Steve McQueen conceived the five films he collectively named “Small Axe,” he could not have foreseen the drastically disrupted world into which they would be released — a world that could shift, and perhaps intensify, the impact with which they would land.

headline: With Paris Theaters Closed, Church Is the Only Show in Town
abstract: Coronavirus restrictions have shut playhouses and concert halls. So our critic went to Mass to get her fix of music, choreography and drama.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Where can you find elaborate costumes, choreographed flourishes and live music in France right now? Not in theaters. Since the country eased its second lockdown in late November, the show has resumed in only one setting: churches.

headline: Jackson Pollock, Before the Drip
abstract: “Mural,” his largest painting, is back in New York for the first time in 20 years, at the Guggenheim.
lead_paragraph: For Jacques-Louis David it was “The Oath of the Horatii,” for Kazimir Malevich it was “Black Square,” for Virginia Woolf it was “Jacob’s Room,” for Amy Winehouse it was “Rehab.” These are the breakthrough works — the hinges between the early career and the mature one. Everything before them looks like a warm-up, everything after like a natural outcome, though at the moment of their creation, who could tell?

headline: Where Are Your Papers? A New Yorker Goes Home to Locked-Down France
abstract: I muddled through the worst of the pandemic in New York. The restrictions in France proved far more onerous.
lead_paragraph: SACLAY, France — Where are my keys, my wallet, my face mask, my backup face mask? Do I have my ID? Have I filled out paperwork describing where I’m going, and when, and why? Is my destination legal? Can I make it back in three hours or less?

headline: ‘Is Exxon a Survivor?’ The Oil Giant Is at a Crossroads.
abstract: Exxon Mobil is struggling to find its footing as demand for oil and gas falls and world leaders and businesses pledge to fight climate change.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Over the last 135 years, Exxon Mobil has survived hostile governments, ill-fated investments and the catastrophic Exxon Valdez oil spill. Through it all, the oil company made bundles of money.

headline: Morocco Joins List of Arab Nations to Begin Normalizing Relations With Israel
abstract: Morocco follows Bahrain, Sudan and the United Arab Emirates in setting aside generations of hostilities toward the Jewish state, part of a major foreign policy effort of the Trump administration.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Morocco has agreed to a rapprochement with Israel in return for American recognition of the kingdom’s sovereignty over a long-disputed territory, under a deal announced on Thursday that gives President Trump another diplomatic victory in his final weeks in office.

headline: Under the Mask, the Next Batman Will Be Black
abstract: In a new comic written by John Ridley, who wrote “12 Years a Slave,” the new Batman will be revealed as Tim Fox, the son of a business associate of Bruce Wayne.
lead_paragraph: Fans of DC Comics have been told for months that a new Batman will premiere in January. They were also teased that underneath the costume of the new caped crusader would likely be a person of color. The identity of the new hero was revealed on Thursday when DC released a cover of the second issue of the new comic: he is Timothy Fox, one of the sons of Lucius Fox, a business associate of Bruce Wayne, the original Batman.

headline: ‘Finding Yingying’ Review: Vanishing Point
abstract: This documentary about the search for a missing student in Illinois takes a compassionate approach to grim material.
lead_paragraph: The chilling documentary “Finding Yingying” watches a family grapple with an unfathomable horror: the disappearance and probable death of a loved one who was living far away. Yingying Zhang, a visiting scholar from China at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, went missing in June 2017. What happened with the investigation and in court can be found online, but most of the film deals with the dread-filled uncertainty before those outcomes, and with the continuing search for Zhang’s body.

headline: When it Comes to Facebook, the Need for Action Has Been Obvious for a Long Time
abstract: It’s not too late for the government to take back power from Big Tech.
lead_paragraph: It’s about time, even if it’s been a very long 22 years.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Choose to Instantly Master
abstract: Which of these six skills would you choose to instantly master? How does your answer compare to what these Times subscribers said?

headline: The Scourge of Child Pornography
abstract: The National Center on Sexual Exploitation calls for the shutdown of Pornhub, and readers point to a public health crisis and a need for better sex education.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Ellen DeGeneres says she has tested positive for the coronavirus.
abstract: “The Ellen DeGeneres Show” has paused filming after its host said on Thursday that she had tested positive for the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: “The Ellen DeGeneres Show” has paused filming after its host said on Thursday that she had tested positive for the coronavirus.

headline: Airlines Gear Up to Transport Vaccines That Could Revive Travel
abstract: Planes are one part of an elaborate supply chain to move billions of doses of vaccines around the world.
lead_paragraph: Months before anyone knew which of the coronavirus vaccine candidates would pull ahead or when they’d be available, airlines were trying to figure out how to transport doses around the world.

headline: Give the A.I. Economy a Human Touch
abstract: Embracing artificial intelligence can help us create a new, equitable social contract — but only if we remember what makes us human.
lead_paragraph: This is an article from Turning Points, a special section that explores what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead.

headline: The Facebook Lawsuits Explained
abstract: Regulators accuse Facebook of buying up rivals. Here’s what this means for us and Big Tech.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: No, there isn’t evidence that Pfizer’s vaccine causes infertility.
abstract: A flurry of rumors online has prompted concern. But scientists assert the claims are baseless.
lead_paragraph: Social media platforms were flooded this week with concerns about an alarming headline purporting that the Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine, which is expected to be cleared for emergency use this week, could cause infertility in women. But experts say these claims are baseless.

headline: The Best Thrillers of 2020
abstract: Which books proved most spine-tingling in this momentous nail-biter of a year?
lead_paragraph: A new Tana French is always cause for celebration, even when it doesn’t feature the textured, compromised detectives from the fictional Dublin Murder Squad. THE SEARCHER (Viking, 451 pp., $27), French’s second stand-alone book, stars a weary retired cop who has fled his old life in Chicago for the quiet obscurity of rural Ireland. That is, until he is thrust headlong into a new mystery that will require all his emotional acumen as well as his skills as a policeman. Read it once for the plot; read it again for the beauty and subtlety of French’s writing.

headline: Wines to Remember in a Year to Forget
abstract: Travel, restaurants and vineyards were all virtually off limits. But a lot of bottles were opened at home, creating a different sort of history.
lead_paragraph: Like many people, I’ve spent most of 2020 sitting at home thinking about what was to have been.

headline: 20 Albums That Put a New Spin on the Holidays
abstract: Standards? Sure! But a crop of seasonal records from Dolly Parton, Tinashe and others introduce fresh original songs, too.
lead_paragraph: Mariah Carey’s modern classic “All I Want for Christmas Is You” finally hit No. 1 (after 25 years) last holiday season, surely inspiring more songwriters to try their hand at a well-worn but welcome annual tradition. Our pop and jazz critics surveyed the latest releases and picked out 20 that offer worthy additions to your seasonal playlists.

headline: Airbnb Tops $100 Billion on First Day of Trading, Reviving Talk of a Bubble
abstract: The home-rental company’s blockbuster I.P.O. followed that of the delivery company DoorDash. Investors piled into both.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Over the last decade, Airbnb has upended the travel industry, riled regulators, frustrated local communities and created a mini-economy of short-term rental operators, all while spinning a warm narrative of belonging and connection.

headline: European Central Bank Steps Up Its Stimulus as the Economy Contracts
abstract: The central bank said it expected the economic impact of the pandemic to last well into 2022, prompting an expansion of relief programs.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The European Central Bank delivered another dose of stimulus to the eurozone economy on Thursday, warning that the economic crisis caused by the pandemic is likely to linger well into 2022 despite the rollout of new vaccines.

headline: What Students Are Saying About Decriminalizing Drugs, Conversation Skills and Favorite Cookies
abstract: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts, and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to another roundup of student comments on our writing prompts. This week we asked teenagers whether drugs should be decriminalized, if they are good conversationalists and what they’d put into their perfect box of cookies.

headline: Museums Are Still Open in New York. Here’s What’s on View (for Now).
abstract: Sanford Biggers, Félix Fénéon and the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s history of itself are some of the exhibitions that remain open to the public.
lead_paragraph: While New York faces another indoor-dining ban because of an increase in coronavirus cases, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has made no suggestion that museums will shut imminently here, as they have closed in San Francisco, Chicago and other cities. For now — and no one knows how long now might last — New Yorkers are free to enjoy the city’s collections of cultural treasures.

headline: ‘Gunda’ Review: A Remarkable Pig’s-Eye View of the World
abstract: This astonishing documentary offers an intimate look at the lives of a sow, her rambunctious piglets, a one-legged chicken and a herd of cows.
lead_paragraph: What do filmmakers see when they look at animals? Not much, apparently: For the most part, animals in movies are atmospheric background — a solitary cat in a window, a horse in a field glimpsed from a car. Occasionally they are symbols, like the many sacrificed bunnies of cinema (“The Rules of the Game” et al.). At other times, animals are cast as favorite companions, and plenty of dogs have played good boy onscreen. Yet even in films as distinct as “Old Yeller” and “Best in Show,” animals are usually in service to the human story, to our feelings and tears.

headline: Boris Johnson Once Mocked the Eurocrats of Brussels. They Haven’t Forgotten.
abstract: As a newspaper reporter decades ago, he made plenty of enemies there with his inflammatory articles. Now, those officials may determine his political fate.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Three decades ago, an enterprising young foreign correspondent named Boris Johnson reported that the European Commission planned to blow up Berlaymont, its hulking, asbestos-riddled headquarters in Brussels. “Sappers will lay explosive charges at key points,” he wrote in The Daily Telegraph.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: South Korea’s biggest coronavirus crisis.
lead_paragraph: As other countries prepare to roll out vaccinations, South Korea is grappling with its biggest wave of coronavirus infections yet.
