headline: Morocco joins a list of Arab nations to begin normalizing relations with Israel.
abstract: Morocco has agreed to begin normalizing relations with Israel, becoming the fourth Arab state this fall to do so, the White House announced on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Morocco has agreed to begin normalizing relations with Israel, becoming the fourth Arab state this fall to do so, the White House announced on Thursday.

headline: Film Club: ‘$30,000 Sneakers? As Demand Grows for Coveted Shoes, So Do Prices’
abstract: Are you a “sneakerhead”? How much would you pay for a pair of sneakers?

headline: The Receding Horizon of Travel’s Return
abstract: Every time it looks like recovery is close, a new surge of the coronavirus pushes back the timeline. Now, even as vaccines raise hopes, for those who rely on tourism for their livelihoods, it might be too late.
lead_paragraph: To work in the travel industry in 2020 is to live in a constant state of limbo.

headline: Afghan War Casualty Report: December 2020
abstract: At least 159 pro-government forces and 93 civilians have been killed in Afghanistan so far this month.
lead_paragraph: At least 80 pro-government forces and 54 civilians were killed in Afghanistan the past week. The deadliest attack took place in Ghazni Province, where an unexploded munition detonated, killing at least 15 civilians, most of them children, and wounded 20 others. The children were selling scrap metal to a salesman at the time of the blast. In Kabul, the capital, a car bomb targeted a convoy of Khan Mohammad Wardak, a member of Afghan parliament, killing 10 civilians and wounding 52 others, including Mr. Wardak. No one has claimed responsibility for the attack.

headline: Inspector General Criticizes V.A.’s Handling of Sexual Assault Complaint
abstract: The inspector general’s report also expressed disappointment that the V.A. did not determine whether to take action “to provide a safer and more welcoming environment” for women at its facilities.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An inspector general inquiry has criticized Robert L. Wilkie, the secretary of veterans affairs, for a response that was “at a minimum unprofessional” after a female Navy veteran reported a sexual assault at a department hospital in Washington.

headline: Supreme Court Backs Muslim Men in Case on No-Fly List
abstract: The court also dismissed a challenge to Delaware’s court system, which takes account of judges’ partisan ties to create ideological balance.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Thursday ruled in favor of three Muslim men who say they were put on the no-fly list in retaliation for refusing to become government informants.

headline: Lillian Blancas, Candidate for a Texas Judgeship, Dies at 47
abstract: Ms. Blancas, a widely respected lawyer, died days before a runoff election in El Paso but remained on the ballot and won. She died of Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Some Covid Patients Are More Equal Than Others
abstract: Readers are dismayed that Rudy Giuliani and Chris Christie went ahead of the line in receiving virus treatment. Also: Better not to prosecute Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Civilian Control of the Military Is Vital
abstract: Biden must give a better explanation for why a waiver is justified and how to stop this from becoming a trend.
lead_paragraph: Joe Biden ran for the White House promising to restore the norms that protect American democracy, which had badly eroded under President Trump. Among the most worrisome is the erosion of the principle that the military should be led by a civilian and those in uniform kept separate from partisan politics.

headline: Has Your Budget Changed During the Pandemic?
abstract: What kind of spending have you prioritized and what’s no longer important? The New York Times would like to hear from you.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic has touched all aspects of our lives, including our finances.

headline: Unemployment Claims Jump, Casting New Shadow Over U.S. Economy
abstract: The recent coronavirus surge is taking a toll on jobs that one economist calls “a slow-moving disaster.”
lead_paragraph: When coronavirus cases began rising across the country this fall, economists sounded a warning: Without government aid, layoffs were sure to follow.

headline: Mastercard and Visa stop allowing their cards to be used on Pornhub.
abstract: The credit card companies had launched separate investigations earlier this week into their financial ties with MindGeek, the parent company of Pornhub.
lead_paragraph: Mastercard and Visa said they had prohibited the use of their cards on the adult website Pornhub, after the New York Times columnist Nicholas Kristof reported that the platform included videos of child abuse and rape.

headline: Covid-19 caused the sudden death of a top state lawmaker in New Hampshire.
abstract: The New Hampshire State Legislature was already fiercely divided over the coronavirus when the new Republican speaker of the House of Representatives, Richard Hinch, died suddenly on Wednesday. Then came the news on Thursday that the cause of his death was Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: The New Hampshire State Legislature was already fiercely divided over the coronavirus when the new Republican speaker of the House of Representatives, Richard Hinch, died suddenly on Wednesday. Then came the news on Thursday that the cause of his death was Covid-19.

headline: Our Food Staff’s 18 Favorite Holiday Recipes
abstract: Reporters and editors shared the NYT Cooking recipes that have become holiday traditions in their homes.
lead_paragraph: Members of The New York Times Food department come across hundreds of new recipes every year, and these are the recipes they can’t live without during the holidays. It was tough to pick just one recipe — most suggested a few — but the most common themes were latkes and, unsurprisingly, cookies of all kinds. Here are some of their favorites.

headline: The Trustbusters Come for Facebook. Finally.
abstract: The government decides to try to enforce antitrust laws.
lead_paragraph: Facebook, like other big tech firms, has sought to maintain its dominance, and to keep profits rolling in, by gobbling up any upstarts that have threatened its market power. The company’s view of competition can be summed up by an email sent in 2008 by its chief executive and founder, Mark Zuckerberg: “It is better to buy than compete.”

headline: 11 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Old worlds spring to life in this week’s recommended titles, from a scientific account of Neanderthal culture to a biography of the seminal American foodie James Beard. There’s a new edition of “The Babur Nama,” the diaries of the 16th-century warlord who founded the Mughal dynasty in India. A look back at the golden age of Egyptology starting in 1822 — which is to say, a look back at archaeologists looking (way) back. A biography of the modernist poet and painter Max Jacob, and one of Eleanor Roosevelt, and a novel set in Britain in the decades after World War II. And there’s a reissue of Susan Taubes’s 1969 novel, “Divorcing,” which itself has much to say about history and the passage of time.

headline: Mnuchin Grilled Over Whether Relief Money Was Politicized
abstract: The Treasury secretary defended a loan to a struggling trucking company and his decision to end emergency lending programs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin was rebuked by a congressional oversight panel over his management of the economic relief effort on Thursday, with members questioning whether he politicized the handling of hundreds of billions of dollars in stimulus funds.

headline: Student Loan Cancellation Sets Up Clash Between Biden and the Left
abstract: Democratic leaders are pressing the president-elect to cancel $50,000 in debt per student borrower by fast executive action, but he wants Congress to pass more modest relief.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. is facing pressure from congressional Democrats to cancel student loan debt on a vast scale, quickly and by executive action, a campaign that will be one of the first tests of his relationship with the liberal wing of his party.

headline: Truck Driver Crashes Into Cyclists, Killing 5, Outside Las Vegas
abstract: The crash happened on Thursday morning as a group of about 20 bicyclists rode on the shoulder of U.S. 95 in Clark County, just north of Searchlight, Nev.
lead_paragraph: It was an annual tradition, a 130-mile ride on long stretches of highway from the M Resort Spa Casino in Henderson, Nev., through Searchlight to Nipton, Calif., and back.

headline: Deb Price, a First as a Columnist on Gay Life, Dies at 62
abstract: If she wrote for mainstream Americans about same-sex couples in everyday situations, she thought, society would have a harder time denying them equal rights.
lead_paragraph: As the nation’s first nationally syndicated lesbian columnist who wrote regularly about gay life, Deb Price certainly covered pointed issues, like the debate over gay people in the military.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Need a good origin story or a cure for vacation envy? This weekend’s selections have you covered.
lead_paragraph: Every Monday, Wednesday and Friday, we offer viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read the latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.

headline: End of ‘One Day at a Time’ Removes One of TV’s Few Latino Families
abstract: After being canceled last year by Netflix, the sitcom, a reboot of a Norman Lear classic, found a new but short-lived home on cable.
lead_paragraph: The sitcom “One Day at a Time,” about a multigenerational Cuban-American household, has had a complicated plotline of its own. When Netflix canceled the show last year after three seasons, it was rescued by a cable network, at least in part because of the outcry from its small but passionate fan base.

headline: F.D.A. Advisory Panel Gives Green Light to Pfizer Vaccine
abstract: The blessing of these experts means that the agency will likely OK the vaccine’s use, paving the way for health care workers to begin getting shots next week.
lead_paragraph: Pfizer’s Covid-19 vaccine passed a critical milestone on Thursday when a panel of experts formally recommended that the Food and Drug Administration authorize the vaccine. The agency is likely to do so within days, giving health care workers and nursing home residents first priority to begin receiving the first shots early next week.

headline: SEC Reaches $3 Billion Deal With Disney, Drawing CBS Ties Toward an End
abstract: The Southeastern Conference is poised to become the richest conference in college football after it struck a television deal with Disney, which owns ABC and ESPN.
lead_paragraph: The broadcast rights to the Southeastern Conference’s biggest football games, like the annual Iron Bowl matchup between Alabama and Auburn, have been purchased by Disney, meaning that all of the league’s games will appear on its networks including ABC and ESPN for 10 years starting in 2024.

headline: U.S. Will Not Punish Olympic Athletes for Peaceful Protests
abstract: Breaking from International Olympic Committee guidelines, the United States Olympic and Paralympic Committee announced it would not penalize athletes who participate in demonstrations.
lead_paragraph: The United States Olympic and Paralympic Committee announced on Thursday that it would no longer punish athletes who participate in peaceful protests, such as kneeling or raising a fist at a medal ceremony, putting itself in direct conflict with the longstanding policy of the International Olympic Committee.

headline: ‘Star Wars,’ ‘Pinocchio’ and More as Disney Leans Sharply Into Streaming
abstract: A blitz of new projects includes 10 series from the “Star Wars” universe for Disney+, which now has 87 million subscribers. Hulu will also get a major content boost.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In February, Robert A. Iger stepped down as Disney’s chief executive and became executive chairman, saying he would decamp entirely in 2021. But he saw himself as having one final task. “I want to make sure that our creative pipelines are vibrant,” Mr. Iger said in an interview at the time. “That is very, very important, especially as we roll out Disney+ around the world.”

headline: Encuentra tu lugar en la fila de vacunación
abstract: Revisa cuándo es posible que recibas la vacuna.
lead_paragraph: Revisa cuándo es posible que recibas la vacuna.

headline: Biden clashes with liberals over student loan cancellation.
abstract: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. is facing pressure from congressional Democrats to cancel student loan debt on a vast scale, quickly and by executive action, a campaign that will be one of the first tests of his relationship with the liberal wing of his party.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. is facing pressure from congressional Democrats to cancel student loan debt on a vast scale, quickly and by executive action, a campaign that will be one of the first tests of his relationship with the liberal wing of his party.

headline: Surfer Dies After Shark Attack in Hawaii
abstract: The 56-year-old man died a day after the attack in Maui. A surf competition scheduled in the area later that day was postponed and moved.
lead_paragraph: A 56-year-old surfer died in Maui, Hawaii, on Wednesday night, one day after a shark had attacked him.

headline: The Battle Over Biden’s Defense Secretary Has Begun
abstract: The president-elect’s pick would be the second recently retired general to lead the Pentagon in less than four years. That’s not supposed to happen.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.

headline: Vaccine,Virus Deaths, California’s Trees: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Fighters Win Key Ruling in Case That Could Upend U.F.C.’s Business
abstract: A judge said he would grant class-action status to a group of fighters arguing that the Ultimate Fighting Championship suppresses pay. If the fighters win, it could force the U.F.C. to pay much, much more.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge said on Thursday that he would make an important procedural ruling in favor of a group of mixed martial artists who are suing the Ultimate Fighting Championship, accusing it of abusing monopoly power to suppress fighter pay. The lawsuit, which will be granted class action status, could eventually cost the U.F.C. billions of dollars, fundamentally alter the world of mixed martial arts and establish new antitrust case law.

headline: Pentagon Weighs Sharp Drawback in Support for C.I.A.
abstract: A broad review of the military’s support for the agency is underway, including pulling back personnel and rethinking support for C.I.A. operations around the world.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration is considering whether to pull back military support for the C.I.A., including potentially taking back much of the drone fleet the C.I.A. uses, according to current and former officials. The shift could sharply curtail the agency’s counterterrorism efforts that were greatly expanded after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks.

headline: Barr Plans to Finish Term Despite Wanting to Leave Early
abstract: The attorney general had weighed whether to step down by the end of the year, potentially avoiding a contentious transition.
lead_paragraph: Attorney General William P. Barr has told others he plans to remain in his post through the end of the Trump administration, setting aside his deliberations about stepping down by the end of the year, according to a person told of his decision.

headline: How a Long Insurgency Plays Into Trump’s Move on Morocco
abstract: The 45-year-old fight between Morocco and separatists in Western Sahara threatens to return to outright war. By recognizing Moroccan sovereignty, the U.S. has taken sides for the first time.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s decision to endorse Moroccan control of Western Sahara puts the United States once again at odds with world opinion, as it takes sides for the first time in a decades-long struggle at a moment when that conflict threatens to return to open warfare.

headline: Phil Linz, Unlikely Baseball Celebrity, Is Dead at 81
abstract: Never a star and rarely a starter as a Yankee in the 1960s, Linz made news not for playing baseball but for playing the harmonica.
lead_paragraph: Phil Linz played on three World Series teams with the Yankees in the 1960s and spent seven seasons in the major leagues.

headline: Trump Tries to Kill Covid Relief
abstract: Is it ignorance, or is it cynicism?
lead_paragraph: The next few months will be terrible. Several thousand Americans are now dying from Covid-19 every day; given the lag between cases and deaths, the daily toll will almost certainly rise through the end of this year, and if people are careless over Christmas it could surge even higher in the new year. Economic recovery has stalled, with employment still down almost 10 million from pre-pandemic levels.

headline: In Blistering Retort, 4 Battleground States Tell Texas to Butt Out of Election
abstract: The attorneys general of Pennsylvania, Michigan, Wisconsin and Georgia asked the Supreme Court to reject a lawsuit from Texas seeking to overturn President-elect Joe Biden’s victories.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In blistering language denouncing Republican efforts to subvert the election, the attorneys general for Pennsylvania, Michigan, Wisconsin and Georgia asked the Supreme Court on Thursday to reject a lawsuit that seeks to overturn the victories in those states by President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr., calling the audacious effort an affront to democracy and the rule of law.

headline: ‘Numb’ and ‘Heartbroken,’ the U.S. Confronts Record Virus Deaths
abstract: For the first time, the United States reported more than 3,000 coronavirus deaths in a day. But with cases still rising, experts warn “the worst is yet to come.”
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Lillian Blancas was a fighter, a proud daughter of immigrants, part of the first generation in her family to attend college and a lawyer in El Paso who was on the brink of fulfilling her dream of becoming a judge.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: A panel of experts at the F.D.A. formally recommended that the agency authorize Pfizer’s vaccine.
lead_paragraph: A panel of experts at the Food and Drug Administration formally recommended today that the agency authorize the vaccine. The agency is likely to do so within days, clearing the way for health care workers and nursing home residents to begin receiving it early next week.

headline: Stimulus Deal Falters as McConnell Signals Republican Resistance
abstract: Aides to the senate majority leader privately warned that most Republicans would be unlikely to support an emerging compromise on liability protections and state and local funding.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Efforts to reach a year-end agreement on a stimulus package to prop up the shuddering economy faltered on Thursday as aides to Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, signaled privately that most Republicans were unlikely to endorse an emerging bipartisan compromise without changes.

headline: Covid Meds Are Scarce, but Not for Trump Cronies
abstract: Rudy Giuliani got monoclonal antibodies. You probably can’t.
lead_paragraph: According to a document from the Department of Health and Human Services, a total of 108 doses of Regeneron’s monoclonal antibody cocktail have been allocated to Washington, which had 265 new coronavirus cases on Wednesday alone. Somehow Rudy Giuliani, Donald Trump’s lawyer, got one of those doses. In an interview with a New York radio station on Tuesday, Giuliani did us all the favor of explaining why he qualified for privileged treatment.

headline: Protesters Erect Barricades in Portland to Save a Black Family’s House
abstract: The family lost its home of 60 years to foreclosure after taking out mortgages to pay legal fees. Some advocates say gentrification and skyrocketing prices are driving Black families out of the city.
lead_paragraph: A standoff between the police and protesters over a mixed-race family’s eviction in Portland, Ore., is stirring up old ghosts of segregation and redlining from the 20th century, when Black families moved in for jobs and found that there were only certain places they could live.

headline: Biden Names Two Obama White House Veterans to New Roles
abstract: Susan Rice, who was President Barack Obama’s national security adviser, will lead the Domestic Policy Council. Denis McDonough, Mr. Obama’s chief of staff, was nominated secretary of veterans affairs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. named two senior officials from the Obama White House to key jobs on Thursday, putting Susan Rice, a former national security adviser, in charge of his Domestic Policy Council and nominating President Barack Obama’s chief of staff, Denis McDonough, to be secretary of veterans affairs.

headline: California Travel Restrictions: What You Need to Know
abstract: Restrictions in the state are complicated and changing quickly, leading to confusion about travel rules.
lead_paragraph: California has introduced new restrictions on travel and other aspects of daily life to combat the state’s surge in coronavirus cases and prevent hospitals from being overwhelmed.

headline: Two reasons the Texas election case is faulty: flawed legal theory and statistical fallacy.
abstract: Texas has asked the Supreme Court to reverse the election results, but the case’s legal argument is flawed and its statistical assertion that Joe Biden had a minuscule chance to win is “comical,” experts said.
lead_paragraph: Ken Paxton, the Texas attorney general, has asked the Supreme Court to do something it has never done before: disenfranchise millions of voters in four states and reverse the results of the presidential election.

headline: Investigation of His Son Is Likely to Hang Over Biden as He Takes Office
abstract: Unless the Trump Justice Department clears Hunter Biden, the new president will confront the prospect of his own administration handling an inquiry that could expose his son to criminal prosecution.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The newly disclosed federal tax investigation into his son will test President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s stated commitment to independent law enforcement while leaving him in a no-win situation that could prove distracting at best and politically and legally perilous at worst.

headline: After more than 3,000 U.S. deaths in a day, a warning: ‘The worst is yet to come.’
abstract: The new daily record of coronavirus deaths is a stunning number in and of itself.
lead_paragraph: The new daily record of coronavirus deaths is a stunning number in and of itself.

headline: Police Footage Shows Raid on Florida Data Scientist
abstract: Body camera footage released by the Florida Department of Law Enforcement shows a search this week at the home of Rebekah D. Jones, a data scientist who had managed the state’s coronavirus dashboard.
lead_paragraph: Body camera footage released by the Florida Department of Law Enforcement shows a search this week at the home of Rebekah D. Jones, a data scientist who had managed the state’s coronavirus dashboard.

headline: Israel-Morocco Deal Follows History of Cooperation on Arms and Spying
abstract: For almost 60 years, the two countries, which agreed to normalize ties, have worked together closely but secretly on military and intelligence matters, assassinations, and migration of Jews to Israel.
lead_paragraph: Behind the announcement Thursday that Israel and Morocco will establish their first formal diplomatic ties, there lies almost six decades of close, secret cooperation on intelligence and military matters between two nations that officially did not acknowledge each other.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Jobless Claims Jump, Casting New Shadow Over Economy
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, December 11, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “Mutual aid between unemployed people can only go so far. People are donating $5 to each other’s GoFundMes in a perpetual circle just trying to survive.”

headline: Rep. Max Rose Moves Toward Entering New York City Mayor’s Race
abstract: The Staten Island Democrat, coming off a re-election loss, filed paperwork indicating that he is set to enter an already crowded field.
lead_paragraph: Representative Max Rose, the Staten Island Democrat who was soundly defeated last month in his bid for a second term, signaled on Thursday that he plans to enter an already crowded field in the 2021 mayor’s race in New York City.

headline: Justice Department Executes Man for Murder Committed When He Was 18
abstract: Despite a high-profile clemency campaign by allies of President Trump, the administration executed Brandon Bernard by lethal injection for his role in the 1999 crime.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Despite a high-profile clemency campaign, the Justice Department executed Brandon Bernard by lethal injection on Thursday for his part in a 1999 double murder-robbery when he was 18.

headline: Take Turns, Say
abstract: Find a friend or two to tackle Ari Richter’s Friday puzzle (here we are!).
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — This is Ari Richter’s second Times puzzle (the first was last spring, a Saturday grid), and it’s another excellent themeless challenge with a bunch of good debuts. It also holds a neat surprise, if you like this sort of detail, which is that it’s a pangram — every letter in the alphabet appears at least once in the entries. It’s only the third one this year, and I always imagine a constructor pulling a string here or there to get that “J” or “X” in with as little clunkiness as possible. In this case, mission definitely accomplished.

headline: The Women Faced Off to Play Soccer. One Team Lost Because of Hair Dye.
abstract: A Chinese university team argued that an opposing player’s hair was not “black enough,” according to the rules, and her team forfeited the match.
lead_paragraph: Forget skill, training or even luck. If you’re a female soccer player in China, sometimes victory or defeat comes down to the color of your hair, as one university team recently found out the hard way.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: An F.D.A. panel gives the Pfizer vaccine the green light.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: How the Vaccine Will Get From the Lab to You
abstract: With a promise to deliver millions of doses in the coming weeks, the government and its massive logistical effort to get the vaccine out across the United States are about to be tested.
lead_paragraph: With a promise to deliver millions of doses in the coming weeks, the government and its massive logistical effort to get the vaccine out across the United States are about to be tested.

headline: Reporting on Indigenous Australia
abstract: The more difficult the access to a story, the more often it is worth doing.
lead_paragraph: When I first heard about Australia’s “bush courts,” I knew they were something I wanted to report on. Makeshift courtrooms, fly-in legal services, and Australians processed through that system who neither understood English nor how the courts worked. The details shocked me.

headline: He Seduced Me With Bread
abstract: An Italian woman, trapped in lockdown, takes daily calls from strangers until she finds one who really knows how to cook.
lead_paragraph: Years ago, with a friend, I played one of those psychological games where you begin by listing 15 things you would bring to a desert island and then narrow the list until you’re down to the two most important. By painfully dismissing one cherished item after another, I was left with my final choices: a guitar and “the people I don’t yet know.”

headline: Biden and Harris Are Time’s Persons of the Year for 2020
abstract: The magazine chose the president-elect and the vice president-elect over frontline health care workers (along with Dr. Anthony S. Fauci), the racial justice movement and President Trump.
lead_paragraph: Time magazine on Thursday named President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Vice President-elect Kamala Harris as its persons of the year, citing the weight of the pandemic and racial injustice that will be shouldered by the history-making Democratic ticket.

headline: Jimmy Lai, Media Mogul, Is Charged Under Hong Kong’s Security Law
abstract: Mr. Lai’s case was followed hours later by a disclosure that the authorities in China had detained a Chinese citizen working for Bloomberg News.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — In two strokes unveiled on Friday, the Chinese Communist Party laid out in stark relief the rapidly shrinking space for speech and independent journalism in China.

headline: Word + Quiz: scud
abstract: This word has appeared in four articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: Jimmy Fallon: Trump’s Hanukkah Party Was a ‘Festival of Lies’
abstract: “Even the dreidel was looking at Trump like, ‘Damn, this guy spins more than I do,’” Fallon joked on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Holiday Flicks
abstract: What are your favorite (or not-so-favorite) holiday films?

headline: Midtown Is Reeling. Should Its Offices Become Apartments?
abstract: The pandemic has created a crisis in New York City’s commercial real estate industry. Some leaders think it’s time to reimagine the city’s business districts.
lead_paragraph: The pandemic is pummeling New York City’s commercial real estate industry, one of its main economic engines, threatening the future of the nation’s largest business districts as well as the city’s finances.

headline: The Threat Against New York’s Bodegas
abstract: Bodegas, often seen as safe havens, have been hit by a crime wave during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Australia Scraps Covid-19 Vaccine That Produced H.I.V. False Positives
abstract: Of the dozens of coronavirus vaccines being tested worldwide, the one under development at the University of Queensland was the first to be abandoned.
lead_paragraph: Australia on Friday canceled a roughly $750 million plan for a large order of a locally developed coronavirus vaccine after the inoculation produced false positive test results for H.I.V. in some volunteers participating in a trial study.

headline: News Quiz: Facebook, Universal, Chuck Yeager
abstract: Did you follow the headlines this week?
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the headlines this week?

headline: With F.D.A. approval, Pfizer will ship millions of vaccine doses immediately.
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration authorized Pfizer’s Covid-19 vaccine for emergency use on Friday, clearing the way for millions of highly vulnerable people to begin receiving the vaccine within days.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration authorized Pfizer’s Covid-19 vaccine for emergency use on Friday, clearing the way for millions of highly vulnerable people to begin receiving the vaccine within days.

headline: Just How White Is the Book Industry?
abstract: New data shows the extent of the race problem in the publishing world.
lead_paragraph: New data shows the extent of the race problem in the publishing world.

headline: New in Paperback: ‘Driving While Black’ and ‘Life Isn’t Everything’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: THE DOLPHIN LETTERS, 1970-1979: Elizabeth Hardwick, Robert Lowell, and Their Circle, edited by Saskia Hamilton. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, 560 pp., $22.) “The Dolphin” is the book of poems in which Lowell lifted, and altered, lines from Hardwick’s anguished letters to him after he left her for the British novelist Carolyn Blackwood. “Their circle” includes the likes of Elizabeth Bishop, Adrienne Rich and Mary McCarthy.

headline: What Role Does Religion Play in Your Life?
abstract: How would you describe your spiritual beliefs? Can you pick and choose which aspects of religion to follow?
lead_paragraph: Note: One of the questions in this forum was suggested by Katarina, a student. She asks: “Can you pick and choose which aspects of religion to follow?” If you have an idea for a question inspired by a New York Times article that we should ask in our Student Opinion column, you can submit it here.

headline: Weekly Health Quiz: Exercise, Weight and Covid Deaths
abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Diamonds and Campaign Trails in Houston
abstract: Erin Mincberg and Scotty Spiegel grew up only five blocks apart, but didn’t connect until decades later when he asked for some career advice about the political world.
lead_paragraph: The Westbury Little League is a sprawling collection of baseball diamonds lumped together like Cracker Jacks in Houston. The fields there vary in size to accommodate players at different stages of youth. If you’d walked onto one of the larger fields on a Saturday in the early 1990s, you would likely have found a 12-year-old Scotty Spiegel leaping up to the plate, happily sweating in the Texas sun. If you’d then strolled over to one of the smaller diamonds, you might have seen the opposite image: Erin Mincberg, age 9, somber in her uniform.

headline: They Ended Up Believing in Marriage (and Santa Delivered)
abstract: Michele Pascuzzi and Brian Nowicki were reluctant to marry again. But they found some magic with each other.
lead_paragraph: Michele Pascuzzi and Brian Nowicki were adamant about not dating. Both had been married before — Ms. Pascuzzi was married twice and Mr. Nowicki once. Ms. Pascuzzi had a son; and Mr. Nowicki had a son with his first wife and two stepchildren. When their mutual friends offered to introduce them, each refused.

headline: In Sickness and in Health, They Stayed in Sync
abstract: Jessica Vande Werken and Robin Goode supported each other when Ms. Goode received a breast cancer diagnosis. Almost a year later, they unknowingly made appointments to pick out engagement rings at the same shop, on the same day.
lead_paragraph: In July 2018, Jessica Vande Werken was nervously waiting for her date, Robin Imogene Goode, at Cubbyhole, a bar in Manhattan. They had matched on Tinder, and were meeting in person for the first time. When Ms. Goode walked into the bar, Ms. Vande Werken noticed her immediately.

headline: Winning in the Contest of Love
abstract: Jennifer McClay and Steve Gustafson, who met at Duke University Hospital, won a free wedding package after a friend entered a contest on their behalf.
lead_paragraph: When Jennifer McClay read the letter her friend Hannah Bentley sent to Cates Farm, a Hillsborough, N.C., events space that was holding a contest for essential workers hoping to win a free wedding package, she cried.

headline: The Third Proposal Stuck
abstract: Carl Mumford Jr. and Antia Adam, who met at Savannah State University, broke up shortly after the first two times he proposed. He didn’t give up.
lead_paragraph: Antia Adams couldn’t blame Carl Mumford Jr. for issuing a warning with his February 2019 marriage proposal. “He said, ‘If you lose this one, that’s it,’” Ms. Adams said. Mr. Mumford had already given her two engagement rings. She lost both.

headline: ‘The 46th’: Who Will Replace Trump in the G.O.P.’s Heart?
abstract: Jane Coaston and Sean Trende join Ross to debate whether Republicans will remain the party of Trumpism, post-Trump.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to “The Argument” from your mobile device:

headline: Marking a Missed Wedding Date With a Bouquet
abstract: Karan Ganjawalla and Juhi Kuchroo were married in a quiet ceremony on Thanksgiving after canceling a multiday Indian wedding planned for last May.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Karan Ganjawalla, a 32-year-old maxillofacial surgery resident at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, ditched his scrubs for biking gear on May 23 and made a special house call.

headline: In Life, She Defied Alzheimer’s. In Death, Her Brain May Show How.
abstract: A woman in Colombia with a rare genetic mutation recently made the ultimate donation to science.
lead_paragraph: MEDELLÍN, Colombia — Aliria Rosa Piedrahita de Villegas carried a rare genetic mutation that had all but guaranteed she would develop Alzheimer’s disease in her 40s. But only at age 72 did she experience the first symptoms of it. Her dementia was not terribly advanced when she died from cancer on Nov. 10, a month shy of her 78th birthday, in her daughter’s home on a hillside that overlooks the city.

headline: Saving a Cactus, and Its Prickly Owner
abstract: I didn’t think I’d ever get over the loss of my best friend. Then her daughter came to live with me.
lead_paragraph: “Will you accept a new tenant and a puppy?” Ceece texted.

headline: Dorian Electra, a Queer Pop Star Who Defies Genres
abstract: The singer recently released music that tangles together metal, dubstep and hard-core punk, “all these hypermasculine, testosterone-filled genres.”
lead_paragraph: Name: Dorian Electra

headline: 18 Things That Happened for the First Time in 2020
abstract: Surprising and serious events and trends noted for the first time ever this year.
lead_paragraph: This is an article from Turning Points, a special section that explores what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead.

headline: They Had Given Up on Love
abstract: Luke Rivett and Sunney Kohlhoss met at a Los Angeles bar last year. “We talked for a few minutes,” he said. “I told her, ‘I’m going to marry you.’”
lead_paragraph: When Luke Rivett spotted Sunney Kohlhoss on March 1, 2019 at the Well, a bar in Los Angeles, both had recently given up on love, resolving halfheartedly, that they would be single forever.

headline: It’s Not Just You: Picking a Health Insurance Plan Is Really Hard
abstract: Most Americans make poor choices. So do most professional insurance brokers, a new study finds. But robots may help.
lead_paragraph: Anya Samek, an economist, has found that consumers make better choices among health plans when presented with a few simple calculations. So when she switched jobs last year and had to choose a plan herself, she tried entering the various plan features into a spreadsheet to replicate her tool. She gave up, determining the task too complicated.

headline: Is Andrew Yang Running for Mayor? All Signs Point to Yes
abstract: The former Democratic presidential candidate is meeting with New York City power brokers and telling them he intends to enter the race to succeed Bill de Blasio.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Yang, the former tech executive who gained a national following as a Democratic presidential candidate, has been privately telling New York City leaders that he intends to run for mayor next year.

headline: The Wild Ways Parents Preserve Their Kids’ Memories
abstract: There’s nothing wrong with collecting belly buttons, teeth and locks of hair. It’s just part of the process.
lead_paragraph: The large, wooden box on the floor of my mom’s bedroom reminded me of a pirate’s treasure chest. We were never allowed to open it ourselves, but every so often, my mother would sit my sisters and me down to share the booty within: locks of our hair, worn photographs of us sitting on Santa’s lap, pictures we drew that she couldn’t bear to part with, a ceramic pig I made in grade school. Her face would soften as she would recount the details of each piece.

headline: Piano Bars and Jazz Clubs Reopened, Calling Live Music ‘Incidental’
abstract: Before Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo moved to ban indoor dining again in New York City, several music clubs had begun offering performances again that they claimed were background music.
lead_paragraph: Although most indoor live performances have been banned in New York since the coronavirus began its deadly spread in March, about a dozen people turned up Wednesday night at Birdland, the jazz club near Times Square, for a 7 p.m. performance that was billed as dinner with live jazz. They had reservations.

headline: A Single Senator Dashes Hopes for Latino and Women’s Museums — For Now
abstract: Senator Mike Lee, Republican of Utah, blocked the creation of Smithsonian museums honoring women and Latinos, warning they would worsen societal divides.
lead_paragraph: For more than two decades, Latinos and their allies in Congress have been fighting to approve the creation of a National Museum of the American Latino in Washington. The push to create a national women’s history museum has taken about as long.

headline: How John Foley, Peloton Co-Founder, Spends His Sundays
abstract: A year ago Peloton was the butt of a holiday joke. Not anymore.
lead_paragraph: John Foley, the chief executive of Peloton, seems a bit uncomfortable with sporting a company logo as a fashion choice.

headline: Jobless Benefits Saved Them, Until States Wanted the Money Back
abstract: A pandemic relief program allows no forgiveness of overpayments, even when recipients are not at fault and the funds are already spent.
lead_paragraph: Unemployment payments that looked like a lifeline may now, for many, become their ruin.

headline: That New York Vibe and a Life in San Diego
abstract: Ana Bowens and Benjamin Schenk, who met at Dartmouth, had a pared-down guest list and ditched the reception dance floor in favor of contests and talent shows.
lead_paragraph: By now, 2020 wedding guests have read the boilerplate. “In light of Covid-19, we want to let you know your health and safety are our top priority,” banners at the top of wedding websites say. This is often followed by this year’s version of the big reveal: whether the wedding is on or off.

headline: How Neighbors Are Coming Together to Buy Local for the Holidays
abstract: “I’m not buying anything from freaking Jeff Bezos,” says a member of a Red Hook business group.
lead_paragraph: Some New Yorkers, in an effort to support entrepreneurs instead of large corporations, are creating hyperlocal shopping experiences this holiday season. Facebook groups, Instagram accounts and neighborhood holiday markets — think of them as micro-Etsy projects, organized via social media — have cropped up to showcase local talents and businesses.

headline: Co-ops in the Time of Covid
abstract: New York’s enduring vertical village, the cooperative, has faced a variety of challenges during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Of the hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers who left the city in the early months of the pandemic, there are a few that Lori Levine van Arsdale won’t miss.

headline: The New Influencer Capital of America
abstract: After years of being passed over by brands and management companies despite driving the internet’s biggest trends, Black influencers in Atlanta are working to shift the paradigm.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — It’s no secret Atlanta is one of the nation’s great culture capitals, home to many power brokers in music, fashion and the arts — a city that, since the 1980s, has produced some of the biggest names in rap, R&B and hip-hop, and over the last decade, seen explosive growth in its entertainment industry (thanks, in part, to Georgia’s generous tax credits).

headline: We Must Do More to Stop Dangerous Doctors in a Pandemic
abstract: Some have crossed the line from free speech to medical practice — or something akin to malpractice.
lead_paragraph: It’s bad enough when our political leaders promote quack theories about the coronavirus and its treatment. But what do we do about the doctors who enable them and use their medical authority to promote pseudoscience?

headline: Manhattan D.A. Intensifies Investigation of Trump
abstract: Prosecutors have recently interviewed employees of President Trump’s lender and insurance brokerage, in the latest indication that he still faces the potential threat of criminal charges once he leaves office.
lead_paragraph: State prosecutors in Manhattan have interviewed several employees of President Trump’s bank and insurance broker in recent weeks, according to people with knowledge of the matter, significantly escalating an investigation into the president that he is powerless to stop.

headline: College Sports Has Reported at Least 6,629 Virus Cases. There Are Many More.
abstract: The N.C.A.A. does not track coronavirus cases, but a New York Times analysis shows the pandemic’s toll across college athletics. Many universities have kept their case counts from the public.
lead_paragraph: More than 6,600 college athletes, coaches and staff members have tested positive for the coronavirus this year, a dispiriting measure of the pathogen’s reach across the United States and its spread among some of the country’s most closely monitored people.

headline: The ‘Trump Won’ Farce Isn’t Funny Anymore
abstract: Republicans are now seriously arguing that elections are legitimate only when their side wins.
lead_paragraph: To tell a joke to a crowd is to learn a little something about the people who laugh.

headline: What’s Fauci Reading? We Take Another Look at Celebrity Bookshelves
abstract: This year is finally coming to an end, so here is one last peek at the books behind Chris Rock, Jeff Bezos, Jemele Hill, Julia Louis-Dreyfus and more.
lead_paragraph: As 2020 winds down and we look back at our pandemic year, it’s possible, through the murk of loneliness and illness, to see the few bright spots that existed for people who love books. We had the chance to peruse a lot of strangers’ bookshelves — nearly every time we turned on the television or began a video call.

headline: A State Scientist Questioned Florida’s Virus Data. Now Her Home’s Been Raided.
abstract: Rebekah Jones became an unlikely celebrity when she lost her job running the state’s coronavirus data dashboard. Police say a breach at the Department of Health was traced to her computer.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The complicated story of how a Florida data scientist responsible for managing the state’s coronavirus numbers wound up with state police agents brandishing guns in her house this week began seven long months ago, when the scientist, Rebekah D. Jones, was removed from her post at the Florida Department of Health.

headline: The Bittersweet Tale of a Diner, a Toy Shop and a Changing New York
abstract: One is expanding. One is closing. But not all is lost.
lead_paragraph: Over time, certain city blocks become niche shopping and dining hubs, destinations that are quintessentially New York, marked by local history and personalities, while defining the broader neighborhood.

headline: The Virus, the Bats and Us
abstract: They probably spread the virus that’s killing humans. We almost certainly spread the fungus that’s killing them.
lead_paragraph: The order of animals known as Chiroptera, the bats, enjoys a mixed reputation among humans. I’m putting this politely: They have been calumniated and abused for centuries.

headline: Argentina Moves Toward Legal Abortion Amid Push for Women’s Rights
abstract: Argentina’s President Alberto Fernández has made the rights of women and of gay and transgender people central to his government, even through a recession and a pandemic.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Argentine lawmakers took a major step on Friday toward legalizing abortion and fulfilling a promise of President Alberto Fernández, who has made women’s rights a central tenet of his government.

headline: Bonus: Kara Swisher and Ben Smith Debrief on Jason Kilar
abstract: It potentially involves a head on a platter.
lead_paragraph: This week, Kara Swisher interviewed WarnerMedia’s chief executive, Jason Kilar, fresh on the heels of the announcement that Warner Bros. will release its 2021 film slate in theaters and on its streaming site, HBO Max, simultaneously. (If you missed that episode — scroll back and hit play! Or click here if you’re on the World Wide Web).

headline: A Guide to Georgia’s Senate Runoffs
abstract: Georgia flipped blue for Joe Biden. Now two costly battles there will decide control of the Senate.
lead_paragraph: In three weeks, an election will take place that could be as important as the presidential vote in determining the course of the next four years.

headline: How to Rediscover the Art of Bipartisan Deal Making
abstract: A group of experts gathered to debate the prospects for compromise in an era of partisanship.
lead_paragraph: Months of negotiations and competing pandemic relief proposals have not yet yielded a deal, prompting lawmakers in Washington recently to extend the deadline for talks. A $908 billion package born from compromise, proposed by a group in the House and the Senate who staked a middle ground between Democrats’ proposed $2 trillion and Republicans’ $500 billion “skinny” bill, is at the center of discussions.

headline: Female Workers Could Take Another Pandemic Hit: To Their Retirements
abstract: Unequal job losses now will translate into smaller nest eggs and Social Security benefits down the road.
lead_paragraph: During the first months of the pandemic, Leah Tyrrell found that she could pull off a balancing act: working in sales for a San Diego clothing maker and caring for her three young daughters at home. Her hours had been reduced, and working remotely in the morning left her time to be with the children the rest of the day.

headline: Secrecy surrounds the reporting of Covid-19 cases in college athletics.
abstract: More than 6,600 college athletes, coaches and staff members have tested positive for the coronavirus this year, a dispiriting measure of the pathogen’s reach across the United States and its spread among some of the country’s most closely monitored people.
lead_paragraph: More than 6,600 college athletes, coaches and staff members have tested positive for the coronavirus this year, a dispiriting measure of the pathogen’s reach across the United States and its spread among some of the country’s most closely monitored people.

headline: Everyone Gather Round the Squirrel Table. (Chipmunks Too!)
abstract: Enticing wildlife to the backyard, with tiny furniture and elaborate meals, has consoled some Americans in quarantine.
lead_paragraph: Thelonious Munk sits down for an alfresco meal at a wooden table. He eagerly picks up a taco prepared with a walnut flour tortilla, which he sniffs before taking a few nibbles. He lingers for a bit after his meal before leaving. He scampers into a bush and through a tunnel — because he isn’t checking out the latest vegan restaurant, but is instead a wild chipmunk.

headline: Falsehoods and Threats
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s attempts to overturn the election result are very unlikely to succeed. For that reason, the effort can sometimes seem like a publicity stunt — an effort by Trump to raise money and burnish his image with his supporters.

headline: ‘The Bee Gees’ Review: Night Fever, for Decades
abstract: The documentary “How Can You Mend a Broken Heart,” from Frank Marshall, strives to paint a wider picture of the band often associated with its disco hits.
lead_paragraph: “The Bee Gees: How Can You Mend a Broken Heart” pays tribute to the Gibb brothers with a tour of their pop music reign. Grooving through the decades, this entertaining documentary aspires to prove that the Bee Gees were more than a hitmaker for disco nightclubs. Rather, Barry, Maurice and Robin were master songwriters and chameleons, continually reinventing themselves to harmonize with the times.

headline: ‘Giving Voice’ Review: August Wilson Is Uplifting a New Generation
abstract: Netflix’s inspirational documentary follows talented theater kids who are devoting themselves to Wilson’s writing.
lead_paragraph: The everyday hopes and heartbreaks of African-Americans were dramatized in August Wilson’s 10-play American Century Cycle. And every year, since Wilson’s death in 2005, thousands of students from 12 different cities vie for the chance to perform a monologue from one of his plays in a competition’s final round on Broadway. James D. Stern and Fernando Villena’s uplifting documentary “Giving Voice” (streaming on Netflix) further explores this competition and explains how the playwright’s legacy is inspiring a new generation.

headline: Biden Clashes With the Left
abstract: Democrats are trying to work out their differences as Biden prepares to take office. It’s Friday, and this is your politics tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: Democrats are trying to work out their differences as Biden prepares to take office. But across party lines, a lot feels unbridgeable. It’s Friday, and this is your politics tip sheet.

headline: Airbnb’s Stunning I.P.O.
abstract: The home-rental company’s stock debut briefly left its own chief speechless.
lead_paragraph: Brian Chesky, Airbnb’s co-founder and C.E.O., was left momentarily speechless on live television yesterday after being told his company’s shares were set to begin trading at $139, after its I.P.O. had priced them at $68. (They eventually closed at $144.71.) He may as well have been speaking for Wall Street and Silicon Valley, which were left agog by a frenzy for tech I.P.O.s this week.

headline: E.U. Agrees to Slash Carbon Emissions by 2030
abstract: The agreement calls for European Union countries to cut their collective greenhouse gas emissions by 55 percent from 1990 levels, a more substantial reduction than previously proposed.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — After an all-night negotiating session, European Union leaders agreed on Friday morning to cut net carbon emissions by 55 percent in the next decade from levels measured in 1990, overcoming the concerns of nations still heavily dependent on coal and taking a critical step in the effort to become climate-neutral by 2050.

headline: Hezbollah Member Sentenced in Absentia Over Killing of Ex-Premier in Lebanon
abstract: A United Nations-backed tribunal in The Hague handed down the symbolic life sentence in connection with the 2005 assassination of Rafik Hariri.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A United Nations-backed tribunal in The Hague on Friday sentenced a member of the Hezbollah militant group to life in prison after convicting him in absentia of conspiring in the 2005 car-bomb attack that killed former Prime Minister Rafik Hariri of Lebanon.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘Tone Is Hard to Grasp Online. Can Tone Indicators Help?’
abstract: In this lesson, students will explore the challenges of communication in the age of the internet — and what we can do to make it better.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “Tone Is Hard to Grasp Online. Can Tone Indicators Help?” by Ezra Marcus with videos by Shane O’Neill

headline: Climate Change and California’s Favorite Trees
abstract: Friday: How wildfires could threaten the coast redwood, the Joshua tree and the giant sequoia. Also: What to know about California’s contact tracing app.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: ‘Safety’ Review: It Takes a University to Raise a Child
abstract: This Disney+ film isn’t your typical sports or adversity movie; it asks questions of what educational institutions owe to their community.
lead_paragraph: They say it takes a village to raise a child, but in “Safety,” it takes an entire university campus to do so. Overly sentimental traps line the plot of the film, streaming on Disney+. But it scores points for giving its lead characters complicated situations, emotional depth and political dimension.

headline: A Top House Democrat Prods Biden to Reopen E.U. Trade Talks
abstract: The chairman of the powerful Ways and Means Committee countered the president-elect’s pledge to focus first on domestic priorities.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The chairman of the powerful House Ways and Means Committee urged the incoming administration to renew trade negotiations with the European Union, countering a pledge by President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. to postpone any new trade talks until after the United States has made significant domestic investments.

headline: How Not to Burn Down Your House With a Space Heater
abstract: The tiny radiators, while useful, cause thousands of fires and hundreds of deaths each year. Here are some tips to stay safe while you stay warm.
lead_paragraph: One day last winter, I was down in my unfinished basement working on some music, and my fingers were too cold to play the guitar. So I grabbed a space heater that I was long-term testing for Wirecutter, placed it on the wooden workbench where my audio workstation was set up, and plugged it into the nearest power strip — the one my Marshall amplifier was also plugged into.

headline: It’s ‘Debt Parking’: When Fake Debts End Up on Your Credit Report
abstract: The F.T.C. recently took its first legal action to stop the fraud. Consumers may not know the debts are on their reports until they apply for a loan.
lead_paragraph: Consider this unnerving situation: You apply for a loan only to learn that your credit report is marred by a delinquent debt — one that you have already paid or maybe don’t recognize.

headline: Zoom Classes. No Chance Meetings. Is Virtual Business School Worth the Cost?
abstract: Students in the M.B.A. class of 2021 have been hit particularly hard. The degree can cost $200,000, not counting lost wages.
lead_paragraph: Getting a master’s in business administration is about a lot more than book learning.

headline: At the U.S. Women’s Open, a Love Story
abstract: They met playing against each other in rec league hockey. Now Alena Sharp and her caddie, Sarah Bowman, are honeymooning on the golf course.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The honeymoon began, as so many do for golf-obsessed newlyweds, with 18 holes.

headline: New Star of ‘The Prom’ Sees a Chance to Make L.G.B.T.Q. Characters Visible
abstract: Like her character, Jo Ellen Pellman identifies as queer, and she is making her film debut in the Netflix musical alongside A-listers like Meryl Streep and Nicole Kidman.
lead_paragraph: During her second day ever on a film set, Jo Ellen Pellman came face to face with an irate Meryl Streep.

headline: Trump slams the F.D.A. ahead of expected vaccine authorization.
abstract: President Trump lashed out anew at the Food and Drug Administration in a Friday morning tweet, attacking the agency’s commissioner, Dr. Stephen M. Hahn, by name for not approving a Covid-19 vaccine faster.
lead_paragraph: President Trump lashed out anew at the Food and Drug Administration in a Friday morning tweet, attacking the agency’s commissioner, Dr. Stephen M. Hahn, by name for not approving a Covid-19 vaccine faster.

headline: Black Ballerina, Playing a Swan, Says She Was Told to Color Her Skin
abstract: The dancer with the Staatsballett Berlin says being directed to use white makeup to perform in “Swan Lake” was one of the racially insensitive incidents she has faced.
lead_paragraph: Chloé Lopes Gomes had done her hair and makeup and fixed the feathered swan headdress in place before the rehearsal in February. Then, she later recounted, she repeatedly dipped a wet sponge into a pot of white pancake makeup, applying it carefully to her face, neck and upper body.

headline: Magic Shows and Inner Beauty
abstract: How André Leon Talley, Sofia Carson and Stuart Weitzman are giving back during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: With the New York charity circuit on hiatus, here is how some philanthropists and society figures are spending their time and resources during the coronavirus crisis.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Gabrielle Hamilton’s marvelous new recipe for white borscht may just become one of your favorites.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Gabrielle Hamilton is in The Times this week with a marvelous new recipe for white borscht (above) that pays homage to the $2.50 bowls of soup she used to eat in her early days in the East Village, when Polish and Ukrainian diners were thick on the ground.

headline: The State of the Virus This Week
abstract: A look at this week’s news from the team tracking the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: A look at this week’s news from the team tracking the coronavirus.

headline: How to Save Phallic Flowers From Being Inbred to Extinction
abstract: To preserve corpse flowers and other rare plants, botanic gardens are borrowing studbooks, an approach used by zoos and horse breeders.
lead_paragraph: To save endangered plant species, horticulturalists are using a tactic they’ve borrowed from horse breeders and zookeepers, building breeding registries or “studbooks” to avoid inbreeding. Naturally, they’re starting with a plant with a Latin name that means “large misshapen penis.”

headline: Texas replies to 4 states in its lawsuit to overturn their election results.
abstract: The justices of the Supreme Court met Friday morning, by telephone, for their usual private conference to discuss which cases they might add to their docket.
lead_paragraph: The justices of the Supreme Court met Friday morning, by telephone, for their usual private conference to discuss which cases they might add to their docket.

headline: Bryn Terfel Returns to the Metropolitan Opera. (Sort Of.)
abstract: A holiday recital, streamed live from Wales, will be this star singer’s first headlining performance for the Met since 2012.
lead_paragraph: The airy studio where Bryn Terfel practices is set a good few yards from the house in Penarth, Wales, that he shares with his wife and two young children. Given his thunderous bass-baritone voice, which has roared through the great roles of Mozart, Puccini, Verdi and Wagner at opera houses around the world over the past 30 years, this is probably essential to family sanity.

headline: Shaming People for Their Covid Choices
abstract: Is the societal shaming of those who refuse to comply with public health advisories an effective way to end bad behavior?
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Beyond the Bob Dylan Deal: A Word From the Music World
abstract: The Artist Rights Alliance says it is fighting for higher baseline royalties for musicians and more equitable rules of the digital road.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Indoor Dining Will Shut Down in New York City Again
abstract: The decision, intended to slow a second wave of coronavirus cases, is a blow to the struggling restaurant industry.
lead_paragraph: Indoor dining will once again be barred in New York City restaurants starting on Monday, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Friday, in a significant reversal of the city’s reopening that comes as officials try to halt the escalation of a second wave of the coronavirus and avoid a broader shutdown.

headline: The Mixed Message of Earth-Friendly Design
abstract: “Broken Nature” at MoMA offers up a trove of ‘restorative’ projects. Does buying more elegant objects help heal the planet?
lead_paragraph: The design store of the Museum of Modern Art sits on the south side of 53rd Street in New York, just up from the ritzy shops of Fifth Avenue. It is dedicated to adding more fabulous objects to the vast supply of goods our households — and planet — are bursting with.

headline: FKA twigs Sues Shia LaBeouf, Citing ‘Relentless’ Abusive Relationship
abstract: The lawsuit, filed in Los Angeles by the musician, accuses the actor of sexual battery, assault and infliction of emotional distress.
lead_paragraph: Just after Valentine’s Day in 2019, the musician FKA twigs was in a car speeding toward Los Angeles. At the wheel was her boyfriend, the actor Shia LaBeouf. He was driving recklessly, she said in a lawsuit filed on Friday, removing his seatbelt and threatening to crash unless she professed her love for him.

headline: The Pandemic’s Toll on College Football
abstract: A Times analysis uncovered a sobering number of coronavirus cases in college athletic departments.
lead_paragraph: This year’s college football season got off to a rocky start as parents protested attempts to cancel the season and President Trump waded into the debate. And it has taken some major hits, with high-profile coaches and players testing positive for the coronavirus and team outbreaks interrupting marquee games.

headline: Gwen Stefani’s Ska-Pop Flashback, and 10 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Sturgill Simpson, John Carpenter, Elle King and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: A Traditional, but Unexpected, Christmas Showstopper
abstract: Yotam Ottolenghi usually leaves the Christmas meals to his husband. But dessert is where he shines, making this riff on the classic bûche de Noël.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — I grew up largely unaware of Christmas.

headline: Roast a Chicken
abstract: Mark Bittman’s simple recipe can yield days of soul-sustaining dinners.
lead_paragraph: Hello and welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes. On Tuesday, I roasted a chicken for dinner, which I don’t do nearly enough. It’s typically faster to cook chicken breasts, thighs or legs instead, and easier to serve them too (no carving). Those little advantages spell big impact when everyone is hungry and cranky.

headline: Give Virus Alert Apps a Shot
abstract: These Google and Apple apps work and aren’t stealing all your data. More people should use them.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: Norman Abramson, Pioneer Behind Wireless Networks, Dies at 88
abstract: His ALOHAnet, designed a half-century ago in Hawaii, was a precursor to the technology used in today’s smartphones and home WiFi networks.
lead_paragraph: Norman Abramson, the leader of a group of scientists and engineers who pioneered the development of wireless computer networks, died on Dec. 1 at his home in San Francisco. He was 88.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: The best actors of 2020. Barack Obama on his best-selling memoir. The rise and fall of a celebrity pastor. An attempt at counting Australia’s koalas. And more.
lead_paragraph: The best actors of 2020. Barack Obama on his best-selling memoir. The rise and fall of a celebrity pastor. An attempt at counting Australia’s koalas. And more.

headline: Pfizer’s Covid Vaccine and Allergies: How Concerned Should You Be?
abstract: British health officials recommended that people with severe allergy reactions not be given the vaccine. Such reactions to vaccines are rare, even in people who have allergies to food or bee stings.
lead_paragraph: The decision by British drug regulators to recommend against use of the coronavirus vaccine made by Pfizer and BioNTech in people who have a history of severe allergic reactions has raised a number of concerns.

headline: After Nagorno-Karabakh War, Trauma, Tragedy and Devastation
abstract: For Armenians uprooted from their homes, and for Azerbaijanis returning to uninhabitable towns, “It’s going to be very hard to forgive.”
lead_paragraph: FIZULI, Azerbaijan — Crossing into territory that Azerbaijan recently recaptured from Armenia is a journey into a devastated wasteland reminiscent of a World War I battlefield. The road passes miles of abandoned trenches and bunkers, and village after village of ruins, the white stones of homesteads scattered, every movable item — roofs, doors, window frames — picked clean.

headline: ‘The Mandalorian’ Season 2, Episode 7 Recap: Face-off on Morak
abstract: Mando joins forces with an old enemy, just one of several major compromises he makes in hopes of rescuing Grogu.
lead_paragraph: It was bound to happen. All season long, Mando has been suffering loss after loss. The Child’s floating transport-egg? Totaled. The Razor Crest? Destroyed. Grogu himself? Kidnapped. So it was inevitable that at some point, Mando was going to have to give up what has mattered to him more than anything for most of his life: his helmet.

headline: Brittanya Karma, German-Vietnamese Social Media Star, Dies at 29
abstract: She used her social media clout to preach and model self-confidence. She died of complications of Covid-19 in a Hamburg hospital.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: How to Make a Spectacular Holiday Trifle
abstract: Flamboyant, fruity and exceedingly merry, trifles are a show-off dessert with a self-effacing name.
lead_paragraph: Of all the British puddings with their whimsical names — the roly-poly, the spotted dick, the whim wham and the Eton mess — none is as popular on this side of the pond as a custardy, boozy, cream-topped trifle.

headline: ‘Evermore,’ Taylor Swift’s ‘Folklore’ Sequel, Is a Journey Deeper Inward
abstract: The singer and songwriter’s July album traded glossy sheen for an acoustic-Minimalistic palette. A second album with the same collaborators moves even further from her pop past.
lead_paragraph: Sequels are always tricky. The original is a creative leap; the follow-up is likely to be incremental. Until now, Taylor Swift has switched up her collaborators and general sound with each album. But she has rightly billed “Evermore,” her surprise-release ninth album, as the “sister” to the one she released less than five months ago, “Folklore.”

headline: The Champions League’s New Twist: Injury Roulette
abstract: With muscle injuries rising and an unforgiving, pandemic-compressed schedule looming, Europe might not crown its best team this season, but the one that’s still standing.
lead_paragraph: The procession was nearly over. Ninety-five of the 96 games that constitute the group phase of the Champions League, six weeks of phony war that largely serve to check boxes, cross Ts and dot Is, were complete. Most of the heavyweights had long since advanced to the knockout rounds.

headline: German Cultural Leaders Warn Against Ban on Israel Sanctions Movement
abstract: Signatories of an open letter say a parliamentary resolution declaring the campaign anti-Semitic has led to self-censorship and is stifling artistic expression.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN —  For months, the leaders of dozens of Germany’s most prominent cultural institutions met in secret, swapping stories of self-censorship, of hours spent worrying about the social media histories of artists or scholars they wanted to invite to their programs, and fears for their futures, if they slipped up.

headline: Senate Sends Military Bill to Trump’s Desk, Spurning His Veto Threat
abstract: The move raised the prospect of a legislative showdown in the president’s final weeks in office on the bill that authorizes pay for the troops.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate overwhelmingly passed a sweeping military policy bill on Friday that would require that Confederate names be stripped from American military bases, clearing the measure for enactment and sending it to President Trump’s desk in defiance of his threats of a veto.

headline: Dreaming About the Ideal Library
abstract: If your fantasies turn toward curling up with a book or perusing endless miles of shelves, we have some food for your imagination.

headline: An Impressive Centerpiece in Just Five Ingredients
abstract: The year has been difficult. Your holiday dinner — a gorgeous slab of salmon cooked beneath a simple glaze — doesn’t have to be.
lead_paragraph: Savory-sweet fish, topped with tangles of herbs and bright lemon juice, looks and tastes like a celebration for your pandemic pod. There’s an unexpected inverse relationship between how easy it is to make this dish and how special it feels when it’s served. A four-ingredient, five-minute glaze coats a single slab of salmon, and the whole thing comes together in under 30 minutes.

headline: 4 Ways to Feel Less Lonely Over the Holidays
abstract: As the weather turns colder and states implement new lockdown restrictions, try one of these ideas to connect with others.
lead_paragraph: As the weather turns colder and states implement new lockdown restrictions, try one of these ideas to connect with others.

headline: Snow Leopards Are the Latest Cats to Be Infected With the Coronavirus
abstract: Lions and tigers had already contracted the virus, but have recovered.
lead_paragraph: Snow leopards at the Louisville Zoo are the latest animals to be infected with the coronavirus.

headline: Jo Nesbo Talks About ‘The Kingdom’
abstract: Nesbo discusses his latest novel, and David Michaelis talks about his new biography of Eleanor Roosevelt.
lead_paragraph: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen

headline: Giannis Antetokounmpo Has Plenty of Pens. But Will He Sign?
abstract: The Milwaukee Bucks superstar was gifted pens by many of his teammates in hopes he would sign a so-called supermax deal with the team. In a complicated business, it’s not that simple.
lead_paragraph: When the Milwaukee Bucks showed up for training camp on Sunday, Khris Middleton presented his teammate Giannis Antetokounmpo with a gift for his 26th birthday: a pen. Antetokounmpo did not understand its significance at first.

headline: Comfort Viewing: 3 Reasons I Love ‘Happy Endings’
abstract: In its day, this hangout comedy was lumped in with “Friends.” But its crisp, rat-a-tat style is more like “30 Rock.”
lead_paragraph: In a second-season episode of “Happy Endings,” the much-loved but little-watched comedy that ran on ABC from 2011 to 2013, the show acknowledged a comparison that had been dogging it since its premiere.

headline: ‘Wander Darkly’ Review: After Death, a Fractured Life
abstract: In this drama, Sienna Miller plays a woman who gets to witness her own funeral after a car crash.
lead_paragraph: Surviving a car crash, even a minor one, is a singular experience. In “Wander Darkly,” a film written and directed by Tara Miele, Adrienne (Sienna Miller) has an extra-singular experience — she dies in her auto accident, but lives on.

headline: Behind the Cover: Great Performers
abstract: A look at the best screen actors of 2020

headline: Love Letter: He Had Her at Sourdough
abstract: Plus: When digital dates fizzle in real life.
lead_paragraph: Many extroverts have gone to extreme measures for a social fix during the pandemic. Albertina Coacci, a self-proclaimed people person, turned to daily phone calls with strangers to pass the time while in lockdown in Italy. What started as a harmless habit soon led to an affair of sorts with a man who spoke her love language: baking.

headline: For Biden’s Economic Team, an Early Focus on Climate
abstract: In announcing key economic advisers in the White House and the cabinet, the president-elect has emphasized action to boost clean energy and reduce emissions
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The video rollouts of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s pick for Treasury secretary, Janet L. Yellen, and National Economic Council director, Brian Deese, began biographically. But they quickly shifted to focus on an issue that could distinguish Mr. Biden’s core economic team from its predecessors: climate change.

headline: The Faces Behind the Covid Statistics
abstract: A reader praises a special section about how people in a coronavirus epicenter in Queens were affected. Also: Trying to undo the presidential election; reforming the Senate; the drug war in Colombia.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Vaccines Are Coming. A Divided and Distrustful America Awaits.
abstract: A vast majority of people will need to be vaccinated to create a decisive decline in infections. Health officials are scrambling to make that happen.
lead_paragraph: As the Lopez family of Truckee, Calif., gathered to prepare dinner on a recent evening, one subject dominated the conversation: the coronavirus vaccine that will soon be shipped out across the country, giving Americans the first concrete hope that the pandemic will eventually end.

headline: Here’s what went viral online this week.
abstract: As Covid-19 killed thousands, the biggest stories on social media were about immigration, K-pop and the death of a “Friday” star.
lead_paragraph: Here at Daily Distortions, we try to debunk false and misleading information that has gone viral. We also want to give you a sense of how popular that misinformation is, in the context of what is being discussed on social media. With the help of NewsWhip, a firm that compiles social media performance data, we made a list of the 10 most-engaged stories of the week in the United States. (NewsWhip tracks the number of reactions, shares and comments each URL receives on Facebook, as well as shares on Pinterest and by a group of influential users on Twitter.)

headline: Their Team Almost Left Town. Now It’s Playing for a Title.
abstract: Fan activism, public pressure and new owners kept the Columbus Crew in Ohio. On Saturday, the team will try to pay back its supporters by winning M.L.S. Cup.
lead_paragraph: The Columbus Crew is not supposed to be here right now.

headline: Australia Scraps Coronavirus Vaccine
abstract: Prime Minister Scott Morrison of Australia on Friday canceled a large order of a developed coronavirus vaccine after not having the approval from the Therapeutic Goods Administration, the country’s drug regulator.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Scott Morrison of Australia on Friday canceled a large order of a developed coronavirus vaccine after not having the approval from the Therapeutic Goods Administration, the country’s drug regulator.

headline: On Barack Obama’s Memoir and Other Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers respond to recent issues of the Sunday Book Review.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Brian Kemp Cast His Lot With Trump, and Has Now Paid the Price
abstract: Mr. Kemp rose to Georgia’s governorship with the help of President Trump, but his refusal to try to overturn the state’s election results has drawn Mr. Trump’s ire — and may affect his political future.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Few politicians have been both elevated and diminished by the vicissitudes of President Trump like Brian Kemp, the Republican governor of Georgia.

headline: Progressive Groups Urge Biden to Move Quickly on Diverse Slate of Judges
abstract: The president-elect faces pressure to install a diverse group of progressives in the courts, but the prospect of a Republican-controlled Senate looms as an obstacle.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hours after Joseph R. Biden Jr. was projected as the winner of the presidential election last month, Russ Feingold, the former Democratic senator who now leads the progressive American Constitution Society, delivered the names of scores of carefully screened candidates for federal judicial posts to top Biden transition officials.

headline: Our Critics’ Top Picks of 2020
abstract: The great film, TV, performance, art and books that emerged in a not-so-great year.
lead_paragraph: The great film, TV, performance, art and books that emerged in a not-so-great year.

headline: The Biggest Casting News From Disney’s Investor Day
