abstract: “Black Panther 2” will not recast King T’Challa. Harrison Ford is picking up the hat and whip again. And “Star Wars” recruited Rosario Dawson for her own show.
lead_paragraph: In unveiling a huge raft of content coming to theaters and its streaming service at a four-hour investor presentation on Thursday, Disney announced major cast news for many of its highest profile properties, including Pixar, Marvel and “Star Wars.”

headline: Tommy Lister, Actor Who Menaced as Deebo in ‘Friday,’ Is Dead at 62
abstract: The actor was found dead in his California home on Thursday after friends and business associates could not reach him, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Tommy Lister, a 6-foot-5-inch actor nicknamed Tiny who played the hulking neighborhood bully Deebo in the “Friday” films, has died at his home in Marina del Rey, Calif. He was 62.

headline: It’s In-Law Season. Here’s How to Get Along.
abstract: In-laws are often thrust into life’s most intimate moments without much agreement on how things should be handled. It can make these relationships … complicated.
lead_paragraph: — Geoffrey Greif, a co-author of “In-Law Relationships: Mothers, Daughters, Fathers, and Sons.”

headline: NYT Cooking’s 20 Most Popular Recipes of 2020
abstract: Caramelized shallot pasta, the perfect chocolate chip cookies, sour cream and onion chicken: These are the recipes that kept readers coming back for more.
lead_paragraph: The year 2020 saw a lot of unexpected food trends: the rise of the bean, so many pastas and readers flocking to home cooking. These are our top 20 recipes by traffic, the recipes that readers came back to time and time again.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week 🌙
abstract: President Trump and his team are still providing a plethora of fodder for late-night hosts. Here are some highlights.
lead_paragraph: President Trump and his team are still providing a plethora of fodder for late-night hosts. Here are some highlights.

headline: As two-thirds of House Republicans support the Texas election suit, a Democrat called them ‘traitors.’
abstract: With nearly two-thirds of House Republicans supporting Texas’s lawsuit seeking to overturn the election in the U.S. Supreme Court, a Democratic House member on Friday called the Republicans “traitors” and urged the House’s Democratic leadership not to seat the Republicans when the 117th Congress convenes in January.
lead_paragraph: With nearly two-thirds of House Republicans supporting Texas’s lawsuit seeking to overturn the election in the U.S. Supreme Court, a Democratic House member on Friday called the Republicans “traitors” and urged the House’s Democratic leadership not to seat the Republicans when the 117th Congress convenes in January.

headline: How We Passed the Time this Year
abstract: Making sense of the year in culture.
lead_paragraph: Welcome. My colleagues are looking back at the ways culture was upended in 2020, and their reflections are helping me make sense of a year that frequently seemed senseless. James Poniewozik put it best, I think, pointing out that this is the year “everything became TV”: We watched “I May Destroy You” on Netflix, and used the same screen to attend school, to take yoga classes, to commune over Thanksgiving dinner.

headline: Same-Sex Kisses Under the Mistletoe: Holiday Movies Rethink a Formula
abstract: In a conservative genre that has mainly told straight stories, six new films, including titles on Hallmark and Lifetime, center on gay or lesbian characters.
lead_paragraph: Will the adorable couple adopt a baby in time to celebrate Christmas with Mom and Dad and the neighborhood kids? Sounds like a delightful holiday TV movie. But this is disruptive 2020, so here’s the thing: the couple are Brandon and Jake and the channel is Hallmark.

headline: How to Handle Bad Co-Workers of the Anti-Mask and Boyfriend Varieties
abstract: It isn’t all about you. Or your officemate (even if you are living with him).
lead_paragraph: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.

headline: Businessman Pays Overdue Utility Bills for Dozens of Floridians, Again
abstract: Mike Esmond knew what it was like to be broke and get his heat cut off in a brutal winter. So, for the second year in a row, he paid residents’ overdue utility bills in Gulf Breeze, Fla.
lead_paragraph: Mike Esmond walked into City Hall in Gulf Breeze, Fla., in November 2019 and cut a check for $4,300 to pay for 36 local residents whose gas and water bills were overdue and at risk of being disconnected.

headline: ‘A Bit of Light on the Horizon’
abstract: What it felt like to witness some of the first coronavirus vaccinations in Britain. Plus, what we’re listening to.
lead_paragraph: Hi Daily friends,

headline: How Many Vaccine Doses Will Your State Get?
abstract: The New York Times surveyed all 50 states for their estimates of coronavirus vaccine doses they expect to receive before the end of the year.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times surveyed all 50 states for their estimates of coronavirus vaccine doses they expect to receive before the end of the year.

headline: Lil Wayne Pleads Guilty to Federal Gun Charge
abstract: The rapper will be sentenced in January, and faces up to 10 years in prison.
lead_paragraph: The rapper Lil Wayne pleaded guilty on Friday to having illegally carried a gold-plated .45-caliber Glock handgun and ammunition as a felon while traveling on a private jet last year.

headline: Hawaii’s Next Wave of Natural Skin-Care Brands
abstract: A new generation of beauty companies is rediscovering the islands’ powerful native ingredients, from taro to ferns.
lead_paragraph: It is not altogether surprising that Hawaii is at the forefront of our current golden age of natural skin care, in which botanical face oils and mushroom-infused elixirs abound. Few places on Earth contain such a diversity of plant species, and Hawaiians have been using this bounty — including nutrient-rich varieties such as hibiscus, coconut, ferns and kukui nuts — as a source of nourishment and healing for generations. Indeed, plants have been prized on the islands since the first millennium A.D., when the ancient Polynesians arrived by canoe, bringing with them life-sustaining crops such as taro, breadfruit and sweet potato. And though centuries of colonization have done their best to erode this deep-rooted connection to the natural world, it has endured. In fact, for many of the founders of the latest wave of Hawaii-based skin-care lines, using locally sourced botanical ingredients is simply common sense, part of a reciprocal, age-old relationship between the islands and their inhabitants.

headline: 6 Injured When Driver Rams Into Protest Against ICE in Manhattan
abstract: The driver, a 52-year-old woman, was charged with reckless endangerment after the police said she hit several people marching in support of immigrant detainees.
lead_paragraph: About a half-dozen people stand around a black BMW sedan on a Manhattan street. At least one slaps a hand onto one of the car’s windows as the vehicle edges through the group.

headline: Material From Giuliani Spurred a Separate Justice Dept. Pursuit of Hunter Biden
abstract: The inquiry, based out of Pittsburgh, was run parallel to an investigation in Delaware and raised alarms among F.B.I. agents about politicization.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As federal investigators in Delaware were examining the finances of Hunter Biden during his father’s campaign for president, a similar inquiry ramped up this year in Pittsburgh, fueled by materials delivered by President Trump’s personal lawyer Rudolph W. Giuliani.

headline: For Cameron Kinley and Navy, the Army Game Can Give 2020 a Highlight
abstract: The rivalry is being played at West Point, the first time the game has not been at a neutral site in 77 years.
lead_paragraph: Cameron Kinley, one of the captains of the Navy football team, read the text on his phone in late October and refused to believe it.

headline: A Cart Crash, a Pain Pill and a Shot at the Lead
abstract: Cristie Kerr was afraid she might not be able to play in the U.S. Women’s Open after an accident that injured her and her caddie last week. Playing in pain, she’s five shots off the lead.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The U.S. Women’s Open is one of Cristie Kerr’s favorite things, the tournament that she most wants to win every year. But in her zeal to add a trophy to bookend her 2007 title in the event, she has often hurt herself by overthinking her strategy, overdoing her preparation, overemphasizing the results.

headline: Pfizer Vaccine, N.Y.C. Dining, Dionne Warwick: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Congress, Paralyzed on a Stimulus Deal, Gives Itself Another Week to Strike One
abstract: The Senate cleared a weeklong stopgap spending bill to buy time for an elusive pandemic aid bill, but negotiators remained short of an agreement.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After months of fruitless haggling and a frenzied few days of revived talks, Congress missed yet another deadline on Friday to deliver an economic stimulus package to help struggling Americans weather the pandemic, instead agreeing to extend government funding for an additional week as leaders continued to search for a deal.

headline: Othella Dallas, Keeper of Katherine Dunham’s Flame, Dies at 95
abstract: Ms. Dallas taught the Afro-Caribbean-influenced Dunham dance technique in Europe well into her 90s. She also had a career as a blues, jazz and R&B singer.
lead_paragraph: Othella Dallas, who was one of the last surviving early members of the Katherine Dunham Dance Company, the nation’s first self-supporting Black modern dance troupe, and taught the Afro-Caribbean-influenced Dunham technique in Europe well into her 90s, died on Nov. 28 at a nursing home in Binningen, Switzerland. She was 95.

headline: The People James Baldwin Knew
abstract: The celebrated writer moved between many worlds, becoming close friends with major figures — from Marlon Brando to Toni Morrison — in art, activism and beyond.
lead_paragraph: This story is part of T’s Book Club, a series of articles and events dedicated to classic works of American literature. Click here to R.S.V.P. to a virtual conversation, led by Ayana Mathis, about “Go Tell It on the Mountain” on Dec. 17.

headline: With the Virus Surging, Arizona Teachers Protest by Calling In Sick
abstract: The sickout in Chandler, Ariz., reflects growing discord over whether classrooms should remain open as virus cases spike.
lead_paragraph: In a reflection of debates nationwide over whether to keep classrooms open during the current surge in coronavirus cases, about 100 teachers in Arizona’s third-largest school district staged a sickout on Friday, demanding that schools close after winter break and stay remote until the region’s infection rate declines.

headline: Supreme Court Rejects Texas Suit Seeking to Subvert Election
abstract: The suit, filed directly in the Supreme Court, sought to bar Georgia, Michigan, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin from casting their electoral votes for Joseph R. Biden Jr.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday rejected a lawsuit by Texas that had asked the court to throw out the election results in four battleground states that President Trump lost in November, ending any prospect that a brazen attempt to use the courts to reverse his defeat at the polls would succeed.

headline: Prominent Architects Group Prohibits Design of Death Chambers
abstract: The American Institute of Architects has changed its stance on members who design spaces for executions or prolonged solitary confinement.
lead_paragraph: The American Institute of Architects said Friday that it had approved new ethics rules prohibiting members from knowingly designing spaces intended for execution or torture, including for prolonged periods of solitary confinement.

headline: Superspreading Boston biotech conference in February is linked to 1.9 percent of all U.S. cases.
abstract: As many as 300,000 coronavirus cases across the United States can be traced to a two-day conference in Boston attended by 175 biotech executives in February, according to a study published Thursday in the journal Science.
lead_paragraph: As many as 300,000 coronavirus cases across the United States can be traced to a two-day conference in Boston attended by 175 biotech executives in February, according to a study published Thursday in the journal Science.

headline: All Fish and No Chips
abstract: Brexit negotiations continue to limp along as a deadline looms.
lead_paragraph: It is hard to recall another negotiating process with as many ups and downs or as many make-or-break deadlines as Brexit. The next deadline, which in principle should conclude the divorce between Britain and the European Union, is Dec. 31. That is when a new trade agreement is supposed to be signed and sealed, clearing the way for Britain and the E.U. to finally start leading their separate lives. But for that to happen, a few knots have to be unraveled, and for that the deadline is Sunday.

headline: This Blockbuster Is Coming to a Living Room Near You
abstract: The next generation of event viewing is likely to look more like ‘Game of Thrones’ and less like ‘Tenet.’
lead_paragraph: In the 1970s, movies like “Jaws” and “Star Wars” proved that audiences would turn out in droves for event films. In the decades since, Hollywood has lived and died by the blockbuster, and so has American pop culture.Studios were defined by their blockbusters, giant investments in search of even bigger returns: “Star Wars” (again) and the Marvel Comics superhero films, “Harry Potter” and “The Fast and the Furious.”

headline: This Is the Test of Our Lifetimes
abstract: More Americans have died from Covid-19 than perished in four years of combat in World War II.
lead_paragraph: This should be a season of hope: We will shortly be getting a highly effective coronavirus vaccine, and the pandemic should wind down in the coming months.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: Vaccines for Americans are just around the corner.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration is expected to issue an emergency authorization for Pfizer’s Covid-19 vaccine on Friday evening — a historic turning point in a pandemic that has taken more than 294,000 lives in the United States alone.

headline: U.K. to Halt Subsidies for Fossil Fuel Projects Abroad
abstract: Prime Minister Boris Johnson has been positioning himself as a leader in fighting global warming, an area where he can make common cause with President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain promised on Friday to end direct taxpayer support for fossil fuel projects overseas as soon as possible, in a move designed to help position his country as a global leader in the battle to curb climate change.

headline: Beneath a Full Moon, a Healing Ritual
abstract: A recent textile work by Diedrick Brackens responds to a startling statistic about the ongoing AIDS epidemic.
lead_paragraph: In each installment of The Artists, T highlights a recent or little-shown work by a Black artist, along with a few words from that artist putting the work into context. This week, we’re looking at a recent piece by Diedrick Brackens, who is known for his woven textiles, which are the subject of a solo exhibition at the Blanton Museum of Art in Austin, Texas, on view through May 16, 2021.

headline: What Happens When a Superspreader Event Keeps Spreading
abstract: A February conference by the drug company Biogen was initially thought to have infected 99 people. By the end of October, it was feared that the number had grown as high as 300,000.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When it was disclosed last spring that the coronavirus had stealthily infected 99 people after the Cambridge, Mass., pharmaceutical company Biogen held a two-day conference in February, it helped add the term “superspreader” to the pandemic lexicon.

headline: 51 Years Later, Coded Message Attributed to Zodiac Killer Has Been Solved, F.B.I. Says
abstract: The code had long baffled cryptographers, law enforcement agents and armchair sleuths obsessed with the shadowy killer, who was blamed for five murders in the late 1960s.
lead_paragraph: It took 51 years to crack, but one of the taunting messages written in code and attributed to the Zodiac Killer has been solved, according to the F.B.I.

headline: The Republicans Who Embraced Nihilism
abstract: The Supreme Court thwarts the latest Trumpist attack on American democracy.
lead_paragraph: What is left to say about a political party that would throw out millions of votes?

headline: Rallying Behind Trump, Most House Republicans Joined Failed Lawsuit
abstract: More than 60 percent of the chamber’s Republicans — including party leaders — signed onto a brief, underscoring the party’s willingness to back the president no matter how extreme the test.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the hours before the Supreme Court rejected it, another 20 House Republicans — including their top leader — joined a legal brief on Friday supporting an extraordinary lawsuit seeking to overturn President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory, underscoring the increasingly extreme lengths to which many in the party are willing to go to invalidate the election results.

headline: Democrats, and Even Some Republicans, Cheer as Justices Spurn Trump
abstract: While a top legal expert exhaled that “Our institutions held,” the Texas Republican Party chairman suggested secession.
lead_paragraph: The rejection came swiftly. The celebrations came just as fast.

headline: A Vaccine Is on Its Way to Canada. Who Will Get It First?
abstract: Determining how to parcel out the long-awaited vaccine is not a simple task for the provinces.
lead_paragraph: When a vaccine for polio was announced in 1953, the CBC reported that in Canada, “the reaction was the same as at the end of a terrible war.” The 13,109 Canadians the Covid-19 has killed, the hundreds of thousands it has made ill and the economic turmoil it has brought to the nation also seem like the toll of a battle. The vaccine approved this week by Canada also seemed like if not an armistice, a turning point. The first shipment of the vaccine created by the American company Pfizer and a German firm, BioNTech, is likely to be still in transit this weekend, and the first inoculations could come as early as Tuesday. The initial quantities will be small compared with the millions of doses expected to arrive in the new year, making the first doses more an appetizer than a rollout.

headline: F.D.A. Clears Pfizer Vaccine, and Millions of Doses Will Be Shipped Right Away
abstract: An initial shipment of about 2.9 million doses of the vaccine will be sent around the United States over the next week.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration authorized Pfizer’s Covid-19 vaccine for emergency use on Friday, clearing the way for millions of highly vulnerable people to begin receiving the vaccine within days.

headline: Justice Department Carries Out 10th Execution This Year
abstract: Alfred Bourgeois was put to death by lethal injection for murdering his 2-year-old daughter.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department on Friday executed Alfred Bourgeois, a 56-year-old inmate sentenced to death for murdering his 2-year-old daughter in 2002.

headline: Los Angeles County could face ‘catastrophic suffering and death,’ a health official warns.
abstract: Los Angeles County could see “catastrophic suffering and death” in the coming weeks, public health officials warn, as the nation’s most populous county reported another record day of new coronavirus cases.
lead_paragraph: Los Angeles County could see “catastrophic suffering and death” in the coming weeks, public health officials warn, as the nation’s most populous county reported another record day of new coronavirus cases.

headline: They Cover All of the Bases
abstract: Sid Sivakumar and Brooke Husic come around again, on a Saturday.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is the second time this year that Sid Sivakumar and Brooke Husic have ganged up on us with a Saturday grid full of inventive combinations and debuts. This time I was hung up on a lot of misdirects, including a couple of big ones in the middle chunk, and I thought the southeast corner was really tough.

headline: Corrections: Dec. 12, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Dec. 12, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about the latest lockdown in California misstated the capacity at which supermarkets can operate under new coronavirus restrictions. They can operate with 35 percent capacity, not 20 percent, after the state modified the original stay-at-home order.

headline: Quotation of the Day: College Sports Has Reported At Least 6,629 Virus Cases. There Are Many More.
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, December 12, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “We felt there was nothing to hide.”

headline: Pregnant and Breastfeeding Women May Opt to Receive the Vaccine
abstract: Although no coronavirus vaccine has been studied in these women, many scientists believe the benefits will outweigh any potential risks.
lead_paragraph: In its emergency authorization of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine on Friday night, the Food and Drug Administration took an unexpected step, leaving open the possibility that pregnant and breastfeeding women may opt for immunization against the coronavirus.

headline: Stormy Fairy Tales
abstract: The children in these three new novels brave blizzards, witches and monsters to convey a heartening message: “We will weather this together.”
lead_paragraph: OTTO TATTERCOAT AND THE FOREST OF LOST THINGSBy Matilda Woods

headline: Protests Erupt as South Korea’s Most Notorious Rapist Walks Free
abstract: Cho Doo-soon served 12 years in prison for raping an 8-year-old girl. His case has led the national legislature to create new rules for sex offenders released from prison.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea’s most infamous rapist was released on Saturday after serving 12 years in prison, sparking angry demonstrations and anonymous death threats that led to an increased police presence outside the predator’s home.

headline: Amid Pandemic, Scientists Reassess Routine Medical Care
abstract: All this year, patients stayed away from doctors’ offices in droves, postponing tests and treatments. Maybe there’s a silver lining.
lead_paragraph: For years, health researchers bemoaned what they saw as excessive medical care in the United States. Too many tests and treatments, they said, are unnecessary or even harmful, and add to the huge cost of health care in this country.

headline: Swimming Against Time, Ignoring the Finish Line
abstract: Swimming the 12 miles across Lake Tahoe, the author was advised to not look ahead but break up the challenge into fathomable chunks. It worked for the swim, and life.
lead_paragraph: For me, a 24-year-old software engineer whose pathetic swim career was best known for a Speedo malfunction while diving into a pool, the challenge was way, way over my head: Swim the 12 miles across a  chilly Lake Tahoe.

headline: Cuomo Tries to Jolt Public by Warning of Overwhelmed Hospitals
abstract: The governor makes a sharp strategic shift to persuade New Yorkers to take the coronavirus seriously as infections surge across the state.
lead_paragraph: With coronavirus cases surging, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York has shifted his strategy sharply away from tackling local clusters and toward protecting the state’s health system in a bid to avoid a return to the worst days of spring, when hospitals were stretched to the limit.

headline: Bhutan Becomes Latest Asian Nation to Dial Back Anti-Gay Laws
abstract: Lawmakers in the Himalayan country voted this week to amend a 2004 law that criminalizes “sexual conduct that is against the order of nature,” previously treated as a reference to gay sex.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The kingdom of Bhutan prides itself on maximizing “gross national happiness,” but it doesn’t always feel that way to members of the country’s L.G.B.T. community.

headline: As France Shifts Right, a Hard-Line Minister Proves Indispensable to Macron
abstract: Interior Minister Gérald Darmanin has become a useful tool for the French president as he responds to growing calls for law and order following a spate of terror attacks.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — He has declared war on the Islamist “enemy within” and halal food shelves in supermarkets. He launched what he described as a “massive” operation against 76 of France’s mosques, and sought to criminalize the filming of police officers. And he announced that he “can’t breathe” when he hears the term “police violence” — mocking a cry against police brutality that originated in the United States and resonated around the world.

headline: An Epic Israeli TV Drama Exposes War Wounds Old and New
abstract: Grappling with the traumatic opening of the 1973 war, when Israel feared destruction, the series “Valley of Tears” has prompted a national outpouring of emotion.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A new Israeli television series based on true events from the 1973 war, when the country was caught off guard on the holiest day of the Jewish calendar and feared total destruction, has prompted an intense public reckoning with the scope of war trauma and the treatment of survivors.

headline: The Best Poetry of 2020
abstract: Our poetry columnist picks some of her favorite collections of the year.
lead_paragraph: I’m uncomfortable using the word “best” on a list — in part because I am just one person whose tastes are subjective. More so, to me it implies that I’ve read every book that came out in 2020 and can therefore rank them like brands of peanut butter (which seem more finite). I didn’t read them all, or even close — I wish my life made that possible. Still, I couldn’t pass up the opportunity to talk about some poetry books that I loved this year. My column gives me limited space, so apart from the books I’ve already had a chance to recommend (like Don Mee Choi’s National Book Award-winning “DMZ Colony” or Chessy Normile’s great debut), here are several collections that I wasn’t able to write about in full or otherwise feel deserve more attention.

headline: What Will D.J.T. Do?
abstract: That’s the question that could define the Republican Party for years to come, even as the president’s time in Washington winds down.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your wrap-up of the week in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

headline: How Much Do I Tip the Building Staff During the Covid Holidays?
abstract: If ever there were a year to open your wallet wide, this is the one. But for New Yorkers who aren’t able to give this year, there are alternatives to cash.
lead_paragraph: Q: Holiday tipping is a mystery to me. I know I am supposed to tip the staff of my Upper West Side co-op, but I never know how much. This year, the question seems complicated by the pandemic. Tell me, how much should I give?

headline: The Blue Flame of Atlanta
abstract: Young entrepreneurs, artists and activists are building on a Southern capital’s long, rich history.
lead_paragraph: When Georgia went blue for Biden last month, some traced it to Stacey Abrams and her nonprofit Fair Fight, whose get-out-the-vote playbook electrified the state. Others cited more college-educated and older suburban voters.

headline: ‘An Indelible Stain’: How the G.O.P. Tried to Topple a Pillar of Democracy
abstract: The Supreme Court repudiation of President Trump was also a blunt rebuke to Republican leaders who had put their interests ahead of the country’s.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court repudiation of President Trump’s desperate bid for a second term not only shredded his effort to overturn the will of voters: It also was a blunt rebuke to Republican leaders in Congress and the states who were willing to damage American democracy by embracing a partisan power grab over a free and fair election.

headline: Trump Spurned New York, but Here’s How He’s Still Tied to the City
abstract: The president switched his residency to Florida, but his footprint in New York remains large. Should he return, this is what he’d come home to.
lead_paragraph: He was the first New York City-born American president since Theodore Roosevelt, but as Donald J. Trump’s days at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue come to a close, his relationship with his hometown appears broken beyond repair.

headline: Treasure Washes Up on Venezuela’s Shore, Bringing Gold and Hope to a Village
abstract: Venezuela’s economic meltdown had pummeled a proud fishing village. Then jewelry started mysteriously surfacing on its beach, easing the pain of an economic crisis.
lead_paragraph: GUACA, Venezuela — The most extraordinary moment in the young fisherman’s life began in the most mundane way: with a morning visit to the latrine.

headline: Thousands of Photographs, and a Year Like No Other
abstract: The Year in Pictures project is an annual celebration of photojournalism. In 2020, photographers were living what they captured.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: How the Vaccine Rollout Will Compare in Britain, Canada and the U.S.
abstract: Within days, all three countries could be giving the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine, but they have varying strategies and challenges. The U.S. plan, working through the states, is the least centralized.
lead_paragraph: With the Food and Drug Administration’s authorization of a coronavirus vaccine on Friday, the United States became the third highly developed Western country — after Britain and Canada — to approve such a shot, and is expected to start inoculating people within days.

headline: Don’t Want to Spring for a Hot Tub? Try a Stock Tank Pool
abstract: Taking the plunge in troughs originally used to feed farm animals.
lead_paragraph: If you happened to find yourself scouring the internet in search of an Intex inflatable pool last spring, only to come up empty-handed, you had company. According to Sabeena Hickman, the president and chief executive of the Pool & Hot Tub Alliance, pool sales skyrocketed as Americans faced a quarantined season at home.

headline: Saunas Are Hot
abstract: Enthusiasts swear there’s no better place to shut out (and sweat out) the world’s current cares.
lead_paragraph: In June, Lauren Warren bought a sauna after monitoring a sale on Wayfair.com and installed it in her living room. “With the winter coming — I really loathe winter — especially with the pandemic, I knew I wasn’t going to be able to get away to get warm,” she said.

headline: Say You Want to Build a Monolith
abstract: Experts in design and special effects said the monoliths appearing around the world are not that difficult to replicate. (That doesn’t mean you should try.)
lead_paragraph: Stuck inside, looking at social media on your phone, bored with what’s on streaming, it could start to seem like a good idea. A monolith, you might reason, could add a glimmer of mystery to your local wilderness, might make people laugh, or at least distract them with a literal shiny object.

headline: Should Companies Require Employees to Take the Vaccine?
abstract: It’s a debate that’s roiling boardrooms around the world.
lead_paragraph: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of a hot-button issue. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.

headline: ‘Very High Risk’: Longshoremen Want Protection From the Virus So They Can Stay on the Job
abstract: Port workers want early access to the coronavirus vaccine so they can prevent outbreaks that could shut down the nation’s ports and further damage the economy.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — It was shortly after Mardi Gras, and Robert D. Givens thought he had a sinus infection.

headline: ‘Free Papua Movement’ Intensifies Amid Escalating Violence
abstract: West Papua was annexed by Indonesia decades ago, leading to a prolonged conflict. A tribal chief who lives overseas recently declared himself president of the embattled territory.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — It has been 59 years since separatists in the Indonesian territory of West Papua raised their red, white and blue flag and declared independence. The region has been in conflict ever since.

headline: First Coronavirus Vaccines Head to States, Starting Historic Effort
abstract: Distributing supplies is a daunting logistical challenge, involving sophisticated tracking equipment, military contingencies and tight security.
lead_paragraph: At Novant Health in Winston-Salem, N.C., the new ultracold freezers are ready — enough to eventually house more than 500,000 doses of the first coronavirus vaccine approved in the United States.

headline: AstraZeneca to Buy Alexion for $39 Billion to Add Rare-Disease Treatments
abstract: The deal for the biopharmaceutical company is the latest big takeover this year, even amid the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The drug maker AstraZeneca agreed on Saturday to buy Alexion, a biopharmaceutical company, for $39 billion in cash and stock, as corporate giants resume big-ticket takeovers, even amid the pandemic.

headline: Cuomo tries to jolt New Yorkers by warning of overwhelmed hospitals.
abstract: With coronavirus cases surging, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York has shifted his strategy sharply away from tackling local clusters and toward protecting the state’s health system in a bid to avoid a return to the worst days of spring, when hospitals were stretched to the limit.
lead_paragraph: With coronavirus cases surging, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York has shifted his strategy sharply away from tackling local clusters and toward protecting the state’s health system in a bid to avoid a return to the worst days of spring, when hospitals were stretched to the limit.

headline: Biden’s Iowa Bus Tour Is Headed for a D.C. Reunion
abstract: A year ago, Joe Biden was on a grim bus tour through Iowa, joined by many old friends, including Tom Vilsack and John Kerry. Now Mr. Biden wants to bring some of the crew back to Washington with him.
lead_paragraph: Joseph R. Biden Jr. wasn’t the main event, and he knew it.

headline: How many vaccine doses will your state get?
abstract: The first shipments of Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccine will not be enough to inoculate even just the medical workers and nursing home residents at the top of the waiting list. But if federal regulators grant emergency authorization, millions of doses will soon be shipped across the country, a small but tangible step toward ending the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The first shipments of Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccine will not be enough to inoculate even just the medical workers and nursing home residents at the top of the waiting list. But if federal regulators grant emergency authorization, millions of doses will soon be shipped across the country, a small but tangible step toward ending the pandemic.

headline: Our 50 Most Popular Recipes of 2020
abstract: Cook the recipes readers obsessed over.
lead_paragraph: Spend the weekend with our most popular recipes of the year: Alison Roman’s caramelized shallot pasta (above); Ravneet Gill’s perfect chocolate chip cookies, adapted by Charlotte Druckman; Yasmin Fahr’s sheet-pan baked feta with broccolini; and many more in the collection below. (And don’t miss our roundups of our most popular desserts and vegetarian recipes.)

headline: A German-Vietnamese social media star dies at 29, and other news from around the world.
abstract: Brittanya Karma posted her bucket list on Instagram last year.
lead_paragraph: Brittanya Karma posted her bucket list on Instagram last year.

headline: Facebook Cannot Buy Its Way Out of Competition
abstract: It wasn’t legal when John D. Rockefeller did it, and it’s still not legal.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission and more than 40 states filed an antitrust suit against Facebook on Wednesday, prompting the company and its defenders to argue that Silicon Valley’s very way of doing business is under attack.

headline: Virus Cases in College Sports Prove Athletes Are Workers
abstract: They should be treated as such.
lead_paragraph: How much longer can the powers that run college sports turn a blind eye to player safety and the health of our communities?

headline: Biden Faces Intense Pressure From All Sides as He Seeks Diverse Cabinet
abstract: The pressure on the Democratic president-elect is intense, even as his efforts to ensure ethnic and gender diversity already go far beyond those of President Trump. And it’s coming from all sides.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The head of the N.A.A.C.P. had a blunt warning for President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. when Mr. Biden met with civil rights leaders in Wilmington this week.

headline: As War Goes On in Ethiopia, Ethnic Harassment Is on the Rise
abstract: Ethnic Tigray people all over the country report an increase in discrimination and abuse from the authorities.
lead_paragraph: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia — On a bright day in mid-November, about a dozen police officers with machine guns barged into the home of Lisanewerk Desta, a theologian who is the head of the library and museum department at the Ethiopian Orthodox Church, and got to work.

headline: Variety: Spiral
abstract: Will Shortz hypnotizes us with a confounding coil of clues.
lead_paragraph: SPIRAL — Will Shortz is the Jedi master of this elegant variety puzzle, which is easy to explain — two strings of clues, running in opposite directions, share one set of letters — but tricky to settle into and solve. It always takes me several hesitations and false starts, especially when the first entries that I feel confident about are in the middle of the spiral, and not on one end.

headline: Trying to Understand What Drives People to Suicide
abstract: Readers, including those who have attempted suicide or who have lost family members, offer their insights.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Young People Have Less Covid-19 Risk, but in College Towns, Deaths Rose Fast
abstract: Links between university outbreaks and deaths in the wider community are often indirect and difficult to document, but some health experts say there are clear signs of a connection.
lead_paragraph: When college students returned to campuses around the country this fall, spurring a spike in new coronavirus infections nationwide, people like Phyllis Baukol seemed at little risk.

headline: UPS and FedEx say plans to ship the vaccine are underway.
abstract: UPS and FedEx, normally rivals, are working side by side to ship the coronavirus vaccine developed by Pfizer and BioNTech, the first of the vaccines to win U.S. government approval.
lead_paragraph: UPS and FedEx, normally rivals, are working side by side to ship the coronavirus vaccine developed by Pfizer and BioNTech, the first of the vaccines to win U.S. government approval.

headline: In Arizona, one of the hardest hit states in the nation, 100 teachers protested by calling in sick.
abstract: About 100 teachers in Arizona’s third-largest school district staged a sickout on Friday, demanding that schools close after winter break and stay remote until the region’s positivity rate declines.
lead_paragraph: About 100 teachers in Arizona’s third-largest school district staged a sickout on Friday, demanding that schools close after winter break and stay remote until the region’s positivity rate declines.

headline: Iran Executes Dissident Accused of Stoking Protests
abstract: Ruhollah Zam had been convicted of encouraging an antigovernment uprising in 2017 through a Telegram channel he ran from exile in France.
lead_paragraph: Iran executed a dissident on Saturday after convicting him of encouraging a wave of antigovernment protests in 2017 through an opposition Telegram channel he ran from exile in France, Iranian news outlets reported.

headline: The Texas Lawsuit and the Age of Dreampolitik
abstract: The separation of political reality from political fantasy still exists — for now.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to Donald Trump’s efforts to claim victory in the 2020 presidential election, there are two Republican Parties. One G.O.P. has behaved entirely normally, certifying elections, rejecting frivolous claims and conspiratorial lawsuits, declining to indulge the conceit that state legislatures might substitute their votes for the electoral outcome.

headline: Build on Common Ground
abstract: There is progress to be made on policies most Americans support.
lead_paragraph: Promises to pursue national healing and unity helped put Joe Biden in the White House. Americans embraced that vision. But the overall election results, with Republicans gaining seats in the House and possibly retaining control of the Senate, both exposed and increased the magnitude of the incoming president’s challenge.

headline: Al Gore: Where I Find Hope
abstract: The Biden administration will have the opportunity to restore confidence in America and take on the worsening climate crisis.

headline: Inside One Woman’s Quest to Preserve the Disappearing Southern Appalachia
abstract: Among the last in her community, an 89-year-old woman self-published a memoir about life in the mountains, where a number of Black families settled after the end of the Civil War.
lead_paragraph: Mary Othella Burnette was born and raised in western North Carolina, in a small community in the mountains where a number of Black families settled after the end of the Civil War. Enslaved people, newly freed from local plantations, put down roots there, and Ms. Burnette is related to many of the earliest settlers of what is known as Southern Appalachia.

headline: Meet the Electoral College’s Biggest Critics: Some of the Electors Themselves
abstract: “Do we really want 538 Bob Nemanichs electing our president?” Bob Nemanich, a former elector, doesn’t. And he is hopeful that 2020 might put future electors out of a gig.
lead_paragraph: Few critics of the Electoral College are quite like Polly Baca.

headline: China, in Nudge to U.S., Makes a New Promise to Tackle Global Warming
abstract: Speaking at an online summit on the fifth anniversary of the Paris climate agreement, Xi Jinping said that China would reduce its carbon intensity by over 65 percent by 2030.
lead_paragraph: China on Saturday promised incremental new steps to address climate change in the next decade, but signaled that it would not reveal all of its plans before seeing the next moves taken by its main global rival, the United States.

headline: Trump Castigates Barr for Not Publicly Disclosing Hunter Biden Investigation
abstract: The critical tweets echoed the president’s attacks on Jeff Sessions, his first attorney general.
lead_paragraph: President Trump on Saturday excoriated Attorney General William P. Barr, castigating him on Twitter for not violating Justice Department policy to publicly reveal an investigation into President-Elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s son.

headline: Big Day for Mets Includes a New Catcher and a New G.M.
abstract: A four-year $40 million deal for James McCann should leave the Mets’ new general manager, Jared Porter, plenty of money to spend on other free agents.
lead_paragraph: Steven A. Cohen and his wife, Alex, spent part of their Saturday outside Citi Field, in the chill and the drizzle, greeting Mets season-ticket holders who stopped by for a bobblehead promotion. By the end of the day, the fans had more than trinkets.

headline: 4 Stabbed and One Shot as Trump Supporters and Opponents Clash
abstract: Supporters of the president in several cities said they were still convinced that the election was stolen, no matter what the courts say. Some confrontations with counterprotesters turned violent.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Incensed by a Supreme Court ruling that further dashed President Trump’s hopes of invalidating his November electoral defeat, thousands of his supporters marched in Washington and several state capitals on Saturday to protest what they contended, against all evidence, was a stolen election.

headline: Roblox Delays I.P.O. Until Next Year
abstract: After witnessing head-turning results for the initial public offerings by Airbnb and DoorDash, the gaming company said it would wait to test the market.
lead_paragraph: Roblox, a gaming company that had been preparing to go public this month, has decided to delay its initial public offering until next year, in a sign that the enthusiastic market for I.P.O.s by DoorDash and Airbnb this past week has made it difficult to price shares accurately.

headline: Nigerian Military in Firefight With Gang That Kidnapped Students
abstract: The country’s president said the kidnappers had been found in a forest, in northwest Katsina state, where a secondary school was attacked Friday, and which has been plagued by violence from outlaw gangs.
lead_paragraph: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria, (Reuters) — The Nigerian military engaged in a firefight Saturday with gunmen who had kidnapped scores of secondary school students in northwestern Katsina state the night before, the country’s president said.

headline: Federal Judge in Wisconsin Deals Trump Another Court Defeat
abstract: A Trump appointee in Milwaukee, Judge Brett H. Ludwig, dismissed a suit contesting the election with a withering rebuke.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Milwaukee on Saturday tossed out President Trump’s latest effort to overturn the election results in Wisconsin, dismissing the case and ruling that it had failed “as a matter of law and fact.”

headline: Charley Pride, Country Music’s First Black Superstar, Dies at 86
abstract: He began his career amid the racial unrest of the 1960s and cemented his place in the country pantheon with hits like “Kiss an Angel Good Mornin’.”
lead_paragraph: Charley Pride, the son of a Mississippi sharecropper who went on to become the first Black superstar in country music, died on Saturday in hospice care in Dallas. He was 86.

headline: C.D.C. Panel Recommends Pfizer Vaccine for Patients as Young as 16
abstract: The advisory panel of experts endorsed the vaccine and will soon issue specific guidance for pregnant and lactating women and for people who have had severe allergic reactions to other shots.
lead_paragraph: An independent committee of experts advising the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Saturday afternoon voted to recommend the Pfizer coronavirus vaccine for people 16 and older. That endorsement, which now awaits only final approval by Dr. Robert Redfield, the director of the C.D.C., is a key signal to hospitals and doctors that they should proceed to inoculate patients.

headline: Noah Creshevsky, Composer of ‘Hyperreal’ Music, Dies at 75
abstract: He built his musical works from myriad sampled sounds, including noises from the street as well as voices and instruments. He was also a respected teacher.
lead_paragraph: Noah Creshevsky, a composer of sophisticated, variegated electroacoustic works that mingled scraps of vocal and instrumental music, speech, outside noise, television snippets and other bits of sound, died on Dec. 3 at his home in Manhattan. He was 75.

headline: Cinéma Vérité
abstract: Dan Margolis reminds us of something we’re missing with his Sunday debut.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — If you take note of the title of the Sunday puzzle before you start it, this grid by Dan Margolis, his Sunday debut, makes a marvelous sort of sense. It’s disarmingly uncontrived; once I realized that, I found it a very relaxing, meditative kind of solve. It’s not easy, and there are a lot of fizzy elements throughout, but there’s a certain flow. Maybe it’s just me.

headline: Charley Pride, country music star, dies from complications of Covid-19.
abstract: Charley Pride, who was celebrated as a country music’s first Black superstar and known for hits such as “Kiss an Angel Good Mornin’” and “Is Anybody Goin’ to San Antone,” died on Saturday at age 86 while in hospice care in Dallas.
lead_paragraph: Charley Pride, who was celebrated as a country music’s first Black superstar and known for hits such as “Kiss an Angel Good Mornin’” and “Is Anybody Goin’ to San Antone,” died on Saturday at age 86 while in hospice care in Dallas.

headline: Republicans Find Themselves Speechless Following a Supreme Court Defeat
abstract: A ruling against President Trump appears to leave no avenue forward for the president, forcing Republicans to “play the hand we’re dealt.”
lead_paragraph: A day after President Trump’s stinging defeat in the Supreme Court, Republicans around the country seemed to be having trouble finding the right words.

headline: 10 Months Later, Iowa Democrats Blame National Party for Caucus Meltdown
abstract: With the future of Iowa’s first-in-the-nation Democratic caucuses in jeopardy, the state party sought to shift blame for a breakdown that delayed results for days after the Feb. 3 contest.
lead_paragraph: With Iowa’s closely watched presidential caucuses more endangered than ever after a disastrous showing in February that delayed results for days, the Iowa Democratic Party on Saturday sought to shift blame for the meltdown onto the Democratic National Committee.

headline: Jerrold M. Post, Specialist in Political Psychology, Dies at 86
abstract: He invented the field at the C.I.A., producing influential “psychobiographies” of world leaders. He later used the same methods to analyze Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: In August 1978, shortly before the opening of negotiations between Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel and President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt at Camp David, President Jimmy Carter paid a visit to C.I.A. headquarters in Langley, Va.

headline: Lawrence Byrne, Former Lawyer for New York Police, Dies at 61
abstract: His younger brother, a police officer, was assassinated by a drug gang at 22, a key moment in the city’s crack epidemic of the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: Lawrence M. Byrne, who as the top lawyer for the New York City Police Department defended several hotly disputed police policies and who also kept alive the legacy of his brother, a rookie police officer who was executed by a drug gang, died on Dec. 6 in Manhattan. He was 61.

headline: Under Biden, Justice Dept. Lawyers Seek a Shield From Partisan Battles
abstract: More than 40 current and former department employees said they wanted an attorney general who would protect them from undue political influence.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Since President Trump took office, the Justice Department has been under sustained attack as he questioned whether the lawyers and investigators who serve the country were loyalists who supported his personal agenda or traitors who should be rooted out and fired.

headline: An Opinion Writer Argued Jill Biden Should Drop the ‘Dr.’ (Few Were Swayed.)
abstract: Many women said Joseph Epstein’s suggestion in The Wall Street Journal was blatantly sexist and underscored the way men often dismiss women’s credentials.
lead_paragraph: Do people who go by Dr. need to carry stethoscopes?

headline: Solve the Puzzle of 2020
abstract: It’s a 🧩. It’s a 🌽. It’s a rebus, too. Play this game to discover a classic holiday song.
lead_paragraph: This has been a long and winding year, but it’s almost at an end. To solve this puzzle, cut out the pieces of the maze and fit them together to make a rectangle, then find your way through the labyrinth to 2020’s finale. Upon your journey, you will encounter a series of images. Use these phonetic clues in the order you pass them to fill in the blanks in the lyrics, then guess the classic song from which they come.

headline: What’s the Right Way to Give in a Pandemic?
abstract: Charities and donors are facing a holiday season like no other. But they have come up with solutions.
lead_paragraph: Talk to the staff members of charitable organizations these days and they will tell you they have never seen a year like 2020, with the Covid-19 pandemic and the hardships it has wrought.  Millions of Americans are out of work or newly living in poverty and many others are socially isolated, creating  a greater-than-ever demand for services. Kenneth Hodder, the national commander of the Salvation Army, described the present moment as “a tsunami of human need” in a telephone interview.

headline: The Small Luxury of Chocolate Truffles
abstract: Enticingly imperfect, hand-rolled truffles are a one-bite affair.
lead_paragraph: Slightly uneven little spheres dusted in cocoa to simulate the soil on a freshly dug fungus — the black Tuber melanosporum — defines a chocolate truffle at its most basic. Inside is a firm yet velvety center, a confection called ganache. Truffles are never cheap, but before you take out the credit card consider the homemade variety; they could not be easier to produce and do not require special equipment. With supervision, an 8-year-old can shape and dip truffles for a nice afternoon activity.

headline: 7 Films to Help Children Dealing With Grief
abstract: We are at a time when large numbers of children are experiencing loss. Here are seven movies to help them develop coping skills.
lead_paragraph: There’s no way to sugarcoat it: The pandemic has plunged the world into a crisis of grief. It has caused the deaths of more than 290,000 people in the United States, many of them grandparents and parents. In New York State alone, 4,200 children lost a parent or caregiver to Covid-19 between March and July, according to a study from the United Hospital Fund. (These were the most recent figures available on parental death from Covid.)

headline: Take a Virtual Drive Down Sunset Boulevard and Listen to the Boston Pops
abstract: This week, make the perfect cheese board, dance with the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater or listen to authors read excerpts from their work.
lead_paragraph: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.

headline: Enjoy More ‘Eureka!’ Moments With Jigsaw Puzzles
abstract: Whether made of cardboard or sculpted out of wood, jigsaw puzzles test skills like spatial reasoning and can help to stave off anxiety. They can also be works of art in their own right.
lead_paragraph: Back in March, when hand sanitizer evaporated, toilet paper shortages loomed and in parts of New York City, cans of Lysol couldn’t be had for love or any reasonable amount of money, another commodity flew from shelves and warehouse pallets: jigsaw puzzles.

headline: Make A DIY Seltzerator
abstract: With our constant need to hit ‘refresh’ right now, sparkling water is in high demand. Here’s how to save money and the planet by making it yourself.
lead_paragraph: For many, sparkling water is the perfect beverage — versatile and utterly refreshing, able to cleanse the palate and it contains zero calories. And it sure seems to be having a moment. Sales of packaged sparkling water have skyrocketed since the pandemic confined so many seltzer fans to their homes, with MarketWatch reporting a dramatic 52 percent jump in March alone. That same month, the demand trickled down to the aluminum can industry and U.S. sales rose 24 percent by volume. If these trends continue, experts predict a widespread can shortage could be on the horizon.

headline: Columbus Wins M.L.S. Cup, the Final Stop on a Journey to Stay Put
abstract: Lucas Zelarayán’s two goals carried the Crew over the Sounders in the stadium the team had almost abandoned three years ago.
lead_paragraph: The celebration was the catharsis Columbus Crew fans had dreamed of since 2017, when the team’s former owner had threatened to move their team to Texas. It was the party they had pined for since 2018, when their campaign to stop him had yielded new owners and new hope. It was the dream that sustained them this year when the coronavirus played havoc with the schedule and locked them out of their stadium.

headline: Cozy Up With Holiday Plays
abstract: Stream productions of reimagined fairy tales and Christmas standards like ‘A Christmas Carol’ being staged at theaters around the world.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Meet the Electoral College’s Biggest Critics
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, December 13, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “The head of the student council in your middle school was elected by a popular vote. I know it’s an old fashioned notion, but the most fundamental democratic value is that all votes should count equally.”

headline: Corrections: Dec. 13, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Dec. 13, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article last Sunday about the actress Candice Bergen, who lived in the house on Cielo Drive later occupied by the director Roman Polanski, misidentified the actress who shared it with him. She was Sharon Tate, not Sharon Stone.

headline: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Sends Up Fauci and Covid-19 Vaccine Rollout
abstract: The episode, hosted by Timothée Chalamet, also featured musical performances by Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Band.
lead_paragraph: While the pandemic has made Dr. Anthony Fauci, the nation’s top expert on infectious diseases, a highly visible figure in American life, “Saturday Night Live” has been circumspect about satirizing him in comedy sketches. When Fauci first turned up as an “S.N.L.” character this past spring, during one of the show’s remotely produced at-home episodes, he was given a mostly glowing treatment and played by none other than Brad Pitt (after Fauci himself had made the suggestion in a CNN interview).

headline: 2020 Was Especially Deadly. Covid Wasn’t the Only Culprit.
abstract: There were 100,000 more deaths in the U.S. than normal attributed to diabetes, Alzheimer's, high blood pressure, pneumonia and other causes beyond Covid, a New York Times analysis shows.
lead_paragraph: There were 100,000 more deaths in the U.S. than normal attributed to diabetes, Alzheimer's, high blood pressure, pneumonia and other causes beyond Covid, a New York Times analysis shows.

headline: ‘It Was My First Day Going to Work After Moving Into a House in Midwood’
abstract: Seasonal advice in Brooklyn, a teenage pastime recalled and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Ski Champion Comes Out as Gay: ‘I’m Ready to Be Happy’
abstract: In an interview with The New York Times, Hig Roberts, a two-time U.S. national champion, becomes the first elite men’s Alpine skier to publicly come out as gay, hoping to encourage others to be themselves.
lead_paragraph: As he prepared to barrel down the slopes in northern Vermont at an event in March 2019, Hig Roberts decided this would be his last race as a professional Alpine skier. It was the day before his 28th birthday, he was skiing in the Nor-Am Cup at the high school where he once trained and it just felt right.

headline: She Stalked Her Daughter’s Killers Across Mexico, One by One
abstract: Armed with a handgun, a fake ID card and disguises, Miriam Rodríguez was a one-woman detective squad, defying a system where criminal impunity often prevails.
lead_paragraph: SAN FERNANDO, Mexico — Miriam Rodríguez clutched a pistol in her purse as she ran past the morning crowds on the bridge to Texas. She stopped every few minutes to catch her breath and study the photo of her next target: the florist.

headline: Geminids Meteor Shower 2020: Watch It Peak in Night Skies
abstract: Meteor showers can light up night skies from dusk to dawn, and if you’re lucky you might be able to catch a glimpse.
lead_paragraph: All year long as Earth revolves around the sun, it passes through streams of cosmic debris. The resulting meteor showers can light up night skies from dusk to dawn, and if you’re lucky you might be able to catch a glimpse.

headline: Rep. Max Rose Launches Exploratory Bid to Run for N.Y.C. Mayor
abstract: The congressman, who lost his re-election bid last month, is casting himself as a blunt populist who would end New York’s cycle of “broken politics.”
lead_paragraph: Representative Max Rose, the brash Staten Island Democrat who recently lost his re-election race, appears all but certain to run for mayor of New York City, confirming for the first time that he is exploring a bid and casting his potential candidacy as a sharp rebuke of the de Blasio administration.

headline: Trump Allies Eye Long-Shot Election Reversal in Congress, Testing Pence
abstract: Some House Republicans plan to try to use Congress’s tallying of electoral results on Jan. 6 to tip the election to President Trump. The attempt will put Republicans in a pinch.
lead_paragraph: President Trump lost key swing states by clear margins. His barrage of lawsuits claiming widespread voting fraud has been almost universally dismissed, most recently by the Supreme Court. And on Monday, the Electoral College will formally cast a majority of its votes for President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: New York Has a Cameo in ‘The Crown.’ Here’s What Really Happened.
abstract: Princess Diana visited the city in 1989, a trip featured on the Netflix series and remembered fondly by the people she met.
lead_paragraph: Long shot of the Concorde landing at Kennedy International Airport. Princess Diana gets out of the plane to cheering throngs and heads to a glittering black-tie reception.

headline: WarnerMedia Chief Has Become a Movie Villain to Some in Hollywood
abstract: Jason Kilar’s decision to release 2021 movies simultaneously in theaters and on HBO Max has angered many in the industry, including some of the star filmmakers his company relies on.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When Jason Kilar began his tenure as the chief executive of Hulu in July 2007, some competitors considered the streaming service so likely to fail that they nicknamed it Clown Co. Yet Mr. Kilar, armed with both the conviction that there was a better way to watch television and the backing of two powerful corporate parents — NBCUniversal and News Corp — sequestered himself and his team in an empty Santa Monica office and got to work. He covered all the windows with newspapers, emphasizing the point that naysayers were to be ignored.

headline: Fears of a ‘Twindemic’ Recede as Flu Lies Low
abstract: Despite early worries, flu patients are not competing with Covid-19 patients for ventilators, and the threat of dueling outbreaks may be waning.
lead_paragraph: Despite the horrifying surge of Covid-19 cases and deaths in the United States right now, one bit of good news is emerging this winter: It looks unlikely that the country will endure a “twindemic” of both flu and the coronavirus at the same time.

headline: Vaccinated? Show Us Your App
abstract: Covid-19 health pass apps could help reopen businesses and restore the economy. They could also unfairly exclude people from travel and workplaces.
lead_paragraph: Among all the tools that health agencies have developed over the years to fight epidemics, at least one has remained a constant for more than a century: paper vaccination certificates.

headline: Vaccine distribution is about to begin in the virus-ravaged U.S.
abstract: The first of nearly three million doses of the first Covid-19 vaccine were packed in dry ice and put on trucks at a Pfizer plant in Kalamazoo, Mich., on Sunday morning, destined for hundreds of distribution centers in all 50 states, the most ambitious vaccination campaign in American history.
lead_paragraph: The first of nearly three million doses of the first Covid-19 vaccine were packed in dry ice and put on trucks at a Pfizer plant in Kalamazoo, Mich., on Sunday morning, destined for hundreds of distribution centers in all 50 states, the most ambitious vaccination campaign in American history.

headline: Going ‘the Extra Mile,’ Britain and E.U. Give Brexit Talks More Time
abstract: The two sides agreed to extend a deadline on the seemingly intractable trade negotiations in an attempt to avoid a disruptive no-deal outcome before Dec. 31.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain and the European Union passed another do-or-die moment in their trade negotiations on Sunday with neither a breakthrough nor a breakdown. But as the talks stretched on, there were distinct glimmers of hope that the two sides might at last find a way to bridge the gulf between them.

headline: Bahrain is the second country to approve a Chinese vaccine, and other news around the world.
abstract: Bahrain said on Sunday that it had approved the use of a Chinese vaccine against the coronavirus, after the United Arab Emirates became the first government to do so on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Bahrain said on Sunday that it had approved the use of a Chinese vaccine against the coronavirus, after the United Arab Emirates became the first government to do so on Wednesday.

headline: Pfizer Vaccine, Electoral College, Holiday Baking: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: The Week in Business: Getting Vaccines From Here to There
abstract: Christmas came early for Airbnb and DoorDash. But Facebook is on the naughty list.
lead_paragraph: Move over, toilet paper: Dry ice may be the next hot commodity in the pandemic economy, as the first vaccine to become available must be stored at freezing temperatures. Here’s what else you need to know for the week ahead in business and tech, and stay warm out there. — Charlotte Cowles

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $750,000
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘Lovers in Auschwitz, Reunited’
abstract: After 72 years, he had one question: Was she the reason he was alive today?
lead_paragraph: Amid the death and desperation of the Auschwitz concentration camp, two inmates, David Wisnia and Helen Spitzer, found love.

headline: Mumbai Police Arrest TV Chief as Media Dispute in India Intensifies
abstract: Vikas Khanchandani was accused of involvement in an effort to falsely bolster ratings data at Republic TV, a right-wing news broadcaster. The network said the allegations were politically motivated.
lead_paragraph: The police in Mumbai on Sunday arrested the chief executive of a right-wing television news broadcaster on suspicion of manipulating ratings figures, escalating a clash that has roiled India’s voluble but increasingly partisan media scene.

headline: A federal judge in Wisconsin deals Trump another defeat in court.
abstract: A federal judge in Milwaukee on Saturday tossed out President Trump’s latest effort to overturn the election results in Wisconsin, dismissing the case and ruling that it had failed “as a matter of law and fact.”
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Milwaukee on Saturday tossed out President Trump’s latest effort to overturn the election results in Wisconsin, dismissing the case and ruling that it had failed “as a matter of law and fact.”

headline: In rejecting Texas lawsuit, Supreme Court delivers a rebuke to G.O.P.
abstract: The Supreme Court repudiation of President Trump’s desperate bid for a second term not only shredded his effort to overturn the will of voters: It was also a blunt rebuke to Republican leaders in Congress and the states who were willing to damage American democracy by embracing a partisan power grab over a free and fair election.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court repudiation of President Trump’s desperate bid for a second term not only shredded his effort to overturn the will of voters: It was also a blunt rebuke to Republican leaders in Congress and the states who were willing to damage American democracy by embracing a partisan power grab over a free and fair election.

headline: When the Trains Stopped, Cyclists Dodged Manila’s Choking Traffic
abstract: City dwellers around the world turned to bicycles as the pandemic forced urban areas to restrict public transit. In the crowded Philippine capital, that meant weaving through notoriously bad traffic.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — Nikko Flores bought his first bicycle with borrowed money when public transit was restricted in the Philippine capital because of the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: After Supreme Court loss, a speechless Republican Party.
abstract: A day after President Trump’s stinging defeat in the Supreme Court, Republicans around the country seemed to be having trouble finding the right words.
lead_paragraph: A day after President Trump’s stinging defeat in the Supreme Court, Republicans around the country seemed to be having trouble finding the right words.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Eat well with a lemony sheet-pan chicken with brussels sprouts, a chicken korma, or a cheesy baked pasta with sausage and ricotta.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Last winter, I walked across the huge parking lot of a bankrupt mall in Maine to eat soggy chimichangas at a knockoff Chili’s, and it was a great night because the bartender was kind and interesting and the room was warm. That same season, I ordered a ham and pineapple pizza at a diner in the Everglades and ended up sharing it with newlyweds who were in town for the fishing. And if the pie was pillowy in the sense that it tasted like a pillow, the couple was nice. They had good stories. That was a great night, too.

headline: Putin Said to Have Two Identical Offices: One in Moscow, the Other at the Beach
abstract: The supposed ruse has enabled him to spend time at a government residence on the Black Sea without risking a potential political backlash, a Russian news site reported.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Political commentators saw signs of infighting among the elite. An opposition leader chalked it up to the Kremlin’s habit of lying. But for many who have been working from home for months, the report from a Russian news site just made perfect sense.

headline: Hundreds of Students Feared Missing After Attack at Nigeria School
abstract: Hundreds of Nigerian students are feared missing after gunmen raided a secondary school in the northern state of Katsina. The military later exchanged fire with the attackers in a forest.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of students in Nigeria are feared missing after gunmen stormed a secondary school in the northern state of Katsina, news agencies and the Nigerian authorities said.

headline: The Electoral College Is Voting Today. Here’s What to Expect.
abstract: Most states are offering livestreams to watch the proceedings, including battlegrounds won by President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. After Monday’s vote, the process moves to Congress.
lead_paragraph: The members of the Electoral College are gathering in their respective states on Monday to cast their official ballots for president. Ordinarily, the process is little more than a formal duty to rubber-stamp the results of the November election.

headline: Ben Bova, Science Fiction Editor and Author, Is Dead at 88
abstract: As editor of the magazines Analog and Omni, he was a champion of a new generation of authors, including George R.R. Martin.
lead_paragraph: Ben Bova was a hard-science guy — and a passionate space program booster — and his visions of the future encompassed a dizzying array of technological advances (and resulting horrors or delights), including cloning, sex in space, climate change, the nuclear arms race, Martian colonies and the search for extraterrestrials. In newspaper articles, short stories and more than 100 books, he explored these and other knotty human problems.

headline: Germany Locks Down Ahead of Christmas as Coronavirus Deaths Rise
abstract: Stores and schools will be closed, and public and private meetings will be restricted over the holidays, in an effort to bring down coronavirus infections and deaths.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Germans will be forced into a strict lockdown over Christmas, after weeks of milder restrictions on public life failed to slow the spread of the coronavirus, leading to record numbers of new infections and deaths, Chancellor Angela Merkel announced on Sunday.

headline: What Will Trump’s Legacy Be?
abstract: Readers react to two Opinion pieces arguing that the president will not leave a big footprint, and urge Times columnists to stop constantly writing about Mr. Trump.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Worried About College Plans for Spring
abstract: A University of Florida faculty member and a resident of Columbia University’s neighborhood express fears about Covid outbreaks. Also: Rohingya refugees; growing meat.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Alex Olmedo, 84, Dies; Tennis Star Known for a Remarkable Year
abstract: In 1959, Olmedo won the Australian and Wimbledon men’s single championships and reached the final of the United States Nationals.
lead_paragraph: Alex Olmedo, the Peruvian who dominated the world of international tennis in 1959 when he won the Australian and Wimbledon men’s single championships and reached the final of the United States Nationals at Forest Hills, died on Wednesday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 84.

headline: How Readers Reacted to FKA twigs and Her Allegations of Abuse
abstract: Women responded on social media with their own stories of violence, and their support for survivors, after the Times reported that FKA twigs had sued Shia LaBeouf, her former boyfriend.
lead_paragraph: After a report The New York Times published on Friday detailing a lawsuit the performer FKA twigs filed against the actor Shia LaBeouf, accusing him of sexual battery, assault and inflicting emotional distress, the reaction on social media was enormous and swift. The topic, trending on Twitter, became the subject of conversation among women who said they had also been abused by a partner.

headline: This week will be decisive in determining whether Congress passes a stimulus deal before the end of the year.
abstract: Congress will reconvene on Monday for a make-or-break week in the effort to deliver badly needed relief to Americans and an economy hit hard by the coronavirus pandemic before the Christmas holidays.
lead_paragraph: Congress will reconvene on Monday for a make-or-break week in the effort to deliver badly needed relief to Americans and an economy hit hard by the coronavirus pandemic before the Christmas holidays.

headline: Trump again threatened to veto a military bill, days after it passed both chambers by veto-proof majorities.
abstract: President Trump on Sunday renewed his threat to veto a sweeping military policy bill, courting what may be the final legislative fight of his presidency with Congress after lawmakers overwhelmingly approved the measure last week.
lead_paragraph: President Trump on Sunday renewed his threat to veto a sweeping military policy bill, courting what may be the final legislative fight of his presidency with Congress after lawmakers overwhelmingly approved the measure last week.

headline: The C.D.C. formally approves allowing people 16 and up to receive the vaccine.
abstract: The director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Dr. Robert Redfield, gave a formal sign-off Saturday evening for Pfizer-BioNTech’s coronavirus vaccine to be administered to people 16 and over, the agency said on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: The director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Dr. Robert Redfield, gave a formal sign-off Saturday evening for Pfizer-BioNTech’s coronavirus vaccine to be administered to people 16 and over, the agency said on Sunday.

headline: Review: Finding Hope in an Unfinished Pam Tanowitz Premiere
abstract: At the Joyce Theater, “Finally Unfinished: Part 1” and “Gustave Le Gray, No. 2” constitute an event in the Merce Cunningham sense, combining old pieces in a new order for a new occasion and space.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday, the Joyce Theater livestreamed a premiere by the choreographer Pam Tanowitz, who began the program by saying, “It isn’t really finished.”

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: The U.S. prepares to start vaccinating.
lead_paragraph: The most ambitious vaccination campaign in U.S. history is set to kick off this week after drug regulators approved a vaccine developed by Pfizer and BioNTech. The rollout comes as the U.S. coronavirus death toll approaches 300,000.

headline: Joe Biden Won the Most Votes. It Doesn’t Matter.
abstract: Majority rule shapes our lives — except when it comes to electing the president.
lead_paragraph: As the 538 members of the Electoral College gather on Monday to carry out their constitutional duty and officially elect Joe Biden as the nation’s 46th president and Kamala Harris as his vice president, we are confronted again with the jarring reminder that it could easily have gone the other way. We came within a hairbreadth of re-electing a man who finished more than seven million votes behind his opponent — and we nearly repeated the shock of 2016, when Donald Trump took office after coming in a distant second in the balloting.

headline: Man Is Arrested in Stabbing at D.C. Election Protest
abstract: The confrontation near the White House between supporters and opponents of President Trump was one of several on Saturday in Washington and in state capitals across the country.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in Washington, D.C., said on Sunday that they had arrested a man in connection with the stabbing of four people on Saturday night as supporters and opponents of President Trump clashed blocks from the White House.

headline: Play Suspension Delays Finish at U.S. Women’s Open
abstract: Golf’s final major of the year experienced a rain delay before play was called Sunday.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The best female golfers had to wait 189 days to start the United States Women’s Open after it was pushed back from June to December because of the coronavirus pandemic. So what’s one more day to crown a winner?

headline: As Biden Prepares to Take Office, a New Rush at the Border
abstract: The president-elect has promised a more humane border policy. But devastated economies and natural disasters in Latin America have fueled a spike in migration that could make pledges hard to keep.
lead_paragraph: SASABE, Ariz. — By the time the Border Patrol spotted the two migrants in a tangle of shrubs on a frigid December morning, they had been meandering aimlessly in the desert for six days. They had lost their way on the final leg of a monthlong journey from Guatemala, encountering only herds of javelinas, lone coyotes and skin-piercing cactuses as they staggered north. Exhausted, thirsty and cold, they did not resist arrest.

headline: 2 Who Escaped in Tennessee Are Caught 2 Days Later in Florida
abstract: Robert Lee Brown and Christopher Osteen escaped from a state prison in Lake County, Tenn., and were tracked down a thousand miles away just off the beach in Broward County, Fla.
lead_paragraph: Two men who escaped from a Tennessee prison, kidnapped a man and stole his truck last week were tracked to an oceanfront block in South Florida and captured on Sunday, the authorities said.

headline: Former Aide Accuses Cuomo of Sexual Harassment
