abstract: Lindsey Boylan, who is now running for Manhattan borough president, said the governor would often discuss her physical appearance when she worked for him.
lead_paragraph: A former aide to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Sunday accused him of sexual harassment, asserting that the governor would often discuss her physical appearance, something she said occurred over the course of years.

headline: Trump delays a plan to fast track vaccines for White House staff members.
abstract: President Trump said on Sunday night that he would delay a plan for senior White House staff members to receive the coronavirus vaccine in the coming days.
lead_paragraph: President Trump said on Sunday night that he would delay a plan for senior White House staff members to receive the coronavirus vaccine in the coming days.

headline: Police Fatally Shoot Man Who Opened Fire Outside Manhattan Cathedral
abstract: The shooting on the steps of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine took place near a crowd of hundreds, just after a carol service ended.
lead_paragraph: A man was fatally shot by the police after he opened fire near a crowd of hundreds of people gathered for a Christmas concert on Sunday afternoon on the steps of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in Morningside Heights, the authorities said.

headline: Anthony Veasna So, Author on the Brink of Stardom, Dies at 28
abstract: His darkly comedic stories explored the experiences of Cambodian-Americans. His first book, the subject of a bidding war, is to be published next August.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Veasna So, the author of crackling, kinetic and darkly comedic stories that made vivid the lives of first-generation Khmer-Americans, died on Dec. 8 at his home in San Francisco. He was 28.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Dec. 14, 2020
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:

headline: John le Carré, Best-Selling Author of Cold War Thrillers, Dies at 89
abstract: Breaking from the James Bond mold, he turned the spy novel into high art as he explored the moral compromises of agents on both sides of the Iron curtain.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — John le Carré, whose exquisitely nuanced, intricately plotted Cold War thrillers elevated the spy novel to high art by presenting both Western and Soviet spies as morally compromised cogs in a rotten system full of treachery, betrayal and personal tragedy, died on Saturday in Cornwall, England. He was 89.

headline: Hospitals prepare for the first shots in America’s most ambitious vaccination campaign.
abstract: Trucks and cargo planes packed with the first of nearly three million doses of coronavirus vaccine fanned out across the country on Sunday as hospitals in all 50 states rushed to set up injection sites and their anxious workers tracked each shipment hour by hour. The inoculation effort, set in motion after the Food and Drug Administration’s emergency authorization of the vaccine on Friday night, comes as the U.S. coronavirus death toll approaches 300,000. Rollout of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine is less centralized in the United States than in other countries that are racing to distribute it.
lead_paragraph: Trucks and cargo planes packed with the first of nearly three million doses of coronavirus vaccine fanned out across the country on Sunday as hospitals in all 50 states rushed to set up injection sites and their anxious workers tracked each shipment hour by hour. The inoculation effort, set in motion after the Food and Drug Administration’s emergency authorization of the vaccine on Friday night, comes as the U.S. coronavirus death toll approaches 300,000. Rollout of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine is less centralized in the United States than in other countries that are racing to distribute it.

headline: Covid Study Shows an Arthritis Drug May Help Patients Recover
abstract: Baricitinib had previously attracted some scrutiny from experts, who were unsure when it would most help their patients.
lead_paragraph: Adding an arthritis drug called baricitinib to Covid treatment regimens that include the antiviral drug remdesivir might shave a day or more off recovery times, especially for those who are seriously sick, according to a study published on Friday.

headline: Hospitals Prepare for First Shots as Virus Vaccine Shipments Blanket U.S.
abstract: The first of nearly three million doses were sent across the country, the start of the most ambitious vaccination campaign in the nation’s history.
lead_paragraph: FARGO, N.D. — Trucks and cargo planes packed with the first of nearly three million doses of coronavirus vaccine fanned out across the country on Sunday as hospitals rushed to set up injection sites and their anxious workers tracked each shipment hour by hour.

headline: Trump Administration Plans a Rushed Effort to Encourage Americans to Be Vaccinated
abstract: A large-scale public education campaign, delayed by false starts and investigations, will get off the ground just as the coronavirus vaccine becomes available to high-risk Americans.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration, scrambling to make up for lost time after a halting start, is rushing to roll out a $250 million public education campaign to encourage Americans to take the coronavirus vaccine, which will reach the first patients in the United States this week.

headline: Down Under Hopper
abstract: Jessie Bullock makes her New York Times Crossword debut, abetted by Ross Trudeau.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — It’s always sweet when couples can enjoy hobbies together.

headline: Apple TV Was Making a Show About Gawker. Then Tim Cook Found Out.
abstract: Big tech companies now exert huge influence over what stories get told. The message is clear: Be careful whom you offend.
lead_paragraph: The show was called “Scraper,” but it was clearly about Gawker Media, the network of aggressive, transgressive blogs that created mischief and headaches for America’s powerful until its targets sued the company into oblivion in 2016.

headline: Russian Hackers Broke Into Federal Agencies, U.S. Officials Suspect
abstract: In one of the most sophisticated and perhaps largest hacks in more than five years, email systems were breached at the Treasury and Commerce Departments. Other breaches are under investigation.
lead_paragraph: The Trump administration acknowledged on Sunday that hackers acting on behalf of a foreign government — almost certainly a Russian intelligence agency, according to federal and private experts — broke into a range of key government networks, including in the Treasury and Commerce Departments, and had free access to their email systems.

headline: Giants Cannot Protect Win Streak Against the Cardinals
abstract: The Giants entered Sunday’s game riding high on a four-game win streak. They left it with a battered quarterback and diminished playoff chances.
lead_paragraph: For more than a month, as they won four successive games, the Giants went from somnolent to startlingly successful, having a stretch that resurrected the team’s fan base and advanced the budding folk hero status of the rookie head coach Joe Judge. But on Sunday, with a meaningful chance at home to maintain the momentum necessary to finish a late-season run at a playoff berth, the Giants collapsed.

headline: What We Learned From Week 14 of the N.F.L. Season
abstract: The Chiefs did not need perfection to win, the Steelers are on a losing streak and the N.F.C. East remained wide open.
lead_paragraph: Most of the favored teams won on Sunday, but there was still a little drama, including a mistake-filled performance by the leading candidate for the Most Valuable Player Award, an unbelievably bad day for a veteran kicker and an upset led by a rookie quarterback making his first start. And the Pittsburgh Steelers, who started the season 11-0, have lost two games in a row.

headline: Trump Rescinds Plan for White House Staff to Be Quickly Vaccinated
abstract: The administration had initially defended a plan to distribute vaccines to its senior members even as the first doses are generally being reserved for high-risk health care workers.
lead_paragraph: President Trump said on Sunday night that he would delay a plan for senior White House staff members to receive the coronavirus vaccine in the coming days, hours after The New York Times reported that the administration was planning to rapidly distribute the vaccine to its staff at a time when the first doses are generally being reserved for high-risk health care workers.

headline: Trump Has Never Believed in Democracy
abstract: He wants to wield power without winning it legitimately.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s continued effort to overturn the result of the election — an effort buttressed by the support of many Republicans in Congress, it should be noted — is nothing short of an attempt at a bloodless coup.

headline: What Does 95% Effective Mean? Teaching the Math of Vaccine Efficacy
abstract: In this lesson plan, students use statistics, probability and math to understand how big a breakthrough the new coronavirus vaccine is and what it might mean for the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Featured article: “2 Companies Say Their Vaccines Are 95% Effective. What Does That Mean?” by Carl Zimmer

headline: Do You Want Your Parents and Grandparents to Get the New Coronavirus Vaccine?
abstract: A vaccine against Covid-19 has begun to be distributed in the United States. Do you plan on getting vaccinated? Do you want your loved ones and friends to get the vaccine?
lead_paragraph: On Dec. 11, the Food and Drug Administration authorized Pfizer’s Covid-19 vaccine for emergency use, clearing the way for millions of highly vulnerable people to begin receiving the vaccine within days. Early this month the United Kingdom and Canada approved the vaccine as well.

headline: Cleveland’s Baseball Team Will Drop Its Indians Team Name
abstract: The decision comes amid a wider push for sports teams to stop using Native American names and imagery as team names and mascots.
lead_paragraph: After years of protests from fans and Native American groups, the Cleveland Indians have decided to change their team name, moving away from a moniker that has long been criticized as racist, three people familiar with the decision said Sunday.

headline: Books Are Really Easy to Wrap
abstract: But that’s not why they make the best gifts.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Once upon a time, not all that long ago, the word “Zoom” meant nothing more to me than the name of an old kids’ show on public television or the punchline of a commercial for fast cars. “Google Hangouts” sounded like something only teenagers needed to know about, and “Microsoft Teams,” if I had to guess, was some kind of technical support department requiring an hour on hold to reach.

headline: As U.S. Deaths Surpass 300,000, Obituaries Force Reckoning with Covid
abstract: Families of some who perished have written pointedly about the virus in remembrances. They tell of agonizing final days. They plead for wearing of masks.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — When Kim Miller sat down in her Illinois house to compose her husband’s obituary, she could not hold back.

headline: Finding More Than Humbug in Scrooge and Company
abstract: This year a critic (and fan) of “A Christmas Carol”  finds it especially resonant as a “timely study of what it truly means to be a decent person in a community.”
lead_paragraph: When I was younger, I drank in every version of “A Christmas Carol” I could find like they were tumblers of eggnog. Eventually, I became a connoisseur. (I maintain the supremacy of “The Muppet Christmas Carol” and “Scrooged,” which I am obligated to watch whenever they’re on TV.)

headline: Wall Street Journal Opinion Editor Defends Item on Dr. Jill Biden
abstract: “There’s nothing like playing the race or gender card to stifle criticism,” Paul A. Gigot said as he accused Democrats of orchestrating a coordinated response to an op-ed piece.
lead_paragraph: The editorial page editor of The Wall Street Journal accused strategists for President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. of instigating a coordinated response to an op-ed article published Friday evening that called on Jill Biden, Mr. Biden’s wife, to refrain from referring to herself as “Dr. Biden” because she is not a medical doctor, but rather holds a doctorate in education.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Germany prepares for a lockdown.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: 2020: The Year in Sports When Everybody Lost
abstract: The state of Wisconsin is a microcosm of the financial devastation the pandemic has brought the sports industry, and those who rely on it.
lead_paragraph: The state of Wisconsin is a microcosm of the financial devastation the pandemic has brought the sports industry, and those who rely on it.

headline: Kevin Durant and Kyrie Irving Shine in Preseason Homecoming
abstract: With both players returning from injuries, Durant and Irving combined for 33 points in their first game together, more than a year after joining the Nets.
lead_paragraph: It’s rare that an N.B.A. preseason game is must-see television.

headline: No Corrections: Dec. 14, 2020
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Dec. 14, 2020.
lead_paragraph: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Dec. 14, 2020.

headline: Stanford’s Tara VanDerveer Ties Record for Coaching Wins
abstract: VanDerveer can pass Pat Summitt, the longtime Tennessee coach who died in 2016, on Tuesday against Pacific.
lead_paragraph: Tara VanDerveer tied Pat Summitt for the most career coaching wins in Division I women’s college basketball on Sunday night when top-ranked Stanford trounced its rival California, 83-38, in Berkeley.

headline: Storm May Bring Over 6 Inches of Snow From Virginia to New England
abstract: Some areas north and west of the Interstate 95 corridor in New Jersey and Pennsylvania may get more than a foot of snow on Wednesday, the National Weather Service said.
lead_paragraph: [Read live coverage of the nor’easter here.]

headline: Google Delays Return to Office and Eyes ‘Flexible Work Week’
abstract: The Silicon Valley company now plans to have employees return to the office in September. It will be different when they get there.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — With the pandemic still in full swing and the first doses of a coronavirus vaccine just starting to ship in the United States, Google has pushed back the planned return to the office by a few months, to September 2021.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘The Art of Political Murder’ and CBS Specials
abstract: A documentary about the murder of the Guatemalan bishop Juan José Gerardi debuts on HBO. And two celebrity benefit shows air on CBS.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Dec. 14-20. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Word + Quiz: frippery
abstract: This word has appeared in nine articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: ‘The Dark Knight’ and ‘The Blues Brothers’ Join National Film Registry
abstract: The movies, along with “A Clockwork Orange” and “Sweet Sweetback’s Baadasssss Song,” are among 25 selected by the Library of Congress.
lead_paragraph: As the oft-quoted line from “The Dark Knight” goes, “You either die a hero or you live long enough to see yourself become the villain.” Now a more respectable immortality awaits this 2008 Christopher Nolan superhero blockbuster, which earned Heath Ledger a posthumous Academy Award for his performance as the Joker: it is among the memorable motion pictures, along with “Shrek,” “A Clockwork Orange” and “Sweet Sweetback’s Baadasssss Song,” that have been chosen for preservation this year on the Library of Congress’s National Film Registry.

headline: Big Tech Turns Its Lobbyists Loose on Europe, Alarming Regulators
abstract: Silicon Valley is building a powerful influence industry in Brussels, which has “never seen this kind of money” spent this way.
lead_paragraph: A leaked document jolted the European Union capital of Brussels in October, laying out in painstaking detail plans by Google to undermine new legislation that could severely damage its digital advertising business.

headline: 5 Highlights of the N.Y.C. Mayor’s Race: Yang and Rose Enter
abstract: As Kathryn Garcia and Shaun Donovan officially launched their campaigns last week, two newcomers, Andrew Yang and Rep. Max Rose, seemed poised to soon join them.
lead_paragraph: One of the traditions of modern-day election cycles is the two-step dance that candidates perform in launching their campaigns. First comes the string of obvious clues: a listening tour, speeches delivered at Sunday church, and perhaps even an announcement of an exploratory bid.

headline: N.Y.C. Restaurants Face Bleak Winter With No Indoor Dining
abstract: Restaurants already struggling during the pandemic are experiencing another setback. Many increasingly wonder how they will survive.
lead_paragraph: After being shut for two months in the spring because of the pandemic, Maria’s Bistro Mexicano in Sunset Park found signs of optimism in the summer. Outdoor dining bolstered sales. Laid-off workers were rehired. The dining room eventually reopened, welcoming dozens of customers every week to tables spaced six feet apart.

headline: China’s Combative Nationalists See a World Turning Their Way
abstract: China’s Communist Party is pushing the narrative that the pandemic has proved the superiority of its authoritarian model. The muscular message is finding fans at home.
lead_paragraph: In one Beijing artist’s recent depiction of the world in 2098, China is a high-tech superpower and the United States is humbled. Americans have embraced communism and Manhattan, draped with the hammer-and-sickle flags of the “People’s Union of America,” has become a quaint tourist precinct.

headline: Conflicting Narratives Emerge in Ohio Shooting, Prompting Protests
abstract: Much about the shooting death of Casey Goodson Jr. by a sheriff’s deputy has been disputed — what led to it, why it happened and where exactly on his body Mr. Goodson was shot.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — In the moment before Casey Goodson Jr. was shot dead by a sheriff’s deputy at the entrance of his home, his lifelong neighbor heard a man shouting, as if he were arguing, and then a burst of gunfire.

headline: Electoral College Voter: Long an Honor, and Now Also a Headache
abstract: Casting votes in the Electoral College has been a routine part of election mechanics, but this year electors have been thrust into the cross hairs of President Trump’s extraordinary effort to overturn the results.
lead_paragraph: In Michigan, Democratic electors have been promised police escorts from their cars into the State Capitol, where on Monday they will formally vote for Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Restaurants Forge Ahead Without Indoor Dining
abstract: The second wave of the coronavirus has brought a new hardship for  restaurants, which now confront a winter with no indoor dining.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Quotation of the Day: Struggling Restaurants Face Bleak Future as Indoor Dining Ban Begins
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, December 14, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “It all happened just like that, and now we have to go through it again?”

headline: U.K. to Ease Rules on Blood Donations by Gay and Bisexual Men
abstract: The new policy, which will take effect next summer, was described by Britain’s health secretary as a landmark and by an activist as “a fundamental shift toward recognizing people are individuals.”
lead_paragraph: Britain announced on Monday that it would loosen restrictions on blood donation by gay and bisexual men beginning next year, a shift in policy called “landmark” by the government and hailed by activists who have long fought rules they described as discriminatory.

headline: An Ode to the Before Times
abstract: Also, I think I’m losing my mind.
lead_paragraph: Also, I think I’m losing my mind.

headline: A Raging Pandemic Inspires Poetry With Little Bite
abstract: “Together in a Sudden Strangeness,” edited by Alice Quinn, gathers poems that react to life during the coronavirus crisis.
lead_paragraph: What are poets for? One answer arrives in Salman Rushdie’s novel “The Satanic Verses,” when the satirical poet Baal comments that “a poet’s work” is “to name the unnamable, to point at frauds, to take sides, start arguments, shape the world and stop it from going to sleep.”

headline: What Can America Learn From South Africa About National Healing?
abstract: “This is something that we have to say: ‘We will never eradicate racism.’” Read an interview with an expert on Truth and Reconciliation.
lead_paragraph: “This is something that we have to say: ‘We will never eradicate racism.’” Read an interview with an expert on Truth and Reconciliation.

headline: Georgia’s Secretary of State on Standing Up to Trump
abstract: Georgia’s secretary of state infuriated Donald Trump when he stood by Georgia’s presidential election results. Now he has the critical task of overseeing two U.S. Senate runoffs that will determine the fate of the nation.
lead_paragraph: Georgia begins early voting today in two runoffs that will decide the composition of the next U.S. Senate. If Democrats win both seats, the Senate will be split 50-50 (with Vice President-elect Kamala Harris acting as tiebreaker). If they don’t, it will be controlled by Republicans who stand ready to block many actions of a Biden presidency.

headline: An Ode to the Before Times
abstract: Also, I think I’m losing my mind.
lead_paragraph: We all miss things that used to be normal — hugging friends, dancing in crowded places, not being terrified of standing near someone with a dry cough. But what about everything else that we took for granted? After nearly a year of social distancing, a new normal is starting to settle into place, and memories of how things used to be are only growing hazier. When we finally emerge on the other side of all this — hopefully with our sanity loosely intact — will we come to miss this strange year, too?

headline: Leave It in ‘Early Quar’?
abstract: As the U.S. prepares for a long, dark winter indoors, a look at some spring 2020 habits to revive, or avoid repeating.
lead_paragraph: As the United States braces for a long Covid winter, many people have been reflecting on the early spring, when the first wave of shutdowns transformed work, leisure and social life overnight.

headline: Beethoven’s 250th Birthday: Here’s Everything You Need to Know
abstract: Explore the music, life and times of the composer who changed culture.
lead_paragraph: No composer left a mark on music quite like Ludwig van Beethoven. He took the popular forms of his time — symphony, string quartet, piano sonata, opera — and stretched them to their breaking points. He embodied the then-new ideal of the musician as passionate, politically engaged Romantic hero.

headline: Autonomous Vehicles Take Another Big Leap
abstract: The Amazon-owned Zoox is unveiling an electric self-driving vehicle. But are we ready for driverless cars?
lead_paragraph: You know how to Google, how to Uber and how to Netflix and chill. Now, can Jeff Bezos get you to Zoox?

headline: Beethoven’s 250th Birthday: His Greatness Is in the Details
abstract: Brahms, Wagner, even Sondheim: All have followed the great master in building their works from small bits of music.
lead_paragraph: The classical music industry had planned to go all out commemorating Beethoven’s 250th anniversary this year, culminating in his birthday this week. As it happens, the precise date of his birth is uncertain. Records indicate that he was baptized in Bonn, Germany, on Dec. 17, 1770. Since it was customary then to carry out that ritual within 24 hours of a birth, it’s been assumed he was born on Dec. 16 — but we don’t know for sure.

headline: Why Paying People to Be Vaccinated Could Backfire
abstract: Some economists and politicians have proposed offering financial incentives, but that risks sending an unintended message.
lead_paragraph: The approval of the first Covid-19 vaccine in the United States was hailed over the weekend as the beginning of the end of the pandemic. But the road between delivering the first doses and widespread vaccination at rates that will arrest the spread of coronavirus is far from straightforward. Besides the logistical challenges of distributing the vaccine, people must also be willing to take it.  A new survey has found that more than a quarter of Americans are hesistant.

headline: The Psychic Toll of a Pandemic Pregnancy
abstract: Women who had Covid while expecting experienced guilt, shame and unhealthy levels of stress.
lead_paragraph: Kate Glaser had chalked up her exhaustion to being 39 weeks pregnant and having twin toddlers in the house. She also wondered whether her flulike symptoms were a sign that she was about to go into labor. But when she woke up one morning with a 100.4-degree fever, she called her doctor and got a rapid Covid-19 test.

headline: Improving Your Balance to Prevent Falls
abstract: Balance is something the body learns to do automatically by engaging the postural muscles.
lead_paragraph: Several times a day, whether I’m indoors or out, my bone doctor’s mantra reverberates in my head: “Do Not Fall!”

headline: Google Dominates Thanks to an Unrivaled View of the Web
abstract: As regulators seek ways to curb the company’s power, there is more focus on the vast index — hundreds of billions of web pages — behind its search engine.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — In 2000, just two years after it was founded, Google reached a milestone that would lay the foundation for its dominance over the next 20 years: It became the world’s largest search engine, with an index of more than one billion web pages.

headline: Can Congress Overturn the Electoral College Results? Probably Not
abstract: Republicans are planning one final showdown. They are almost certain to fail, but not before Vice President Mike Pence is thrust into having to declare President Trump the loser.
lead_paragraph: The Electoral College’s certification on Monday of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory left just one final venue for President Trump and his supporters to challenge the results of the 2020 election: a joint session of Congress in January.

headline: What’s Next for Trump Voters Who Believe the Election Was Stolen?
abstract: Some are certain the election was fraudulent. Others aren’t so sure. What becomes of their skepticism has important implications for American democracy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Richard Everit walked with a heavy heart from his hotel to join a rally being held by President Trump’s supporters near the White House on Saturday morning. The Supreme Court had rejected a lawsuit by Texas the night before, extinguishing what little hope he had left for the re-election of Mr. Trump, the man who had inspired the first vote of his life.

headline: How Do We Get to Herd Immunity for Fake News?
abstract: We need to match our focus on the supply of misinformation with a focus on the demand for it.
lead_paragraph: Last week, veto-proof majorities of the House and Senate rejected President Trump’s demand that they use a defense-spending bill to repeal liability protections for social media companies. The demand arose from Mr. Trump’s frustration with platforms like Twitter for taking more assertive measures against misinformation and disinformation, including his own.

headline: It’s a Terrible Time for Small Businesses. Except When It’s Not.
abstract: Some entrepreneurs are finding opportunities in unlikely places.
lead_paragraph: A counterintuitive silver lining to the pandemic is developing: While droves of small businesses across the United States have been crushed by Covid-19 and its restrictions, others have been pushed to lift off.

headline: Shopping for Firewood Holders
abstract: If you have a working fireplace, it’s time to stock up on wood. And you’ll need somewhere to put it.
lead_paragraph: If you’re lucky enough to have a wood-burning fireplace, you can look forward to one of winter’s most enjoyable activities: spending cozy nights around the hearth.

headline: Why This Force of 150 Sheriff’s Deputies Is Enforcing Virus Rules
abstract: The New York City Sheriff’s Office, a law enforcement team unknown to most New Yorkers, has been thrust into the spotlight during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: When it came time to crack down on Mac’s Public House, the Staten Island bar that has notoriously defied Covid-19 restrictions, the city sent in a law enforcement team in familiar blue officers’ uniforms wearing badges and carrying guns.

headline: In Indonesia, a Blurred Boundary Between the Living and the Dead
abstract: The Toraja people of southern Sulawesi, one of Indonesia’s largest islands, are known for their elaborate death rituals, which include preserving and exhuming the dead.
lead_paragraph: Editor’s note: This photo essay contains images of human remains that may disturb some readers.

headline: Silent Night: Scenes of a Pandemic Christmas
abstract: Photographers around the country captured how the pandemic has brought many hectic holiday traditions to a halt.
lead_paragraph: Every year, while braving the crowds and jammed parking lots at the mall, I vow that the next holiday season will be different: I’ll spend less time rushing and more time with my family. And yet, one harried holiday seems to blur with the next, like an annual form of amnesia set off by the sweet smell of freshly cut Christmas trees.

headline: A Gym Is Where You Work Out. Everything Else Is Optional.
abstract: Forced to close its physical location because of the pandemic, a Long Island gym has adapted to its members’ settings and abilities, creating an entirely new type of fitness community.
lead_paragraph: In March 2014, Dennis Guerrero and his business partner opened a gym on Long Island. The pair shared a passion for fitness, a dream of creating a community of like-minded people and a willingness to take a risk. Over the next six years, hundreds of members experienced and embraced an environment that fostered a palpable energy, helping athletes of all ages and abilities reach their potential.

headline: Trump delays a plan to fast-track vaccines for White House staff members.
abstract: President Trump said on Sunday night that he would delay a plan for senior White House staff members to receive the coronavirus vaccine in the coming days.
lead_paragraph: President Trump said on Sunday night that he would delay a plan for senior White House staff members to receive the coronavirus vaccine in the coming days.

headline: In many Covid-19 obituaries, personal details are accompanied by virus pleas.
abstract: By Sunday, deaths from the coronavirus were approaching 300,000 in the United States, a toll comparable to losing the entire population of Pittsburgh or St. Louis. Reports of new deaths have more than doubled in the last month to an average of nearly 2,400 each day, more than at any other point in the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: By Sunday, deaths from the coronavirus were approaching 300,000 in the United States, a toll comparable to losing the entire population of Pittsburgh or St. Louis. Reports of new deaths have more than doubled in the last month to an average of nearly 2,400 each day, more than at any other point in the pandemic.

headline: A new study shows an arthritis drug may help Covid-19 patients recover.
abstract: Adding an arthritis drug called baricitinib to Covid-19 treatment regimens that include the antiviral drug remdesivir might shave a day or more off recovery times, especially for those who are seriously sick, according to a study published on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Adding an arthritis drug called baricitinib to Covid-19 treatment regimens that include the antiviral drug remdesivir might shave a day or more off recovery times, especially for those who are seriously sick, according to a study published on Friday.

headline: How Climate Policy Will Change in 2021
abstract: A group of experts gathered to debate the prospects for the new White House administration’s big promises on the environment.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. made action on climate change a central part of his platform during the election campaign, promising a $1.7 trillion investment in clean energy and environmental justice, net-zero emissions in the United States by 2050 and an immediate return to the Paris Agreement. He has reportedly raised the issue of climate in every congratulatory call he has accepted from world leaders, and he has pledged to make climate a focus in every federal agency so that the issue doesn’t end up sidelined in the daily grind of governance.

headline: The U.S. Approves a Vaccine
abstract: An initial shipment of about 2.9 million doses of Pfizer’s coronavirus vaccine will be sent around the United States over the next week. So what happens next?
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration authorized Pfizer’s Covid-19 vaccine for emergency use on Friday, clearing the way for millions of highly vulnerable people to begin receiving inoculations within days.

headline: Sudan Celebrates ‘New Era’ as U.S. Drops It From Terrorism List
abstract: The Trump administration formally removed the country from a list of state sponsors of terrorism on Monday, ending nearly three decades of international isolation.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Sudan took a major step back into the international fold on Monday when the United States formally removed it from a list of nations that sponsor terrorism, ending a 27-year period of isolation that left the vast African country a diplomatic pariah, hobbled its economy and blocked access to financial aid that it now urgently needs.

headline: A Big Day in the U.S.
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: The members of the Electoral College will meet in states across the country today. And while President Trump has tried to disrupt the process, his chances of succeeding remain very slim.

headline: The Electoral College Meets
abstract: An archaic institution finds itself in the spotlight: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: The Electoral College will vote today, but protesters from coast to coast are still unwilling to accept the election’s results. It’s Monday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

headline: Google’s apps crash in a worldwide outage.
abstract: The tech giant’s popular services like Gmail, Hangouts, Meet and YouTube went offline, halting work across the globe.
lead_paragraph: Internet users worldwide received a jarring reminder on Monday about just how reliant they were on Google, when the Silicon Valley giant suffered a major outage for about an hour, sending many of its most popular services offline.

headline: Tech I.P.O.s Take a Breather
abstract: Roblox delayed its debut as Wall Street worries about a bubble.
lead_paragraph: The eye-popping stock market debuts of Airbnb and DoorDash last week have led to the delay of at least one eagerly awaited I.P.O., as executives are taken aback by the strength of the tech stock craze.

headline: Bicycling surges in Manila amid coronavirus lockdowns.
abstract: As the need for social distancing forces governments around the world to reduce public transportation service, city dwellers are hopping on bikes instead. Global bicycle sales have surged to the point where even Giant, the world’s largest bike maker, has struggled to fill orders.
lead_paragraph: As the need for social distancing forces governments around the world to reduce public transportation service, city dwellers are hopping on bikes instead. Global bicycle sales have surged to the point where even Giant, the world’s largest bike maker, has struggled to fill orders.

headline: President Trump still shows no sign he will concede.
abstract: Despite recently suffering the most consequential in a string of defeats in his quest to subvert the results of November’s election, President Trump continued to insist over the weekend that his plans to challenge his loss were “not over.”
lead_paragraph: Despite recently suffering the most consequential in a string of defeats in his quest to subvert the results of November’s election, President Trump continued to insist over the weekend that his plans to challenge his loss were “not over.”

headline: The Electoral College votes in key battleground states for Biden without any surprises or defections.
abstract: The Electoral College was nearing completion Monday afternoon of the process that will officially designate Joseph R. Biden Jr. as the president-elect, as electors in battleground states President Trump had contested — Pennsylvania, Michigan, Wisconsin, Georgia and Arizona — voted with no surprises or defections.
lead_paragraph: The Electoral College was nearing completion Monday afternoon of the process that will officially designate Joseph R. Biden Jr. as the president-elect, as electors in battleground states President Trump had contested — Pennsylvania, Michigan, Wisconsin, Georgia and Arizona — voted with no surprises or defections.

headline: 1st Vaccination in U.S. Is Given in New York, Hard Hit in Outbreak’s First Days
abstract: A nurse in Queens received the coronavirus vaccine during a news conference with Gov. Andrew Cuomo.
lead_paragraph: The first coronavirus vaccination in the United States took place on Monday morning in Queens, state officials said, signaling a turning point in the battle against a pandemic that has profoundly scarred New York, killing more than 35,000 people and severely weakening the economy.

headline: How Much Do You Know About the Philippines?
abstract: Can you find the Philippines on a map? What else do you know about this Pacific island nation with about 110 million people?
lead_paragraph: Can you find the Philippines on a map? What else do you know about this Pacific island nation with about 110 million people?

headline: Bills Beat the Steelers, Surging as a Rival Sinks
abstract: Buffalo can clinch the A.F.C. East title on Saturday. Pittsburgh fell behind Kansas City in the race for the top seed in the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: After the interception that cemented Buffalo’s standing among the N.F.L. elite, the Bills’ defense assembled and jogged the remaining length of the field together, toward the end zone and the cameras and oceans of blue seats. It was midway through the fourth quarter Sunday on a night at Bills Stadium that begged for fans, dancing in the aisles to “Shout” and swilling their Labatts and celebrating a victory that reverberated far beyond western New York.

headline: The first vaccine reached New York on Monday at a fraught moment in the state.
abstract: The first coronavirus vaccines have arrived in New York at a time of urgency, with the virus regaining a foothold in a state that it has profoundly scarred, killing more than 35,000 people and severely weakening the economy.
lead_paragraph: The first coronavirus vaccines have arrived in New York at a time of urgency, with the virus regaining a foothold in a state that it has profoundly scarred, killing more than 35,000 people and severely weakening the economy.

headline: Young Kim Discusses the California G.O.P., After Trump
abstract: Monday: The representative-elect discusses the state’s pandemic response and the future of the Republican Party: “This is not a Trump or Biden issue.”
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: A recent surge in border crossings will test Biden’s promise to enact a more humane border policy.
abstract: After a steep decline in border crossings through much of this year, interceptions of unauthorized migrants are climbing again, setting the stage for the first significant challenge to President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s pledge to adopt a more compassionate policy along America’s 1,100-mile border with Mexico.
lead_paragraph: After a steep decline in border crossings through much of this year, interceptions of unauthorized migrants are climbing again, setting the stage for the first significant challenge to President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s pledge to adopt a more compassionate policy along America’s 1,100-mile border with Mexico.

headline: An Agent’s Mistake Cost an N.B.A. Player $3 Million. He Paid Him Back.
abstract: All Bill Duffy had to do was inform the Miami Heat that Anthony Carter planned to return. Two decades after failing to do that, Duffy has made his client whole.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Carter is one of the most consequential figures in Miami Heat history. And it was all because of a mistake.

headline: Stephen King Has Thoughts About Stephen King TV Shows
abstract: With a new adaptation of “The Stand” arriving Thursday on CBS All Access, the best-selling author looked back at the best and worst adaptations of his stories for television.
lead_paragraph: Stephen King has written some of the most beloved horror novels in the history of popular fiction, and many have been turned into equally acclaimed and successful films. Movies like “Carrie,” “Stand by Me” and “The Shawshank Redemption” have more than earned esteemed spots within the cinematic canon. Others — “Maximum Overdrive,” “Thinner,” “The Dark Tower” — have not.

headline: What You Get for $2.5 Million in California
abstract: A new three-bedroom house in Los Angeles, a Shingle-style home in Inverness and a Mediterranean retreat in Santa Barbara.
lead_paragraph: A new three-bedroom house in Los Angeles, a Shingle-style home in Inverness and a Mediterranean retreat in Santa Barbara.

headline: $2.5 Million Homes in California
abstract: A new three-bedroom house in Los Angeles, a Shingle-style home in Inverness and a Mediterranean retreat in Santa Barbara.
lead_paragraph: The Silver Lake section of Los Angeles was developed in the early 20th century around Silver Lake Reservoir, a man-made lake about a mile from this house. The reservoir remains a center of neighborhood life, surrounded by walking trails, a dog park and a recreation center.

headline: The People Who Actually Had a Pretty Great Year
abstract: It’s not just the filthy rich. Much of America’s professional class has quietly, if a bit guiltily, been doing just fine, despite 2020.
lead_paragraph: In late spring, after almost two months of pandemic-induced shutdown, Dr. Anita Kulkarni was finally allowed to reopen her plastic surgery practice near Dupont Circle in northwest Washington. “It was like I had opened a floodgate,” she said. “I had 40 appointments, Monday to Friday, 9 to 5. It was insane.”

headline: Biden’s 306 Electoral College Votes Make His Victory Official
abstract: See how the 538 members of the Electoral College voted for president.
lead_paragraph: See how the 538 members of the Electoral College voted for president.

headline: Pound for Pound, Taiwan Is the Most Important Place in the World
abstract: Its excellence in the computer chip market puts it at the center of the battle for global technological supremacy.
lead_paragraph: The Cold War between the United States and the Soviet Union perpetually threatened to spark conflict in nations all over the world, including battles over the control of a vast array of natural and industrial resources. The new Cold War, between the United States and China, is increasingly focused on access to just one industry in one place: computer chips made in Taiwan.

headline: John le Carré, a Master of Spy Novels Where the Real Action Was Internal
abstract: The author, who died on Saturday, “had a knack for language of every variety,” our critic Dwight Garner writes. “His books hum with the flavorful and recondite language of espionage.”
lead_paragraph: George Orwell wrote that a creative writer can expect to remain at the top of his form for only about 15 years. John le Carré wrote espionage novels at a high level for nearly 60. His first, “Call for the Dead,” was published in 1961; his last, “Agent Running in the Field,” appeared just last year. There were mediocre books in between, but surprisingly few of them.

headline: Just When Restaurants Thought 2020 Couldn’t Get Any Worse …
abstract: Everything seemed to conspire against New York City’s food and drink businesses. Now, indoor dining has been taken away again.
lead_paragraph: Most New York City restaurants, if they followed the rules and adapted to the pandemic, have been able to serve seated customers for a total of about nine months this year.

headline: Cook Through This
abstract: These are hard times, and still, we’re here to say that cooking can help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. How are you? It’s been nine months of this for a lot of us, and even if the vaccine news is good, it’s not like we’ll be crowding into Katz’s for pastrami any time soon. We’re exhausted. We’re exhausted by so much: anxiety, grief, employment worries, childcare issues, food insecurity, general uneasiness about the state of the world.

headline: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on 2 Iranian Officials in Robert Levinson Case
abstract: The Treasury imposed sanctions on two Interior Ministry officials, who it said were “involved in the abduction, detention and probable death” of Mr. Levinson, a former F.B.I. agent.
lead_paragraph: The Trump administration announced sanctions on two Iranian officials for their involvement in the 2007 disappearance and presumed death of the former F.B.I. agent Robert Levinson, the first time the U.S. government has officially implicated Iran’s government in Mr. Levinson’s case.

headline: Claims of ‘Bleak’ Environmental Justice Record Appear to Fell a Biden Favorite
abstract: The president-elect’s transition team is scrambling to find a new candidate for the E.P.A. after advocates objected to Mary D. Nichols.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Joseph R. Biden, Jr. won the presidential election, his top candidate to lead the nation’s most powerful environmental agency appeared clear: Mary D. Nichols, California’s clean air regulator and arguably the country’s most experienced climate change official, was seen as a lock to run the Environmental Protection Agency.

headline: Early voting begins in the Georgia runoffs, which will determine control of the Senate.
abstract: For weeks, the runoff races for Georgia’s two Senate seats have virtually been impossible for residents to escape, as campaign coverage has dominated the local news and advertisements praising or attacking the candidates have filled every commercial break.
lead_paragraph: For weeks, the runoff races for Georgia’s two Senate seats have virtually been impossible for residents to escape, as campaign coverage has dominated the local news and advertisements praising or attacking the candidates have filled every commercial break.

headline: Watch Live: Electoral College Vote in Georgia
abstract: On Monday, state electors in Georgia will meet to officially cast their Electoral College vote.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, state electors in Georgia will meet to officially cast their Electoral College vote.

headline: Cyberpunk 2077 Developer Apologizes and Offers Refund for Game Glitches
abstract: The company behind the long-awaited video game pledged to fix the bugs and crashes after complaints from players poured in over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: The maker behind Cyberpunk 2077, one of the year’s most highly anticipated video games, on Monday apologized and offered refunds to players who were disappointed in the game’s performance, after days of complaints over glitches and poor visuals on some platforms following its release last week.

headline: ‘Playing With Lives’: Brazil’s Covid Vaccine Plan Is Mired in Chaos
abstract: Political infighting, haphazard planning and a rising anti-vaccine movement have turned the country into a cautionary tale in the coronavirus era.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — As countries rushed their preparations to inoculate citizens against the coronavirus, Brazil, with its world-renowned immunization program and a robust pharmaceutical manufacturing capacity, should have been at a significant advantage.

headline: 16 Delightful Cooking Projects to Brighten Up the Holidays
abstract: If you’ve got time on your hands, these recipes are a joy to make.
lead_paragraph: Unlike the frenzied holidays of seasons past, this one is quieter. With so many plans canceled and calendars cleared, escapist cooking can bring new holiday thrills for ambitious cooks. These festive, intricate recipes are a labor of love but a joy to create. Treat yourself while you have the time.

headline: Hearing Aids Could Use Some Help
abstract: The vital medical devices could be inexpensive and available over the counter. But efforts have stalled under the F.D.A.
lead_paragraph: By now, we were supposed to be swiftly approaching the day when we could walk into a CVS or Walgreens, a Best Buy or Walmart, and walk out with a pair of quality, affordable hearing aids approved by the Food and Drug Administration.

headline: Watch live: Electors to vote in Pennsylvania.
Wisconsin’s Supreme Court denies a last-ditch Trump effort to toss 200,000 votes from Milwaukee and Madison.
abstract: The Wisconsin Supreme Court on Monday denied President Trump’s attempt to invalidate more than 200,000 votes in the state’s two biggest Democratic bastions for the second time this month.
lead_paragraph: The Wisconsin Supreme Court on Monday denied President Trump’s attempt to invalidate more than 200,000 votes in the state’s two biggest Democratic bastions for the second time this month.

headline: New York City restaurants brace for a brutal winter.
abstract: A surge in coronavirus infections prompted Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo to announce a ban on indoor dining in New York City restaurants, which went into effect on Monday. Now, thousands of restaurants face an uncertain future as they brace for brutal winter months that could reduce business to new lows.
lead_paragraph: A surge in coronavirus infections prompted Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo to announce a ban on indoor dining in New York City restaurants, which went into effect on Monday. Now, thousands of restaurants face an uncertain future as they brace for brutal winter months that could reduce business to new lows.

headline: The Crossword Stumper
abstract: A look at one of the entries that fooled solvers in last week’s puzzles.
lead_paragraph: STOP-TIME is a rhythmic device commonly used in early jazz. The accompanying instruments will play staccato accents (notes that have been cut short) while the soloist continues to play. This exaggerates the rhythm and highlights the soloist’s playing.

headline: How Selfish Are Plants? Let’s Do Some Root Analysis
abstract: A new model further untangles the complex strategy games playing out under our feet.
lead_paragraph: Imagine you’re a pepper plant. You need water and nutrients. Luckily, you can grow roots that grab that stuff from the soil and pipe it back to you. So far, so good.

headline: Shawn Mendes Hits No. 1 for the Fourth Time
abstract: The pop-rock singer and songwriter’s latest album, “Wonder,” debuted at the top a week before Taylor Swift’s surprise “Evermore” arrives on the chart.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago, Shawn Mendes was a fresh-faced 11th-grader from Pickering, Ontario, who had ridden a wave of six-second videos on the defunct app Vine — the proto-TikTok — into a surprise No. 1 debut album.

headline: 9 Great John le Carré Adaptations to Stream
abstract: From the beginning, his novels of Cold War espionage and moral ambiguity attracted leading actors and filmmakers. Here are nine that can be streamed.
lead_paragraph: Few authors have had a better shake at the movies than John le Carré, whose sophisticated novels of Cold War atmosphere, moral ambiguities and wryly observed backroom machinations have long attracted talented filmmakers and leading actors.

headline: In Iowa, an emergency room nurse is first in line for vaccination.
abstract: IOWA CITY, Iowa — The vaccine arrived at the University of Iowa Hospital at 7:30 a.m. in a refrigerated FedEx truck, and it was not long before the first dose was injected into the arm of David Conway, 39, an emergency-room nurse.
lead_paragraph: IOWA CITY, Iowa — The vaccine arrived at the University of Iowa Hospital at 7:30 a.m. in a refrigerated FedEx truck, and it was not long before the first dose was injected into the arm of David Conway, 39, an emergency-room nurse.

headline: New Arrests in Killing of White South African Farmer
abstract: A case that made headlines because of perceived racial overtones has taken on new implications after the arrest of the victim’s wife.
lead_paragraph: The murder attracted global attention: A white South African farmer was shot dead in his home last year, not long after seeing his vineyards invaded by shack dwellers.

headline: How the Bee Gees Stayed Alive
abstract: The HBO documentary “The Bee Gees: How Can You Mend a Broken Heart” traces the decades-long arc of a band that mastered a rare pop skill: adaptation.
lead_paragraph: Discovered, embraced, disbanded, reunited, ignored, reinvented, hailed, scorned, disguised, recognized — the Bee Gees’ long career was filled with improbable ups and downs. Most bands are lucky to get one Top 10 hitmaking streak. The Bee Gees — the brothers Barry, Robin and Maurice Gibb — had at least two, singing heartache ballads in the late 1960s and re-emerging in the mid-1970s as the multiplatinum pop face of disco.

headline: Schools Will Close in Germany as Cases Surge
abstract: Even in a country once seen as a success story, the second wave is taking a toll on education
lead_paragraph: This fall, even as cases surged across Europe, Germany worked hard to keep schools open, prioritizing them over other aspects of daily life like restaurants and bars.

headline: Michigan Republican leaders affirm state’s electoral votes and reprimand lawmaker who suggested there might be violence.
abstract: The two most senior leaders in the Michigan legislature, both Republicans, on Monday affirmed the state’s electoral votes that would formalize Joseph R. Biden’s victory, as a fellow lawmaker was punished for suggesting there may be violence at the meeting of electors.
lead_paragraph: The two most senior leaders in the Michigan legislature, both Republicans, on Monday affirmed the state’s electoral votes that would formalize Joseph R. Biden’s victory, as a fellow lawmaker was punished for suggesting there may be violence at the meeting of electors.

headline: Kaatsbaan Announces Spring Festival
abstract: The Hudson Valley arts organization expands its outdoor dance festival to include concerts and panels at its 153 acre campus in Tivoli, N.Y., in May.
lead_paragraph: American Ballet Theater, Mark Morris Dance Group and dancers from New York City Ballet and Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater will headline Kaatsbaan Cultural Park’s follow up to its successful inaugural performance festival last summer. Kaatsbaan, which occupies 153 acres in Tivoli, N.Y., will present outdoor performances, concerts and panels in May, the arts organization announced on Monday.

headline: Answers to Your Questions About the New Covid Vaccines in the U.S.
abstract: Vaccines are rolling out to health workers now and will reach the arms of the rest of us by spring. Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: Here’s the expected order for vaccinations:

headline: A TikTok Doctor Talks Vaccines
abstract: He brings the energy of popular short videos to cancer screenings and infection rates.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: Lidia Menapace, Who Fought Fascists and Sexists, Dies at 96
abstract: She was a partisan in northern Italy during World War II and denounced efforts to discount the role of women in the Resistance. She had been hospitalized with Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: With Americans Stuck at Home, Trade With China Roars Back
abstract: Reducing trade with China was supposed to happen in 2020. But demand for Chinese goods has soared amid pandemic lockdowns.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American imports from China are surging as the year draws to a close, fueled by stay-at-home shoppers who are snapping up Chinese-made furniture and appliances, along with Barbie Dream Houses and bicycles for the holidays.

headline: Canada and the Coronavirus Vaccine: Here’s What It Means
abstract: Who gets its first? Is it safe? And just how soon will life return to normal? As Canada vaccinates its first citizens, here are answers to some common questions.
lead_paragraph: Canada on Monday joined Britain and the United States as the first Western nations to start inoculating their citizens against the coronavirus.

headline: The number of people with the virus who died in the U.S. passes 300,000.
abstract: The number of people with the coronavirus in the United States who have died passed 300,000 on Monday, another wrenching record that comes less than four weeks after the nation’s virus deaths reached a quarter-million.
lead_paragraph: The number of people with the coronavirus in the United States who have died passed 300,000 on Monday, another wrenching record that comes less than four weeks after the nation’s virus deaths reached a quarter-million.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: The U.S. rolls out vaccines.
lead_paragraph: The first shots were given in the American mass vaccination campaign on Monday morning, opening a new chapter in the battle against the coronavirus pandemic, which has killed more people in the U.S. than in any other country.

headline: What Country Music Asked of Charley Pride
abstract: The singer put himself on the line to become the genre’s first Black superstar. He died on Saturday not long after performing at a largely mask-free awards ceremony.
lead_paragraph: At the 54th annual Country Music Association Awards last month, there was Charley Pride, onstage singing his indelible 1971 hit “Kiss an Angel Good Mornin’” alongside the rising country star Jimmie Allen. In the socially distanced audience, Nashville luminaries took in the wondrous spectacle. Eric Church, exuding stoic cool — no mask. Brothers Osborne singing along — no masks. Ashley McBryde swaying to the music — no mask.

headline: CNN and MSNBC Fret Over Post-Trump Future
abstract: Ratings have hit new highs, but executives and journalists at both networks are uneasy about the year ahead.
lead_paragraph: CNN and MSNBC thrived during the Trump years, reaching new heights in ratings and revenue while devoting countless prime-time hours to criticizing a White House antagonist their viewers just could not quit.

headline: Review: A World of Cardsharps and Zoom Dupes in ‘The Future’
abstract: In his latest magic show, Helder Guimarães shuffles an old genre into a new technology with mixed results.
lead_paragraph: When a used-car salesman says, “I will be honest,” it’s a sure sign he won’t be.

headline: The Cleveland Biebers? A Baseball Team Is in Need of a Name
abstract: As fans speculate what name Cleveland will choose to replace “Indians,” the team’s past presents some fairly odd options.
lead_paragraph: Baseball teams have been named for animals, local landmarks and a brand of handgun. Several of them have been identified by the color of their socks. There is one named after a mountain range and another that references dodging the trolleys of a city the team left more than 60 years ago.

headline: Review: This ‘Nutcracker’ Is a Fantasy You Can Enter
abstract: Troy Schumacher’s immersive “The Nutcracker at Wethersfield” provides a dreamlike experience.
lead_paragraph: You may have seen the “The Nutcracker” countless times. Watching it every year might be a holiday tradition. But have you ever been inside it?

headline: ‘Spy, Novelist, Moralist’: The Genius of John le Carré
abstract: A former intelligence official praises the accomplishments of the writer, who died on Saturday at 89. Also: Fast track climate change.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Days After Reopening, London Theaters Must Shut
abstract: The musical “Six” and a concert version of “Les Miserables” are among the shows that will close because of rising coronavirus cases in the city.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — On Dec. 5, “Six” — the hit show about the wives of Henry VIII — staged a triumphant comeback when it became the first musical to be staged in London’s West End since the coronavirus pandemic began in March.

headline: Social Isolation May Increase Your Risk of Falls
abstract: People who lived alone or who had few social contacts were up to 24 percent more likely to have falls than their socially connected peers.
lead_paragraph: Living alone or being socially isolated may increase the risk for falls in older people, British researchers report.

headline: The Failed Efforts to Overturn the Election
abstract: “We are living through the gravest domestic threat to our nation and democracy since the Civil War,” writes one reader. Others express their concerns.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: For London, Tighter Virus Rules. For Boris Johnson, More Pressure.
abstract: The prime minister, already facing a tough week with Brexit, risks additional wrath from Conservatives over the closing of pubs and restaurants again.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson was already facing a treacherous week as he weighs whether to strike a Brexit trade deal with the European Union. Now, Mr. Johnson faces pressure on another front, after his government on Monday imposed tighter restrictions on London to curb a flare-up of the coronavirus.

headline: De Blasio Warns of Another Full Shutdown
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York said the increasing amount of hospitalizations from the coronavirus could lead to another shutdown of nonessential businesses.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York said the increasing amount of hospitalizations from the coronavirus could lead to another shutdown of nonessential businesses.

headline: The Essential John le Carré
abstract: The novelist transformed moral ambiguity and the lives of Cold War spies into high art. If you’ve never read any of his thrillers, here are seven we recommend.
lead_paragraph: John le Carré, who died over the weekend at age 89, left behind a remarkable literary legacy. He wrote 25 novels over nearly six decades, zeroing in on the machinations of the espionage community and distilling complex interior conflicts into eminently readable tales.

headline: Biden calls Trump’s attacks on voting ‘unconscionable.’
abstract: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Monday denounced the attacks on voting by President Trump and his allies, calling them “unconscionable” and saying that no officials should ever face the kind of pressure they received to falsely proclaim an election to be fraudulent.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Monday denounced the attacks on voting by President Trump and his allies, calling them “unconscionable” and saying that no officials should ever face the kind of pressure they received to falsely proclaim an election to be fraudulent.

headline: Russian Officers Were Near Navalny When He Was Poisoned, Report Says
abstract: The agents, from a unit with poisonous chemicals expertise, were tracked by their telephones, the Bellingcat investigative group said, the strongest evidence of Moscow’s involvement in the nerve agent attack.
lead_paragraph: Officers from a secret Russian spy unit with expertise in poisonous substances trailed the Russian opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny for years and were nearby at the time he was exposed to a highly toxic nerve agent that almost killed him last summer, according to a report by Bellingcat, a research group that specializes in open-source investigations.

headline: N.C.A.A. Will Hold 2021 Women’s Basketball Tournament in One Region
abstract: The N.C.A.A. announced that it was in preliminary talks with officials in and around San Antonio to host the entire 63-game tournament in the spring.
lead_paragraph: The 2021 N.C.A.A. women’s basketball tournament will be held in one region in hopes that reduced travel will limit the spread of the coronavirus across the 64 teams expected to play, the Division I Women’s Basketball Committee announced Monday, mirroring the format set last month for the men’s competition.

headline: Introduction to ‘Current Events Conversations’
abstract: Want to learn more about this feature? Watch this short introduction video on our weekly roundup of student conversations.

headline: Pinterest Settles Gender Discrimination Suit for $22.5 Million
abstract: The suit had been brought by Françoise Brougher, Pinterest’s former chief operating officer, who said she was fired after speaking up about mistreatment.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Pinterest on Monday agreed to pay $22.5 million to settle a gender discrimination and retaliation lawsuit from Françoise Brougher, its former chief operating officer, in one of the largest publicly announced individual settlements for gender discrimination.

headline: After a Covid-19 Semester, College Doctors Reflect on Sports
abstract: Weighing the risks and benefits of participating in sports against the larger public health factors.
lead_paragraph: My latest column, about the American Academy of Pediatrics’ new guidance on youth sports in the time of Covid, drew two very different sets of parental responses. The guidance emphasizes the importance of wearing face coverings, and also the importance of making sure that any young athletes who have had Covid infections — even asymptomatic infections — are checked out medically before they return, gradually, to full activity.

headline: Leslie-Lohman Museum Announces New Director
abstract: The nonprofit executive Alyssa Nitchun will lead the museum after its last director, Gonzalo Casals, became the Cultural Affairs Commissioner of New York City.
lead_paragraph: The question of who should steer the Leslie-Lohman Museum of Art through the coronavirus pandemic and toward a new chapter in its 50-year history of championing queer art was answered Monday when the board announced it had selected the nonprofit executive Alyssa Nitchun to become its next director.

headline: To quash vaccine misinformation, this doctor opts for facts over fighting fiction.
abstract: The coronavirus vaccinations are starting. Now Americans need to be persuaded to trust and accept them.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus vaccinations are starting. Now Americans need to be persuaded to trust and accept them.

headline: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on Turkey Over 2017 Purchase of Russian Missile Defenses
abstract: Trump had resisted the economic penalties against Turkey in favor of his personal relationship with President
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration issued sanctions against Turkey’s military acquisitions agency on Monday to punish the NATO ally more than three years after it bought a missile defense system from Russia.

headline: Mikaela Shiffrin Wins First World Cup Race Since January
abstract: Shiffrin’s 67th victory places her third on the career list and comes 10 months after the death of her father, Jeff.
lead_paragraph: Calling the victory bittersweet, Mikaela Shiffrin, the two-time Olympic champion, won a World Cup giant slalom on Monday in Courchevel, France, her first time atop an Alpine podium since the accidental death of her father, Jeff, 10 months ago.

headline: The Next Vaccine Challenge: Reassuring Older Americans
abstract: The two leading coronavirus vaccines seemed to work well in elderly trial volunteers. “I just can’t understand why people are afraid,” one 95-year-old said.
lead_paragraph: He can barely see or hear, but 95-year-old Frank Bruno lives on his own terms: alone, unafraid and now — thanks to the coronavirus vaccine — “ironclad,” as he describes it.

headline: Fruit Flies Are Essential to Science. So Are the Workers Who Keep Them Alive.
abstract: Sustaining the world’s biggest Drosophila collection during the pandemic has been a challenge, but the people in Indiana who supply the insects to labs around the world stay dedicated to the task.
lead_paragraph: The rooms that make up the Bloomington Drosophila Stock Center at Indiana University are lined wall to wall with identical shelves. Each shelf is filled with uniform racks, and each rack with indistinguishable glass vials.

headline: Norman Pearlstine, Top Editor of Los Angeles Times, Takes Adviser Role
abstract: The veteran journalist took charge of the newsroom two years ago in an effort to bring stability to the paper under new ownership.
lead_paragraph: Norman Pearlstine, the executive editor of The Los Angeles Times, has moved into a senior adviser role while the search for his successor continues, the paper’s owner said in an email to the staff on Monday.

headline: What Happens to the Unemployed When the Checks Run Out
abstract: Millions face a steep and immediate drop in spending power when federal jobless benefits end this month, with a sharp rise in the poverty rate.
lead_paragraph: When jobless workers get their last unemployment check, the effect on spending is sharp and swift.

headline: Depression in Childhood Tied to Physical Illnesses in Young Adulthood
abstract: Youths with depression had elevated risks of liver disease, thyroid illness and other problems in their 20s.
lead_paragraph: Children and adolescents diagnosed with depression may be at increased risk for physical diseases and premature death as young adults, researchers report.

headline: California’s electors are meeting now. Their votes are expected to push Biden over the top.
abstract: California’s 55 electors are meeting now as they prepare to cast their votes for President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.
lead_paragraph: California’s 55 electors are meeting now as they prepare to cast their votes for President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Watch Live: Biden Speaks Following Electoral College Certification
abstract: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. delivers remarks after electors in states across the country cast their votes for president.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. delivers remarks after electors in states across the country cast their votes for president.

headline: Electoral College Declares Biden President-Elect
abstract: The Electoral College officially designated Joseph R. Biden Jr. as the president-elect and Kamala Harris vice-president elect.
lead_paragraph: The Electoral College officially designated Joseph R. Biden Jr. as the president-elect and Kamala Harris vice-president elect.

headline: Donald Trump Lost His Battle. The Culture War Goes On.
abstract: The reality-TV president was a practitioner, and a product, of a style of pop-cultural grievance that will outlast him.
lead_paragraph: You could say that the Trump presidency effectively ended when the polls closed election night or when news outlets called the contest for Joseph R. Biden Jr. four days later. You could say that it ended when the Electoral College voted on Monday to make Mr. Biden the president, or that it will end when Mr. Biden is sworn in on Jan. 20.

headline: Vaccines, Electoral College, Google: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: ‘I Trust Science,’ Says Nurse Who Is First to Get Vaccine in U.S.
abstract: Sandra Lindsay, a nurse at a Queens hospital, was the first person in the United States to be vaccinated. She wanted to “inspire people who look like me.”
lead_paragraph: When officials at the Long Island Jewish Medical Center asked for staff volunteers to be among the first to take the coronavirus vaccine, Sandra Lindsay raised her hand.

headline: William Barr Is Out as Attorney General
abstract: Mr. Barr was one of the most powerful members of President Trump’s cabinet and faced widespread criticism over his willingness to advance Mr. Trump’s political agenda.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said on Monday that Attorney General William P. Barr would depart next week, ending a tenure marked by Mr. Barr’s willingness to advance the president’s political agenda and by criticism that he eroded the post-Watergate independence of the Justice Department.

headline: Representative Paul Mitchell leaves Republican Party over its refusal to accept Trump’s loss.
abstract: Representative Paul Mitchell of Michigan, a two-term Republican who voted for President Trump this year, announced on Monday that he would immediately sever his ties with the Republican Party over its refusal to accept the president’s election defeat.
lead_paragraph: Representative Paul Mitchell of Michigan, a two-term Republican who voted for President Trump this year, announced on Monday that he would immediately sever his ties with the Republican Party over its refusal to accept the president’s election defeat.

headline: 4 Takeaways From Biden’s Electoral College Victory
abstract: Joe Biden was confirmed as the winner of the election, but President Trump’s war on the results is likely to have lasting effects for the country.
lead_paragraph: Some electors received police escorts. Some cast their votes in an undisclosed location. Some drew a nationwide audience for what is usually a procedural and obscure constitutional undertaking. Most wore masks and adhered to social distancing rules in deference to the coronavirus pandemic that has defined this long campaign.

headline: A.I. and I
abstract: Artificial intelligence has given my pancreas a mind of its own. Am I the human being of the future?
lead_paragraph: Artificial intelligence often scares us. If you think going for a ride in a self-driving car requires a leap of faith, try having your life depend on an autonomous pancreas hitched to your belt whose algorithms are, for you, the difference between life and death.

headline: Perez Hilton vs. the Fan Armies
abstract: The celebrity blogger was banned from TikTok on Saturday in a move he said was influenced by the app’s biggest stars.
lead_paragraph: Perez Hilton, the early gossip blogger turned media personality, has been permanently banned from TikTok for violating community guidelines, effective Dec. 12.

headline: Cleveland Makes Name Removal Official, Saying It Is ‘Moving Forward’
abstract: The baseball team’s process is being lauded by many rights groups for its thoughtful reconsideration of the name “Indians.”
lead_paragraph: Over the summer, while the country was still roiled by protests over the death of George Floyd at the hands of the police, the Cleveland Indians began to investigate a name change. The team had been known as the Indians since 1915, but after years of protest and criticism over a name that was deemed by many to be racist, it said the time was right to determine whether the name was still appropriate.

headline: Turnout Surges in Georgia as Voting Begins in High-Stakes Senate Runoffs
abstract: The first day of early voting in the runoffs eclipsed the one for the general election, reflecting the interest the campaigns have drawn as Republican control of the Senate hangs in the balance.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — When the polls opened on the first day of early voting in Georgia, weeks before the Nov. 3 election, turnout was so high that it eclipsed a record set four years earlier by 42 percent. It was a staggering level of participation, particularly during a pandemic, state officials boasted, sending a clear signal of the passion surrounding the election.

headline: Did You Get the Coronavirus Vaccine, or Are You Planning To?
abstract: The New York Times would like to hear from people in the U.S. who received a vaccination against Covid-19, or hoped to get one.
lead_paragraph: With approval from the Food and Drug Administration now in hand, Pfizer is shipping doses of its coronavirus vaccine this week to hospitals around the country.

headline: When Did Republicans Start Hating Facts?
abstract: A straight line runs from Reagan to the Trump dead-enders.
lead_paragraph: Republicans spent most of 2020 rejecting science in the face of a runaway pandemic; now they’re rejecting democracy in the face of a clear election loss.

headline: No, Republican attempts to organize ‘alternate’ electors won’t affect the official Electoral College tally.
abstract: Try as they might, the Republicans in Georgia and Michigan who organized uncertified shadow electors to cast votes for President Trump will not be succeeding in their attempt to change their states’ Electoral College votes.
lead_paragraph: Try as they might, the Republicans in Georgia and Michigan who organized uncertified shadow electors to cast votes for President Trump will not be succeeding in their attempt to change their states’ Electoral College votes.

headline: A Hotel That Pays Tribute to Rajasthani Arts and Crafts
abstract: Located in Jaipur’s jewelry district, where fine stones are sold alongside sweets and produce, the Johri shines as bright as any gem.
lead_paragraph: A stone’s throw from the lines of veteran vendors selling sweets, fresh vegetables and gems for fine jewelry at the famous Johri Bazaar in Jaipur’s walled Old City sits a hulking late 19th-century limestone building with a terra cotta-colored facade long known as Lal Haveli. For decades, it operated as a single-family home owned by a branch of the Kasliwal family, members of which have made jewelry for maharajahs, kings and queens since the 16th century and whose business, Gem Palace, is now run by the ninth-generation jeweler and entrepreneur Siddharth Kasliwal.

headline: A Lim Kim Waited Out the Field to Win the U.S. Women’s Open
abstract: The South Korean golfer scanned anxious texts from home while waiting for challengers to finish the rain-delayed final round of the major championship.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — A Lim Kim ran into trouble after she birdied the final three holes for a three-under 67 that catapulted her to victory on Monday in the 75th United States Women’s Open.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: Vaccinations Begin in the U.S.
abstract: A moment of hope, as the country passes another tragic milestone.
lead_paragraph: Today an array of frontline health care workers received the first doses of a mass vaccination campaign that could bring an end to the coronavirus pandemic in the United States.

headline: In Canada, First Vaccines Leave Health Workers in Tears of Relief
abstract: “We were desperate.” As nursing home employees received the first vaccinations on Monday, memories of the pandemic’s first wave left some overwhelmed with emotion.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — During the applause, the celebratory elbow bumps, the camera flashes, Colette Cameron watched through tears as four of her colleagues got jabbed Monday with the country’s first coronavirus vaccinations. Then she removed her suit jacket to follow them herself.

headline: Jared Porter Wants the Mets to Win the Season, Not the Off-Season
abstract: The team’s new general manager has four World Series rings. He hopes he can add another to his collection.
