headline: Court Finds Evidence of Crimes Against Humanity in the Philippines
abstract: The International Criminal Court has released its latest report on President Rodrigo Duterte’s bloody war on drugs.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — The International Criminal Court issued a preliminary report on Tuesday in which it said there was evidence to show crimes against humanity had been committed in the Philippines under President Rodrigo Duterte, whose bloody drug war has left thousands dead since 2016.

headline: Tighter virus restrictions in London add to pressure on Boris Johnson.
abstract: Prime Minister Boris Johnson was already facing a treacherous week as he weighs whether to strike a Brexit trade deal with the European Union. Now, he faces pressure on another front, after his government on Monday imposed tighter restrictions on London to curb a virus flare-up.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Boris Johnson was already facing a treacherous week as he weighs whether to strike a Brexit trade deal with the European Union. Now, he faces pressure on another front, after his government on Monday imposed tighter restrictions on London to curb a virus flare-up.

headline: The first Covid-19 vaccines bring Americans hope in small doses.
abstract: Some of the medical centers that have endured the worst of the coronavirus outbreak in the United States found the gloom that has long filled their corridors replaced by elation and hope on Monday as health care workers became the first to take part in a mass vaccination campaign aimed at ending the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Some of the medical centers that have endured the worst of the coronavirus outbreak in the United States found the gloom that has long filled their corridors replaced by elation and hope on Monday as health care workers became the first to take part in a mass vaccination campaign aimed at ending the pandemic.

headline: Here’s why Brazil’s Covid-19 vaccine plan is mired in chaos.
abstract: As countries rushed their preparations to inoculate citizens against the coronavirus, Brazil, with its world-renowned immunization program and a robust pharmaceutical manufacturing capacity, should have been at a significant advantage.
lead_paragraph: As countries rushed their preparations to inoculate citizens against the coronavirus, Brazil, with its world-renowned immunization program and a robust pharmaceutical manufacturing capacity, should have been at a significant advantage.

headline: Delivery workers in South Korea say they’re dying of ‘overwork.’
abstract: At a logistics depot in southern Seoul, couriers recently held a ritual at the start of another grueling work day: They stood for a moment of silence to remember 15 fellow couriers who they say died this year from overwork.
lead_paragraph: At a logistics depot in southern Seoul, couriers recently held a ritual at the start of another grueling work day: They stood for a moment of silence to remember 15 fellow couriers who they say died this year from overwork.

headline: A Black Student’s Mother Complained About ‘Fences.’ He Was Expelled.
abstract: A dispute about the reading of August Wilson’s Pulitzer Prize-winning play in an English class escalated at the mostly white Providence Day School in Charlotte, N.C.
lead_paragraph: When the mother of a Black ninth grader at a private school in Charlotte, N.C., learned last month that his English class was going to be studying August Wilson’s “Fences,” an acclaimed play examining racism in 1950s America, she complained to the school.

headline: If teachers get vaccinated quickly, can students go back to school?
abstract: In Arizona, where several schools have moved online in recent weeks amid a virus surge, Gov. Doug Ducey declared that teachers would be among the very first people inoculated. “Teachers are essential to our state,” he said. Utah’s governor, Gary Herbert, talked about possibly getting shots to educators this month. And Los Angeles officials urged prioritizing teachers alongside firefighters and prison guards.
lead_paragraph: In Arizona, where several schools have moved online in recent weeks amid a virus surge, Gov. Doug Ducey declared that teachers would be among the very first people inoculated. “Teachers are essential to our state,” he said. Utah’s governor, Gary Herbert, talked about possibly getting shots to educators this month. And Los Angeles officials urged prioritizing teachers alongside firefighters and prison guards.

headline: America’s First Coronavirus Vaccinations
abstract: As the first shots are administered in the United States, we hear what it was like for health care workers in North Dakota and New Orleans.
lead_paragraph: It was like a scene from a movie. In North Dakota, health care workers lifted a bag of dry ice covering one of the state’s first shipments of the coronavirus vaccine and a cloud filled the room. The strict guidelines governing the vaccine’s storage make even opening the box a complex and time-sensitive process.

headline: In a Hard Year, Families Find Joy in Real Christmas Trees
abstract: Bell’s Christmas Trees in Accord, N.Y., closed early this month after its customers, worn down by the pandemic and looking for a safe family activity, bought out its entire inventory.
lead_paragraph: When Allison Protsko was a child, the arrival of the Christmas season meant driving with her family to pick out a Christmas tree, cutting it down themselves and dragging it home.

headline: Japan’s ‘Twitter Killer’ Given Death Sentence for 9 Murders
abstract: Takahiro Shiraishi confessed to killing eight women he stalked on social media, and a man he thought suspected him, in crimes that evoked many of the country’s social fears.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — A Japanese court on Thursday sentenced to death a man who had confessed to stalking and murdering women who had expressed suicidal thoughts on social media, bringing an end to a grisly case that played to many of the country’s social anxieties.

headline: The Fast Path to a Vaccine
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: Before Covid-19, the record for the fastest vaccine development — for mumps — was four years. Most vaccines have required more than a decade of research and experimentation.

headline: ‘Tenet’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: The writer and director Christopher Nolan narrates an action scene from “Tenet.”
lead_paragraph: The writer and director Christopher Nolan narrates an action scene from “Tenet.”

headline: Somalia Severs Diplomatic Ties With Kenya
abstract: Somalia accused its East African neighbor of meddling in its internal affairs, weeks before a crucial general election.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Somalia severed diplomatic ties with Kenya on Tuesday, accusing the neighboring East African nation of meddling in its internal political affairs weeks before a crucial general election.

headline: No Labels, Planning Centrist Push in New Congress, Taps Larry Hogan
abstract: The bipartisan organization has selected the Maryland governor, a Republican, as a leader, ramping up its campaign to influence the new Congress.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The bipartisan political organization No Labels named Gov. Larry Hogan of Maryland, a Republican, as its new national co-chairman on Tuesday as it pushed lawmakers to embrace centrist policies in a new Congress.

headline: Watch the Stars of ‘Tenet’ Leap Tall Buildings
abstract: The writer-director Christopher Nolan discusses a scene that follows John David Washington and Robert Pattinson’s characters as they’re launched up the side of a tower. The movie is now available on demand.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: ‘Faith in Our Institutions Held’
abstract: Biden passes an electoral milestone as the Republicans’ dam cracks: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: The Electoral College votes, affirming Biden’s victory. So now it’s official, again. It’s Tuesday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

headline: Blade Takes Off for the Stock Markets
abstract: The private helicopter taxi company is merging with a blank-check fund.
lead_paragraph: Blade Urban Air Mobility, the New York-based helicopter taxi service, has struck a deal to go public via a sale to a blank-check company backed by KSL Capital that values the company at about $825 million. The deal includes $400 million in proceeds, which includes a $125 million infusion along with the cash in the SPAC. Pending the deal’s closure, it will trade on the Nasdaq under the ticker “BLDE.”

headline: Hungary Passes Laws Curtailing Gay Rights and Expanding Executive Power
abstract: The legislation allows Prime Minister Viktor Orban to further consolidate power while eroding civil liberties. It also makes it harder to scrutinize how the government spends public funds.
lead_paragraph: BUDAPEST — The Hungarian Parliament passed a raft of sweeping measures on Tuesday that curtail the rights of gay citizens and make it more difficult for opposition parties to challenge Prime Minister Viktor Orban and his party in future elections.

headline: I.C.C. Won’t Investigate China’s Detention of Muslims
abstract: The International Criminal Court’s decision angered rights activists, who had lobbied it to investigate Beijing’s repressive policies against Uighurs.
lead_paragraph: The International Criminal Court has decided not to pursue an investigation into China’s mass detention of Muslims, a setback for activists eager to hold Beijing accountable for persecution of ethnic and religious minorities.

headline: Still at Home for the Holidays
abstract: Asked not to travel, many New Yorkers are looking to create new traditions. Some residential buildings are stepping into the void, and have already cued Santa and the jazz band.
lead_paragraph: Like many Americans, Jacob Underwood, a 39-year-old who works in finance, will be staying put for the holidays because of the pandemic. “I usually travel somewhere exotic,” he said. “It’s very sad.”

headline: Moderna Vaccine Is Highly Protective Against Covid-19, the F.D.A. Finds
abstract: The positive review most likely ensures that the Food and Drug Administration will grant emergency authorization to a second coronavirus vaccine this week for millions of Americans.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The coronavirus vaccine made by Moderna is highly protective, according to new data released on Tuesday, setting the stage for its emergency authorization this week by federal regulators and the start of its distribution across the country.

headline: Biden won the Electoral College, but Trump’s attacks on the process will have lasting effects on democracy.
abstract: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory was affirmed by the Electoral College on Monday, despite President Trump’s relentless promotion of conspiracy theories and attacks on the integrity of the results.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory was affirmed by the Electoral College on Monday, despite President Trump’s relentless promotion of conspiracy theories and attacks on the integrity of the results.

headline: Families at the border will present a familiar test for Biden’s Homeland Security pick.
abstract: Alejandro N. Mayorkas, President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s choice to lead the Department of Homeland Security, will immediately face the challenge of rolling back President Trump’s restrictive immigration policies, while balancing demands from the left for more lenient policies with those of the moderates who see any show of tolerance as an instigator to an uptick in illegal migration.
lead_paragraph: Alejandro N. Mayorkas, President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s choice to lead the Department of Homeland Security, will immediately face the challenge of rolling back President Trump’s restrictive immigration policies, while balancing demands from the left for more lenient policies with those of the moderates who see any show of tolerance as an instigator to an uptick in illegal migration.

headline: The next vaccine challenge is to reassure older Americans.
abstract: Older Americans are pivotal to the success of the vaccination campaign rolling out across the United States. They are the most likely to be hospitalized and to die from Covid-19, and the least likely to muster a strong immune response to the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Older Americans are pivotal to the success of the vaccination campaign rolling out across the United States. They are the most likely to be hospitalized and to die from Covid-19, and the least likely to muster a strong immune response to the coronavirus.

headline: Wary Companies Hesitate on Super Bowl Commercials, Citing Pandemic
abstract: As the virus cuts into the annual ad blitz, CBS has yet to book all of the 30-second slots available for the big game.
lead_paragraph: It seemed like money well spent, when Sabra paid millions to book a 30-second slot for the 2020 Super Bowl.

headline: More Senate Republicans warily accept Trump’s loss after Electoral College vote.
abstract: Support for President Trump’s attempt to overturn his election loss began to collapse in the Senate on Monday after the Electoral College certified President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory, with many of the chamber’s top Republicans saying the time had come to recognize results that have been evident for weeks.
lead_paragraph: Support for President Trump’s attempt to overturn his election loss began to collapse in the Senate on Monday after the Electoral College certified President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory, with many of the chamber’s top Republicans saying the time had come to recognize results that have been evident for weeks.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
abstract: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.
lead_paragraph: $2.325 MILLION

headline: How Biden Can Move His Economic Agenda Without Congress
abstract: Union leaders and policy experts say the next administration could do plenty on behalf of workers through regulation and other powers.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s ability to reshape the economy through legislation hinges in large part on the outcome of the two Georgia runoffs in January that will decide control of the Senate. But even without a cooperative Congress, his administration will be able to act on its agenda of raising workers’ standard of living and creating good jobs by taking a series of unilateral actions under existing law.

headline: Modular Construction Meets Changing Needs in the Pandemic
abstract: The process of creating prefabricated units that can be quickly assembled has shifted as developers turn to medical buildings, affordable housing, data centers and even a Chick-fil-A restaurant.
lead_paragraph: When the University of Denver reopened for classes this fall, there was a new building on campus next to the student athletics center: a coronavirus testing center created using modular construction.

headline: Endeavor Expands N.B.A. Talent Reach With Stake in BDA Sports
abstract: Bill Duffy, who founded BDA Sports Management more than two decades ago, represents rising basketball stars like the N.B.A.’s Luka Doncic and the W.N.B.A.’s Sabrina Ionescu.
lead_paragraph: Endeavor, the entertainment and sports conglomerate, expanded its sports representation business Tuesday by purchasing a stake in BDA Sports Management, the firm led by the influential N.B.A. agent Bill Duffy.

headline: Vaccines Come With a Dose of Caution in California
abstract: Tuesday: Health care workers in the state received vaccines on Monday. Also: Images of San Francisco’s Cliff House.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Another Effect of Covid: Thousands of Double Proxy Weddings
abstract: Randy Nuñez and Sasha Nuñez-Carvalho were 4,000 miles apart on the day they were married. The couple, both of whom are in the Navy, were married when two strangers in Montana stood in for them.
lead_paragraph: Randy Nuñez and Sasha Nuñez-Carvalho were married in October while he was quarantined with the coronavirus in San Diego and she was deployed by the Navy, 4,000 miles away, in Europe. Ms. Nuñez-Carvalho was drinking at a bar when her fiancée, now husband, called her to tell her the news.

headline: Biden will have to make difficult decisions about the Guantánamo Bay prison.
abstract: The incoming Biden administration has yet to lay out plans for the Guantánamo Bay military prison on the U.S. Navy base where leftover fragments of the Bush administration’s most disputed responses to the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks remain unresolved three presidencies later.
lead_paragraph: The incoming Biden administration has yet to lay out plans for the Guantánamo Bay military prison on the U.S. Navy base where leftover fragments of the Bush administration’s most disputed responses to the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks remain unresolved three presidencies later.

headline: ‘Heat’ and the TV Movie That Paved Its Way to Becoming a Classic
abstract: What if you could shoot a complete prototype for a movie? That’s essentially what Michael Mann did with “L.A. Takedown” on NBC.
lead_paragraph: Early in Michael Mann’s 1995 crime drama “Heat,” his protagonist destroys a television set. It makes sense in the context of the film (well, sort of), but it also can be read as a wink: Mann, a writer, director and producer who made his name with the TV smash “Miami Vice” (not to mention “Crime Story”), taking a moment from his star-studded, big-screen epic to bite the hand that fed him.

headline: Keegan-Michael Key Reaches into the Past With ‘Midnight Run’ and ‘Electric Ladyland’
abstract: The actor, who appears in the upcoming musical “The Prom,” looks back on improv guides, Whoopi Goldberg’s comedy and Diego Rivera’s murals.
lead_paragraph: The world may have turned upside-down this year, but the actor-producer Keegan-Michael Key has grounded himself in his work, finding a refuge from the isolation and anxiety of the pandemic.

headline: A Deeper, Darker Look at James Beard, Food Oracle and Gay Man
abstract: A new biography traces the influence he wielded as a writer and the pain he endured for his sexuality in an unwelcoming world.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years ago, this is how the foremost American food authority described his favorite menu for a holiday open house:

headline: McConnell congratulates Biden and lobbies colleagues to oppose a final-stage G.O.P. effort to overturn his victory.
abstract: Breaking with President Trump’s drive to overturn his election loss, Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky on Tuesday congratulated President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. on his victory and began a campaign to keep fellow Republicans from joining a last-ditch effort to reverse the outcome when Congress tallies the results next month.
lead_paragraph: Breaking with President Trump’s drive to overturn his election loss, Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky on Tuesday congratulated President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. on his victory and began a campaign to keep fellow Republicans from joining a last-ditch effort to reverse the outcome when Congress tallies the results next month.

headline: These Educators and Activists Can Help You Navigate Intimacy Now
abstract: They’ve taught people how to be close through H.I.V., S.T.I.s and now the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This year, physical distance and safety became part of a suddenly urgent conversation for everyone. But for educators focused on intimacy and consent, questions about bodies and boundaries are a constant focus. Here’s how a number of experts are teaching people how to treat themselves and others well — and where they can teach you.

headline: Big Fines and Strict Rules Unveiled Against ‘Big Tech’ in Europe
abstract: European Union and British authorities released draft laws to halt the spread of harmful content and improve competition.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Authorities in the European Union and Britain built momentum on Tuesday for tougher oversight of the technology industry, as they introduced new regulations to pressure the world’s biggest tech companies to take down harmful content and open themselves up to more competition.

headline: Use It or Lose It: Tenant Aid Effort Nears a Federal Cutoff
abstract: Emergency pandemic funding to help renters must be distributed by Dec. 30. But getting the money to those who need it is no small task.
lead_paragraph: For several months, Gregory Heller, an official with a Philadelphia nonprofit group, has grappled with an unusual problem. He had $60 million in rental aid to help low-income tenants weather the pandemic — and a whole lot of trouble spending it.

headline: Biden struggles to manage the Democratic Party’s competing interests.
abstract: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. is confronting outbreaks of factionalism and fierce impatience within his own party, as the groups that make up the Democratic coalition see President Trump crumbling as an adversary and turn instead toward the battle to define the personnel and policies of a new administration.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. is confronting outbreaks of factionalism and fierce impatience within his own party, as the groups that make up the Democratic coalition see President Trump crumbling as an adversary and turn instead toward the battle to define the personnel and policies of a new administration.

headline: Taylor Swift’s ‘Evermore’: Let’s Discuss
abstract: A second album written and recorded during pandemic lockdown carries the singer and songwriter further from conventional pop.
lead_paragraph: Less than five months after Taylor Swift surprise-released “Folklore,” which she conceived and recorded wholly within pandemic isolation, comes a follow-up album, “Evermore,” on which she works with many of the same collaborators, including Aaron Dessner, Jack Antonoff and Justin Vernon.

headline: In New Hampshire, the governor will wait his turn to get the vaccine.
abstract: It was not quite 30 degrees in Manchester, N.H. — with a wind chill of 19 — but Gov. Chris Sununu looked relieved and happy as the first few health care workers in the state were vaccinated against Covid-19 Tuesday morning outside the Elliot Hospital.
lead_paragraph: It was not quite 30 degrees in Manchester, N.H. — with a wind chill of 19 — but Gov. Chris Sununu looked relieved and happy as the first few health care workers in the state were vaccinated against Covid-19 Tuesday morning outside the Elliot Hospital.

headline: ‘The Last Blockbuster’ Review: All the Nostalgia, With No Late Fees
abstract: Through celebrity interviews, this documentary looks back at the history of the home video retail industry.
lead_paragraph: You ever hear the one about the guy who asked for “Of Human Bondage” at the video store and was told to look in the “adult” section? I saw it happen. In the ’80s. A fair amount of “The Last Blockbuster,” a documentary on video stores — and on one store in particular, as the title implies — spends time with Gen X folks kicking around not dissimilar reminiscences.

headline: How Full Are Hospital I.C.U.s Near You?
abstract: See how many Covid-19 patients are being treated, and how many I.C.U. beds remain available, at individual U.S. hospitals.
lead_paragraph: See how many Covid-19 patients are being treated, and how many I.C.U. beds remain available, at individual U.S. hospitals.

headline: As U.S. Vaccinations Begin, Hope Mixes With Worry
abstract: Readers discuss whether employers should mandate vaccines, foresee restaurants welcoming the vaccinated and urge continued vigilance.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Outdoor Dining Confronts Its Latest Challenge: Snow
abstract: Roadway restaurant installations in the city will close and virus testing at Health and Hospitals sites will stop Wednesday afternoon, when up to a foot of snow is forecast to begin falling.
lead_paragraph: [Nor’easter live updates: Messy snowstorm moves up the East Coast.]

headline: Holiday Cheer, Spiked or Straight
abstract: How do you like your celebration? Taylor Mac gives it to you dazzling and arch, while “Meet Me in St. Louis” is a nostalgic comfort.
lead_paragraph: Taylor Mac’s autumn-harvest headdress is such an elaborate landscape of apples and gourds that the gleaming green talons reaching out of it come across as a subtle touch.

headline: Man Is Jailed After Taking Jet Ski Across Irish Sea to See Girlfriend
abstract: Defying the Isle of Man’s coronavirus restrictions, a 28-year-old traveled from Scotland to the island on Friday. Days after he arrived, he was sentenced to jail for four weeks.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Last Thursday, Dale Mclaughlan bought a Jet Ski.

headline: One Wild Mink Near Utah Fur Farms Tests Positive for Virus
abstract: Infection seems to have come from farm animals, but there is no evidence of further spreading.
lead_paragraph: A wild mink in Utah has tested positive for the coronavirus. Mink on fur farms in the area have been infected with the virus, and the U.S. Agriculture Department, with other government agencies, was testing wild animals looking for potential infections spreading from those farms.

headline: Inauguration planners ask Americans to stay home on Jan. 20 and watch the historic event virtually.
abstract: The committee charged with planning the inauguration of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Vice President-elect Kamala Harris is asking the public to stay home on Jan. 20 and participate in virtual activities instead.
lead_paragraph: The committee charged with planning the inauguration of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Vice President-elect Kamala Harris is asking the public to stay home on Jan. 20 and participate in virtual activities instead.

headline: East Coast Braces for Winter Storm on Wednesday
abstract: Heavy snow is forecast to sweep through the Mid-Atlantic States and barrel north through New England, dropping up to two feet of snow in some areas, but the fast-moving system won’t stick around for long.
lead_paragraph: A major winter storm is forecast to sweep through parts of the Mid-Atlantic States and the Northeast starting early Wednesday, sending heavy snow, freezing rain and strong winds surging through the region into Thursday.

headline: After Wildfires, Mourning the Loss of California’s Giants
abstract: For one reporter, documenting the destruction of redwoods and sequoias was a heartbreaking assignment.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Monarch Butterflies Qualify for Endangered List. They Still Won’t Be Protected.
abstract: Officials said they did not have the money or resources to protect the species even though it meets the criteria under the Endangered Species Act.
lead_paragraph: The monarch butterfly is threatened with extinction, but will not come under federal protection because other species are a higher priority, federal officials announced Tuesday.

headline: What Is José Mourinho Telling Us on Instagram?
abstract: The Tottenham coach’s account is a surprisingly unfiltered window into his personality. It’s revealing a side of him he hasn’t always wanted people to see.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The content itself does not, when you type the words, sound especially fascinating. A 15-second video of a man buffing his shoes. A photograph of that moment he checked his phone in the snow, or that time he sat on a bus, or the day he ate some popcorn.

headline: Ann Reinking: Playful, Refined and With Legs for Days
abstract: Discipline and abandon gave the dancer an ingrained elegance, an internal organization of the body that you sense even when it’s not pronounced.
lead_paragraph: When I think of Ann Reinking, I see legs. Legs in shimmering black tights. Legs in heels. Legs that extend effortlessly to a 6 o’clock extension. They weren’t the only thing that made her dancing so resplendent, but they were the anchor to her daring. Aside from their shape, they had a strength that rooted her body, giving her pelvic isolations a silky sort of groove and her precision a natural, teasing sensuality. Even stretched out on a bed, her legs could tell a story.

headline: Online Shopping Is Amazing. Or Is It?
abstract: So many shower curtains! But with the endless choice comes the risk of being fooled.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: Fashion Mogul Peter Nygard Indicted on Sex-Trafficking Charges
abstract: Mr. Nygard was arrested in Canada at the request of U.S. authorities. A federal indictment in New York City accused him of recruiting dozens of women and teenage girls for sex.
lead_paragraph: Peter Nygard, the Canadian fashion executive, has been charged with sex trafficking, racketeering conspiracy and other crimes that involved dozens of women and teenage girls as victims in the United States, the Bahamas and Canada, federal prosecutors in Manhattan said on Tuesday.

headline: A New Breed of Animal Documentary
abstract: “Gunda” and “My Octopus Teacher” present creatures as distinct beings with qualities that have nothing to do with humans.
lead_paragraph: There’s a moment in “Gunda,” an artful documentary about barnyard animals, that could take its place in a list of the year’s best scenes. The star, a sow with a bustling litter of piglets, has just experienced an unmistakable trauma. Pacing around the farm, she conveys a palpable agitation and emotion, before turning to look at the camera, pointedly.

headline: A snowstorm in the Northeast threatens to snarl vaccine deliveries.
abstract: A major winter storm is bearing down on the Northeast, from Virginia to New England, with the potential to snarl distribution of the Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine in the region.
lead_paragraph: A major winter storm is bearing down on the Northeast, from Virginia to New England, with the potential to snarl distribution of the Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine in the region.

headline: Violent Tragedy Upends a Bible Belt Town in This Brisk Novel
abstract: “The Ancient Hours,” by Michael Bible, examines lives in a North Carolina town after a deadly church fire.
lead_paragraph: THE ANCIENT HOURSBy Michael Bible

headline: New Restaurant Offerings Amid the Pandemic
abstract: Though indoor dining has been suspended indefinitely in New York City, many restaurants continue to seek out creative ways to stay afloat. Here are a few.
lead_paragraph: The suspension of indoor dining in New York City ordered by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is a blow to the restaurants struggling to stay afloat and keep their workers employed. Since the pandemic started, many have tried creative solutions like sharing kitchen space or offering meal kits. Some restaurants, like Avena Downtown, have turned their premises into pop-up shops, or opened markets adjacent to their spaces. Others are joining forces to sell food from their menus, or to become restaurants within restaurants; Osteria Morini, Lafayette and Frenchette have spun-off bakeries.

headline: Panel Finds ‘Serious Concerns’ With Mexican Labor Reforms
abstract: A new report examining Mexican labor reforms required under the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement highlights one of the biggest trade challenges for the incoming Biden administration.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Mexico has made progress in putting in place the sweeping overhauls to its labor system required by the new trade agreement between the United States, Mexico and Canada, but serious challenges still remain, according to a new report by an independent board set up to evaluate those changes.

headline: Review: Catching Up to ‘The Expanse,’ the Space Opera You Love
abstract: The undisputed heir to “Battlestar Galactica” begins its fifth (and next to last) season on Amazon Prime Video.
lead_paragraph: Every year at this time, I and my colleagues on the television beat publish our lists of the year’s best shows and wait, with much interest and some resignation, to be told what we missed. Our most egregious omissions this year, according to readers, included new shows like Netflix’s “Queen’s Gambit,” Apple TV+’s “Ted Lasso” and HBO’s “How to With John Wilson.”

headline: The Virus Trains: How Lockdown Chaos Spread Covid-19 Across India
abstract: Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s coronavirus restrictions sent migrant workers fleeing. To get them home, the government offered special trains. But the trains would spread the virus across the country.
lead_paragraph: SURAT, India — The crowds surged through the gates, fought their way up the stairs of the 160-year-old station, poured across the platforms and engulfed the trains.

headline: What We Saw on Day 1 of the Vaccine Rollout
abstract: Times correspondents report on the first coronavirus vaccinations in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Times correspondents report on the first coronavirus vaccinations in the United States.

headline: New York City Cultural Groups Awarded More Than $47 Million in Grants
abstract: The Department of Cultural Affairs announced Tuesday that more than 1,000 of the city’s cultural organizations would receive the funds.
lead_paragraph: In a year filled with layoffs and budget cuts, New York City’s cultural institutions got some good news on Tuesday: The Department of Cultural Affairs announced that it would award $47.1 million in its newest round of grants, which this year will go to more than 1,000 of the city’s nonprofit organizations.

headline: New At-Home Covid Test Gets Green Light From F.D.A.
abstract: Unlike similar at-home tests, Ellume’s does not require a prescription.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday issued an emergency authorization for the country’s first coronavirus test that can run from start to finish at home without the need for a prescription.

headline: I Can’t Stop Watching Coronavirus Vaccine Videos
abstract: Unboxing a hopeful future.
lead_paragraph: All I seem to want to do these days is stare mindlessly at health care workers and the elderly getting stuck in the arm with a needle.

headline: Biden picks Pete Buttigieg for transportation secretary.
abstract: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. will nominate Pete Buttigieg, the former mayor of South Bend, Ind., to lead the Department of Transportation, adding a young-generation voice to his team, the transition team announced on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. will nominate Pete Buttigieg, the former mayor of South Bend, Ind., to lead the Department of Transportation, adding a young-generation voice to his team, the transition team announced on Tuesday.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: A rich-poor divide in vaccine doses.
lead_paragraph: The U.S., Britain, Canada and others are rolling out coronavirus vaccines after ordering doses that far outnumber their populations. They’ve already laid claim to more than half of the doses coming on the market through 2021, as many poorer nations struggle to secure enough.

headline: Nursing Home Fire in Russia Kills 11
abstract: Small privately run facilities are filling a niche in the country, but fires in these homes are common occurrences.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Two years ago, a private nursing home opened in a village outside the hardscrabble capital of Russia’s steel industry, Magnitogorsk. The home, a social-media advertisement said, was meant for people “whose own family cannot, for this or that reason, provide the necessary care.”

headline: Biden to Face a Confrontational Russia in a World Changed From His Time in Office
abstract: The president-elect will have to assure American national security in ways that will require pushing back on the Kremlin at times and, at others, seeking Russian cooperation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The extensive hack of American government computer systems, almost certainly orchestrated by the Kremlin, underscores the daunting foreign policy challenge that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia poses to the incoming Biden administration.

headline: Tara VanDerveer’s Current Math: 1,099 Wins and Counting
abstract: The Stanford women’s basketball coach surpassed Pat Summitt’s record for wins on Tuesday night. And she isn’t stopping there.
lead_paragraph: One day in the ninth grade, Tara VanDerveer was playing basketball — as she did most days while growing up in upstate New York — when her father interrupted the bounce, bounce, bounce of the ball and ordered her into the house. He wanted her to work on what he viewed as a less trivial pursuit: her math homework.

headline: When Publishing Women Was a Radical Act: A British Editor Looks Back
abstract: In “A Bite of the Apple,” Lennie Goodings recalls her time at Virago Books, occupying a front seat to feminist history.
lead_paragraph: Lennie Goodings, the chair of the trailblazing feminist press Virago, was 5 years old when she spotted her first typo. “I pointed it out to my mother and that was when it first dawned on me that there were humans behind books,” she said in a 2013 interview. “It felt like a secret discovery.”

headline: Critical to Vaccines, Cold Storage Is Wall Street’s Shiny New Thing
abstract: Smaller companies that are key to the cold storage and distribution of Covid-19 vaccines are seeing a flurry of new investments.
lead_paragraph: The situation was dire. As the pandemic raged in March, some Covid-19 patients in Milan were going into septic shock and their blood pressure was perilously low.

headline: Menopause Stories
abstract: ‘There are still many women who think that menopause is the end of your life.’
lead_paragraph: ‘There are still many women who think that menopause is the end of your life.’

headline: Sundance Goes Virtual With a More Accessible 2021 Lineup
abstract: Among the 72 feature films chosen for the slimmed-down festival are a Tessa Thompson racial-issues drama and a music documentary from Questlove.
lead_paragraph: The movies still feel like Sundance. But without the snow, the parties and all those packed premieres, will Sundance still feel like Sundance?

headline: To Cut Emissions to Zero, U.S. Needs to Make Big Changes in Next 10 Years
abstract: New research details major infrastructure work — including immense construction projects — that would need to start right away to achieve Biden’s goal of zero emissions by 2050.
lead_paragraph: If the United States wants to get serious about tackling climate change, the country will need to build a staggering amount of new energy infrastructure in just the next 10 years, laying down steel and concrete at a pace barely being contemplated today.

headline: ‘I Wouldn’t Have Known That My Mom Had Gone Through Menopause’
abstract: Why are we so unprepared for one of life’s inevitable transitions?
lead_paragraph: About half of the world’s population will experience menopause, yet it’s a period that can be isolating for a woman in their personal and professional life. Menopause marks the end of menstruation, and the changes that come with it are often not discussed openly. In the short documentary above, women across England share their intimate, complicated and illuminating experiences with menopause. It’s a conversation that should happen more often, and without fear.

headline: Nursing Home Fire in Russia Kills 11
abstract: On Tuesday, a private nursing home in a village outside the capital of Russia’s steel industry, Magnitogorsk, burned down killing 11 residents.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, a private nursing home in a village outside the capital of Russia’s steel industry, Magnitogorsk, burned down killing 11 residents.

headline: Condé Nast Puts Anna Wintour in Charge of Magazines Worldwide
abstract: The veteran editor gets more power and two new job titles — chief content officer and global editorial director of Vogue — as part of a broader shake-up.
lead_paragraph: Going into this week, Anna Wintour was already one of the most powerful people in the magazine world. She has been the editor in chief of the United States edition of Vogue since 1988, the artistic director of Vogue’s parent, Condé Nast, since 2013, and the company’s global content adviser since 2019.

headline: Facebook lifts ban on political ads for Georgia runoff elections.
abstract: The social network said it made the change because of the“importance of expressing voice and using our tools to reach voters.”
lead_paragraph: Facebook said on Tuesday that it would allow some advertisers to run political issue and candidacy ads in Georgia, a change from its recent ban on political ads in the United States and just weeks before a major runoff election in the state could decide the future of the Senate.

headline: Who Is Jeffrey Rosen, Who Will Lead the Justice Dept. for Trump’s Endgame?
abstract: Attorney General William P. Barr’s resignation makes his low-profile deputy the nation’s top law enforcement official for President Trump’s last month.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the deputy attorney general, Jeffrey A. Rosen, testified at his confirmation hearing in April 2019, he seemed to pledge to keep politics out of law enforcement decisions, telling the Senate: “I would expect in all prosecutorial matters to proceed on the facts and the law and not any improper political influences.”

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Tears Start Before My Feet Stop’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: In 2017, on the way to our third family funeral in four weeks, our car died outside a Minnesota highway sex shop. I hopped around the parking lot to stay warm as my husband called the tow company. “We’re trying to get to a funeral,” he said. “Our car died outside of — Pure Pleasure.” He’s always resilient, but I worried about his spirits; this was another setback during a harsh year. His mother and stepmother texted, suggesting that his recently deceased father had pranked us. We smiled, joking about going inside the shop to “warm up,” but the tow arrived. — Laura Logsdon

headline: Republicans Said, ‘Let the Voters Decide.’ They Have.
abstract: Two readers urge the G.O.P. to accept the election results and move on. Also: Asylum seekers’ plight; women’s sports coverage.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: John le Carré: Writer, Spy, Neighbor, Friend
abstract: The great thriller writer was the best raconteur I have ever known.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — I came to know David Cornwell, who wrote as John le Carré, just after the United States and Britain removed Saddam Hussein from power. He was a neighbor; we met in our local pub in Hampstead in North London. We were introduced by a mutual friend who knew the genial white-haired gentleman in brown suede shoes. “Who was that?” I asked as we reached our own table.

headline: Carlos Araujo Preza, Doctor on the Pandemic’s Front Lines, Dies at 51
abstract: A pulmonologist, he tested positive for Covid-19 and was treated at the same hospital where he once saw patients. He died of the disease.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Giannis Antetokounmpo Signs $228 Million Extension With Bucks
abstract: With less than a week before the deadline, Antetokounmpo signed a five-year extension with the team that drafted him in 2013. He has won the past two N.B.A. Most Valuable Player Awards.
lead_paragraph: Giannis Antetokounmpo redoubled his commitment to the only N.B.A. franchise he has known by signing a five-year contract extension worth an estimated $228 million from the Milwaukee Bucks.

headline: In Sweden, Infections and Calls for a Lockdown Are Rising
abstract: The country has been keeping restaurants and bars open, trying not to let the pandemic disrupt life. But the second wave is forcing the authorities to reconsider their approach.
lead_paragraph: Sweden has been an outlier in the pandemic: It eschewed lockdowns and kept restaurants, bars, schools, movie theaters and gyms mostly open. And while death rates were high compared to its Nordic neighbors, they were comparable to those of larger European countries.

headline: ‘We Are Not at the Finish Line,’ Newsom Says Despite Virus Vaccine
abstract: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California heralded the arrival of the coronavirus vaccine in his state, but he underscored the danger the state faces in the next few weeks.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California heralded the arrival of the coronavirus vaccine in his state, but he underscored the danger the state faces in the next few weeks.

headline: Fed Joins Climate Network, to Applause From the Left
abstract: The central bank joined a network of global financial regulators focused on climate risk. The response to the move underlined its tricky politics.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve is joining a network of central banks and other financial regulators focused on conducting research and shaping policies to help prepare the financial system for the effects of climate change.

headline: No, there aren’t ‘alternate electors’ who can vote for President Trump.
abstract: It’s meaningless theater.
lead_paragraph: Once the Electoral College has met and every state’s election has been certified, there is no constitutional provision for an “alternate slate” of electors. A group of people who gather in a room and claim they are electors, as state-party-backed Republicans did in a few states on Monday, have no more authority than if the people reading this article decided that they, too, wanted to be members of the Electoral College.

headline: 18 Easy Holiday Desserts
abstract: No-fuss treats for a sweet season.
lead_paragraph: Whether you’re an experienced baker who makes a Hogwarts sorting hat croquembouche for fun, or a beginner who rarely turns on the oven, sometimes you want something delicious and festive that you can throw together in a snap. These 18 simple recipes are just that, and most of them take less prep time than it takes to watch “The Grinch.” (The 25-minute 1966 original, of course.)

headline: Who is Jeffrey Rosen, the man set to take over the Justice Dept. for the last month of Trump’s presidency?
abstract: Since the Senate confirmed him to be President Trump’s deputy attorney general in 2019, Jeffrey A. Rosen has kept a low profile.
lead_paragraph: Since the Senate confirmed him to be President Trump’s deputy attorney general in 2019, Jeffrey A. Rosen has kept a low profile.

headline: California Is Banning Short-Term Rentals. Why Can’t Travelers Get Refunds?
abstract: The state’s latest travel restrictions make most hotel or short term lodging illegal. But Airbnb and Vrbo, the biggest home-sharing companies, are sticking to no-refund policies.
lead_paragraph: Travel and travel planning are being disrupted by the worldwide spread of the coronavirus. For the latest updates, read The New York Times’s Covid-19 coverage here.

headline: Could Congress overturn Biden’s Electoral College win? Possibly. Will it? No.
abstract: While the Constitution gives Congress the final say in the election, there is no chance that it will agree to overturn the results.
lead_paragraph: Even after the Electoral College certified President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. as the winner of the election on Monday, some of President Trump’s staunchest allies in Congress refused to accept his loss, vowing that they could still reverse the results on the floor of the United States House of Representatives.

headline: New & Noteworthy Visual Books, From Boxing to Hollywood Candids
abstract: A selection of recent visual books of interest; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
lead_paragraph: FACE TO FACE: The Photographs of Camilla McGrath, by Camilla McGrath et al. (Knopf, $75.) From the 1950s to the ’90s, the socialite captured casual moments with some of the biggest names in entertainment. More than 600 of her photos are here, with text from the likes of Harrison Ford and Fran Lebowitz.

headline: Richard Hinch, Speaker of New Hampshire House, Dies at 71
abstract: A Republican, he had a staunchly conservative agenda as his party took control of the state government in the November election. He died of Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: The F.D.A. confirmed that Moderna’s vaccine was highly effective in preventing Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration released new data today confirming that Moderna’s vaccine was 94.1 percent effective in preventing Covid-19. The positive review means the agency is expected to authorize the vaccine for emergency use on Friday.

headline: Running From Gunshots at the Cathedral With My Son
abstract: Lessons in gratitude from a concert where a gunman opened fire.
lead_paragraph: We almost didn’t go. I’d put the outdoor concert on our calendar, but as Sunday unfurled and some work I had to do relentlessly stared me down and inertia took hold of our family, I announced, “If no one REALLY wants to go to the concert, we’re going to skip it.”

headline: Is the Legal System an Effective Solution to Domestic Violence?
abstract: FKA Twigs has highlighted a problem that 1 in 3 American women face. But it is still rare for aggressors to face charges, convictions or financial penalties.
lead_paragraph: — FKA Twigs on how the actor Shia LaBeouf treated her

headline: Best Comedy of 2020
abstract: Comedians like Leslie Jones, Chelsea Handler and Hannibal Buress adjusted to the new abnormal, turning to Zoom, YouTube, rooftops and parks.
lead_paragraph: The comedy boom finally busted. Not only did the pandemic shut down comedy institutions, but New York clubs like Dangerfield’s, which was half a century old, and the stalwart The Creek & the Cave closed for good, as did the city’s branches of the improv powerhouse, the Upright Citizens Brigade. At the same time, comedians adjusted to the new abnormal, transitioning to Zoom and Instagram Live, and to shows in parks and on rooftops. It was a period of experimentation and stagnancy, contraction and accessibility, despair and occasional joy. In a low year, here were the highlights:

headline: Children Love Snow Days. The Pandemic May End Them Forever.
abstract: In New York City and elsewhere, classes will be held online no matter how bad storms are this year in a shift that makes some parents wistful.
lead_paragraph: [Nor’easter live updates: Messy snowstorm moves up the East Coast.]

headline: Gifts for Everyone on Your List (and We Mean Everyone)
abstract: Though the holiday season is upon us, you might still be looking for gifts for your hardest-to-shop-for acquaintances: quirky, picky, eccentric, fancy family members and friends.
lead_paragraph: Though the holiday season is upon us, you might still be looking for gifts for your hardest-to-shop-for acquaintances: quirky, picky, eccentric, fancy family members and friends.

headline: Moderna, Joe Biden, Giannis Antetokounmpo: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Biden Campaigns in Georgia Ahead of Crucial Runoffs
abstract: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. arrived in Atlanta on Tuesday one day after in-person early voting began. He encouraged Georgians to vote for Democratic Senate candidates in two critical runoffs next month that could give his party full control of Congress.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. arrived in Atlanta on Tuesday one day after in-person early voting began. He encouraged Georgians to vote for Democratic Senate candidates in two critical runoffs next month that could give his party full control of Congress.

headline: How to Pet-Proof Your Holiday Decor
abstract: The holidays are a magical time even for pets, but the cheerful decor can be harmful if you’re not careful.
lead_paragraph: The holidays are a magical time even for pets, but the cheerful decor can be harmful if you’re not careful.

headline: Biden to Pick Jennifer Granholm, Former Michigan Governor, for Energy Secretary
abstract: Ms. Granholm is widely credited with steering her state through a recession and working with the Obama administration on a bailout of the automobile industry.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden will nominate Jennifer M. Granholm, a former governor of Michigan and a longtime champion of renewable energy development, to be the next secretary of energy, according to four people close to the president-elect’s transition team.

headline: Defying Trump, McConnell Seeks to Squelch Bid to Overturn the Election
abstract: Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, congratulated President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. and pleaded with Republicans privately not to join an effort by House members to throw out the results.
lead_paragraph: Breaking with President Trump’s drive to overturn his election loss, Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky on Tuesday congratulated President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. on his victory and began a campaign to keep fellow Republicans from joining a doomed last-ditch effort to reverse the outcome in Congress.

headline: The Vaccine Arrived in a 63-Pound Box, Packed in Dry Ice
abstract: Inside the race to give the first shots: Hospitals around the country scrambled after waiting months for the coronavirus vaccine.
lead_paragraph: The first shipment of the vaccine arrived at a loading dock in Queens shortly after sunrise on Monday. The head pharmacist for one of Northwell Health’s hospitals, who had been tracking the package, opened the 63-pound box, packed in dry ice. He took out a single vial.

headline: Where Does American Democracy Go From Here?
abstract: Six weeks after the election, Republican leaders are finally acknowledging Biden’s victory. Is that a relief, or an omen?
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.

headline: D.C. Passes Bill to Give Young Offenders Chance at Reduced Sentences
abstract: Fueled by a debate over when the justice system should consider young people adults, the legislation would apply to those under 25 when they committed a crime who have served at least 15 years.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The District of Columbia Council passed legislation on Tuesday that would give people who committed crimes as young adults a chance to have their sentences reduced, reflecting a growing national debate over whether offenders in their late teens and early 20s should be treated the same as older people when it comes to sentencing.

headline: Drug Makers Are Pulling Back From a Program to Help the Needy
abstract: Some pharmaceutical companies are scaling back their participation in a federally mandated drug discount program. State attorneys general are demanding that the administration take action.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Some of the nation’s top pharmaceutical companies have stopped giving federally mandated drug discounts to hospitals and clinics that care for the poorest Americans, a move that is prompting bipartisan calls for the health secretary, Alex M. Azar II, to demand reinstatement of the price breaks or punish the firms.

headline: Dominion’s C.E.O. defends his firm’s voting machines to Michigan lawmakers, denouncing a ‘reckless disinformation campaign.’
abstract: A day after Michigan’s 16 electoral votes formally went to President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr., a voting machine manufacturer told state senators that he stood by his company’s work, and shot down unfounded allegations that the results may have been manipulated.
lead_paragraph: A day after Michigan’s 16 electoral votes formally went to President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr., a voting machine manufacturer told state senators that he stood by his company’s work, and shot down unfounded allegations that the results may have been manipulated.

headline: Biden to Name Gina McCarthy, Former E.P.A. Chief, as White House Climate Coordinator
abstract: Ms. McCarthy will serve as a senior adviser to President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr., coordinating climate change policy throughout the government.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. is expected to pick Gina McCarthy, the former administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency under President Barack Obama and the architect of some of his most far-reaching regulations to limit greenhouse gas emissions, to serve as senior White House adviser on climate change, according to three people close to the Biden transition team.

headline: Kamala Harris Deserves a More Important Job
abstract: She could be at the forefront of helping a part of America that’s been left behind.
lead_paragraph: I was speaking recently to Matt Dunne, founder of the Center on Rural Innovation, which promotes digital economic development in small-town America, and he was telling me about a Vermont community near his home with a great public library: “You could drive by on any Sunday and the parking lot would be full,” he said. “There was just one problem: The library was closed on Sundays.”

headline: He’s Too Quiet for His Mate to Hear Him. So He Makes a Megaphone.
abstract: Some tree crickets amplify their calls with leaves, giving them an opportunity to mate that they otherwise might miss.
lead_paragraph: For better or for worse, female tree crickets tend to prioritize two traits in their mates: loudness and size. The louder the boy cricket, the more likely a lady is to be wooed by his serenade. The larger he is when she finds him, the more time she will stay locked in a sexual tryst — in some cases, up to an hour of rollicking, sperm-shuttling fun.

headline: Leaders in Congress Meet in Search of Spending and Stimulus Deals
abstract: The top four congressional leaders had their first in-person spending discussions in months, but were still short of a deal on a pandemic stimulus measure or a broader spending plan.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congressional leaders scrambled on Tuesday to reach agreement on a stimulus bill and a catchall omnibus funding package to keep government funding flowing, meeting to try to hammer out critical spending deals ahead of a Friday deadline.

headline: Trump Didn’t Break Our Democracy. But Did He Fatally Weaken It?
abstract: The election provides a clear example of resilience to authoritarian pressure. But it doesn’t mean our democracy is unbreakable.
lead_paragraph: After the Electoral College vote on Monday affirming his election, Joe Biden declared that “nothing, not even a pandemic or an abuse of power, can extinguish” the “flame of democracy.” Mr. Biden’s speech and the vote capped a series of victories for democratic institutions, including the Supreme Court’s dismissal of a Texas lawsuit that sought to overturn the election results — just the latest turn in the extended refusal of President Trump and his Republican enablers to accept the outcome.

headline: Campaigning in Georgia, Biden Presses for the Senate Majority He Will Need
abstract: The president-elect urged voters at a rally in Atlanta to defeat both the state’s incumbent Republican senators and elect Jon Ossoff and Raphael Warnock, which would give Democrats Senate control.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Tuesday urged Georgia voters to cast ballots for two Democratic Senate candidates in a pair of critical runoffs early next month that he hopes will give his party control of the Senate and help Democrats advance the agenda he promised during his campaign.

headline: U.S. and Pfizer Are Negotiating Deal for More Vaccine Doses Next Year
abstract: The Trump administration is discussing helping the drug maker get the raw materials it would need to produce tens of millions of extra doses of its Covid-19 vaccine in the spring.
lead_paragraph: The Trump administration is negotiating a deal to use its power to free up supplies of raw materials to help Pfizer produce tens of millions of additional doses of its Covid-19 vaccine for Americans in the first half of next year, people familiar with the situation said.

headline: MacKenzie Scott Announces $4.2 Billion More in Charitable Giving
abstract: “She’s disrupting the norms around billionaire philanthropy by moving quickly,” an expert on charities said.
lead_paragraph: In her short career as one of the world’s leading philanthropists, MacKenzie Scott has made a mark through the enormous scale of her giving and also through its speed, donating nearly $6 billion of her fortune this year alone.

headline: Biden Taps Pete Buttigieg for Transportation Secretary
abstract: Mr. Buttigieg would bring a younger voice to the cabinet and add to its diversity as its first openly gay member.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. will nominate Pete Buttigieg to be secretary of transportation, Mr. Biden’s transition team announced Tuesday, selecting a former mayor of South Bend, Ind., and former opponent who would bring a younger voice to the cabinet and add to its diversity as its first openly gay member.

headline: Biden’s Climate Team Begins to Take Shape
abstract: The president-elect is expected to pick Gina McCarthy, a former E.P.A. chief, as White House climate coordinator. Jennifer Granholm, a former Michigan governor, is said to be his choice for the Energy Department.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. is expected to announce a significant part of his energy and environment team this week.

headline: Mexico, in Rebuke to U.S., Adopts Measure Restricting Foreign Agents
abstract: The legislation, which is likely to limit cooperation with U.S. drug agents, was approved after weeks of tension over the Americans’ short-lived arrest of a former Mexican official.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Lawmakers in Mexico approved legislation Tuesday that could sharply limit cooperation with American narcotics agents, delivering a stinging rebuke to the United States after its short-lived arrest of a former Mexican official brought tensions to a boil.

headline: The U.S. and Pfizer are negotiating a deal for more vaccine doses next year.
abstract: The Trump administration is negotiating a deal to use its power to free up supplies of raw materials to help Pfizer produce tens of millions of additional doses of its Covid-19 vaccine for Americans in the first half of next year, people familiar with the situation said.
lead_paragraph: The Trump administration is negotiating a deal to use its power to free up supplies of raw materials to help Pfizer produce tens of millions of additional doses of its Covid-19 vaccine for Americans in the first half of next year, people familiar with the situation said.

headline: Santa Tests Positive for Virus After Photo Session With 50 Children
abstract: A husband and wife who dressed up as Santa and Mrs. Claus for an annual Christmas parade and tree-lighting ceremony in Georgia learned three days after the festivities that they had the coronavirus, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A Georgia couple who dressed up as Santa and Mrs. Claus for an outdoor photo session that was attended by about 50 children last week learned that they had tested positive for the coronavirus three days after the event, the county’s top elected official said on Tuesday.

headline: A man who rode a Jet Ski across the Irish Sea to see his girlfriend was jailed for defying virus restrictions.
abstract: Last Thursday, Dale Mclaughlan bought a Jet Ski.
lead_paragraph: Last Thursday, Dale Mclaughlan bought a Jet Ski.

headline: Myon Burrell Released From Prison in Minnesota
abstract: Myon Burrell, who was sentenced to life in prison as a teenager in a murder case, was released on Tuesday after a vote by the Minnesota Board of Pardons. His case gained national attention after serious flaws in the police investigation came to light.
lead_paragraph: Myon Burrell, who was sentenced to life in prison as a teenager in a murder case, was released on Tuesday after a vote by the Minnesota Board of Pardons. His case gained national attention after serious flaws in the police investigation came to light.

headline: Something You Grin and Bare
abstract: Alex Eaton-Salners collaborates with his cryptologist father, Ed Salners.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — When you have spent your career working as a cryptologist, it’s plausible to believe that you went into the field because you enjoy interpreting information and deciphering codes.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Poorer nations struggle to access a coronavirus vaccine.

headline: Corrections: Dec. 16, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Dec. 16, 2020.
lead_paragraph: A picture caption with an article on Tuesday about the Electoral College’s affirmation of Joe Biden’s victory misidentified an elector. He is Calvin Smyre, not Van Johnson.

headline: Minnesota Releases Myon Burrell, Man Given Life Sentence After a Murder
abstract: Mr. Burrell, who has maintained his innocence, was 16 when an 11-year-old was killed by a stray bullet. The case posed challenges for Senator Amy Klobuchar during her presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: Myon Burrell, 34, was released from a state prison on Tuesday after the Minnesota Board of Pardons commuted his life sentence in a murder case that angered advocates of criminal justice reform and hampered Senator Amy Klobuchar’s presidential campaign.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Rush by Rich Countries to Reserve Early Doses Leaves the Poor Behind
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, December 16, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “The high-income countries have gotten to the front of the line and cleared the shelves.”

headline: Disabled Former N.F.L. Players Get a Reprieve on Benefit Cuts
abstract: A reduction of disability payments, scheduled to start next month, has been delayed for three years, the players union announced.
lead_paragraph: When the N.F.L. Players Association agreed in March to cut payments to some of the league’s most vulnerable former players by reducing their disability benefits starting Jan. 1, 2021, the decision was met with outrage and legal challenges from retired players and their families.

headline: Was Merkel Right to Compromise With the Populists?
abstract: Liberal critics see compromise with the leaders of Hungary and Poland as betraying pro-European forces in those countries.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — The philosopher Avishai Margalit was born in 1939, at the onset of World War II, and has lived most of his life in Israel, a country that has always existed between war and peace. That the value of political compromise has always occupied Professor Margalit’s thinking should come as no surprise. He is haunted by how political compromise becomes an act of political maturity and moral responsibility, and under what conditions it becomes morally unacceptable.

headline: Tom Cruise Erupts at ‘Mission: Impossible’ Crew Over Covid-19 Breach
abstract: On a film set in Britain, the actor tore into the crew with an expletive-laden rant. Production of the blockbuster film had previously been delayed by the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The actor Tom Cruise recently erupted at crew members on the set of “Mission: Impossible 7” over a breach of Covid-19 protocols in an apparent effort to prevent further disruptions to a film whose production has already been delayed by the pandemic.

headline: Word + Quiz: rakish
abstract: This word has appeared in 15 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: Tom Cruise erupts at the ‘Mission: Impossible’ crew over a breach of Covid-19 protocols.
abstract: The actor Tom Cruise recently erupted at crew members on the set of “Mission: Impossible 7” over a breach of Covid-19 protocols. His expletive-laden rant was an apparent effort to prevent further disruptions to a film whose production has already been delayed by the pandemic.

headline: Some Republicans Finally Face ‘Their Biggest Fear: Reality,’ Colbert Says
abstract: Mitch McConnell’s congratulating Joe Biden on his victory in the election was big news among late-night hosts like Stephen Colbert.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Five Minutes of Beethoven
abstract: What emotions, images or ideas does this piano sonata evoke for you?
lead_paragraph: Beethoven was born 250 years ago this month and The Times is celebrating. In “5 Minutes That Will Make You Love Beethoven,” Times music editors and other experts invite you to  “listen to the best of the stormy, tender work of the composer who changed music.”

headline: Can Any A.F.C. Team Catch the Chiefs?
abstract: Sure, Kansas City (12-1) is flawed, but its closest challengers have a long way to go to usurp a Super Bowl berth.
lead_paragraph: The only real danger to the Kansas City Chiefs in the playoffs will be the Chiefs themselves.

headline: Suspect Is Charged With Murder Over Japan Animation Studio Fire
abstract: Prosecutors accused Shinji Aoba in connection with a blaze in Kyoto last year that killed 36, making it the country’s deadliest attack in decades.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japanese prosecutors on Wednesday charged a man with arson and murder in connection with a fire last year that killed 36 at an animation studio in Kyoto, the country’s deadliest attack in decades.

headline: A snowstorm in the Northeast threatens to snarl vaccine deliveries.
abstract: The major winter storm bearing down on the Northeast has the potential to snarl distribution of the Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine in the region.
lead_paragraph: The major winter storm bearing down on the Northeast has the potential to snarl distribution of the Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine in the region.

headline: Huge pileups leave dead and injured on treacherous roads.
abstract: The fast-moving winter storm that barreled through the Mid-Atlantic and into the Northeast on Wednesday and Thursday created hazardous road conditions in the affected areas.
lead_paragraph: The fast-moving winter storm that barreled through the Mid-Atlantic and into the Northeast on Wednesday and Thursday created hazardous road conditions in the affected areas.

headline: The Most Valuable Condiment of 2020: Salsa Macha
abstract: This chunky Mexican chile oil got Tejal Rao through the year. It can make everything from fried eggs to potatoes more delicious.
lead_paragraph: Every time I open the fridge — bored, peckish, frenzied, whatever the mood — I’m reassured by a small clutter of condiments. Preserved lemons from a neighbor’s tree. Sludgy garlic pickles in a distressingly greasy jar. Tubs of fermented bean pastes and bottles of fish sauce, mouths crusted with salty crystals.

headline: ‘Fantasia,’ ‘Snow White,’ Betty Boop, Popeye and the First Golden Age of Animation
abstract: Reid Mitenbuler’s “Wild Minds” is full of high-flown aspirations and zany anecdotes.
lead_paragraph: By the time Walt Disney’s “Fantasia” premiered at Manhattan’s Broadway Theater on Nov. 13, 1940, what had started out as an animated short to revive Mickey Mouse’s flagging career had become a feature-length extravaganza. Images in the movie channeled evolutionary theory and abstract art, depicting roaring dinosaurs, vibrating shapes and dancing brooms. Everything was set to classical music and blasted over the new Fantasound system, whose volume could apparently reach 165 decibels — enough, The New Yorker reported at the time, to “kill many elderly members of the audience, knock the others cold and deafen the survivors for life.” The magazine continued: “Don’t worry about it, though. You’re safe with Walt Disney.”

headline: The Magic Number for Reducing Infections and Keeping Businesses Open
abstract: Data from early in the pandemic reveals there’s a “sweet spot.”
lead_paragraph: Data from early in the pandemic reveals there’s a “sweet spot.”

headline: Her Wrist Was Swollen and Excruciatingly Painful. Steroids Didn’t Help Much.
abstract: At first, it was just sore. Then she could barely turn a doorknob or hold her cellphone. What brought this on?
lead_paragraph: It was the worst pain she had ever felt, the 57-year-old woman told Dr. Mark Vitale. He was a hand surgeon in Greenwich, Conn. — part of the same practice she had visited earlier that year for pain in her hips. But this wrist pain was so much worse.

headline: He Wanted to Count Every Vote in Philadelphia. His Party Had Other Ideas.
abstract: When Donald Trump’s campaign tried to overturn the election results in Pennsylvania, Al Schmidt found himself trapped between his party and his principles.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: For This Christmas Tree Farmer, It’s ‘the Best Year I’ve Ever Seen’
abstract: Plantations Réal Beloin is a family-run tree farm in Quebec that has been operating since the 1980s. This year, it sold out of trees in August and packed up his its last shipment to the U.S. on Thanksgiving weekend.
lead_paragraph: Plantations Réal Beloin is a family-run tree farm in Quebec that has been operating since the 1980s. This year, it sold out of trees in August and packed up his its last shipment to the U.S. on Thanksgiving weekend.

headline: We Asked: Why Does Oreo Keep Releasing New Flavors?
abstract: The brand’s strategy is stunning in its simplicity.
lead_paragraph: The team of people who come up with limited-edition Oreo flavors and collaborations is a half-dozen strong and extremely secretive. Their privacy is so tightly guarded, said Justin Parnell, the senior director of the Oreo brand, that he could not even reveal the team’s name.

headline: My 50-Pound Bag of Flour Is Gone. My Sanity Remains.
abstract: Turns out, all I needed to survive lockdown was sourdough.
lead_paragraph: For a few innocent weeks about 10,000 years ago, at the dawn of the quarantine era of 2020, my Instagram feed and perhaps yours, too, was suddenly overrun with images of impossibly lovely loaves of homemade bread. It was one of the first social-media show-off fads of the pandemic; with everyone stuck at home, cut off from gym mirrors and airplane wings at sunset, bread-making virtuosity emerged in certain circles as the hottest new way to show everyone online how much better you were than everyone else.

headline: When Can We Start Making Plans?
abstract: We asked Dr. Anthony S. Fauci and other experts when they thought life would start to feel more normal.
lead_paragraph: The United States moved one step closer to getting back to normal this week with the first Covid vaccinations of health care workers around the country. While the majority of Americans won’t get their shots until spring, the vaccine rollout is a hopeful sign of better days ahead. We asked Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, as well as several epidemiologists and health and science writers for The Times, for their predictions about the months ahead. Here’s what they had to say.

headline: Makeup Without the Markup
abstract: With her latest venture, the Bliss founder Marcia Kilgore is selling high-end beauty products at prices closer to what the factories charge. Will consumers want a slice of Beauty Pie?
lead_paragraph: Some people are lucky enough to have one good idea in life that they then build into a successful business. Marcia Kilgore had five.

headline: Time to Break Out the Lipstick
abstract: At the end of a socially distanced year, simply having the excuse to put on some makeup, like lip color, feels like a cause for celebration.
lead_paragraph: Like so many things this year, holiday get-togethers — perhaps attended on Zoom, possibly in leggings hidden from the computer screen — don’t look all that much like a traditional seasonal gathering.

headline: What the Asian-American Coalition Can Teach the Democrats
abstract: Its ability to form a solid majority around a shared politics despite its many differences is a model for the party — and the nation.
lead_paragraph: In coalition politics, every part of the coalition matters, especially when elections are close. For Democrats, Asian-Americans are suddenly crucial: They are the fastest-growing racial or ethnic group in the U.S. electorate, constituting 4.7 percent of the voting population — enough to make a difference in the presidential contest in Georgia, where Joe Biden won by some 12,000 votes.

headline: 2020: A Year in Fitness Like No Other
abstract: The novel coronavirus crept into and transformed every aspect of our lives, including the way we work out.
lead_paragraph: This year, the novel coronavirus crept into and transformed every aspect of our lives, including our fitness. In countless ways — some surprising, and a few beneficial and potentially lasting — it altered how, why and what we need from exercise.

headline: This Is the Health System That Biden Inherits From Trump
abstract: With medical spending down for the first time in decades, gains in care for the poor and vulnerable are under threat.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Joe Biden will inherit a health system that is trying to care for a population made sicker by both coronavirus and skipped preventive care, all while trying to make up for money lost in 2020.

headline: It Took Mitch McConnell Six Weeks
abstract: With its surreal defiance, the Republican Party has established a new normal for anti-democratic behavior.
lead_paragraph: Early this week, electors in 50 states and Washington, D.C., formally chose Joe Biden as the next president of the United States.

headline: The Endless Debate: Cancel or Rebook?
abstract: Would-be travelers this year have spent hours on hold, learning the ins and outs of refund policies.
lead_paragraph: A 50th birthday, 50 new places: That was Allison Andrews’ plan for the year.

headline: ‘Like a Hand Grasping’: Trump Appointees Describe the Crushing of the C.D.C.
abstract: Kyle McGowan, a former chief of staff at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, and his deputy, Amanda Campbell, go public on the Trump administration’s manipulation of the agency.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Kyle McGowan, a former chief of staff at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, and his deputy, Amanda Campbell, were installed in 2018 as two of the youngest political appointees in the history of the world’s premier public health agency, young Republicans returning to their native Georgia to dream jobs.

headline: Senator Jon Tester on Democrats and Rural Voters: ‘Our Message Is Really, Really Flawed’
abstract: Mr. Tester, a Montana farmer, detailed in an interview how Democrats had failed to connect with many voters: “You cannot have Chuck Schumer talking rural issues to rural people.”
lead_paragraph: President Trump visited Montana four times in 2018 as part of the Republican Party’s attempt at unseating Senator Jon Tester. It didn’t work: Mr. Tester was re-elected that year to a third term.

headline: Nikki Giovanni, Finding the Song in the Darkest Days
abstract: Part of the Black Arts Movement in the 1960s, part of a Biden campaign ad in 2020, she has never stopped writing.
