lead_paragraph: Over the course of her 52-year career, Nikki Giovanni has written 12 children’s books and eight nonfiction books, and she has released 10 spoken word albums. But the genre for which she is best known is poetry.

headline: America, We Have a Problem
abstract: The rise of “political sectarianism” is putting us all in danger.
lead_paragraph: The turbulence that followed the Nov. 3 election has roiled American politics, demonstrating an ominous vulnerability in our political system.

headline: What Makes You Think 2021 Will Be Better?
abstract: Most of the issues that made 2020 feel like a horror story will roll along with us into the new year.
lead_paragraph: I’m not a Debbie Downer. Far from it. I’m usually an optimist who pushes for hope in the most dire of circumstances. However, when I hear friends talk about how the new year and Joe Biden’s presidency will answer our collective prayers and cleanse our collective palate from 2020’s unrelenting onslaught of pain and misery, I can’t help but feel skeptical.

headline: Why Christmas Tree Sellers Feel Like Lucy at Her Psychiatrist Stand
abstract: Vendors in New York say they have seen a rush of customers eager for a sense of comfort in a year of constant turbulence.
lead_paragraph: Diana Karvelis spent 15 minutes choosing just the right Christmas tree — a five-footer that cost $65 — at a stand in the East Village on a freezing weekday night.

headline: Fed Closes Out Wild Year as All Eyes Focus on Bond-Buying Program
abstract: The central bank’s meeting will wrap up Wednesday, as the Fed stares down a bifurcated economic outlook.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve is wrapping up what might be the most activist year in its history with a final scheduled policy meeting this week, one at which it is expected to leave interest rates at rock bottom and to signal continued willingness to help the economy through the challenging pandemic era.

headline: Living In ... Newburgh, N.Y.
abstract: As many New Yorkers have discovered, this Orange County city doesn’t just have good bones, it is magnificent — and still relatively affordable.
lead_paragraph: As many New Yorkers have discovered, this Orange County city doesn’t just have good bones, it is magnificent — and still relatively affordable.

headline: Pandemic Leaves More Military Families Seeking Food Assistance
abstract: Veterans are in a similar situation, hunger advocates and service organizations have found.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Fort Bragg, the largest military base in the United States, has all the trappings of a small American city: shopping centers, a barber shop and social clubs. In a sign of the times, it also has a food bank.

headline: Newburgh, N.Y.: Onetime Jewel of the Hudson River
abstract: As many New Yorkers discovered during the pandemic, this Orange County city doesn’t just have good bones, it is magnificent — and still fairly affordable.
lead_paragraph: Eight years before she moved up to Newburgh, Cher Vickers started a blog called Newburgh Restoration. Writing from the Bronx and then Amityville, N.Y., she sang the praises of this city of 28,000 in Orange County that not so long ago was called the “murder capital of New York.” Many of the posts featured luscious Victorian houses — some intact, others not so much — each a representative of the state’s largest historic district outside of New York City.

headline: Counting on Biden, M.T.A. Shifts From Doomsday Budget to a Wishful One
abstract: New York’s transportation agency is expected to pass a stopgap budget that omits the draconian cuts transit officials have threatened in recent months.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has warned for months that the agency would be forced to make draconian cuts, including slashing New York City’s subway service by 40 percent, as the pandemic plunged the nation’s largest public transit agency into its worst financial crisis.

headline: A Portraitist Whose Subjects Are All in Her Head
abstract: A major new exhibition at Tate Britain in London puts the spotlight on Lynette Yiadom-Boakye, an artist who paints enigmatic Black characters of her own invention.
lead_paragraph: The British artist Lynette Yiadom-Boakye is a committed painter of people. Every piece she shows is, on first impression, a portrait — a careful study of one person, or, at most, a small group, with little to distract from their presence and force.

headline: From Voter Fraud to Vaccine Lies: Misinformation Peddlers Shift Gears
abstract: Election-related falsehoods have subsided, but misleading claims about the coronavirus vaccines are surging — often spread by the same people.
lead_paragraph: Sidney Powell, a lawyer who was part of President Trump’s legal team, spread a conspiracy theory last month about election fraud. For days, she claimed that she would “release the Kraken” by showing voluminous evidence that Mr. Trump had won the election by a landslide.

headline: How Putting on a Mask Raised Naomi Osaka’s Voice
abstract: She used her time away from competing during the pandemic to reflect on the world and her place within it. When the time came to speak, she approached it in her own distinct way.
lead_paragraph: As usual, Naomi Osaka’s postmatch interview struck an emotional chord.

headline: As cases surge and criticism swells, Sweden rethinks its response.
abstract: Since the pandemic began, a debate has raged both inside and outside of Sweden over how to curb the virus. As other countries went into lockdown in the spring, Sweden stayed open out of concern that keeping everyone holed up at home would have long-term detrimental effects on children and adults and could lead to depression, suicide, postponed health care and job losses.
lead_paragraph: Since the pandemic began, a debate has raged both inside and outside of Sweden over how to curb the virus. As other countries went into lockdown in the spring, Sweden stayed open out of concern that keeping everyone holed up at home would have long-term detrimental effects on children and adults and could lead to depression, suicide, postponed health care and job losses.

headline: The pandemic has forced more military families and veterans to seek food assistance.
abstract: This spring, the Y.M.C.A. on Fort Bragg, the largest military base in the United States, saw a 40 percent increase in requests for groceries at its food pantry. During the same period, grocery requests to AmericaServes, a network that helps military families, jumped to the biggest service request in the organization’s history.
lead_paragraph: This spring, the Y.M.C.A. on Fort Bragg, the largest military base in the United States, saw a 40 percent increase in requests for groceries at its food pantry. During the same period, grocery requests to AmericaServes, a network that helps military families, jumped to the biggest service request in the organization’s history.

headline: Snow in N.Y.C.: When Will It Start, and How Much Will Fall?
abstract: Wednesday's snowstorm in New York City will be the biggest in recent years. Many New Yorkers were planning to stay home anyway.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: How Russia Wins the Climate Crisis
abstract: Climate change is propelling enormous human migrations, transforming global agriculture and remaking the world order — and no country stands to gain more than Russia.
lead_paragraph: Climate change is propelling enormous human migrations, transforming global agriculture and remaking the world order — and no country stands to gain more than Russia.

headline: Here’s how the Trump administration crushed the C.D.C., according to two who were there.
abstract: Kyle McGowan, a former chief of staff at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, and his deputy, Amanda Campbell, were installed in 2018 as two of the youngest political appointees in the history of the world’s premier public health agency, young Republicans returning to their native Georgia to dream jobs.
lead_paragraph: Kyle McGowan, a former chief of staff at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, and his deputy, Amanda Campbell, were installed in 2018 as two of the youngest political appointees in the history of the world’s premier public health agency, young Republicans returning to their native Georgia to dream jobs.

headline: What is a nor’easter, exactly?
abstract: The storms can produce dangerous conditions such as power outages, icy roads and fallen trees
lead_paragraph: The word “nor’easter” usually elicits images of streets blanketed in heaps of snow and power lines defeated by intense winds. But what, exactly, makes a storm a nor’easter?

headline: Trains and lockdown chaos helped spread the coronavirus across India.
abstract: SURAT, India — The crowds surged through the gates, fought their way up the stairs of the 160-year-old station, poured across the platforms and engulfed the trains.
lead_paragraph: SURAT, India — The crowds surged through the gates, fought their way up the stairs of the 160-year-old station, poured across the platforms and engulfed the trains.

headline: Who Made My Puzzle?
abstract: This month’s spotlight shines on the wife-and-husband team of Amanda Chung and Karl Ni.
lead_paragraph: Mountain View, Calif.

headline: How Capitalism Is Coping in an Era of Populism
abstract: A group of experts gathered to debate the role of government and business, and what each can do to address rising anger over inequality.
lead_paragraph: Recent years have seen a marked rise of populism, as leaders like President Trump tapped into fury over growing chasms in society to assume power and reshape American institutions. Even President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr., an embodiment of the Washington establishment for decades, has embraced populist elements in his platform. (Core to his “Build Back Better” plan is “Buy American,” after all.)

headline: How to Revive the Economy, and When to Worry About All That Debt
abstract: A group of experts gathered to debate the priorities for economic policy with the end of the pandemic (seemingly) in sight.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic has taken a brutal toll on the U.S. economy. Job losses resulting from the health crisis wiped out years’ worth of gains, hitting women, people of color and lower-paid workers already vulnerable to economic swings the hardest. An estimated 60 percent of businesses — about 100,000 individual establishments — that closed their doors temporarily as a result of Covid-19 have shut down for good, and more may follow in the months to come.

headline: Hacked, Again
abstract: Undetected for months, a sophisticated hacking operation gave foreign agents access to the inner workings of American government. Who was behind it and why does it keep happening?
lead_paragraph: Once again, hackers working on behalf of a foreign government have been able to breach U.S. government computer networks.

headline: Comparing Virus Surges
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: It’s happening again: For the second time this year, the United States has fallen behind nearly every other country in combating the virus.

headline: Pantomimes, an annual British cultural institution, are canceled.
abstract: The pantomime — merry, family-friendly musical comedy shows which take top billing at theaters throughout December — remains a peculiarly British tradition. It is nominally a children’s Christmas show based on a fairy tale such as “Sleeping Beauty,” “Cinderella” or “Jack and the Beanstalk” to which music-hall elements are added. Those include the dame (an actor in drag, who usually has a penchant for sexual innuendo), song-and-dance routines with topical lyrics, slapstick, in-jokes, call-and-response (“Oh no it isn’t!” “Oh yes it is!”) and familiar celebrity guest stars.
lead_paragraph: The pantomime — merry, family-friendly musical comedy shows which take top billing at theaters throughout December — remains a peculiarly British tradition. It is nominally a children’s Christmas show based on a fairy tale such as “Sleeping Beauty,” “Cinderella” or “Jack and the Beanstalk” to which music-hall elements are added. Those include the dame (an actor in drag, who usually has a penchant for sexual innuendo), song-and-dance routines with topical lyrics, slapstick, in-jokes, call-and-response (“Oh no it isn’t!” “Oh yes it is!”) and familiar celebrity guest stars.

headline: How to Get a Fragrant Tween to Shower
abstract: And why they don’t want to in the first place.
lead_paragraph: As stay-at-home orders return and each day seems to blend into the next, I’m hearing from colleagues and readers alike that their older kids are resisting shower time. While the littler ones can get by with a full bath once or twice a week, unless they’ve decided to make mud pies, the older ones get … let’s say, fragrant. If you’re nestled up beside them doing online learning, that makes for a distinctly unpleasant familial experience.

headline: Companies crucial to vaccine distribution are seeing a flurry of investments.
abstract: companies that are key to the cold storage and distribution of Covid-19 vaccines are seeing a flurry of new investments.
lead_paragraph: Until recently, the temperature-controlled storage and shipping of pharmaceutical products, known as the “cold chain,” was a relatively sleepy corner of the health care industry.

headline: Advocacy groups are rushing to get aid to renters before a federal cutoff date.
abstract: Almost from the moment the pandemic spread across the United States, advocacy groups have warned that the economic fallout could cause mass displacement of low-income tenants.
lead_paragraph: Almost from the moment the pandemic spread across the United States, advocacy groups have warned that the economic fallout could cause mass displacement of low-income tenants.

headline: Biden Rallies Democrats in Georgia
abstract: The president-elect chooses some familiar names for his cabinet: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: McConnell congratulates Biden on his victory for the first time, while Biden is down in Georgia trying to claw the Senate majority away from him. It’s Wednesday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

headline: Wall Street Sees Cold, Hard Cash in Vaccine Storage
abstract: Investors see a path to riches in the “cold chain.”
lead_paragraph: As Pfizer’s Covid-19 vaccine is rolled out across the U.S. and Moderna’s moves closer to gaining emergency approval, financiers are — naturally — seeking ways to profit. As The Times’s Kate Kelly reports, one popular path runs through the normally unsexy business of medical freezers.

headline: Turkey’s coffeehouses, a hub of male social life, may not survive the pandemic.
abstract: For years, Varan Suzme has frequented the Kiral Coffeehouse near his home, where men of his Istanbul neighborhood while away hours chatting, sipping from tiny, steaming cups and playing backgammon and cards.
lead_paragraph: For years, Varan Suzme has frequented the Kiral Coffeehouse near his home, where men of his Istanbul neighborhood while away hours chatting, sipping from tiny, steaming cups and playing backgammon and cards.

headline: China Battles the World’s Biggest Coal Exporter, and Coal Is Losing
abstract: China has officially blocked coal imports from Australia after months of vague restrictions. For Australia, the world’s largest coal exporter, the decision is a gut punch.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — China is forcing Australia to confront what many countries are concluding: The coal era is coming to an end.

headline: Go inside the race to offer the first Covid-19 vaccinations in the United States.
abstract: Hospitals around the country who have been waiting months for the first doses rapidly scrambled to put together events after unknowns about the vaccine and its distribution made it difficult to perfectly plan for its arrival.
lead_paragraph: Hospitals around the country who have been waiting months for the first doses rapidly scrambled to put together events after unknowns about the vaccine and its distribution made it difficult to perfectly plan for its arrival.

headline: China Charges Hong Kong Activists Caught Fleeing to Taiwan
abstract: The group has been denied access to lawyers hired by their families, raising fears in Hong Kong.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Ten Hong Kong activists who were captured at sea while trying to flee to Taiwan in August were charged in mainland China on Wednesday with illegal boundary-crossing offenses that could put some of them behind bars for years.

headline: How Should Racial Slurs in Literature Be Handled in the Classroom?
abstract: We look at whether the school context — the student body, teachers and larger community — should affect the way that books addressing race and racism are taught.
lead_paragraph: Have you ever been assigned to read a book that included racial slurs? How was that material introduced to you by your teacher? Were students given instructions for how to handle the racial slur when reading aloud? How did you feel and react when engaging with that content?

headline: Wealthier, Whiter Areas Are More Likely to Get Help After Fires, Data Show
abstract: New research offers further signs that racial and economic inequality leave some Americans more exposed to the worsening effects of climate change.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Wealthier and whiter neighborhoods stricken by wildfires are more likely to get help to reduce the risk of future fires, new data suggest, the latest evidence that racial and economic inequality leaves some Americans more exposed to the worsening effects of climate change.

headline: Trump Administration Says Vietnam and Switzerland Manipulated Currency
abstract: The decision to label the countries currency manipulators for the first time is likely to raise tensions with two trading partners.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration on Wednesday labeled Vietnam and Switzerland currency manipulators, accusing them for the first time of improperly intervening in foreign exchange markets and setting off a new economic confrontation with two trading partners.

headline: Red Flags for Economy as Retail Sales Fall for a Second Month
abstract: Drops in November and October raise questions about how retailers are faring in the all-important holiday shopping season.
lead_paragraph: Consumer spending has been one of the few bright spots in the pandemic-battered economy. Since the spring, Americans have spent more each month even in the face of mounting job losses, political turmoil and recurring virus outbreaks.

headline: Biden’s climate team begins to take shape.
abstract: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. is expected to announce a significant part of his energy and environment team this week.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. is expected to announce a significant part of his energy and environment team this week.

headline: The steady pace of Biden’s announcements frustrates some progressives in his party.
abstract: Many in the left wing of the Democratic Party want President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. to move faster in announcing substantive plans for his administration, such as a sweeping plan to bring the coronavirus crisis under control, urging him to provide more than just glimpses of what he might do early on.
lead_paragraph: Many in the left wing of the Democratic Party want President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. to move faster in announcing substantive plans for his administration, such as a sweeping plan to bring the coronavirus crisis under control, urging him to provide more than just glimpses of what he might do early on.

headline: A bolder Russia is setting up to be a greater challenge for Biden than Obama.
abstract: The extensive hack of American government computer systems, almost certainly orchestrated by the Kremlin, underscores the daunting foreign policy challenge that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia poses to the incoming Biden administration.
lead_paragraph: The extensive hack of American government computer systems, almost certainly orchestrated by the Kremlin, underscores the daunting foreign policy challenge that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia poses to the incoming Biden administration.

headline: ‘This Was Coming Full Circle’
abstract: Wednesday: The intensive care nurse who was the first person in California to get a vaccine dose talks about the experience.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Red Sox. White Sox. Blue Sox? Manny Is Still Manny.
abstract: The Sydney Blue Sox were stunned that Manny Ramirez, 48, wanted to join the Australian Baseball League. They’re counting on the former superstar to raise baseball’s profile in the country.
lead_paragraph: Adam Dobb thought he was being punked.

headline: How to Send a Recap of 2020 to Friends and Family
abstract: Even if you’ve never done a year-end newsletter, there’s still time to squeeze in a personalized message before the calendar flips the page.
lead_paragraph: For many people, 2020 has been a disruptive, frustrating, heartbreaking and disorienting year. But as December winds down, it’s also an opportunity to take stock of the things that happened and to let your friends and family know how you’ve been doing through it all.

headline: What You Get for $700,000
abstract: A soaring kit house in Catskill, N.Y.; a two-bedroom condominium in an 1852 mansion in Newport, R.I.; and a limestone house in Bloomington, Ind.
lead_paragraph: A soaring kit house in Catskill, N.Y.; a two-bedroom condominium in an 1852 mansion in Newport, R.I.; and a limestone house in Bloomington, Ind.

headline: $700,000 Homes in New York, Rhode Island and Indiana
abstract: A soaring kit house in Catskill, a two-bedroom condominium in an 1852 mansion in Newport and a limestone house in Bloomington.
lead_paragraph: This kit house from the Backcountry Hut Company, in Vancouver, British Columbia, was finished by local craft workers. It is about eight miles southwest of Catskill, a village on the Hudson River in Greene County associated with the painter Thomas Cole. (His home there is now a national historic site.) The property is about 11 miles southeast of Kaaterskill Falls, a waterfall that has been the subject of many Hudson River School artists, and 15 miles southeast of the ski slopes at Hunter Mountain. The drive to Upper Manhattan is about two hours.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘4 Takeaways From Biden’s Electoral College Victory’
abstract: In this lesson, students will learn about the longer-term effects of President Trump’s refusal to accept the election outcome and the future of the democratic process in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “4 Takeaways From Biden’s Electoral College Victory” by Shane Goldmacher and Adam Nagourney

headline: A Stately Mansion on Lake Como
abstract: This seven-bedroom, 19th-century waterfront villa on the western shore of Lake Como, in northern Italy, is on the market for $6.1 million.
lead_paragraph: This seven-bedroom, 19th-century waterfront villa on the western shore of Lake Como, in northern Italy, is on the market for $6.1 million.

headline: House Hunting in Italy: A 19th-Century Villa on Lake Como
abstract: The northern region of Lombardy has struggled mightily with the coronavirus, but its lake towns remain among Europe’s most sought-after destinations.
lead_paragraph: This 19th-century waterfront villa is in the town of Tremezzina, on the shores of Italy’s Lake Como, known for its impressive scenery, historic villas and celebrated residents, about 50 miles north of Milan.

headline: Hundreds of flights are canceled, and Amtrak modifies service.
abstract: Transportation companies were altering operations, and officials were warning drivers to take extra care on the roads.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of flights were canceled, rail service was suspended and driving on some busy roads was restricted as a snowstorm hit the East Coast on Wednesday and complicated holiday travel plans.

headline: Faced With Protests, Pakistan Says Rapists Could Be Chemically Castrated
abstract: After an official cast blame on a rape survivor, setting off protests, the government has promised swifter justice and chemical castrations.
lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan — When a top police official in the eastern city of Lahore said that a woman who was raped on a deserted highway was partly to blame for the attack, thousands of protesters swarmed city streets. Now, in response to months of protest, the government has passed a measure that says men convicted of rape can be sentenced to chemical castration.

headline: Paul Farmer Is Awarded the $1 Million Berggruen Prize
abstract: The medical anthropologist won the prize, which is given to “thinkers whose ideas have profoundly shaped human self-understanding and advancement.”
lead_paragraph: Paul Farmer, a medical anthropologist who has fought for stronger public health care infrastructure around the world, has been named the recipient of the 2020 Berggruen Prize.

headline: In Miami, Sugarplum Dreams Under the Palm Trees
abstract: Miami City Ballet’s version of “The Nutcracker” already has color and heat. This year, the company is adding a new element: the outdoors.
lead_paragraph: Lourdes Lopez, the artistic director of Miami City Ballet, is facing a new unknown. It’s a fear she’s never had. And it stresses her out.

headline: 5 Art Accounts to Follow on Instagram Now
abstract: Existential, fantastical, searching, and silly, these feeds help transport our critic while she’s stuck at home.
lead_paragraph: Before the pandemic, I wasn’t exactly an art world jet-setter, but I did travel somewhat regularly. This year, being homebound for the better part of nine months has left me feeling loopy and itching for escape. I want to get away, not just from my apartment but from my own brain. Looking at art helps with that, as does scrolling through social media — and these Instagram accounts, in particular, transport me. Existential, fantastical, searching and silly, they reconnect me to the world by shifting my perspective on it.

headline: In its last currency report, Trump administration labels 2 countries currency manipulators.
abstract: The Trump administration on Wednesday labeled Vietnam and Switzerland as currency manipulators, accusing them for the first time of improperly intervening in foreign exchange markets and setting off a new economic confrontation with two trading partners.
lead_paragraph: The Trump administration on Wednesday labeled Vietnam and Switzerland as currency manipulators, accusing them for the first time of improperly intervening in foreign exchange markets and setting off a new economic confrontation with two trading partners.

headline: The Books That Gave Booksellers Comfort in 2020
abstract: Many of us turned to books this year, but what about the people whose recommendations have kept us afloat?
lead_paragraph: Many of us turned to books this year, but what about the people whose recommendations have kept us afloat?

headline: Biden Picks His Climate Team
abstract: Also this week: Wildfires destroyed ‘irreplaceable’ trees
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Climate Fwd: newsletter. The New York Times climate team emails readers once a week with stories and insights about climate change. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

headline: The Best of ‘This American Life’: 25th Anniversary Episodes
abstract: The show pioneered a new form of audio narrative journalism. Listen to some classics selected by the show’s host, Ira Glass.
lead_paragraph: When the public radio show I host went on the air 25 years ago, I was firmly against publicity photos. They were anti-radio, I’d tell anyone willing to listen to my little rant on the subject. Better not to be seen. Better to be a voice. A presence. Hearing Howard Stern has a power that seeing him does not. Ditto Rush Limbaugh or Terry Gross or anyone who knows what they’re doing on the mic. Why give up invisibility, which makes radio so powerful?

headline: McConnell tells Republicans that Georgia’s senators were ‘getting hammered’ for Congress’s failure to act.
abstract: Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, privately made the case to Republicans on Wednesday for a stimulus deal that includes another round of direct payments to struggling Americans, suggesting that delivering such help could boost the party’s hopes of hanging onto their majority in the Senate.
lead_paragraph: Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, privately made the case to Republicans on Wednesday for a stimulus deal that includes another round of direct payments to struggling Americans, suggesting that delivering such help could boost the party’s hopes of hanging onto their majority in the Senate.

headline: A Recipe From Nikki Giovanni
abstract: The poet’s no-recipe recipe is perfect for dinner.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I’ll get to the corned beef (above) I made for tacos soon enough — corning’s my new pandemic jam — but my pal Elizabeth Harris has a lovely interview in The Times this week with the poet Nikki Giovanni, 77, whose 19th collection of poems, “Make Me Rain,” came out this fall. In the course of their discussion, Giovanni told Liz about the butter-fried chicken she makes for dinner sometimes. That recipe didn’t make it into the interview, but I asked Liz to see if Giovanni would share with the rest of us.

headline: Misinformation messengers pivot from election fraud to peddling vaccine conspiracy theories.
abstract: Sidney Powell, a lawyer who was part of President Trump’s legal team, spread a conspiracy theory last month about election fraud. For days, she claimed that she would “release the Kraken” by showing voluminous evidence that Mr. Trump had won the election by a landslide.
lead_paragraph: Sidney Powell, a lawyer who was part of President Trump’s legal team, spread a conspiracy theory last month about election fraud. For days, she claimed that she would “release the Kraken” by showing voluminous evidence that Mr. Trump had won the election by a landslide.

headline: China Brings Moon Rocks to Earth, and a New Era of Competition to Space
abstract: The Chang’e-5 mission’s success highlights the progress of China’s space program, and growing rivalry with the United States.
lead_paragraph: China may have been a latecomer to the moon, but when its capsule full of lunar rocks and soil returned to Earth early Thursday, it set the stage for a new space race over the coming decades. This time, it will be a competition over resources on the moon that could propel deeper space exploration.

headline: In New York, outdoor dining confronts the approaching snowstorm.
abstract: But the storm will pose a significant test for how the city’s outdoor dining program can withstand severe winter weather.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s restaurants, already staggered by the loss of indoor dining this week, must close their roadway dining programs at 2 p.m. on Wednesday, ahead of the major snowstorm that is expected to sweep into the area.

headline: Biden formally names Buttigieg as his nominee for transportation secretary.
abstract: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Wednesday formally introduced Pete Buttigieg as his nominee for transportation secretary, a role that will be key to advancing Mr. Biden’s ambitious agenda on rebuilding the nation’s infrastructure and on climate change.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Wednesday formally introduced Pete Buttigieg as his nominee for transportation secretary, a role that will be key to advancing Mr. Biden’s ambitious agenda on rebuilding the nation’s infrastructure and on climate change.

headline: Vaccination Campaign at Nursing Homes Faces Obstacles and Confusion
abstract: Walgreens and CVS staff will soon begin vaccinations at tens of thousands of long-term care facilities. Some staff and residents are wary, and there are thorny issues of consent.
lead_paragraph: In coming days, squads of CVS and Walgreens employees, clad in protective gear and carrying small coolers, will begin to arrive at tens of thousands of nursing homes and assisted-living facilities to vaccinate staff and residents against the coronavirus.

headline: Sake and Oysters: A Perfect Pair
abstract: Four culinary experts weigh in on how to marry seafood and sake’s umami flavors.
lead_paragraph: Four culinary experts weigh in on how to marry seafood and sake’s umami flavors.

headline: People Thought Covid-19 Was Relatively Harmless for Younger Adults. They Were Wrong.
abstract: New research shows that July may have been the deadliest month for young adults in modern American history.
lead_paragraph: The largest burden of Covid-19 has undoubtedly fallen on people older than 65; they account for around 80 percent of deaths in the United States. But if we momentarily eclipse that from our mind’s eye, something else becomes visible: The corona of this virus.

headline: Macron, Once a Darling of Liberals, Shows a New Face as Elections Near
abstract: A centrist straddling France’s traditional political divide, President Emmanuel Macron now chases voters on the right and has alienated some supporters and members of his own party.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — He was the boy wonder of Western politics in 2017, soaring above outmoded cleavages between left and right. He was the whip-smart former banker who was going to turn a tradition-bound society into a start-up nation. He was the liberal bulwark against rising populism in Europe — an anti-Trump.

headline: ‘This Is Who I Am’ Review: Cooking With Dad, Remotely
abstract: A son in New York and a father in the West Bank prepare a favorite family recipe. Longing and resentment are in the mix, too.
lead_paragraph: There is nothing like a recipe from someone you love to stoke the memories. You pluck it from the leaves of the cookbook — or, if you’re neater than I am, maybe from a recipe file — and instantly they’re there with you in the kitchen, at least in your mind.

headline: Dutch Court Rules Against Jewish Heirs on Claim for Kandinsky Work
abstract: A recent finding of fault with a Restitution Commissions panel had led the heirs to hope that the court might find for them and return the painting.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — In a decision watched closely by restitution experts, a court in Amsterdam ruled on Wednesday that the Stedelijk Museum there can retain a Wassily Kandinsky painting that it acquired during World War II and which came from a Jewish collection.

headline: 19 Recipes Our Food Staff Cooked on Repeat in 2020
abstract: Spotify has its end-of-year lists, and NYT Cooking has one, too: Reporters and editors shared their go-to recipes.
lead_paragraph: At the end of each year, Spotify releases personalized lists of the songs and artists that users listened to most over the last 12 months. There’s no algorithm to count exactly how many times the Food staff made the recipes below in 2020, but consider it the NYT Cooking version of the streaming giant’s end-of-year recap. Among the greatest hits: cheesy pan pizza, Momofuku bo ssam, and, of course, the year’s sleeper hit, Mark Bittman’s No-Knead Bread.

headline: How Are You Managing the Holidays in a Pandemic?
abstract: Financial hardship and a battened-down economy are making this a challenging season. The New York Times would like to hear how you have been affected.
lead_paragraph: The economic upheaval caused by the pandemic is making this a very unusual holiday season.

headline: How to Squash Kids’ Fights in 4 Steps
abstract: Use these mediation techniques to build empathy and help them settle disputes themselves.
lead_paragraph: Use these mediation techniques to build empathy and help them settle disputes themselves.

headline: Billions Spent on U.S. Defenses Failed to Detect Giant Russian Hack
abstract: The broad Russian espionage attack on the U.S. government and private companies, underway since spring and detected only a few weeks ago, is among the greatest intelligence failures of modern times.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Over the past few years, the United States government has spent tens of billions of dollars on cyberoffensive abilities, building a giant war room at Fort Meade, Md., for United States Cyber Command, while installing defensive sensors all around the country — a system named Einstein to give it an air of genius — to deter the nation’s enemies from picking its networks clean, again.

headline: Kenyan Planned 9/11-Style Attack After Training as Pilot, U.S. Says
abstract: An operative for the Qaeda branch in East Africa, known as Shabab, is accused of training as a pilot in the Philippines and researching how to hijack planes.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan have charged a Kenyan man with plotting a Sept. 11-style attack on a building in an American city, according to a newly unsealed federal indictment.

headline: Death of Detained Ukrainian Causes Uproar in Portugal
abstract: The man’s death after what prosecutors called “inhumane treatment” has raised questions about the country’s detention policies and prompted calls for the interior minister to step down.
lead_paragraph: Arriving in the Lisbon airport without a work visa in March, Ihor Homeniuk, a Ukrainian citizen, was sent to a nearby detention center after refusing to board a flight out of Portugal.

headline: What to Wear Next Year
abstract: The last shows of the season, from Saint Laurent, Alexander McQueen and Bottega Veneta, offered some ideas. Loungewear, meet life.
lead_paragraph: The spring 2021 fashion season, which began with the promise of normalcy in the form of Jason Wu’s show on a roof in front of a live audience back in September, finally came to an end in mid-December. It closed with the triple-header of a Bottega Veneta show bathed in eerie green light, an Alexander McQueen mini-film set in the graveled, muddy banks of the Thames, and a Saint Laurent show on the dunes of an unnamed desert, beamed over the brand’s social media channels.

headline: Gone but Never Forgotten in a Quilt
abstract: Members of the national Women of Color Quilters Network draw on personal experiences of injustice, turning their needlework into symbols of liberation, resistance and empowerment.
lead_paragraph: Peggie Hartwell, a fourth-generation quilter from South Carolina, has found it hard to return to her needlework since she completed “Ode to George Floyd,” in which she renders Mr. Floyd’s face in subtle brown batiks, and an image of his mother barely visible behind a grove of trees. “I had to talk to him, get to know him,” the 81-year-old quilter said of the process. “I pick up a piece of fabric and see his face.”

headline: Theater to Stream: ‘Spring Awakening’ and Audra McDonald
abstract: Plays by Mike Bartlett, Christina Anderson and Halley Feiffer are watchable at home, too. And for an alternative holiday hit, “Burning Bluebeard.”
lead_paragraph: As the pandemic has forced theater companies to reinvent themselves as digital creators, colleges and even high schools have delivered some of the most innovative projects. The latest example is Baldwin Wallace University’s exciting take on Steven Sater and Duncan Sheik’s Broadway hit “Spring Awakening,” which the university, in Ohio, is bringing back for an encore after a November run.

headline: As China Tracked Muslims, Alibaba Showed Customers How They Could, Too
abstract: The website for the tech titan’s cloud business described facial recognition software that could detect members of a minority group whose persecution has drawn international condemnation.
lead_paragraph: As the Chinese government tracked and persecuted members of predominantly Muslim minority groups, the technology giant Alibaba taught its corporate customers how they could play a part.

headline: Soccer Will Run Trials on Concussion Substitutes in 2021
abstract: The move follows growing concern about the long-term effects of head injuries and the often-rushed treatment players receive.
lead_paragraph: Soccer leagues and tournaments around the world will be allowed to experiment with concussion substitutes starting in January, the body that oversees the sport’s rules announced Wednesday. The change is the most tangible action to be taken by soccer leaders amid growing concerns about the effects of head injuries at all levels of the game.

headline: 2 Alaska Health Workers Got Emergency Treatment After Receiving Pfizer’s Vaccine
abstract: One of the workers, who did not have a history of allergies, remained in the hospital on Wednesday night. Some reactions to the vaccine were also reported last week in Britain.
lead_paragraph: Two health care workers at the same hospital in Alaska developed concerning reactions just minutes after receiving Pfizer’s coronavirus vaccine this week, including one staff member who was to remain hospitalized until Thursday.

headline: ‘Sticky Bombs’ Sow Terror and Chaos in a City on Edge
abstract: The Taliban’s recent shift to magnetic bombs to target Afghan officials in Kabul underscores the government’s struggle to protect its own people.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — As he has done most workdays, Mahbubullah Mohibi left his home on Tuesday morning in a white armored S.U.V. with government plates, bound for his office job as deputy governor for Kabul Province.

headline: Already struggling with Covid-19, hospitals and nursing homes prepare for a winter storm.
abstract: Hospitals across the Northeast, already strained by an increase in Covid-19 patients and the first week of vaccine distribution, were preparing Wednesday for a winter storm with the potential to bring accident victims to their doors.
lead_paragraph: Hospitals across the Northeast, already strained by an increase in Covid-19 patients and the first week of vaccine distribution, were preparing Wednesday for a winter storm with the potential to bring accident victims to their doors.

headline: Are We Ready to Laugh About Covid-19? A British Sitcom Hopes So
abstract: With ‘Pandemonium,’ the BBC is betting that an audience will find humor in reliving the ordeals of a very awful year.
lead_paragraph: A British family is walking along a frigid beach, treating a fall vacation like it’s a restaurant entree everyone wants to send back to the kitchen. The whole expedition is a lame Plan B. The Jessups were originally going to Disneyland, followed by three days of hiking at Yosemite. Then the coronavirus struck and sunny California was out of the question. Now the clan is making do in Margate, a forlorn British seaside town that peaked decades ago.

headline: Vaccines Need Effective Messengers
abstract: How health care professionals and internet companies can help in the fight against misinformation.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: City of Paris Fined Nearly $110,000 for Appointing Too Many Women
abstract: The French government ordered the city to pay up under a 2012 law intended to address gender imbalance at senior levels of the country’s Civil Service. The mayor deemed the decision “absurd.”
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Nothing, it has been said, succeeds like excess.

headline: 4 Art Gallery Shows to See Right Now
abstract: Julie Mehretu’s vibrant colors; Minjung Kim’s gray and black ink paintings; Jean Katambayi Mukendi’s “Quarantaine” drawings; and Bosco Sodi’s clay spheres.
lead_paragraph: Julie Mehretu’s work has grown steadily stronger, especially over the last few years. It helped to eliminate the fussy layers of finely drawn architectural elevations, planning grids and weather maps that cramped her large canvases’ style, scale and apocalyptic mood, and to work more loosely by hand. This much was evident in the largely grisaille efforts in her 2016 show at Marian Goodman, where a new softness of line prevailed. It’s even more apparent in “about the space of half an hour,” her latest show at the gallery, whose title, from the Book of Revelation, refers to the short silence between the breaking of the Seventh Seal and God’s unleashing of the Final Judgment.

headline: Review: Mother Teresa Sings, in Drag and With Doubts
abstract: In Heather Christian’s “I Am Sending You the Sacred Face,” the saint of Calcutta vogues and lip-syncs and broods on the nature of selflessness.
lead_paragraph: Theater in Quarantine, a company that since March has been streaming experimental works from its founder’s closet, turns the constraints of its odd conditions into a marvelous style.

headline: Endangering Others by Flouting Covid Guidelines
abstract: “We shouldn’t have to shame ‘those who flout pandemic safety guidance’; we should be able to dial 911,” a reader writes.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘A Heroic Place:’ Elmhurst Hospital Workers Get Coronavirus Vaccine
abstract: Two staff members of Elmhurst Hospital in Queens, a public hospital hit hard during the city’s spring coronavirus crisis, became the first at the hospital to be vaccinated Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Two staff members of Elmhurst Hospital in Queens, a public hospital hit hard during the city’s spring coronavirus crisis, became the first at the hospital to be vaccinated Wednesday.

headline: When Will It Be Like 2019 Again?
abstract: Vaccines will soon be available for teachers — but what comes next is complicated.
lead_paragraph: Teachers are near the front of the line to receive vaccines. Does that mean schools are close to returning to a pre-Covid normality? Not exactly.

headline: Chicago Girl Raises $22,000 for Children’s Hospital With Friendship Bracelets
abstract: Hayley Orlinsky, 7, has sold some 9,000 bracelets to raise money for Covid-19 equipment at the hospital that cared for her as an infant.
lead_paragraph: When Hayley Orlinsky of Chicago learned on the news in March that doctors and nurses were running low on masks amid the frantic early weeks of the coronavirus pandemic, she wanted to help.

headline: Court Finds 14 Guilty of Aiding Charlie Hebdo and Anti-Semitic Attacks
abstract: The accused were sentenced to between four years and life imprisonment for their roles in the 2015 attacks on a kosher supermarket and the magazine that killed 17 people.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A French court on Wednesday found 14 defendants guilty of aiding in the terrorist attacks that killed 17 people in January 2015, including 10 people at the offices of the satirical magazine Charlie Hebdo, which had published cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad.

headline: New York City has 330,000 tons of salt on hand to clear its streets.
abstract: Even before the snow began falling in New York City on Wednesday afternoon, the Department of Sanitation had turned away from its daily trash collecting and toward the plowing of the city’s 6,300 miles of streets.
lead_paragraph: Even before the snow began falling in New York City on Wednesday afternoon, the Department of Sanitation had turned away from its daily trash collecting and toward the plowing of the city’s 6,300 miles of streets.

headline: Cookie Monster Mural Puzzles Artist and Enrages Property Owner
abstract: A man claiming to be a property owner in Peoria, Ill., wanted a Soviet-style mural of Cookie Monster. The artist who did the job now says he was tricked (and paid) by an impostor.
lead_paragraph: Joshua Hawkins said the request seemed “pretty weird,” but the dark-haired man who made it was offering cash, and a lot of it.

headline: U.S. Said to Be Near Charges for Another Suspect in 1988 Lockerbie Bombing
abstract: The attack on Pan Am flight 103 killed 270 people, including 190 Americans.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General William P. Barr was serving his first stint in the job nearly three decades ago when two Libyan intelligence officials were indicted in the 1988 bombing of a U.S. jetliner over Lockerbie, Scotland, that killed 270 people, including 190 Americans.

headline: Congress will make far fewer tickets available for Biden’s inaugural to guard against the spread of the virus.
abstract: The congressional committee planning January’s inauguration ceremony announced on Wednesday that it would drastically cut the number of tickets issued for President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s swearing in to guard against spread of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: The congressional committee planning January’s inauguration ceremony announced on Wednesday that it would drastically cut the number of tickets issued for President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s swearing in to guard against spread of the coronavirus.

headline: ‘The Stand’ Review: Stephen King’s Pandemic Story Hits TV Again
abstract: A mini-series from CBS All Access adapts the sprawling novel about opposing camps of survivors in a post-apocalyptic America.
lead_paragraph: Stephen King’s slab of a novel, “The Stand” (originally 800-plus pages, later expanded to 1,100-plus), begins with a manufactured viral epidemic that wipes out most of the human race. That would seem to make it pretty relevant, or at least timely, in the year of Covid-19.

headline: National Endowment for the Humanities Announces New Grants
abstract: The final round of funding for the year totals $32.8 million and will support 213 projects across the country.
lead_paragraph: Carnegie Hall, the National World War I Memorial in Washington and the Kurt Vonnegut Memorial Library in Indianapolis are among the 213 beneficiaries of new grants from the National Endowment for the Humanities that were announced on Wednesday.

headline: Fed Leaves Rates Unchanged and Commits to Ongoing Bond Purchases
abstract: Central bank officials left rates near-zero at their December meeting and tied bond buying to their employment and price goals.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal Reserve officials pledged to help the economy through the painful pandemic era, making clear at their final meeting of the year that the central bank would continue cushioning businesses and households by keeping interest rates at rock bottom and buying government-backed debt for the foreseeable future.

headline: Baseball Rights a Wrong by Adding Negro Leagues to Official Records
abstract: More than 3,400 players from seven leagues that operated from 1920 to 1948 will now be considered major leaguers in a move that will shake up the record books.
lead_paragraph: If baseball somehow reflects America, as romanticists like to believe, then it also shares in its blemishes. The National and American leagues were segregated until 1947, and the decades since have been marked by a halting kind of reckoning.

headline: Despite scaled-back plans, Biden inauguration offers perks to major donors.
abstract: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s inaugural committee released a menu of perks for donors to his inauguration this week, reflecting an aggressive fund-raising effort, despite plans for a less expensive and mostly virtual event lacking the elaborate balls and concerts that have been staples of past inaugurations.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s inaugural committee released a menu of perks for donors to his inauguration this week, reflecting an aggressive fund-raising effort, despite plans for a less expensive and mostly virtual event lacking the elaborate balls and concerts that have been staples of past inaugurations.

headline: No Scrooge Here: Johnson Resists ‘Canceling’ Christmas to Stem Coronavirus
abstract: Britain’s prime minister has stuck by a pledge to lift restrictions on gatherings between Dec. 23 and 27 despite growing calls to  keep the measures in place as cases surge.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In a year of hard decisions about how to confront the coronavirus, perhaps none has proved as anguished for Prime Minister Boris Johnson as whether to ban Britons from getting together for a little Christmas cheer.

headline: New Scan Finds Prostate Cancer Cells Hiding in the Body
abstract: The test seems likely to improve the diagnosis and treatment of a disease that kills 33,000 American men each year.
lead_paragraph: After doctors found cancer in Dr. Mark Samberg’s prostate last spring, the 70-year-old retired urologist prepared to have his prostate removed. He knew that the surgery would cure him, assuming the cancer was confined to the organ.

headline: Jack Steinberger, Nobel Winner in Physics, Dies at 99
abstract: Dr. Steinberger shared the prize in 1988 for expanding understanding of the neutrino, a staggeringly ubiquitous subatomic particle.
lead_paragraph: Jack Steinberger, who shared the 1988 Nobel Prize in Physics for expanding understanding of the ghostly neutrino, a staggeringly ubiquitous subatomic particle, died on Saturday at his home in Geneva. He was 99.

headline: 10 States Accuse Google of Abusing Monopoly in Online Ads
abstract: The suit focuses on the advertisements that generate a vast majority of the company’s profits.
lead_paragraph: Ten state attorneys general on Wednesday accused Google of illegally abusing its monopoly over the technology that delivers ads online, adding to the company’s legal troubles with a case that strikes at the heart of its business.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Fighting the virus in Europe.
lead_paragraph: Even as vaccines show promise, the coronavirus is continuing to surge across Europe.

headline: Mitch McConnell’s Motive: Self-Interest
abstract: A reader writes that the majority leader acknowledged Joe Biden’s victory to ensure his hold on power. Also: A simple inauguration for Joe Biden; a CD collection to savor.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Supreme Court to Rule on N.C.A.A. Limits on Paying College Athletes
abstract: An appeals court said restrictions on compensation tied to education violated federal antitrust laws.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court agreed on Wednesday to decide whether the N.C.A.A. had violated federal antitrust laws by restricting what college athletes could be paid.

headline: How Effective Is the Mask You’re Wearing? You May Know Soon
abstract: A C.D.C. division is working with an industry standards group to develop filtration standards — and products that meet them will be able to carry labels saying so.
lead_paragraph: More than 100,000 varieties of face masks are currently for sale. They come in silk, cotton and synthetics; with filters and without; over-the-head and over-the-ears. They have sparkles and sunflowers; friendly greetings and insults; cartoon characters and teeny reindeer.

headline: Twitter will begin removing vaccine misinformation.
abstract: Twitter said on Wednesday that it would begin removing misinformation about coronavirus vaccines. The planned takedowns, which will begin next week, were announced as misinformation about the vaccines, which are just starting to be distributed in the United States, is increasing.
lead_paragraph: Twitter said on Wednesday that it would begin removing misinformation about coronavirus vaccines. The planned takedowns, which will begin next week, were announced as misinformation about the vaccines, which are just starting to be distributed in the United States, is increasing.

headline: The Small Irish Animation Studio That Keeps Getting the Oscars’ Attention
abstract: With “Wolfwalkers,” Cartoon Saloon completes a hand-drawn trilogy based on Celtic mythology. The film epitomizes everything the studio stands for.
lead_paragraph: When Tomm Moore and 11 friends in the small city of Kilkenny, Ireland, set out to make an animated movie in 1999 based on Celtic mythology, they could hardly imagine their labor of love would become a studio that would revolutionize the animation industry in Ireland, revitalize interest in folklore at home and connect with a global audience.

headline: ‘Goodbye, Dragon Inn’: The Last Picture Show in Taipei
abstract: Tsai Ming-liang’s 2003 movie watches moviegoers as they watch a martial-arts classic inside a cavernous theater.
lead_paragraph: A sparse audience attends the last show in a cavernous movie house. Now all the more poignant for being streamed, Tsai Ming-liang’s 2003 “Goodbye, Dragon Inn,” newly restored, is a love letter to cinema and also cinemas.

headline: The Importance of Anticipation
abstract: We need things to look forward to.
lead_paragraph: Welcome. We’re expecting a storm today, in the Mid-Atlantic and Northeastern U.S., the sort of blanketing that for children growing up in colder climes has long brought anticipation of the most delicious sort: Will schools be closed? Will we spend a day inside in our pajamas? Surely there’ll be sledding, snowmen and snow angels. An unexpected departure from the norm, a disruption of the rhythms of the week.

headline: Modern Love Podcast: ‘Desire Is Never the Mistake’
abstract: This holiday season, it’s OK to want more.
lead_paragraph: Paula grew up in foster care, and year after year she would find herself “clobbered by desire” when the holidays rolled around. She longed for a mother and father to rescue her and “make everything better”; she wished for the hip-huggers and games she saw on TV.

headline: Fired Cybersecurity Chief Condemns Threats Against Election Workers
abstract: Christopher Krebs, the former cybersecurity chief fired by President Trump after disputing his false claims of election fraud, called on Republican leaders to stand up against efforts to undermine the 2020 election.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Krebs, the former cybersecurity chief fired by President Trump after disputing his false claims of election fraud, called on Republican leaders to stand up against efforts to undermine the 2020 election.

headline: Biden to Pick Brenda Mallory to Run White House Environment Office
abstract: The office, the Council on Environmental Quality, is expected to have an expanded focus on environmental justice under Ms. Mallory, an environmental lawyer.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. has chosen Brenda Mallory, an environmental lawyer who spent more than 15 years working in the federal government under both Republican and Democratic presidents, to lead the Council on Environmental Quality, according to two people close to the Biden transition team.

headline: ‘Break It All’ Celebrates the Oppositional Energy of Latin Rock
abstract: A new six-part Netflix series explores half a century of music under pressure.
lead_paragraph: Latin America has taken rock seriously. Seriously enough for governments to suppress it. Seriously enough for bands to sing about political issues, societal troubles and the spirit of rebellion. Seriously enough for fans to risk arrests and beatings to see a concert. While Latin rock can be thoroughly entertaining — catchy, playful, rambunctious, over the top — it rarely settles for being mere entertainment. There’s often far more going on behind the melody, rhythm and noise.

headline: N.B.A. Hopes for ‘as Close to a Normal Season as Possible’
abstract: The league is embarking on a season with restrictions but no bubble: Yes to trips to Whole Foods. No to crowded elevators and the hotel gift shop.
lead_paragraph: The first team to take up residence at the N.B.A. bubble in July was one of the first to be assigned a road trip last week. The Orlando Magic on Thursday afternoon boarded a team flight for the first time since March and made the short journey to Atlanta to jump-start a season like no other.

headline: Facebook Takes the Gloves Off in Feud With Apple
abstract: The social network said it opposed changes that Apple was making to the tracking of apps and would provide information for an antitrust complaint against the iPhone maker.
lead_paragraph: For years, signs of discord have brewed between Facebook and Apple.

headline: My $200,000 Sushi Dinner
abstract: In 2013, this reporter spent 10 Bitcoin, worth $1,000 at the time, on a dinner for dozens of strangers in San Francisco. The owner of the restaurant wisely held onto it.
lead_paragraph: The hell year that is 2020 has wreaked havoc on life as we know it. But you know what it’s been good for? Bitcoin.

headline: A Conversation on ‘Go Tell It on the Mountain’
abstract: The novelist Ayana Mathis speaks about James Baldwin’s 1953 classic.
lead_paragraph: T’s Book Club consists of a series of articles and discussions dedicated to classic works of American literature. Here, our first (virtual) event, on James Baldwin’s 1953 novel, “Go Tell It on the Mountain,” featuring the novelist Ayana Mathis — who first read the book as a teenager and has returned to it many times since — in conversation with T features director Thessaly La Force.

headline: In Landmark Ruling, Air Pollution Recorded as a Cause of Death for British Girl
abstract: Legal and environmental experts hailed a coroner’s ruling that, for the first time in Britain, directly linked a specific person’s death to air pollution.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A 9-year-old girl who suffered a fatal asthma attack in 2013 became the first person in Britain to officially have air pollution listed as a cause of death, a British official said.

headline: Driver Who Killed 5 Cyclists Had Methamphetamine in His System, Prosecutors Say
abstract: Jordan Barson faces several felony charges after the authorities said he drove a box truck into a group of cyclists who were riding on a highway outside Las Vegas last week.
lead_paragraph: A truck driver who slammed into a group of bicyclists, killing five, on a Nevada highway last week, has been charged with multiple felonies after he was found to have methamphetamine in his system, prosecutors said.

headline: Biden is expected to name Brenda Mallory to lead the Council on Environmental Quality.
abstract: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. has chosen Brenda Mallory, an environmental lawyer who spent more than 15 years working in the federal government under both Republican and Democratic presidents, to lead the Council on Environmental Quality, according to two people close to the Biden transition team.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. has chosen Brenda Mallory, an environmental lawyer who spent more than 15 years working in the federal government under both Republican and Democratic presidents, to lead the Council on Environmental Quality, according to two people close to the Biden transition team.

headline: Fed Will Keep Interest Rates Near Zero
abstract: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve Chair, said Wednesday that the central bank will keep interest rates near zero to support the economy as coronavirus cases surge nationwide, adding that “a full economic recovery is unlikely until people are confident that it is safe to re-engage in a broad range of activities.”
lead_paragraph: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve Chair, said Wednesday that the central bank will keep interest rates near zero to support the economy as coronavirus cases surge nationwide, adding that “a full economic recovery is unlikely until people are confident that it is safe to re-engage in a broad range of activities.”

headline: Joseph Safra, Banker Who Was the Richest Brazilian, Dies at 82
abstract: An immigrant from Lebanon, he earned a reputation as a canny dealmaker overseeing a family banking empire reaching from São Paulo to Geneva to New York.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Joseph Safra, a former immigrant from Lebanon who became Brazil’s richest person and one of the most successful bankers in the world through a lifetime of deal-making, died on Dec. 10 in São Paulo, Brazil. He was 82.

headline: Number of Executions in U.S. Falls Despite Push by Trump Administration
abstract: States carried out fewer executions in 2020 than in any year since 1983, but the federal government carried out more than it had in over a century.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In part because of the effects of the pandemic on the criminal justice system, the number of executions in the United States fell this year to the lowest level since 1991 despite the Trump administration’s revival of the federal death penalty, according to a study released on Wednesday.

headline: Yankees Say D.J. LeMahieu Is Worth Waiting For
abstract: The team’s primary off-season goal remains re-signing the free-agent infielder, who could command a lucrative four-year contract at age 32.
lead_paragraph: In case it wasn’t abundantly clear, General Manager Brian Cashman reiterated the Yankees’ primary goal of this off-season to reporters on Wednesday: re-signing infielder D.J. LeMahieu, a free agent.

headline: Biden’s Twin Climate Chiefs, McCarthy and Kerry, Face a Monumental Task
abstract: The president-elect’s choices so far firm up his strategy to try to reclaim global climate leadership for the United States, despite many obstacles.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One of President-elect Joseph R. Biden’s loftiest campaign pledges was to reimagine the federal government to enforce new climate policies everywhere he can, while reclaiming the global climate leadership role abandoned by President Trump — objectives with few precedents and many barriers.

headline: Trump taps Giuliani’s son for membership on the Holocaust Memorial Council.
abstract: After elevating a coterie of close friends and allies to prime spots on boards and commissions in recent weeks, President Trump on Wednesday announced plans to appoint Andrew H. Giuliani, a White House aide and the son of his personal lawyer, Rudolph W. Giuliani, to serve as a member of the United States Holocaust Memorial Council.
lead_paragraph: After elevating a coterie of close friends and allies to prime spots on boards and commissions in recent weeks, President Trump on Wednesday announced plans to appoint Andrew H. Giuliani, a White House aide and the son of his personal lawyer, Rudolph W. Giuliani, to serve as a member of the United States Holocaust Memorial Council.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: Nursing home residents and staff are beginning to receive the vaccine.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. is moving to the next phase of its mass vaccination campaign as nursing home residents and staff are beginning to receive their shots.

headline: Stimulus, Winter Storm, M.L.B.: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Pelosi backs Haaland for interior secretary, calling her ‘one of the best’ members of Congress.
abstract: Top Democrats in the House, including Speaker Nancy Pelosi, publicly expressed support on Wednesday for President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. to choose Representative Deb Haaland of New Mexico as interior secretary, rebuffing criticism that they were standing in the way of her appointment over concerns about the party’s slim majority in their chamber.
lead_paragraph: Top Democrats in the House, including Speaker Nancy Pelosi, publicly expressed support on Wednesday for President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. to choose Representative Deb Haaland of New Mexico as interior secretary, rebuffing criticism that they were standing in the way of her appointment over concerns about the party’s slim majority in their chamber.

headline: Chinese Lunar Mission Returns to Earth
abstract: The lunar capsule from China’s Chang’e-5 spacecraft returned to Earth early Thursday, bringing back as much as 4.4 pounds of rock and soil samples from a volcanic plain known as Mons Rümker.
lead_paragraph: The lunar capsule from China’s Chang’e-5 spacecraft returned to Earth early Thursday, bringing back as much as 4.4 pounds of rock and soil samples from a volcanic plain known as Mons Rümker.

headline: Former Houston Officer Investigating ‘Fraudulent’ Ballots Is Charged With Assault
abstract: Mark A. Aguirre, a former police captain hired by a conservative group to investigate voter fraud, pointed his gun at a man and pinned him to the ground, officials said. No fake ballots were found.
lead_paragraph: A former Houston police captain, who the authorities said was investigating a voter fraud conspiracy theory for a conservative activist group, was arrested and charged with pointing his gun at an air-conditioner repairman he had pursued to try to uncover fraudulent ballots, prosecutors said Tuesday.

headline: Hundreds of Religious Leaders Call for End to L.G.B.T.Q. Conversion Therapy
abstract: The declaration, spearheaded by the Global Interfaith Commission on LGBT+ Lives, also calls for an end to violence and criminalization against L.G.B.T.Q. people.
lead_paragraph: In a show of unity aimed at fighting for the rights of L.G.B.T.Q. people, more than 370 international spiritual leaders have signed a declaration demanding a global ban on disputed conversion therapy.

headline: Buttigieg Recalls Discrimination Against Gay People, as Biden Celebrates Cabinet’s Diversity
abstract: Pete Buttigieg would be the first openly gay cabinet secretary, one of the firsts that President-elect Joe Biden cited in introducing him as his transportation secretary.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Pete Buttigieg was a teenager, not yet openly gay, and had dreams of being an airline pilot when he watched Republicans in the late 1990s deny a confirmation vote to President Bill Clinton’s choice for ambassador to Luxembourg because of his sexual orientation.

headline: ‘I Was Stunned’: Big Gifts to Small Colleges From an Unexpected Source
abstract: MacKenzie Scott’s donations to colleges serving often overlooked students were a surprise — and potentially transformational.
lead_paragraph: They came like gifts from a Secret Santa, $20 million here, $40 million there, all to higher education, but not to the elite universities that usually hog all the attention. These donations went to colleges and universities that many people have never heard of, and that tended to serve regional, minority and lower-income students.

headline: Liverpool Pulls in Front, but Premier League Race Has Far to Go
abstract: A lineup altered by injury, and supplemented by youth, summons the energy to beat Tottenham at Anfield.
lead_paragraph: LIVERPOOL, England — José Mourinho left one name off his list. The Tottenham manager had been busy using his final news conference before his team’s trip to Liverpool to indulge his taste — and his talent — for sophistry, trying to prove Jürgen Klopp’s squad was not quite as threadbare as has been advertised by reeling off names of all the players that would be available.

headline: Hospitals Discover a Surprise in Their Vaccine Deliveries: Extra Doses
abstract: Pharmacists have found that they can squeeze an additional dose from some of the glass vials that were supposed to contain five doses of the Pfizer vaccine.
lead_paragraph: As boxes of Pfizer vaccines began arriving around the country this week, hospital pharmacists made a surprising discovery: Some of the glass vials that are supposed to hold five doses contained enough for a sixth — or even a seventh — person.

headline: After personal threats over a local mask mandate, the Dodge City, Kansas, mayor resigns.
abstract: The emails Joyce Warshaw received as mayor of Dodge City, Kan., were hostile enough last month, when the city was merely considering passing a mask mandate.
lead_paragraph: The emails Joyce Warshaw received as mayor of Dodge City, Kan., were hostile enough last month, when the city was merely considering passing a mask mandate.

headline: A Glitch in Trump’s Plan to Live at Mar-a-Lago: A Pact He Signed Says He Can’t
abstract: Neighbors of the president say he has violated the 1993 agreement he made with Palm Beach that allowed him to convert a private residence into a moneymaking club.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s neighbors in Florida are seeking to enforce a decades-old compact that says Mar-a-Lago, his private social club, cannot be used as a full-time residence — as Mr. Trump has suggested he plans to do after he leaves the White House.

headline: Staring Down Deadline, Congress Nears $900 Billion Stimulus Deal
abstract: The emerging compromise would provide emergency stimulus payments, jobless aid and rental assistance, extending help to businesses and funding the distribution of a vaccine. But more is likely to be needed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After months of stalemate, congressional leaders were on the verge on Wednesday of cementing a roughly $900 billion stimulus deal to deliver emergency aid to individuals and companies devastated by the toll of the worsening pandemic, racing to finish the details and stave off a government shutdown on Friday.

headline: Mobster Pleads in Plot Against ‘Real Housewives’ Boyfriend, U.S. Says
abstract: A man who was dating a former New Jersey “housewife” was beaten up. Her ex-husband asked a Lucchese crime family member to commit the assault, prosecutors say.
lead_paragraph: The sordid and violent tale laid out by federal prosecutors seemed ripped from “The Sopranos”: A well-connected ex-husband, angry that his former wife had found a new boyfriend, enticed a New Jersey mobster to beat the boyfriend up by dangling the prospect of a cut-rate deal on a flashy wedding reception.

headline: Biden’s Inaugural Will Be Mostly Virtual, but Money From Donors Will Be Real
abstract: The president-elect’s allies have begun an ambitious fund-raising campaign for the celebration of his swearing-in. Big donors will get “virtual signed photos” — and a chance to generate good will.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s allies have begun an ambitious campaign to raise millions of dollars from corporations and individuals by offering special “V.I.P. participation” in reimagined inaugural festivities that will be largely virtual because of the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: The election is over, but Ron Johnson keeps promoting false claims of fraud.
abstract: At a Senate hearing, witnesses made legal arguments and claims that courts have called “meritless” or otherwise dismissed.
lead_paragraph: Two days after the Electoral College confirmed President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory, a Senate committee provided a platform on Wednesday for another round of specious legal arguments and falsehoods about widespread voter fraud that have been repeatedly rejected by courts across the country.

headline: What’s It Like to Live in a Nursing Home During a Pandemic?
abstract: Tell us what you or your peers have experienced.
lead_paragraph: Many residents of nursing homes are in precarious situations because of Covid-19. On top of spending months isolated from loved ones, nursing home residents are particularly vulnerable to the coronavirus. A New York Times analysis found that 38 percent of coronavirus deaths are tied to long-term care facilities.

headline: Move On, but Never Forget
abstract: What Blackness, fairness, coalition-building and chicken-and-egg dilemmas have in common.
lead_paragraph: Imagine this scene, which is a common experience for Black people:

headline: Facebook reverses postelection algorithm changes that boosted news from authoritative sources.
abstract: Facebook confirmed that it has in the past few days rolled back a change that lifted news from authoritative outlets over hyperpartisan sources after November’s election, signaling a return to normalcy for the social network.
lead_paragraph: Facebook confirmed that it has in the past few days rolled back a change that lifted news from authoritative outlets over hyperpartisan sources after November’s election, signaling a return to normalcy for the social network.

headline: I Was the Homeland Security Adviser to Trump. We’re Being Hacked.
abstract: The magnitude of this national security breach is hard to overstate.
lead_paragraph: At the worst possible time, when the United States is at its most vulnerable — during a presidential transition and a devastating public health crisis — the networks of the federal government and much of corporate America are compromised by a foreign nation. We need to understand the scale and significance of what is happening.

headline: A 27-year-old agreement may prevent Trump from living at Mar-a-Lago.
abstract: Neighbors of President Trump in Florida sent a letter to the Town of Palm Beach and the U.S. Secret Service on Tuesday complaining that Mr. Trump has violated a 1993 agreement he made with the town that says Mar-a-Lago, his private social club, cannot be used as a full-time residence, as Mr. Trump has suggested he plans to do.
lead_paragraph: Neighbors of President Trump in Florida sent a letter to the Town of Palm Beach and the U.S. Secret Service on Tuesday complaining that Mr. Trump has violated a 1993 agreement he made with the town that says Mar-a-Lago, his private social club, cannot be used as a full-time residence, as Mr. Trump has suggested he plans to do.

headline: ‘The Art of Political Murder’ Review: Behind a Bishop’s Assassination
abstract: This documentary from Paul Taylor explores the killing of Bishop Juan Gerardi Conedera in Guatemala in 1998.
lead_paragraph: The murder in “The Art of the Political Murder,” a documentary based on the book of the same title by Francisco Goldman, is the killing of Bishop Juan Gerardi Conedera in Guatemala in 1998. Suspiciously, his death came two days after he had presented a report on human rights abuses during the country’s decades-long civil war, which had ended in 1996.

headline: Northeast Faces First Winter Storm of Season
abstract: A winter storm barreled into the Mid-Atlantic States and Northeast on Wednesday and continued into Thursday with forecasters predicting up to two feet of snow in places.
lead_paragraph: A winter storm barreled into the Mid-Atlantic States and Northeast on Wednesday and continued into Thursday with forecasters predicting up to two feet of snow in places.

headline: The Year in Climate
abstract: A lot happened in 2020. Here’s how The Times’s Climate Desk covered it.
lead_paragraph: A lot happened in 2020. Here’s how The Times’s Climate Desk covered it.

headline: Nearly 2.8 Million People in the U.S. Have Gotten a Covid-19 Vaccine
abstract: The government says it has distributed more than 12.4 million doses of the Covid-19 vaccine to states and other jurisdictions. See where the shots have gone.
lead_paragraph: The government says it has distributed more than 12.4 million doses of the Covid-19 vaccine to states and other jurisdictions. See where the shots have gone.

headline: That’s Gnus to Me!
abstract: Kathryn Ladner makes her New York Times Crossword debut. It’s got a good beat and you can dance to it.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Sometimes the universe aligns properly and it makes for some wonderful serendipity. I love when that happens.

headline: Storm Dumps Snow on East Coast, Shutting Schools and Virus Testing
abstract: Three people died in highway crashes in Pennsylvania and Virginia. New York expecting up to a foot of precipitation as the mess moved on to New England.
lead_paragraph: The first major winter storm of the season made its way up the East Coast on Wednesday, heading for New England after dumping rain, ice and snow from Virginia through New York — and like everything in 2020, it was made more complicated by the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Australian Open Is Postponed Because of the Coronavirus Pandemic
abstract: With infections surging in other parts of the world, the first Grand Slam tennis event of 2021 has been delayed by three weeks, according to a schedule released by the men’s tour.
lead_paragraph: The delayed start of the Australian Open, and the meandering path that officials followed in coming to the decision, revealed much about the state of international sports and tennis specifically at this unique moment.
