headline: Quotation of the Day: Inoculations at Nursing Homes Face an Obstacle Over Consent
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, December 17, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “I don’t want to be a guinea pig.”

headline: Corrections: Dec. 17, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Dec. 17, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Saturday about an open letter signed by German cultural leaders rejecting the Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions movement against Israel misstated the reason that Achille Mbebe did not address the Ruhrtrienniale festival. He was not disinvited; the festival was canceled because of the coronavirus pandemic, after lawmakers and officials called for Mr. Mbebe to be removed from the program.

headline: N.F.L. Week 15 Predictions: Our Picks Against the Spread
abstract: Saturday games return, but this week is dominated by a potential Super Bowl preview between the Saints and the Chiefs.
lead_paragraph: A Thursday matchup that needed overtime to be decided. A pair of entertaining games on Saturday. A potential Super Bowl preview on Sunday. This is shaping up to be an excellent week of football, and we dug in on each team’s playoff chances using The Upshot’s playoff simulator.

headline: Who Gets to Breathe Clean Air in New Delhi?
abstract: We measured how much air pollution two children, Monu and Aamya, breathed for a day to see how much inequality makes a difference.
lead_paragraph: We measured how much air pollution two children, Monu and Aamya, breathed for a day to see how much inequality makes a difference.

headline: Waste, Negligence and Cronyism: Inside Britain’s Pandemic Spending
abstract: In the desperate scramble for protective gear and other equipment, political insiders reaped billions.
lead_paragraph: In the desperate scramble for protective gear and other equipment, political insiders reaped billions.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Cronyism and waste in Britain’s pandemic spending.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: ‘Nightmare’ Australia Housing Lockdown Called Breach of Human Rights
abstract: An ombudsman’s report condemned a rushed lockdown of nine public housing towers in Melbourne that left thousands of residents without adequate food and medication and access to fresh air.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — The sudden lockdown this summer of nine public housing towers in Melbourne that left 3,000 people without adequate food and medication and access to fresh air during the city’s second coronavirus wave breached human rights laws, an investigation found.

headline: Word + Quiz: seersucker
abstract: This word has appeared in eight articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: Jimmy Kimmel Finds It Fitting That Trump’s Neighbors Don’t Want Him
abstract: Residents of Palm Beach, Fla., objected to President Trump’s post-White House plan to live at his Mar-a-Lago resort. “In other words, God exists and has a very good sense of humor about all of this,” Kimmel said.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Calendar
abstract: What is this image saying?

headline: As Trump Leaves the White House, His Imprint on the Judiciary Deepens
abstract: Published opinions from the nation’s appeals courts this year show that Trump appointees stand out from other judges, even those named by other Republican presidents.
lead_paragraph: As Democrats look to the incoming Biden administration to reverse much of President Trump’s work, the conservative imprint he has left on the federal courts is only deepening.

headline: New York Spent $1 Billion on Virus Supplies. Now It Wants Money Back.
abstract: City and state officials are trying to recover millions from quick deals made during the worst weeks of the pandemic this spring.
lead_paragraph: As the coronavirus ravaged New York this spring, state officials faced a terrifying prospect: Casualties were mounting, and the reserve of ventilators and masks was dwindling. As doctors considered rationing lifesaving treatment, the state rushed into $1.1 billion in deals for supplies and equipment.

headline: Nursing Homes, Ravaged by Covid-19, Start Vaccinating the Most Vulnerable
abstract: Vaccines have now been administered at long-term care facilities in several states, but administrators warn that they will not bring a quick end to the long siege of the virus.
lead_paragraph: Patricia John was still in her nightgown this week in the West Virginia nursing home where she lives when a nurse hurried her out of her room to join a line that had formed in the hallway.

headline: Auctioning Off a Dead Mall
abstract: When a shopping mall closes, where does all of its stuff go?
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — The body parts come as a surprise, even if you expect them, when they’re the only things left behind.

headline: How climate change is affecting winter storms.
abstract: The major winter storm that hit the Eastern United States on Wednesday and Thursday probably prompted some people to ask, “What happened to global warming?”
lead_paragraph: The major winter storm that hit the Eastern United States on Wednesday and Thursday probably prompted some people to ask, “What happened to global warming?”

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘Treasure Washes Up on Venezuela’s Shore, Bringing Gold and Hope to a Village’
abstract: In this lesson, students will learn about the mysterious appearance of treasure in a fishing village. Then, they will reflect artistically on the article, or learn more about Venezuela.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “Treasure Washes Up on Venezuela’s Shore, Bringing Gold and Hope to a Village” by Anatoly Kurmanaev and Isayen Herrera

headline: In New York City, snowfall tops all of last winter’s.
abstract: With forecasters predicting New York could get up to a foot of snow when a nor’easter hit on Wednesday, residents braced for what had the potential to be the most severe winter storm since a blizzard shut down the city in January 2016.
lead_paragraph: With forecasters predicting New York could get up to a foot of snow when a nor’easter hit on Wednesday, residents braced for what had the potential to be the most severe winter storm since a blizzard shut down the city in January 2016.

headline: M.T.A. officials breathe a sigh of relief with Biden.
abstract: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has warned for months that the agency will be forced to make draconian cuts, including slashing New York City’s subway service 40 percent, as the pandemic plunged the nation’s largest public transit agency into its worst financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has warned for months that the agency will be forced to make draconian cuts, including slashing New York City’s subway service 40 percent, as the pandemic plunged the nation’s largest public transit agency into its worst financial crisis.

headline: Cold storage, crucial to the vaccine, has caught Wall Street’s eye.
abstract: As countries prepare to distribute hundreds of millions of Covid-19 vaccines — some of which require storage as cold as the South Pole in winter — the highly specialized operations of companies like PCI Pharma Services, which specializes in packaging and shipping drugs around the world, are in heavy demand. And Wall Street, which likes nothing better than a hot trade with the potential for big profits, is rushing to grab a piece of the action.
lead_paragraph: As countries prepare to distribute hundreds of millions of Covid-19 vaccines — some of which require storage as cold as the South Pole in winter — the highly specialized operations of companies like PCI Pharma Services, which specializes in packaging and shipping drugs around the world, are in heavy demand. And Wall Street, which likes nothing better than a hot trade with the potential for big profits, is rushing to grab a piece of the action.

headline: A day of hope, and warning, as a vaccine is rolled out in the U.S.
abstract: Pharmacists across the United States got a happy surprise when they opened up newly delivered coronavirus vaccine vials and discovered that some held more than their labels indicated.
lead_paragraph: Pharmacists across the United States got a happy surprise when they opened up newly delivered coronavirus vaccine vials and discovered that some held more than their labels indicated.

headline: Misinformation peddlers have shifted gears from the election to coronavirus vaccines.
abstract: Sidney Powell, a lawyer who was part of President Trump’s legal team, spread a conspiracy theory last month about election fraud. For days, she claimed that she would “release the Kraken” by showing voluminous evidence that Mr. Trump had won the election by a landslide.
lead_paragraph: Sidney Powell, a lawyer who was part of President Trump’s legal team, spread a conspiracy theory last month about election fraud. For days, she claimed that she would “release the Kraken” by showing voluminous evidence that Mr. Trump had won the election by a landslide.

headline: Nursing home residents rejoice over first coronavirus vaccines.
abstract: Patricia John was still in her nightgown this week in the West Virginia nursing home where she lives when a nurse hurried her out of her room to join a line that had formed in the hallway.
lead_paragraph: Patricia John was still in her nightgown this week in the West Virginia nursing home where she lives when a nurse hurried her out of her room to join a line that had formed in the hallway.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Eating Mashed Potatoes
abstract: A deeply personal choice: Should you use a spoon or a fork?
lead_paragraph: Ruth writes: I don’t really care that my spouse, Jesse, insists on eating his mashed potatoes with a spoon, but I do care that he insists this is normal. Surely his Mennonite mother, who knows all things about starch and butter and who has excellent cooking skills, taught him better. Please order him to admit that he’s an outlier, not me.

headline: Want to Talk About Racism? Sit Next to Frederick Joseph
abstract: This debut author has learned not to read the comments about his new book, “The Black Friend.” Some are supportive; others contain death threats.
lead_paragraph: VOICE OF EXPERIENCE Frederick Joseph realized he wanted — and needed — to write “The Black Friend: On Being a Better White Person” when he was riding the New York City subway on his way to work. “I sat next to a white woman in one of the available seats and she clutched her purse, looked at me as if she was deathly afraid, got up and walked to another seat to sit next to a white man,” recalls the philanthropist and marketing guru who, according to Forbes’s 30 Under 30, “raised nearly $1 million to send some 73,000 children” to see “Black Panther.”

headline: These Buses Bring School to Students
abstract: Remote learning is extra hard for millions of students who lack reliable internet at home. Wi-Fi buses are the solution in this Michigan community.
lead_paragraph: Remote learning is extra hard for millions of students who lack reliable internet at home. Wi-Fi buses are the solution in this Michigan community.

headline: Emerald Fennell’s Dark, Jaded, Funny, Furious Fables of Female Revenge
abstract: A brilliant young showrunner from “Killing Eve” unveils her first film, “Promising Young Woman,” bringing macabre feminist wit to experiences that no one wants to talk about.
lead_paragraph: The germ of the idea for “Promising Young Woman” first lodged itself in Emerald Fennell’s mind six or seven years ago, at a dinner party she and her roommates were throwing for some old college friends in London. Everyone was sitting around the kitchen table, eating pasta, when one woman happened to mention a creepy encounter she’d had with a guy on the tube on her way over. The men at the table were shocked. The women were shocked that the men were shocked. What world did they live in? Apparently not one filled with creeps who followed you home, or groped you on public transport, or catcalled you and turned nasty when you ignored them.

headline: How the Economy Is Actually Doing, in 9 Charts
abstract: The unemployment rate doesn't tell the whole story. We talked to a panel of economists to find out what other measures can shed light on whether we're in a short-term crisis — or the start of a long recession.
lead_paragraph: The unemployment rate doesn't tell the whole story. We talked to a panel of economists to find out what other measures can shed light on whether we're in a short-term crisis — or the start of a long recession.

headline: With Rents Going Down, They Looked to Trade Up. Which of These Homes Would You Choose?
abstract: For their first place together, a couple joined forces (and budgets) to find a place with some sunlight and enough space to work from home.
lead_paragraph: For their first place together, a couple joined forces (and budgets) to find a place with some sunlight and enough space to work from home.

headline: The Tactic of Our Time: Sound Urgent, Be Incomprehensible
abstract: In an era of institutional rot, cranks can be hard to tell from heroes.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve ever attended an open meeting regarding any function of your local government, you’ll understand how crucial it is to American democracy that ordinary citizens not be expected to represent themselves with the vocabulary of lawyers or the poise of politicians. Still: Of the many Michiganders the Trump campaign trotted before state legislators early this month to air dubious allegations of electoral fraud, some worked hard to convey a sense of real gravity and sobriety. The actual content of their testimony may have been, by turns, witless, pointless and bizarre — for the most part, they failed to understand mundane features of election law and thus considered them suspicious — but there was, surprisingly often, a real attempt made to dress nonsense in a presentable suit.

headline: A Breakout Star From Ryan Murphy’s ‘The Politician’
abstract: Theo Germaine was dog sitting and working at a cafe when his agent called with a life-changing role.
lead_paragraph: Name: Theo Germaine

headline: How Will You Be Celebrating the Holidays This Year?
abstract: What traditions do you, your family, friends and community have for the winter holidays? How are you finding ways to adapt them in our present circumstances?
lead_paragraph: Note: Today’s question comes from Hannah Grogan, 17, a student at Glenbard West High School in Illinois, who wanted to know “what new [holiday] traditions people are forming, now that so many old ones are impossible to carry out.” If you have an idea for a question inspired by a New York Times article that we should ask in our Student Opinion column, please submit it here.

headline: The Afghan War Is Over. Did Anyone Notice?
abstract: The troops are staying, but we can declare an end to our forever war.
lead_paragraph: I first read the “Iliad” in high school. The translation my teacher handed out had a single photograph on the cover: American G.I.s on D-Day storming out of a landing craft onto Omaha Beach.

headline: Poem: American Income
abstract: George Floyd. Eric Garner. A poem that speaks to it all.
lead_paragraph: Some days you feel like this. Maybe after watching the news that George Floyd was killed. Remembering that Eric Garner, too, could not breathe on an American street, under the hold of American police. And you wonder what poetry says to any of this. Afaa Michael Weaver’s “American Income” is a kind of answer. A noticing of it all, how sometimes it feels that your suffering is the path to someone else’s enlightenment, how sometimes, under the weight of it all, you fail where you would rather love. Or, as Weaver says of Black men, sometimes we keep “the weeping heads of gods in their eyes.”

headline: Thank the Supreme Court, for Now
abstract: The justices did the right thing by declining to hear the case brought by red states to overturn the election results. But let’s see what happens down the road.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court was never going to hear, let alone grant, the request by red-state attorneys general and the White House to overturn the election results in four battleground states that went for Joe Biden. We knew that, we privileged few who could have offered an inventory of the lawsuit’s flaws while standing on one foot. We had not the slightest doubt that the case was a non-starter.

headline: Workers Tap Retirement Savings as a Last Resort
abstract: At least two million workers have turned to their workplace retirement plans for cash under temporary rules created during the pandemic. But so far, most people have left their accounts alone.
lead_paragraph: About a month into the pandemic, Tyler Mathiesen lost his position at a tech company, his first full-time job out of college. For several months, everything was fine: Payments on his $75,000 in student loans were paused, and the extra $600 weekly federal unemployment benefit helped pay the rest. He even managed to save some money.

headline: A Call to Help, Still Sounding a Century On
abstract: In 1918, as soldiers returned from war and New York navigated a pandemic, readers opened their wallets. In 2020, the generosity continues.
lead_paragraph: It was a bad year that brought a new question, one familiar today: how to ask for more from people who have lost so much.

headline: Parenting a Ski Jumper as a Leap of Faith
abstract: Watching my 13-year-old son fling himself off a mountain has been keeping me grounded in the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: In the season of the pandemic — now three seasons, and counting — I have come to realize that the most normal part of my day is the hour I spend watching my second-born child fling himself off the side of a mountain.

headline: The New R.S.V.P.: A Signed Coronavirus ‘Waiver’
abstract: Hosts are asking guests to be absolved of liability if someone gets infected. But is the waiver enforceable?
lead_paragraph: Before Ali Stagnitta, 26, an entertainment reporter who lives in Greenwich Village, could attend a weekend retreat in the Catskills last month organized by Soho House, a private club, she had to check off a few things.

headline: Can Kara Swisher Be Vulnerable?
abstract: Brené Brown tries her best.
lead_paragraph: Brené Brown’s best-selling books and TED talks about embracing vulnerability and shame have made her a cultural phenomenon. Silicon Valley executives often invite her to speak to their companies, though she is skeptical about their intentions to follow through on her advice. “For some people, I am the kombucha shake of the month,” she says.

headline: This Is Not the Way New Yorkers Normally Greet a Major Snowstorm
abstract: Sleds were sold out all over as the city, for once, met an oncoming nor’easter with a measure of delight.
lead_paragraph: It’s a New York City nightmare: a midweek nor’easter that dumps almost a foot of snow before the morning commute, snarling traffic, shutting down airports and commuter train lines, slowing subways and forcing parents to somehow work around small children thrilled by a day off from school.

headline: She Saved Thousands of Best Friends. Then Covid-19 Killed Her.
abstract: Valerie Louie rescued dogs and matched them with families, including ours. These beloved pets helped countless people bear up during the pandemic, making her death a particular Covid-19 cruelty.
lead_paragraph: Valerie Louie saved our beloved Uncle Mort from a life of abuse. Then she became a pandemic casualty. Her death is being mourned by households with four-pawed members across San Francisco and the Bay Area.

headline: You’re Choosing a Gift. Here’s What Not to Do.
abstract: Many of our natural impulses turn out to be wrong. Psychological research can help us choose wisely.
lead_paragraph: On Christmas morning, a husband quietly apologizes to his wife that his gifts this year are humble — money is tight. She bravely affirms that she loves the pajamas and the sweater. Later, as the children play with their new toys, the husband reveals one last gift box, in which the wife discovers a diamond necklace. She squeals with astonished delight.

headline: For Cocoa With Panache, Make Hot Chocolate Bombs
abstract: You’ve seen them on TikTok, now you can create them at home.
lead_paragraph: A few ingredients go a long way when it comes to hot chocolate bombs, a cozy treat that has quickly gained popularity on social media. These chocolate balls may look unassuming from the outside, but when placed in a cup of warm milk, the outer shell “explodes” to reveal hot cocoa powder and marshmallows within. Once mixed together, it makes for a rich cup of hot chocolate, and a fun recipe to assemble and give as gifts to family and friends.

headline: These People Helped Shape Video Game Culture in 2020
abstract: Designers, competitors, streamers, voice actors and labor activists have been working to make gaming more inclusive.
lead_paragraph: It should come as no surprise that 2020 was a monumental year for the video game industry. While other business sectors saw revenues shrink and storefronts close, gaming companies have profited over these many months when millions of people have been spending more time at home.

headline: The Vaccines Are Supposed to Be Free. Surprise Bills Could Happen Anyway.
abstract: “It is the American health care system, so there are bound to be loopholes.”
lead_paragraph: When Americans receive a coronavirus vaccine, federal rules say they shouldn’t have to pay anything out of pocket.

headline: Nurses Are Anxious and Angry in 2nd Wave: ‘We’re Not Prepared’
abstract: “We’re worse off in some ways than we were in the beginning,” said one nurse about the lack of workers and resources at her New York hospital.
lead_paragraph: In Albany, an outbreak of the coronavirus erupted among nurses and patients in the cancer unit of a hospital.

headline: Booking Travel in 2021? Here’s How to Protect Your Investment
abstract: The crystal ball remains cloudy when it comes to travel. Here’s how to avoid losing money if you have to cancel.
lead_paragraph: Between the promise of a coronavirus vaccine and the plethora of trips, cruises and lodgings on sale, travelers may be tempted to buy now for future vacations. But the crystal ball remains cloudy as to when you might be able to travel freely, given the frequency of virus surges, shifting quarantine requirements and border closures. Given weak bookings, will your travel provider even be in business by the time your trip rolls around?

headline: Some Health Care Workers Are Getting the Vaccine. Others Aren’t. Who Decides?
abstract: Many primary care doctors, firefighters and others at risk of exposure are waiting to learn when they will get vaccinated.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Biron Baker runs a family medicine clinic in Bismarck, N.D. Every day patients walk through the door, and any number of them could be sick with the coronavirus. Dr. Baker treats them anyway, doing the best he can with his small staff to keep from getting sick.

headline: Falling Behind on Weekly Rent and Afraid of Being Evicted
abstract: Residents of weekly rentals worry they will be kicked out if they can’t pay the rent. It’s unclear if the federal moratorium on evictions applies to them.
lead_paragraph: Demetress Malone came back to his weekly rental one day in early September to find that the door to his unit had been taken off its hinges and the electrical power shut off.

headline: The Man I Saw Them Kill
abstract: The Trump administration has resumed federal executions after a 17-year hiatus. I witnessed the latest one.
lead_paragraph: TERRE HAUTE, Ind. — On Thursday evening, I sat in the lobby of a Marriott hotel in Terre Haute, Ind., as Shawn Nolan and Victor Abreu tried to save a man’s life. Both wore bluejeans, button-down shirts and a day or more of scruff — Mr. Nolan’s salt-and-pepper, Mr. Abreu’s black. We shared a bottle of red wine in plastic cups as the two men, public defenders whose caseloads are strictly death penalty appeals, discussed the merits of pleading with the Supreme Court for a stay of execution.

headline: Big Pharma Is Fooling Us
abstract: Heroic work went into the development of the coronavirus vaccines. But that doesn’t mean this industry deserves your affection.
lead_paragraph: It’s about as near as science gets to a miracle: A coronavirus vaccine has arrived — and the main reason is that mRNA vaccines, a previously untested technology, appears to work better than almost anyone had hoped.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience virtually.
lead_paragraph: For “Treacherous With Old Magic,” one of the presentations at the Future Fair’s virtual Holiday Market, the curator and art adviser Nico Wheadon put together a group of artworks, each selling for no more than $5,000 (the fair’s price cap for pieces), made by female artists of color like Saya Woolfalk and Joiri Minaya. Woolfalk’s screen print “Encyclopedia of Cloud Divination (Plate 3),” which incorporates her signature Afrofuturist elements, is part of a collection that investigates how identities are formed and maintained.

headline: What Happened in 2020 Will Not Stay in 2020
abstract: Elections are not intended to be open-ended affairs. But is any campaign with Donald Trump on the ballot bound to linger past its sell-by date?
lead_paragraph: Long after the final vote had been cast, long after the verdict of the electorate was clear, a curious thing began happening recently within the space-time perplexity of Trump-era politics: At last, it started to feel as if the election might be over, really and truly.

headline: The Video Games That Got Us Through 2020
abstract: These are not necessarily the best games or the newest games. But these are the games that people across The New York Times played for hundreds of hours this year.
lead_paragraph: I’ve spent the last few months doing almost exactly what I was doing 20 years ago: suspended in deep space, riding undulating rainbow roads in Mario Kart. Now, I play on my Switch. Then, on my Nintendo 64. Maybe you were new to video games in 2020, each day of social distancing nudging you closer to an alternate reality. (You wouldn’t be alone; the industry saw record spending and profits this year.) Or maybe you’ve been playing since you developed the motor skills to grip a controller. In any case, what matters is that video games provided a much-needed outlet in a bizarre time.

headline: The Best TV Episodes of 2020
abstract: Jackie Daytona. Dave Chappelle’s monologue. John Wilson’s risotto lesson. These are the episodes that cut through the clutter this year.
lead_paragraph: Even deep into the binge-watching era — and in a year when most of us binged more than ever before — individual episodes still matter. Here, the television critics of The New York Times recall which, of the thousands they watched this year, cut through the clutter and stuck with them in 2020.

headline: Viola Davis and Company on ‘Ma Rainey’ and Chadwick Boseman’s Last Bow
abstract: Members of the creative team discuss what it took to adapt the August Wilson play for Netflix and trying not to be “outdone” by the late actor.
lead_paragraph: A nation riven by racial violence, an industry with a history of exploiting Black culture, white executives eager to portray themselves as allies, and Black artists at the center of it all, contending with a system that would toast them with one arm and pick their pockets with the other.

headline: The 25 Best Classical Music Tracks of 2020
abstract: Listen to our critics’ favorites from a year in which much of the energy in music came from recordings.
lead_paragraph: The composer Thomas Adès and the pianist Kirill Gerstein’s artistically fruitful friendship has given us two essential albums this year: the premiere recording of Mr. Adès’s Concerto for Piano and Orchestra, featuring Mr. Gerstein and the Boston Symphony Orchestra (Deutsche Grammophon); and this one, which includes a solo arrangement of the harrowing and slippery Berceuse from Mr. Adès’s opera “The Exterminating Angel.” JOSHUA BARONE

headline: Pence is to be vaccinated publicly on Friday, and other top Washington figures will soon follow.
abstract: Vice President Mike Pence and his wife, Karen Pence, will receive a coronavirus vaccine on Friday, according to the White House, a move that the Trump administration says is intended to “promote the safety and efficacy of the vaccine and build confidence among the American people.”
lead_paragraph: Vice President Mike Pence and his wife, Karen Pence, will receive a coronavirus vaccine on Friday, according to the White House, a move that the Trump administration says is intended to “promote the safety and efficacy of the vaccine and build confidence among the American people.”

headline: What New Yorkers Need to Know About the Snowstorm
abstract: The National Weather Service suggested that snow accumulations in New York City could end up on the low end of the initial forecasts of eight to 12 inches.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: How to Reimagine Policing and Public Safety that Works for Everyone
abstract: A group of police chiefs, activists and policymakers gathered to debate how to reform law enforcement in America in a time of unrest and upheaval.
lead_paragraph: In a year of near universal upheaval brought on by the global spread of a new disease, Americans also confronted a crisis that has long plagued the nation: racism and its brutal manifestations in policing.

headline: A 1958 ’Vette Translated Into Modern Chinese
abstract: SongSan’s SS Dolphin is the latest in a long line of Chinese attempts at cloning more prominent vehicles.
lead_paragraph: On the floor of the international auto show this fall in Beijing, among the gleaming boldface names and futuristic concepts, was a car that from a distance looked like a 1958 Corvette.

headline: Should Facebook Be Broken Up?
abstract: The U.S. government and more than 40 states say the social networking company has become an unlawful monopoly that is hurting consumers.
lead_paragraph: This episode contains strong language.

headline: In the U.K., Johnson resists ‘canceling’ Christmas to stem the coronavirus.
abstract: In a year of hard decisions about how to confront the coronavirus, perhaps none has proved as anguished for Prime Minister Boris Johnson as whether to ban people in Britain from getting together for a little Christmas cheer.
lead_paragraph: In a year of hard decisions about how to confront the coronavirus, perhaps none has proved as anguished for Prime Minister Boris Johnson as whether to ban people in Britain from getting together for a little Christmas cheer.

headline: 51 Is Greater Than 1
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: Over the spring and summer, Mitch McConnell repeatedly declared that he had a litmus test for any new coronavirus stimulus bill: It had to protect businesses from lawsuits from workers or customers who contracted the virus.

headline: Humboldt Forum in Berlin Finally Opens (Kind of)
abstract: A modest ceremony inaugurated the troubled museum, one of the most expensive and ambitious culture projects in Europe. The only thing is, you can’t go in.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — After years of hand-wringing about its place in German history, strife over the provenance of its objects and delays in its construction, the Humboldt Forum, an attraction in central Berlin conceived as Germany’s equivalent to the Louvre or the British Museum, finally opened with a ceremony on Wednesday.

headline: Putin Denies Involvement in Poisoning of Navalny
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia laughed off a question about the opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny at a marathon news conference, where he praised his country’s Covid-19 response and President Trump.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia denied on Thursday that he was behind the near-deadly poisoning of his most prominent political opponent, telling journalists with a laugh that if Russian agents had wanted to kill Aleksei A. Navalny, “they would have probably finished the job.”

headline: ‘Monster Hunter’ Review: Beasts of Boredom
abstract: Milla Jovovich stars as an Army Ranger trapped in an alternate universe in this video game-derived silliness.
lead_paragraph: “Monster Hunter” — 80 percent monsters, 20 percent hunter — proves definitively that neither gaping wounds nor a gargantuan armored earwig can stop Milla Jovovich.

headline: ‘The Belovs’ Review: Another View of Farm Life
abstract: The director of “Gunda” filmed two Russian siblings in the early 1990s.
lead_paragraph: For viewers charmed by the Russian documentarian Victor Kossakovsky’s “Gunda,” an immersion in the sights and sounds of farm life from something close to a pig’s-eye point of view, Film Forum is streaming an intriguing portrait of agrarian living that the director filmed in 1992.

headline: ‘Nasrin’ Review: Righting Wrongs in Iran
abstract: Filmed in secret, Jeff Kaufman’s portrait of the Iranian lawyer Nasrin Sotoudeh captures her ongoing battles for the rights of women, children and minorities.
lead_paragraph: “Nasrin,” a surreptitiously filmed documentary about the imprisoned Iranian human rights lawyer Nasrin Sotoudeh, offers a strangely cheerful portrait of extreme sacrifice and ongoing suffering.

headline: ‘Effigy — Poison and the City’ Review: Death and the Matron
abstract: Udo Flohr’s stagy drama follows the investigation of a real-life serial killer in 1820s Germany.
lead_paragraph: A surreal period drama inspired by real events, Udo Flohr’s “Effigy — Poison and the City” dramatizes the multiple deaths surrounding a beautiful widow in 1820s Bremen, Germany.

headline: Dear Santa: It’s Been a Hard Year
abstract: In 23,000 letters addressed to the North Pole, collected through a U.S. Postal Service program, wish lists from children across the nation reflect the strain of this year.
lead_paragraph: “Dear Santa,” began a letter written by Alani, age 9, addressed to 123 Elf Road, North Pole, 88888.

headline: At Long Last, a Stimulus Nears
abstract: Worried about Georgia, Mitch McConnell plays ball in Washington: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: Are McConnell and Pelosi really close to a deal? Just close your eyes until next week, then ask again. It’s Thursday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

headline: New England saw more snow and cold temperatures.
abstract: More snow was expected in Boston
lead_paragraph: By Thursday evening, the storm that blanketed much of the Northeast and Mid-Atlantic was making its way out to sea, off the coast of Cape Cod and eastern Maine. Left behind in many places was an astonishing amount of snow in some places, with flakes persisting into Thursday afternoon, according to the National Weather Service.

headline: ‘Waking me up and banging on the door every day’: Residents of weekly rentals are at risk of eviction.
He Spent 20 Years in Prison, Until a Serial Killer Confessed to the Crime
abstract: Yoon Sung-yeo was sentenced to life for a crime he did not commit in South Korea. He was able to clear his name after a notorious serial killer confessed last year.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — A man in South Korea who spent 20 years in prison for the murder of a 13-year-old girl was acquitted in a retrial on Thursday after the country’s most infamous serial killer confessed to the crime last year.

headline: The plan to vaccinate nursing home residents faces a key obstacle: consent.
abstract: There remains widespread confusion about a key element of the plan to protect some of the most vulnerable Americans against the coronavirus, report Rebecca Robbins and Jessica Silver-Greenberg for The New York Times: how nursing homes will get consent to vaccinate residents who aren’t able to make their own medical decisions.
lead_paragraph: There remains widespread confusion about a key element of the plan to protect some of the most vulnerable Americans against the coronavirus, report Rebecca Robbins and Jessica Silver-Greenberg for The New York Times: how nursing homes will get consent to vaccinate residents who aren’t able to make their own medical decisions.

headline: Big Tech’s Circular Firing Squad
abstract: Facebook’s slap at Apple shows Silicon Valley is feeling the regulatory heat.
lead_paragraph: When Big Tech’s C.E.O.s are hauled before Congress and accused of amassing excessive power, the leaders from Apple, Facebook, Google and others have often tried to present a united front. But these companies are also competitors, and have recently taken to calling on regulators to go after each other.

headline: Jess Walter Doesn’t Have a Lot of Patience for Memoirs
abstract: “I get claustrophobic spending too much time in the head of another writer.”
lead_paragraph: “Maybe it’s fatigue with social media and the confessional tone of reality television,” says the author of the new novel “The Cold Millions,” “but I get claustrophobic spending too much time in the head of another writer.”

headline: ‘Ma Rainey’s Black Bottom’ Review: All the Blues That’s Fit to Sing
abstract: Viola Davis and Chadwick Boseman star in a potent adaptation of August Wilson’s play.
lead_paragraph: “White folks don’t understand about the blues,” says the pioneering singer Ma Rainey, as imagined by August Wilson and incarnated by Viola Davis. “They hear it come out, but they don’t know how it got there. They don’t understand that that’s life’s way of talking.”

headline: The Bank of England holds interest rates steady as Brexit talks continue.
abstract: The Bank of England, which has been battling not only a pandemic but the threat of a disruptive exit from the European Union, made no changes to its monetary policy Thursday amid signs that both threats could be receding.
lead_paragraph: The Bank of England, which has been battling not only a pandemic but the threat of a disruptive exit from the European Union, made no changes to its monetary policy Thursday amid signs that both threats could be receding.

headline: A Discussion About the Electoral College and Voting Rights
abstract: Thursday: Assemblywoman Shirley Weber says, “I continue to be amazed at being able to participate in the process at this level.” Also: A pandemic update.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Here’s how many inches of snow fell in different U.S. cities.
abstract: Central Park in Manhattan got 10 inches, and Binghamton in upstate New York recorded 41.
lead_paragraph: Cities from the Mid-Atlantic to New England were blanketed by snow and ice on Wednesday and Thursday, with some recording more snowfall overnight than they had all last winter.

headline: I Said They Didn’t Have to Come to My Wedding. But I’m Still Hurt.
abstract: How to deal with declined invitations and delayed R.S.V.P.s in the time of Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: I recently got married. After several changes to our original plans, we had a small, in-person, socially distanced event. We told invited guests that we would also livestream the wedding and that there would be no hard feelings if they decided that was the better choice for them. We outlined the safety protocols of the venue to all invitees. But we still had to ask for firm R.S.V.P.’s like any other wedding. Some guests declined parts of the celebration (after the deadline) and others didn’t show up after saying they would. Every single one of them cited Covid-19 as their reason. I am really hurt by this — especially from our nearest and dearest. How do I move forward with these people?

headline: The T List: Six Things We Recommend This Week
abstract: Housewares from the Hudson Valley, shearling accessories — and more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we’re sharing things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. You can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

headline: Fewer Homes for Sale Across the Country
abstract: Inventory is down across the country, throwing the housing market ‘out of whack.’ Here are the metro areas with the greatest changes in listing supply.
lead_paragraph: The pandemic housing market across the U.S. is putting interested buyers in a serious bind: Demand for new homes is on the rise but homeowners are largely staying put, meaning inventory is limited, competition is heated and prices are spiking. Among the nation’s 50 largest metro areas, 38 percent fewer homes were on the market in the third quarter of 2020 than during the same period last year, according to a study from Nerdwallet, the personal-finance company.

headline: An Elixir From the French Alps, Frozen in Time
abstract: Only two monks know the full recipe for Chartreuse, and even in the pandemic they stuck to their Middle Ages motto: “The cross is steady while the world turns.”
lead_paragraph: GRENOBLE, France — When the world went into lockdowns this year, the monks of Chartreuse simply added another tick to their 900-year record of self-imposed isolation.

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
abstract: This week’s properties are a six-bedroom house in Mount Kisco, N.Y., and a four-bedroom colonial in Robbinsville, N.J.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are a six-bedroom house in Mount Kisco, N.Y., and a four-bedroom colonial in Robbinsville, N.J.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
abstract: This week’s properties are a six-bedroom house in Mount Kisco, N.Y., and a four-bedroom colonial in Robbinsville, N.J.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: This week’s properties are in Park Slope, the East Village and Mott Haven.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are in Park Slope, the East Village and Mott Haven.

headline: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn, Manhattan and the Bronx
abstract: This week’s properties are in Park Slope, the East Village and Mott Haven.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: Dominion demands that Sidney Powell retract ‘baseless and false allegations’ about voting machines.
abstract: Dominion Voting Systems sent a blistering letter on Wednesday night to the right-wing lawyer Sidney Powell, demanding that she publicly retract her “wild, knowingly baseless and false accusations” about the company’s voting machines, which have repeatedly found themselves at the heart of conspiracy theories surrounding the election.
lead_paragraph: Dominion Voting Systems sent a blistering letter on Wednesday night to the right-wing lawyer Sidney Powell, demanding that she publicly retract her “wild, knowingly baseless and false accusations” about the company’s voting machines, which have repeatedly found themselves at the heart of conspiracy theories surrounding the election.

headline: Robinhood Pays $65 Million Fine to Settle Charges of Misleading Customers
abstract: Millions of investors have turned to Robinhood in recent years, lured by a sales pitch of no trading fees. The charges announced on Thursday apply to Robinhood’s disclosures from 2015 to late 2018, the regulator said.
lead_paragraph: Robinhood, a fast-growing financial app, has attracted millions of young customers in recent years by making it fun and free to trade stocks, as well as riskier investments like options and Bitcoin.

headline: Russia’s Doping Ban Is Cut to a Largely Symbolic Two Years
abstract: The ruling by the Court of Arbitration for Sport reduced a four-year ban to two. It will keep Russian teams — but not necessarily Russian athletes — out of the next two Olympics.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s four-year ban from global sports was halved on Thursday by a court in Switzerland, a decision that could signal the end of its yearslong battle with antidoping regulators who had accused the country of running one of the most sophisticated doping schemes in history in pursuit of sporting glory and Olympic medals.

headline: ‘Nightmare’ lockdown in Australian towers is called a breach of human rights.
abstract: The sudden lockdown this summer of 3,000 public housing residents in Melbourne, Australia, violated human rights laws, an investigation has found.
lead_paragraph: The sudden lockdown this summer of 3,000 public housing residents in Melbourne, Australia, violated human rights laws, an investigation has found.

headline: Dorothy Gill Barnes, 93, Artist Whose Raw Material Came From Trees, Dies
abstract: She created works from bark, wood and roots, sometimes carving patterns into trees and waiting years to see the scarring. She died of complications of Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Puppy Scams Have Spiked in the Pandemic
abstract: As the demand for pets has surged since the arrival of the coronavirus, consumer advocates are warning people to be wary of offers that seem too good to be true.
lead_paragraph: Sylvia Lopez, who was laid off from her job this year because of the pandemic, saw an adorable pug puppy named Ted online. For $400, a price advertised as a promotion, she bought the puppy, and then paid more than $800 to have it flown from Virginia to her home in Texas, where she and her family were in quarantine.

headline: Indian Call-Center Plot Fooled Americans Into Paying Over $14 Million
abstract: The scammers told victims that their assets and bank accounts had been linked to drug cartels and would be seized if they didn’t pay up, the authorities in India said.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The police in New Delhi say they have arrested more than 50 people involved in a call-center scheme that lured victims into thinking their assets were being frozen as part of an elaborate drug investigation. The victims were convinced they had to transfer money to the scammers or risk going to jail.

headline: Get Rid of the Electoral College, at Last?
abstract: Readers offer their arguments for and against, citing the concerns of America’s founders and the way campaigns focus on battleground states.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Emmanuel Macron Tests Positive for the Coronavirus
abstract: European leaders who have been in contact with the French president will isolate and be tested. Mr. Macron has experienced symptoms, but showed no signs of illness in a video appearance.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — President Emmanuel Macron of France has tested positive for the coronavirus and will work in isolation for the next week, prompting other European leaders he has met to take precautionary measures and complicating Europe’s efforts to overcome a crippling second wave of the pandemic.

headline: To the Rescue This Year: The People Who Put Orchestras Online
abstract: Across the country, fall concerts were saved by staff whose work shifted rapidly from promotional videos to high-quality broadcasts.
lead_paragraph: As recently as March, Brandon Cardley’s work as the Boston Symphony Orchestra’s video engineer was largely limited to small projects, like cutting clips of concerts for social media and marketing materials. But once the coronavirus pandemic’s spread started to cancel performances through summer and fall, then winter and spring, his job suddenly looked a lot different.

headline: After a yearlong review, Europe approves Google’s FitBit acquisition.
abstract: Google received a kernel of good news on Thursday when European Union authorities approved its acquisition of the fitness-tracking company Fitbit after a lengthy review to determine whether the $2.1 billion takeover violated antitrust laws.
lead_paragraph: Google received a kernel of good news on Thursday when European Union authorities approved its acquisition of the fitness-tracking company Fitbit after a lengthy review to determine whether the $2.1 billion takeover violated antitrust laws.

headline: Read the CAS Decision Reducing Russia’s Doping Ban
abstract: The ruling reduced a four-year ban to two, but will keep Russian teams out of the next two Olympics and dozens of other global competitions.
lead_paragraph: The ruling reduced a four-year ban to two, but will keep Russian teams out of the next two Olympics and dozens of other global competitions.

headline: Putin says Russians may get one vaccine shot, not two, to speed things up.
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said on Thursday that his government was considering giving each member of the public just one dose of its main coronavirus vaccine, instead of two, in order to get the vaccine quickly to more people.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said on Thursday that his government was considering giving each member of the public just one dose of its main coronavirus vaccine, instead of two, in order to get the vaccine quickly to more people.

headline: ‘Museum Town’ Review: A Love Letter to Mass MoCA
abstract: This documentary looks at how a contemporary art museum in Western Massachusetts transformed a struggling small town.
lead_paragraph: At its heart, the documentary “Museum Town,” is a love letter — to the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art, to artistic experimentation and to North Adams, the struggling factory town where the institution is situated.

headline: Annotated by the Author: ‘Lizzo in Concert: A Dynamic Reminder of the Power of Self-Acceptance’
abstract: Elizabeth Phelps, a winner of our 2019 Student Review Contest, tells us why going to a Lizzo concert is like going to church.
lead_paragraph: In our “Annotated by the Author” series, we invite New York Times journalists and winners of our student contests to comment on their work to help demystify the writing and research process.

headline: We looked inside Britain’s pandemic spending, and found waste, negligence and cronyism.
abstract: When the pandemic exploded in March, British officials embarked on a desperate scramble to procure the personal protective equipment, ventilators, coronavirus tests and other supplies critical to containing the surge. In the months following those fevered days, the government handed out thousands of contracts to fight the virus, some of them in a secretive “V.I.P. lane” to a select few companies with connections to the governing Conservative Party.
lead_paragraph: When the pandemic exploded in March, British officials embarked on a desperate scramble to procure the personal protective equipment, ventilators, coronavirus tests and other supplies critical to containing the surge. In the months following those fevered days, the government handed out thousands of contracts to fight the virus, some of them in a secretive “V.I.P. lane” to a select few companies with connections to the governing Conservative Party.

headline: Ivory From Shipwreck Reveals Elephant Slaughter During Spice Trade
abstract: A trove from a Portuguese trading ship that sank in 1533 preserved genetic traces of whole lineages that have vanished from West Africa.
lead_paragraph: In 2008, workers searching for diamonds off the coast of Namibia found a different kind of treasure: hundreds of gold coins mixed with timber and other debris. They had stumbled upon Bom Jesus, a Portuguese trading vessel lost during a voyage to India in 1533. Among the 40 tons of cargo recovered from the sunken ship were more than 100 elephant tusks.

headline: ‘I Learned to Appreciate My Husband,’ and Other Silver Linings From 2020
abstract: We asked readers to name one good thing that happened in an otherwise dismal year. Here is a selection from the more than 1,500 responses.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: What’s in Our Queue? ‘On the Rocks’
abstract: I'm a pop culture reporter here at The Times. Here's what I've been watching, reading and listening to.
lead_paragraph: I'm a pop culture reporter here at The Times. Here's what I've been watching, reading and listening to.

headline: Denmark Toughens Rape Law to Include Sex Without Consent
abstract: Rights groups and assault survivors welcomed the change, saying it was long overdue in a country that prides itself on gender equality.
lead_paragraph: Denmark toughened its rape law on Thursday by criminalizing sex without explicit consent, a long-awaited victory for assault survivors and human rights groups.

headline: Harold Budd, Composer of Spaciousness and Calm, Dies at 84
abstract: Known for his collaborations with art-pop artists like Brian Eno and Cocteau Twins, he created a signature sound suspended in reverberation and drone.
lead_paragraph: Harold Budd, a composer and pianist known for the preternatural spaciousness and melancholy calm of his music, and for his collaborations with art-pop artists like Brian Eno and Cocteau Twins, died on Dec. 8 in a hospital in Arcadia, Calif. He was 84.

headline: Will a Famous Critic’s Desk Cure My Writer’s Block?
abstract: Seeking inspiration from Vincent Canby’s Gothic trestle table.
lead_paragraph: Because of the pandemic, I have Vincent Canby’s desk. Millions of witty words must have drummed from his fingertips where I now slouch, stalled and mostly unproductive, without deadlines to drive me.

headline: It Was a Landmark Crime Bill. Then a State Senator Added a Special Favor.
abstract: The clause to weaken penalties for official misconduct in New Jersey was added by a powerful Democrat whose girlfriend’s son faces five years in prison.
lead_paragraph: Legislation that would usher in landmark changes to the criminal justice system in New Jersey has been awaiting final action for a year.

headline: Gunman Sentenced to Life in Prison for 2015 Attack on Paris-Bound Train
abstract: The trial of the main assailant, Ayoub El Khazzani, and three accomplices provided a rare opportunity for prosecutors to delve into the operations of the Islamic State in Europe.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Four men involved in a terrorist attack on a Paris-bound train in 2015 that was foiled only by the courageous action of other passengers were convicted of attempted murder, complicity and criminal terrorist association, and sentenced to prison terms ranging from seven years to life.

headline: Microsoft’s Lessons for Google
abstract: What the Microsoft case teaches us about antitrust and the power of Big Tech today.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: 2020: A Theater of the Absurd for Europe’s Playhouses
abstract: The Times’s theater critics in London, Paris and Berlin reflect on a year of closures, reopenings, restrictions and curfews, in which the show somehow went on.
lead_paragraph: Theater of the absurd has nothing on the bizarre scenario endured by Britain’s playhouses during 2020. March 16 was the first of several doomsdays on which the coronavirus pandemic forced them to close their doors, bringing to a halt a theatrical economy worth billions of pounds.

headline: Axios Buys Charlotte Agenda, a Digital Start-Up, as Part of Push Into Local News
abstract: The site focuses on service journalism for North Carolina’s largest city. Now it has been scooped up in a deal valued at nearly $5 million and will be a partial model for other cities.
lead_paragraph: In the winter of 2015, Ted Williams was at the dinner table in his four-bedroom house in Charlotte, N.C., bending his wife’s ear about the future of the news media business.

headline: As Singapore Ventures Back Out, Migrant Workers Are Kept In
abstract: The low-wage workers, almost half of whom have contracted the coronavirus, continue to be mostly confined to dormitories even as the city-state eases restrictions.
lead_paragraph: On most days, there are zero new coronavirus cases among migrant workers in Singapore, who bore the brunt of the city-state’s outbreak this year. But as the government prepares for its final phase of reopening this month, those workers won’t be part of it.

headline: ‘On Pointe’: The Real-Life Adventures of Some Very Young Dancers
abstract: This six-part documentary on Disney+ takes viewers inside the School of American Ballet. You’ll get your “Nutcracker” fix, too.
lead_paragraph: The filmmaker Larissa Bills wasn’t the only girl growing up in the 1970s to obsess over “A Very Young Dancer,” Jill Krementz’s photo-driven look at the life of a 10-year-old student at the School of American Ballet during “Nutcracker” season. When she was given the green light to direct “On Pointe,” a documentary about the school, she went straight to eBay.

headline: Kim Ki-duk, Award-Winning South Korean Filmmaker, Dies at 59
abstract: He was celebrated for movies centered on society’s underbelly, but he was later accused of sexual misconduct. He died of Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Kim Ki-duk, ​an internationally celebrated South Korean film director who made movies ​about people ​on ​the margins of society​ that ​often ​included ​shocking scenes of violence against women, and whose career was dogged by allegations of sexual misconduct, died on Dec. 11 in Latvia.​ He was 59.

headline: A Very, Very Bright House: Lighting Dyker Heights for the Holidays
abstract: Nine snowflakes, eight penguins, five angels and three life-size Nutcrackers. “I spend several thousand dollars — at the least — each year.”

headline: Michael Regan, Biden’s E.P.A. Pick, Faces ‘Massive Reconstruction and Rebuilding’
abstract: Mr. Regan, if confirmed, will take over an agency central to achieving the new administration’s climate agenda.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. has selected Michael S. Regan, North Carolina’s top environmental regulator, to lead the Environmental Protection Agency, Mr. Biden’s transition team announced Thursday. The decision elevates for the first time a Black man to lead the powerful department, which is central to achieving the new administration’s climate change agenda.

headline: Google’s Legal Peril Grows in Face of Third Antitrust Suit
abstract: More than 30 states said that the company downplayed websites that let users search for information in specialized areas.
lead_paragraph: More than 30 states added to Google’s mushrooming legal woes on Thursday, accusing the Silicon Valley titan of illegally arranging its search results to push out smaller rivals.

headline: An Agonizing Wait After Nigeria Abductions, Then a Flood of Relief
abstract: The seizure of more than 300 boys brought immediate comparisons to the 2014 kidnapping of hundreds of schoolgirls. But an anguishing six days later, a state governor said the boys had been released.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — For six days, the parents kept a vigil at the school in northwestern Nigeria where their boys, more than 300 of them, were taken by armed men in the night.

headline: Guillaume Kientz Named Director at Hispanic Society
abstract: The former curator at the Louvre in Paris will take on the task of reinvigorating the struggling museum, which has been closed for renovations since 2017.
lead_paragraph: Guillaume Kientz, a Velázquez and El Greco expert and former curator at the Louvre in Paris, has been named director and chief executive of the Hispanic Society Museum & Library in New York, which boasts one of the world’s greatest collections of Spanish art and literature but has faced financial struggles and has been closed since 2017 for renovations.

headline: How to Find the Best Champagne for You
abstract: The name “Champagne” is no guarantee of quality. Here are 10 excellent big houses, 10 small grower-producers and a glossary.
lead_paragraph: The bigger producers of Champagne can make excellent wines, even at the entry level. Smaller grower-producers offer a different, often more distinctive expression of Champagne. Here are 10 big brands and 10 small growers well worth seeking out, and a glossary to help you navigate the selections.

headline: 10 Sparkling Wines for Leaving 2020 Behind
abstract: The end-of-the-year parties will look different in 2020, but the featured bottles will still be bubbly, whether they come from Champagne or elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a dismal year, but let’s look at the bright side: It’s nearly over.

headline: Bill Offers New College Sports Model: Give Athletes a Cut of the Profits
abstract: The legislation, introduced by Senator Cory Booker, could allow college football players and men’s basketball players to receive six-figure paychecks.
lead_paragraph: It would be one thing to suggest that Trevor Lawrence, the dynamic Clemson quarterback, be paid $173,000 this season. But what about the long snapper at Bowling Green? And it would raise few eyebrows to say that Luka Garza, the University of Iowa basketball star, should be paid $115,600. But what about the backup point guard at Portland State?

headline: My Neighbor Won’t Shovel the Snow. How Do I Make Him?
abstract: Shoveling snow is difficult work, and many people have obstacles that make it even harder. But it still has to get done.
lead_paragraph: Q: I live in a brownstone in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, and one of my neighbors does a terrible job shoveling his sidewalk. He shovels a narrow path barely the width of the shovel and usually leaves behind a layer of snow that becomes slick and icy. His property is at the corner, and he rarely clears the curb cut, making it hard to cross the street. How do I tell him to shovel better?

headline: No, there are no microchips in coronavirus vaccines.
abstract: Pfizer’s vaccine has 10 ingredients. None can track your location.
lead_paragraph: There are 10 ingredients in Pfizer’s coronavirus vaccines. Contrary to several conspiracy theories circulating online, a tracking microchip planted by the government to surveil the movements of Americans is not among them.

headline: How Can I Make a Home After Moving Again?
abstract: “Create constancy and continuity for your family,” writes our advice columnist.
lead_paragraph: In T’s advice column, Culture Therapist, either Ligaya Mishan or Megan O’Grady solves your problems using art. Have a question? Need some comfort? Email us at advice@nytimes.com.

headline: Takashi Oka, Journalist Who Interpreted Japan for U.S., Dies at 96
abstract: A former war crimes trial interpreter, he was the first native-born Tokyo bureau chief for The New York Times and a longtime correspondent for The Christian Science Monitor.
lead_paragraph: Takashi Oka, a journalist who illuminated a rising Japan for American readers during a long career at The Christian Science Monitor and as the first Japanese-born Tokyo bureau chief for The New York Times, died on Dec. 2 at his home in New York City. He was 96.

headline: Convicted Using False Testimony, Michigan Man Is Free After 38 Years
abstract: After years of outreach by University of Michigan law students, a woman admitted that her account of seeing Walter Forbes help set a deadly fire had been “a complete fabrication.”
lead_paragraph: Walter Forbes had enrolled in drafting technology classes at the community college in Jackson, Mich., in hopes of jump-starting a career in real estate development. That plan ended when he was arrested, at age 25, in connection with an arson death.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: European leaders who met Macron go into quarantine.
lead_paragraph: After President Emmanuel Macron of France tested positive for the coronavirus, other European leaders he recently met have begun to self-quarantine.

headline: More Hacking Attacks Found as Officials Warn of ‘Grave Risk’ to U.S. Government
abstract: Minutes after the government statement, President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. warned that his administration would impose “substantial costs” on those responsible. President Trump has been silent on the hacking.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal officials issued an urgent warning on Thursday that hackers who American intelligence agencies believed were working for the Kremlin used a far wider variety of tools than previously known to penetrate government systems, and said that the cyberoffensive was “a grave risk to the federal government.”

headline: The Lesson of the Last Four Years
abstract: The author of a book about Senator Joseph McCarthy says our country is “more resilient than we’d feared.” Also: Workplace flexibility for women.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Binghamton, N.Y., got a record-breaking amount of snow.
abstract: Officials said that 41 inches fell in the city, and Governor Cuomo declared a state of emergency across a wide swath of the state.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY, N.Y. — The snowstorm that blanketed the Northeast delivered record or near-record snowfalls to parts of upstate New York, prompting Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Thursday to declare a state of emergency in 18 counties outside New York City and its immediate suburbs.

headline: Exploring James Baldwin’s Old Haunts in New York and Paris
abstract: The writer — who grew up in Harlem in the 1920s and ’30s, moved to Greenwich Village and later to Paris in the 1940s — was no stranger to either city, frequenting nightclubs, restaurants and more. Here, we retrace some of his steps.
lead_paragraph: The writer — who grew up in Harlem in the 1920s and ’30s, moved to Greenwich Village and later to Paris in the 1940s — was no stranger to either city, frequenting nightclubs, restaurants and more. Here, we retrace some of his steps.

headline: How the Oxford-AstraZeneca Vaccine Works
abstract: An adenovirus helps prime the immune system to fight the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: An adenovirus helps prime the immune system to fight the coronavirus.

headline: As California I.C.U.s fill up, the dead are counted by the hour.
abstract: Just two weeks ago, Gov. Gavin Newsom warned Californians that the state’s intensive care beds might be full before Christmas.
lead_paragraph: Just two weeks ago, Gov. Gavin Newsom warned Californians that the state’s intensive care beds might be full before Christmas.

headline: Annotated by the Author: ‘New York Penn Station: Incoherent Urban Calamity’
abstract: Henry Hsiao, a winner of our 2019 Student Review Contest, tells us how he writes with his audience in mind.
lead_paragraph: In our “Annotated by the Author” series, we invite New York Times journalists and winners of our student contests to comment on their work to help demystify the writing and research process.

headline: Biden Picks Deb Haaland to Lead Interior Department
abstract: The historic choice would elevate a Native American to a cabinet secretary position for the first time, and do so at an agency that played a central role in the nation’s long-running abuse of native peoples.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a historic decision, President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. has chosen Deb Haaland, a congressional representative from New Mexico and a Native American, to lead the Interior Department, an agency that for much of the nation’s history played a central role in the dislocation and abuse of Indigenous communities from coast to coast.

headline: 11 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: On a video call recently, a colleague and I were discussing a book from last February when she stopped short. “Was that 2020?” she asked, wonderingly. “It feels like a lifetime ago.”

headline: A First for Sarah Fuller, but That Wasn’t the Last of It
abstract: Women broke through glass ceilings to gain roles in men’s sports this year. But the celebration of their place in history, and sometimes the pushback, can overshadow their work.
lead_paragraph: A first is always going to be noticed.

headline: Coinbase, a top cryptocurrency company, files for initial public offering.
abstract: The cryptocurrency company Coinbase has joined the rush of start-ups looking to go public.
lead_paragraph: The cryptocurrency company Coinbase has joined the rush of start-ups looking to go public.

headline: Kaley Cuoco Thanks You for Flying With ‘The Flight Attendant’
abstract: Cuoco, the star and executive producer of the HBO Max thriller, and the showrunner Steve Yockey discuss the season finale and their ideas for Season 2.
lead_paragraph: This interview includes spoilers for Thursday’s finale of “The Flight Attendant.”

headline: What’s at Stake for Those Awaiting Pandemic Relief?
abstract: If you work at a social services agency, we want to hear about how coronavirus relief impacts your work.
lead_paragraph: Congress is deep in negotiations this week to pass a coronavirus relief bill. In the meantime, many aid programs — from expanded unemployment to the federal eviction moratorium and student loan freeze — may expire at year’s end, or experience a lapse once a stimulus package is approved. Without ongoing government support, many Americans find themselves in limbo: More than 30 million renters are at risk of eviction, and according to an analysis by The Century Foundation, approximately 12 million workers will be cut off from unemployment insurance tied to the pandemic.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Looking for a prickly (and fictional) political drama or your next comedy binge? This weekend’s selections have you covered.
lead_paragraph: Every Monday, Wednesday and Friday, we offer viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read the latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.

headline: ‘The Stand’: Tracing the Stephen King Epic Through Its Many Mutations
abstract: King’s post-apocalyptic novel about the aftermath of a deadly pandemic has been adapted into a new mini-series for CBS All Access. But the story has a complex history of its own.
lead_paragraph: Take a pandemic. Add the paranormal. Make it a uniquely American story of survival horror. The result: “The Stand,” Stephen King’s epic post-apocalyptic novel from 1978, a new mini-series adaptation of which debuted Thursday on CBS All Access.

headline: Snowstorm Delayed Vaccine Deliveries, Says N.J. Governor
abstract: Gov. Philip D. Murphy of New Jersey said that the snowstorm that hit the East Coast on Wednesday and into Thursday morning delayed the delivery of coronavirus vaccines to some hospitals by several hours.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Philip D. Murphy of New Jersey said that the snowstorm that hit the East Coast on Wednesday and into Thursday morning delayed the delivery of coronavirus vaccines to some hospitals by several hours.

headline: Even When the Music Returns, Pandemic Pay Cuts Will Linger
abstract: The coronavirus crisis is leading many performing arts unions to agree to concessions, but some fear it could change the balance of power between labor and management.
lead_paragraph: When the coronavirus outbreak brought performances across the United States to a screeching halt, many of the nation’s leading orchestras, dance companies and opera houses temporarily cut the pay of their workers, and some stopped paying them at all.

headline: Sacklers Face Furious Questions in Rare Testimony on Opioid Epidemic
abstract: It was the first time in years that members of the family that owns Purdue Pharma have taken questions publicly, but they continued to deny personal responsibility for the decades-long addiction crisis.
lead_paragraph: Members of Congress on Thursday hurled withering comments and furious questions at two members of the billionaire Sackler family that owns Purdue Pharma, the maker of OxyContin, seeking to use a rare public appearance to extract admissions of personal responsibility for the deadly opioid epidemic as well as details about $10 billion that records show the family withdrew from the company.

headline: No, There Are No Microchips in Coronavirus Vaccines
abstract: Pfizer’s vaccine has 10 ingredients. None can track your location.
lead_paragraph: Pfizer’s vaccine has 10 ingredients. None can track your location.

headline: The Artists Who Redesigned a War-Shattered Europe
abstract: The Museum of Modern Art debuts a transformative acquisition of Soviet, Polish, German and Dutch graphic arts from after World War I.
lead_paragraph: Hostile times don’t automatically engender great art. Let’s put to rest that chestnut, which resurfaced during and after the 2016 election — and which, as the presidency of Donald J. Trump draws to a close, is looking pretty deflated. A crisis can inspire your vision, but just as easily it can wash you out. And rising to the challenges of an anxious age takes ambition, stamina and not a little bravery.

headline: ‘No One Should Get Fired on a Whim’: Fast Food Workers Win More Job Security
abstract: The New York City Council passed a bill that would shield workers from being fired without a valid reason. Fast food restaurants say the new rules will make it harder to hire and keep the best workers.
lead_paragraph: Gavin Florence was returning to New York City from vacation last fall when his flight got delayed. He said he called his manager at a Chipotle in Manhattan to say he was going to miss his shift. A co-worker covered for him. The next day, Mr. Florence said he was fired.

headline: Ex-Modeling Agent and Epstein Associate Is Arrested in France
abstract: Jean-Luc Brunel was arrested at an airport near Paris by French authorities investigating possible sex crimes committed by Jeffrey Epstein and his associates.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A former modeling agent and associate of the financier Jeffrey Epstein was arrested at an airport near Paris this week as part of an investigation into allegations of rape and sexual assault, including against minors, French prosecutors said on Thursday.

headline: Will a Looted Pissarro End Up in Oklahoma, or France?
abstract: A painting by the French Impressionist artist, with a back story of plunder and family tragedy, is at the center of courtroom battles on both sides of the Atlantic.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — For more than 70 years, Léone Meyer’s family has fought to reclaim a looted painting, and yet she cannot bear the thought of displaying it in her Left Bank home, across from the River Seine.

headline: Henrik Lundqvist Will Not Play Next Season Because of a Heart Condition
abstract: Two months after signing with the Washington Capitals, the former Rangers goaltender said he made the decision after “many weeks of tests and conversations with specialists around the country.”
lead_paragraph: Two months after signing with the Washington Capitals, Henrik Lundqvist said on Thursday that he would not be able to play in the coming season because of a heart condition.

headline: ‘It’s Beautiful’: New York Gets Its Biggest Snowfall in Years
abstract: New York received its heaviest snowfall in years after a storm pummeled the Northeast on Wednesday and Thursday. The National Weather Service recorded 10 inches of precipitation in Central Park. Upstate, Binghamton got 41.
lead_paragraph: New York received its heaviest snowfall in years after a storm pummeled the Northeast on Wednesday and Thursday. The National Weather Service recorded 10 inches of precipitation in Central Park. Upstate, Binghamton got 41.

headline: Show Us a Positive Moment From 2020
abstract: We want to see the good moments you captured in photos and video during this challenging year, and hear what they mean to you now.
lead_paragraph: There is no way of getting around it: 2020 has been a challenging, and for many, a terrible year.

headline: Spanish Lawmakers Pass Bill Allowing Euthanasia and Assisted Suicide
abstract: The draft law goes to the Senate, where it is likely to pass. The country would join a handful of others allowing terminally ill patients to obtain aid to end their lives.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Spanish lawmakers on Thursday voted in favor of a law decriminalizing euthanasia and physician-assisted suicide, making it likely that Spain will  join a handful of other countries where terminally ill patients can legally obtain help to end their lives.

headline: Will Ghost Sharks Vanish Before Scientists Can Study Them?
abstract: Much remains to be learned about the cartilaginous, little understood fishes that inhabit the deep-sea.
lead_paragraph: Take one look at a ghost shark and you may say, “What’s up with that weird-looking fish?”

headline: F.D.A. Panel Endorses Moderna’s Covid-19 Vaccine
abstract: An advisory group’s recommendation will mean millions more Americans can be inoculated, extending protection against Covid beyond major urban areas into rural and suburban regions.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus vaccine made by Moderna moved closer to authorization on Thursday, a significant step that would expand the reach of the nation’s vaccination campaign to rural areas and many more hospitals.

headline: Chicago Mayor Apologizes to Social Worker Who Was Handcuffed Naked
abstract: Police body-camera footage of a 2019 raid on Anjanette Young’s apartment shows her screaming and crying as she tells the officers that they had the wrong person.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Lori Lightfoot of Chicago has apologized to a social worker who was handcuffed while she was naked after police officers who were executing a search warrant burst into her apartment with a battering ram last year.

headline: Sweden’s King: ‘We Have Failed’ Coronavirus Response
abstract: King Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden said the nation’s coronavirus response, which has been much more relaxed than other European countries, was a failure because more lives weren’t saved during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: King Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden said the nation’s coronavirus response, which has been much more relaxed than other European countries, was a failure because more lives weren’t saved during the pandemic.

headline: States Complain of Smaller Vaccine Shipments Than Expected
abstract: The smaller number of expected doses, which appeared to be the result of a scheduling hiccup, reignited tensions between the federal government and Pfizer over vaccine supply.
lead_paragraph: Officials in several states said that they were caught off guard on Wednesday when they learned that next week’s shipment of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine would contain fewer doses than the first week.

headline: In Georgia, a Rare Campaign Where People’s Eyes Aren’t Glued to the Polls
abstract: Two consequential Senate races are taking place with very few public opinion surveys to help understand how voters feel.
lead_paragraph: Polls missed the mark across the country in November — just as they had four years earlier. So far, pollsters haven’t determined with any finality what caused the failures. And in Georgia, where two Senate runoff elections are set for Jan. 5, there’s no time to figure it out.

headline: The Year in Improvised Music: ‘Everything’s Changing. So the Music Should.’
abstract: The pandemic compressed live music onto screens, and Black Lives Matter protests brought it back to the streets. What will it all look like, and sound like, in 2021?
lead_paragraph: When concerts and in-person gatherings shut down this spring, livestreamed shows quickly started to feel like a glorified last resort. I found myself avoiding them. But a Facebook video caught my eye one day in June, of the trombonist Craig Harris performing at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.
