Accompanied by the keyboardist Pete Drungle, framed by a flowering grove and a trellis, he played “Breathe,” a suite of concise and soothing music that sounds like the sum of Mr. Harris’s experiences on the New York scene since the 1970s.

headline: Congress May Finally Give Americans More Money
abstract: But is it enough?
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.

headline: One of Biden’s closest advisers, Cedric Richmond, tests positive for the virus.
abstract: Representative Cedric L. Richmond, Democrat of Louisiana and one of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s closest advisers, has tested positive for the coronavirus and has started a 14-day quarantine, a spokeswoman for the transition said Thursday evening.
lead_paragraph: Representative Cedric L. Richmond, Democrat of Louisiana and one of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s closest advisers, has tested positive for the coronavirus and has started a 14-day quarantine, a spokeswoman for the transition said Thursday evening.

headline: Stimulus Deal, Snowstorm, Moderna: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Supreme Court Rejects Religious School’s Challenge to Kentucky Virus Order
abstract: The governor had ordered all of the state’s K-12 schools, whether public or private, to close temporarily to combat the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Thursday refused to exempt religious schools in Kentucky from an order from Gov. Andy Beshear that temporarily shut down all elementary, middle and high schools, whether public or private, in an effort to combat the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Unemployment Claims Show Impact of Layoffs as Virus Surges
abstract: “It’s going to be a challenging few months,” one economist says. A new pandemic relief bill from Congress could soften the blow.
lead_paragraph: The surge in coronavirus cases is rippling through the economy, forcing employers to lay off workers at an extraordinarily high rate even as new vaccines and the possibility of more federal aid offer hope for next year.

headline: Biden Faces Challenge as Congress Drops State Aid to Secure Stimulus
abstract: A campaign by conservative activists and disputes over how to divvy up federal assistance have thwarted negotiators. But President-elect Joe Biden will make a new push for such funding next year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As lawmakers race to put the final touches on a $900 billion bipartisan stimulus package, one thing is becoming clear: Congress has left a significant challenge for the incoming president, Joseph R. Biden Jr., and his efforts to revive the faltering economy.

headline: Closing In on Stimulus Deal, Lawmakers Clash Over Fed’s Role
abstract: Democrats worked to include more emergency aid to states while Republicans moved to prevent the Federal Reserve from restarting loan programs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As lawmakers pushed to finalize a roughly $900 billion stimulus deal, congressional leaders remained divided on Thursday over a handful of issues whose outcome could help determine the course of a sputtering economic recovery.

headline: The W.T.O. Is Having a Midlife Crisis
abstract: Fixing the global trading system means first coming to grips with why it is broken.
lead_paragraph: If the World Trade Organization were a person, it would be that dude at the bar drinking the afternoon away in his business suit and wondering where it all went wrong. He used to be a big shot.

headline: Pence Will Be Vaccinated on Live TV, Adding to Administration’s Mixed Virus Message
abstract: Public health officials say it is President Trump who most needs to show his support for the vaccine.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At 8 a.m. on Friday, Vice President Mike Pence will roll up his sleeve to receive the coronavirus vaccine, a televised symbol of reassurance for vaccine skeptics worried about its dangers. President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. is scheduled to receive his injection on camera next week.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: President Emmanuel Macron of France has become the latest world leader to contract Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: They may have access to near unlimited testing and a glut of resources, but we’ve learned time and again this year that the world’s top officials are still vulnerable.

headline: Mark Shields and the Best of American Liberalism
abstract: The man who loves politics.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday evening for the last 19 years, Mark Shields and I have gathered to talk politics on the “PBS NewsHour.” When people come up to me to discuss our segment, sometimes they mention the things we said to each other, but more often they mention how we clearly feel about each other — the affection, friendship and respect. We’ve had thousands of disagreements over the years, but never a second of acrimony. Mark radiates a generosity of spirit that improves all who come within his light.

headline: Return of the Phony Deficit Hawks
abstract: Suddenly, Republicans are pretending to care about debt.
lead_paragraph: It looks as if Congress will soon pass a much-needed economic relief (not stimulus) bill — something that will help distressed Americans get through the next few months, while we wait for widespread vaccination to set the stage for economic recovery. That’s good news, because something is better than nothing, even though what we know about the legislation says that it’s going to be deeply flawed.

headline: Drug-Dealing Network Alleged at Duke, U.N.C. Chapel Hill and Appalachian State
abstract: Prosecutors said current or former students were part of an operation that funneled thousands of pounds of marijuana, hundreds of kilograms of cocaine and other drugs to fraternities and colleges campuses.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-one people, including current and former students at Duke University, the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and Appalachian State University, have been charged with dealing thousands of pounds of marijuana, hundreds of kilograms of cocaine and other drugs on campus and in fraternity houses, federal prosecutors said on Thursday.

headline: Moderna Coronavirus Vaccine Moves Closer to Authorization
abstract: A panel of experts recommended on Thursday that the Food and Drug Administration approve an emergency use authorization for the Moderna vaccine, which would make it easier to expand the country’s vaccination campaign to rural areas and smaller clinics.
lead_paragraph: A panel of experts recommended on Thursday that the Food and Drug Administration approve an emergency use authorization for the Moderna vaccine, which would make it easier to expand the country’s vaccination campaign to rural areas and smaller clinics.

headline: See What Happens When N.Y.C. Streets Are Full of People Instead of Cars
abstract: As the pandemic lockdown cleared the roads and as governments instituted popular programs to keep restaurants and small businesses alive, communities have gotten a glimpse at what the city is like when the streets are reimagined. New Yorkers don’t want to look back.
lead_paragraph: As the pandemic lockdown cleared the roads and as governments instituted popular programs to keep restaurants and small businesses alive, communities have gotten a glimpse at what the city is like when the streets are reimagined. New Yorkers don’t want to look back.

headline: Biden addresses accusations against his son, saying, ‘I think it’s kind of foul play.’
abstract: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Thursday defended his son, Hunter Biden, who is under federal investigation for tax fraud, saying that accusations of wrongdoing against him were “kind of foul play.”
lead_paragraph: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Thursday defended his son, Hunter Biden, who is under federal investigation for tax fraud, saying that accusations of wrongdoing against him were “kind of foul play.”

headline: At Least 240,000 Chickens Are Killed in Fire at Florida Egg Farm
abstract: The financial loss from the fire, which destroyed two barns owned by Cal-Maine Foods in Dade City, Fla., was estimated at $1 million, officials said.
lead_paragraph: At least 240,000 chickens were killed early Thursday when a fire swept through two densely packed barns in Florida owned by one of the nation’s largest distributors of eggs, the authorities said.

headline: Line Outside the Entrance
abstract: Damon Gulczynski delivers a delicious puzzle.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — If we were to compare solving a crossword puzzle to dining — because that’s my main point of reference anyway — this puzzle by Damon Gulczynski would be a whole meal. It covers just about every food group, metaphorically speaking, it is intensely flavorful and it is interesting to the palate. You might need to floss afterward, but it will be totally worth it.

headline: Sacklers Deny Personal Responsibility for Opioid Epidemic
abstract: Members of Congress on Thursday heard testimony from two members of the billionaire Sackler family that owns Purdue Pharma, the maker of OxyContin. Both insisted that while they regretted the role the drug had played in the opioid epidemic, they did not bear personal responsibility.
lead_paragraph: Members of Congress on Thursday heard testimony from two members of the billionaire Sackler family that owns Purdue Pharma, the maker of OxyContin. Both insisted that while they regretted the role the drug had played in the opioid epidemic, they did not bear personal responsibility.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: European leaders self-quarantine after meeting with Macron.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Jeremy Bulloch, 75, Dies; Played Boba Fett in ‘Star Wars’ Movies
abstract: Mr. Bulloch said he based his performance as the menacing bounty hunter in part on Clint Eastwood’s performance as a laconic gunslinger.
lead_paragraph: Jeremy Bulloch, the British actor who helped to make Boba Fett, the menacing bounty hunter with the dented helmet and T-shaped visor, one of the most popular characters in the “Star Wars” firmament, died on Thursday in London. He was 75.

headline: International students in Australia prepare to spend the holidays away from family
abstract: It’s been a rough year surviving the pandemic away from home.
lead_paragraph: Around this time in a normal year, Decheng Sun would be preparing to fly to China to see his parents after wrapping up another semester at the University of Sydney. He would celebrate the Lunar New Year there, cooking up a huge festive meal with his family and watching fireworks with his relatives before returning to Australia to continue his studies.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Time of Acrimony and Accusations, and It Isn’t Over
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, December 18, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “I look forward to 2020 ending sometime in 2025.”

headline: Corrections: Dec. 18, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Dec. 18, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about the East Coast snowstorm misstated the surname of a boy enjoying his first major snowstorm in Philadelphia. He is Lucas Coyle, not Lucas Whiffen.

headline: Auditioning for the Role of Boyfriend
abstract: When you have been strung along and ghosted by guys who play it cool, how do you handle a man who is adoring and sincere?
lead_paragraph: It was nearly midnight by the time I reached Erica’s backyard party, after going to a concert in Prospect Park and taking a long subway ride to Williamsburg. Honestly, I was proud that I had managed to drag myself out at all.

headline: Man Who Killed Two in Racial Attack at Kroger Gets Life
abstract: Gregory Bush, who is white, who shot two Black people at a supermarket in Jeffersontown, Ky., in 2018.
lead_paragraph: A white man who fatally shot two Black people at a Kroger supermarket in Jeffersontown, Ky., in 2018 in a racially motivated attack was sentenced this week to life in prison without the possibility of parole.

headline: The Best Book Covers of 2020
abstract: The Book Review’s art director offers his annual laurels to the covers that distinguished themselves in his eyes.
lead_paragraph: Amid a pandemic, my expectations of a book cover became simpler. It either needed to signal the book’s intent to explore mortality, which we spend our lives struggling to make peace with, or it had to take the opposite route and remind a prospective reader — loudly, if possible — that the possibilities of curiosity, wonder, exploration, beauty, art and life still mattered in a year roundly dominated by hand sanitizing while doomscrolling.

headline: Late Night Compares Trump Health Adviser, Paul Alexander, to a Comic Book Villain
abstract: The former Health and Human Services adviser’s leaked emails encouraged herd immunity to deal with the pandemic, writing of Americans, “We want them infected.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Word + Quiz: windfall
abstract: This word has appeared in 155 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: Benny Napoleon, Michigan Sheriff and Ex-Detroit Police Chief, Dies at 65
abstract: Sheriff Napoleon served for more than a decade in the Michigan county that includes Detroit, and ran unsuccessfully for the city’s mayor.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Best Animal Feeds?
abstract: Have you been watching any live feeds of animals during quarantine? Which are your favorites, and why?
lead_paragraph: A new study has found that watching footage of cute animals can reduce your anxiety, blood pressure and heart rate, and we could all use that right now.

headline: News Quiz: Vaccinations, Russian Hackers, Pete Buttigieg
abstract: Did you follow the headlines this week?
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the headlines this week?

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘Australia Gears Up for the Great Koala Count, Using Drones, Droppings and Dogs’
abstract: In this lesson, students will learn about an upcoming effort to accurately count the koala population in Australia. Then, they will participate in a species count of their own.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “Australia Gears Up for the Great Koala Count, Using Drones, Droppings and Dogs” by Yan Zhuang

headline: ‘A Social Species’: How Kangaroos Communicate With People
abstract: Researchers say that kangaroos are the first wild animals to exhibit interspecies communication that is more commonly seen in animals that have evolved alongside humans.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — When they’re hungry, they’ll let you know by coming up to you and looking beseechingly at you and the container of food.

headline: Reopening a New York City School: ‘It’s Been a Tough Start’
abstract: This fall New York City’s public schools faced perhaps their biggest challenge in memory: Could they resume in person safely? And for how long? We filmed in one school for 33 days to chronicle every step of the reopening.
lead_paragraph: This fall New York City’s public schools faced perhaps their biggest challenge in memory: Could they resume in person safely? And for how long? We filmed in one school for 33 days to chronicle every step of the reopening.

headline: Inside One N.Y.C. School That Reopened During the Pandemic
abstract: Should schools be open in the United States while the pandemic is still raging? Elected officials, educators, unions, public health experts, parents and students have been debating this for months.
lead_paragraph: Should schools be open in the United States while the pandemic is still raging? Elected officials, educators, unions, public health experts, parents and students have been debating this for months.

headline: Evictions return, and a sheriff in Massachusetts hunts for a humane approach.
abstract: With a federal moratorium set to lapse on Dec. 31, America’s vast eviction machine is gradually coming back online, allowing landlords to get rid of nonpaying tenants.
lead_paragraph: With a federal moratorium set to lapse on Dec. 31, America’s vast eviction machine is gradually coming back online, allowing landlords to get rid of nonpaying tenants.

headline: California counts the dead by the hour as its I.C.U.s fill up.
abstract: Just two weeks ago, Gov. Gavin Newsom warned Californians that the state’s intensive care beds might be full before Christmas.
lead_paragraph: Just two weeks ago, Gov. Gavin Newsom warned Californians that the state’s intensive care beds might be full before Christmas.

headline: Masks may soon come with labels saying how well they work.
abstract: They come in an astonishing variety of colors, designs and materials, but what the 100,000-plus face masks that have hit the market don’t come with is a label that says how well they block infectious particles.
lead_paragraph: They come in an astonishing variety of colors, designs and materials, but what the 100,000-plus face masks that have hit the market don’t come with is a label that says how well they block infectious particles.

headline: Chinese Journalist Who Documented Communist History Is Detained in Beijing
abstract: Friends of Du Bin said that his detention might have been related to book projects critical of the history of Communism and China’s Communist Party.
lead_paragraph: As China intensified its clampdown on independent reporting, the authorities detained a journalist who recently worked on books that were critical of Communism and the Chinese Communist Party, the journalist’s friends and family said on Friday.

headline: Dancing to ‘Yellow Submarine,’ Neanderthal Extinction and Other Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers respond to recent issues of the Sunday Book Review.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Weekly Health Quiz: Covid Vaccines, Winter Sports and a Cancer Breakthrough
abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: The Coronavirus Has Found a Safe Harbor
abstract: We broke our addiction to locking people up. But it didn’t last.
lead_paragraph: We broke our addiction to locking people up. But it didn’t last.

headline: New in Paperback: ‘The Dutch House’ and ‘The Nation City’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: THE DUTCH HOUSE, by Ann Patchett. (Harper Perennial, 352 pp., $17.) This modern-day brother-and-sister fairy tale, which was a finalist for the 2020 Pulitzer Prize, “takes a winding road through the forest and doesn’t rush to a finish,” Martha Southgate, our reviewer, wrote. “But if you allow yourself to walk along with Patchett, you’ll find riches at the end of the trail. And you won’t end up shoved into an oven.”

headline: Should There Still Be Snow Days?
abstract: The rise of virtual learning this year could mean the end of snow days. Is this a good thing?
lead_paragraph: In response to a large storm that hit the East Coast this week, school districts across the United States continued with virtual instruction instead of canceling classes. The change could become permanent. How do you feel about the possible end of snow days?

headline: How to Move In With Your Parents (and, Eventually, Move Out)
abstract: A few tips for remaining a full adult in your childhood home.
lead_paragraph: The empty nests are starting to feel a bit full.

headline: ‘The 46th’: Will Georgia’s Races Change the Senate?
abstract: Jamelle Bouie joins Michelle and Ross to predict the results of the runoff elections.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to “The Argument” from your mobile device:

headline: Should Ivy League Schools Randomly Select Students (At Least for a Little While)?
abstract: College admissions have favored the well-off for ages, and the pandemic has only made things worse. Now is the time to change the process.
lead_paragraph: From mid-December through the end of March, tens of thousands of high-school seniors around the country will endure the torture of waiting to hear whether they have been accepted to college. The current admissions season is unfolding now amid a pandemic that has only intensified inequities in an education system that has relentlessly favored the well-off and aggressively prepared.

headline: Like a John Prine Song: ‘Just Wanna Be With You’
abstract: Madeline McKeever and Grant Smith, who met on the dating app Bumble, solidified their bond through their love of running and music.
lead_paragraph: Pickup trucks, campers and S.U.V.’s, bench seats and trail races, and their little dog, Marie.

headline: Can We Do Twice as Many Vaccinations as We Thought?
abstract: Data suggests significant protection even without a second shot. If studies prove that’s true, it could be a game changer.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a very good month for Covid-19 vaccines. Last week, the Food and Drug Administration provided an emergency authorization for a vaccine produced by Pfizer-BioNTech. On Thursday, an advisory committee recommended authorizing a vaccine by Moderna, and the F.D.A. is expected to authorize it soon.

headline: How to Reform the Presidency After the Wreckage of Trump
abstract: Our post-Watergate laws and practices for the presidency need revamping.
lead_paragraph: Now that Donald Trump’s time in the White House is ending, an urgent task is the reform of the presidency that for four years he sought to shape in his image and to run in his personal and political self-interest. What those years have shown is that the array of laws and norms that arose after Watergate and Vietnam requires an overhaul.

headline: A Return to California Leads to Romance
abstract: Pearl Losoya and David Velasco grew up in the same California community, but went their separate ways after high school. A decade later they reconnected.
lead_paragraph: Pearl Losoya and David Velasco appeared on each other’s radars as far back as middle school in Union City, Calif., a small city east of San Francisco. Their families were friendly, but in high school they ran in different crowds. She described herself as “bookish” and focused on her studies. Mr. Velasco said he affiliated with “the bad boys.”

headline: Teaching My Kids to Drive While Black
abstract: I’ve raised them to be confident and to advocate for themselves. Now here I was saying, don’t do it with the police.
lead_paragraph: There was lightning, thunder and heavy rain the recent day I accompanied my 18-year-old son and 19-year-old daughter to get their driver’s licenses in Austin, Texas.

headline: Mock Debates as Relationship Prep
abstract: Susan Webster and Blake Murphy met through student government at the University of Florida, where Mr. Murphy was Ms. Webster’s campaign manager during a bid for student body president. (She won.)
lead_paragraph: Some evenings in late 2015 and early 2016, lights would snap on in an empty classroom at the University of Florida. Susan Dorothy Clara Webster and members of her campaign staff would waft in, along with the smell of pizza or sandwiches — brain fuel to consume as they worked to get Ms. Webster elected student body president. The front of the room would be arranged to replicate a debate stage. Ms. Webster would station herself there, alongside her vice president candidate and her treasurer candidate. Then Ms. Webster’s campaign manager, Blake Daniel Murphy, would begin grilling them all.

headline: The 20 Phrases That Defined 2020
abstract: We picked up a whole new vocabulary this year — some of it words that have been around forever.
lead_paragraph: Happy Blursday! Now quit doomscrolling, grab a quarantini and please keep social distancing.

headline: It Took Them a Couple of Years to Become a Pair
abstract: Kelly Connor and Noah Wunsch’s first meeting involved denim and discouragement. They had better luck down the line.
lead_paragraph: The night Noah Wunsch met Kelly Connor there were more pants in the room than people.

headline: Why Some States Are Seeing Higher Revenue Than Expected Amid Job Losses
abstract: As the pandemic batters the poor, the rich prop up state budgets.
lead_paragraph: As Congress has spent the last few weeks debating aid to state and local governments, a number of states have announced surprising news: Their finances no longer look quite as bad as they had feared in the uncertain early days of the pandemic.

headline: College Football Season Is Nearly Over. Then the Big TV Negotiations Begin.
abstract: ESPN and Fox didn’t get about 20 games from the Big Ten Conference this season. Those events were worth roughly $110 million, leaving college sports and TV executives with much to resolve.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Warren, the commissioner of the Big Ten Conference, might exhale slightly on Saturday afternoon in Indianapolis once the final whistle blows and Northwestern or Ohio State is crowned the league’s champion. His conference will have completed a most unusual football season, one where matters like whether it was even safe to play at all became far more urgent than who won or lost.

headline: In 2020, These Things Came Out on Top
abstract: A tough year turned out to be good for rescue animals, rotten bananas and more.
lead_paragraph: We may think of 2020 as a year of seemingly endless bad news as the pandemic threatened our health, forced us to stay at home and upended most facets of life. But it wasn’t all bad. Here’s a look at some of the things that managed to come out on top.

headline: A One-Way Ticket to Chicago
abstract: Sarah Attermann planned to spend only a couple of weeks in Chicago with Scott Topal during the pandemic. She ended up staying.
lead_paragraph: While Sarah Ariel Attermann spent a quiet evening at home on Jan. 18, 2019 sipping white wine on her couch in Washington, she sent Scott Michael Topal, who lived in Chicago, a Facebook message: “From what I’ve heard, you’re a great person to know. Hope you’ll plan a visit to D.C. soon!”

headline: What’s It Like to Cruise in the Covid Era? To Find Out, I Went Aboard
abstract: A “cruise to nowhere” offered one correspondent a chance to understand an interesting trend, and to interview people in person.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: A Power Couple Finds the Spark Once Again
abstract: Laura Stachel and Hal Aronson, who created the Solar Suitcase, had a Jewish wedding ceremony in 2000, but they never had a legal one. Twenty years later, it finally seemed time to be married.
lead_paragraph: When Hal Aronson walked Dr. Laura Stachel back to the hospital after their first meeting in March 1999, neither wanted to say goodbye. They weren’t at all each other’s type, yet their chemistry was instant. They hugged.

headline: The Next 3 Months Are Going to Be Pure Hell
abstract: Lessons from Lewis and Clark on living through the darkest days and longest nights.
lead_paragraph: Every five years or so I try to return to land’s end, the continent’s edge, where the Columbia River empties into the Pacific Ocean — the final heave of the River of the West. I prefer to go during winter solstice, the long night of the soul in the Northern Hemisphere.

headline: They Passed the Ikea Test
abstract: Amy Wong and Michael Jastrzebski are used to building things as mechanical engineers, so a certain furniture store was no match for their skills, or love.
lead_paragraph: Even the most loving couples can struggle to put together a simple Ikea bookshelf without arguments and acrimony. But Amy Lai Wong and Michael Jastrzebski, who were married Nov. 29 at their home in Newark, Calif., bonded over much more complicated projects while working together as the only two mechanical engineers at a technology start-up company in Silicon Valley.

headline: The World Is Full of Challenges. Here’s How Biden Can Meet Them.
abstract: The incoming administration needs to update American policy to meet the challenges of the 21st century.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Joe Biden appears to be framing his foreign policy around three themes: re-engaging with America’s friends and allies, renewing our participation in international organizations and relying more heavily on nonmilitary instruments of power. Considering the challenges posed by China and other countries, as well as transnational threats that range from pandemics to climate change, these are, in my view, the correct priorities. (Though, of course, unparalleled military power must remain the backdrop for America’s relations with the world.)

headline: What Is Death?
abstract: How the pandemic is changing our understanding of mortality.
lead_paragraph: This year has awakened us to the fact that we die. We’ve always known it to be true in a technical sense, but a pandemic demands that we internalize this understanding. It’s one thing to acknowledge the deaths of others, and another to accept our own. It’s not just emotionally taxing; it is difficult even to conceive. To do this means to imagine it, reckon with it and, most important, personalize it. Your life. Your death.

headline: The Classical Concert That Changed Their Lives
abstract: Carrie Sun was a couple of weeks away from moving to Virginia, and then she met Christopher Cerrone at a concert in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Carrie Sun and Christopher Cerrone met on April 20, 2018 in Manhattan after a classical music concert held at St. Peter’s Church. She had just quit her job at a hedge fund and was planning to leave New York. Her movers were coming in 21 days.

headline: Bumps on the Road From Broadway to Hollywood
abstract: Not for decades have so many plays and musicals been turned into movies. But even in the best of the new crop, a lot gets lost in translation.
lead_paragraph: A moment I barely noticed in the 2019 Broadway production of David Byrne’s “American Utopia” jumped out at me with new resonance in Spike Lee’s film of the show for HBO.

headline: Bill That Trump Is Vowing to Veto Strengthens Hacking Defenses, Lawmakers Say
abstract: Additional powers to actively hunt down hackers across federal agencies could have given the government more of a chance to detect the recent Russia hack more quickly, they said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The military spending bill that President Trump is threatening to veto contains provisions that would help protect against the kind of broad Russian hacking discovered in recent days, according to experts and lawmakers.

headline: 5 Takeaways From the First Week of Vaccines in New York
abstract: The mass vaccination program is off to an encouraging, if slow, start.
lead_paragraph: Since its arrival on Monday, the coronavirus vaccine has brought hope to New Yorkers.

headline: For Those Behind Corporate Events, Parties Are on Pause
abstract: As companies cancel their year-end events, the 2020 holiday season has made a terrible year even worse for those in the events business.
lead_paragraph: It has been a devastating year for those in the events business. Todd Fiscus, of Dallas-based Todd Events, said his company made $2.4 million in December 2019 alone from largely corporate holiday gatherings. But this year, his December revenue will drop to just $191,000.

headline: Their Publishing Imprint Closed. Now They’re Bringing It Back.
abstract: In a literary landscape dominated by the biggest players, Cindy Spiegel and Julie Grau are among the executives rejecting the corporate publishing model and instead starting their own companies.
lead_paragraph: Last year, after Penguin Random House shut down the literary imprint Spiegel & Grau, the veteran editors Cindy Spiegel and Julie Grau pondered what to do next.

headline: How a Sous Chef Turned Fried Chicken Master Spends His Sundays
abstract: Eric Huang preps and delivers about 50 meals a day from his uncle’s shuttered restaurant in Queens.
lead_paragraph: In January, Eric Huang left his post as sous chef at Eleven Madison Park with aspirations to open his own restaurant. As the son of Taiwanese immigrants who owned restaurants in Queens and on Long Island, he wanted to present Chinese flavors in a new way, giving them a fine-dining platform. “There was this really entrenched perception of Chinese-American cuisine,” he said.

headline: How May We Serve You? For Restaurant Chains, It Depends on the Location
abstract: Large dine-in chains are finding it difficult to enact uniform approaches to the pandemic when dealing with different regulations across the country about how they can operate.
lead_paragraph: Executives at the Brazilian steakhouse chain Fogo de Chão thought they had seen the worst of it.

headline: From Mod-Chic Chairs to Virus Barriers
abstract: What Plexi-Craft — an upscale furniture factory in the Bronx — has, the city wants: Acrylic resin skills.
lead_paragraph: For almost 60 years, Plexi-Craft Quality Products in the Bronx has been turning out chic, mod-looking coffee tables, chairs and even tissue boxes, made with crystal-clear acrylic resin. But when the coronavirus struck in March, its factory, the city’s last surviving acrylic furniture maker, temporarily closed.

headline: For Opponents of Native American Nicknames, 2020 Has Brought Hope
abstract: Leaders in the movement to rid sports of such nicknames and the logos that accompany them saw a domino effect building in public schools after two major professional teams made changes. But there are staunch holdouts.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Sports department is revisiting the subjects of some compelling articles from the last year or so. Here is our July report on schools’ considering dropping Native American nicknames and mascots.

headline: Punch After Punch, Rape After Rape, a Murderer Was Made
abstract: The execution of Lisa Montgomery would be an injustice on top of an injustice.
lead_paragraph: This article contains descriptions of sexual assault.

headline: Carrier Plant Is Bustling, but Workers Are Wary as Trump Exits
abstract: The president championed an Indiana factory facing a shutdown four years ago. Hundreds of jobs were kept, and overtime abounds. Can the revival last?
lead_paragraph: For the workers fortunate enough to remain employed at Carrier’s Indianapolis factory, which Donald Trump singled out as a symbol of American manufacturing distress in 2016, these should be the best of times. The assembly line is churning out furnaces seven days a week, overtime is abundant, and shares of Carrier are soaring even as Covid-19 ravages the overall economy.

headline: Tips for Hanging Outdoor Holiday Lights
abstract: Make a plan and be safe.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve never decorated the outside of a house before, the prospect of climbing a ladder up onto your roof can seem like a daunting proposition. But with a little strategy and planning, your home could be the shining jewel of the block.

headline: 10 Powerful ‘Daily’ Episodes From 2020
abstract: In a year defined by a pandemic, protests and politics, “The Daily” sought out personal stories. Here’s a holiday playlist of the episodes that Michael Barbaro and our team can’t forget.
lead_paragraph: In moments of crisis, the journalistic urge to chronicle and memorialize becomes a kind of civic duty. That’s what 2020 was for “The Daily.” A rolling catastrophe that summoned us — to track down the most memorable characters, the most searing sounds, the most unforgettable scenes.

headline: In a Tough Year, a Nativity Scene ‘That Has Had Problems’
abstract: The Vatican’s Nativity scene this year has prompted much criticism — and some head-scratching.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — A couple stood in front of the Vatican’s new Christmas Nativity scene in St. Peter’s Square, trying to understand exactly what they were looking at.

headline: Escape From the City: 9 Winter Outings That Fight Cabin Fever
abstract: Snow biking near Seattle, winter bird-watching near New York and seven other cold-weather activities near large U.S. cities.
lead_paragraph: Sledding on the Blue Ridge Parkway in North Carolina; going on a photo safari in Sedona, Ariz.; winter surfing in Ventura, Calif.: There are many ways for outdoor enthusiasts to enjoy the winter, while maintaining plenty of social distancing. Here are some suggestions.

headline: How New York City Vaccinated 6 Million People in Less Than a Month
abstract: When a single case of smallpox arrived in Manhattan in 1947, a severe outbreak was possible. A decisive civil servant made a bold decision.
lead_paragraph: On Easter weekend in 1947, New York City buzzed with an air of invincibility. The miseries of World War II were finally over, and New York, like the rest of the country, was buoyant. The future promised great things. The Polaroid Land camera had just been invented. Consumer TV sets were appearing in living rooms. The transistor radio was in the works.

headline: A Holiday Light Show
abstract: The pandemic has prompted many homeowners to go bigger with their holiday decorations this year.
lead_paragraph: The pandemic has prompted many homeowners to go bigger with their holiday decorations this year.

headline: Holiday Lights Go Big This Year
abstract: In this upended holiday season, Americans are decorating their rooflines and yards with gusto as a way to demand some cheer from a gloomy year.
lead_paragraph: Pandemic-bound homeowners got to work earlier than usual this holiday season, spending much more time and money on outside decorations than in previous years.

headline: The Biggest Snowstorm in Years Blanketed New York
abstract: Some pockets of New York City saw nearly a foot of snow. Upstate, some towns saw more than three feet of snowfall.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Pelosi receives the vaccine, to be followed by other members of Congress and Supreme Court justices.
Sony Removes Cyberpunk 2077 From PlayStation Store After Complaints
abstract: Both Sony and Microsoft, the maker of Xbox, said they would also offer refunds to gamers while the developer of the much-hyped title works to fix bugs and glitches.
lead_paragraph: Sony, the company that owns and operates PlayStation, announced late Thursday that it would offer refunds to people who purchased Cyberpunk 2077 and remove what had been one of the year’s most highly anticipated video games from its online store, after a week of negative reviews and criticism from users over its poor performance.

headline: How to Reset the Relationship Between the U.S. and China
abstract: A group of experts gathered to debate the prospects for cooperation and competition between the world’s most powerful economies.
lead_paragraph: When President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. moves into the White House, he will inherit a relationship with China that is at its lowest point in decades. Among the issues on his to-do list are tariffs, which he has said he plans to maintain when he takes over; how to handle human rights violations in China’s Xinjiang region; and a tech Cold War that has raised questions over data, sovereignty and power.

headline: QAnon is still spreading on Facebook, despite a ban.
abstract: QAnon “superspreaders” have continued to be active on Facebook, even after the company banned the conspiracy movement from its platform two months ago, according to a report released on Friday.
lead_paragraph: QAnon “superspreaders” have continued to be active on Facebook, even after the company banned the conspiracy movement from its platform two months ago, according to a report released on Friday.

headline: Evicted During the Pandemic
abstract: The coronavirus has intensified America’s eviction crisis. We speak to a single mother from Georgia about the struggle to hold on to her home.
lead_paragraph: For years there has been an eviction crisis in the United States. For many low-income families, wages have been stagnant for two decades while rent has doubled and government assistance has remained elusive.

headline: A Riveting ISIS Story, Told in a Times Podcast, Falls Apart
abstract: A Canadian’s gruesome account as an Islamic State executioner in Syria, which was the subject of the “Caliphate” podcast by The New York Times, was fabricated, officials say. A Times review found no corroboration of his claim to have committed atrocities.
lead_paragraph: He described the killings in lurid detail — how he shot one man in the head and stabbed another in the heart before hanging the corpse on a cross.

headline: New York Times Says ‘Caliphate’ Podcast Fell Short of Standards
abstract: The Times cited an institutional failure and determined the “Caliphate” team gave too much credence to the claims of a supposed former terrorist.
lead_paragraph: After an internal review that took more than two months, The New York Times has determined that “Caliphate,” its award-winning 2018 podcast, did not meet the standards for Times journalism.

headline: The Least for Those Who Need It Most
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: Alcorn State University, Santa Fe College and West Kentucky Community and Technical College are all working-class colleges. Most of their students are lower-income, and many are trying to become the first member of their family to earn a college degree.

headline: America’s Leaders Begin to Get Vaccinated
abstract: Pence today, Biden and McConnell soon: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: Vaccines are being distributed in Washington, while Congress haggles over the details of the stimulus deal. It’s Friday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

headline: Catch up: Coinbase files for initial public offering.
Coinbase’s Crypto Conundrum
abstract: The cryptocurrency giant’s initial public offering holds big potential — and significant risks.
lead_paragraph: Cryptocurrency is having a banner week in an already big year. In the past day, the value of Bitcoin set a new high and the digital currency exchange Coinbase, the most valuable American crypto company, announced that it had filed for an I.P.O. with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Pence receives a coronavirus vaccine in a public White House event.
abstract: Vice President Mike Pence received a coronavirus vaccine on live television Friday morning at the White House, a measure that the Trump administration said was intended to “promote the safety and efficacy of the vaccine and build confidence among the American people.”
lead_paragraph: Vice President Mike Pence received a coronavirus vaccine on live television Friday morning at the White House, a measure that the Trump administration said was intended to “promote the safety and efficacy of the vaccine and build confidence among the American people.”

headline: This Man Is Betting $1.7 Billion on the Rights to Your Favorite Songs
abstract: Merck Mercuriadis thinks songwriters deserve more credit — starting with blockbuster paydays for their catalogs. But not all artists want to sell out.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Merck Mercuriadis was sitting in a small office at Abbey Road Studios, pecking away at a vegan breakfast bowl and calmly laying out his plan to dismantle the part of the music business that he loves the most.

headline: ‘Fatale’ Review: Another Attraction of the Fatal Kind
abstract: Hilary Swank plays a police detective who seduces Michael Ealy into a very tangled web.
lead_paragraph: For someone as successful as he is — a sports agent who built his own company from the ground up — Derrick (Michael Ealy) is a tense fellow. He brings his furrowed brow with him on a trip from L.A. to Vegas, taking a break from, among other things, his troubled marriage.

headline: Clueless About 2020, Wall Street Forecasters Are at It Again for 2021
abstract: Despite a horrendous record in forecasting, Wall Street is making bullish predictions for the stock market next year. Ignore them but invest anyway, our columnist says.
lead_paragraph: If you want to know where the stock market will end up one year from now, I’m sorry — I can’t help with that.

headline: Rock Hall of Fame Reveals Plan for Expansion
abstract: The $100 million project would add more programming space and a new band shell and renovate the Rock Hall’s original I.M. Pei building in Cleveland.
lead_paragraph: The Rock & Roll Hall of Fame and Museum in Cleveland on Friday released designs for a $100 million renovation and expansion, which would grow the museum’s footprint by a third with a dramatic addition to the original I.M. Pei building.

headline: A Worrisome Drop in College Aid Applications
abstract: The pandemic has already led to one “lost class” of freshmen. The low rate of completing the financial aid form may signal another.
lead_paragraph: Fewer high school students are completing an important step in the college financial aid process, raising concerns about another “lost class” of college freshmen in the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Stuck at Home, People Are Splurging on Wine and Spirits
abstract: Sales of wine, beer and spirits are up across the board, but “consumers are trading up and spending more,” one analyst said.
lead_paragraph: The pandemic has been a boon to retail alcohol sales of all kinds. Beer sales are up, as are those of wine and vodka. Even the lowly vermouth — the anonymous mixer that blends with the name-brand spirits in martinis and Manhattans — has seen a spike in business as consumers substitute drinking at home for visits to local bars or restaurants.

headline: Mariah! Dolly! Carrie! 2020 Can’t Quarantine This Cheer
abstract: Pop stars try to pull off a Christmas spectacular in tough times, with three sparkly but heartfelt specials now on streaming services.
lead_paragraph: With the C.D.C. advising against faithful friends who are dear to us gathering anywhere near to us, it’s understandable that we all might need some extra assistance getting into the holiday spirit this year. One of the few bright spots of the season, though, is the abundance of new Christmastime musical specials, helmed by some of our most beloved and benevolent divas. Thank the streaming wars, in part: HBO Max, Apple TV+ and CBS All Access have all jockeyed to get a different A-list angel atop their trees, perhaps in hopes that they’ll persuade you to subscribe to one of their services before your long winter hibernation (or at least forget to cancel before your free trial is over.) Whether gaudy, glorious excess or down-home simplicity, each offers a different take on a perplexing question: How do you stage a Christmas spectacular in decidedly unspectacular times?

headline: Zoom Cocktails 2.0: The Holiday Edition
abstract: The virtual happy hour was novel nine months ago, and now it’s back to get us through the holidays. But can we overcome the limits of a virtual social life?
lead_paragraph: The Zoom cocktail party is back, so throw that shimmery blouse over your sweatpants, pour a glass of spiked eggnog and find a spot with reasonable lighting, because you’re about to spend the holidays with your friends and family on mute.

headline: What It Was Like to Participate in a Covid-19 Vaccine Trial
abstract: Friday: We spoke with one Los Angeles nurse about why she volunteered for the Pfizer-BioNTech clinical trial.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Lost and Found: A Missing Camus Biography and a Christmas Miracle
abstract: Geoff Dyer remembers the book that came back.
lead_paragraph: I had been away from my study in London for six months, but as soon as I got back last December, I sensed that something was wrong. Everything was as I had left it: filing cabinet, desk, lights, reclining chair for reading and napping. The floor-to-ceiling shelves, covering almost every inch of available wall, were stuffed with books, arranged in an order that makes sense only to me. There were some new books to cram into already tightly packed shelves. Old hardbacks were reunited with the dust jackets that had been left behind as placeholders. There were quotes to check, and it was a pleasure, as always, to look these up — but some lingering, unspecified unease remained.

headline: New York City Will Change Many Selective Schools to Address Segregation
abstract: The pandemic prompted the mayor’s most significant action yet on integration: a major shift in how hundreds of schools admit students.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio announced on Friday major changes to the way hundreds of New York City’s selective middle and high schools admit their students, a move intended to address long-simmering concerns that admissions policies have discriminated against Black and Latino students and exacerbated segregation in the country’s largest school district.

headline: An Unprepared N.Y.P.D. Badly Mishandled Floyd Protests, Watchdog Says
abstract: “I look back with remorse,” Mayor Bill de Blasio said after a city oversight agency found the department’s tactics “produced excessive enforcement.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Police Department badly mishandled protests against police brutality over the summer, engaging in “excessive enforcement” that only heightened tensions with demonstrators, according to a report from a city oversight agency released on Friday.

headline: An Examination of ‘Caliphate’
abstract: Dean Baquet, the executive editor of The Times, discusses where “Caliphate” failed to meet Times standards. And Mark Mazzetti, an investigative correspondent for The Times, details new reporting that casts significant doubt on the claims of a central figure in the series.
lead_paragraph: Editors’ Note [Dec. 18, 2020]: In 2018, The Times released a 12-part narrative podcast series called “Caliphate” on the Islamic State terrorist group and its operations. While parts of the series involved a broad examination of the group’s tactics and influence, multiple episodes were driven primarily by the confessional tale of a Canadian man of Pakistani origin who called himself Abu Huzayfah and claimed to have been a member of the Islamic State who had taken part in killings in Syria.During the course of reporting for the series, The Times discovered significant falsehoods and other discrepancies in Huzayfah’s story. The Times took a number of steps, including seeking confirmation of details from intelligence officials in the United States, to find independent evidence of Huzayfah’s story. The decision was made to proceed with the project but to include an episode, Chapter 6, devoted to exploring major discrepancies and highlighting the fact-checking process that sought to verify key elements of the narrative. In September — two and a half years after the podcast was released — the Canadian police arrested Huzayfah, whose real name is Shehroze Chaudhry, and charged him with perpetrating a terrorist hoax. Canadian officials say they believe that Mr. Chaudhry’s account of supposed terrorist activity is completely fabricated. The hoax charge led The Times to investigate what Canadian officials had discovered, and to re-examine Mr. Chaudhry’s account and the earlier efforts to determine its validity. This new examination found a history of misrepresentations by Mr. Chaudhry and no corroboration that he committed the atrocities he described in the “Caliphate” podcast.As a result, The Times has concluded that the episodes of “Caliphate” that presented Mr. Chaudhry’s claims did not meet our standards for accuracy.From the outset, “Caliphate” should have had the regular participation of an editor experienced in the subject matter. In addition, The Times should have pressed harder to verify Mr. Chaudhry’s claims before deciding to place so much emphasis on one individual’s account. For example, reporters and editors could have vetted more thoroughly materials Mr. Chaudhry provided for evidence that he had traveled to Syria to join the Islamic State, and pushed harder and earlier to determine what the authorities knew about him. It is also clear that elements of the original fact-checking process were not sufficiently rigorous: Times journalists were too credulous about the verification steps that were undertaken and dismissive of the lack of corroboration of essential aspects of Mr. Chaudhry’s account. In the absence of firmer evidence, “Caliphate” should have been substantially revised to exclude the material related to Mr. Chaudhry. The podcast as a whole should not have been produced with Mr. Chaudhry as a central narrative character.A fuller description of what The Times has learned about Mr. Chaudhry was published on Dec. 18, 2020.

headline: Swapping Songs With Chess Grandmaster Garry Kasparov
abstract: Music brought a critic and a guest together, in a conversation about Bach, Beethoven, chess and politics.
lead_paragraph: Music, we all know, can bring people together. To stimulate a conversation between a music critic and a guest — in this case, the Russian chess grandmaster Garry Kasparov — about listening and life, there was one ground rule: Each participant suggests a single piece for the other to listen to ahead of the chat.

headline: Bill Ford: ‘Our Family Name Is on the Line Every Day’
abstract: The chairman of Ford Motor and the great-grandson of Henry Ford is an elder statesman in an industry where C.E.O.s come and go.
lead_paragraph: With the coronavirus rapidly disrupting American life in mid-March and organized labor pressuring carmakers to ensure worker safety, Bill Ford reached out to the competition.

headline: With ‘Bridgerton,’ Scandal Comes to Regency England
abstract: For her first Netflix series, Shonda Rhimes and her team infuse period-drama escapism with modern-day sensibilities.
lead_paragraph: Shonda Rhimes generally doesn’t pay much attention to the breathless fan chatter around her television shows. (It’s because she’s too busy, she said, not because she doesn’t care.)

headline: Is There Such a Thing as a Humane Eviction?
abstract: As a bulge of evictions looms, a Massachusetts sheriff is searching for ways to soften the blow.
lead_paragraph: CHICOPEE, Mass. — The tenants in the third-floor apartment had 30 minutes to leave.

headline: U.K. Lawmaker Under Fire for Calling UNICEF’s Free Meals a ‘Political Stunt’
abstract: Jacob Rees-Mogg said the agency should be ashamed of itself for providing free meals to 15,000 children in Britain, prompting a backlash.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Jacob Rees-Mogg, a Conservative British lawmaker who serves as leader of the House of Commons, has provoked anger by criticizing a UNICEF program that is set to provide free meals to children in Britain for the first time in the organization’s 74-year history.

headline: What Qualifies as Success?
abstract: Borussia Dortmund’s business is winning matches and grooming some of the world’s best young talent. To do both, sometimes you have to put up with a few growing pains.
lead_paragraph: Even after Lucien Favre turned 60, he could still do things with a ball that left even some of European soccer’s brightest talents just a little awe-struck.

headline: Tiger Woods, Playing Partner and Parent
abstract: Watching Woods and his son, Charlie, on the golf course offers a rare window into a side of Woods fans never see: dad.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — The kid, like others of his generation, had never seen Tiger Woods win a major. He had no clue how cool golf could be.

headline: Christmas Is Coming. Cue the Guilt Trips and Tears.
abstract: Thanksgiving gatherings were upended by the pandemic. With Christmas upon us, families are having another round of fraught conversations about in-person celebrations.
lead_paragraph: They are fraught conversations, some ending with a forlorn “that’s OK” or a vague promise to gather in the new year. Others conclude in frustration, or even in tears.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Revel in NYT Cooking’s end-of-year lists, with recipes for the days ahead.
lead_paragraph: Everything’s lists for me, these days. Lists of gifts to buy, yes, and lists of tasks to complete around the house, lists of ingredients I need for the tiny Christmas feast I’m planning, but also work lists: our most popular recipes of the year, along with our most popular desserts; our most popular vegetarian recipes and on down the line.

headline: They Died in the French and Indian War. Their Remains Await Reburial.
abstract: The bones of British soldiers and colonial militia were disinterred during a reconstruction of Fort William Henry nearly 70 years ago.
lead_paragraph: At points over the past decade, disinterred human remains — the full skeletons and fragmentary bones of British soldiers and colonial militia who died during the French and Indian War — have been a cause of some concern in the environs of Lake George, N.Y.

headline: Justices Put Off Ruling on Trump Plan for Unauthorized Immigrants and Census
abstract: The Supreme Court said a challenge to efforts to exclude unauthorized immigrants from the tabulations used to allocate House seats was premature.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday dismissed a lawsuit challenging the Trump administration’s plan to exclude unauthorized immigrants from the calculations used to allocate seats in the House, saying it was premature.

headline: ‘Ma Rainey’s Black Bottom’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: George C. Wolfe narrates a sequence from his film featuring Viola Davis and Chadwick Boseman.
lead_paragraph: George C. Wolfe narrates a sequence from his film featuring Viola Davis and Chadwick Boseman.

headline: Watch Chadwick Boseman in a Scene From ‘Ma Rainey’s Black Bottom’
abstract: The director George C. Wolfe discusses a tense sequence featuring the actor and Viola Davis.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: A Chicken Dish That Makes It Feel Like Christmas
abstract: When Nik Sharma left Mumbai for Ohio years ago, he had to leave his family’s holiday celebration behind too. Now he recreates one of his favorite dishes, chicken cafreal, in his own kitchen.
lead_paragraph: In the days leading up to my first Christmas in America, I felt a bit lost and alone. It was 2002, and earlier that summer, I’d packed my belongings in Mumbai and flown across the world to attend graduate school in Ohio. This would be the first time I’d spend the holiday away from my family. I was now more than 8,000 miles away from home.

headline: A Raw Meat Sandwich Warning Draws Eyes on Wisconsin (and More Warnings)
abstract: Health experts urged people not to eat raw meat, in any dish, after a warning about a holiday tradition by Wisconsin’s health department intrigued and confused some outside the Midwest.
lead_paragraph: Please don’t eat the raw meat sandwich.

headline: Ralph K. Winter Jr., a Top Conservative Judicial Mind, Dies at 85
abstract: As a scholar and a federal appellate judge, he changed the shape of laws on campaign finance and corporate governance.
lead_paragraph: Ralph K. Winter Jr., a conservative legal scholar whose work as a professor at Yale Law School and later as an appellate court judge changed the shape of campaign finance law and corporate governance, died on Dec. 8 in Guilford, Conn. He was 85.

headline: More Mammals Are Hiding Their Secret Glow
abstract: First it was platypuses. Now we may be dealing with glowing Tasmanian devils, echidnas and wombats.
lead_paragraph: Were platypuses just the beginning?

headline: A Record-Breaking Week for the Virus, by the Numbers
abstract: The state of the virus this week
lead_paragraph: The state of the virus this week

headline: Covax, an international health group, announces vaccine deals to help less wealthy countries.
abstract: Leaders of an international body established to promote global access to coronavirus vaccines, known as Covax, announced on Friday that the effort had reached additional deals with manufacturers that would allow it to access nearly two billion doses of candidate vaccines, more than half of them intended to be delivered to low- and middle-income countries.
lead_paragraph: Leaders of an international body established to promote global access to coronavirus vaccines, known as Covax, announced on Friday that the effort had reached additional deals with manufacturers that would allow it to access nearly two billion doses of candidate vaccines, more than half of them intended to be delivered to low- and middle-income countries.

headline: This Solstice, Solace for the Darkness
abstract: A rare conjunction of planets serves as a reminder that there is more to the universe than just ourselves.
lead_paragraph: We have now arrived at the longest, darkest night of the longest, darkest year. And yet rarely have the heavens so proclaimed their glory.

headline: Captain America: 80 Years in 8 Stories
abstract: Captain America, who was created in response to World War II, turns 80 on Dec. 20. Check out how he’s changed with the times.
lead_paragraph: Captain America, who was created in response to World War II, turns 80 on Dec. 20. Check out how he’s changed with the times.

headline: Berlin Film Festival Is Delayed. Will Cannes and Venice Follow?
abstract: The postponement of the first major international movie event of 2021 raises the specter of another difficult year for the industry.
lead_paragraph: The Berlin Film Festival, which was scheduled to start Feb. 11, has been postponed because of the coronavirus, its organizers said on Friday in a news release, making it the first — but probably not the last — major cultural event of 2021 to be affected by the pandemic.

headline: Emmanuel Macron says Covid-19 symptoms have slowed him down and warns the French to remain vigilant.
abstract: President Emmanuel Macron of France said on Friday that he felt mostly fine but was working more slowly after being infected with the coronavirus, as he pleaded with the French to remain vigilant and warned that “no one is sheltered from this virus.”
lead_paragraph: President Emmanuel Macron of France said on Friday that he felt mostly fine but was working more slowly after being infected with the coronavirus, as he pleaded with the French to remain vigilant and warned that “no one is sheltered from this virus.”

headline: Tariffs, Traffic and Red Tape: What a ‘No-Deal’ Brexit Could Mean for Britain
abstract: If British and E.U. negotiators fail to reach a trade deal before a Dec. 31 deadline, disruptions at ports and on roads could ensue, and goods are likely to get more expensive because of new duties.
lead_paragraph: LONDON —  In recent days negotiators have seemed tantalizingly close to striking a post-Brexit trade deal between Britain and the European Union. But time is running out with just two weeks until the Dec. 31 deadline when Britain withdraws from the European Union’s economic zone, the single market and customs union.

headline: 14 Largely Skeptical, Somewhat Unconventional Holiday Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by U.S. Girls, 100 gecs, Big Freedia and more.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Trump’s Future: Tons of Cash and Plenty of Options for Spending It
abstract: When President Trump departs the White House, he will have a huge pile of cash to fuel his future ambitions. He can hold rallies, hire staff and even lay groundwork for a potential 2024 run.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump will exit the White House as a private citizen next month perched atop a pile of campaign cash unheard-of for an outgoing president, and with few legal limits on how he can spend it.

headline: A Simple Fix: Kindergarten at Night
abstract: To help working parents keep their kids focused on remote learning, one school switched up its schedule.
lead_paragraph: It’s almost impossible for kindergarten students and first graders to learn remotely without adult supervision. But school and work start and end around the same time. It’s difficult for parents to oversee remote learning and do their jobs at the same time, even if they’re working from home.

headline: Lara Trump served on the board of a company through which the Trump political operation spent more than $700 million.
abstract: Lara Trump, President Trump’s daughter-in-law and a senior campaign adviser, served on the board of a limited liability company through which the Trump political operation has spent more than $700 million since 2019, according to documents reviewed by The New York Times. She was also named on drafts of the company’s incorporation papers.
lead_paragraph: Lara Trump, President Trump’s daughter-in-law and a senior campaign adviser, served on the board of a limited liability company through which the Trump political operation has spent more than $700 million since 2019, according to documents reviewed by The New York Times. She was also named on drafts of the company’s incorporation papers.

headline: Overlooked No More: Clarice Lispector, Novelist Who Captivated Brazil
abstract: Critics lauded her stream-of-consciousness style and described her as glamorous and mysterious. But she didn’t always welcome the attention she received.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

headline: Here’s What People With Allergies Should Know About Covid Vaccines
abstract: Four people so far have had allergic reactions after getting the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine. Experts say that shouldn’t deter most people from getting a jab.
lead_paragraph: Allergic reactions reported in two health workers who received a dose of Pfizer’s vaccine in Alaska this week have reignited concerns that people with a history of extreme immune flare-ups might not be good candidates for the newly cleared shots.

headline: A Finger-Food Countdown to 2021
abstract: This menu of tasty party snacks is perfect for the 2020 version of a holiday blowout — that is, all-night nibbling on the couch.
lead_paragraph: There’s a lot I’ll miss about my usual holiday shindigs this December. There’ll be no sipping eggnog in red lipstick and spangles, no parking myself in front of platters of Camembert and Stilton, not even any sleeves of Ritz crackers with that unidentifiable orange cheese spread I look forward to year after year.

headline: To Understand Red-State America, He Urges a Look at Red-State Israel
abstract: An Israeli sociologist argues that Trump voters, like Netanyahu supporters in Israel, have legitimate reasons to find liberal values threatening.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Liberals were confounded. The right-wing incumbent’s blue-collar base was sticking by him, cheering as he weaponized identity politics, attacked democratic institutions and appeared to place his own interests ahead of the nation’s.

headline: Combating an Epidemic of Loneliness
abstract: Ways to seek support while social distancing.
lead_paragraph: Humans can survive three minutes without air, three days without water, three weeks without food and — according to survival lore — three months without companionship. Whether true or not, what’s clear is that people need people. And pandemics, many of us are learning, can be lonely times.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: Discover the recipes that got us through 2020. Also in this edition: a tribute to John le Carré from one of his friends, photos of a very different holiday season, and more.
lead_paragraph: Discover the recipes that got us through 2020. Also in this edition: a tribute to John le Carré from one of his friends, photos of a very different holiday season, and more.

headline: Big Tech Should Try Radical Candor
abstract: As the power of Google, Apple and other tech giants grows, the companies should do more to explain how they work.
lead_paragraph: This is the last edition of On Tech for 2020. Thank you for reading, please be well and I’ll see you back here on Jan. 4.

headline: A Portrait of 19th-Century Creole Culture
abstract: In an unfinished painting, the artist Andrew LaMar Hopkins depicts an interracial couple in 1830s Alabama.
lead_paragraph: In each installment of The Artists, T highlights a recent or little-shown work by a Black artist, along with a few words from that artist putting the work in context. This week, we’re looking at an unfinished canvas by Andrew LaMar Hopkins, a self-taught painter known for his faux-naïve depictions of life in the antebellum Gulf States. His first solo show, “Créolité,” was on view at Venus Over Manhattan in New York this fall.

headline: Three New Cinderella-Inspired Romance Novels
abstract: There’s something for everyone in these intelligent, offbeat happily-ever-afters.
lead_paragraph: “Cinderella” retellings start to look a lot less escapist once you realize that “princess” is just a metaphor for a better, more rewarding kind of job. One with advancement potential built right in. Because labor is as much a part of the fairy tale as romance is: Cinderella shouldn’t have to work so hard for nothing. Seen through this lens, a heroine’s happy ending isn’t about beauty or luxury or even innate goodness, it’s about having her efforts recognized and recompensed. This is the subversive streak of the fairy tale that can never quite be suppressed, the thorn that lurks in the heirloom roses.

headline: Better Than Besties: Why Gay Holiday Films Matter
abstract: This season’s movies with queer characters may be a largely chaste affair, but their comforting formulas also tell L.G.B.T.Q. viewers that they are seen.
lead_paragraph: I gasped so loudly, it sounded like Judy Garland had shown up at my Christmas party.

headline: Film Academy Museum Delays Its Opening Again
abstract: The Academy Museum of Motion Pictures pushed back its opening to Sept. 30, 2021, from April 30, citing the difficulty of forecasting when public life may begin to normalize.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Academy Museum of Motion Pictures is starting to feel a little cursed. Since the project was announced in 2012 — with an opening expected in 2017 — setbacks have included sparring architects, the discovery of mastodon fossils by excavation crews, a budget that ballooned by roughly 90 percent, the ouster of its founding director and now, for the second time, the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Major Arts Group Leader Steps Aside Amid Workplace Complaints
abstract: Robert Lynch of AFTA, the advocacy organization, is on leave as former and current employees raised concerns over diversity, equity and management.
lead_paragraph: Robert Lynch, the chief executive of Americans for the Arts, the powerful national advocacy group, has stepped aside amid complaints and investigations into the organization’s equity and diversity practices and its workplace management.

headline: What Time Do Jupiter and Saturn Align?
abstract: A celestial meet-cute will unfold before our eyes today. Here’s why you should be excited about that.
lead_paragraph: The last time Saturn and Jupiter, the largest planets in our solar system, orbited as closely as they will on Dec. 21 and were visible in the sky, the year was 1226.

headline: Its Football Season Over, Cal Wonders: Was It Worth It?
abstract: Some top programs will play a dozen games this season. The Golden Bears managed only four before their season ended with a text message.
lead_paragraph: For much of 2020, the Cal football program thought it had a chance to play in Friday night’s Pac-12 Conference championship game. It thought it had a chance to win its first outright conference title in more than 60 years. It thought it had a chance to play in a major bowl game.

headline: Brexit Trade Deal Really Is Coming Down to the Wire
abstract: Until now, the deadlines have seemed notional and the extensions endless, but New Year’s Eve is when the Brexit transition period ends. Talks could go well beyond that day.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In the neverland of post-Brexit trade talks, where every deadline seems notional and the extensions endless, there is nonetheless a sense that Britain and the European Union are — really and truly — coming to the end of the road.

headline: Facebook’s Tone-Deaf Attack on Apple
abstract: The company declared in newspaper ads that it was “standing up to Apple.” It’s a desperate ploy that’s unlikely to work.
lead_paragraph: If there’s anything that Facebook has learned from its many years of cozying up to the Trump administration, it’s figuring out that shamelessness works.

headline: Read the Criminal Complaint Against Julien Jin
abstract: Mr. Jin is accused of engaging in a conspiracy to censor Zoom users in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Jin is accused of engaging in a conspiracy to censor Zoom users in the United States.

headline: When Doctors Go Off Script on Covid
abstract: Readers say there should be consequences for dismissing the science. Another says medical advances depend on unconventional ideas.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Should You Bank Your Baby’s Cord Blood?
abstract: The stem cells in this vital fluid could save someone’s life, but it probably won’t be your child’s.
lead_paragraph: To bank or not to bank — that is the question I found myself reckoning with around six months into my pregnancy, when advertisements for private cord blood banks seemed to be popping up everywhere. “Protect what matters most,” a poster in my obstetrician’s office said. “Build your family a healthy future,” an ad on my Instagram feed prompted.

headline: The Primal Scream Line
abstract: Are you a parent who's tired as hell? Click the number to scream after the beep.
lead_paragraph: Are you a parent who's tired as hell? Click the number to scream after the beep.

headline: The Cyberwarfare Threat
abstract: A reader discusses reports of a hacking of government and business systems, with Russia the likely culprit. Also: Vaccinations at the top; regaining our strength as a country.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Barbara Windsor, Beloved British TV and Film Star, Dies at 83
abstract: She went from bubbly sex symbol in the “Carry On” films to working-class hero on “EastEnders.” Her private life was often as troubled as her “EastEnders” character’s.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Barbara Windsor, a star of the “Carry On” films and the long-running BBC soap opera “EastEnders,” whose dirty staccato laugh and ability to embody working-class life seared her into Britain’s collective memory, died on Dec. 10 at a care home here. She was 83.

headline: ‘The Mandalorian’ Season Finale: A Force to Be Reckoned With
abstract: The Season 2 finale brought back multiple Star Wars legends and pointed toward new frontiers for Baby Yoda, among others.
lead_paragraph: Throughout this season of “The Mandalorian,” I’ve seen some beefing online about how the show’s creator Jon Favreau has been bringing in pre-existing characters and ideas from the larger “Star Wars” universe. The essence of the complaint is that to understand all the nuances of the story now — to get all the references to “Grand Admiral Thrawn” and “Operation Cinder” and the like — you’ll need to have seen all the cartoons, played all the video games and read all the novels and comics.

headline: The Ailey Company Meets the Challenge of This Lost Season
abstract: In a pandemic year, Ailey celebrates the 60th anniversary of its cornerstone, “Revelations,” and premieres two fine new works, one by Jamar Roberts.
lead_paragraph: The centrality of “Revelations” in the repertory of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater is like nothing else in dance. Ballet companies may perform “The Nutcracker” every winter; the Ailey troupe performs “Revelations” on nearly every program, the whole year through. It’s the blueprint for most other works the company dances and the standard against which they’re all judged. It’s the perennial billboard for the company’s brand and its bible, too.

headline: Take Your Kids on Vacation, At Home
abstract: Keep your kids occupied during winter break by recreating the best parts of being away.
lead_paragraph: At the beginning of quarantine, parents tie-dyed like there was no tomorrow. Their production of friendship bracelets was matched only by the number of scavenger hunts they organized on the fly. In the quest to keep their children busy, they left no stone unturned. (Or untumbled in the rock tumbler, or undecorated with paint markers purchased hastily on Amazon.)

headline: Karen Killilea, 80, Dies; Turned Disability Into Triumph
abstract: She refused to be limited by her cerebral palsy. Her story was the subject of two widely read books and became an inspiration to many.
lead_paragraph: When Karen Killilea was born in 1940, she was three months premature and weighed less than two pounds. She spent her first nine months in a neonatal intensive care unit.

headline: Sublime Salmon
abstract: Make Genevieve Ko’s simple new salmon recipe, or try sautéed chicken with green olives or umami garlic noodles.
lead_paragraph: Hello and welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes. It is the craziest time of any year, let alone the craziest year. Anything that is not explicitly connected to holiday celebration should be pretty simple to execute. I haven’t finished shopping! I haven’t wrapped presents! I haven’t even made the list of all the other things I need to do, and will probably forget to do!

headline: Behind the Cover: Russia and Climate Change
abstract: A look at how no country is better positioned to capitalize on climate change than Russia.

headline: Homeland Security’s Latest Target: Vaccine Scams
abstract: A division of the Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency, working with the Justice Department, is hunting down websites offering fraudulent deals to buy coronavirus vaccines.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Va. — A team of agents from the Department of Homeland Security was combing thousands of websites scouting for evidence of the next phase of fraud schemes: offers of treatments or vaccines for the coronavirus.

headline: A European Official Reveals a Secret: The U.S. Is Paying More for Coronavirus Vaccines
abstract: But the price difference is negligible considering the enormous economic consequences of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The European Union appears to have paid less than the United States for some of the coronavirus vaccines it secured, according to confidential pricing data that was released in a seeming blunder.

headline: Complete or Incomplete?
abstract: Try to guess whether these N.F.L. receivers caught the ball or whether it fell incomplete.
lead_paragraph: Try to guess whether these N.F.L. receivers caught the ball or whether it fell incomplete.

headline: 8 Catholic Sisters Die of Covid-19 Within a Week at a Wisconsin Home
abstract: They were educators, music teachers and liturgists, living out their remaining years in a retirement residence after lifetimes of service.
lead_paragraph: They were educators, music teachers and community activists who served tirelessly for those living in poverty.
