abstract: No matter our intentions, lawyers like me were complicit. We owe the country our honesty about what we saw — and should do in the future.
lead_paragraph: I was an attorney at the Justice Department when Donald Trump was elected president. I worked in the Office of Legal Counsel, which is where presidents turn for permission slips that say their executive orders and other contemplated actions are lawful. I joined the department during the Obama administration, as a career attorney whose work was supposed to be independent of politics.

headline: Looking for Light on the Longest Night of the Year
abstract: Monday is the winter solstice. The next day will be brighter, and the next day will be brighter still.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Midway through December, in the midst of an unseasonable warm spell, I sent a text to the gang: “Shall we meet on our deck around 6:30?”

headline: This Deal Is Good Enough
abstract: It should be larger. It should have happened months ago. But an agreement on coronavirus aid is still a welcome dose of good news.
lead_paragraph: The $900 billion pandemic aid package that emerged Sunday from months of on-and-off negotiations between House Democrats and Senate Republicans is a necessary measure that will ease the suffering of millions of Americans. It will help unemployed workers to feed their families and to avoid eviction. It will help small businesses avoid bankruptcy. It will help to keep the trains and buses running in cities across the country.

headline: Trump Administration Is Criticized Over Proposal to Split Cyberoperations Leadership
abstract: As the government grapples with a vast hack, the Pentagon is weighing whether to separate management of the National Security Agency from the United States Cyber Command.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Confronted with a vast cyberattack believed to have been carried out by Russia, the Trump administration is suddenly reviving an old idea: Strip the general who leads the United States Cyber Command of his second title as the director of the National Security Agency, the country’s largest spy operation.

headline: Stimulus Deal Provides Economic Relief, for Now
abstract: The aid package will keep millions from losing jobless benefits. But it comes too late to prevent lasting damage to many families and businesses.
lead_paragraph: The congressional agreement on a $900 billion dose of aid to fuel the slowing economic recovery has probably spared millions of Americans from a winter of poverty and kept the country from falling back into recession.

headline: Jets’ First Win May Cost Them the No. 1 Pick
abstract: The Jets beat the Los Angeles Rams for their first win of the season, but the victory may give the Jacksonville Jaguars the top pick in the 2021 N.F.L. draft.
lead_paragraph: The Jets did the seemingly unthinkable on Sunday. They won.

headline: N.H.L. and Players’ Union Reach Framework for 2020-21 Season
abstract: The season would start Jan. 13 with all seven Canadian teams in one division, but authorities in Canada need to approve plans for teams to practice and play in their markets.
lead_paragraph: Protracted negotiations involving the N.H.L., its board of governors, the players’ union and several moving parts related to municipal, state, provincial and national protocols in two countries culminated Sunday with an agreement for next season.

headline: Not an Ideal Process or an Ideal Agreement, but, Finally, a Deal
abstract: Americans nationwide are glad that Congress, after a painfully prolonged process, has agreed to a stimulus package, however imperfect.
lead_paragraph: BOULDER, Colo. — On the day before Thanksgiving, Dave Query had to close his restaurant for good. For some 26 years, Zolo Grill had been a popular eatery in Boulder offering Southwestern fare. But the slowdown in business, he said, and the cost of complying with state and county safety protocols became too much.

headline: Surprise Medical Bills Cost Americans Millions. Congress Finally Banned Most of Them.
abstract: Efforts to solve the common consumer problem had been stalled by lobbying pressure and legislative squabbles.
lead_paragraph: After years of being stymied by well-funded interests, Congress has agreed to ban one of the most costly and exasperating practices in medicine: surprise medical bills.

headline: Black and Armed
abstract: The surge in Black gun-buying is a response to America’s failing to create a society where all citizens feel safe.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in rural northern Louisiana, everyone I knew, at least every household, seemed to have guns. Men had guns racked in the back windows of their pickup trucks, and pistols under their seats. Women, like my mother, tucked smaller handguns into their purses.

headline: The ‘Red Slime’ Lawsuit That Could Sink Right-Wing Media
abstract: Voting machine companies threaten “highly dangerous” cases against Fox, Newsmax and OAN, says Floyd Abrams.
lead_paragraph: Antonio Mugica was in Boca Raton when an American presidential election really melted down in 2000, and he watched with shocked fascination as local government officials argued over hanging chads and butterfly ballots.

headline: Tested Again, the Chiefs Flex Their Survival Skills
abstract: Kansas City (13-1) has come back in four of its last six games, and while the Chiefs do not seem invincible, they hardly seem beatable.
lead_paragraph: To an exclusive cohort in the N.F.L., the regular season serves as a preamble, offering those powerful teams 16 opportunities to tinker, learn and adapt. What might work in September might not in January, when the playoffs beckon.

headline: The Stimulus Package: What’s in It for You
abstract: Lawmakers agreed to issue stimulus payments of $600 and distribute a federal unemployment benefit of $300 for 11 weeks. But that money will take time to start arriving.
lead_paragraph: Another dose of relief is finally on the way for the millions of Americans facing financial distress because of the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Coronavirus, Stimulus Deal, Rohingya: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: A worrying mutation of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Quotation of the Day: No Warning, No Strings, No Fanfare: A Billionaire Bestows Gifts
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, December 21, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “Usually you don’t have very large philanthropists wandering the landscape looking to drop millions of dollars very quietly into organizations that they care about. The first email literally got stuck in my junk mail.”

headline: No Corrections: Dec. 21, 2020
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Dec. 21, 2020.
lead_paragraph: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Dec. 21, 2020.

headline: Reopen Schools, and Reform Them
abstract: Scrapping the high-stakes admission tests for New York’s specialized public high schools is long overdue. They severely disadvantage talented Black and Latino students.
lead_paragraph: The achievement gap in New York’s segregated and unequal schools is poised to become a chasm in the wake of the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Missing Fort Drum Soldier Is Found Dead in New Jersey
abstract: A dispute over a car swap appeared to have played a role in the killing of Cpl. Hayden Allen Harris. A fellow soldier was expected to be charged in connection with his death, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Two Fort Drum soldiers’ plans to exchange cars late last week ended with one soldier dead in a remote part of New Jersey and the other arrested and expected to face murder and kidnapping charges, officials said.

headline: Cause of Life
abstract: The more than 300,000 people we lost to the pandemic in 2020 form a portrait of America. For this series of short films, we asked five people to celebrate the life of someone close to them.
lead_paragraph: The more than 300,000 people we lost to the pandemic in 2020 form a portrait of America. For this series of short films, we asked five people to celebrate the life of someone close to them.

headline: Immigrant Neighborhoods Shifted Red as the Country Chose Blue
abstract: These maps show how areas with Latino and Asian residents shifted the vote in a way that may scramble the future of electoral politics, according to a New York Times analysis of 28,000 precincts.
lead_paragraph: These maps show how areas with Latino and Asian residents shifted the vote in a way that may scramble the future of electoral politics, according to a New York Times analysis of 28,000 precincts.

headline: She Called Police Over a Neo-Nazi Threat. But the Neo-Nazis Were Inside the Police.
abstract: Death threats linked to police computers and the discovery of far-right chat groups in police departments across Germany have fed concerns about far-right infiltration.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Traveling for work and far from home, Seda Basay-Yildiz received a chilling fax at her hotel: “You filthy Turkish sow,” it read. “We will slaughter your daughter.”

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘City Hall’ and ‘The Masked Dancer’
abstract: Frederick Wiseman’s latest documentary airs on PBS. And “The Masked Dancer” debuts on Fox.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Dec. 21-27. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Word + Quiz: doctrinaire
abstract: This word has appeared in 19 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: E.U. Approves Pfizer Vaccine, Setting Stage for High-Stakes Rollout
abstract: In a landmark collective undertaking, the bloc is poised to start distributing shots to all 27 member nations and their 410 million citizens.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — From Stockholm to Athens and from Lisbon to Warsaw, European Union governments are gearing up to receive a coronavirus vaccine later this week, even as cases keep rising in some parts of the continent.

headline: How to Manage Performance Evaluations in the Work-From-Home Era
abstract: A guide for managers in assessing 2020 and looking ahead to next year.
lead_paragraph: A performance review, done well, applauds excellent work, delivers beneficial feedback and inspires a feeling of forward momentum. It’s not easy to pull off in the best of times, and as work-from-home drags on, the task can feel even more challenging.

headline: 5 Takeaways From the Mayor’s Race: A Subway Pledge and Police Scrutiny
abstract: Some New York City candidates vowed to reform the Police Department — or to ride the subway more often than Mayor Bill de Blasio.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic candidates running for mayor of New York City differ on many issues, but they tend to agree on one thing: All aspire to be different from Mayor Bill de Blasio, a Democrat in his second term whose approval rating dropped after his failed run for president last year.

headline: It’s 2020. Indigenous Team Names in Sports Have to Go.
abstract: The Chiefs, Braves, Blackhawks and Seminoles need to follow the Cleveland baseball team in dropping their offensive names.
lead_paragraph: Before the Kansas City Chiefs play, Rhonda LeValdo does not feel excitement and joy. She feels outrage.

headline: N.B.A. Western Conference Preview: The Lakers Reloaded
abstract: Their championship glow still strong, the Lakers are poised to make another run, even as the Warriors bounce back and the Suns ascend.
lead_paragraph: LeBron James was surprised, and a little annoyed, when the N.B.A. unveiled its schedule for the 2020-21 season. He had been hoping for a mid-January start for his title defense with the Los Angeles Lakers. It was wishful thinking.

headline: N.B.A. Eastern Conference Preview: Will the Nets Reign Supreme?
abstract: The Bucks got better, but the Nets with Kyrie Irving and Kevin Durant might be too much for Milwaukee — or any other team in the East — to overcome.
lead_paragraph: Is it already the most wonderful time of year again? With LeBron alley-ooping and referees demanding we be of good cheer? There’ll be dunks used for posting, Kawhi laughs for roasting and trash talking out in the snowwwww.

headline: The Life of Angela Chaddlesone McCarthy, a Modern-Day Warrior for the Kiowa Tribe
abstract: “Cause of Life” celebrates the messy, tenacious, and extraordinary lives of five people we lost to Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: “Cause of Life” celebrates the messy, tenacious, and extraordinary lives of five people we lost to Covid-19.

headline: The Life of Humberto Trujillo, the Postmaster of Phoenix
abstract: “Cause of Life” celebrates the messy, tenacious, and extraordinary lives of five people we lost to Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: “Cause of Life” celebrates the messy, tenacious, and extraordinary lives of five people we lost to Covid-19.

headline: The Life of Calvin Haworth, a Veteran Who Helped Raise His Granddaughters After Unspeakable Loss
abstract: “Cause of Life” celebrates the messy, tenacious, and extraordinary lives of five people we lost to Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: “Cause of Life” celebrates the messy, tenacious, and extraordinary lives of five people we lost to Covid-19.

headline: The Life of Rosary Castro-Olega, a Retired Nurse Who Returned to the Front Lines
abstract: “Cause of Life” celebrates the messy, imperfect and extraordinary lives of five people we lost to Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: “Cause of Life” celebrates the messy, imperfect and extraordinary lives of five people we lost to Covid-19.

headline: The Life of Jerry Givens, a State Executioner Turned Death-Row Abolitionist
abstract: “Cause of Life” celebrates the messy, tenacious, and extraordinary lives of five people we lost to Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: “Cause of Life” celebrates the messy, tenacious, and extraordinary lives of five people we lost to Covid-19.

headline: After striking a stimulus deal, Congress faces yet another midnight deadline to approve it.
abstract: After congressional leaders struck a long-sought agreement on a $900 billion pandemic relief package, lawmakers in both chambers on Monday will race to finalize legislative text and send the measure to President Trump’s desk before government funding lapses.
lead_paragraph: After congressional leaders struck a long-sought agreement on a $900 billion pandemic relief package, lawmakers in both chambers on Monday will race to finalize legislative text and send the measure to President Trump’s desk before government funding lapses.

headline: Moderna’s vaccine rolls out in the U.S.
abstract: A week after planes and trucks carried the first Covid-19 vaccine across the United States, inching a weary public toward hope, the second was shipped to sites around the country. The Moderna vaccine, like Pfizer’s, requires two shots, spaced weeks apart. The Food and Drug Administration authorized its emergency use on Friday.
lead_paragraph: A week after planes and trucks carried the first Covid-19 vaccine across the United States, inching a weary public toward hope, the second was shipped to sites around the country. The Moderna vaccine, like Pfizer’s, requires two shots, spaced weeks apart. The Food and Drug Administration authorized its emergency use on Friday.

headline: What Is Something Good That Happened in 2020?
abstract: What is something positive you discovered about yourself, your family, your community and maybe even your world this year?
lead_paragraph: When you look back at 2020, it might be easy to think of all the challenges. But even though this has been a dark year for so many people, can you think of the good things that happened as well? Did you start any new hobbies, strengthen any relationships, or learn anything about yourself or about the world?

headline: M.L.B.’s Records Were Never Real. But the Racism Was. Ask Satchel Paige.
abstract: Major League Baseball’s plan to formally recognize the Negro leagues exposes the ugliness that has existed all along.
lead_paragraph: Major League Baseball keeps vowing to redress its racist past, but its half-steps only reinforce the elusiveness of that goal, for it and the rest of America.

headline: Your Card Payment Has Been Declined
abstract: Mastercard’s chief executive oversees $6.5 trillion in transactions. That gives him unique insights into our economic recovery, and power over companies like Pornhub.
lead_paragraph: Ajay Banga has spent a decade as chief executive of Mastercard. Last year, he oversaw $6.5 trillion in transactions. That means he knows what we’re spending right now (aggregated and anonymized, of course) and how long it might take to get us out of our current economic funk. It also means Mr. Banga has leverage over virtually any business that relies on credit card payments. For example, following recent reporting from New York Times columnist Nicholas Kristof on the scale of child pornography on Pornhub, Mastercard announced that it would terminate payments on that site.

headline: What Pediatricians Say Can’t Wait
abstract: As we celebrate the rollout of the new Covid-19 vaccines, don’t forget the standard immunizations and other steps to keep children safe.
lead_paragraph: Last May, the American Academy of Pediatrics launched a campaign named #CallYourPediatrician. There were humorous visuals, to-do lists with “call pediatrician” right above “learn 3rd grade math,” informational graphics about safe visits in the time of Covid, and adorable videos (watch the baby panda getting his checkup).

headline: When the Weather Outside Is Frightful, Here’s How to Stay Warm
abstract: The right gear, a little planning and practicing for the cold temperatures can help you take celebrations outdoors to avoid Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: How do you stay safe and stay connected with family and friends during a Covid winter?

headline: How Having a Child With Autism Helps Me Ride Out the Pandemic
abstract: My life has been filled with uncertainty for a long time, but my son has helped me stay flexible, adjust expectations and persevere.
lead_paragraph: It feels like forever since we took up residence in the United States of Anxiety. As the months drag on, that mix of fear and fortitude I felt at the beginning of the pandemic is giving way to fatigue and frustration.

headline: I Am Guilty of Violating the Espionage Act
abstract: The Justice Department is setting a dangerous precedent that threatens reporters — and the truth.
lead_paragraph: I am guilty of violating the Espionage Act, Title 18, U.S. Code Sections 793 and 798. If charged and convicted, I could spend the rest of my life in prison.

headline: Naomi Osaka: Athletes, Speak Up
abstract: We’re affected by bias and racism, just like everyone else. Why shouldn’t we say so?
lead_paragraph: This is an article from Turning Points, a special section that explores what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead.

headline: If I’d Stayed in My Hometown, Would I Be a Trump Voter?
abstract: My family lost its shared reality. But some ties still bind.
lead_paragraph: XENIA, OHIO — My 93-year-old mother was dying. It was the Saturday after the election, and the suburban Georgia votes were being tallied. My sister Cookie and I were sitting in Mom’s memory-care unit, the lights dimmed. About the only thing Cookie and I agreed on politically was not to discuss the orange elephant in the room.

headline: 95 Percent of Representatives Have a Degree. Look Where That’s Got Us.
abstract: All these credentials haven’t led to better results.
lead_paragraph: Over the last few decades, Congress has diversified in important ways. It has gotten less white, less male, less straight — all positive developments. But as I was staring at one of the many recent Senate hearings, filled with the usual magisterial blustering and self-important yada yada, it dawned on me that there’s a way that Congress has moved in a wrong direction, and become quite brazenly unrepresentative.

headline: Biden’s Choice of Vilsack for U.S.D.A. Raises Fears for Small Farmers
abstract: Democrats have struggled to win voters in rural America, and critics say the return of Tom Vilsack, a former agriculture secretary, won’t help.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Soon after President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. beat President Trump last month, Tom Vilsack, the former agriculture secretary and one of Mr. Biden’s early backers, received an exasperated call from a former aide. Despite the elation over Mr. Biden’s victory, Democrats were again defeated resoundingly in rural America.

headline: New York Is Ousting Older Judges to Save Money. They’re Fighting Back.
abstract: Dozens of judges are being forced to retire to close a pandemic budget gap. They have sued New York State, charging age discrimination.
lead_paragraph: It was last March 11: the day President Trump shut down travel from Europe and Tom Hanks announced he had coronavirus. The mayor of New York was warning people about the risks of leaving home.

headline: Should I Have Elective Surgery in the Pandemic?
abstract: Patients must balance the chance of a life-threatening Covid-19 exposure against the opportunity for relief from a condition that may be painful but is not considered urgent.
lead_paragraph: With the Covid-19 pandemic raging across the country, many people hoping to undergo elective surgery can expect their operations to be on hold indefinitely. Hospitals in many places are at or near bed capacity and facing staff shortages. Even facilities still able to handle operations not considered urgent are likely to experience cancellations when patients themselves, fearing contagion, postpone the procedures.

headline: Time Isn’t Supposed to Last This Long
abstract: We’re living in a perpetual present tense. And we are waiting.
lead_paragraph: BETHANY, Conn. — Since March, my family has kept track of time in the changing palette from early spring to fall, a steady transition from gray to gold. A menagerie of birds and beasts, including a fat black bear, have visited, all of them arriving outside our kitchen window for birdseed without the slightest concern about gathering in groups or sharing a meal. We’ve watched them, envious of their audacious freedom.

headline: What You Can Do Post-Vaccine, and When
abstract: Particularly in the early months of vaccination, many activities should wait, experts say — and plan to keep your masks.
lead_paragraph: Vaccines are here, bringing hope of the pandemic’s end. But even when you get your dose, it won’t mean an immediate return to life as you knew it.

headline: The Hall of Fame Tries to Contextualize Baseball’s Racist Past
abstract: Rather than remove the plaques of its most problematic inductees, the Baseball Hall of Fame is hoping to explain them.
lead_paragraph: A plaque at the Baseball Hall of Fame in Cooperstown, N.Y., confers a kind of halo to each member. The gallery feels like a chapel, and the Hall of Famers are the saints. A few gilded sentences summarize the reasons to honor each one.

headline: The Year of Telfar
abstract: A queer Liberian-American designer became the success story of the pandemic. Now he wants to smash the old fashion system to bits.
lead_paragraph: In January 2020, around the time word first began to leak of Covid-19 in China, Telfar Clemens, the queer Liberian-American designer who has been preaching the gospel of inclusivity for 15 years, had a wine-drenched banquet and sleepover for more than 40 of his closest creative collaborators and friends in the Pitti Palace, a former home of the Medicis in Florence.

headline: Climate Change Legislation Included in Coronavirus Relief Deal
abstract: The legislation calls for cutting the use of powerful planet-warming chemicals common in air-conditioners and refrigerators.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the waning days of the 116th Congress, lawmakers have authorized $35 billion in spending on wind, solar and other clean power sources while curtailing the use of a potent planet-warming chemical used in air-conditioners and refrigerators.

headline: Wintry Scenes From a Swedish Wonderland
abstract: With his foreign assignments canceled for the year, a photographer refocuses on his homeland — and finds plenty to admire.
lead_paragraph: I consistently give the same advice to aspiring photographers: Wherever home is, that’s where you should begin.

headline: China Long Avoided Discussing Mental Health. The Pandemic Changed That.
abstract: The government has deployed extensive resources to address the spike in depression and anxiety. But social stigmas and long-term challenges remain.
lead_paragraph: China’s fight against the coronavirus was mostly over, but Zhang Xiaochun, a doctor in Wuhan, was sinking into depression, convinced she had failed as a daughter and mother. She agonized over her decision to keep working even after her father fell critically ill. She worried about her young daughter, whom she had frequently left alone at home.

headline: Who Gets the Vaccine Next?
abstract: Companies, unions and trade groups are making pitches that their workers should be prioritized.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Biden receives the coronavirus vaccine.
abstract: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. received the coronavirus vaccine on live television on Monday at Christiana Hospital in Newark, Del., sending a message to Americans across the country that the vaccine is safe to take.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. received the coronavirus vaccine on live television on Monday at Christiana Hospital in Newark, Del., sending a message to Americans across the country that the vaccine is safe to take.

headline: A Brazen Police Shooting Caught on Video Sparks Anger in the Philippines
abstract: The video shows a police officer shooting a woman and her son after a dispute over a noisemaker. Some activists linked the killings to a culture of violence in which the police are allowed to act with impunity.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — A video of a police officer shooting a woman and her adult son at close range on Sunday has spread rapidly across social media in the Philippines, provoking a wave of outrage directed at the government and a police force that many say acts with impunity.

headline: More Than Twice the Size of Texas
abstract: That’s how much land Biden wants to conserve over the next decade. But is it possible?
lead_paragraph: To slow extinctions and climate change, President-elect Joe Biden has embraced a plan to conserve 30 percent of U.S. land and 30 percent of its ocean waters by 2030. It is perhaps the most ambitious commitment to conservation by a U.S. president. How he proceeds will determine whether he unites or further divides Americans in a pivotal decade for the planet.

headline: Stocks are roiled as a fast-spreading virus strain in Britain overshadows the stimulus deal.
abstract: Financial markets were jolted on Monday after the emergence of a fast-spreading coronavirus variant led to the suspension of some trade and travel with Britain as well as another lockdown in London, a new threat that overshadowed progress in Washington toward a long-awaited economic aid package.
lead_paragraph: Financial markets were jolted on Monday after the emergence of a fast-spreading coronavirus variant led to the suspension of some trade and travel with Britain as well as another lockdown in London, a new threat that overshadowed progress in Washington toward a long-awaited economic aid package.

headline: A former big tech insider is helping with antitrust cases against the companies.
abstract: A former tech industry insider is now playing a key role in the wave of antitrust lawsuits against the giant tech companies.
lead_paragraph: A former tech industry insider is now playing a key role in the wave of antitrust lawsuits against the giant tech companies.

headline: A much-hyped video game has turned into a nightmare for its developer.
abstract: Since the release of the highly anticipated Cyberpunk 2077 video game on Dec. 10, thousands of gamers have created viral videos featuring a multitude of glitches and bugs — many hilarious — that mar the game and render it virtually unplayable for many users.
lead_paragraph: Since the release of the highly anticipated Cyberpunk 2077 video game on Dec. 10, thousands of gamers have created viral videos featuring a multitude of glitches and bugs — many hilarious — that mar the game and render it virtually unplayable for many users.

headline: Worker Ran Illegal Winery in Alabama Sewage Plant, Sheriff Says
abstract: The DeKalb County Sheriff’s Office received a tip about an alcohol operation in a wastewater treatment plant in Rainsville, Ala. A 15-year city employee was arrested and charged.
lead_paragraph: A municipal worker in Alabama was arrested after he was caught running an illegal winemaking operation inside a sewage treatment plant, the authorities said.

headline: Delilah
abstract: With snippets of love, loss and struggle soothed by music, she has become one of American radio’s most popular — and trusted — voices. We decided to give her a call.
lead_paragraph: This episode was hosted and produced by Andy Mills and Bianca Giaever, with help from Leslye Davis. It was edited by Sara Sarasohn, Wendy Dorr and Lisa Tobin.

headline: German White Supremacist Is Sentenced to Life for Synagogue Attack
abstract: The 28-year-old attacker was convicted of killing two as he tried to storm a synagogue last year. It was described in court as the most despicable act of anti-Semitism in Germany since World War II.
lead_paragraph: MAGDEBURG, Germany — A white supremacist who live-streamed his efforts to blast his way into a synagogue in Germany last year on the holiest day on the Jewish calendar, failing to cause widespread bloodshed only because he could not breach a heavy wooden door, was sentenced on Monday to life in prison.

headline: Charting the Virus
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: Let’s check in on the latest coronavirus data this morning, with help from three charts.

headline: Can We Talk About the Mom in ‘A Christmas Story’?
abstract: The woman hasn’t had a hot meal in 15 years and she’s always cooped up at home. 2020 is the year to give this character from a classic holiday movie her due.
lead_paragraph: It’s been tough to watch movies in 2020 and not project our frustrations and anxieties onto the screen. Maybe the extravagant wedding sequence in “The Godfather” suddenly felt garish compared to all of this year’s Zoom “I Dos.” Or maybe you put on “Elf” to pass some quarantine time, and the crowded mall scenes launched you into a cold sweat, because everyone is inside and no one is wearing a mask.

headline: What You Get for $725,000 in California
abstract: A renovated 1978 house in Rancho Mirage, a 1991 farmhouse with a 10-acre walnut orchard in Corning and a Mediterranean-style home in Oakland.
lead_paragraph: A renovated 1978 house in Rancho Mirage, a 1991 farmhouse with a 10-acre walnut orchard in Corning and a Mediterranean-style home in Oakland.

headline: $725,000 Homes in California
abstract: A renovated 1978 house in Rancho Mirage, a 1991 farmhouse with a 10-acre walnut orchard in Corning and a Mediterranean-style home in Oakland.
lead_paragraph: Built in the late 1970s, this house was updated by Thomas Troy, a local builder and designer known for contemporary interpretations of midcentury-modern style. In addition to an interior makeover, the house got a new roof and an outdoor water feature.

headline: It’s Finally Here. But Is It Enough?
abstract: Congress finally reached a stimulus deal. Some worry it’s too little, too late.
lead_paragraph: Lawmakers finally struck a $900 billion stimulus compromise yesterday, after months of warnings from economists, corporate leaders and the Fed that the U.S. economy needed additional help. The questions now are whether it’s enough, and who will benefit the most.

headline: A Covid Deal and Pee-wee’s Christmas Card
abstract: Monday: Applause for the stimulus deal is muted and the governor is back in quarantine, but another vaccine is expected today.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: ‘The Whole City Was Dark’: China Rations Electricity for Millions
abstract: Warning of coal shortages, officials are trying to curb energy usage by telling residents not to use electric stoves and extinguishing lights on building facades and billboards.
lead_paragraph: In the city of Yiwu in eastern China, the authorities turned off streetlights for several days and ordered factories to open only part-time. In coastal Wenzhou, the government ordered some companies not to heat their offices unless temperatures are close to freezing. In southern Hunan Province, workers have reported climbing dozens of flights of stairs after elevators were shut down.

headline: Kilauea Volcano Erupts in Hawaii, Prompting Warning to Stay Inside
abstract: The civil defense authorities warned people to stay indoors to avoid the fallout of ash carried by the winds.
lead_paragraph: The Kilauea volcano in Hawaii erupted overnight Sunday, prompting the authorities to warn residents to shelter from ash driven by the wind, but there were no immediate concerns about evacuations or threats to life.

headline: A ‘Messiah’ for the Multitudes, Freed From History’s Bonds
abstract: A polyglot, nonsectarian, gender-inclusive film from Canada remakes the Handel classic for today’s world.
lead_paragraph: A gay Chinese-Canadian tenor struts through the streets of Vancouver, joyously proclaiming that “ev’ry valley shall be exalted” as the camera focuses in on his six-inch-high stiletto heels.

headline: Mexico Misled Citizens About the Severity of Coronavirus in its Capital
abstract: The federal government had data that should have prompted an immediate lockdown in early December. Instead, it kept the city open for another two weeks.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — In early December, the pandemic was roaring back in Mexico City: After declining over the summer, the coronavirus was spreading rapidly, hospitalizations were spiking and ventilators were running low.

headline: Kansas City Star Apologizes for Racism in Decades of Reporting
abstract: The newspaper said it had “disenfranchised, ignored and scorned” generations of Black people. The apology comes after one in September by The Los Angeles Times.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — When Mará Rose Williams, an education reporter for The Kansas City Star, was assigned to cover a local Black Lives Matter protest over the summer, she was struck by the difference between what she said she witnessed and what had been reported in previous days.

headline: Videos Show Kilauea Volcano Eruption in Hawaii
abstract: The Kilauea volcano in Hawaii, considered one of the most active in the world, erupted overnight Sunday, prompting the authorities to warn residents to shelter from ash from the volcano.
lead_paragraph: The Kilauea volcano in Hawaii, considered one of the most active in the world, erupted overnight Sunday, prompting the authorities to warn residents to shelter from ash from the volcano.

headline: Millions are traveling in the U.S., despite warnings.
abstract: Airport security checkpoints have handled more than one million passengers a day since Friday.
lead_paragraph: More than a million travelers a day passed through airport security checkpoints on each of the last three days in the United States.

headline: Who Takes the Eurostar? Almost No One, as the Pandemic Fuels a Rail Crisis
abstract: A plunge in ridership at the international high-speed train mirrors wider troubles gripping Europe’s railway industry.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Earlier this month, David-Alexander Leduc rolled his suitcase down a nearly empty platform at the Gare du Nord train station and scanned his ticket at the turnstile to board the sole Eurostar leaving that day for London.

headline: Condiment City
abstract: Make Tejal Rao’s recipe for salsa macha, a rich chile oil from Veracruz, Mexico.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. One of the few joys of the pandemic lockdown, as Tejal Rao wrote for The Times last week, is the sharp increase in the number of condiments many of us have put in our refrigerators since March. Tejal listed beautiful examples: “Preserved lemons from a neighbor’s tree. Sludgy garlic pickles in a distressingly greasy jar. Tubs of fermented bean pastes and bottles of fish sauce, mouths crusted with salty crystals.”

headline: A Wolf Pup Mummy From the Ancient Arctic
abstract: Melting permafrost yields secrets of how a 6-week-old wolf puppy lived and died.
lead_paragraph: More than 50,000 years ago, a den in sandy soil collapsed on a wolf pup and killed her, sealing her away from air and moisture so the pup’s body mummified in the cold.

headline: A Winter Solstice, a Meteor Shower, Jupiter and Saturn Walk Into Your Night Sky
abstract: One day that has room for three distinct astronomical events.
lead_paragraph: While it’s been a terrible year in a lot of ways, 2020 has had some impressive astronomical occurrences. Remember Comet NEOWISE? Or when Betelgeuse dimmed in night skies? Those were just a couple of the celestial highlights as we stumbled our way around the sun during these 366 days (it was a leap year, too).

headline: 2 People-Smugglers Are Convicted of Manslaughter in U.K. Truck Deaths
abstract: Gheorghe Nica, of Romania, and Eamonn Harrison, of Northern Ireland, were found guilty for the deaths of 39 Vietnamese migrants who were found in a container in southeastern England in 2019.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Two members of an international people-smuggling gang were convicted of manslaughter on Monday over the deaths of 39 people whose bodies were found in the back of a container truck in southeastern England last year.

headline: What to Watch: Sci-Fi Movies Led by Women
abstract: Aliens aren't all these heroes have to contend with. Check out these films with women at the forefront.
lead_paragraph: Aliens aren't all these heroes have to contend with. Check out these films with women at the forefront.

headline: Barr Sees ‘No Reason’ for Special Counsels for Hunter Biden or the Election
abstract: The departing attorney general, William P. Barr, again broke with President Trump on his unsupported claims of widespread election fraud and the need to appoint a special counsel to investigate the president-elect’s son.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General William P. Barr distanced himself again from President Trump on Monday, saying he saw no reason to appoint special counsels to oversee the Justice Department’s criminal investigation into Hunter Biden, son of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr., or to investigate Mr. Trump’s baseless claims of widespread voter fraud.

headline: Taylor Swift Lands Her Second No. 1 Album of the Year With ‘Evermore’
abstract: The sequel to “Folklore” did not have the commercial impact of its predecessor, due in part to changes in the Billboard rules.
lead_paragraph: Due in part to changes in how album sales are counted, Taylor Swift’s second release of the year, “Evermore,” did not have the commercial impact of her first, although it was more than enough to hit No. 1 again.

headline: The Best New Podcasts of 2020
abstract: Some of this tumultuous year’s most absorbing programming — whether escapist or heartbreaking — could be found in these shows.
lead_paragraph: Every so often the C.I.A. oversees an absolutely deranged project: spy cats, mind control experiments, a booby-trapped conch shell. So the idea that the agency wrote a popular heavy metal song, one that helped thaw the Cold War? Maybe not so crazy. In this eight-episode audio documentary, soft power meets power ballad. The New Yorker writer Patrick Radden Keefe investigates an irresistible rumor — that the C.I.A. composed the Scorpions’ 1990 glasnost-positive anthem, “Wind of Change.” On a shaggy dog international tour, Keefe interviews ex-spies, shadowy music industry figures and the Scorpions’ frontman, Klaus Meine. But this is ultimately a podcast about a conspiracy theory and, as with most conspiracy theories, the solid evidence is thinner than a vinyl pressing. Still, Keefe’s keen reporting and obvious excitement keep your earbuds in, even into the two bonus episodes. ALEXIS SOLOSKI

headline: Concerns About Coronavirus Variant Cut Off U.K. From Europe
abstract: Dozens of countries banned air and rail links to Britain, foreshadowing what a “no deal” Brexit could look like in 10 days.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain was all but cut off from the rest of Europe on Monday, with flights and trains banned by some 40 countries and freight deliveries halted at French ports, as its neighbors tried desperately to stop a fast-spreading variant of the coronavirus from leaping across the English Channel.

headline: The Crossword Stumper
abstract: A look at one of the entries that fooled solvers in last week’s puzzles.
lead_paragraph: A ZEBU is a type of cattle native to South Asia. They are recognizable by the hump on their shoulders, and are renowned for their resistance to heat and insects.

headline: Pandemic Aid Bolsters Biden and Shows Potential Path for His Agenda in Congress
abstract: Working together with the president-elect, bipartisan groups in the Senate and House helped push feuding leaders to compromise. It could be a template for the future.
lead_paragraph: Producing it was a torturous, time-consuming affair that did nothing to improve Congress’s reputation for dysfunction. But the agreement on a new pandemic aid package showed the ascendance of moderates as a new force in a divided Senate and validated President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s belief that it is still possible to make deals on Capitol Hill.

headline: Patty Jenkins on ‘Wonder Woman 1984’ and the Future of Theaters
abstract: Jenkins made history with a lucrative deal to direct this sequel. With Warner Bros. opting to debut it on HBO Max, will she come back for a third film? “We’ll see.”
lead_paragraph: The first “Wonder Woman” movie, directed by Patty Jenkins, was a cinematic game-changer that proved female superheroes were every bit as mighty as men. The new sequel, “Wonder Woman 1984” (due Dec. 25), promises to be a very different kind of game-changer: Once positioned for a billion-dollar box-office gross, it will now debut on the same day both in theaters and on the streaming service HBO Max, a corporate priority for Warner Bros. and its parent company AT&T.

headline: ‘Star Trek’ and Dr. Seuss Mash-Up Not Protected, Court Rules
abstract: The book, titled “Oh, the Places You’ll Boldly Go!”, hewed too closely to the original to be considered a parody under the “fair use” doctrine, a three-judge federal appeals panel declared.
lead_paragraph: An unauthorized mash-up of the “Star Trek” and Dr. Seuss universes, a book titled “Oh, the Places You’ll Boldly Go!”, is not protected from a copyright infringement claim, a federal appeals court ruled last week.

headline: Moratorium on evictions and foreclosures for F.H.A. loans is extended.
abstract: The moratorium will now run through Feb. 28. It had been set to expire at the end of the month.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Housing and Urban Development has extend a moratorium on evictions and foreclosures on home mortgages its insures against default, protecting many first-time home buyers.

headline: Armed protesters angry over virus restrictions try to force their way into the Oregon Statehouse.
abstract: Armed protesters trying to force their way into Oregon’s State Capitol building on Monday were met by officers in riot gear, as lawmakers gathered for a one-day special session amid growing tension over coronavirus restrictions in the state.
lead_paragraph: Armed protesters trying to force their way into Oregon’s State Capitol building on Monday were met by officers in riot gear, as lawmakers gathered for a one-day special session amid growing tension over coronavirus restrictions in the state.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Parts of Asia and Europe bar travelers from Britain.
lead_paragraph: Countries across Asia and Europe are racing to bar travelers from Britain, as the U.K. struggles to contain an outbreak of what officials said was a more contagious variant of the coronavirus.

headline: Take a Walking Tour of New York
abstract: Months ago, our architecture critic invited a few people to suggest modest strolls around places meaningful to them. Here’s where they went.
lead_paragraph: Months ago, our architecture critic invited a few people to suggest modest strolls around places meaningful to them. Here’s where they went.

headline: N.J. Approves $14 Billion in Corporate Tax Breaks in Less Than a Week
abstract: The incentive package was pushed by Gov. Philip D. Murphy, a progressive Democrat who has railed against similar tax breaks in the past. His allies are not happy.
lead_paragraph: No issue has defined Gov. Philip D. Murphy’s first term in office more than corporate tax incentives. He railed against them as a Democratic candidate for governor and, once elected, initiated an investigation that exposed the program he inherited from his Republican predecessor as a poorly managed boon for politically connected firms.

headline: Disney names a new chairman for its movie division.
abstract: Disney on Monday cleared up a lingering question at its movie division: Alan Bergman, 54, was named chairman, succeeding Alan F. Horn, 77, a venerable figure in Hollywood who has led Walt Disney Studios since 2012. Mr. Horn will continue to serve as chief creative officer.
lead_paragraph: Disney on Monday cleared up a lingering question at its movie division: Alan Bergman, 54, was named chairman, succeeding Alan F. Horn, 77, a venerable figure in Hollywood who has led Walt Disney Studios since 2012. Mr. Horn will continue to serve as chief creative officer.

headline: The ‘Student-Athlete’ Myth
abstract: Two academics say the pandemic has highlighted the “utter hypocrisy” of the label. Also: The virus as war.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Trump’s Loss, the Republic’s Win
abstract: Readers respond to an Op-Ed essay about the important role of “civic virtue.”

headline: Ex-Bloomberg Reporter Who Covered Martin Shkreli Reveals Relationship With Him
abstract: Christie Smythe helped break the story of Mr. Shkreli’s arrest in 2015. Then she “started to fall for him,” she said, and quit her job at Bloomberg News.
lead_paragraph: “Your Honor, finding love with Martin was a great joy for me.”

headline: Kelly Loeffler, a Wall Street Senator With a Hardscrabble Pitch
abstract: The hard right turn of Ms. Loeffler, one of two Republican candidates in Georgia’s pivotal Senate runoff elections, reflects the ideological gymnastics embraced by her party in the Trump era.
lead_paragraph: In the year since Kelly Loeffler was appointed to the Senate, the largely unknown financial executive has crafted a narrative of her life and built a campaign around it.

headline: Navalny Says Russian Agent Confessed to Plot to Poison Him
abstract: Aleksei A. Navalny, the Russian opposition leader, published a recording of a phone call in which he says he tricked a security official into exposing the plot.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Aleksei A. Navalny, the Russian opposition leader recovering from a nerve agent attack, has made a career of needling his country’s sprawling security establishment.

headline: Rosendo and Rogelio Mendoza, Twins and Texas Welders, Die at 56
abstract: The Mendoza brothers, identical twins who worked together, died of complications of Covid-19 on the same day.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Why on Earth Is Someone Stealing Unpublished Book Manuscripts?
abstract: A phishing scam with unclear motive or payoff is targeting authors, agents and editors big and small, baffling the publishing industry.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, the book industry website Publishers Marketplace announced that Little, Brown would be publishing “Re-Entry,” a novel by James Hannaham about a transgender woman paroled from a men’s prison. The book would be edited by Ben George.

headline: Stimulus Offers $15 Billion in Relief for Struggling Arts Venues
abstract: The coronavirus relief package that Congressional leaders agreed to this week includes grant money that many small proprietors described as a last hope for survival.
lead_paragraph: For the music venue owners, theater producers and cultural institutions that have suffered through the pandemic with no business, the coronavirus relief package that Congress passed on Monday night offers the prospect of aid at last: it includes $15 billion to help them weather a crisis that has closed theaters and silenced halls.

headline: A Close Reading of Ariana Grande’s Engagement Announcement
abstract: In an extremely 2020 move, Ms. Grande got quarantine-engaged and announced it in an Instagram photo dump.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, when Ariana Grande announced her engagement on Instagram, the congratulatory likes and comments flowed in immediately. So did the questions: about her fiancé (a luxury real estate agent named Dalton Gomez), the duration of their relationship (roughly a year, though quarantine timelines should probably be weighted to account for constant contact), the composition of her photography (was she in a car?) and, of course, the ring.

headline: Now That Grandma Has Been Vaccinated, May I Visit Her?
abstract: The start of a mass coronavirus vaccination campaign at U.S. nursing homes has brought hope to many families. But it may be a while before restrictions loosen. Here are answers to common questions.
lead_paragraph: A watershed moment has arrived for many families: This week health care workers from CVS and Walgreens, under contract from the federal government, will fan out to nursing homes across the country to begin vaccinating residents against the coronavirus. The shots not only will help protect the nation’s elderly and infirm — and the staff who care for them — but they raise the prospect of ending the devastating isolation many residents have felt for months.

headline: ‘It Doesn’t Work’: Critics of Russia’s Doping Ban Blame the System
abstract: While athletes and experts lament a court’s reduced punishment for Russia’s doping scandal, the country is already trying to wring a new concession.
lead_paragraph: Clare Egan heard the news last week while resting between training sessions in her hotel room in Hochfilzen, Austria, where she was preparing to compete in a biathlon World Cup event.

headline: $1 Trillion, Too Little, Too Late
abstract: The arbitrary politics of price tags ended up robbing Americans of more help in the new coronavirus relief bill.
lead_paragraph: We now know that millions of unemployed workers won’t be kicked off unemployment insurance (for at least 11 weeks) and will now get $300 every week in addition to their current state benefit; a vast majority of Americans will receive $600 direct payments from the government; and small businesses will have access to a modest new tranche of forgivable government loans.

headline: Congress Approves New Museums Honoring Women and Latinos
abstract: Long-sought Smithsonian museums dedicated to the contributions of these two groups made it into the $2.3-trillion year-end spending bill. A vote passed in the Senate and the House.
lead_paragraph: After decades-long campaigns, a National Museum of the American Latino and a national museum of women’s history are finally on their way to becoming reality in Washington.

headline: Kwanzaa’s Principles and Traditions
abstract: More about Nguzo Saba, the seven principles of Kwanzaa, as well as some of the symbols of the celebration.
lead_paragraph: During the height of the Black freedom movement in 1960s Los Angeles, Maulana Karenga designed a Black holiday, Kwanzaa, that was modeled after West African harvest festivals on the African continent and used Swahili words and phrases. (Swahili is a lingua franca and mother tongue primarily spoken along the eastern coast of Africa.)

headline: A Plan by Eastern States to Cap Tailpipe Emissions Gets Off to a Slow Start
abstract: Connecticut, Massachusetts, Rhode Island and Washington, D.C., all announced they would join a cap-and-trade program for cars and trucks. But many bigger states have yet to join.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An ambitious plan by Eastern states for a regional cap-and-trade program to curb greenhouse gas emissions from cars and trucks got off to a slow start Monday after just three states — Connecticut, Massachusetts and Rhode Island — plus Washington, D.C., formally agreed to adopt it.

headline: Five Kwanzaa Celebrations Around the Country
abstract: For many Black Americans, the holiday is a time for bonding, joy and repose. The Times visited five households to see how people cook and gather, engage and reflect.
lead_paragraph: Kwanzaa is more than an end-of-year display of deep orange and burnt burgundy Dutch wax-print fabrics, and righteous images of fruit bowls sitting near wooden cups. It’s an edifying lifestyle choice.

headline: Trump Makes Classical Style the Default for Federal Buildings
abstract: An executive order stopped short of banning modernist architecture, but states that “the preferred architecture” style for new buildings should be classical.
lead_paragraph: President Trump signed an executive order on Monday that establishes classical architecture as the preferred style for new federal buildings but stops short of banning newer designs from consideration.

headline: Governors impose new restrictions on travelers from Britain as holiday travel ratchets up.
abstract: Alarmed by the coronavirus variant spreading in Britain, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York announced on Monday that British Airways, Virgin Atlantic and Delta Air Lines have agreed to require a negative coronavirus test result from passengers boarding flights from Britain to New York.
lead_paragraph: Alarmed by the coronavirus variant spreading in Britain, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York announced on Monday that British Airways, Virgin Atlantic and Delta Air Lines have agreed to require a negative coronavirus test result from passengers boarding flights from Britain to New York.

headline: Runners’ Races Were Canceled. Their Coaches Filled the Void.
abstract: Coaches and agents were desperate to help their athletes compete in a year void of competition. So they created a marathon themselves, and watched the list of the fastest American marathons times get rewritten.
lead_paragraph: There were three winners at Sunday’s Marathon Project, a bright spot in an otherwise uncertain year for professional runners.

headline: Cook Like Alex Guarnaschelli
abstract: The chef and television personality’s latest cookbook, “Cook With Me,” features unpretentious recipes.
lead_paragraph: Helpful, funny, personal and typically self-deprecating, the voice of Alex Guarnaschelli, the chef, restaurateur and television cooking personality, is unmistakable throughout her new book, “Cook With Me.” There are many great recipes that should have a place on your table. Something for New Year’s? Go no further than her deviled eggs soaked in borscht (not necessarily homemade) to color them purple with whipped cream — whipped cream! — to fluff the filling. Or broil and flame some provolone for delicious fun (it works). And don’t forget dumplings without wrappers, cauliflower steaks, mixed mushrooms or salmon and kale on a sheet pan, a salad of rescued vegetable tops and mulled white wine.

headline: Citrus Flavors From Ladurée
abstract: The French pastry specialist has enlisted the expertise of Jean-François Piège for its holiday offerings.
lead_paragraph: This holiday season, Ladurée has enlisted the Parisian chef Jean-François Piège to create some of its French pastries: macarons, stunning bûches de Noël and, a favorite of mine with a glass of Champagne or just to nibble, his take on a simple loaf cake. Called the Cake, it’s a buttery, citrusy confection festive enough with its tracings of candied peel atop its lemon glaze.

headline: U.S. Unseals Charges Against New Suspect in 1988 Lockerbie Bombing
abstract: Attorney General William P. Barr said that investigators had obtained a confession in 2012 from a bomb expert admitting his role in the terrorist attack on a jetliner over Scotland.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General William P. Barr on Monday announced criminal charges against a former Libyan intelligence operative accused of building the explosive device that was used in the 1988 bombing of Pan Am Flight 103, one of the deadliest terrorist attacks in United States history, stemming partly to a confession that he gave nearly a decade ago while imprisoned in Libya.

headline: A Hudson Valley Brewery Branches Out to Distilling
abstract: Arrowood Farms in Accord, N.Y., now makes a neutral vodka and a citrusy gin.
lead_paragraph: Arrowood Farms, in Accord, N.Y., caught my eye in 2016 because it was a brewery growing its own hops. The Hudson Valley farm has now grown to include a restaurant, the Apiary, and a distillery, which, like the brewery, is sustainable, using yeast developed from its own honey cultures, locally grown grain and water from a spring on the property. The vodka (80 proof) is quite neutral, mostly about its satiny texture to enjoy well chilled, with just a twist. Caviar would not be a mistake alongside. The gin (90 proof) is dry, but with hints of citrus peel, wildflowers and pine both on nose and palate, making it good martini material if you don’t overdo the vermouth. Their new bourbon (90 proof) aged in Adirondack oak barrels is $35 for a 375-milliliter bottle. The brewery has expanded to produce a range of beers and ales, some seasonal. Come summer, you’ll want Lion’s Tooth, a farmhouse ale brewed with dandelion.

headline: Stimulus, Mutating Virus, Barr: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: The Warmth of Ethiopian Honey
abstract: Maryiza sells four honeys from southwest Ethiopia, and sales help combat deforestation in the region.
lead_paragraph: Assorted raw tree honeys from Ethiopia — prized by a number of chefs for their complex flavors suggesting jasmine, praline, smoke and wheat — are now sold in a tasting set of four from Maryiza. Abalo, Bissana, Grawa and Geteme are the varieties. The honey is gathered in southwest Ethiopia from indigenous trees during flowering season. Sales of the honeys help to support the forests and the local community.

headline: Pâtés en Croûte Worthy of a Celebration
abstract: You might think these gorgeous spreads are from Paris, but they’re from the West Coast shop of the chef Nicolas Delaroque.
lead_paragraph: In response to the pandemic, Nicolas Delaroque has turned his Restaurant Nico in San Francisco into Maison Nico, with the sommelier Paul Einbund. It’s what the French call an épicerie, or gourmet shop, where a selection of fine packaged and freshly made products are sold. The online shop features Mr. Delaroque’s exceptional pâtés en croûte, gorgeous, savory mosaics of meats, including duck, sausage, game, offal and spices, encased in well-burnished pastry. It’s an item worth a holiday celebration, and it can be ordered for shipping nationwide by the portion or whole. Beef cheeks or bouillabaisse-style seafood are layered in aspic and also available for local delivery.

headline: Financial Aid Is Restored for Prisoners as Part of the Stimulus Bill
abstract: Reversing a ban on Pell grants for prisoners, begun in the 1994 crime bill, is just one of several higher-education equity provisions included in the huge funding bill.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Tucked into Congress’s voluminous stimulus package are significant changes to higher-education law, including the resumption of federal financial aid to prison inmates that was banned in the 1994 crime bill championed by then-Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: For U.K., an Early Taste of Brexit as Borders Are Sealed
abstract: Battling a new coronavirus variant even as they steel themselves for the looming split with the E.U., Britons are feeling profoundly isolated.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Christmas plans were canceled. Many flights off the island were stopped. And lawmakers called for cultivating new plots of land to shore up the nation’s food supply, conjuring images of plates full of root vegetables.

headline: The U.K. Coronavirus Variant: What We Know
abstract: A newly identified variant of the SARS-CoV-2 virus appears to be more contagious than established ones. Here’s what scientists know.
lead_paragraph: In recent days, the world has watched with curiosity and growing alarm as scientists in the U.K. have described a newly identified variant of the coronavirus that appears to be more contagious than, and genetically distinct from, more established variants. Initial studies of the new variant prompted Prime Minister Boris Johnson to tighten restrictions over Christmas, and spurred officials in the Netherlands, Germany and other European countries to ban travel from the U.K.

headline: Virus Hits Federal Death Row, Prompting Calls for Delays in Executions
abstract: At least 14 of the roughly 50 men held in the secure facility at the federal penitentiary in Terre Haute, Ind., have tested positive. Staff members involved in executions have also gotten sick.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The coronavirus pandemic is sweeping through death row at the federal penitentiary in Terre Haute, Ind., with at least 14 of the roughly 50 men there having tested positive, lawyers for the prisoners and others familiar with their cases said.

headline: Relief Deal Would Give Small Businesses a Shot at a Second Loan
abstract: The stimulus package being negotiated in Washington includes $285 billion for a renewed Paycheck Protection Program.
lead_paragraph: Federal lawmakers have agreed to revive the signature small-business relief effort established last spring, committing $285 billion for additional loans under the Paycheck Protection Program and allowing particularly hard-hit companies to get a second loan.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: A new variant in Britain has prompted travel bans across the world.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, Britain imposed a wholesale lockdown on London and most of the country’s southeast, citing fears about a new strain of the coronavirus, which officials say is more contagious..

headline: Senate Candidates Duel in Georgia as G.O.P. Voters’ Anger Persists
abstract: As the state’s Republican senators rallied with Ivanka Trump, and their Democratic challengers welcomed Kamala Harris, conservative voters were focused on the president’s election loss.
lead_paragraph: MILTON, Ga. — Five Republicans spoke at a rally on Monday in suburban Atlanta, including two state lawmakers, Senators Kelly Loeffler and David Perdue, and Ivanka Trump, the president’s daughter and senior adviser.

headline: 1998 U.S. Embassy Bombing Victims Are Assured Equal Compensation in Deal With Sudan
abstract: A new congressional agreement largely puts to rest months of furious negotiations over how to help Sudan’s fragile transitional government, which faces lawsuits accusing the country of harboring Al Qaeda.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Victims of the 1998 bombings of two United States Embassies in East Africa will soon receive up to $485 million in compensation as part of a wide-ranging settlement to remove Sudan from a list of state sponsors of terrorism and, in turn, foster peace with Israel.

headline: Google Denies Antitrust Claims in Early Response to U.S. Lawsuit
abstract: The company said people use its services because they choose to, not because they lack alternatives.
lead_paragraph: Google said on Monday that it had not used its multibillion-dollar deals with other large tech firms to protect its position as the dominant online search engine, in the company’s first formal rebuttal to the Justice Department’s accusations that those deals violated antitrust laws.

headline: 2 Passengers and a Dog Slide Out of Moving Plane at La Guardia
abstract: Delta Flight 462 was delayed for hours after a male passenger forced open a cabin door while the plane was taxiing. He and his companions slid their way out of the plane.
lead_paragraph: Brian Plummer was sitting toward the back of a Delta Air Lines flight readying to depart La Guardia Airport on Monday when, he said, he noticed a man and a woman with a large service dog nearby.

headline: The Ghost of Sabotage Future
abstract: This winter’s economy won’t be as grim as feared, but what about after?
lead_paragraph: The not-a-stimulus deal Congress reached over the weekend — seriously, this is about disaster relief, not boosting the economy — didn’t come a moment too soon. Actually, it came much too late: Crucial aid to many unemployed Americans and businesses expired months ago. But now some of that aid is back, for a while.

headline: Congress Passes Huge Coronavirus Relief Bill
abstract: Lawmakers approved a $900 billion pandemic aid bill that provides a $600 payment for most Americans.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congress on Monday night overwhelmingly approved a $900 billion stimulus package that would send billions of dollars to American households and businesses grappling with the economic and health toll of the pandemic.

headline: California builds field hospitals and considers rationing care as virus spreads unabated.
abstract: LOS ANGELES — As California’s new coronavirus cases, hospitalizations and deaths continue to soar, the nation’s most populous state has emerged as the epicenter of the pandemic heading into a dangerous holiday week.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — As California’s new coronavirus cases, hospitalizations and deaths continue to soar, the nation’s most populous state has emerged as the epicenter of the pandemic heading into a dangerous holiday week.

headline: Who Can Endure the Loneliness Required of This Moment?
abstract: Emotional respite has become a scarce public resource.
lead_paragraph: The journalist Anne Helen Petersen recently asked, on Twitter, for articles about the “long-term psychological effects” of the pandemic. She soon noticed that many of the replies were about the damage it was doing to children.

headline: More Than 70 West Point Cadets Are Accused in Cheating Scandal
abstract: The U.S. Military Academy faces its biggest academic scandal in nearly 50 years over allegations of cheating on a calculus exam.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Military Academy at West Point is confronting its biggest academic scandal in nearly five decades after more than 70 cadets were accused of cheating on a calculus exam last spring, officials said.

headline: A Hong Kong Activist, Nathan Law, Seeks Political Asylum in Britain
abstract: The prominent dissident fled to London shortly before a security law was imposed in Hong Kong. Affording him asylum would likely incense China.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Hong Kong democracy activist Nathan Law said on Monday that he had applied for political asylum in Britain, a petition that will likely inflame tensions with China if granted.

headline: Treasury Department’s Senior Leaders Were Targeted by Hacking
abstract: The disclosure was the first acknowledgment of a specific intrusion in the vast cyberattack. At the White House, national security leaders met to assess how to deal with the situation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Russian hackers who penetrated United States government agencies broke into the email system used by the Treasury Department’s most senior leadership, a Democratic member of the Senate Finance Committee said on Monday, the first detail of how deeply Moscow burrowed into the Trump administration’s networks.

headline: The Fate and Fortunes of the Fashion-Adjacent Economy
abstract: Influencers and street-style photographers changed the fashion ecosystem, creating an entirely new way of selling fantasy. Then came a pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Tamu McPherson, one of the original street-style stars and a former editor of Grazia Italia, has 319,000 followers on Instagram. For years, many have watched her pose in immaculately styled outfits at runway shows, glittery parties and on vacation. During the fashion weeks in September 2019, Ms. McPherson, who was born in Jamaica and lives now in Milan, flew to New York and back four times to produce content for her Rolodex of clients, which include the jewelry brand Bulgari, the fashion label Etro and the fast-fashion retailer Mango.

headline: Quotation of the Day: N.J. Approves $14 Billion in Corporate Tax Breaks in Less Than a Week
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, December 22, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “When you rush things in Trenton, bad things happen.”

headline: Cause for a Blessing
abstract: Amy Yanni makes her New York Times Crossword debut, ably abetted by Jeff Chen.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Happy Tuesday! The sign of a good puzzle, I believe, is when you come out of it smiling. We have extra reasons to smile today: The first is Amy Yanni’s New York Times Crossword debut (in a collaboration with Jeff Chen), and the second is the fact that this is such an uplifting puzzle.

headline: Cryptocurrency Company Ripple Is Sued by S.E.C.
abstract: The value of the third most valuable digital token, XRP, was called into question after regulators filed a lawsuit against the company behind it.
lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission sued the company behind one of the most valuable cryptocurrencies on Tuesday, raising fundamental questions about the viability of the token.

headline: Robert E. Lee Statue Is Removed From U.S. Capitol
abstract: The statue of the Confederate general will be replaced with one of the civil rights leader Barbara Johns, who led a school walkout in Virginia in 1951.
lead_paragraph: Virginia’s statue of the Confederate general Robert E. Lee was removed from its post in the U.S. Capitol on Monday morning, closing a year that saw Confederate statues toppled as the nation reckoned with racism in its history and institutions.

headline: Circus Acrobats Reach $52.5 Million Settlement in 2014 Fall
abstract: “There are safety standards and safety features that were supposed to be in place for every event,” a lawyer for the acrobats said.
lead_paragraph: When eight acrobats suspended high above the ground at a performance in Rhode Island suddenly came crashing down in May 2014, gasps and screams ripped through the crowd of spectators. In a YouTube video of the episode, one person can be heard asking, “Were they supposed to fall like that?”

headline: Corrections: Dec. 22, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Dec. 22, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Sunday about new Sesame Street characters based on Rohingya Muslims, using information provided by a publicist, misspelled the surname of the president of social impact for Sesame Workshop. She is Sherrie Westin, not Weston.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Britain’s sudden coronavirus Christmas isolation.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: ‘Ariana Grande: Excuse Me, I Love You’ Review: It’s Mutual
abstract: Sometimes it’s enough to adore a pop star from afar, even if you aren’t an Arianator.
lead_paragraph: So is there actual footage of Ariana Grande cleaning up dog poop? And why was Kristin Chenoweth on FaceTime with Grande as she was picking it up? You might be asking yourself the same dumb questions after watching the new music documentary “Excuse Me, I Love You,” with the pony-tailed pop star at its performance-driven center.

headline: A Dinner, a Deal and Moonshine: How the Stimulus Came Together
abstract: Top party leaders cinched a $900 billion relief deal after laying down their swords. But it took an empowered, bipartisan group of moderates to help bridge the divide.
lead_paragraph: A week before Thanksgiving, a small group of moderate senators gathered in the spacious living room of Senator Lisa Murkowski’s home on Capitol Hill to embark on what they considered an urgent assignment.

headline: Number of Journalists Killed for Their Reporting Doubled in 2020
abstract: At least 30 journalists were killed this year, according to the Committee to Protect Journalists, with 21 slain as a direct result of their work.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The number of journalists killed as a result of their work more than doubled in 2020, an international media watchdog group said on Tuesday, with armed conflict and gang violence making Mexico and Afghanistan among the deadliest countries for reporters globally.

headline: 5 Picture Books About Civil Rights
abstract: From “the father of the Underground Railroad” to the first woman vice president, these Black action figures are poetry in motion.
lead_paragraph: SHIRLEY CHISHOLM IS A VERB!Written by Veronica ChambersIllustrated by Rachelle Baker

headline: After Bars and Beaches, Gibbons Await a New Home in Thailand
abstract: The small apes were once widespread across much of Asia. But rampant deforestation and ruthless hunting of the acrobatic animal has greatly reduced its numbers and its habitat.
lead_paragraph: KHAO PHRA THAEO WILDLIFE SANCTUARY, Thailand — The white-handed gibbon, captured as an infant by poachers, was rescued from a grim life amusing inebriated visitors in tourist bars, then spent eight years in a cage at a rehabilitation center.

headline: Word + Quiz: factitious
abstract: This word has appeared in one article on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: Lonely Dining
abstract: Do you miss going out to restaurants?

headline: N.B.A. 2020-21 Predictions: LeBron vs. Luka for M.V.P.
abstract: Our panel predicts a big year for the Nets and the Pelicans’ Zion Williamson, a surprise from Damian Lillard, a Lakers repeat and a fierce battle among the rookies.
lead_paragraph: The last time the sports staff of The New York Times and assorted friends gathered to make the annual set of N.B.A. preseason predictions, we got some things right.

headline: In Mexico, Childbirth in Covid’s Shadow
abstract: Midwives and doctors struggle to help women give birth safely during the grim days of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Rafaela López Juárez was determined that if she ever had another child, she would try to give birth at home with a trusted midwife, surrounded by family. Her first birth at a hospital had been a traumatic ordeal, and her perspective changed drastically afterward, when she trained to become a professional midwife.

headline: ‘Wintering’ Offers Hopeful Perspective on Embracing Difficult Times
abstract: In her memoir, Katherine May writes about coping with “a fallow period in life when you’re cut off from the world, feeling rejected, sidelined, blocked from progress.”
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, The Financial Times published a sobering essay on an urgent subject: loneliness in the time of Covid. Written by the paper’s Chicago correspondent, Claire Bushey, it described what it has felt like to live by yourself in this miserable year.

headline: New & Noteworthy, From Astrophysics to Reading Nabokov
abstract: A selection of recent titles of interest; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
lead_paragraph: PERESTROIKA IN PARIS, by Jane Smiley. (Knopf, $26.95.) Two decades after Smiley wrote about the world of horse racing in her 2000 novel “Horse Heaven,” she revisits the theme in this lighthearted romp about a racehorse on the loose in the big city.

headline: What if Remote Learning Slows Them Down?
abstract: Bianca Barragán is counting on her children’s bilingual education program to teach them English. From afar, that’s a challenge.
lead_paragraph: Bianca Barragán is counting on her children’s bilingual education program to teach them English. From afar, that’s a challenge.

headline: Bronx Nursing Home Residents Get Their First Shots of Vaccine
abstract: Nearly 1,600 residents and staff were vaccinated on Monday at a nursing home in Riverdale. It provided a long-awaited cause for optimism.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 1,600 residents and staff were vaccinated on Monday at a nursing home in Riverdale. It provided a long-awaited cause for optimism.

headline: What New Flavor Ideas Do You Have for Your Favorite Foods?
abstract: How do you feel about novelty Oreo flavors like Key Lime Pie, Wasabi and Peeps?
lead_paragraph: Do you wish there were jalapeño Pop-Tarts or watermelon gummy bears? How about bacon-flavored Skittles? What new flavor ideas do you have for your favorite snacks?

headline: A Mother Who Tries to Rescue Her Sons From the Maws of War
abstract: In “Lara’s Story,” the Polish journalist Wojciech Jagielski recounts how one woman went searching in Syria for a son who had succumbed to radical Islam.
lead_paragraph: ALL LARA’S WARSBy Wojciech Jagielski

headline: Welcome to the Ruthless, Cutthroat World of Paleoanthropology
abstract: Two new books, Kermit Pattison’s “Fossil Men” and Meave Leakey’s “The Sediments of Time,” offer a glimpse into the adventurous world of the men and women searching for our origins.
lead_paragraph: FOSSIL MENThe Quest for the Oldest Skeleton and the Origins of HumankindBy Kermit Pattison

headline: For Europe, It’s Wave After Wave
abstract: In a roller coaster year of pandemic, the one constant has been the strain on frontline workers, who are already girding themselves for the next surge.
lead_paragraph: In a roller coaster year of pandemic, the one constant has been the strain on frontline workers, who are already girding themselves for the next surge.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘‘R’ is for Rohingya: Sesame Street Creates New Muppets for Refugees’
abstract: In this lesson, students will learn about new Sesame Street characters. Then, they will consider the potential impact of children’s TV shows in different communities.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “‘R’ is for Rohingya: Sesame Street Creates New Muppets for Refugees”

headline: A Wintry Tale of Deliverance
abstract: The George Saunders story “Tenth of December” poses a question that absorbs many patients and caregivers: Can we save ourselves or each other from suffering?
lead_paragraph: When I learn, as I did a few days ago, of a cherished member of my cancer support group going into hospice, I find myself alienated from holiday cheer, as many do this year. Rather than reading a holiday story like “A Christmas Carol,” I open instead George Saunders’ short story “Tenth of December.” In it, a man who dreads end-of-life cancer connects with a boy who has been bullied in school. Through their interaction, the tale poses a question that absorbs many patients and caregivers. Can we — how can we — save ourselves or each other from suffering?

headline: Bonus: Kara Swisher and Nick Kristof Discuss Pornhub and Mastercard
abstract: They also discuss the slippery slope from guns to sugary cereals.
lead_paragraph: On yesterday’s episode of Sway, the chief executive of Mastercard spoke about why the company blocked subscription payments on Pornhub. Was it too little too late? Kara asks Nicholas Kristof, the journalist whose reporting on child pornography forced the payment company’s hand.

headline: The Joys of Frivolous Sex
abstract: The pandemic has brought out a nasty puritanism.
