One Christmas, I brought over a large cheesecake as a consolation gift: None of us were spending Christmas with our families, and none of us were thrilled about it.

headline: Feminism Has Failed Women
abstract: If the pandemic undid three decades of progress on gender equality, one has to wonder: How real was that progress in the first place?
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, or maybe it was a few months ago, I decided to watch my two favorite ’80s movies about working mothers: “Baby Boom,” a rom-com starring Diane Keaton as an advertising executive turned work-from-home applesauce mogul; and “Aliens,” James Cameron’s thriller centered around a woman’s struggle to defeat a race of genocidal aliens. Both mother-protagonists struggle with what has come to be known as “work-life balance.”

headline: The Ups and Downs of Fashion in 2020
abstract: What happened in 2020, when everyone’s life (and wardrobe) was turned upside down.
lead_paragraph: It is a truth generally acknowledged that 2020 will be known as the year that changed everything: our attitude toward our health, technology and the fragility of democracy; the economies of the arts, hospitality, sports and travel.

headline: Some Said the Vaccine Rollout Would Be a ‘Nightmare.’ They Were Right.
abstract: There are already signs that distribution will be messy, confusing and chaotic.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Even before there was a vaccine, some seasoned doctors and public health experts warned, Cassandra-like, that its distribution would be “a logistical nightmare.”

headline: Biden’s Withering Olive Branch
abstract: The new year will prove whether we have any decency left in us.
lead_paragraph: The year will turn, Joe Biden will take the oath of office, and we’ll heal.

headline: Two Cities and Two Weddings — but Only One Couple
abstract: Kelly Orians and Thomas Frampton had two weddings in one day, one in Washington and the other in New Orleans, so family members would not have to risk traveling during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Kelly Orians and Thomas Frampton had two weddings in two cities in one day.

headline: Simple, Affordable and Socially Distanced, Snowshoeing Gets Hot
abstract: As biking was to spring, snowshoeing is to winter as exercisers adapt to cold weather.
lead_paragraph: When the pandemic struck in the height of the 2020 ski season, closing the downhill ski mountain in Breckenridge, Colo., the Breckenridge Nordic & Snowshoe Adventure Center found families turning to its snow sports, which were, by their natures, socially distanced, pandemic or not.

headline: Make Schools More Human
abstract: The pandemic showed us that education was broken. It also showed us how to fix it.
lead_paragraph: If a measure of a society is how well it takes care of its young, the past nine months are a damning indictment of our nation.

headline: The Beauty Products That Got Us Through 2020
abstract: The year home became not just an office, but a salon and spa.
lead_paragraph: Unable to visit their hair stylists, aestheticians, hair braiders or nail technicians for much of this year, many people began D.I.Y.-ing their beauty routines. At-home haircuts and dye jobs boomed. Online shopping took center stage.

headline: You Can Learn a Lot About Human Nature From Takeout Orders
abstract: In a world where everything was changing, the menu at a small New Orleans restaurant also had to adapt. Not everyone seemed to get that.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Opening a restaurant is hard. A lot of people will tell you it’s a bad idea. Especially in 2020.

headline: Isolation Helps Homeless Population Escape Worst of Virus
abstract: Despite outbreaks in shelters and the prospect of more, the rates of infection among homeless populations are lower than feared.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Under a highway overpass in downtown Oakland, Camilla Everette sleeps on a couch, with a blue-and-white-striped summer parasol offering the only protection from the drops of rainwater that fall from the concrete above her.

headline: For Millions of Jobless, Christmas Is a Season to Endure, Not Celebrate
abstract: Even with the prospect of new federal aid, many Americans face a holiday of tough choices, trying to celebrate while dealing with pressing needs.
lead_paragraph: Nicole Craig, an unemployed mother of two from Pittsburgh, will have no Christmas gifts for her two children, and the ham she bought with food stamps will be far less than their usual holiday dinner. Months behind on her rent and utility bills, she has been struggling to afford formula and diapers. But there is one thing she couldn’t give up: a small Christmas tree and the trimmings to go with it.

headline: The Breakout Stars of 2020
abstract: Here are the 12 stars and trends that managed to thrive and shine in an impossible year.
lead_paragraph: While plenty of us felt trapped this year, wandering through the same spaces and talking to the same people, it was the artists and entertainers who kicked open windows to new sights, sounds and experiences. Yes, the pandemic dealt a significant hit to the culture world, but nothing could derail its creativity. So, despite the limitations, stars in a variety of disciplines managed to thrive and shine, and by doing so, made a difficult year more tolerable for most everyone. Here are 12 artists and trends who gave us a fresh perspective in 2020.

headline: Carey Mulligan Won’t Let Hollywood Off the Hook
abstract: The actress delivered the performance of her career in the dark comedy “Promising Young Woman.” Then came those with their tired views of women.
lead_paragraph: Not every Carey Mulligan movie begins with a Charli XCX song, but maybe more of them should. When “Promising Young Woman” deploys the 2017 pop bop “Boys” in its opening moments, it’s the first sign you’re about to get something from Mulligan that you’re not used to: namely, a contemporary setting.

headline: Walter Tevis Was a Novelist. You Might Know His Books (Much) Better as Movies.
abstract: In addition to “The Queen’s Gambit,” adapted into the current Netflix hit, Walter Tevis wrote the novels “The Hustler,” “The Color of Money” and “The Man Who Fell to Earth.”
lead_paragraph: The wildly popular Netflix series “The Queen’s Gambit” has done for chess what Julia Child once did for French cooking. Chess set sales have skyrocketed; enrollment in online chess classes has surged. The series has been the subject of hundreds of articles and interviews. The novel that inspired the show, first published in 1983, has been on The New York Times’s trade paperback best-seller list for five weeks.

headline: Police Took Their Son Away. Then the Merchants of Hope Showed Up.
abstract: The police seize and kill young men in Nigeria. Then pastors, lawyers and so-called human rights advocates squeeze money out of their families, promising to help find them.
lead_paragraph: AWKA, Nigeria — In the small family portrait gallery hanging above the television in the cozy home of the Iloanya family, only two framed photographs remain that include the youngest son, Chijioke.

headline: How 5 New Yorkers Are Coping with Holidays Alone
abstract: For many in New York City, their pandemic-imposed loneliness has been even more pronounced during the holiday season.
lead_paragraph: On March 12, I took my last subway ride home from work. I was listening to John Cale’s “Dying on the Vine” while standing in the middle of a cramped car. I could feel tension in the air — a mix of fear and uncertainty. As New Yorkers retreated indoors, many struggled with a new kind of loneliness.

headline: The Virus That Stole Most of 2020 Now Steals Christmas, Too
abstract: Across Italy and beyond, those who lost loved ones this year had looked forward to a holiday with the rest of their friends and relatives. But for many, it’s not to be.
lead_paragraph: ROME — This will be Rinaldo Verzeni’s first Christmas without his father.

headline: European Soccer Learns a New Virtue: Patience
abstract: Why have so few managers been fired this year? Pandemic economics play a role, but there are bigger forces at work, too.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Enrico Preziosi could hardly have held Thiago Motta in higher esteem. As a player, Motta spent only a single season at Genoa, the Italian soccer team Preziosi owns, but he made such an impression that, a decade later, his old boss cited him as his ideal professional. “A smart and empathetic man,” Preziosi said. “He taught me many things.”

headline: The Tech That Was Fixed in 2020 and the Tech That Still Needs Fixing
abstract: From videoconferencing to fitness apps, the best tech helped us endure a hard year. But there were also low points.
lead_paragraph: To put it lightly, 2020 was rough. More than ever, we turned to our personal tech this year to help find respite, stay healthy and remain connected with the people we care about.

headline: Living On ... The Lower East Side
abstract: In recent years, the country’s ‘most famous immigrant neighborhood’ has welcomed new, high-end development. But it still has an old-school vibe.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, the country’s ‘most famous immigrant neighborhood’ has welcomed new, high-end development. But it still has an old-school vibe.

headline: The Lower East Side: Where Historic Tenements Meet Glassy Towers
abstract: In recent years, the country’s ‘most famous immigrant neighborhood’ has welcomed new high-end development. But it still has an old-school vibe.
lead_paragraph: Richard Kimmel was drawn to the Lower East Side partly by “a lot of family history,” he said, including his great-grandmother, “who arrived at Ellis Island on the Fourth of July in 1898,” and made her way to the densely populated neighborhood that has long been a haven for immigrants of many origins, with Eastern European Jews predominating at the turn of the last century.

headline: West Point Cheating Scandal: What to Know
abstract: More than 70 West Point cadets  have been accused of cheating on an exam, the institution's largest academic scandal in decades.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: As at-home rapid tests enter the market, remember that ‘negative’ doesn’t always mean negative.
abstract: Since the start of the pandemic, the Food and Drug Administration has issued emergency green lights to more than 200 types of coronavirus tests, each with its own curiosities and quirks. Yet we tend to talk about all of them in the same binary way, with identical terms: positive, negative, true, false.
lead_paragraph: Since the start of the pandemic, the Food and Drug Administration has issued emergency green lights to more than 200 types of coronavirus tests, each with its own curiosities and quirks. Yet we tend to talk about all of them in the same binary way, with identical terms: positive, negative, true, false.

headline: Even after border reopens, truckers stuck at British ports scuffle with the police.
abstract: Britain agreed to broad virus tests for truck drivers as part of a deal to reopen land, air and sea routes to France.
lead_paragraph: After blocking freight traffic from Britain in an attempt to stop the spread of a possibly more contagious variant of the coronavirus, France reopened its border on Wednesday to truck transport.

headline: Overwhelmed by virus victims, a New York funeral home became a scene of ‘horrifying disrespect.’
abstract: Andrew T. Cleckley was the first funeral director in New York to have his license revoked over the way he handled the remains of pandemic victims.
lead_paragraph: Sharon Escobar paid a Brooklyn funeral home to tend to the remains of her father, Elisha Magosha, after he died from complications of Covid-19 in April.

headline: ‘Covid conga line’ with Queens Republicans prompts criticism and an investigation.
abstract: When the Whitestone Republican Club held a holiday party at Il Bacco, an Italian restaurant in Little Neck, Queens, on Dec. 9, more than a dozen people formed a conga line as part of the revelry, shimmying through a glitzy banquet room.
lead_paragraph: When the Whitestone Republican Club held a holiday party at Il Bacco, an Italian restaurant in Little Neck, Queens, on Dec. 9, more than a dozen people formed a conga line as part of the revelry, shimmying through a glitzy banquet room.

headline: The Lives They Lived
abstract: Remembering some of the artists, innovators and thinkers we lost in the past year.
lead_paragraph: Remembering some of the artists, innovators and thinkers we lost in the past year.

headline: John Thompson Was Every Black Boy’s Longed-For Coach
abstract: A stern disciplinarian with a white towel on his shoulder, he made Georgetown’s basketball team champions.
lead_paragraph: A stern disciplinarian with a white towel on his shoulder, he made Georgetown’s basketball team champions.

headline: Diane di Prima Was a Rare Woman Among the Beatniks
abstract: A writer and poet who came of age before the women’s movement, she forged a path toward her own desires.
lead_paragraph: A writer and poet who came of age before the women’s movement, she forged a path toward her own desires.

headline: Grant Imahara Was a Geek Before (and After) It Was Cool
abstract: His lifelong love of robotics led to a star turn on “Mythbusters.”
lead_paragraph: His lifelong love of robotics led to a star turn on “Mythbusters.”

headline: Linda Tripp Was Cast as a Villain During the Clinton Impeachment
abstract: Recent years have been kinder to women once judged harshly. But she is unlikely to ever get redemption.
lead_paragraph: Recent years have been kinder to women once judged harshly. But she is unlikely to ever get redemption.

headline: Mike Hoare Was a Soldier for Hire Who Led a Spectacularly Failed Coup
abstract: Mad Mike was already in his 60s when he tried to overthrow the Marxist president of the Seychelles.
lead_paragraph: Mad Mike was already in his 60s when he tried to overthrow the Marxist president of the Seychelles.

headline: Konrad Steffen Was a Prophet of Climate Change, and its Victim
abstract: The very ice melt he warned would threaten the planet turned out to be his undoing.
lead_paragraph: The very ice melt he warned would threaten the planet turned out to be his undoing.

headline: Mimi Jones Understood the Power of Public Resistance From a Young Age
abstract: When she was 17, she leapt into a segregated Florida swimming pool — and landed on the front page.
lead_paragraph: When she was 17, she leapt into a segregated Florida swimming pool — and landed on the front page.

headline: Helen Reddy Embodied Her Feminist Anthem, ‘I Am Woman’
abstract: She hit No. 1 with that song, and her own life was proof of what it took to get there.
lead_paragraph: She hit No. 1 with that song, and her own life was proof of what it took to get there.

headline: Stanley Chera Was a Mogul Who Made Covid-19 Personal for Trump
abstract: The New York real estate titan was in some ways a foil to the president — and was on his mind as he went to Walter Reed.
lead_paragraph: The New York real estate titan was in some ways a foil to the president — and was on his mind as he went to Walter Reed.

headline: Tom Seaver Was the Greatest Met Ever. The Mets Still Broke His Heart.
abstract: He put the franchise on the map — and was traded away in return.
lead_paragraph: He put the franchise on the map — and was traded away in return.

headline: Shere Hite Explained How Women Orgasm, and Was Hated for It
abstract: “The Hite Report” provoked a sexual revolution. Then came death threats and the paparazzi.
lead_paragraph: “The Hite Report” provoked a sexual revolution. Then came death threats and the paparazzi.

headline: The Afterlife of Breonna Taylor
abstract: People shared her name and image in grief and solidarity, but why didn’t it feel like enough?
lead_paragraph: People shared her name and image in grief and solidarity, but why didn’t it feel like enough?

headline: Cecilia Chiang Lost Everything in China, and Built It Back in California
abstract: She twice escaped war in China, and eventually landed in an America that was hungry for a new kind of Asian cuisine.
lead_paragraph: She twice escaped war in China, and eventually landed in an America that was hungry for a new kind of Asian cuisine.

headline: Sy Sperling Brought Dignity to the Bald
abstract: You didn’t need to be ashamed to join the Hair Club for Men.
lead_paragraph: You didn’t need to be ashamed to join the Hair Club for Men.

headline: Want the Good Life? This Philosopher Suggests Learning From Cats
abstract: In “Feline Philosophy,” John Gray concedes that we “cannot know what it is like to be a cat,” but that doesn’t stop him from trying.
lead_paragraph: An uncertain fate awaits the most bracing and contrarian writers: Will the insights they offer still come across as stingingly original if the disillusion they so often recommend becomes commonplace?

headline: Mary J. Wilson Was Baltimore’s First Black Senior Zookeeper
abstract: She had no specialized training, but she did have a way with the fiercest and most vulnerable animals.
lead_paragraph: She had no specialized training, but she did have a way with the fiercest and most vulnerable animals.

headline: Bill Withers Was a Working Man Who Became a Star
abstract: He went from manual labor to musical phenomenon in a matter of months, but his struggles were always there in the music.
lead_paragraph: He went from manual labor to musical phenomenon in a matter of months, but his struggles were always there in the music.

headline: Denny O’Neil Changed the World of Superheroes
abstract: The comic-book writer took stock of a country’s turmoil and put it into his work.
lead_paragraph: The comic-book writer took stock of a country’s turmoil and put it into his work.

headline: Tad Jones Lived Alone in Nature, Until Nature Revolted
abstract: He spent decades under the redwoods. Then came this summer’s fire season.
lead_paragraph: He spent decades under the redwoods. Then came this summer’s fire season.

headline: Stanley Crouch Was a Critic Who Didn’t Hold Back Punches
abstract: He was an intellectual, a holder of court, a jazz connoisseur, a snob and a contrarian of the Black condition.
lead_paragraph: He was an intellectual, a holder of court, a jazz connoisseur, a snob and a contrarian of the Black condition.

headline: Chadwick Boseman Played Great Men, and Created One
abstract: He built his career portraying giants of American history. But it was a fictional character that transformed him into a kind of political figure.
lead_paragraph: He built his career portraying giants of American history. But it was a fictional character that transformed him into a kind of political figure.

headline: James Harvey Celebrated the Pleasure of a Packed Movie Theater
abstract: No one was more passionate about the cinema, one more experience we lost this year.
lead_paragraph: No one was more passionate about the cinema, one more experience we lost this year.

headline: Escape the Room, Escape the World
abstract: A family takes refuge from life’s sharper edges by solving puzzles together.
lead_paragraph: On a warm Saturday evening, my 6-year-old drew invitations by hand and passed them out to his brother, his father and me. You are invited! Dress nice!

headline: Moms on the Frontlines
abstract: Health care workers are still fighting to keep their homes and communities safe.
lead_paragraph: When I spoke to Dr. Stephanie Whitener, 41, an anesthesia critical care physician and mother of two, the parent-teacher organization at her son’s elementary school was planning an in-person happy hour for teachers. “I spent yesterday trying to rally all the parents I knew in health care to stop it, because of the risk to them, and also to in-person learning,” said Dr. Whitener, who lives in Charleston, S.C.

headline: The Year in Good News
abstract: In a bleak year, our listeners offer some brightness — from all over the world.
lead_paragraph: The idea for this episode came in mid-November, when The Daily team received an email about the upcoming release of the hip-hop artist Megan Thee Stallion’s album “Good News.” It had been a wild year for Megan: She said she suffered gunshot wounds in July; months later, she appeared on Cardi B’s hit single “WAP.”

headline: Pundit Accountability
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: Americans under the age of 40 vote at relatively low rates. They also lean left politically. The same is true of Latinos and Asian-Americans.

headline: Isolation appears to have helped homeless populations avoid the worst of the pandemic.
abstract: Early in the pandemic, health officials were terrified that the virus would decimate America’s homeless populations, the half-million people who live in shelters or on the streets. Those same specialists now say they are relieved that street encampments and homeless shelters did not suffer the same devastation as nursing homes.
lead_paragraph: Early in the pandemic, health officials were terrified that the virus would decimate America’s homeless populations, the half-million people who live in shelters or on the streets. Those same specialists now say they are relieved that street encampments and homeless shelters did not suffer the same devastation as nursing homes.

headline: After 32 Years, Charges Are Filed in Kidnapping of 9-Year-Old Girl
abstract: Witnesses saw Michaela Garecht kidnapped in Northern California in 1988. This week the authorities charged an incarcerated man with murder during a kidnapping.
lead_paragraph: For more than 30 years, the kidnapping of a 9-year-old girl, Michaela Garecht, has remained a mystery in Northern California, a crime witnessed by only a few people, including a child who was her best friend.

headline: ‘Dyker Lights’: Brighter Displays, Fewer Tourists
abstract: The famous holiday displays in Dyker Heights are attracting smaller crowds, but some homeowners are determined to bring cheer.
lead_paragraph: The famous holiday displays in Dyker Heights are attracting smaller crowds, but some homeowners are determined to bring cheer.

headline: Trump Threw the Stimulus a Curveball
abstract: The president threatened to upend a hard-fought compromise, but he may not get what he wants.
lead_paragraph: Not even a day after lawmakers agreed on a $900 billion stimulus package, President Trump called it a “disgrace” and suggested that he might reject the heavily negotiated bill at the eleventh hour.

headline: The Department Store That Does Holiday Cheer Like No Other
abstract: With its fanciful window displays and winter grotto, Macy’s has long been synonymous with Christmas in New York.
lead_paragraph: In this series for T, the author Reggie Nadelson revisits New York institutions that have defined cool for decades, from time-honored restaurants to unsung dives.

headline: This Band Is Fun on TikTok. In Belarus, It’s Serious.
abstract: Molchat Doma, a synth-pop trio, has become an unlikely social media star. Back home, its music was the soundtrack to a traumatic year.
lead_paragraph: MINSK, Belarus — On a recent Saturday night, Hide, a trendy nightclub in Belarus’s capital, was packed. More than 600 clubgoers were jostling for a view of the stage in the tiny venue, hidden in an inner-city courtyard.

headline: No Tweets, No Interviews: Jimmy Lai’s Unusual Bail Conditions
abstract: The Hong Kong pro-democracy media tycoon is freed on bail, but was placed under house arrest and barred from meeting foreign officials and publishing articles.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A Hong Kong judge granted the pro-democracy media tycoon Jimmy Lai bail on Wednesday, but imposed extensive restrictions barring him from using social media, giving interviews or leaving his home, stoking concerns about the deterioration of free speech under a national security law.

headline: Our Best Reporting of 2020
abstract: Also this week: Women on the front lines of climate activism
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Climate Fwd: newsletter. The New York Times climate team emails readers once a week with stories and insights about climate change. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

headline: Meet Alex Padilla, California’s Next Senator
abstract: Wednesday: He will be the state’s first Latino senator. Also: Shirley Weber will be secretary of state.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: What You Get for $1.25 Million
abstract: A sculptural concrete house in La Selva Beach, Calif.; an 1880 Victorian in New Orleans; and a converted 19th-century fire station in Highland Park, Ill.
lead_paragraph: A sculptural concrete house in La Selva Beach, Calif.; an 1880 Victorian in New Orleans; and a converted 19th-century fire station in Highland Park, Ill.

headline: $1.25 Million Homes in California, Louisiana and Illinois
abstract: A sculptural concrete house in Santa Cruz County, an 1880 Victorian in New Orleans and a converted 19th-century fire station in Highland Park.
lead_paragraph: In 1972, Mary Gordon, a landscape architect, designed an organic concrete house near the beach in an unincorporated area of Santa Cruz County, which she intended to use as retirement quarters for herself and her husband. Constructed by boat builders — with tubular forms protruding from a rounded base, including a windowed cylinder emerging from the top like a periscope — the house ultimately became Ms. Gordon’s studio and a showplace for her gardening talents. Seven years ago, it was sold to a second owner, who made it homier by adding a stainless-steel spiral staircase inside and improving the kitchen and bathroom.

headline: Why Israel Faces a Fourth Election in Just Two Years
abstract: What to know as Israel gears up for another vote, this time set for March 23.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — With Israel heading to its fourth election in two years after the collapse of its government, many Israelis are wondering whether it’s a case of too much democracy.

headline: Built Into a Mountain Outside Cape Town
abstract: This four-bedroom home, nestled in the side of a mountain overlooking Hout Bay, in southwestern South Africa, is on the market for $760,000.
lead_paragraph: This four-bedroom home, nestled in the side of a mountain overlooking Hout Bay, in southwestern South Africa, is on the market for $760,000.

headline: House Hunting in South Africa: A Mountainside Perch for $760,000
abstract: Reduced interest rates and transfer duties are luring buyers back to the housing market in South Africa, but the path to recovery remains rocky.
lead_paragraph: This four-bedroom house sits at the foot of the Skoorsteenberg peaks in Hout Bay, a coastal suburb of Cape Town, South Africa, where hikers and mountain climbers flock for views of the valley below and the Atlantic Ocean on the horizon.

headline: ‘The Midnight Sky’ Review: It’s the End of the World, in the Arctic
abstract: George Clooney takes on his biggest challenge, as both actor and director, yet: Saving humanity itself.
lead_paragraph: George Clooney turns off his movie-star charm for much of “The Midnight Sky,” a futuristic adventure he stars in and directed. He plays Augustine Lofthouse, a scientist who, as the movie begins — in 2049, “3 weeks after the event,” a deliberately vague onscreen text puts it — has lived to become something of a prophet.

headline: Indian airports are struggling with the ban on flights from Britain.
abstract: Passengers flying into India from Britain and other European countries said they spent hours waiting in lines at the airport over the past two days as the authorities struggled to implement new quarantine measures intended to counter the spread of a coronavirus variant that has emerged in Britain.
lead_paragraph: Passengers flying into India from Britain and other European countries said they spent hours waiting in lines at the airport over the past two days as the authorities struggled to implement new quarantine measures intended to counter the spread of a coronavirus variant that has emerged in Britain.

headline: ‘It’s More Money Than I Imagined.’ So He’s Giving Some of It Away.
abstract: How Jeremy O. Harris has turned his good fortune into grants, commissions and donations to other playwrights, and to libraries in need.
lead_paragraph: Jeremy O. Harris is a playwright, a performer, and a provocateur. And now, he’s a philanthropist.

headline: An Online Show that Runs and Runs (and Runs)
abstract: “Stars in the House,” a variety show and fund-raiser, started just after the Broadway shutdown. Some 250 episodes later, its creators won’t quit.
lead_paragraph: In late February, Seth Rudetsky and his husband, James Wesley, finished hosting a Broadway-themed cruise that meandered through the Eastern Caribbean with talent like Lillias White and Beth Leavel aboard. As Covid-19 fears grew, Rudetsky, a Sirius XM radio host, concert accompanist and comedy writer, flew to Scottsdale, Ariz., for a show with the singer Norm Lewis. Wesley soon joined him in Houston to host a political fund-raiser. That was on Thursday, March 12, the day that New York State announced that Broadway would shutter.

headline: Actors and Writers and Now, Congressional Lobbyists
abstract: Be an #ArtsHero started with a failed effort to extend unemployment benefits. It’s gone on to be a prime proponent of the message: Cultural work is labor.
lead_paragraph: Art is what binds us. It illuminates the human condition. It’s good for the soul.

headline: The Hotels Reimagining Their Rooms as Stylish Work Spaces
abstract: Throughout the pandemic, the hospitality industry has found new ways to attract and serve guests — including providing them with a desk for the day.
lead_paragraph: For some people fortunate enough to be working from home during the pandemic, forgoing a commute and sending emails from the living room has been a surprisingly welcome adjustment. For others — especially those sharing small spaces with loved ones — not so much. Where can you take a call when every room in your home is occupied by another family member, when a pipe bursts or when deafening jackhammering begins outside your window? Hotels, which have been hit hard during this time of social distancing and travel restrictions, have in recent months begun offering a possible solution, repositioning their rooms — in some instances by actually swapping out beds for luxurious desks and comfortable chairs — as picturesque offices in which to work in peace for a reduced day rate.

headline: Covid Antibody Drugs Go Unused as Need Soars
abstract: While such treatments are promising, their use has been slowed by testing lags, overwhelmed hospitals and a perception the therapies are only for well-connected people.
lead_paragraph: When federal regulators approved two antibody treatments last month for emergency use in high-risk Covid-19 patients, doctors worried there would not be enough to go around.

headline: Rental protections, nursing home funding, food stamps: Here’s what’s included in the stimulus bill.
abstract: The $900 billion stimulus bill passed by Congress this week is meant to address the needs of millions of Americans who have weathered the effects of the coronavirus pandemic for months, even as many federal programs to provide aid ran thin or expired.
lead_paragraph: The $900 billion stimulus bill passed by Congress this week is meant to address the needs of millions of Americans who have weathered the effects of the coronavirus pandemic for months, even as many federal programs to provide aid ran thin or expired.

headline: Your New Year’s Spread
abstract: Melissa Clark has four recipes for ideal holiday snacking. Make them soon.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark has a lament in The Times this week. It’s about missing the holiday parties we can’t have this year on account of the pandemic. “There’ll be no sipping eggnog in red lipstick and spangles,” she wrote, “no parking myself in front of platters of Camembert and Stilton, not even any sleeves of Ritz crackers with that unidentifiable orange cheese spread I look forward to year after year.”

headline: The State of the Virus Ahead of the Christmas Holiday
abstract: A look at this week’s news from the team tracking the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: A look at this week’s news from the team tracking the coronavirus.

headline: 23 Are Rescued After Baltimore Building Explosion
abstract: The explosion happened on the 16th floor of the Baltimore Gas and Electric Company building. The cause was not immediately clear, but the utility said it was likely a construction accident.
lead_paragraph: Nearly two dozen people were rescued on Wednesday morning after an explosion in an office building in downtown Baltimore caused part of the structure’s roof to collapse, the authorities said.

headline: Advocating and Agitating, Connecting and Inventing
abstract: With their field rocked by unprecedented challenges in 2020, these people and groups — some notable, some new — stepped into the breach.
lead_paragraph: There are producers serving on committees. Performers signing petitions. Then there is Andrew Lloyd Webber, the most successful living musical theater composer, who offered his body in an effort to resuscitate his beloved industry. The 72-year-old Briton, whose hit list includes “Cats” and “The Phantom of the Opera,” in August joined a vaccine trial in England, taking a shot of the experimental drug in his left arm while wearing a “Save Our Stages” T-shirt. And he’s been a relentless champion of theater’s return: In July he hosted the first West End pandemic show at his Palladium Theater in London (“This is a rather sad sight,” he said as he looked at the socially distanced audience), and he continued to press forward, recently presenting a holiday pantomime show whose audience included Prince William and his family.

headline: What to Know About the Covid Antibody Drugs That Could Help Many
abstract: Here’s information about who these therapies can help, how much they cost and how to find out if you can get them where you live.
lead_paragraph: Two new antibody treatments have shown promise in keeping high-risk Covid-19 patients out of the hospital.

headline: Ancient DNA Is Changing How We Think About the Caribbean
abstract: New research delivers surprising findings about Indigenous people in the region before contact with Europeans.
lead_paragraph: In 1492, Christopher Columbus touched land for the first time in the Americas, reaching the Bahamas, Hispaniola (present-day Dominican Republic and Haiti) and eastern Cuba. After he returned to Spain he reported that he had encountered islands rich in gold. A few years later his brother Bartholomew, who also traveled to the Americas, reported that Hispaniola had a large population whose labor and land could be put to the advantage of the Spanish crown. He estimated the population at 1.1 million people.

headline: Ancient DNA Shows Humans Settled Caribbean in 2 Distinct Waves
abstract: Millions of people living on the islands today inherited genes from the people who made them home before Europeans arrived.
lead_paragraph: When Dr. Juan Aviles went to school in Puerto Rico, teachers taught him that the original people of the island, the Taino, vanished soon after Spain colonized it. Violence, disease and forced labor wiped them out, destroying their culture and language, the teachers said, and the colonizers repopulated the island with enslaved people, including Indigenous people from Central and South America and Africans.

headline: A President Unhappy, Unleashed and Unpredictable
abstract: President Trump remains the most powerful man in the world, but powerless to achieve what he most wants: to avoid leaving office as a loser.
lead_paragraph: With four weeks left in President Trump’s term, he is at perhaps his most unleashed — and, as events of the past few days have demonstrated, at the most unpredictable point in his presidency.

headline: These Bacon and Eggs Practically Cook Themselves
abstract: A big holiday breakfast is great — unless you’re the one stuck making it. This sheet-pan recipe is the solution.
lead_paragraph: There’s a way to plates of crispy bacon and sunny-side-up eggs that doesn’t demand you stand over a hot skillet and get greasy. “Frying” bacon in a hot oven, then cooking eggs on the same sheet pan, turns out a meal for four in 15 minutes and requires almost no attention.

headline: The Workweek Diary of a Plant-Loving Home Décor Guru
abstract: Justina Blakeney preaches the gospel of infusing your home with good vibes, thoughtful intentions, and lots and lots of plants.
lead_paragraph: “The home is not a static place,” the home décor maven Justina Blakeney said, reflecting on the importance of design in our living spaces. “Your home needs to grow and change as you grow and change. It can support you, if you put your mind to it.”

headline: Switzerland begins Covid-19 vaccinations.
abstract: GENEVA — A 90-year-old woman living in a retirement home received the first Covid-19 inoculation in Switzerland on Wednesday as the Alpine nation began its Covid-19 vaccination program.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — A 90-year-old woman living in a retirement home received the first Covid-19 inoculation in Switzerland on Wednesday as the Alpine nation began its Covid-19 vaccination program.

headline: Rebecca Luker, a Broadway Star for Three Decades, Dies at 59
abstract: Her Broadway career, fueled by her crystal-clear operatic soprano, brought her Tony Award nominations for “Show Boat,” “The Music Man” and “Mary Poppins.”
lead_paragraph: Rebecca Luker, the actress and singer who in a lauded three-decade career on the New York stage embodied the essence of the Broadway musical ingénue in hit revivals of “Show Boat,” “The Sound of Music” and “The Music Man,” died on Wednesday in a hospital in Manhattan. She was 59.

headline: Meet the People Who Can’t Bring You ‘Messiah’ This Year
abstract: Listen as nine performers guide you through the emotional arc of Handel’s classic, from comfort to grief to jubilation.
lead_paragraph: Every year, Handel’s “Messiah” is a communal ritual — a glittering parade of recitatives, arias and choruses that binds listeners and performers together in a story of promise, betrayal and redemption.

headline: How Mink, Like Humans, Were Slammed by the Coronavirus
abstract: Rampaging infections at farms caused scandal, scientific head-scratching and a search for a vaccine — for mink.
lead_paragraph: Denmark’s mink industry is gone, a victim of the coronavirus. The nation killed all its 17 million mink because of fears of a mutation in the virus that had spread from mink to people.

headline: 2020 Popcast Listener Mailbag: Taylor, Dua, MGK and More
abstract: Answering your questions about the year’s biggest stars, and also some of its curious flops.
lead_paragraph: This wild, wildly disorienting year is coming to a close, and as usual, the Popcast opened up its listener mailbag to tackle the questions that have been keeping listeners up at night (when they’re not up at night listening to Popcast, that is).

headline: A New Population of Blue Whales Was Discovered Hiding in the Indian Ocean
abstract: The whales in the group seem to sing a unique song.
lead_paragraph: Weighing up to 380,000 pounds and stretching some 100 feet long, the blue whale — the largest creature to have ever lived on Earth — might at first seem difficult for human eyes and ears to miss.

headline: Reclaiming the Tiki Bar
abstract: Tiki bars are a beverage industry mainstay — with a painful and underexamined past. Can the format be repaired?
lead_paragraph: It is an unquestionably difficult time for the hospitality industry. Every day, another restaurant shutters, one more bar pulls its steel gate down for good. Since its invention, one kind of watering hole has seen America through its most grueling times: the tiki bar.

headline: Clubhouse Makes Way for Influencers
abstract: Tech investors have warmed to the idea that being a content creator is a legitimate form of business.
lead_paragraph: Nearly every social media platform has turned its top users into stars: YouTubers, Viners, Dubsmashers, TikTokers, even LinkedIn influencers. Now, Clubhouse, an audio-only app that built its name with tech investors before expanding into entertainment, is trying to cultivate its own local celebrities.

headline: 5 Die in ‘Catastrophic’ Crash That Splits Car in Half
abstract: Four recent high school graduates from Yonkers, N.Y., were killed when a speeding driver collided with their car.
lead_paragraph: The surveillance video shows a car that streaked across the avenue like a comet and then burst into flames as it collided with an oncoming sedan, splitting it clean in half.

headline: ‘Fertility Is a Team Sport’: Father’s Health Tied to Pregnancy Loss
abstract: Conditions like hypertension, high cholesterol, obesity and diabetes in a father may affect whether a pregnancy reaches full term.
lead_paragraph: A father’s poor health before conception may increase the risk for pregnancy loss, a new study suggests.

headline: Virginia Shackles, Painter of Vivid Scenery, Dies at 99
abstract: Ms. Shackles loved to paint cliffs and ocean scenes in the coastal city of Monterey, Calif. She died of complications from Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Our 2nd Annual STEM Writing Contest
abstract: We invite students to choose an issue or question in science, technology, engineering, math or health, then write an engaging 500-word explanation. Contest Dates: Jan. 19-March 2, 2021.
lead_paragraph: Note: Register for our live webinar on Jan. 14 on teaching informational writing with a STEM theme.

headline: With a Beloved Cafe Threatened, Broadway Stars Put on a Show
abstract: Fans in the theater world, including Matthew Broderick and Debra Messing, will appear in a Christmas Day telethon to try to save the West Bank Cafe.
lead_paragraph: When Tom D’Angora got the news that the West Bank Cafe — a popular show business hangout whose basement theater hosted the first “Sunday in the Park With George” rehearsals and Joan Rivers’s final performance — was in danger of closing, he sprang into action.

headline: George Clooney on ‘The Midnight Sky’ and Donald Trump
abstract: His new movie is on Netflix, but the actor-director says theaters won’t go away and Hollywood will be fine. He’s not so sure about Washington.
lead_paragraph: In the Zoom era, the room behind you can really tell a story, and so it goes with George Clooney. On a recent video call to talk about his new Netflix movie, “The Midnight Sky,” Clooney gestured to the living room shelves behind him, which had been hastily stocked with books and booze.

headline: Canada approves the Moderna vaccine, paving the way for inoculations in its vast Far North.
abstract: Canada’s regulator approved Moderna’s vaccine on Wednesday, a move that will make it easier to inoculate people in the country’s remote and northern regions.
lead_paragraph: Canada’s regulator approved Moderna’s vaccine on Wednesday, a move that will make it easier to inoculate people in the country’s remote and northern regions.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: More areas in England lock down over new variant.
lead_paragraph: Struggling to curb the spread of a potentially more infectious variant of the coronavirus, the British government on Wednesday ordered more sections of England to be placed under restrictive lockdown.

headline: What’s in Our Queue? ‘Attack on Titan’
abstract: I'm a senior news assistant on The Times's Culture desk. Here's what I've been watching, reading and listening to.
lead_paragraph: I'm a senior news assistant on The Times's Culture desk. Here's what I've been watching, reading and listening to.

headline: How Pop and Jazz Wrapped Up the Past in 16 Boxed Sets
abstract: Reissues and deluxe editions of albums by PJ Harvey, Lil Peep, Charles Mingus and others provide fresh looks at familiar works, and the creative processes that birthed them.
lead_paragraph: (Virgin/UMC; three CDs, $63.89; three LPs, $75.98)

headline: Review: ‘Bridgerton’ Is a Sparkly Period Piece With a Difference
abstract: The first Netflix series from Shonda Rhimes’s company updates the genre with modern race and gender attitudes (and lots of skin).
lead_paragraph: Netflix’s “Bridgerton” begins like any other British period drama about the fancy folk. The sun shines on Grosvenor Square. Horses pull fine carriages along a resplendent street. A dapper gentleman out for a stroll nods his head to a passer-by.

headline: A New Pinocchio Film Returns to the Tale’s Dark Origins
abstract: The Italian director Matteo Garrone hopes to surprise audiences this Christmas with a very literal retelling of the children’s classic.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Carlo Collodi’s “Pinocchio” is one of the world’s best-loved children’s books, translated into over 280 languages and dialects, and the subject of countless films and television series.

headline: Pennsylvania man is accused of casting Trump vote for his dead mother.
abstract: The Trump campaign had circulated the mother’s name while arguing there was widespread voter fraud that helped propel Joseph R. Biden Jr. to victory.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after the November election, the Trump campaign circulated on its Facebook and Twitter accounts, as well as its website, the names of seven dead Americans in the battleground states of Georgia and Pennsylvania. The dead people were used to cast votes in last month’s election, the campaign claimed, pointing to the incidents as evidence of widespread voter fraud that enabled President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory.

headline: The Wildest Animal News From 2020
abstract: These are the stories about birds, bugs, fish and mammals that surprised and delighted readers the most this year.
lead_paragraph: It was a rough year for Homo sapiens. The coronavirus pandemic highlighted our vulnerabilities in a natural world that is constantly changing. Many were pushed to find new levels of resolve and creativity to survive.

headline: Salman Toor, a Painter at Home in Two Worlds
abstract: A brilliant debut at the Whitney Museum by the artist — born in Pakistan and based in New York — refreshes figurative painting by using it as a means to explore identity.
lead_paragraph: Salman Toor’s evocative, tenderly executed paintings begin to pluck at your heartstrings almost as soon as you see them. The 15 examples of new and recent work that form “How Will I Know,” the artist’s brilliant New York institutional debut at the Whitney Museum of American Art tell the stories of lanky, slightly rubbery dark-haired young men, gentle souls who wouldn’t hurt a flea. The narrative import zigzags from the personal to the social and political and back.

headline: Expanding Access and Instilling Faith in Vaccines
abstract: One reader disagrees with suspending intellectual property rights. Another says past testing helped safely speed up the coronavirus vaccines. Also: Major League Baseball and the Negro Leagues.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: 13 New Books to Watch For in January
abstract: Essays from Joan Didion, George Saunders on why fiction matters and plenty more.
lead_paragraph: If your days are feeling monotonous, you might find entertainment and variety in this flurry of new books about subjects that span the globe. A Danish writer’s collected memoirs trace her effort to nurture artistic ambition in spite of a grim family life and, later, addiction. A biography revisits the lives of two pioneering sisters who paved the way for women to practice medicine in the United States. And a debut novel imagines a romance between two enslaved men in Civil War-era Mississippi. No matter what you’re seeking, you can find it in the pages of a book next month.

headline: U.K. Tightens Restrictions as Alarm About Virus Variant Grows
abstract: British officials said severely curtailing human contact was the only way to protect people. Efforts to restart trade stalled, with more than 5,000 trucks stuck at English ports.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British authorities put even more areas of England under the tightest restrictions on Wednesday as officials struggled to slow the spread of a coronavirus variant that is potentially more infectious than those that have already wreaked havoc around the world.

headline: The Evictions Are Coming. Housing Activists Are Ready.
abstract: Orders to halt evictions in New York expire soon. What happens next?
lead_paragraph: Housing activists in New York have spent much of the year preparing for the end of it. Tenant evictions have been halted or delayed by coronavirus relief measures, for the most part, until January 2021.

headline: Trump Corrupted the Presidential Pardon. Biden Must Repair It.
abstract: There are clear ways to reform the pardon process to work as the founders intended.
lead_paragraph: This editorial has been updated to reflect breaking news.

headline: Nobody Is Singing for This Kind of Christmas Storm
abstract: Forecasters predict blizzards in the Midwest. Freezing temperatures in the South. Flooding and power outages in the Northeast. And maybe tornadoes in Florida.
lead_paragraph: [Read the latest updates on the Christmas Eve winter storm.]

headline: Which Animal Best Embodies 2020?
abstract: It was a rough year for Homo sapiens.
lead_paragraph: It was a rough year for Homo sapiens.

headline: How Trump Has Jeopardized Stimulus Relief
abstract: The president’s demand that Congress amend a giant coronavirus relief and government spending bill has raised the unexpected prospect that help may no longer be days away.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Tuesday unexpectedly threatened to reject a far-reaching, catchall spending package that includes $900 billion in coronavirus relief and funding for the government through Sept. 30. The threat in effect dropped a depth charge on the Republican Party, but beyond politics, the coming days will determine whether his actions actually deny or delay relief to struggling Americans and shut down the government.

headline: Is Trump Abusing Presidential Pardons?
abstract: Readers are disturbed by what one calls “politically motivated pardons to corrupt cronies.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Trump Vetoes Military Spending Bill, Setting Up a Congressional Showdown
abstract: The legislation passed with a veto-proof majority in the House and Senate, but it is unclear whether Congress will override the president.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Wednesday made good on his promise to veto the annual military policy bill, setting up what could be the first veto override of his presidency after both chambers of Congress overwhelmingly approved the legislation.

headline: The Year the Fed Changed Forever
abstract: Jerome H. Powell’s central bank slashed rates, bought bonds in huge sums and rolled out never-before-tried loan programs that shifted its identity. The backlash is already beginning.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, rang in 2020 in Florida, where he was celebrating his son’s wedding, his work life seemed to be entering a period of relative calm. President Trump’s public attacks on the central bank had eased up after 18 months of steady criticism, and the trade war with China seemed to be cooling, brightening the outlook for markets and the economy.

headline: At Home’s Best of 2020
abstract: What we watched, read, listened to and cooked this year.
lead_paragraph: Welcome. It’s the time of year when “best of” lists proliferate, when critics look back on the previous 12 months and select their favorite stuff. The Times’s critics’ 2020 lists are splendid; I’ve already tracked down most of Manohla Dargis’s film picks and a bunch of the best podcasts and have them all ready to go in my various queues.

headline: Modern Love Podcast: What the Silence Said
abstract: Two marriages dissolve without a sound.
lead_paragraph: When Laura Pritchett and her husband divorced after two decades of marriage, their “little Colorado mountain town” could barely tell. It was quiet compared to the dramatic natural disasters that were afflicting the area — like flooding and wildfires. There were no raised voices, no feelings of fury.

headline: Jack Lenor Larsen, Innovative Textile Designer, Dies at 93
abstract: He blended ancient techniques and modern technology to weave fabrics that are in the collections of MoMA and the Louvre, which gave him a one-man retrospective.
lead_paragraph: Jack Lenor Larsen, a textile designer who blended ancient techniques and modern technology to weave fabrics that enlivened postwar American homes and workplaces and in the process became an international presence, died on Tuesday at his home in East Hampton, N.Y. He was 93.

headline: Pfizer Seals Deal With U.S. for 100 Million More Vaccine Doses
abstract: The company agreed to deliver the additional doses of its coronavirus vaccine by the end of July, helping address a looming shortage.
lead_paragraph: The Trump administration and Pfizer announced a deal on Wednesday for the pharmaceutical company to provide an additional 100 million doses of its coronavirus vaccine by the end of July, easing a potential shortage.

headline: Make Your Own Party Blower
abstract: Even if your New Year’s Eve celebrations are smaller this year, you’ll still need festive supplies. Here’s how to make your own party blower.
lead_paragraph: Even if your New Year’s Eve celebrations are smaller this year, you’ll still need festive supplies. Here’s how to make your own party blower.

headline: The Modern Love Podcast: 10 Episodes to Binge Through the Holidays
abstract: 2020 has been a year of isolation and grief, but there’s always room for love.
lead_paragraph: The Modern Love podcast got a revamp this year, with two new hosts and a fresh sound produced entirely by The New York Times. And, of course, there were new stories to tell. Some were unique to the moment — like a serendipitous romance that bloomed on a train ride from Paris to Barcelona, then was abruptly stunted by lockdown. For other stories, we dug into the archives to unearth some of our favorite essays and check back in with the authors.

headline: Amar’e Stoudemire Is a Coach Now. But Don’t Call Him That.
abstract: Stoudemire has reunited with his Phoenix Suns cohort of Steve Nash and Mike D’Antoni on the Nets’ staff. It’s weird to him, too.
lead_paragraph: As recently as late July, Amar’e Stoudemire was seemingly as far away as possible from joining the Nets’ coaching staff and a high-wattage reunion of Phoenix Suns alumni in Brooklyn. Stoudemire was still playing abroad — and helping Maccabi Tel Aviv win a 54th league championship in Israel.

headline: Chinese Swimmer’s Doping Ban Is Lifted After Accusation of Racism
abstract: Lawyers for Sun Yang, a three-time Olympic champion, presented evidence that one of the arbitrators who issued his eight-year suspension had made racist comments about China on social media.
lead_paragraph: Sun Yang, a three-time Olympic champion and one of China’s most celebrated athletes, had his eight-year ban from swimming suddenly overturned Wednesday by Switzerland’s federal court, which upheld a challenge questioning the neutrality of one of the panelists who had issued the penalty.

headline: Globetrotting
abstract: Your sneak preview of books coming out in 2021 from around the world, updated each season.
lead_paragraph: Your sneak preview of books coming out in 2021 from around the world, updated each season.

headline: New Signs of Economic Distress Emerge as Trump Imperils Aid Deal
abstract: A decline in consumer income and spending poses a further challenge to the recovery as jobless claims remain high and benefits approach a cutoff.
lead_paragraph: With the fate of a federal aid package suddenly thrown into doubt by President Trump, economic data on Wednesday showed why the help is so desperately needed.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: Antibody treatments have shown promise, but tens of thousands of doses are sitting unused in hospital refrigerators.
lead_paragraph: When President Trump fell ill with the coronavirus over two months ago, he took an antibody cocktail, made by Regeneron, and later promoted the treatment as a “cure.”

headline: N.B.A. Postpones Rockets Game, an Early Test of the League’s Virus Rules
abstract: Multiple positive or inconclusive coronavirus tests, and a health protocol breach, left the Houston Rockets with too few players to compete in their season opener Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: In an immediate blow to the N.B.A.’s attempt to stage a season without the protection of a restricted-access bubble, league officials were forced to postpone the Houston Rockets’ season opener on Wednesday night against the Oklahoma City Thunder when the Rockets were unable to field the required minimum of eight players in uniform.

headline: Blackwater’s Bullets Scarred Iraqis. Trump’s Pardon Renewed the Pain.
abstract: Iraqi witnesses against Blackwater guards were promised justice after a mass killing in Baghdad in 2007. ‘Today,’ one said, the bullets still in his leg, ‘they proved to me it was just theater.’
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq — Haider Ahmed Rabia was stuck in traffic in Baghdad 13 years ago when guards with the American security contractor Blackwater opened fire with machine guns and grenade launchers, killing or wounding at least 31 Iraqi civilians. He still carries some of those bullets in his legs.

headline: Stimulus, Pardons, Blue Whales: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: ‘Blue’ Gene Tyranny, Whose Music Melded Genres, Dies at 75
abstract: A creator of modern music as a teenager, he later juggled a breezy pop sensibility with conceptual rigor. He was an important collaborator with the composer Robert Ashley.
lead_paragraph: Robert Sheff, a composer and pianist who worked under the name “Blue” Gene Tyranny as a solo performer and a collaborator with artists including Iggy Pop, the composer Robert Ashley and the jazz composer and arranger Carla Bley, died on Dec. 12 in hospice care in Long Island City, Queens. He was 75.

headline: Now Airing on the Local News in Tennessee: Ads for Georgia Candidates
abstract: Nearly $470 million is set to be spent on ads for the Georgia Senate runoff races. With the airwaves already saturated, the candidates are heading across state lines to seek any possible advantage.
lead_paragraph: The Georgia Senate runoffs are so awash in political cash that the ad wars are spilling into neighboring states.

headline: Pulse Oximeters May Be Less Accurate for Black People. Should You Use One?
abstract: Although a new study showed the devices are more error-prone in people with darker skin, doctors say they are still useful for anyone monitoring Covid-19 at home.
lead_paragraph: Home pulse oximeters have been the personal tech gadget of 2020 and a reassuring way for patients to monitor their health at home during Covid-19.

headline: As Evidence Mounts that Navalny Was Poisoned by State, Russians Just Sigh
abstract: Aleksei Navalny, the top critic of President Putin, has aired evidence that he was poisoned by his own government. Russians have responded with fear, disbelief and a lot of apathy.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Vitaly Mansky, a filmmaker, posed in front of the headquarters of Russia’s domestic intelligence agency brandishing a pair of checkered blue boxers. He was immediately detained by the police.

headline: Israeli Election, Take Four: Conservatives vs. Conservatives
abstract: After the center-left failed in three elections to oust Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, the fourth one is shaping up into a contest among right-wing leaders.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — For three elections in a row, Israel’s conservative prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, has managed to stave off challenges from the center-left.

headline: A Middle-Aged Christmas
abstract: The meaning of Christmas nostalgia in the middle of life’s journey.
lead_paragraph: Marching toward middle age is a sequence of older-than moments, when you realize that you’ve passed some famous age that seemed impossibly distant as a child. First you pass the prodigies: Older than William Pitt the Younger when he became prime minister, older than Donna Tartt when she published “The Secret History,” older than Alexander the Great when he conquered Persia. Then come the athletes: When you reach your later 30s, you realize that if you had actually become a baseball star, you would now be Kirk Gibson gimping to the plate, an old man in baseball years.

headline: Dear Santa, Why Are You Behind Plexiglass?
abstract: All over the country, the annual Christmas ritual for children looks and feels different this year.
lead_paragraph: Santa Claus is different this year. He wears a mask and his lap is mostly off limits. Outdoors he waves to boys and girls from a safe distance, and indoors a sheet of plexiglass separates him from his visitors.

headline: Backlash Over Leniency at West Point After 73 Cadets Are Accused of Cheating
abstract: The revelations — and the academy’s handling of them — have prompted a debate about integrity, rehabilitation, and what it means to be a cadet.
lead_paragraph: It is engraved in a stone monument on the grounds of the U.S. Military Academy at West Point: “A cadet will not lie, cheat, steal, or tolerate those who do.”

headline: Trump’s Attack on Coronavirus Relief Divides G.O.P. and Threatens Recovery
abstract: From the campaign trail in Georgia to Capitol Hill, President Trump’s demand for changes to the $900 billion pandemic relief plan upended political and economic calculations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s denunciation of the $900 billion coronavirus relief deal drove a wedge through the Republican Party on Wednesday, drawing harsh criticism from House Republicans and threatening the delivery of unemployment checks, a reprieve on evictions and direct payments to struggling Americans.

headline: Black Doctor Dies of Covid-19 After Complaining of Racist Treatment
abstract: “He made me feel like a drug addict,” Dr. Susan Moore said, accusing a white doctor of downplaying her complaints of pain and suggesting she should be discharged.
lead_paragraph: [To read more stories on race from The New York Times, sign up here for our Race/Related newsletter.]

headline: Trump Gives Clemency to More Allies, Including Manafort, Stone and Charles Kushner
abstract: It was the second wave of pardons and commutations by the president in two days, showing his willingness to use his power aggressively on behalf of loyalists.
lead_paragraph: President Trump doled out clemency to a new group of loyalists on Wednesday, wiping away convictions and sentences as he aggressively employed his power to override courts, juries and prosecutors to apply his own standard of justice for his allies.

headline: Britain and E.U. Scramble to Reach Brexit Deal Before Christmas
abstract: With a deadline closing in fast, negotiators were racing to strike a deal, with an agreement said to be imminent.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain and the European Union appeared on the cusp of a landmark post-Brexit trade agreement on Wednesday, with negotiators in Brussels all but resolving the final issues, a person briefed on the talks said.

headline: Stella Tennant, Aristocratic British Model, Is Dead at 50
abstract: Noble lineage, classic beauty and punk attitude combined in a model who stood at fashion’s apex for three decades.
lead_paragraph: Stella Tennant, the unimpeachably aristocratic model and inspiration to designers like Karl Lagerfeld and Gianni Versace, died on Tuesday in Duns, Scotland. She was 50.

headline: With Hacking, the United States Needs to Stop Playing the Victim
abstract: The U.S. also uses cybertools to defend its interests. It’s the age of perpetual cyberconflict.
lead_paragraph: There is indignant howling over what is surely Russia’s role in infiltrating, again, the networks of the U.S. government and corporations — this time through a tainted software update by the company SolarWinds. Politicians of both parties have called it a virtual act of war. “America must retaliate, and not just with sanctions,” Senator Marco Rubio said.

headline: With Alibaba Investigation, China Gets Tougher on Tech
abstract: Jack Ma and other entrepreneurs prospered under Beijing’s laissez-faire attitude toward the business side of the internet. The dynamic is shifting as the companies have grown in power.
lead_paragraph: China’s internet giants came to dominate segments of the world’s No. 2 economy because Beijing’s authoritarian government largely looked the other way while they grew and grew.

headline: Additional modeling shows the British variant’s high transmissibility.
abstract: A team of British scientists released a worrying study on Wednesday of the newly discovered coronavirus variant sweeping Britain. They warned that the variant was so contagious that new control measures, such as closing down schools and universities, might be necessary. Dr. Nicholas Davies, the lead author of the study, said that the findings “are pretty convincing that more rapid vaccination is going to be a really important thing for any country that has to deal with this or similar variants.”
lead_paragraph: A team of British scientists released a worrying study on Wednesday of the newly discovered coronavirus variant sweeping Britain. They warned that the variant was so contagious that new control measures, such as closing down schools and universities, might be necessary. Dr. Nicholas Davies, the lead author of the study, said that the findings “are pretty convincing that more rapid vaccination is going to be a really important thing for any country that has to deal with this or similar variants.”

headline: Trump Warns Iran of Retaliation After Attacks on U.S. Embassy in Baghdad
abstract: The administration and military officials blame Tehran for recent rocket attacks in Iraq, adding to the growing tensions between the United States and Iran.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump warned Iran on Wednesday that he would hold it accountable “if one American is killed” in rocket attacks in Iraq that the Trump administration and military officials blamed on Tehran.

headline: A Slow Day at the Restaurant
abstract: Billy Ouska makes his New York Times Crossword debut, with plenty to spare.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — I’m really enjoying all these new voices in the Crossword. That doesn’t mean that I don’t appreciate our veteran constructors, but I see it as similar to the Scouts song “Make New Friends”: “Make new friends, but keep the old. One is silver, the other is gold.” There’s room for everyone, and new constructors reveal new perspectives on things.

headline: Leslie West, ‘Mississippi Queen’ Rocker, Is Dead at 75
abstract: He rose to fame with Mountain, which Rolling Stone called a “louder version of Cream” — a band Mr. West idolized. One of the group’s first gigs was Woodstock.
lead_paragraph: Leslie West, whose meaty guitar riffs and snarling lead lines powered the hit band Mountain through “Mississippi Queen” and other rock anthems of the 1970s, died on Wednesday in Palm Coast, Fla. He was 75.

headline: Coronavirus Variant Is Indeed More Transmissible, New Study Suggests
abstract: Researchers warn that the British variant is so contagious that new control measures, including closing down schools and universities, may be necessary.
lead_paragraph: A team of British scientists released a worrying study on Wednesday of the new coronavirus variant sweeping the United Kingdom. They warned that the variant is so contagious that new control measures, including closing down schools and universities, might be necessary. Even that may not be enough, they noted, saying, “It may be necessary to greatly accelerate vaccine rollout.”

headline: Eleanor Roosevelt Buying Pears and Other Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers respond to recent issues of the Sunday Book Review.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: New in Paperback: ‘Brother & Sister’ and ‘The Resisters’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: BROTHER & SISTER: A Memoir, by Diane Keaton. (Vintage, 192 pp., $16.) Made up of journal entries, letters, poetry and collages — of which Keaton’s younger brother made hundreds as he descended into mental illness — this memoir charts the ebb and flow of a close sibling relationship. Elisabeth Egan, who interviewed the Oscar-winning actress for our Inside the List column, called it “brave.”

headline: Quotation of the Day: Spending Drops as Income Falls, Spurring Alarm
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, December 24, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “We know that things are going to get worse. The question is how much worse.”

headline: Corrections: Dec. 24, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Dec. 24, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about presidential pardons misstated the status of a meeting between Erik Prince and a Russia-sanctioned banker in the Seychelles. The meeting took place during the 2017 presidential transition; it was not the case that it did not occur.

headline: N.F.L. Week 16 Predictions: Our Picks Against the Spread
abstract: The Colts are favored on the road in Pittsburgh, the Rams will try to stay alive in Seattle and a frozen matchup between Tennessee and Green Bay should still have plenty of offense.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. playoff picture should come into sharp focus this weekend, with several division titles and wild-card spots likely to be decided. There will be games on Friday, Saturday, Sunday and Monday, and while a few of them are irrelevant, most can have an impact on the standings.

headline: A Flying Elephant, a Teacher’s Hugs: 12 Tales of Pandemic Resilience
abstract: The virus has been crushing spirits around the world, but some people refuse to be bowed. Here are their stories.
lead_paragraph: . . . wrote the third grader. A few months into quarantine, his teacher, Maura Cristina Silva, could tell that her vivacious students were starting to buckle.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: A last-minute Brexit scramble.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Your Most-Played Song of 2020 Is … White Noise?
abstract: Ambient music, background noise and calming sound effects have soothed the anxious, isolated and sleep deprived this year.
lead_paragraph: The soundtrack to Maya Montoya’s year was white noise. Specifically, a track on Spotify called “Celestial White Noise”: three whole hours of warm, soothing fuzz.

headline: Petr Cech Is in His Comfort Zone: In the Middle of Everything
abstract: For the recently retired goalkeeper, a role as Chelsea’s technical director is appealing because of how different it is from playing.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Petr Cech does not watch a lot of television. Switching his brain off, by his own admission, does not come easily to him. He has always preferred, he said, to fill every minute of his day, not just with work and family but with a moderately intimidating litany of pastimes and projects. Settling down on the sofa counts, to his mind, as time wasted.

headline: A Covid Christmas Comes to Bethlehem
abstract: Every Christmas, the quiet West Bank town of Bethlehem becomes a bustling hub for pilgrims, tourists and dignitaries. Not this year.
lead_paragraph: BETHLEHEM, West Bank — The Church of the Nativity was closed, and most souvenir shops shuttered. Hotels that are usually sold out months in advance were deserted.

headline: Influencers May Face Fines as China Tackles Obesity and Food Waste
abstract: According to a new government report, more than half of the country’s adult population is either overweight or obese. Chinese officials have vowed to address the problem with a campaign.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — More than half of China’s adult population is either overweight or obese, according to a new government report released on Wednesday.

headline: Let’s Start Over
abstract: Vaccines are coming. Donald Trump is going. Sometime in 2021, life will look a lot more normal. But it won’t be the same.
lead_paragraph: Vaccines are coming. Donald Trump is going. Sometime in 2021, life will look a lot more normal. But it won’t be the same.

headline: Aimee Nezhukumatathil Wants You to Get Some Fresh Air
abstract: In her best-selling essay collection, the veteran poet offers a cynicism-busting perspective on nature.
lead_paragraph: WONDER WOMAN It’s not every day that pets come up during a phone interview, but the subject is relevant when you’re talking to Aimee Nezhukumatathil, whose illustrated essay collection, “World of Wonders,” doubles as a love letter to little creatures. It turns out she shares her home with a small, mostly Chihuahua-based mutt named Haiku. “He’s a really teeny dog and I’m a nerdy poet, so there you go,” she explains. “Unfortunately he has a little bit of pandemic weight on him, so now we joke that he’s a haibun, which is a larger form of Japanese poetry.”

headline: Andrew Sullivan on the War Within Conservatism and Why It Matters to All of Us
abstract: Edmund Fawcett’s “Conservatism” is a sweeping history that reaches deep into the past but with startling relevance for the present.
lead_paragraph: CONSERVATISMThe Fight for a TraditionBy Edmund Fawcett

headline: They Wanted Something Rundown, With Potential. Which Apartment Did They Choose?
abstract: As they planned their Zoom wedding, one young couple went on the hunt for a Manhattan home that was nice — but not too nice — in a convenient location with some outdoor space. Here’s where they landed.
lead_paragraph: As they planned their Zoom wedding, one young couple went on the hunt for a Manhattan home that was nice — but not too nice — in a convenient location with some outdoor space. Here’s where they landed.

headline: Mixing Politics and Romance
abstract: Sarah Lockman and John Collins met two years ago at a political roast and benefit in Delaware, where she serves as a state legislator.
lead_paragraph: For Sarah Lockman and John Collins, the pivotal moment in their relationship occurred in a most unusual place: high atop the staircase of Mr. Collins’s new home in St. Michael, Md., where he and Ms. Lockman struggled for three hours to carry a futon down the stairs this past January.

headline: When Needs Are Acute, Going an Extra Mile at the Holidays
abstract: Gift drives via video conference. Deliveries from the food bank. Nonprofits adapted to continue providing for people in need.
lead_paragraph: In Decembers past, millions of families made gift drives part of their holiday preparations, a way to share with others as they shopped for their own loved ones.

headline: The New Words for Our New Misery
abstract: Doomscrolling, mask-hole, Zoom fatigue and more from the pandemic lexicon.
lead_paragraph: Of all the personal development opportunities presented by quarantine — knitting, baking sourdough, starting a TikTok — there is none so user-friendly as talking to yourself.

headline: Sometimes a Broken Laptop Can Be a Good Thing
abstract: Ugene Bynum, a software engineer, made a lasting impression on Stacy Prather, who had sought his help to fix her computer.
lead_paragraph: Ugene Bynum knew he might not be able to fix Stacy Prather’s broken laptop, but when she and her godmother knocked on his Philadelphia front door asking for help in the fall of 2016, he didn’t turn them away.

headline: First a Trial Run, Then the Real Thing
abstract: After six months of dating, Chelsea Graham and Matthew Kocurek moved in together for a week, calling it a “practice run.” They’ve lived together ever since.
lead_paragraph: It took Chelsea Graham and Matthew Kocurek four years to to get to their first date.

headline: When the Pandemic Ends, Don’t Put Off Any More Adventures
abstract: The future of travel will involve fewer selfies from Icelandic spas.
lead_paragraph: In early March, I was walking around the most magical place on earth — Disney World’s Magic Kingdom in Orlando, Fla. — asking guests why they were comfortable being at a theme park with thousands of strangers and sticky-fingered children as a virus that we then believed to be passed through touch was spreading throughout the world.

headline: I Will Never Bail on My Friends Again
abstract: It’s been a year of loneliness and isolation. In 2021, we’ll celebrate.
lead_paragraph: I finished television during the pandemic and started on movies. Now I’m almost finished with those, too! My hips have locked in a supine position and my eyes are dry as a bone, but I persist. What else is there to do?

headline: The Sidney Awards
abstract: A hard year produces great writing.
lead_paragraph: This has not been a great period for free expression. The range of socially acceptable opinion has shrunk, as independent-minded journalists and experts have been eased out of their jobs at places ranging from New York magazine to Boeing and Civis Analytics for saying unorthodox things. The esteemed scholar James R. Flynn wrote a book called “In Defense of Free Speech” which was in turn canceled by his publisher for being too controversial.

headline: How We Reported on Pollution in New Delhi Through Two Children
abstract: The idea was simple: compare the difference in exposure to unclean air among wealthy and poor families by tracking two kids for a day. Pulling it off was trickier.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: The ‘Trump Bump’ for Books Has Been Significant. Can It Continue?
abstract: As a new administration looms, publishers have snapped up another crop of forthcoming Trump books by prominent journalists and pundits.
lead_paragraph: In the past four years, publishers have released more than a thousand books about Donald J. Trump. Authors have examined seemingly every facet of his persona, in works about his presidency, family, political rise, business dealings, reality-TV career and golfing habits. The body of work is so voluminous that there’s even a book about all the Trump books.

headline: How Does an 83-Year-Old Jesuit End Up in Prison?
abstract: Father Stan Swamy spent decades fighting for the rights of India’s marginalized people. In October, Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s government imprisoned him under antiterrorism laws.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — What I remember most is the way my grandfather struggled with everyday things. Eating, drinking, even smiling in response to a joke or a favorite song. The disease froze his muscles, turning the majestically expressive face of an aging patriarch into a mask.

headline: The Tiny Victories That Got Parents Through 2020
abstract: It’s been a rough year. Let’s celebrate the little wins.
lead_paragraph: In a year filled with chaos and uncertainty, at least there were moments of closeness, levity and relief for parents, despite the pandemic and other disasters. We asked, and you delivered the tiny victories that got you through this wretched year.

headline: How the Virus Stole Christmas
abstract: For immigrant families from India, the holidays come closest to the long, riotous wedding seasons in the homeland.
