lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Many years ago, when my brother and I were just out of the house, my parents entered a raffle and won a Christmas tree. It was fake, 12 feet tall and covered in hundreds of Raggedy Ann dolls.

headline: A Parent Trap? New Data Offers More Dire View of College Debt
abstract: In a separate loan program, more parents are loading up on debt, often in greater amounts than their children.
lead_paragraph: If you have children nearing college age, you’ve probably heard a lot about student loans. Americans owe $1.7 trillion in college debt, an amount that grows every year. And while colleges differ greatly in their propensity to load up families with debt, it has been hard to identify the biggest offenders — until now.

headline: How Did Mistletoe Get Into the Treetops?
abstract: Before someone hung it up in your home, some animal had to get it into the canopies where it thrives to this day.
lead_paragraph: It’s unclear what trendsetter first hung up mistletoe. Some blame the ancient Greeks, who kissed under the plants during harvest festivals. Others pin it on first-century druids, who might have decorated their homes with them for good luck.

headline: Want a Nice Dinner Out? Your Hotel Room Awaits
abstract: Restaurateurs and hoteliers are teaming up to create private dining experiences that allow guests to get out of the house, but limit their exposure to others.
lead_paragraph: It had been six months since Nick Bayer and his wife had been on a date. But with freezing temperatures gripping Philadelphia and indoor restaurant service banned, dinner in a tent wasn’t appealing. So instead of sitting outdoors at the Walnut Street Cafe, a local restaurant, they opted for an elegant meal served in a hotel room that had been converted into a private dining space.

headline: No More All-Nighters!
abstract: How to navigate an office where all-night work sessions are celebrated, tips for transitions and what to do with a charismatic but abusive colleague.
lead_paragraph: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.

headline: The Start of a New Chapter in Their Favorite Bookstore
abstract: LaMarr Coles proposed to Stephanie Williams at Greedy Reads in Baltimore, where a few months earlier they had made their relationship official.
lead_paragraph: If Stephanie Williams didn’t know she was going to marry LaMarr Coles III after their first phone call, she sensed she might after their first date. And she definitely knew it two weeks in, at the end of date No. 3.

headline: Brad Parscale Fell From Trump’s Favor. Now He’s Plotting a Comeback.
abstract: Mr. Parscale, President Trump’s former campaign manager, was angry after he was demoted last summer, and wanted out of politics. That didn’t last long. He is starting a new political data company.
lead_paragraph: Brad Parscale was sounding upbeat. He has a new company and, he believes, a brighter future.

headline: With Money, and Waste, China Fights for Chip Independence
abstract: Beijing’s drive to free itself from reliance on imported semiconductors has lifted start-ups and big firms alike. Some have flamed out. But there has been progress.
lead_paragraph: Liu Fengfeng had more than a decade under his belt at one of the world’s most prominent technology companies before he realized where the real gold rush in China was taking place.

headline: Eight-Armed Underwater Bullies: Watch Octopuses Punch Fish
abstract: The solitary cephalopods occasionally join a hunting party with fish, then lash out for reasons that scientists are studying.
lead_paragraph: The first time Eduardo Sampaio saw an octopus wind up and punch a fish, “I burst out laughing,” he said. That was a problem because he was scuba diving in the Red Sea and nearly choked on his diving regulator.

headline: How Much Herd Immunity Is Enough?
abstract: Scientists initially estimated that 60 to 70 percent of the population needed to acquire resistance to the coronavirus to banish it. Now Dr. Anthony Fauci and others are quietly shifting that number upward.
lead_paragraph: At what point does a country achieve herd immunity? What portion of the population must acquire resistance to the coronavirus, either through infection or vaccination, in order for the disease to fade away and life to return to normal?

headline: The Forgotten Radicalism of Jesus Christ
abstract: First-century Christians weren’t prepared for what a truly inclusive figure he was, and what was true then is still true today.
lead_paragraph: “Get used to different.”

headline: The Surprising Places in New York City Where Trump’s Support Grew
abstract: Joseph R. Biden Jr. won President Trump’s hometown handily. But a deeper look at election data suggests a surge in support for the president in some districts.
lead_paragraph: In the months leading up to the election, as the restaurant where she has worked for 18 years in Corona, Queens, struggled to survive, Juliana Rodriguez wavered over her choice for president.

headline: These Businesses Thrived as Others Struggled to Survive
abstract: As the pandemic ravaged small businesses across America, some were surprised — and conflicted — about their success.
lead_paragraph: Small businesses were devastated in 2020. They have pivoted so frequently to deal with state-mandated shutdowns, new customer needs and pandemic safety protocols that many aren’t sure what direction they’re facing anymore. Nine months into the coronavirus crisis, more than a quarter remain closed, at least temporarily, according to data from Opportunity Insights, a research group at Harvard University.

headline: In the Rio Grande Valley, Death Has Become a Family Affair
abstract: Christmas will be quieter in the Texas borderlands, where aunts and uncles, grandparents and adult siblings often live under the same roof. That closeness let the coronavirus ravage families.
lead_paragraph: EDINBURG, Texas — Days after her Thanksgiving feast was prepared, served and eaten, Maribel Rodriguez tried to muster the will to unpack the tree, lights and decorations of boisterous Christmases past.

headline: People Are Dying. Whom Do We Save First With the Vaccine?
abstract: With limited doses available, and a pandemic claiming more lives every day, a complex moral calculus has begun. Five thinkers weigh the choices ahead.
lead_paragraph: In mid-December, before a key vote by an advisory panel for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, a public debate flared up over what might well be the most momentous policy decision of 2021: how to distribute the Covid-19 vaccine. This particular fight centered on how to balance the vaccination of seniors (who die from the coronavirus at much higher rates than younger people) against that of essential workers (who, because they come into contact with many people over the course of any given day, risk getting sick themselves and becoming superspreaders).

headline: How much herd immunity is enough?
abstract: At what point does a country achieve herd immunity? What portion of the population must acquire resistance to the coronavirus, either through infection or vaccination, for the disease to fade away and life to return to normal?
lead_paragraph: At what point does a country achieve herd immunity? What portion of the population must acquire resistance to the coronavirus, either through infection or vaccination, for the disease to fade away and life to return to normal?

headline: A Covid Christmas comes to Bethlehem.
abstract: The pandemic has put a damper on Christmas at the place where it is said to have all begun: the town of Bethlehem in the West Bank.
lead_paragraph: The pandemic has put a damper on Christmas at the place where it is said to have all begun: the town of Bethlehem in the West Bank.

headline: Death comes in multiples in a close-knit valley on the Mexican border.
abstract: Days after her Thanksgiving feast was prepared, served and eaten, Maribel Rodriguez tried to muster the will to unpack the tree, lights and decorations of boisterous Christmases past.
lead_paragraph: Days after her Thanksgiving feast was prepared, served and eaten, Maribel Rodriguez tried to muster the will to unpack the tree, lights and decorations of boisterous Christmases past.

headline: In a lonely time, a teacher in Brazil creates a ‘hugging kit’ for her students.
abstract: While much as the pandemic has been a story of devastation and loss, it has also been one of resilience — of individual people, families and entire communities not only surviving a deadly threat but seeing in the moment a chance to serve others. Some even dare remind us that joy is still a possibility. We asked our correspondents around the world to share stories from this year that speak to the strength of the human spirit, and to how disruption can bring out the best in us.
lead_paragraph: While much as the pandemic has been a story of devastation and loss, it has also been one of resilience — of individual people, families and entire communities not only surviving a deadly threat but seeing in the moment a chance to serve others. Some even dare remind us that joy is still a possibility. We asked our correspondents around the world to share stories from this year that speak to the strength of the human spirit, and to how disruption can bring out the best in us.

headline: Why You Can’t Meet God Over Zoom
abstract: Virtual services are inadequate — but I keep going.
lead_paragraph: When our congregation, Church of the Savior, moved to online services some nine months ago, our family tried to keep things normal. We had the children dress in nice Sunday clothes, though we would be watching via screen instead of entering a sanctuary. We arranged the chairs in the living room to look like pews. We tried to follow along, bowing at the right times and crossing ourselves at the right moment.

headline: A freight traffic logjam eases at British ports, and other news from around the world.
abstract: Trucks began boarding ferries in Dover on Thursday to cross the English Channel for the first time in four days, a step toward ending a thousands-deep traffic jam that piled up at the border after France banned crossings from Britain to limit the spread of a coronavirus variant.
lead_paragraph: Trucks began boarding ferries in Dover on Thursday to cross the English Channel for the first time in four days, a step toward ending a thousands-deep traffic jam that piled up at the border after France banned crossings from Britain to limit the spread of a coronavirus variant.

headline: 24 Hours Inside a Brooklyn Hospital: An Update
abstract: In the spring, with permission from staff, patients and their families, we shadowed one doctor for a day to get a sense of what it is like on the front lines of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: This episode contains strong language.

headline: Rolling Homes That Make an R.V. Look Palatial
abstract: Two couples have spent years on the road with about 50 square feet or less to call home. It takes wanderlust — and a seriously concise kitchen plan.
lead_paragraph: What if you went on a road trip, and never came back?

headline: A Conversation With Joe Biden
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: “It will be the first priority, the second priority and the third priority — to deal with Covid and bring down the spread and bring down the death rate,” President-elect Joe Biden told me during a phone call yesterday.

headline: ‘Charm City Kings,’ ‘Babyteeth’ and Other Hidden Streaming Gems
abstract: You may have missed these under-the-radar movies this year. Now’s your chance to catch up.
lead_paragraph: As 2020 sputters to its conclusion and film critics devise their year-end best-of lists (Manohla Dargis and A.O. Scott’s are here), the customary consensus begins to form around a handful of widely beloved titles: “First Cow,” “Never Rarely Sometimes Always,” “Beanpole,” “Martin Eden,” and the like. But a wide variety of at-home viewing options made this a particularly rich year for independent cinema, so in that spirit, this month’s selection of hidden streaming gems focuses solely on the films of 2020 — from heartfelt indie dramas to searing documentaries to, yes, a thriller about a man and his posterior.

headline: ‘Dear Comrades!’ Review: When the Party Line Becomes a Tightrope
abstract: With a bureaucrat as the central character, the film at times takes on a bleakly comic tone as it fills in the circumstances surrounding a massacre.
lead_paragraph: In 1962, Soviet government forces violently suppressed a strike against rising food prices in Novocherkassk, a city in the Don River region of southern Russia. It would be decades before the event received acknowledgment from official sources. A K.G.B. report, revealed after the fall of the Soviet Union, said that 20 bodies from the “liquidation” had been “buried in various places.” But for years, the slaughter was obscured from public view. Bodies? What bodies?

headline: ‘Pinocchio’ Review: An Enchanting Yet Befuddling Adaptation
abstract: Matteo Garrone, who directed the searing true-crime drama “Gomorrah,” takes a whack at Carlo Collodi’s classic tale.
lead_paragraph: This new cinematic imagining of Carlo Collodi’s classic fantasy tale is alternately enchanting and befuddling. Roberto Benigni plays the woodworker Geppetto — before you recoil at the prospect, let’s note that the frequently over-the-top actor is relatively restrained and appropriate throughout. At the movie’s opening, the character is in such dire straits that he finds fault with the furniture at his local osteria, offering to fix it in exchange for a meal.

headline: ‘DNA’ Review: Digging for Roots
abstract: After her immigrant grandfather dies, a woman wants to reclaim her ethnicity.
lead_paragraph: “DNA,” the fifth feature from the French actress and filmmaker Maïwenn, opens in clamor and closes in calm. In between is a journey taken by Neige (played by Maïwenn and inspired by her own life) as she moves away from the fractious embrace of her extravagantly maladjusted family and toward her Algerian roots.

headline: ‘Your Name Engraved Herein’ Review: When Love Is All You Can See
abstract: The filmmaker Patrick Liu keeps the focus on the two young men in this Taiwanese drama and blurs the rest.
lead_paragraph: The love story in the touching, simple Taiwanese drama “Your Name Engraved Herein” unfolds at a Catholic high school for boys. It’s 1987, shortly after the end of nearly four decades of martial law, but before the easing of social repression.

headline: What We’re Looking Forward To in 2021
abstract: Amid the challenges of 2020, there are reasons to be optimistic heading into the new year.
lead_paragraph: To say that 2020 was stressful is an understatement, what with a pandemic that the world hasn’t yet emerged from, a sharply divisive U.S. presidential election whose controversies have yet to ebb, social unrest over vast inequalities … need we go on?

headline: Japan’s Prime Minister Apologizes Over Scandal Tarring His Term
abstract: Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga said he had unintentionally misrepresented the facts around a political scandal after prosecutors announced they would seek to punish a former aide to Shinzo Abe.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga of Japan apologized on Thursday for what he said were unintentionally false statements about a political spending scandal that has tarred the first months of his administration.

headline: In a Pandemic Fairy Tale, a Garden Leads to a Magical Friendship
abstract: A 4-year-old girl coping with the loneliness of the pandemic created a tiny garden, and kindled an unlikely friendship with an enchanted neighbor who moved into her tree.
lead_paragraph: Kelly Kenney was taking a late-night walk to clear her thoughts in her Los Angeles neighborhood this spring when a colorful pinwheel caught her eye. She stopped and found herself gazing down at an elaborate fairy garden at the base of a tree, complete with painted rocks and tiny trinkets.

headline: ‘News of the World’ Review: Tom Hanks Does the Strong, Silent Type
abstract: The star can’t help but bring decency to Paul Greengrass’s lean, efficient western set in 1870s Texas.
lead_paragraph: Nowadays, if you want a selection of news stories culled from various publications, you can use a cellphone app. But if you lived in Texas in 1870, you could pay a dime to watch Tom Hanks shuffle through a stack of newspapers and read selected articles aloud. It seems like a much better deal.

headline: A garden leads to a magical friendship.
abstract: Kelly Kenney was taking a late-night walk to clear her thoughts in her Los Angeles neighborhood this spring when a colorful pinwheel caught her eye. She stopped and found herself gazing down at an elaborate fairy garden at the base of a tree, complete with painted rocks and tiny trinkets.
lead_paragraph: Kelly Kenney was taking a late-night walk to clear her thoughts in her Los Angeles neighborhood this spring when a colorful pinwheel caught her eye. She stopped and found herself gazing down at an elaborate fairy garden at the base of a tree, complete with painted rocks and tiny trinkets.

headline: Emmanuel Macron, Free of Covid-19 Symptoms, Leaves Isolation
abstract: The French leader, who suffered from a cough, headaches and fatigue after contracting the coronavirus, has remained active during his quarantine period, his office said.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A week after he first tested positive for the coronavirus, President Emmanuel Macron of France has stopped isolating himself because he no longer shows symptoms, a statement from the Élysée Palace, his official office, said on Thursday.

headline: Social Q’s: Covid Christmas Edition
abstract: The holidays are always complicated and especially so this year.
lead_paragraph: My three sisters and I have been doing Secret Santa with our kids for years. Each child picks a cousin’s name. They love exchanging gifts! This year, I told my sisters that my family would not be joining them for Christmas because of Covid but that we’d still like to be part of the Secret Santa. (I could drop off our gifts in advance.) But after following up, I learned that my sisters decided to limit the exchange to cousins who would be there in person. I am hurt that my kids will be excluded and, worse, that my sisters made this decision without discussing it with me. They said the cousins like to watch each other opening gifts, so it made no sense to include my two. Thoughts?

headline: ‘Soul’ Review: Pixar’s New Feature Gets Musical, and Metaphysical
abstract: This inventive tale stars Jamie Foxx as a jazz musician caught in a world that human souls pass through on their way into and out of life.
lead_paragraph: In about 100 jaunty, poignant minutes, “Soul,” the new Pixar Animation feature, tackles some of the questions that many of us have been losing sleep over since childhood. Why do I exist? What’s the point of being alive? What comes after?

headline: What Are You Paying For in a $300 Chess Set? Mostly the Knights
abstract: The horses in higher-end wooden sets must be hand-carved, a long, specialized process to make sure all four are exactly the same.
lead_paragraph: If you bought a wooden chess set after watching “The Queen’s Gambit,” the price you paid was most likely dictated by just four pieces.

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: This week’s listings are in Brooklyn Heights, Long Island City and Turtle Bay.
lead_paragraph: This week’s listings are in Brooklyn Heights, Long Island City and Turtle Bay.

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
abstract: This week’s properties include a five-bedroom house in Tarrytown, N.Y., and three-bedroom apartment in Stamford, Conn.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties include a five-bedroom house in Tarrytown, N.Y., and three-bedroom apartment in Stamford, Conn.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
abstract: This week’s properties include a five-bedroom house in Tarrytown, N.Y., and three-bedroom apartment in Stamford, Conn.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn, Queens and Manhattan
abstract: This week’s listings are in Brooklyn Heights, Long Island City and Turtle Bay.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: A Christmas Unlike Any Other
abstract: Thursday: Wishing you comfort, safety and rest.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Bollywood, Reeling From the Pandemic, Shifts to Streaming
abstract: India’s film industry, which relied on theatrical releases, is experimenting with going straight to streaming services such as Amazon, Netflix and Disney’s Hotstar.
lead_paragraph: “Coolie No. 1” has all the hallmarks of a big Bollywood film: colorful costumes, larger-than-life sets, foot-tapping music and a melodramatic story about a man who pretends he has a twin to woo the woman of his dreams.

headline: Why China Turned Against Jack Ma
abstract: The Alibaba chief paid for pushing back against Beijing. But the shift in attitude also speaks to a growing wealth gap and diminished opportunities for the young.
lead_paragraph: In China, Jack Ma is synonymous with success. The English teacher turned internet entrepreneur is the country’s richest person. He founded Alibaba, the closest thing Amazon has to a peer and rival. After Donald J. Trump was elected president in 2016, Mr. Ma was the first high-profile Chinese person he met with.

headline: Lawsuit Accuses Tony Robbins of Discriminating Against Employee Who Got Covid
abstract: A sales executive who was placed on a ventilator while in a coma says she was denied accommodations to work from home as she recovered.
lead_paragraph: Tony Robbins, the life coach and motivational speaker, discriminated against one of his employees by refusing to grant her the accommodations she needed to work from home after she contracted a debilitating case of Covid-19 in the spring, according to a lawsuit filed Wednesday.

headline: How the Sinovac Vaccine Works
abstract: Using inactivated coronaviruses to train the immune system.
lead_paragraph: Using inactivated coronaviruses to train the immune system.

headline: The Met Casts New Light on its Greatest Hits and History
abstract: Goya, Caravaggio, Rubens, Velázquez and more are in skylit splendor in the European galleries. And the museum is acknowledging the shaping force on art of colonialism, slavery, the disenfranchisement of women.
lead_paragraph: “In a dark time, the eye begins to see,” the poet wrote. And after the dark, dark time we’ve been through, this year’s winter solstice, marking the start of slow climb back into light, may carry more metaphorical weight than usual.

headline: The Most Popular Listings of November
abstract: The most popular listings include a pair of super-expensive houses, two sunny, Manhattan apartments, and a chic condo in Montreal, Canada.
lead_paragraph: The most popular listings on The New York Times’s Find a Home site in November include a pair of super-expensive homes, two sunny, Manhattan apartments, and a smartly designed three-bedroom condo in Montreal, Canada.

headline: ‘Promising Young Woman’ Review: Courting Dangerous Liaisons
abstract: Carey Mulligan stars in this feminist revenge thriller that too often backs away from its potentially searing setup.
lead_paragraph: A hard candy with a sour center, “Promising Young Woman” turns sociopathy into a style and trauma into a joke. Embodying both, Cassandra (Carey Mulligan), 30, a medical school dropout still living with her concerned parents (Jennifer Coolidge and Clancy Brown), is a weekday barista and a weekend huntress. Her prey is two-legged, but single-minded: men who equate a woman’s inebriation with consent.

headline: For Ijeoma Oluo, Books and Bedtime Are a Perfect Combination
abstract: "Lately, I’ve been able to find a few minutes to read in bed each night after my family has gone to sleep and it’s been absolutely heavenly.”
lead_paragraph: “Lately, I’ve been able to find a few minutes to read in bed each night after my family has gone to sleep,” says the author of “Mediocre,” “and it’s been absolutely heavenly.”

headline: Britain and E.U. Reach Landmark Deal on Brexit
abstract: The trade agreement comes after months of negotiations, and still leaves critical details to be worked out.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain and the European Union struck a hard-fought trade agreement on Thursday, settling a bitter divorce that stretched over more than four years and setting the terms for a post-Brexit future as close neighbors living apart.

headline: ‘Wonder Woman 1984’ Review: It’s Not About What We Deserve
abstract: The sequel to the 2017 hit finds Diana Prince, a.k.a. Wonder Woman, pining for love and saddled with a movie unworthy of her.
lead_paragraph: When Wonder Woman first hit the big screen in 2017, the possibilities for the character felt endless. After 76 years without a blockbuster to call her own — she muscled into comics, bracelets flashing, in 1941 — she had made it, becoming a box-office sensation. And, yay! The movies love sexpot vixens vamping in fetish wear (meow) and nice girls simpering in the wings, so it was relief that this Wonder Woman was neither. She was sovereign, powerful and lightly charming, and even when the movie had teasing fun with her it took the character, her mighty sword and cultural significance seriously.

headline: Dancing by Herself: When the Waltz Went Solo
abstract: Grete Wiesenthal, a ballet-trained Viennese dancer, made the waltz modern and a vehicle for solo expression.
lead_paragraph: Waltzing can go on for hours in an endless rotation, as partners coiled in each other’s arms whisk around a brimming dance floor. It requires a significant amount of physical contact, which is why the waltz was considered somewhat of a guilty pleasure until the early 19th century, when its popularity finally overthrew propriety. And now during the coronavirus pandemic close partner dancing raises eyebrows again.

headline: Britain Gets a Boost With a Brexit Trade Deal, but Challenges Loom
abstract: The free-trade pact would help both sides avoid tariffs, but Britain would still face economic costs from being outside the European Union.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British economy got a jolt of confidence Thursday as Britain and the European Union announced an agreement that will define their future trading relationship after years of negotiations since the country voted in 2016 to leave the bloc.

headline: Biden Is Expected to Expand U.S.-India Relations While Stressing Human Rights
abstract: Most experts agree that China will be the driving force behind how India’s relationship with Washington changes in a Biden administration.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration has significantly invested in its relationship with India over the past four years, seeing the country as a crucial partner in counterbalancing the rise of China.

headline: ‘Eyes Open. Hit First. Move Fast. Stop When He’s Dead.’
abstract: The Butcher’s Boy may no longer be a professional hit man, but he hasn’t forgotten how to kill, as we learn in Thomas Perry’s new novel, “Eddie’s Boy.”
lead_paragraph: The Butcher’s Boy — the professional killer we first met in Thomas Perry’s debut novel back in 1982 — hasn’t lost his extremely sharp edge. In his fourth outing, EDDIE’S BOY (The Mysterious Press, 274 pp., $26), Michael Schaeffer, as he now calls himself, shows how far he has come in the world since his early career as a hit man. (“He’d had a long life for a man in his line of work,” he acknowledges, with some satisfaction.) Schaeffer is living uneventfully with his English wife in Bath when his previous life intrudes with a vengeance. Four armed men have come to kill him, and while their corpses are now safely stowed in a big black sedan, Michael has no idea who sent them. Some mob family must have called for his assassination — but which one?

headline: Brexit Is Finally Done, but It Already Seems Out of Date
abstract: The idea of an agile “Global Britain” was an effective sales pitch. But that was before President Trump and other populists began erecting barriers to trade.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It took 11 grueling months for negotiators from Britain and the European Union to hammer out the terms of a post-Brexit trade deal. But in many respects, the deal is already four and a half years out of date.

headline: Pakistani Court Orders Men Released in Daniel Pearl Case
abstract: A detention order had been applied to four men accused in the American journalist’s abduction and murder even after their convictions were overturned.
lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan — A Pakistani court on Thursday ordered the release of four men being held over the 2002 abduction and killing of the American journalist Daniel Pearl, arguing that they had been acquitted months ago, and that their continued detention was illegal.

headline: What Is Brexit? And What Happens Next?
abstract: Britain’s split from the European Union takes full effect as 2021 begins. Here is a guide to what it means, how it came about and what the future might hold.
lead_paragraph: Britain breaks from the European Union’s regulatory orbit on Jan. 1, casting off nearly half a century inside the bloc. While it formally left in January 2020, for 11 months Britain was in a transition period, operating under E.U. rules as negotiators settled on terms of the two sides’ future commercial relations.

headline: An Irish boy writes to Pfizer requesting a vaccination for Santa, and receives a reply from its C.E.O.
abstract: When six-year-old Callum Thornhill heard that Pfizer had developed a coronavirus vaccine, he wrote to the company with an urgent request: to prioritize Santa Claus.
lead_paragraph: When six-year-old Callum Thornhill heard that Pfizer had developed a coronavirus vaccine, he wrote to the company with an urgent request: to prioritize Santa Claus.

headline: For Christmas, Pastors Offer Comfort and Joy in a Somber Season
abstract: “The darkness seems pretty dark at the moment,” said one minister, who will preach about hope in the face of fear.
lead_paragraph: When the Rev. Timothy Cole learned he had Covid-19 in early March, it was the first known case of the virus in Washington. Mr. Cole, the rector of Christ Church Georgetown, was hospitalized for three weeks.

headline: She’s a Chess Champion Who Can Barely See the Board
abstract: Like the fictional Beth Harmon in “The Queen’s Gambit,” she’s trying to find a way to get to Russia to compete. Unlike Beth, she’s blind.
lead_paragraph: Have you heard this story before? Girl has rough start in life, discovers chess. She becomes a United States champion. She studies Russian. And now she needs to find a way to get to Russia to play chess, because she can’t afford it.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Christmas Weekend
abstract: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience virtually.
lead_paragraph: In the fantasy version of a December evening, we would sweep in off West 54th Street, down the staircase and into the cozy, enveloping glamour that always makes Feinstein’s/54 Below feel like it’s ready for its close-up. We would slide into a booth and order a little something lovely. Then the long-running cabaret series “Sondheim Unplugged” would begin — one more shimmering perk to spending the holidays in New York.

headline: Answering Trump, Democrats Try and Fail to Jam $2,000 Payments Through House
abstract: In a brief bit of political theater, the House majority leader opened the chamber for business to ask for unanimous consent to accede to President Trump’s request for larger checks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The fate of $900 billion in pandemic aid will remain in limbo over the Christmas break after House Democrats tried and failed on Thursday to more than triple the size of relief checks, then adjourned the House until Monday, when they will try again.

headline: A Century After Phony Flu Ads, Companies Hype Dubious Covid Cures
abstract: Musical medicine? Corona-fighting herbs? “Human beings haven’t changed all that much,” a marketing professor says of the similarities between ads from 1918 and recent months.
lead_paragraph: With a pandemic raging, a spate of ads promised dubious remedies in the form of lozenges, tonics, unguents, blood-builders and an antiseptic shield to be used while kissing.

headline: Jerry Harris Pleads Not Guilty in Child-Pornography Case
abstract: The 21-year-old fan favorite on the Netflix series “Cheer” pleaded not guilty to multiple felony charges, including soliciting sex from minors.
lead_paragraph: Jerry Harris, the 21-year-old breakout star of the Netflix series “Cheer,” has pleaded not guilty to federal child pornography charges and accusations that he solicited sex from minors.

headline: ‘Schitt’s Creek’ Fans Arrive in Goodwood
abstract: The hamlet that was the backdrop for the hit television series “Schitt’s Creek” has become a pilgrimage site for fans, to the joy and consternation of locals.
lead_paragraph: GOODWOOD, Ontario — Joe Toby was recently giving a young couple a tour of his workshop, when the man sprinkled rose petals on the concrete floor and got down on one knee.

headline: Hospital Workers Start to ‘Turn Against Each Other’ to Get Vaccine
abstract: “I am so disappointed and saddened that this happened,” a New York hospital executive wrote to his staff after workers who did not have priority cut the line for the vaccine.
lead_paragraph: At NewYork-Presbyterian Morgan Stanley Children’s Hospital, one of the most highly regarded hospitals in New York City, a rumor spread last week that the line for the coronavirus vaccine on the ninth floor was unguarded and anyone could stealthily join and receive the shot.

headline: Our Favorite Arts Pictures of 2020
abstract: Celebrities, artists, musicians and actors at home, outdoors and in lockdown: The stories behind the pictures that defined our year.
lead_paragraph: The magenta glow of an exhibition outside the Guggenheim Museum, whose white spiral was off-limits to art lovers. The deserted grand staircase of a Metropolitan Opera silenced by the pandemic, its Sputnik chandeliers with no crowds to illuminate. Movie buffs, barred from cinemas, enjoying films at least semi-communally at a drive-in.

headline: 8 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: As the end of this endless year approaches, we find ourselves in a retrospective mood: Out with the old, in with the even older! Our recommended books this week cast an eye back on the Bolshevik Revolution and the seeds of the Cold War (“The Lenin Plot,” by Barnes Carr); and on the little-known role that people fleeing slavery played in American foreign and domestic policy before the Civil War (“South to Freedom,” by Alice L. Baumgartner); and on the ways that Winston Churchill’s larger-than-life legacy continues to shape British politics to this day (“The Churchill Myths,” by Steven Fielding, Bill Schwarz and Richard Toye).

headline: Mexico Begins Vaccinations Amid Virus Surge
abstract: Mexico is the first country in Latin America, a region hard hit by the coronavirus, to begin delivering vaccines. A head nurse at a Mexico City hospital was the first to get a shot.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Mexico began its coronavirus vaccination campaign on Thursday, becoming the first country in Latin America to do so, and providing a sliver of hope to the population amid a roaring resurgence of the virus.

headline: A Christmas Eve ‘Travel Nightmare’: Snow, Flooding, Maybe Tornadoes
abstract: On a holiday when health experts admonished people not to travel, the weather brought its own hazards across much of the country.
lead_paragraph: A nasty winter storm slammed the eastern United States on Christmas Eve, pushing drivers off the roads and threatening to spoil the plans of holiday travelers and last-minute shoppers in a season already dampened by the coronavirus.

headline: The 2020 Baseball Trivia Extravaganza
abstract: This test is not for the faint of heart, or the casual fan. See how your knowledge of the sport holds up in our fourth annual holiday baseball quiz.
lead_paragraph: This test is not for the faint of heart, or the casual fan. See how your knowledge of the sport holds up in our fourth annual holiday baseball quiz.

headline: With Olympics Postponed, U.S. Marathon Champion Decided to Have a Baby
abstract: When competitive running events for 2020 largely disappeared, Aliphine Tuliamuk and her partner saw the opportunity to have a child before the next Olympics.
lead_paragraph: Aliphine Tuliamuk was the surprise winner of the Olympic Trials marathon on Feb. 29.

headline: Britain and E.U. Reach Long-Awaited Brexit Trade Deal
abstract: Britain and the European Union reached a landmark trade agreement on Brexit after 11 months of negotiations and just a week before a year-end deadline.
lead_paragraph: Britain and the European Union reached a landmark trade agreement on Brexit after 11 months of negotiations and just a week before a year-end deadline.

headline: Trucks Stuck at U.K. Port Begin Moving, but Many Face a Roadside Christmas
abstract: France closed the border to help limit the spread of a coronavirus variant. With the border now reopened, testing thousands of drivers and clearing the backlog of freight will take some time.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Trucks began boarding ferries in Dover on Thursday to cross the English Channel for the first time in four days, a step toward ending a thousands-deep traffic jam that piled up at the border after France banned crossings from Britain to limit the spread of a coronavirus variant.

headline: For the E.U., It’s a Pretty Good Deal
abstract: The Brexit pact preserves crucial E.U. principles like the single market, and lets the bloc look ahead to its future without Britain.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Union emerges from fraught negotiations with Britain over its exit from the bloc with a sense of satisfaction — that it has maintained its unity and its core principles, especially the integrity of the single market of now 450 million consumers that is the foundation of its influence.

headline: ‘The Dissident’ Review: A Murder for Power
abstract: Bryan Fogel’s new documentary about the killing of Jamal Khashoggi underlines the disregard for human rights when money and geopolitics are at play.
lead_paragraph: A cinematic retelling of the murder of the Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi requires no embellishments. The raw facts are sinister and dramatic in themselves, involving a gruesome killing inside a consulate in a foreign country, an ambitious prince intolerant of dissenters and a kingdom with far-reaching financial clout. Yet Bryan Fogel’s new documentary, “The Dissident,” goes the extra mile, deploying an aggressive score, frenzied editing and C.G.I. elements to drive home the pathos of Khashoggi’s story and what it reveals about Saudi Arabia’s insidious machinery of surveillance and repression.

headline: Silly Season: How British Pantomime Looks From Across the Pond
abstract: Thanks to streaming, two American critics got to binge a bunch of the traditional holiday spectacles. They’re amused, and confused, by what they saw.
lead_paragraph: In a year of theatrical catastrophes, English pantomime looked to be one more. Big-heart, big-joke, big-budget extravaganzas, these shows depend on live audiences like few others. Staged at Christmastime and performed throughout much of the Anglophone world, pantos take classic fairy tales and zhuzh them up with famous guest stars, topical humor and song parodies.

headline: Black Voters Want President Biden to Take a Cue From Candidate Biden
abstract: In his victory speech, the president-elect said of Black voters: “You’ve always had my back, and I’ll have yours.” Many of those voters are watching to see what he does in office.
lead_paragraph: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C. — Joseph R. Biden Jr. went to the Royal Missionary Baptist Church in South Carolina in late February, before the state’s presidential primary, and listened as the Rev. Isaac J. Holt Jr. delivered a message of encouragement.

headline: For a Defeated President, Pardons as an Expression of Grievance
abstract: President Trump’s grants of clemency to convicted liars, corrupt congressmen and child-killing war criminals are a way to lash out at a system that he believes has treated him and his friends unfairly.
lead_paragraph: The statement announcing the latest raft of presidential pardons was officially attributed to the White House press secretary, but it bristled with President Trump’s own deep-seated grievances.

headline: The Doodles of Great Writers
abstract: Nabokov left a butterfly, Roxane Gay drew an elephant and Isabel Allende offered a caricature of herself — a few gems hidden in the guest book of the 92nd Street Y’s Unterberg Poetry Center.
lead_paragraph: When writers exit stage right after a reading at the 92nd Street Y’s Unterberg Poetry Center, they may feel satisfaction or relief, elation or the sense of a job well done. Writers being writers, they may feel that they did not deserve the audience’s applause — or that they deserved more of it. What happens next is always the same. I ask them to sign our guest book.

headline: General Austin: A Role Model for Young Black Americans
abstract: A reader praises President-elect Joe Biden’s choice for defense secretary. Also: Stresses in teaching today.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Sweet Breakfast With a Secret
abstract: A hidden layer of crumbs makes these muffins feel like the best coffee cakes.
lead_paragraph: The best muffins are the ones that veer into cupcake territory. Buttery, rich and occasionally glazed or iced, a muffin is intended to make eating cake acceptable for breakfast.

headline: Biden’s Cabinet: ‘Old Guard’ and Centrist
abstract: Readers are either comforted by the experience of the cabinet picks or disappointed by the Democratic Party’s pro-corporate policies.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Miss the N.Y.C. Subway? These Radio Plays Bring It Back to Life
abstract: A new audio series from Rattlestick Playwrights Theater imagines the bustle of the trains before the pandemic — one story and one station at a time.
lead_paragraph: Jasmine, a student at Brooklyn College, sprints across the platform to catch an idling train. She had lingered on the No. 2 a second too long, distracted by a performer-cum-mystic doling out free advice that felt eerily relevant. Now she was moments away from missing her transfer.

headline: Roger Berlind, 90, Dies; Broadway Impresario Who Amassed 25 Tonys
abstract: He played a role in producing more than 100 plays and musicals. And while he kept an eye on the bottom line, he could be seduced by sheer artistry.
lead_paragraph: Roger Berlind, who produced or co-produced more than 100 plays and musicals on Broadway, including such critical and box-office hits as “The Book of Mormon,” “Dear Evan Hansen,” “City of Angels” and revivals of “Guys and Dolls” and “Kiss Me, Kate,” died on Dec. 18 at his home in Manhattan. He was 90.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: A 2020 retrospective.
lead_paragraph: Seeking moments of light, we found solace in rescue animals, banana bread and — for the messy among us — the joy of not tidying up. We watched an awful lot of television, some of it excellent. We cooked, and cooked, and cooked (see below) — and then ordered takeout. Sometimes, we just played The Sims 4.

headline: Jeannie Morris, Trailblazing Chicago Sportscaster, Dies at 85
abstract: She was a rare woman in broadcast sports journalism when she began her career in the late 1960s, but she helped pave the way for the many women who followed.
lead_paragraph: Jeannie Morris, a television sports reporter, was in the visitors’ dugout in 1972 before a game at Comiskey Park in Chicago when the Hall of Fame hitter Ted Williams, who was managing the Texas Rangers, ordered her out.

headline: An Oscar Winner Made a Khashoggi Documentary. Streaming Services Didn’t Want It.
abstract: Bryan Fogel’s examination of the killing of the Saudi dissident Jamal Khashoggi had trouble finding a home among the companies that can be premier platforms for documentary films.
lead_paragraph: Bryan Fogel’s first documentary, “Icarus,” helped uncover the Russian doping scandal that led to the country’s expulsion from the 2018 Winter Olympics. It also won an Oscar for him and for Netflix, which released the film.

headline: ‘You Checked Tesla the Most’: Robinhood Recaps From a Volatile Year
abstract: And you thought your Spotify Wrapped was a bummer.
lead_paragraph: In 2020, wild fluctuations in the stock market caused by the pandemic turned millions of people into opportunistic investors. After stocks plunged in March, experienced traders and Nasdaq novices poured their dollars into buzzy tech companies like Tesla and Zoom, as well as businesses bludgeoned by Covid restrictions, including airlines, restaurants and cruises.

headline: Trump’s Most Disgusting Pardons
abstract: Blackwater mercenaries committed a massacre. Now they’ll go free.
lead_paragraph: The youngest victim of the 2007 massacre in Baghdad’s Nisour Square, committed by Blackwater mercenaries whom Donald Trump pardoned on Tuesday, was a 9-year-old boy named Ali Kinani.

headline: On Working With Congress, Biden Predicts Success Where Predecessors Failed
abstract: The president-elect insisted that his skills and his history would enable him to secure bipartisan support for bold initiatives.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When he takes office next month, President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. will confront a sharply divided Congress where many Republicans argued that his election was fraudulent.

headline: Parents of ‘Balloon Boy’ Are Pardoned by Colorado’s Governor
abstract: Richard and Mayumi Heene were accused of concocting a hoax after their 6-year-old son was feared to have floated away in a balloon in 2009. The boy was found safe at home.
lead_paragraph: In 2009, the authorities chased a silver helium balloon resembling a U.F.O. as it soared over Northern Colorado, fearing that a young boy was trapped inside. The frantic rescue effort unfolded on live television, but when the balloon landed, there was no boy inside.

headline: Disadvantaged Students More Likely to Be Learning Remotely, Study Finds
abstract: Research from Columbia University suggests that less effective instruction will widen the achievement gap.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Disadvantaged students are much more likely than others to be engaged in remote schooling during the coronavirus pandemic, increasing the risk that less effective instruction will widen the achievement gap, according to the first comprehensive analysis of attendance patterns.

headline: Facing Deportation, They Fled to the Safety of a Church. Now They are Free.
abstract: A Jamaican couple spent nearly two and a half years inside Philadelphia churches, isolated even further by the pandemic. This month, U.S. immigration officials relented.
lead_paragraph: Hand in hand, Oneita and Clive Thompson danced out of the Tabernacle United Church in Philadelphia, their fists raised in victory. The Jamaican couple had spent nearly two and a half years living in churches to avoid deportation.

headline: Her Father Had a Theory About Her Killing. Then Came the Arrest.
abstract: Ola Salem’s body was found in a Staten Island park last year. Her father said she had talked about being followed on the highway.
lead_paragraph: When Ola Salem’s body was discovered in a park on Staten Island in October 2019, her friends and relatives were left grasping for an explanation.

headline: Stimulus, Brexit, Storm:Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Covid-19 Patient Is Bludgeoned to Death in California Hospital
abstract: The victim, an 82-year-old man, was hit with an oxygen tank by another patient with whom he was sharing a room, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: An 82-year-old man who was being treated for Covid-19 at a hospital north of Los Angeles was bludgeoned to death with an oxygen tank last week by his roommate, the authorities said.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: In a disrupted holiday season, even Bethlehem is quieter than usual.
lead_paragraph: Despite Dr. Anthony Fauci’s claim of having vaccinated Santa Claus and NORAD’s annual wink-wink tracking of his sleigh, this is clearly an interrupted holiday season from pole to pole.

headline: Behind Trump Clemency, a Case Study in Special Access
abstract: Philip Esformes was sentenced last year to 20 years for Medicare fraud. Then a well-connected organization supported by his family weighed in with the White House.
lead_paragraph: Philip Esformes acquired a $1.6 million Ferrari and a $360,000 Swiss watch and traveled around the United States on a private jet, a spending spree fueled by the spoils from what federal prosecutors called one of the largest Medicare fraud cases in history.

headline: Columbus Officials Move to Fire Officer in Fatal Shooting of Black Man
abstract: The police chief said Officer Adam Coy “must be terminated immediately” for not quickly turning on a body camera and not providing aid to the man he shot.
lead_paragraph: Two days after a police officer in Columbus, Ohio, fatally shot a Black man within seconds of encountering him, the mayor and police chief moved to fire that officer.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Beijing Reins In Tech Behemoths It Let Run Free
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, December 25, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “In Chinese culture, if you are a rich guy and you have very strong economic power and social influence, then you are politically dangerous and you need to keep a very low profile to be safe.”

headline: Corrections: Dec. 25, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Dec. 25, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about the decline of the New England Patriots misstated the round in which quarterback Jarrett Stidham was drafted. It was the fourth round, not the sixth.

headline: A Perfect Score … or Half of One
abstract: Erik Agard collaborates with Wendy L. Brandes, who makes her New York Times Crossword debut.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — We’ve been floating along this week — solving some gloriously happy debuts — and this is another one, at least for one of the constructors. Wendy L. Brandes makes her New York Times Crossword debut in a challenging Friday collaboration with Erik Agard, who now serves as the editor of the USA Today crossword.

headline: Retries
abstract: John Guzzetta’s themeless grid rewards persistence.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This John Guzzetta puzzle is an interesting variation on the chunky themeless, because its biggest blocks are vertical. I wager that this makes a difference in the average difficulty of a solve, because most of us scan the across section of a grid completely before hitting the downs, so you’re bound to have a few crosses to help you at that point. I know there are some dedicated down-first solvers; this is the kind of puzzle that makes a good challenge for them.

headline: Russians Are Believed to Have Used Microsoft Resellers in Cyberattacks
abstract: Evidence from the security firm CrowdStrike suggests that companies that sell software on behalf of Microsoft were used to break into Microsoft’s Office 365 customers.
lead_paragraph: As the United States comes to grips with a far-reaching Russian cyberattack on federal agencies, private corporations and the nation’s infrastructure, new evidence has emerged that the hackers hunted their victims through multiple channels.

headline: Police Officer Is Shot in Brooklyn, but Vest Stops the Bullet
abstract: The 27-year-old officer, who had responded to a call about domestic violence, was “in a little pain” but “extremely good spirits” at a Brooklyn hospital, the police commissioner said.
lead_paragraph: A New York City police officer responding to a call about domestic violence was shot in the back Thursday night, but his vest stopped the bullet and he left a Brooklyn hospital on Friday, police officials said.

headline: U.S. Will Require a Negative Coronavirus Test for All Travelers From U.K.
abstract: The new rule, which takes effect on Monday, will apply to Americans as well as foreign nationals.
lead_paragraph: The United States will require all airline passengers arriving from Britain to test negative for the coronavirus within 72 hours of their departure, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said on Thursday.

headline: How My Father Escaped Jail for Christmas
abstract: He got out for good by (almost) dying.
lead_paragraph: My wife and I were getting ready for a Christmas party two years ago when my mother called to tell me that my father was in a coma. She explained the severity of the situation as I watched my wife slip on a black dress she had purchased for the occasion.

headline: What Happened When Henry Yao Almost Went Bust
abstract: His customers cherished his small business — and him — more than he ever knew.
lead_paragraph: It was time, perhaps, to go.

headline: An N.B.A. Christmas Gift: LeBron, Steph and Luka in Action
abstract: With LeBron James, Stephen Curry and Luka Doncic playing, there’s something for everyone. If you haven’t kept up since last season, here’s everything you need to know.
lead_paragraph: Christmas Day isn’t just the most important day of the year for our friends in the North Pole. It’s also a landmark day for the N.B.A., where for decades the league has put its top stars and best teams in matchups against each other for viewers to watch while guzzling egg nog. (The league’s first Christmas Day games came in 1947, when the Baltimore Bullets beat the Chicago Stags, 87-70 at the Baltimore Coliseum.)

headline: In Bethlehem and Jolly and Antlers, an American Christmas
abstract: Scenes from a holiday season that shone bright in dark times.
lead_paragraph: The roads were icy in Frostburg, Md. In Jolly, Texas, the mood was somber. Still, despite a season filled with challenges at every turn, by the time I got to Snowbird, Utah, it was clear that the holidays were in full swing.

headline: Weekly Health Quiz: Body Fat, Pulse Oximeters and a New Strain of Coronavirus
abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Adapting to a Holiday Season Stripped of Its Essence
abstract: Pandemic restrictions mean friends and families will not be gathering this year, but Canadians are coming together in other ways.
lead_paragraph: It always seemed odd that Joni Mitchell’s “River” became a Christmas standard. The music certainly contains bits of “Jingle Bells,” and the opening verses describe holiday activities. But it is fundamentally about a sad longing to escape the pain of heartbreak while evoking a metaphor from her home province, Saskatchewan: “I wish I had a river/I could skate away on.”

headline: In One Person, the Story of a Place
abstract: Since 2002, the Saturday Profile has sought the universal in characters around the world.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: What Biden and Harris Owe the Poor
abstract: They must reject the politics of austerity and fulfill their commitment to policies that address human needs.
lead_paragraph: Before he was elected in November, Joe Biden promised that his “theory of change” for reforming the economy would be “ending poverty.” He pledged to champion a $15 minimum wage, affordable health care for all and federal action to address systemic racism. In the midst of an economic crisis, a pandemic and an uprising for racial justice, low-income Americans — Black, white, brown, Asian and Native — voted to overwhelm a reactionary base that President Trump had stoked with lies and fear.

headline: Ending 2020 With a Sweet Bit of Release
abstract: The hot chocolate bomb is a tasty metaphor for a pent-up year.
lead_paragraph: After months upon months of palliative food trends — baking sourdough bread, swirling up cups of Dalgona coffee, cutting into deceptive cakes — 2020 is ending not with a whimper but a bang, in the form of a hot chocolate bomb.

headline: ‘Vodka in Your Coffee Cup’: When Pandemic Drinking Goes Too Far
abstract: Some women are seeking to regain control over their alcohol habits after months of laissez-faire consumption.
lead_paragraph: Martha Duke, who has been sober since Jan. 1, 2018, didn’t set out to become an abstinence guru during the “what does it matter anyway” drinking frenzy of 2020.

headline: Butter, Sugar and a Tablespoon of Grief
abstract: At the darkest time of year, we bake our pain and loss into something to pass to others when it becomes too much to carry.
lead_paragraph: For my mom, the weeks before Christmas exist solely for baking cookies.

headline: Small Donations Aiming to Make a Big Splash
abstract: Environmental issues may seem too big to tackle, but some smaller foundations have figured out ways to have an impact.
lead_paragraph: Brett Howell, a program manager at Coca-Cola in Atlanta, has found a way to use his small family foundation to take on environmental issues that have a big impact.

headline: Southern California’s Hospitals Are Overwhelmed, and It May Get Worse
abstract: Each day in California brings a mind-numbing new accounting of the tragedy underway. This week, the state became the first to reach two million virus cases.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — If this were any other year, members of the Los Angeles Opera would have been singing Christmas carols this week in the wards of Martin Luther King Jr. Community Hospital, which serves the largely poor and Latino communities of South Los Angeles. Instead, a street choir from Skid Row stepped in with a video to bring holiday cheer to the growing number of dying coronavirus patients and traumatized staff.

headline: Stateless, She Became the Face of a Largely Invisible Plight
abstract: Maha Mamo had no citizenship. Born in Lebanon of Syrian parents, she was ineligible for either nationality. It took her years of perseverance and some lucky breaks to find a homeland — in Brazil.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The subject was taboo during her childhood in Lebanon, whispered about but never discussed openly.

headline: How a Young Chess Phenom Spends His Sundays
abstract: Between studying moves with tutors in India and New York, Oliver Boydell has homework (with video game breaks, of course).
lead_paragraph: The problem with contemporary chess, said Oliver Boydell, who has won titles at the city, state and national levels, is that it has become too “positional,” without the mistakes and dazzling reversals of past chess eras. It is just not that much fun to watch.

headline: 8 Things We Hated About New York Until 2020 Happened
abstract: New Yorkers are world-famous kvetchers. But when we got something real to complain about, we changed our tune.
lead_paragraph: The arrival of the coronavirus in New York City at the end of last winter upended everything we did, thought and talked about. That friend who was always 15 minutes late to everything? Now many of us actually fantasize about sitting in a cramped bar, waiting for him.

headline: At French Resorts, Skiing Has Become an Uphill Sport
abstract: The government closed ski lifts, fearing they might spread the coronavirus. The skiers came anyway.
lead_paragraph: CHAMONIX, France — Last Saturday morning, dozens of skiers dotted the slopes above the Alpine hamlet of Le Tour. The cloud-snarled peak of Mont Blanc loomed above the Chamonix valley. The snow conditions were mediocre. The sky was blue. There was only one thing that made the early-season scene atypical: All of the visitors, every last one of them, were skiing up the mountain, not just down.

headline: How Pop Music Fandom Became Sports, Politics, Religion and All-Out War
abstract: On social media this year, the stan was ascendant, fueling commercial competition, trolling and other arcane battles. How did we get here?
lead_paragraph: Benjamin Cordero, a high school student from western New York, has a thing for pop divas, but especially Lady Gaga.

headline: The Loveliest Gift: Friends and Books, All Wrapped Together
abstract: Long before I worked at The New York Times, my friends and I leaned on the Books section for holiday cheer. We still do.
lead_paragraph: For the past few years, four of my friends and I have taken part in a Secret Santa book swap, turning to The New York Times’s annual 100 Notable Books list for selections. We comb the titles, flagging a few we might like and imagining which ones we would pick for one another.

headline: The Real Estate Collapse of 2020
abstract: The pandemic devastated the housing industry this year, but there were a few flickers of life.
lead_paragraph: At the beginning of 2020, the real estate market in New York City was still gaining steam. Sales prices had leveled off, but the rental market was strong. Then the pandemic turned everything upside down.

headline: Vaccine Memories of Another Time and Place
abstract: Many older Americans, shut in during this year’s pandemic, share haunting recollections from the polio era of their childhood.
lead_paragraph: Lizzo’s “Good As Hell” greeted the arrival of Covid-19 vaccines this month at Boston Medical Center, where the scene of dancing health care workers quickly spread on TikTok. Others shared triumphant selfies of their arms post-injection.

headline: ‘Stay Alive and Survive’: Ski Resorts Brace for a Pandemic Season
abstract: Many have put capacity restrictions in place, even as new lockdowns may spook visitors.
lead_paragraph: OLYMPIC VALLEY, Calif. — A trickle of skiers recently zigzagged down the slopes at the Squaw Valley Ski Resort. Couples and families wandered through the resort’s village, which was decorated with golden Christmas lights and frosted with snow.

headline: 25 Stories for December 25th
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: Every December, media organizations publish lists of the year’s “most read” stories (and you’ll see The Times’s list in a newsletter next week). But today — on Christmas — we’re going to do something different.

headline: Kristen Wiig Would Have Said Yes to One Line in ‘Wonder Woman 1984’
abstract: Getting to play Cheetah was even better for the “Saturday Night Live” star, who loves superhero movies: “It was huge on my list of things I wanted to do.”
lead_paragraph: “I want you to know, I dressed up for the interview,” a dryly sarcastic Kristen Wiig said from a computer screen. Clad in a well-worn sweatshirt, she was relating a familiar plight: how a monthslong regimen of video chats and conferences had gradually worn down her efforts to appear presentable on camera.

headline: Los últimos días de Trump en la Casa Blanca
abstract: Nacimientos en pandemia, la mejor música clásica y lo más reciente sobre brexit.
lead_paragraph: Es Navidad y, como escribía una lectora ayer, “casi da vergüenza decir felices fiestas”. Así que aquí está tu boletín en español de The New York Times, con algunas de las mejores lecturas para el fin de semana y nuestros mejores deseos para esta temporada.

headline: The Listeners’ Episode: Editors and Critics Answer Your Questions
abstract: We respond to questions about criticism, reading habits, favorite stories and more.
lead_paragraph: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen

headline: You Got a Bicycle, Now You Have to Take Care of It
abstract: Tips from an expert for properly storing your bike and giving it the maintenance it needs in the colder weather. You might even be able to cycle all winter if you dress for the occasion.
lead_paragraph: I first took up cycling in New York City in 2005, and at the time, I had never seen so much interest in biking — until Covid-19 struck. As the coronavirus pandemic has encouraged millions of Americans to rethink how they exercise, entertain themselves and move around their own cities and towns, bicycle sales and repairs have surged.

headline: U.K. Increasingly Isolated as U.S. Restricts Travel
abstract: America’s requirement that passengers coming from Britain provide negative coronavirus tests is just the latest woe to strike the country this Christmas period.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It was one more reminder, delivered before dawn on Christmas morning, that Britain is not only an island nation, but one that finds itself increasingly alone.

headline: How Pixar’s ‘Soul’ Animates Jazz
abstract: A look at the ways filmmakers and musicians collaborated to present an accurate view of players’ artistry.
lead_paragraph: Pixar’s animators have a history of achieving impressive feats, making characters and textures feel more authentic in increasingly complex ways. (That flowing hair! Those landscapes!) But how would they portray jazz?

headline: A Warning, Then a Blast: Nashville Explosion Was Deliberate, Police Say
abstract: An explosion linked to a vehicle sent debris and shattered glass into the streets, and injured three people.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — First came the warning, then came the blast, shattering the Christmas morning silence in the heart of the city’s tourist district.

headline: Boris Johnson Delivered on Brexit. It May Not Soothe His Unruly Party.
abstract: Conservatives are united for now over the British prime minister’s trade deal, but as details emerge, he could face challenges from hard-liners and business groups.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — An “exceptional victory,” the result of “fantastic work” and a deal that “delivered” for the British people.

headline: David Attenborough Still Has Hope for Our Future
abstract: At 94, the beloved British naturalist remains curious and optimistic. He talked about his new docu-series, “A Perfect Planet,” and why the coronavirus may prove to have some positive consequences.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Take away the state-of-the-art drones and the gyro-stabilized 4K cameras from the BBC’s latest blue-chip natural history series, “A Perfect Planet.” Strip out the luscious score and the stunning close-ups of nature at its most intimate.

headline: Minoru Makihara, Who Ran Mitsubishi After It Stumbled, Dies at 90
abstract: He steered the company, then the world’s largest, through the troubles of a collapsing economy, and dedicated himself to improving relations with the U.S.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Minoru Makihara, who led the Mitsubishi Corporation — then the world’s largest company — through the doldrums of Japan’s post-bubble era in the 1990s and helped it meet the demands of a globalizing economy, died on Dec. 13 in Tokyo. He was 90.

headline: Cook Yourself a Merry Christmas
abstract: Waffles, eggs Benedict, tips for a perfect rib roast: Eat well for the holiday.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Merry Christmas, if you’re celebrating. Hope you’re getting dim sum if you’re not, a nice spread of Peking duck, some version of spicy big tray chicken. It’s a marvelous day for takeout and relaxation. And even if you can’t get to the movies this year, you can always stream. Try “The Flight Attendant.” That Kaley Cuoco is good.

headline: 7 Podcasts to Comfort and Connect
abstract: If you’re feeling unmoored this holiday season, or just burned out from the past 10 months, these shows can provide a balm.
lead_paragraph: It’s almost time to bid goodbye and good riddance to 2020, one of the worst years most of us have ever lived through. Though the end of the pandemic is in sight, this holiday season remains a lonely, difficult one, with renewed lockdowns keeping many separated from their loved ones, their communities and their festive traditions.

headline: Pope Francis Makes Christmas Appeal for Nations to Share Vaccines
abstract: The pope made his remarks from inside the Vatican instead of before large crowds on St. Peter’s Square, as Christians around the world scaled back or reimagined Christmas traditions.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Pope Francis on Friday called on world leaders, businesses and international organizations to help ensure that the most vulnerable and needy have access to newly developed coronavirus vaccines.

headline: Russian Police Arrest a Top Navalny Ally
abstract: The police detained Lyubov Sobol amid a crackdown on activists seeking to draw attention to the nerve-agent poisoning of the opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The police on Friday arrested a top ally and two employees of Aleksei A. Navalny, the Russian opposition leader who over the summer narrowly survived a nerve-agent poisoning.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: A finger-food countdown to 2021. The rise and fall of the video game Cyberpunk 2077. A sanctuary for gibbons in Thailand. George Clooney on his new film. And more.
lead_paragraph: A finger-food countdown to 2021. The rise and fall of the video game Cyberpunk 2077. A sanctuary for gibbons in Thailand. George Clooney on his new film. And more.

headline: One Vaccine Side Effect: Global Economic Inequality
abstract: As Covid inoculations begin, the economic downturn stands to be reversed, but developing countries are at risk of being left behind.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The end of the pandemic is finally in view. So is rescue from the most traumatic global economic catastrophe since the Great Depression. As Covid vaccines enter the bloodstream, recovery has become reality.

headline: Explosion That Appears ‘Intentional’ Rattles Downtown Nashville
abstract: An explosion injured three people, damaged buildings and forced evacuations in downtown Nashville on Christmas morning. The authorities said they believed it was intentional and caused when a parked R.V. detonated outside an AT&T building.
lead_paragraph: An explosion injured three people, damaged buildings and forced evacuations in downtown Nashville on Christmas morning. The authorities said they believed it was intentional and caused when a parked R.V. detonated outside an AT&T building.

headline: Fried Chicken Is Joy
abstract: Try Nicole Taylor’s recipe, marinated in berry jam, or make a Gruyère puff, a classic pasta dish or a glorious pan of nachos this week.
lead_paragraph: Merry Christmas! Welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes, and while some of you may be off from work next week, you’ve still got to eat — and presumably, if you’re reading this, you’ve also got to cook. Even the most devoted home cooks have been tried in this endless year of endless kitchen tasks, as Tejal Rao wrote so eloquently about in The Times, and Helen Rosner in The New Yorker. (Do you read Helen Rosner on food in The New Yorker? You must.) I’ve felt it, too, not so much in the cooking itself, but in the relentless meal planning, and the loading and unloading and reloading of the dishwasher.

headline: Nancye Radmin, Pioneer of Plus-Size Fashion, Is Dead at 82
abstract: The Forgotten Woman boutique, which she opened in 1977, spoke directly to the nascent idea of body acceptance. It soon became a chain.
lead_paragraph: Nancye Radmin, a pioneer of plus-size fashion who for two decades ran an upscale chain of stores, the Forgotten Woman, that served a group of women who had otherwise been overlooked by high fashion, died on Dec. 8 at her home in Lakeland, Fla. She was 82.

headline: ‘Box’ or Gem? A Scramble to Save Asia’s Modernist Buildings
abstract: Groups across the region are rallying to save buildings that officials consider too new, too ugly or too unimportant to protect from demolition.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — When the General Post Office opened on Hong Kong’s waterfront in 1976, a local newspaper predicted that the Modernist-style building would “certainly become as much of a landmark” as its Victorian-era predecessor.

headline: With Pandemic Raging, London Homeless Take Shelter in Hotels for a While
abstract: Many homeless people in London will stay in hotels over the Christmas and New Year holidays, if not longer, through funding from charities and the government.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — There were a few places Roland Le felt comfortable sleeping in London: the doorway of shops he knew were closed and a wooded area near the city’s canal. Still, Mr. Le, who became homeless after he lost his job as a cleaner during the pandemic, never quite relaxed.

headline: For a Civil Rights Hero, 90, a New Battle Unfolds on His Childhood Street
abstract: Before he defended Rosa Parks and became a leading legal force, Fred Gray grew up on an avenue named for Jefferson Davis in Montgomery, Ala. Now a push is underway for a new name for the street: Mr. Gray’s.
lead_paragraph: MONTGOMERY, Ala. — This summer, as Mayor Steven L. Reed of Montgomery mulled over ways to commemorate the 65th anniversary of the city’s bus boycott, he took a critical look at whose legacies had been honored since that protest — and whose, it seemed, had been forgotten.

headline: Boston Doctor Reports Serious Allergic Reaction After Getting Moderna’s Covid Vaccine
abstract: The patient, who has a severe shellfish allergy, recovered quickly with treatment. Until now, reports of severe reactions had been linked to the Pfizer vaccine.
lead_paragraph: A Boston physician said he developed a severe allergic reaction minutes after receiving Moderna’s coronavirus vaccine on Thursday, in the first week of the nationwide rollout for the company’s shots.

headline: Generosity to Colleges in Need
abstract: Readers discuss the importance of gifts from MacKenzie Scott, the former wife of Amazon’s founder, Jeff Bezos.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Leave the Foreign Service to the Pros
abstract: A former officer seconds an Op-Ed essay’s urging of an end to the “sale” of ambassadorships. Also: Military spending; cheating at West Point.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Turkey and Brazil Say Chinese Vaccine Effective, With Sparse Supporting Data
abstract: The clinical trial in Turkey was much smaller than those of other major vaccine candidates, making the researchers’ claims for it less certain.
lead_paragraph: Turkish officials announced Thursday that a vaccine from the Chinese company Sinovac has an efficacy rate of 91.25 percent, but the finding was based on preliminary results from a small clinical trial and none of the data was published in a journal or posted online.

headline: Democrats in Georgia Runoffs Bring in Record Haul
abstract: The Rev. Raphael G. Warnock and Jon Ossoff each raised more than $100 million, according to campaign filings, signaling Democrats’ optimism heading into the Jan. 5 contests.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The Rev. Raphael G. Warnock and Jon Ossoff, the Democratic challengers in the Senate runoffs in Georgia, have each raised more than $100 million since October — enormous sums that surpassed their Republican opponents by a significant margin and underscored Democrats’ confidence after recent gains the party has made in the state and their hopes that they might capture the Senate.

headline: At Home Readers’ Best of 2020
abstract: What you watched, read and listened to this year.
lead_paragraph: Welcome, and Merry Christmas to those celebrating the holiday today. Perhaps you’ve been opening presents, perhaps cooking a feast, or caring for or hanging out with those you love. You might be working today, or hunkered down with a book. Hopefully, whatever you’re doing, you’re somewhere warm and safe.

headline: New York’s Pandemic Christmas: Muted Cheer, but Some Stick to Traditions
abstract: Bus terminals and train stations were all but empty and restaurant owners said business was slow. Still, the city’s resilience was evident.
lead_paragraph: There was no Santa Claus at the flagship Macy’s store, no Rockettes dazzling audiences with sky-high kicks at Radio City Music Hall. Broadway stayed dark through what is usually its busiest season, and with tourism severely diminished, there was so much room at New York’s inns that many hotels had to close.

headline: K.C. Jones, Celtics Standout as Player and Coach, Dies at 88
abstract: As a defense-minded guard, he played on eight consecutive championship teams. He later found success leading the team from the sidelines.
lead_paragraph: K.C. Jones, the quietly tenacious Hall of Fame guard who played on eight consecutive N.B.A. championship teams with the Boston Celtics and later coached the team to two league titles, died on Friday. He was 88.

headline: Images of Light: Christmas Services Penetrate Darkness Around the World
abstract: Despite the pandemic, Christmas traditions endure, shedding some brightness in a gloomy season.
lead_paragraph: Christmas falls on one of the darkest days of the year, coming soon after winter solstice. This year, it also came during a dark time for humanity amid a worldwide viral pandemic.

headline: Brexit Deal Done, Britain Now Scrambles to See How It Will Work
abstract: Britain is finally departing from the European Union, but its formal exit is only the beginning of a high-stakes experiment to unstitch commercial relations across an integrated continent.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For weary Brexit negotiators on both sides of the English Channel, a Christmas Eve trade agreement sealed 11 months of painstaking deliberations over Britain’s departure from the European Union, encompassing details as arcane as what species of fish could be caught by each side’s boats in British waters.

headline: Robert Thacker, 102, Dies; Survived Pearl Harbor to Fly in 3 Wars
abstract: His unarmed bomber was caught in the thick of Japan’s attack. He went on to fly some 80 missions in World War II and to become a record-setting test pilot.
lead_paragraph: Robert Thacker, who found himself caught in the middle of Japan’s surprise attack on Pearl Harbor when he was piloting an unarmed B-17 bomber to Hawaii for refueling, but managed to make a hair-raising landing and went on to a distinguished flying career in war and peace, died on Nov. 25 at his home in San Clemente, Calif. He was 102.

headline: Unemployment Aid Set to Lapse Saturday as Trump’s Plans for Relief Bill Remain Unclear
abstract: At least a temporary lapse in expanded unemployment benefits for millions of Americans is now inevitable because of President Trump’s delay in signing a $900 billion pandemic relief bill.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Expanded unemployment benefits were set to lapse for millions of struggling Americans on Saturday, a day after President Trump expressed more criticism of a $900 billion pandemic relief bill that was awaiting his signature and would extend them.

headline: Duke Women’s Basketball Ends Season Early Because of Virus Concerns
abstract: The team is the first Power Five basketball team to start and stop its season because of the pandemic. The men’s basketball team is expected to continue playing.
lead_paragraph: The women’s basketball program at Duke University will end its season early, the team announced Friday, because of mounting coronavirus concerns. It’s the first Power Five basketball team to start and stop its season because of the pandemic.

headline: She Chronicled China’s Crisis. Now She Is Accused of Spreading Lies.
