abstract: Zhang Zhan, who reported about the coronavirus from Wuhan during the lockdown, will face trial next week, in the first known case against a citizen journalist from the crisis.
lead_paragraph: In one video, during the lockdown in Wuhan, she filmed a hospital hallway lined with rolling beds, the patients hooked up to blue oxygen tanks. In another, she panned over a community health center, noting that a man said he was charged for a coronavirus test, even though residents believed the tests would be free.

headline: Corrections: Dec. 26, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Dec. 26, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Page 4 about the online variety show “Stars in the House” misstates the date of its first livestream. It was March 16, not March 17. The article also misstates when the number of shows per week was reduced. It was in June, not May.

headline: The Warriors’ Championship Glow Is Gone. And Yet …
abstract: Yes, the Golden State Warriors have looked awful in two blowout losses to start the season. But there are a few reasons for optimism. One big one: James Wiseman.
lead_paragraph: Before traveling to Milwaukee for their game against the Bucks on Friday afternoon, the Golden State Warriors spent four nights in New York.

headline: Ruling on Woman on Death Row Puts Her Execution in Doubt
abstract: A new delay could push Lisa Montgomery’s execution into the administration of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr., who has said he opposes the death penalty.
lead_paragraph: A ruling by a federal judge to delay the execution of the only woman on federal death row could push the new date into the early days of the administration of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr., who has said he would work to end federal capital punishment.

headline: Alvin Kamara Runs for Six Touchdowns Against Vikings
abstract: The Saints running back tied an N.F.L. record set in 1929 in New Orleans’ 52-33 win over the Minnesota Vikings.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS (AP) — Alvin Kamara expects to be fined for wearing a pair of Christmas-themed cleats that, as it turned out, would also be worthy of a Hall of Fame display.

headline: France and Japan report cases of the virus variant that prompted lockdowns in Britain.
abstract: France and Japan have reported their first cases of the coronavirus variant that prompted lockdowns in Britain and is feared to be more contagious than other strains.
lead_paragraph: France and Japan have reported their first cases of the coronavirus variant that prompted lockdowns in Britain and is feared to be more contagious than other strains.

headline: Why 530 Frozen Bodies Sit in a Brooklyn Warehouse
abstract: In the first wave of Covid, the crush of bodies overwhelmed New York City’s capacity to deal with the dead. Now, the city is prepared if a second onslaught occurs.
lead_paragraph: At the marine terminal in South Brooklyn this month, a sign that said “funeral director” pointed to the left of a vast warehouse just past the guard gate. A row of 53-foot refrigerated trailers, about 20 in all, sat in the black-tarred parking lot. Tucked past the fashionable furniture warehouses of Industry City and next to a crumbling pier building, the facility was quiet.

headline: A ‘Great Cultural Depression’ Looms for Legions of Unemployed Performers
abstract: With theaters and concert halls shuttered, unemployment in the arts has cut deeper than in restaurants and other hard-hit industries.
lead_paragraph: In the top echelons of classical music, the violinist Jennifer Koh is by any measure a star.

headline: As Virus Resurges in Africa, Doctors Fear the Worst Is Yet to Come
abstract: The coronavirus killed far fewer people in Africa than in Europe and the Americas, leading to a widespread perception that it was a disease of the West. Now, a tide of new cases on the continent is raising alarms.
lead_paragraph: PORT ELIZABETH, South Africa — At the center of a terrifying coronavirus surge, 242 patients lay in row after row of beds under the soaring metal beams of a decommissioned Volkswagen factory.

headline: 1895: Wretched Weather Mars Christmas in London
abstract: Rain, snow and driving sleet hit the British capital 125 years ago, though a program offering poor children a hamper of holiday foods was a bright spot.
lead_paragraph: [BY THE HERALD’S SPECIAL WIRE.] LONDON, Dec. 26. — At the best, London is a dull and desolate city in which to spend Christmas Day, but yesterday the weather was successful in giving the town a specially wretched appearance. The streets, after the heavy rain which had fallen through the night, were wet and muddy, and rain, snow and driving sleet fell at intervals during the entire day and kept the streets clearer of foot passengers than on an ordinary Sunday.

headline: The Brexit Fight, Through a Reporter’s Prism of a Changed Continent
abstract: Alan Cowell, a longtime New York Times correspondent, recalls a different Europe, one of currency controls, cumbersome paperwork and burdensome cross-border regulations.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — An image from my sepia-toned memory in the 1950s: by a summery wheat field freckled with poppies in northern France, English vacationers have halted for tea. A man primes a hand-cranked paraffin stove. A battered kettle is produced, and a teapot. Driving by in their bouncy Citroën 2CVs and curvy Renault Dauphines, French motorists observe the ritual with tolerant bemusement or haughty disdain. British travelers, a rarity then, wave when they spot a kindred license plate.

headline: Special Delivery: Thousands of Books
abstract: Children in remote parts of Alaska receive inspiration, with some books teaching Indigenous students about their cultures.
lead_paragraph: Lily Rivera, 11, likes to invent other worlds. She lives in a setting that often inspires her: Alaska’s Adak Island, which is home to the westernmost town in the United States and has sweeping views of the Bering Sea and volcanic mountains. Another inspiration: books. “If I’m reading a book, and I’m really into it, then I can actually see the characters go and do all the things that they’re doing," Lily says.

headline: A Stinging Setback in California Is a Warning for Democrats in 2022
abstract: Democrats lost four swing House districts in the state, suggesting that their hold on a number of formerly Republican seats is tenuous at best.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Two years ago, Democrats celebrated a sweep of seven Republican-held congressional seats in California as evidence of the party’s growing ability to compete in swing districts here and across the nation.

headline: The Darkest Timeline
abstract: “Deep Adaptation” made people confront the end of the world from climate change. Does it matter if it’s not correct?
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, an influential paper suggested that we were too late to save the world.

headline: Sailors Stranded for Months as China Refuses to Let Ships Unload Australian Coal
abstract: China is vague about why vessels that carried Australian coal to its ports can’t unload their cargo. “We’re all depressed; our mental health is deteriorating,” one sailor said.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — For the past six months, Virendrasinh Bhosale, a seafarer from India, has been trapped on a hunk of metal floating off China’s eastern coast.

headline: Brazil Is Famous for Its Meat. But Vegetarianism Is Soaring.
abstract: The number of vegetarians in Brazil doubled over a six-year period, which has given rise to a booming plant-based industry that is seeking to turn meatpacking plants obsolete.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — After years of whipping up large vegan meals for an ashram in the mountains outside Rio de Janeiro, Luiza de Marilac Tavares found her life upended, and herself out of a job, when the pandemic forced the center to shut down.

headline: Dad Got the Vaccine, but No One Else Did — Yet
abstract: Vaccinated health workers must navigate another new normal: households in which not all family members are immunized.
lead_paragraph: On the morning of Dec. 16, the threat of a Virginia snowstorm canceled school for 7-year-old Alain Bell. He instead spent the morning scribbling a scowling face in black marker onto his father’s newly vaccinated upper arm.

headline: Photography From the Year Time Stopped
abstract: Remember when? You probably don’t.
lead_paragraph: Usually, a photograph captures a moment in time and space. But this year, time and space were slippery and elastic. In the United States, things started off normally enough. January and February were sharply in focus: 2020 vision. But by March, time and space took on new implications and contexts. Time was counted in lockdown days; space, measured in increments of a safe six feet apart.

headline: George Blake, British Spy Who Betrayed the West, Dies at 98
abstract: He was caught spilling secrets to the Soviets in 1961 and imprisoned. Five years later, he escaped and fled to Moscow, where he was hailed as a hero.
lead_paragraph: George Blake, a notorious British double agent who betrayed Cold War secrets and Western spies to the Soviet Union in the 1950s and, after being caught, staged a spectacular escape to live out his life as a K.G.B. colonel in Moscow, has died. He was 98.

headline: Truck Jam Eases at U.K. Port Days After France Reopens Border
abstract: Even with new restrictions around the world to try to stop the transmission of a virus variant sweeping rapidly across Britain, the mutation has already spread to France, Spain and Japan.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A huge truck jam at the Port of Dover in England eased further on Saturday, days after France lifted a border blockade imposed over fears of a fast-spreading variant of the coronavirus that has already been transmitted to continental Europe and Japan.

headline: Early Vaccine Doubters Now Show a Willingness to Roll Up Their Sleeves
abstract: Polls show that pervasive skepticism is melting, partly because of the high efficacy rates in trials and the images of real people getting the shot.
lead_paragraph: Ever since the race to develop a coronavirus vaccine began last spring, upbeat announcements were stalked by ominous polls: No matter how encouraging the news, growing numbers of people said they would refuse to get the shot.

headline: Market Edges Toward Euphoria, Despite Pandemic’s Toll
abstract: Investors of all stripes piled into stocks this year, creating levels of froth reminiscent of the dot-com boom. Analysts say there’s room to go higher, but some worry about a bubble.
lead_paragraph: The stock market will not quit.

headline: It’s lonely on the top, and in the lodge, as ski resorts struggle.
abstract: A trickle of skiers recently zigzagged down the slopes at the Squaw Valley Ski Resort. Couples and families wandered through the resort’s village, which was decorated with golden Christmas lights and frosted with snow.
lead_paragraph: A trickle of skiers recently zigzagged down the slopes at the Squaw Valley Ski Resort. Couples and families wandered through the resort’s village, which was decorated with golden Christmas lights and frosted with snow.

headline: The truck jam at a U.K. port is easing, days after France reopened its border.
abstract: A huge truck jam at the Port of Dover in England eased further on Saturday, days after France lifted a border blockade imposed over fears of a fast-spreading variant of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: A huge truck jam at the Port of Dover in England eased further on Saturday, days after France lifted a border blockade imposed over fears of a fast-spreading variant of the coronavirus.

headline: Our 50 Most Popular Vegetarian Recipes of 2020
abstract: Save and cook them all.
lead_paragraph: Save and cook our most popular vegetarian recipes of the year: Colu Henry’s roasted tomato and white bean stew (above); Yasmin Fahr’s sheet-pan baked feta with broccolini, tomatoes and lemon; Yewande Komolafe’s crispy tofu with cashews and blistered snap peas; Alison Roman’s spicy white bean stew with broccoli rabe; and many more in the collection below. (And don’t miss our roundups of all our most popular recipes and desserts.)

headline: Snail, Fish and Sheep Soup, Anyone? Savory New Finds at Pompeii
abstract: The ancient site is the archaeological gift that keeps on giving. A food shop excavated this month suggests that its ancient residents had singular culinary tastes.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Wine turned white with crushed fava beans. A soupy concoction of snails, sheep and fish.

headline: She Turned 2020 Misery Into a Breakthrough
abstract: Sara Hall is a 37-year-old elite marathoner and mother of four. She showed me how years of setbacks can lead to unexpected rewards.
lead_paragraph: Just a few months ago, the veteran American distance runner Sara Hall seemed to be facing her own version of pandemic misery. She had failed to qualify for the Olympics, dropping out of her last two marathons. Now everything was canceled and she was caring for four daughters at home. She was 37, an age when many elite athletes’ careers start winding down.

headline: Austria enters its third lockdown. Israel is set to follow suit.
abstract: Austria entered a third lockdown on Saturday, with all nonessential shops and schools to remain closed for three weeks and movement to be restricted, after the country eased restrictions in mid-December to allow for preparations ahead of the Christmas holiday.
lead_paragraph: Austria entered a third lockdown on Saturday, with all nonessential shops and schools to remain closed for three weeks and movement to be restricted, after the country eased restrictions in mid-December to allow for preparations ahead of the Christmas holiday.

headline: Japan, Spain, France, Sweden and Canada find cases of the new coronavirus variant.
abstract: The discovery of the U.K. variant has prompted more travel restrictions.
lead_paragraph: Japan, Spain, France, Sweden and Canada have found small numbers of infections involving a new, potentially more transmissible variant of the coronavirus, most linked to travel from Britain, where it was first detected.

headline: What to Watch: Wars of the Past
abstract: Battles at sea, in the trenches and in city streets: The movies have gone there. Here are five films that look back at the world’s conflicts.
lead_paragraph: Battles at sea, in the trenches and in city streets: The movies have gone there. Here are five films that look back at the world’s conflicts.

headline: Nashville Explosion: What to Know
abstract: A girlfriend of the man who officials say set off a bomb in downtown Nashville had called police to his home last year, claiming that he was making bombs there, according to a police report.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — On Christmas morning, an R.V. exploded in downtown Nashville, injuring three people and disrupting telecommunications across the region. The authorities say the bomber, identified as Anthony Quinn Warner, died in the explosion. Here’s what else we know:

headline: Major Truck Jam Eases at U.K. Port
abstract: Drivers stuck outside Port of Dover in England were tested for the coronavirus before they could cross into France. On Saturday, nearly 1,600 trucks remained in the days-long jam, down from nearly 6,000 at its peak.
lead_paragraph: Drivers stuck outside Port of Dover in England were tested for the coronavirus before they could cross into France. On Saturday, nearly 1,600 trucks remained in the days-long jam, down from nearly 6,000 at its peak.

headline: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon work on their off week to send us into 2021.
lead_paragraph: CRYPTIC CROSSWORD — The cryptic is the crossword for the Sisyphus in all of us. Every time I finish a tough one, I feel as if I’ve made progress — so why is the next one never any easier? This is not a lament, let alone a complaint, yet it bears mentioning in case anyone else feels the same. Cryptics are always so much fun, though, and it is true that practice makes for a better solve, and a higher level of appreciation for cryptic “setters” or constructors.

headline: A Racial Slur, a Viral Video, and a Reckoning
abstract: A white high school student withdrew from her chosen college after a three-second video caused an uproar online. The classmate who shared it publicly has no regrets.
lead_paragraph: [To read more stories on race from The New York Times, sign up here for our Race/Related newsletter.]

headline: 2020 N.F.L. Playoff Picture: Mapping the Paths That Remain for Each Team
abstract: Visualizing the possible outcomes with two weeks to go.
lead_paragraph: Visualizing the possible outcomes with two weeks to go.

headline: Trump’s Fraud Claims Died in Court, but the Myth of Stolen Elections Lives On
abstract: For years, Republicans have used the specter of cheating as a reason to impose barriers to ballot access. A definitive debunking of claims of wrongdoing in 2020 has not changed that message.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s baseless and desperate claims of a stolen election over the last seven weeks — the most aggressive promotion of “voter fraud” in American history — failed to get any traction in courts across seven states, or come anywhere close to reversing the loss he suffered to Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: The E.U.’s vaccinations are set to begin Sunday, but a few places have jumped the gun.
abstract: The full rollout of the European Union’s vast vaccine campaign begins Sunday.
lead_paragraph: A 101-year-old woman in a nursing home in eastern Germany became the country’s first recipient of the BioNTech-Pfizer vaccine on Saturday, a day ahead of the European Union’s planned immunization campaign, an ambitious effort to eventually inoculate more than 450 million people across the 27 nations in the European Union against the coronavirus.

headline: Neverland Ranch, Former Home of Michael Jackson, Is Sold
abstract: Ronald W. Burkle, the billionaire co-founder of the investment firm Yucaipa Companies, bought the ranch for a reported $22 million.
lead_paragraph: A billionaire former associate of Michael Jackson has purchased the pop star’s former home, Neverland Ranch.

headline: A Beloved World War II Photo Comes to Life in a Virtual Reunion
abstract: Martin Adler, now 96, was looking for German troops in 1944 when he almost shot three Italian children. His daughter’s internet appeal brought them all together again this month.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Martin Adler was a 20-year-old private first class in the 339th Infantry regiment in 1944 when he and a fellow soldier went door to door in an Italian town looking for German troops.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Will Pandemic End My Career, Performers Ask
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, December 26, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “My fear is we’re not just losing jobs, we’re losing careers.”

headline: Fanny Waterman, Doyenne of the Leeds Piano Competition, Dies at 100
abstract: A British pianist and teacher, she helped establish one of the world’s most important piano showcases and then presided over it for decades.
lead_paragraph: Fanny Waterman, the British pianist and teacher who co-founded the prestigious Leeds International Piano Competition and oversaw it as chairwoman and artistic director for more than five decades, died on Dec. 20 at a care home in Ilkley, Yorkshire. She was 100.

headline: Federal Agents Scour Home as They Hunt for Clues in Nashville Blast
abstract: Investigators said they were working to determine whether more than one person was involved in the Christmas Day explosion that rattled the city.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Investigators were rushing on Saturday to piece together what officials described as an elaborate jigsaw puzzle, chasing hundreds of leads, to identify the culprit and the motivation behind the Christmas Day bombing that rocked Nashville.

headline: Michael Alig, Fixture of New York City Nightlife, Dies at 54
abstract: Mr. Alig, who gained fame in the 1980s as a party promoter, was a tabloid celebrity who served 17 years in prison for manslaughter.
lead_paragraph: Michael Alig, a longstanding tabloid fixture of New York City and a notorious promoter of its nightlife, died on Friday at his apartment in Washington Heights. He was 54.

headline: John Fletcher, a.k.a. Ecstasy of the Group Whodini, Dies at 56
abstract: He was, the executive who signed Whodini said, “truly one of the first rap stars” and a sex symbol “when they were very scarce in the early days of rap.”
lead_paragraph: John Fletcher, who as Ecstasy of the foundational hip-hop group Whodini was the engine for some of the genre’s first pop successes, wearing a flamboyant Zorroesque hat all the while, died on Wednesday in Atlanta. He was 56.

headline: Partnerships
abstract: Daniel Grinberg makes his Sunday debut with a companionable puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Daniel Grinberg is one of our multisport constructors, a researcher and user experience designer who also earned a Ph.D. in film and media studies. This is only his second Times grid, and his Sunday debut, the culmination of much pandemic pondering and punnifying, if you read his notes.

headline: Central and Southern California have 0 percent I.C.U. capacity, in a state already low on hospital beds.
abstract: California, the wealthiest and most populous state of the world’s wealthiest country, has long had a dearth of hospital beds — just 1.8 beds per 1,000 people, according to 2018 data compiled by the Kaiser Family Foundation. Now a record-shattering slew of coronavirus cases has wiped out intensive care unit capacity in a large swath of the state.
lead_paragraph: California, the wealthiest and most populous state of the world’s wealthiest country, has long had a dearth of hospital beds — just 1.8 beds per 1,000 people, according to 2018 data compiled by the Kaiser Family Foundation. Now a record-shattering slew of coronavirus cases has wiped out intensive care unit capacity in a large swath of the state.

headline: Jobless Benefits Run Out as Trump Resists Signing Relief Bill
abstract: Millions of Americans lost crucial unemployment coverage as President Trump continued to criticize the bill that would keep pandemic aid from lapsing.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Millions of Americans lost their unemployment coverage on Saturday as President Trump resisted signing a sweeping $900 billion aid package until lawmakers more than tripled the size of relief checks, putting the fate of the measure in limbo.

headline: The Haunting of Tulsa, Okla.
abstract: A recently unearthed mass grave may soon provide answers about what happened to victims of the 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre.
lead_paragraph: The Tulsa, Okla., police department set the stage for mass murder in the spring of 1921 when it deputized members of a mob that invaded and destroyed the prosperous Black enclave of Greenwood. The armed marauders who swept into the community in the early hours of June 1 wreaked havoc in the spirit of a police directive that urged white Tulsans to “Get a gun, and get busy and try to get a nigger.”

headline: Barry Lopez, Lyrical Writer Who Was Likened to Thoreau, Dies at 75
abstract: Mr. Lopez spent five years in the Arctic, and his books, essays and short stories explored the kinship of nature and human culture.
lead_paragraph: Barry Lopez, a lyrical writer who steeped himself in Arctic wildernesses, the habitats of wolves and exotic landscapes around the world for award-winning books that explored the kinship of nature and human culture, died on Friday at his home in Eugene, Ore. He was 75.

headline: Watch the Nutcracker and Listen to NASA’s Golden Record
abstract: This week, bake a classic tarte Tatin, celebrate Noon Year’s Eve or enjoy a birthday concert from Patti Smith.
lead_paragraph: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Federal Agents Comb Nashville Bomb Site as Telecom Outages Stall City
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, December 27, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “It is like a giant jigsaw puzzle created by a bomb that throws pieces of evidence across multiple city blocks.”

headline: Enhance Your Family Zoom Calls With an Online Game
abstract: The best way to digitally bond may be to beat the pants off your father-in-law.
lead_paragraph: At their best, good video calls are a mediocre substitute for real interaction. And when they’re bad? They can be really bad. If your Thanksgiving family Zoom devolved into melting down toddlers and bored teenagers, maybe it’s time to consider adding a little friendly competition to the mix.

headline: Indulge in Some Hot Cocktails
abstract: Festive and full of good cheer, these warm drinks will bring comfort to cold nights ahead.
lead_paragraph: There’s nothing like sitting bundled up outdoors around a firepit, or even indoors to escape the chill, with a hot drink to warm the hands, body and mood. Like a Southside in summer, warm cocktails and other drinks want winter. There are classics, like glühwein, Irish coffee and Tom and Jerry, or you can always toss a shot of brandy into a cup of hot chocolate or tea.

headline: Take Back Your Sex Life
abstract: With all its stress and uncertainty, this year hasn’t exactly been a banner year for intimacy. But that can change.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Petro is a 40-year-old writer who lives in New York with her husband of four years and two children. She and her husband switch off between working and kid duty. According to Ms. Petro, the always-on nature of parenting a 12-month-old and a 3-year old in a pandemic has been “relentless, exhausting and not sexy.” Recently her husband has been sleeping on the family room couch.

headline: A Global New Year’s Playlist for Your Party of One
abstract: This year finally coming to an end is reason enough to celebrate a bit.  Even if you had to stay home, your music can travel the world.
lead_paragraph: Around the world, New Year’s Eve is going to look very different this year, but the applause and cheers at midnight might have a level of catharsis not seen for awhile. People will certainly be celebrating 2020’s passing.

headline: Celebrate the New Year Safely
abstract: A highlight reel of what to watch and do (virtually, of course) to ring in the new year.
lead_paragraph: Along with so many things, the pandemic has dashed many of  go-to New Year’s traditions — no raging clubs, no in-person ball drop, no kissing strangers at midnight, not even the annual party that you begrudgingly went to year after year.

headline: How to Manage Your New-Year Expectations
abstract: A ‘Happy New Feels-The-Same Year’ isn’t too exciting a prospect. Here’s how to emotionally prepare yourself for the excitement lag.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our New Year’s Eve live coverage

headline: Opting Out of the N.F.L. Brings No Regret for This Jets Lineman
abstract: Leo Koloamatangi says he misses his team, even in a dreadful season, and that he has wondered what he might have accomplished this year. But he finds comfort in knowing his family is at a lower risk.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Sports department is revisiting the subjects of some compelling articles from the last year or so. Here is our August report on N.F.L. players who opted out of the league during the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: ‘As the Train Pulled Out of the Station, the Older Man Stood Up’
abstract: A late ride up the Hudson, a coincidence in Central Park and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: With Each Run, a City Shaken by Racism Is ‘Finding the Greater Good’
abstract: The route William Jones III designed 15 years ago through predominantly Black neighborhoods in Charlottesville, Va., has become the impetus for a diverse running group that’s grown since the summer.
lead_paragraph: In 2006, William Jones III moved with his wife, Yolonda, to Charlottesville, Va. Two years before, Jones, who is Black, had started jogging regularly. But when he looked around Charlottesville, he saw only white people running.

headline: The Treasured Diners and Hidden Haunts That Covid-19 Closed for Good
abstract: A Pittsburgh hot dog joint, a famous Cambridge dive bar and a vibrant Filipino restaurant in Los Angeles were among the casualties of 2020.
lead_paragraph: We gather today to mourn the 150-year-old restaurant that served up platters of fried chicken and creamed corn to Abilene, Kan. To bid farewell to the New Orleans cafe that was a destination for huge crab omelets and endless conversation. To raise one last glass to the tavern in Cambridge, Mass., where the regulars arrived at 8 a.m. and the Austin diner where Janis Joplin nearly sang the neon lights off the walls.

headline: Welcoming a New Year at an Ancient Festival in Pakistan
abstract: Chawmos, a festival of Pakistan’s tiny Kalash community, is a portrait in contrasts: solemn ritual and joyous dancing, gender segregation and public flirtation, togetherness and isolation.
lead_paragraph: RUMBUR, Pakistan — In a remote valley in northern Pakistan, hemmed in by sheer rock walls and high pastures, members of a tiny community gathered.

headline: Jobless benefits run out as Trump resists signing the relief bill.
abstract: Two critical federal unemployment programs expired on Saturday as President Trump resisted signing a sweeping $900 billion aid package into law until lawmakers more than tripled the size of relief checks.
lead_paragraph: Two critical federal unemployment programs expired on Saturday as President Trump resisted signing a sweeping $900 billion aid package into law until lawmakers more than tripled the size of relief checks.

headline: E.U.’s Mass Vaccination Campaign Starts, With Nursing Homes as Focus
abstract: An ambitious plan to inoculate more than 450 million people comes at a precarious moment for the continent, with many countries struggling with their worst outbreaks since the start of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — From nursing homes in France to hospitals in Poland, older Europeans and the workers who care for them rolled up their sleeves on Sunday to receive coronavirus vaccine shots in a campaign to protect more than 450 million people across the European Union.

headline: ‘I Want to Be at the Table When the Next Donald Trump Shows Up’
abstract: What’s your resolution for the next four years?
lead_paragraph: The last four years have been divisive and exhausting. But, for many, they were also a call to change what we can control: our own lives.

headline: Can Jeff Koons Teach Me to Paint?
abstract: Jeff Koons has entered the classroom at 65, signing on as an instructor for MasterClass. An art critic tuned in to glean some of the master’s magic.
lead_paragraph: The history of vanguard artists teaching — as a job, as art, or as some combination of the two — is rich and varied. Joseph Beuys conceived of lectures as performances, explaining artworks to a dead hare in a famous 1965 piece. Faith Ringgold has worked with students from pre-K through college and composed remarkable children’s books. Ian Wilson, who died in April, spent years leading discussions of his ideas in a Socratic style.

headline: The Place Hit Hardest by the Virus
abstract: The coronavirus has disfigured Gallup, a small New Mexico town near Native American reservations that is now one of the hardest hit places in the country.
lead_paragraph: Hospitals in Gallup are nearly full. Most stores are empty. The unemployment rate in the county where the city sits is one and a half times the national average. Earlier this month, it had the most cases per capita of any metro area in the United States, according to a New York Times database.

headline: Man Sues Police After Being Pepper-Sprayed While Filming Son’s Arrest
abstract: An officer involved in the episode, which happened in Keller, Texas, was demoted for misconduct, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Marco and Dillon Puente, a father and son, say that living in the city of Keller, Texas, often means looking over their shoulder.

headline: China Orders Ant Group to Revamp Its Business
abstract: The country’s central bank made clear its displeasure with the financial technology company, adding to the growing scrutiny of Chinese internet giants.
lead_paragraph: Chinese regulators on Sunday ordered the financial-technology giant Ant Group to fix what they described as a litany of business failings, escalating a pressure campaign that has been building since the government abruptly halted the company’s plans for a record-breaking share listing last month.

headline: Pandemic Relief, Nashville, Brexit: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: The Week in Business: The Bitter End
abstract: It wouldn’t be 2020 without a last-minute wrench in a much-needed pandemic aid bill.
lead_paragraph: Goodbye, 2020, and good riddance. Here’s what you need to know for the week ahead in business and tech, but most important, cheers to a better 2021. Please ring in the new year safely. — Charlotte Cowles

headline: Corrections: Dec. 27, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Dec. 27, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Page 4 about the online variety show “Stars in the House” misstates the date of its first livestream. It was March 16, not March 17. The article also misstates when the number of shows per week was reduced. It was in June, not May.

headline: In efforts to vaccinate Europeans, a push to overcome skepticism.
abstract: Prime Minister Andrej Babis of the Czech Republic received his country’s first coronavirus vaccination on Sunday, followed by a World War II veteran, as the nation began both a vaccine campaign and a stricter lockdown to confront a second wave of infection that is sweeping thorough Eastern Europe.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Andrej Babis of the Czech Republic received his country’s first coronavirus vaccination on Sunday, followed by a World War II veteran, as the nation began both a vaccine campaign and a stricter lockdown to confront a second wave of infection that is sweeping thorough Eastern Europe.

headline: In a Village of Widows, the Opium Trade Has Taken a Deadly Toll
abstract: Afghan men in an impoverished border settlement die trying to smuggle opium into Iran, leaving behind loved ones forced to survive on their own.
lead_paragraph: MIR ALI, Afghanistan — On the barren high plains of western Afghanistan, along a roadway south of Herat city, is a collection of sturdy earthen huts known as Qala-e-Biwaha, or “village of widows.”

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘Cher Everlasting’
abstract: “Moonstruck” sustained many people through the pandemic. Caity Weaver spoke with Cher about why the film endures.
lead_paragraph: The escapism of movies took on a new importance during pandemic isolation. Caity Weaver, the author of this week’s Sunday Read, says that to properly embrace this year’s cinematic achievements, the Academy Awards should not only hand out accolades to new releases, but also to the older films that sustained us through this period.

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $450,000
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: Trump signs a pandemic relief bill.
abstract: WASHINGTON — President Trump abruptly signed a measure on Sunday providing $900 billion in pandemic aid and funding the government through September, ending last-minute turmoil over a possible government shutdown and an economic lifeline for millions of Americans.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump abruptly signed a measure on Sunday providing $900 billion in pandemic aid and funding the government through September, ending last-minute turmoil over a possible government shutdown and an economic lifeline for millions of Americans.

headline: I Think Beethoven Encoded His Deafness in His Music
abstract: Gabriela Lena Frank, a composer born with high-moderate/near-profound hearing loss, describes her creative experience.
lead_paragraph: Gabriela Lena Frank, a composer and pianist and the founder of the Gabriela Lena Frank Creative Academy of Music, which aims to foster diverse compositional voices and artist-citizens, was born with a neurosensory high-moderate/near-profound hearing loss. In an interview with Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim, she described her creative practice and her exploration of the music of Beethoven, who gradually lost his hearing and by his 40s was almost totally deaf. These are edited excerpts from the conversation.

headline: Army Green Beret Charged in Fatal Shooting at Illinois Bowling Alley
abstract: Three people were killed and three others injured in what the police described as a “completely random” act.
lead_paragraph: The suspect in a fatal shooting at a bowling alley in Illinois is a U.S. Army Green Beret assigned to the Army’s 7th Special Forces Group based in Florida, the authorities said on Sunday.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Nicole Taylor spoke with five families celebrating Kwanzaa, and returned with incredible recipes for BBQ tofu, coffee-rubbed grilled fish and vegan doughnuts.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Kwanzaa began on Saturday, a tradition modeled after harvest or “first fruits” celebrations in ancient Africa that started in Los Angeles in 1966 and that has since taken root across the nation. For The Times this week, Nicole Taylor spoke with five celebrating families to explore the foodways of the holiday, and returned with some incredible recipes you might try this week, including for BBQ tofu, coffee-rubbed grilled fish and vegan doughnuts (above).

headline: Ex-Military Officers Criticize Spain’s Government and Praise Franco
abstract: The comments by former officers, and some current ones, struck a raw nerve in a country that had been ruled by a military dictatorship.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Earlier this month, 271 former members of Spain’s armed forces used the anniversary of the country’s Constitution to issue a manifesto criticizing the left-wing coalition government and warning that Spain’s unity was under threat.

headline: 1 of every 17 people in the U.S. has been infected, and 1 in 1,000 has died. Yet the worst may lie ahead.
abstract: With bubble-enclosed Santas and Zoom-enhanced family gatherings, much of the United States played it safe over Christmas while the coronavirus rampaged across the country.
lead_paragraph: With bubble-enclosed Santas and Zoom-enhanced family gatherings, much of the United States played it safe over Christmas while the coronavirus rampaged across the country.

headline: Reginald Foster, Vatican Latinist Who Tweeted in the Language, Dies at 81
abstract: One of the world’s foremost experts on Latin, Father Foster was a monk who looked like a stevedore, dressed like a janitor and swore like a sailor.
lead_paragraph: Reginald Foster, a former plumber’s apprentice from Wisconsin who, in four decades as an official Latinist of the Vatican, dreamed in Latin, cursed in Latin, banked in Latin and ultimately tweeted in Latin, died on Christmas Day at a nursing home in Milwaukee. He was LXXXI.

headline: Battered Turkish Economy Puts a Powerful Erdogan to the Test
abstract: Turkey’s veteran leader played an aggressive hand abroad, but as the country’s economy plummets, he is feeling ire at home as many Turks struggle to buy food.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Hobbled by restrictions on his tobacco shop, Ozgur Akbas helped organize a demonstration in Istanbul last month to protest what he called unfair rules imposed on merchants during the pandemic.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Vaccines roll out across Europe.
lead_paragraph: From nursing homes in France to hospitals in Poland, older Europeans and the workers who care for them rolled up their sleeves on Sunday to receive coronavirus vaccine shots.

headline: Barbara Rose, Critic and Historian of Modern Art, Dies at 84
abstract: She wrote a celebrated college textbook, but, extending her reach beyond academia, she preferred exploring the unfolding art of the present.
lead_paragraph: Barbara Rose, the influential art historian and critic who began her career as a champion of Minimalism and wrote about culture with an authority informed by her close friendships with two generations of artists in New York and abroad, died on Friday in Concord, N.H. She was 84.

headline: Phil Niekro, Hall of Fame Knuckleball Pitcher, Dies at 81
abstract: A five-time all-star, he played in the major leagues for 24 seasons, but never made it to the World Series.
lead_paragraph: Phil Niekro, the Hall of Fame pitcher who confounded batters with his fluttering knuckleballs for 24 seasons, winning 318 games, mostly with mediocre Atlanta Braves teams, before retiring at the ripe age of 48, died on Saturday. He was 81.

headline: Jon Huber, Who Rose to Fame With World Wrestling Entertainment, Dies at 41
abstract: Mr. Huber, who was known in the ring as Brodie Lee and Luke Harper, died from a “lung issue” unrelated to Covid-19, his wife said.
lead_paragraph: Jon Huber, a pro wrestler known in the ring as Luke Harper and Brodie Lee, died on Saturday. He was 41.

headline: From Reagan to Trump, Denying Facts
abstract: Readers react to a column by Paul Krugman about a history of G.O.P. rejection of science and facts.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Mark Shields Gave Us the Best of Commentary
abstract: Readers join David Brooks in extending thanks to Mr. Shields as he steps down from his “PBS NewsHour” role. Also: Affordable housing in Midtown; my insulin pump.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The big question for the U.S. vaccine campaign: Who’s next?
abstract: Not all states will follow the guidance of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
lead_paragraph: The federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends that the first shots of the coronavirus vaccines go to people in nursing homes and other long-term care facilities as well as to doctors, nurses and frontline health care workers, and there has been little disagreement over that guidance.

headline: Did These New York Clinics Ignore Rules on Who Gets Vaccinated First?
abstract: The state is investigating whether a network of urgent care clinics provided vaccinations to members of the public who were not yet entitled to have the shots.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus vaccine has finally arrived in New York, but only a select group of at-risk people are supposed to receive it in the first round.

headline: Managing Movie Superheroes Is About to Get a Lot More Complicated
abstract: Walter Hamada, who runs DC Films, is overseeing a dizzying number of projects, part of a swarm of comics-based stories coming from Hollywood.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Walter Hamada is not a typical superhero wrangler.

headline: Jets Start a Winning Streak and Diminish Browns’ Playoff Hopes
abstract: The Jets’ second win of the season removed the possibility of them getting the No. 1 pick in next year’s draft, while Cleveland is at risk of extending the league’s longest postseason drought.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. (AP) — Baker Mayfield coughed up the ball — and the Cleveland Browns’ chances to secure a playoff spot.

headline: Who Wants Candy?
abstract: The unbeatable Alan Massengill and Andrea Carla Michaels return for another collaboration with great aspirations.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — The dynamic duo of Andrea Carla Michaels (a.k.a. ACME) and Alan Massengill eases us into the slow and lazy week between Christmas and New Year’s Day, a time when you might toss aside your Zoom meeting blazer to lounge around the home office, catching up on crosswords. Though this puzzle — accessible and smooth, even for a Monday — has more than its share of crosswordese answers, it’s cleverly clued to make the most of them.

headline: As Bills Pile Up, Many Anxiously Keep Tabs on the Stimulus Bill
abstract: Financially pressed Americans are looking forward to extended unemployment benefits and a $600 check, finally signed into law by the president.
lead_paragraph: More than 10 million Americans who have been left in financial limbo — many of them on the brink of poverty — spent the weekend anxiously awaiting word about whether President Trump would continue to withhold approval of the $900 billion pandemic relief package sent to him on Christmas Eve.

headline: Ravens Snatch Back Giants’ Playoff Hopes
abstract: Baltimore made its case for the wild-card spot as the Giants fell back to earth — and toward the bottom of the N.F.C. East — in a rout.
lead_paragraph: [Read our NFL Playoff Picture Forecast, Odds and Scenarios for Week 17]

headline: What We Learned From Week 16 of the N.F.L. Season
abstract: The Steelers came back to beat the Colts, Kansas City survived against Atlanta and Jacksonville secured the No. 1 pick in the draft.
lead_paragraph: [Read our NFL Playoff Picture Forecast, Odds and Scenarios for Week 17]

headline: Heather Cox Richardson Offers a Break From the Media Maelstrom. It’s Working.
abstract: She is the breakout star of the newsletter platform Substack, doing the opposite of most media as she calmly situates the news of the day in the long sweep of American history.
lead_paragraph: Last Wednesday, I broke the news to Heather Cox Richardson that she was the most successful individual author of a paid publication on the breakout newsletter platform Substack.

headline: Video Shows Black 14-Year-Old Falsely Accused of Theft in a SoHo Hotel
abstract: A woman falsely accused the teenager of taking her phone in the video, which fueled concerns about racial profiling. It was shared by the teenager’s father, a prominent jazz musician.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday afternoon, Keyon Harrold, a prominent jazz musician, and his 14-year-old son walked into the lobby of the Arlo, a boutique hotel in SoHo where they were staying, when they were accosted by a woman they had never seen before.

headline: Black Teenager Falsely Accused of Cellphone Theft in SoHo Hotel
abstract: A woman can be seen yelling at the 14-year-old in video captured at the Arlo Hotel in New York City on Saturday by his father, the jazz musician Keyon Harrold. Mr. Harrold said her phone was later found in an Uber.
lead_paragraph: A woman can be seen yelling at the 14-year-old in video captured at the Arlo Hotel in New York City on Saturday by his father, the jazz musician Keyon Harrold. Mr. Harrold said her phone was later found in an Uber.

headline: A Quiet Life, a Thunderous Death, and a Nightmare That Shook Nashville
abstract: DNA tests show that Anthony Warner blew himself up along with a stretch of downtown Nashville on Christmas morning.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Anthony Warner had a solitary job as an information technology specialist, stopping in to various offices to fix computers. He was 63. He was not married. His neighbors barely knew him.

headline: Trump Signs Pandemic Relief Bill After Unemployment Aid Lapses
abstract: After calling the measure a “disgrace,” President Trump unexpectedly signed the bill, extending expanded unemployment benefits and an eviction moratorium, and keeping the government open.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Sunday abruptly signed a measure providing $900 billion in pandemic aid and funding the government through September, ending last-minute turmoil he himself had created over legislation that will offer an economic lifeline to millions of Americans and avert a government shutdown.

headline: 7 Wonderful Non-Covid Things We Learned in 2020
abstract: Sleep more, procrastinate less and get better at money in 2021.
lead_paragraph: What a year! Yes, it was terrible and awful and no one felt good about it, but on the other hand, time is a human invention and everything bad about 2020 will continue straight into 2021, because the end-and-begin points of a new year are arbitrary and meaningless.

headline: Seahawks Defense Is an Asset Again in Division-Clinching Win
abstract: Seattle’s much-maligned defense held Los Angeles to field goals as the two N.F.C. West teams streak in opposite directions to end the regular season.
lead_paragraph: [Read our NFL Playoff Picture Forecast, Odds and Scenarios for Week 17]

headline: Vaccine, Brexit, Trump: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: More Than 190,000 Ceiling Fans Are Recalled After Blades Detach
abstract: The flying blades can cause injury and damage property, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said.
lead_paragraph: More than 190,000 ceiling fans available through The Home Depot have been recalled after it was found that their blades could detach while spinning, causing injuries and property damage.

headline: Betty Campbell-Adams, Bronx Evangelist of Carrot Cake, Dies at 65
abstract: The bakery Ms. Campbell-Adams founded with her husband has won legions of fans all over the world for the Caribbean-infused delicacy that is its specialty.
lead_paragraph: Betty Campbell-Adams, who with her husband — and the help of his Caribbean grandmother’s secret carrot cake recipe — founded Lloyd’s Carrot Cake, a Bronx institution that has become internationally renowned for its sweet delicacy, died on Dec. 11 in Mount Vernon, N.Y. She was 65.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Jimmy Carter Rock & Roll President’ and ‘RuPaul’s Drag Race’
abstract: A recent documentary about Jimmy Carter airs on CNN. And the 13th season of “RuPaul’s Drag Race” debuts on VH1.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Dec. 28-Jan. 3. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Italy Turns to Flower Power to Help Spread Vaccine Message
abstract: The architect Stefano Boeri has designed primrose-themed pavilions where coronavirus shots will be given, but not everybody is thrilled with the idea.
lead_paragraph: ROME — This has been an ugly year for Italy.

headline: Our Altered View of Sports After 2020
abstract: The coronavirus changed sports. But it also changed us. Will our connection as fans always be divided into a before, and an after?
lead_paragraph: [Read our NFL Playoff Picture Forecast, Odds and Scenarios for Week 17]

headline: Quotation of the Day: E.U. Sets in Motion a Plan to Vaccinate Nearly Half a Billion People
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, December 28, 2020
lead_paragraph: “It is not even for me, but it is the only way to stop the virus.”

headline: No Corrections: Dec. 28, 2020
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Dec. 28, 2020.
lead_paragraph: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Dec. 28, 2020.

headline: Chinese Citizen Journalist Sentenced to 4 Years for Covid Reporting
abstract: Zhang Zhan, a former lawyer, is the first known person to be tried for challenging the Chinese government’s narrative about the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: A Chinese court on Monday sentenced a citizen journalist who documented the early days of the coronavirus outbreak to four years in prison, sending a stark warning to those challenging the government’s official narrative of the pandemic.

headline: Yang Presses Forward, Wiley Is Sidelined: Highlights From Mayor’s Race
abstract: Andrew Yang met with the Rev. Al Sharpton, and Maya Wiley is in quarantine. Yet another candidate joined those seeking to become New York City’s next mayor.
lead_paragraph: Few elected officials seem more eager than Mayor Bill de Blasio to put, as he phrased it, this “God-forsaken” year behind him. But 2020 was not without its lessons for this mayor and for those seeking to succeed him.

headline: Refugees Come Under Fire as Old Foes Fight in Concert in Ethiopia
abstract: Forces from neighboring Eritrea have joined the war in northern Ethiopia, and have rampaged through refugee camps committing human rights violations, officials and witnesses say.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — As fighting raged across the Tigray region of northern Ethiopia last month, a group of soldiers arrived one day at Hitsats, a small hamlet ringed by scrubby hills that was home to a sprawling refugee camp of 25,000 people.

headline: Democrats’ Georgia Hopes Rest on Jon Ossoff, 33. How Did He Get Here?
abstract: Some well-timed introductions and a knack for opportunity have helped Mr. Ossoff’s rise in Georgia politics. Now he is pursuing his most ambitious goal yet, a U.S. Senate seat.
lead_paragraph: Jon Ossoff was 16 years old when he wrote a letter to John Lewis, the Georgia congressman and civil rights pioneer, that led to a spot as a volunteer in Mr. Lewis’s office.

headline: How the Pandemic Is Imperiling a Working-Class College
abstract: The coronavirus has hurt Indiana University of Pennsylvania, but its financial problems were planted years ago.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Foor’s grandparents are in their 70s, so when the pandemic hit, its stresses gave her such stomach pains that she could not eat or sleep. She worried she would infect them if she brought the coronavirus home from Indiana University of Pennsylvania, where she is a senior, or from Walmart, where she stocks milk and eggs to help pay tuition.

headline: How the Police Killed Breonna Taylor
abstract: None of the police officers who raided Breonna Taylor’s home wore body cameras, impeding the public from a full understanding of what happened. The Times’s visual investigation team built a 3-D model of the scene and pieced together critical sequences of events to show how poor planning and shoddy police work led to a fatal outcome.
lead_paragraph: None of the police officers who raided Breonna Taylor’s home wore body cameras, impeding the public from a full understanding of what happened. The Times’s visual investigation team built a 3-D model of the scene and pieced together critical sequences of events to show how poor planning and shoddy police work led to a fatal outcome.

headline: A New Theory About the Monolith: We’re the Aliens
abstract: A mysterious metal pillar in a desert would be interesting in any year. But something about 2020 has made one a global phenomenon.
lead_paragraph: The desert of southeastern Utah is a wilderness of flat-topped mesas, jutting buttes and plunging canyons. It is a fantastical landscape, the kind of scenery that pulls your thoughts toward things not quite of this earth. Indigenous people from the region have told stories of deities who formed the mountains by sweeping rocks through a hole in the heavens, and of warrior gods who stomped the topography into existence with their mighty footfalls. Other local legends hold that the desert is haunted by screaming ghosts or stalked by a phantom wolf. The area is known for U.F.O. sightings, and its arid terrain, dotted with crimson sandstone outcroppings, has often been likened to Mars. Since 2001, a group advocating the human settlement of Mars has maintained a research center outside a small town called Hanksville, where crews live for weekslong stretches to simulate habitation on the red planet. The desert is, literally, home to would-be Martians.

headline: Her Stomach Hurt Unbearably. Her Doctors Were Baffled.
abstract: Then she remembered a story from her mother.
lead_paragraph: The 45-year-old leaned forward in the car’s front seat, the seatbelt tight across her chest. She and her partner had driven to pick up some groceries, but now she was afraid to move, terrified of doing anything that might trigger the intense pain she was suffering. Her boyfriend looked at her, worried and frustrated. You have to go to the hospital, he told her. She had been in pain all morning, but each time he suggested they go to the E.R., she refused. Now she finally relented. He edged the car out into traffic and drove to nearby Cooley Dickinson hospital in Northampton, Mass.

headline: How My Pet Snake Taught Me to Really See
abstract: For most of us, snakes are as much symbol as animal. But I haven’t communed with a metaphor for all these years.
lead_paragraph: When prompted by a website’s security question or a nostalgic turn in conversation, I say my first best friend was a boy named Colby. We met at age 2 and share a birthday, Jan. 5, a coincidence that seemed meaningful so early in life, enough to base a friendship on. It is an easy story to tell. But it’s not the whole truth.

headline: Rev. William Barber on Greed, Poverty and Evangelical Politics
abstract: “Jesus never charged a leper a co-pay!”
lead_paragraph: “Jesus never charged a leper a co-pay!”

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Jan. 6, 2021
abstract: How many workers are there in frontline and essential occupations? Who should get vaccinated first?

headline: How Parade Underwear Took Over Instagram
abstract: Free underwear went a long way for this small business.
lead_paragraph: The tagged photo section on the Instagram page for Parade, an underwear start-up founded in fall 2019, shows a surfeit of images of young women modeling brightly colored briefs and bikinis. Many of them pose in studio apartments, stretched out on velvet couches and propped up on dressers. Some press against vinyl shower curtains, donning the neon underwear in mirror selfies. All of them look effortless.

headline: This Astrologer Has Some Things to Tell Kara Swisher
abstract: Chani Nicholas demystifies a $2.2 billion industry (and reads Kara’s birth chart).
lead_paragraph: Astrology has been around for thousands of years, so why are “Mercury in retrograde” memes and horoscopes still so popular in 2020?

headline: Turning the Page on the Year
abstract: If ever there were a new year that called for a new notebook, this would be it.
lead_paragraph: The empty pages of my notebooks mock me at this time of year, as they have done ever since I was a child.

headline: Which Developing Economies Will Rise After the Pandemic?
abstract: The crisis has created many obstacles to growth, but also some opportunities.
lead_paragraph: After 2000, globalization and surging commodity prices astronomically boosted economic growth among nations with emerging economies. Over the next decade their share of the global economy nearly doubled, growing to 35 percent. By 2007, 107 of the 110 developing economies featured in the Penn World Table were catching up to the United States in average income, helping millions to escape poverty. The celebratory mood was captured in a popular phrase: “The rise of the rest.”

headline: I Hate the Mom That Covid Has Made Me
abstract: The pandemic has changed my relationship with my teens.
lead_paragraph: One recent Thursday, I sent my 14- and 15-year-old boys off to the skate park near our house. I’m a parent who values a childhood lived outdoors. To that end, I’ve been a fairly free-range mom with my four kids, but as they left for the park, I gave them a warning that still feels foreign, even eight months into this pandemic. “Leave your masks on!” They both gave a nod of agreement and were off.

headline: It’s Not That Hard to Buy Nothing
abstract: Some people re-evaluated their relationship to things in 2020. Here’s what they learned.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Chai decided she would not buy anything in 2020, with the exception of food, coffee, toiletries (if she ran out of something essential) and the occasional service like a haircut. She would resist the urge to add to her wardrobe or to buy anything material for her home. She would fix things or borrow them instead of purchasing new ones, and she would get rid of stuff she already had; 2,020 items sold, donated or tossed was her goal.

headline: A State Skirmish Over N.C.A.A. Amateurism Rules Has Quickly Become a National Battle
abstract: Since California passed a law allowing college athletes to profit from their fame, the issue has broadened and moved to Capitol Hill.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Sports department is revisiting the subjects of some compelling articles from the last year or so. Here is our original report on the introduction of a California bill that would allow college athletes to benefit financially from their fame.

headline: California May Lose Some of Its Stars. But Silicon Valley Is Forever.
abstract: The obituary for the state’s tech industry has been written before, and it will be rewritten again and again and again.
lead_paragraph: Is Texas the new Silicon Valley? This month Oracle said it was moving its headquarters to Austin after more than 40 years in California. Hewlett Packard Enterprise, descended from the Valley’s original garage start-up, is off to Houston. Elon Musk has moved to Texas, too, and has hinted that Tesla, the car company he co-founded and leads, may also relocate.

headline: The Risks of Using Steroids for Respiratory Infections
abstract: Doctors often prescribe them for sore throats and the common cold, even though evidence of benefit is sorely lacking.
lead_paragraph: “Steroid Shots and the Culture of Instant Gratification,” an editorial published Oct. 8 in JAMA Otolaryngology-Head & Neck Surgery online, highlights a chronic ailment in American medical care: a frequent failure to practice evidence-based medicine. Maybe I’ve been living under a rock, but I was surprised to learn that doctors often prescribe oral or injected corticosteroids for acute respiratory tract infections like sore throat, sinusitis, bronchitis and the common cold even though evidence of benefit is sorely lacking and risks of the drugs are widely known.

headline: Some of Jackie O.’s Favorite Fabrics are Back on the Market
abstract: In the late 1960s, Tillett Textiles teamed up with designers in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, for a historically significant collaboration. Now the prints are being reissued.
lead_paragraph: The party that introduced the Design Works of Bedford-Stuyvesant textile collection at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in the fall of 1971 drew quite a crowd.

headline: A Cheerleader’s Vulgar Message Prompts a First Amendment Showdown
abstract: A Pennsylvania school district has asked the Supreme Court to rule on whether students may be disciplined for what they say on social media.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was a Saturday in the spring of 2017, and a ninth-grade student in Pennsylvania was having a bad day. She had just learned that she had failed to make the varsity cheerleading squad and would remain on junior varsity.

headline: The 48 Mountains That Held My Grief
abstract: After my son Ben died by suicide, I turned to hiking. I found myself: broken, but braver.
lead_paragraph: On the first day of 2020, my anxiety roared as I approached the summit of Mount Pierce in northern New Hampshire. At about 4,300 feet elevation, the wind was picking up, the visibility dropping to near zero. I was about to turn around in defeat when I heard faint voices ahead of me: two women, zipping up their coats as I approached.

headline: Not Just Another Pipeline
abstract: The expansion of Enbridge’s Line 3 pipeline is a breathtaking betrayal of Minnesota’s Indigenous communities — and the environment.
lead_paragraph: PALISADE, Minn. — My daughter and I are walking along the fast-flowing stream of pure darkness that is the young Mississippi River. We are two hours north of Minneapolis, in Palisade, Minn., where people are gathering to oppose the Line 3 pipeline. Patches of snow crunch on pads of russet leaves as we near the zhaabondawaan, a sacred lodge along the river’s banks. It is here that Enbridge is due to horizontally drill a new pipeline crossing beneath the river. We enter the lodge. The peace, the sweetness, the clarity of the water is hard to bear. The brush and trees hardly muffle the roar of earth-moving and tree-felling equipment across the road. The pipeline is almost at the river.

headline: Shopping for Night Lights
abstract: Even if you’re not afraid of the dark, you may want one of these.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve ever stubbed your toe while stumbling to the bathroom in the middle of the night, the value of a good night light is obvious — even if you’re no longer a child.

headline: Soothing Anxiety and Stress: Advice From the Year in Well
abstract: Exercise, new news habits, even dipping your face into an icy plunge pool are among the steps you can take for a mellower new year.
lead_paragraph: For many of us, 2020 was an exceptionally stressful year, dominated by fears about the coronavirus pandemic. Even with the vaccine on the horizon, we’re likely to need some stress management strategies to carry us into 2021. There’s lots of advice in this guide by Tara Parker-Pope, How to Be Better at Stress. Stress doesn’t have to get you down, she writes: “Approach it the right way, and it won’t rule your life — it can even be good for you. Here are ways to deal with stress, reduce its harm and even use your daily stress to make you stronger.”

headline: Saying Goodbye to the Knuckleball, and Its Master
abstract: Phil Niekro is the seventh member of the Baseball Hall of Fame to die this year. The pitch he perfected also appears to be lost.
lead_paragraph: They gather every year, except for this cruel one, in the village where they are immortal. The men on the stage in Cooperstown, N.Y., at the annual Baseball Hall of Fame induction ceremonies, brought joy to millions. We look at them and see endless summer.

headline: What the Vaccine Side Effects Feel Like, According to Those Who’ve Gotten It
abstract: Here is what some of the first Americans to be vaccinated against Covid-19 are saying about how they felt afterward, with some side effects but no second thoughts.
lead_paragraph: Two and a half hours after being injected with a Covid-19 vaccine, Dr. Taneisha Wilson was hit with the worst headache of her life.

headline: Italy uses flowers to help spread a vaccine message.
abstract: This has been an ugly year for Italy.
lead_paragraph: This has been an ugly year for Italy.

headline: The Year Inequality Became Less Visible, and More Visible Than Ever
abstract: Even as shared public spaces emptied out, the gap between the economically privileged and the precarious became impossible to ignore.
lead_paragraph: This year, many Americans left the places where it was still possible to encounter one another. White-collar workers stopped going downtown, past homeless encampments and to lunch counters with minimum-wage staff. The well-off stopped riding public transit, where in some cities they once sat alongside commuting students and custodial workers. Diners stopped eating in restaurants, where their tips formed the wages of the people who served them.

headline: Watching Earth Burn
abstract: For 10 days in September, satellites in orbit sent tragic evidence of climate change’s destructive power.
lead_paragraph: I have a pastime, one that used to give me considerable pleasure, but lately it has morphed into a source of anxiety, even horror: earth-watching.

headline: The Lasting Lessons of John Conway’s Game of Life
abstract: Fifty years on, the mathematician’s best known (and, to him, least favorite) creation confirms that “uncertainty is the only certainty.”
lead_paragraph: In March of 1970, Martin Gardner opened a letter jammed with ideas for his Mathematical Games column in Scientific American. Sent by John Horton Conway, then a mathematician at the University of Cambridge, the letter ran 12 pages, typed hunt-and-peck style.

headline: The Gospel of Hydrogen Power
abstract: Mike Strizki powers his house and cars with hydrogen he home-brews. He is using his retirement to evangelize for the planet-saving advantages of hydrogen batteries.
lead_paragraph: In December, the California Fuel Cell Partnership tallied 8,890 electric cars and 48 electric buses running on hydrogen batteries, which are refillable in minutes at any of 42 stations there. On the East Coast, the number of people who own and drive a hydrogen electric car is somewhat lower. In fact, there’s just one. His name is Mike Strizki. He is so devoted to hydrogen fuel-cell energy that he drives a Toyota Mirai even though it requires him to refine hydrogen fuel in his yard himself.

headline: Revisiting the Unseen Corners of the World
abstract: During a year with limited travel possibilities, our World Through a Lens series offered Times readers a weekly escape. Here are some of the highlights.
lead_paragraph: At the onset of the coronavirus pandemic, with travel restrictions in place worldwide, we launched a new series to help transport you, virtually, to some of our planet’s most beautiful and intriguing places.

headline: The Girl Scouts Accuse the Boy Scouts of Unfair Competition in Trademark Dispute
abstract: The use of the terms “scouts” and “scouting” in the recruitment of girls is a focus of a legal and public relations feud between the organizations.
lead_paragraph: The recruiting pitches are strikingly familiar: Character-building and leadership opportunities for girls await in time-honored scouting programs.

headline: How a Small Bar Battled to Survive the Coronavirus: An Update
abstract: We chart the trials of a tavern in Oakland, Calif., that was thriving until the pandemic brought economic and emotional turmoil.
lead_paragraph: This week, The Daily is revisiting some of our favorite episodes of the year and checking in on what has happened in the time since they first ran.

headline: The Most-Read Stories of 2020
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: What were the most-read stories in The New York Times this year? You may not be surprised to learn that two topics — the election and the pandemic — dominate the list, accounting for 90 of the top 100 entries. Here’s a selection of those stories, plus some other subjects that drew big reader interest.

headline: A History of the Cheetah in ‘Wonder Woman’
abstract: This villain, played by Kristen Wiig in “Wonder Woman 1984,” has had a long, complicated relationship with her rival.
lead_paragraph: While the Cheetah may not be the most popular cat woman DC Comics has been responsible for, her high-profile appearance in the “Wonder Woman” sequel has a chance to earn her a whole new generation of fans.

headline: What You Get for $1.4 Million in California
abstract: A log-cabin-style house in Los Angeles, a two-bedroom condominium in San Francisco and a riverfront home in Guerneville.
lead_paragraph: A log-cabin-style house in Los Angeles, a two-bedroom condominium in San Francisco and a riverfront home in Guerneville.

headline: $1.4 Million Homes in California
abstract: A log-cabin-style house in Los Angeles, a two-bedroom condominium in San Francisco and a riverfront home in Guerneville.
lead_paragraph: This property, which has horse stables and a riding rink, is a few miles from Old Santa Susana Stage Road, used in the 19th century by travelers from Southern California to San Francisco. The road is now part of a state park in the foothills of the Santa Susana Mountains and is popular with hikers and horseback riders.

headline: Saudi Activist Who Fought for Women’s Right to Drive Is Sentenced to Prison
abstract: Loujain al-Hathloul, who was arrested just before the driving ban was lifted, was charged with undermining the kingdom in a case that supporters decried as a political persecution.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — One of Saudi Arabia’s best-known prisoners, the women’s rights activist Loujain al-Hathloul, was sentenced on Monday to five years and eight months in prison, capping a two-and-a-half-year legal ordeal that rights groups and her supporters called punishment for her political advocacy.

headline: The Year in Spaceflight
abstract: It started with a literal bang.
lead_paragraph: It started with a literal bang.

headline: With No Tickets to Sell, Arts Groups Appeal to Donors to Survive
abstract: Virtual cocktail parties have replaced black-tie galas as cultural institutions struggle to pay their operating costs.
lead_paragraph: One of the headliners of the New York Philharmonic’s fall gala last month was Leonard Bernstein, leading his old orchestra in the overture to “Candide.”

headline: Lori Loughlin Released From Federal Prison
abstract: The actress has completed a two-month sentence for conspiring to pass her daughters off as rowers so they would be admitted to the University of Southern California.
lead_paragraph: The actress Lori Loughlin was released from federal prison in Dublin, Calif., on Monday, having completed a two-month sentence for conspiring to pass her daughters off as rowers so they would be admitted to the University of Southern California.

headline: The Best Breakfast
abstract: Genevieve Ko has an ace recipe for sheet-pan bacon and eggs that’s sure to be a game-changer.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. We’re hurtling toward the end of the year now, a year that’s been like no other any of us has experienced, and I made a pizza and ate it with my daughter and walked the dog and got to thinking about how much better I hope 2021 will be for all of us and particularly for those who read this newsletter in search of a measure of hope and deliciousness against the torrent of dark news and difficult days.

headline: For Television and Romance Novels, Love at Last?
abstract: The new Netflix series “Bridgerton” joins a tiny but growing handful of prestige shows adapted from mass-market romance books. What took so long?
lead_paragraph: Chris Van Dusen doesn’t describe himself as an avid romance reader. “I’ve dabbled,” he said in a recent interview. “I wouldn’t say that I have romance books lining my bookshelf.”

headline: Jackie Saccoccio, Painter of Explosive Abstraction, Dies at 56
abstract: She specialized in large canvases on which splashes of luminous color swirled and clashed. Her goal was to make her paintings seem as if they were moving.
lead_paragraph: Jackie Saccoccio, a painter known for explosive yet delicately structured, almost atmospheric abstract paintings that exploited paint’s fluidity in the tradition of Jackson Pollock, Paul Jenkins and Helen Frankenthaler, died on Dec. 4 in Manhattan. She was 56.

headline: The House voted to advance $2,000 stimulus checks demanded by Trump.
abstract: The House voted on Monday evening to increase the size of individual stimulus checks to $2,000 from $600, endorsing a measure demanded by President Trump and daring Senate Republicans to either approve the heftier sum or defy the president, whose demands for bigger checks nearly scuttled the entire stimulus package.
lead_paragraph: The House voted on Monday evening to increase the size of individual stimulus checks to $2,000 from $600, endorsing a measure demanded by President Trump and daring Senate Republicans to either approve the heftier sum or defy the president, whose demands for bigger checks nearly scuttled the entire stimulus package.

headline: For His Second Act, Nnamdi Asomugha Made Preparation His Byword
abstract: The former pro football player has pushed himself in acting classes, onstage and in films. His latest drama, “Sylvie’s Love,” also meant returning to an early passion: music.
lead_paragraph: The lead in a romance may seem like a prize for most actors, but the star of the new drama “Sylvie’s Love” had reservations.

headline: New York Bans Most Evictions as Tenants Struggle to Pay Rent
abstract: The Legislature, addressing hardship caused by the pandemic, convened an unusual special session between Christmas and New Year’s to pass the measure.
lead_paragraph: The New York Legislature on Monday overwhelmingly passed one of the most comprehensive anti-eviction laws in the nation, as the state contends with high levels of unemployment caused by a pandemic that has taken more than 330,000 lives nationwide.

headline: Reviewing a Wild Year in Art With the ‘Culture Gabfest’
abstract: The co-hosts of Slate’s long-running and influential podcast discuss the “urgency” of art in a crisis and whether Meryl Streep should play Anthony Fauci.
lead_paragraph: This year was bittersweet for the culture consumer under lockdown. Some ways of experiencing art (reading, watching television, listening to podcasts) felt more necessary than ever, while the absence or degradation of others (going to the movies, or to the theater, or to a live music performance) left an agonizing void. The pandemic and subsequent crises of racial justice and democracy bled into all of it, posing new questions about meaning and merit that will linger long after the virus fades.

headline: A Look at What’s in the Stimulus Package Trump Signed
abstract: The $900 billion package provides more relief beyond the $600 checks that have become the focus in Washington.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The $900 billion stimulus bill that President Trump finally signed into law on Sunday evening goes well beyond providing the $600 checks that became a huge sticking point in getting the legislation across the finish line.

headline: Small Number of Covid Patients Develop Severe Psychotic Symptoms
abstract: Most had no history of mental illness and became psychotic weeks after contracting the virus. Cases are expected to remain rare but are being reported worldwide.
lead_paragraph: Almost immediately, Dr. Hisam Goueli could tell that the patient who came to his psychiatric hospital on Long Island this summer was unusual.

headline: Don’t Let the Pandemic Stop Your Shots
abstract: Even as older adults await the coronavirus vaccine, many are skipping the standard ones. That’s not wise, health experts say.
lead_paragraph: Peggy Stein, 68, a retired teacher in Berkeley, Calif., skipped a flu shot this year. Her reasoning: “How could I get the flu if I’m being so incredibly careful because of Covid?”

headline: Murdoch’s New York Post Blasts President’s Fraud Claims
abstract: With a scathing front-page editorial, the Trump-friendly tabloid joined another of Rupert Murdoch’s papers, The Wall Street Journal, in attacking the president’s attempts to undo the election result.
lead_paragraph: “Give it up, Mr. President — for your sake and the nation’s.”

headline: Karl Ove Knausgaard’s Essays Struggle With Big Ideas
abstract: “In the Land of the Cyclops” collects earnest essays about artists and photographers, “Madame Bovary,” Ingmar Bergman, Michel Houellebecq and more.
lead_paragraph: Randy Newman’s catalog includes a remarkable song, heard to best effect on his 2011 album “Live in London,” called “I’m Dead (But I Don’t Know It).” It’s about being an artist whose best work is thought to be in the rearview mirror.

headline: New York to Investigate Rise in Virus Positivity Rate
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York announced on Monday that the state’s coronavirus positive test rate had surpassed 8 percent, the highest daily figure in months, but said there were anomalies in testing and reporting around the holidays.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York announced on Monday that the state’s coronavirus positive test rate had surpassed 8 percent, the highest daily figure in months, but said there were anomalies in testing and reporting around the holidays.

headline: All Alone With a Microphone
abstract: In 2020, pop learned how much simple physical proximity affects music, and how to cope with isolation.
lead_paragraph: The last time I applauded live music with a roomful of strangers was sometime back in February.
