lead_paragraph: This year was a soul-crushing hellscape of a dumpster fire. For sanity’s sake, large chunks of it should be repressed as soon as possible.

headline: 2 Cleveland Police Officers Avoid Federal Charges in Killing of Tamir Rice
abstract: Finding a lack of evidence to prosecute, the Justice Department ended a five-year inquiry into the death of the 12-year-old Black boy, who had been carrying a pellet gun when an officer shot him.
lead_paragraph: Two Cleveland police officers will avoid federal criminal charges for their role in the killing of Tamir Rice, a 12-year-old Black boy who had been carrying a pellet gun when he was shot in 2014, the Justice Department announced on Tuesday, citing a lack of evidence in the high-profile case.

headline: New Year’s Resolutions for the Planet
abstract: Here are some ideas you wonderful readers sent to us.
lead_paragraph: Here are some ideas you wonderful readers sent to us.

headline: Chicago Blackhawks’ Jonathan Toews Is Out Indefinitely Because of Illness
abstract: Toews, 32, the team captain, did not say what his condition was but said that it had left him “drained and lethargic.”
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Toews, the Chicago Blackhawks’ center and team captain, announced on Tuesday that he would not join the team when it begins training camp on Sunday and that he would be out indefinitely because of a medical condition. He did not say what the condition was, but he described its effects.

headline: Contract Killers
abstract: Kate Hawkins creates a virtual community of sorts.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Among the rising stars in the New York Times crossworld, Kate Hawkins is a veritable constellation. Her Times debut was in August, and this puzzle is already her third to appear here. Like a cut-glass candy dish this time of year, it’s piled high with colorful treats — trivia from pop culture, botany, the Olympics, animated rodents. You know the drill.

headline: Erasmus, Covid-19, Croatia: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Hong Kong Protesters Who Fled by Boat Are Sentenced to Prison in China
abstract: The pro-democracy activists, who hoped to reach Taiwan, were caught by the Chinese Coast Guard and tried in the mainland’s opaque criminal justice system.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A group of Hong Kong protesters who were arrested by the Chinese authorities while fleeing the city by speedboat were sentenced by a mainland court to between seven months and three years in prison on Wednesday, in the Chinese Communist Party’s latest offensive against pro-democracy activists.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Pandemic Worsens Poverty’s Ills for Families
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, December 30, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “For African-Americans in this country, it’s almost a birthright to be resilient. We’ve learned those skills, sometimes at 4 years old. Now it’s about surviving.”

headline: Corrections: Dec. 30, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Dec. 30, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about challenges faced by Nashville in 2020 misidentified one of the Nashville restaurants run by Trey Cioccia. It is the Farm House, not the Treehouse.

headline: Nashville Suspect’s Girlfriend Told Police Last Year That He Was Making Bombs
abstract: Officers visited the home of Anthony Warner after his girlfriend said he was producing explosives in his R.V., according to a police report. They said then that there was no evidence of a crime.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — A girlfriend of the man who the authorities say set off a bomb in downtown Nashville on Christmas had called police officers to his home last year, claiming that he had been making bombs in the R.V. parked there, according to a police incident report.

headline: China Approves Covid-19 Vaccine as It Moves to Inoculate Millions
abstract: Sinopharm, a state-controlled company, said its candidate had a 79 percent efficacy rate in interim late-stage trials. But crucial questions remained unanswered.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese government said on Thursday that it had approved a homegrown coronavirus vaccine after an early analysis of clinical trial results showed that it was effective. The announcements sent a positive signal for the global rollout of Chinese vaccines but lacked crucial details.

headline: A Chinese coronavirus vaccine has proved effective, its maker said.
abstract: A Chinese pharmaceutical company on Wednesday said late-stage drug trials showed that one of its coronavirus vaccines was effective, delivering positive results that could pave the way for the global rollout of hundreds of millions of Chinese vaccine doses in the coming months.
lead_paragraph: A Chinese pharmaceutical company on Wednesday said late-stage drug trials showed that one of its coronavirus vaccines was effective, delivering positive results that could pave the way for the global rollout of hundreds of millions of Chinese vaccine doses in the coming months.

headline: Numbers, Knowledge and Better Set Pieces: a View Into Soccer’s Future
abstract: F.C. Midtjylland’s search for competitive advantage has made it a place where ideas emerge. The problem is pretty soon everyone else has them, too.
lead_paragraph: Everything that happens at F.C. Midtjylland is quantified. Well, almost everything. Every game played by every one of the Danish soccer club’s teams produces data points in the thousands. Each training session, from the first team to the preteens in the academy, is recorded and codified and analyzed.

headline: U.K. Authorizes Covid-19 Vaccine From Oxford and AstraZeneca
abstract: Health officials hope to soon vaccinate up to two million people per week as the country’s hospitals are overwhelmed by cases of a new, more contagious coronavirus variant.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain on Wednesday became the first country to give emergency authorization to the coronavirus vaccine developed by AstraZeneca and the University of Oxford, clearing the path for a cheap and easy-to-store shot that much of the world will rely on to help end the pandemic.

headline: Argentina Legalizes Abortion, a Milestone in a Conservative Region
abstract: The Senate vote on Wednesday was a major victory for Latin America’s growing feminist movement, and its ripple effects are likely to be widespread.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Argentina on Wednesday became the largest nation in Latin America to legalize abortion, a landmark vote in a conservative region and a victory for a grass-roots movement that turned years of rallies into political power.

headline: Quarterback Keeper? Jets, Browns and Bears Face Contract Decisions
abstract: Sam Darnold, Baker Mayfield and Mitchell Trubisky have all been marginally impressive at times. But is that enough for their teams to sign them to salary-cap-straining contracts?
lead_paragraph: [Read our NFL Playoff Picture Forecast, Odds and Scenarios for Week 17]

headline: He Was Hospitalized for Covid-19. Then Hospitalized Again. And Again.
abstract: Significant numbers of coronavirus patients experience long-term symptoms that send them back to the hospital, taxing an already overburdened health system.
lead_paragraph: The routine things in Chris Long’s life used to include biking 30 miles three times a week and taking courses toward a Ph.D. in eight-week sessions.

headline: Jonathan Pollard, Spy for Israel, Gets Hero’s Welcome From Netanyahu: ‘You’re Home’
abstract: Mr. Pollard, who gave a range of classified documents to Israel starting in 1984, recently completed his parole. His case was a longstanding irritant to American-Israeli ties.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Jonathan J. Pollard, the American who served 30 years in prison for spying for Israel in a Cold War-era espionage case that had been a thorn in relations between the two allies, arrived in Israel early Wednesday to a carefully staged, if relatively subdued, hero’s welcome from Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Calling Yourself Middle-Aged
abstract: Is 32 the new 45?
lead_paragraph: Blake writes: My mother thinks I’m too young to call myself middle-aged. I’m 32, well into the middle range of the average American male life span. My wife and I are expecting our second child. May I say I’m middle-aged?

headline: The Great News Quiz of 2020
abstract: It’s been a newsy year. As 2020 comes to a close, how well do you remember it all?
lead_paragraph: It’s been a newsy year. As 2020 comes to a close, how well do you remember it all?

headline: Vaccines Are Safe, No Matter What Bobby Kennedy Says
abstract: I love my uncle. But when it comes to vaccines, he is wrong.
lead_paragraph: My hospital, along with hundreds of others across the country, recently began to administer the first Covid-19 vaccines. My social media feed is filled with pictures of friends and colleagues, sleeves rolled up, writing about how much this vaccination means to them. In an otherwise dark year, it’s a moment of hope.

headline: What Can Be Learned From Differing Rates of Suicide Among Groups
abstract: White Americans have higher rates than most other racial and ethnic groups.
lead_paragraph: U.S. suicide rates vary widely across racial and ethnic groups in ways that can upend expectations. The explanations may suggest avenues for prevention.

headline: How to Stay Connected and Fend Off Loneliness in the New Year
abstract: As we head into 2021, here is some advice from Well on how to replace loneliness with opportunities for connection.
lead_paragraph: This pandemic year has left too many of us feeling isolated and lonely. As we head into 2021, here is some advice from Well on how to replace loneliness with opportunities for connection.

headline: Can 4 Seconds of Exercise Make a Difference?
abstract: Four seconds of intense intervals, repeated until they amount to a minute of total exertion, led to rapid improvements in strength and fitness in middle-aged and older adults.
lead_paragraph: In what is probably the definitive word on how little exercise we can get away with, a new study finds that a mere four seconds of intense intervals, repeated until they amount to about a minute of total exertion, lead to rapid and meaningful improvements in strength, fitness and general physical performance among middle-aged and older adults.

headline: A 12-Year-Old’s Letter to Her Post-Pandemic Self
abstract: How will you retain gratitude for the return to normal life? “I’ve come from 2020 to remind you not to forget,” my daughter wrote to her future self.
lead_paragraph: My 12-year-old daughter, Audrey, told me recently on one of our many walks around the neighborhood that she would never forget this pandemic, and that she never wanted to take for granted having friends over, visiting extended family or hugging her grandparents again. She wondered, though, whether people would really live with new appreciation. Over time, would we all forget? Would a hug or a handshake become commonplace again?

headline: Sleep Better in the New Year
abstract: Advice from Well on how to get more and sounder sleep in 2021.
lead_paragraph: For many, 2020 was a year that provided lots of worries that kept us tossing and turning at night. Tara Parker-Pope’s guide, How to Get a Better Night’s Sleep, is packed with advice:

headline: The Risks of the Covid Vaccine, in Context
abstract: We should expect some people to experience side effects. The shot is still safer than the disease.
lead_paragraph: At this point, most of us have heard about allergic reactions to Covid-19 vaccines: the doctor in Boston who had to administer his EpiPen, the hospital worker in Alaska who had trouble breathing. But it’s not at all surprising that allergic reactions happen. What matters most is the severity and the rate at which they occur. And for the Covid vaccines, there’s no doubt that the value of vaccination outweighs the risk.

headline: New Train Hall Opens at Penn Station, Echoing Building’s Former Glory
abstract: The Moynihan Train Hall, with glass skylights and 92-foot-high ceilings, will open Jan. 1 as an area for Amtrak and Long Island Rail Road riders.
lead_paragraph: For more than half a century, New Yorkers have trudged through the crammed platforms, dark hallways and oppressively low ceilings of Pennsylvania Station, the busiest and perhaps most miserable train hub in North America.

headline: Andy Cohen Had a Year
abstract: Bravo’s main man bids adieu to what may have been the twenty-twentiest 2020 ever.
lead_paragraph: In February, the Bravo host and executive producer Andy Cohen sent his beagle, Wacha, to live with his animal trainer in Connecticut. Experts said Wacha needed to be rehomed for his safety and that of Mr. Cohen’s one-year-old son, Benjamin. “It truly was so traumatic, and so upsetting.” Mr. Cohen said recently. “I thought, ‘Wow, 2020 really stinks. Like, it could never, ever get worse than this.’”

headline: How to Reassure Black Americans That the Vaccine Is Safe
abstract: After centuries of mistreatment, many African-Americans are wary of the Covid-19 shot. A public health campaign could help rebuild trust.
lead_paragraph: Many Black Americans say they are wary of taking the coronavirus vaccine, the logical result of centuries of abuse and exploitation by the United States health care system. We empathize with the patient who told one of us, “Baby, I just don’t trust vaccines,” and with our friends and family who say they are “just going to wait.”

headline: Cuttlefish Took Something Like a Marshmallow Test. Many Passed.
abstract: It turns out that camouflage isn’t the only talent these cephalopods have.
lead_paragraph: Zipping through water like shimmering arrowheads, cuttlefish are swift, sure hunters — death on eight limbs and two waving tentacles for small creatures in their vicinity. They morph to match the landscape, shifting between a variety of hues and even textures, using tiny structures that expand and contract beneath their skin. They even seem to have depth perception, researchers using tiny 3-D vision glasses found, placing them apart from octopuses and squids. And their accuracy at striking prey is remarkable.

headline: Saudi Arabia Is Slowly Killing My Father
abstract: President-elect Joe Biden must push the country to release its political prisoners.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, a court in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, sentenced Loujain al-Hathloul, the Saudi activist, to five years and eight months in prison. Ms. al-Hathloul, who campaigned for the right of women to drive, was convicted of “trying to harm national security” and advancing “a foreign agenda.” She has already been in prison for two and a half years. A combination of time served and partial sentence suspension could lead to her release in a month or so.

headline: The 2020 Good Tech Awards
abstract: This year, technology firms big and small stepped up to help with the Covid-19 pandemic and other thorny challenges.
lead_paragraph: Some years, I have to dig deep to come up with worthy honorees for the Good Tech Awards, my annual column that honors what I consider the most humane and altruistic tech projects of the year.

headline: Was the College Football Season Worth It?
abstract: It brought joy — and revenue. But the full cost will never be tallied.
lead_paragraph: On a Friday evening in early August, Kevin Warren logged in to a video call with medical officials from athletic departments around the Big Ten. By then, Warren had been the commissioner of the conference for eight months. Those months had not gone according to plan. He had come from the N.F.L., where his most recent job was chief operating officer for the Minnesota Vikings. The first African-American commissioner of a major college conference, he had almost no experience in college sports. He was regarded as an outsider, a perception he shared. To help overcome that, Warren had intended to hold a town-hall meeting on each of the 14 Big Ten campuses during his first year as commissioner. The conference fielded 350 teams across 28 sports, and Warren planned to see every one of them in action. When the pandemic hit in early March, he had seen 105 teams play and hosted three town halls. He still barely knew the university presidents and chancellors, who hired him, or the athletic directors. Unlike his predecessor, Jim Delany, whose tenure as commissioner lasted three decades, Warren had no particular friends or allies among either group. And now he faced one of the most consequential decisions in conference history: Should the Big Ten play football in 2020?

headline: Robert Jones Jr. Is Son of Baldwin, and More
abstract: The writer’s debut novel, “The Prophets,” is the Black queer love story he longed to read.
lead_paragraph: In his 1985 essay “Here Be Dragons,” James Baldwin wrote: “At bottom, what I had learned was that the male desire for a male roams everywhere, avid, desperate, unimaginably lonely.” America’s attitudes toward sexuality, he added, are tragically, inextricably linked with its “ideals” of hyper-masculinity and racialized violence.

headline: The ‘Resistance’ Formed Because of Trump, With an Assist From Jon Ossoff
abstract: Mr. Ossoff’s 2017 special election was the first campaign Democrats had to focus on, after the shock of President Trump’s win. He lost, but the organizations formed around that race kept growing.
lead_paragraph: In early 2017, Angelika Kausche was frustrated, demoralized and looking for somewhere — or someone — to help her channel the rage she had recently expressed at the Women’s March.

headline: What’s on the Horizon for the Climate Desk
abstract: After a year when climate-related disasters seemed to become the norm, the team will be monitoring a 2021 that is pivotal for the world.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: One Way to Avoid Other Guests? Book the Entire Hotel
abstract: For those who aren’t deterred by a bill in the thousands, if not tens of thousands, buyouts of entire hotels or resorts offer the amenities and services of a hotel and the privacy and control of a vacation rental.
lead_paragraph: When Jack Samenuk checked into Zabriskie House this week, there was no mystery about who he would encounter in the inn’s double parlor or wood-paneled dining room.

headline: When Sports Made Us Happy in 2020
abstract: Sports were not a simple salve for the events of 2020, but they still provided some moments of joy, levity and shared humanity.
lead_paragraph: In a year in which Covid-19 caused more than 1.7 million deaths worldwide, sports competitions took place amid much debate over their necessity and the wisdom of their proceeding during a global health crisis. Did any good come from them?

headline: Living In ... Wood-Ridge, N.J.
abstract: This unpretentious suburb in Bergen County offers residents comfortable proximity to Manhattan and reasonably priced homes (some with skyline views).
lead_paragraph: This unpretentious suburb in Bergen County offers residents comfortable proximity to Manhattan and reasonably priced homes (some with skyline views).

headline: Wood-Ridge, N.J.: Not Too Close to the City, or Too Far Away
abstract: This unpretentious suburb in Bergen County offers residents comfortable proximity to Manhattan and reasonably priced homes (some with skyline views).
lead_paragraph: In Wood-Ridge, N.J., residents are accustomed to clarifying where they live. “People don’t always get what you mean when you say ‘Wood-Ridge,’” said Melanie Nicoletti, a former Brooklynite. “Ridgewood and Woodbridge” — higher profile addresses in the Garden State — “they get.”

headline: The Hilaria Baldwin Story: ‘I’m Living My Life’
abstract: Accused of a “decade long grift where she impersonates a Spanish person,” the entrepreneur and spouse of Alec Baldwin talks about Spain, Boston, her children, Instagram and more.
lead_paragraph: The first signs that Hilaria Baldwin’s life was going seriously off the rails came from the same place where she usually derives her sense of control. “I started seeing comments on my Instagram,” she said in an interview Tuesday.

headline: No Crowds, but Times Square Ball Drop Is Still Happening. Here’s How.
abstract: For the first time in decades, Times Square will be closed to the public on New Year’s Eve. Instead, dozens of frontline workers and their families will be honored with spots near the stage.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our New Year’s Eve live coverage

headline: A ‘Frankenstein’ That Never Lived
abstract: On Jan. 4, 1981, the effects-heavy production opened and closed on the same night. Forty years later, the creators revisit a very expensive Broadway flop.
lead_paragraph: When the curtain went up at the Palace Theater on Jan. 4, 1981, the expectations — and the stakes — were high.

headline: 25 Days That Changed the World: How Covid-19 Slipped China’s Grasp
abstract: Beijing acted against the coronavirus with stunning force, as its official narratives recount. But not before a political logjam had allowed a local outbreak to kindle a global pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The most famous doctor in China was on an urgent mission.

headline: ‘Let’s Talk About “Personal Responsibility”’: A Year of Tough Conversations in the Comments
abstract: Opinion writers reflect on what readers had to say in 2020.
lead_paragraph: This has been a tumultuous 12 months, a harrowing ride through the pandemic and elections, racial injustices and civic turmoil. Through it all, in your comments, you’ve shared your fears, frustrations and anger, but also hope, humor and much wisdom. In the process, you helped document this extraordinary year.

headline: Indonesia Disbands Radical Islamic Group Over Charges of Violence
abstract: The government dissolved the Islamic Defenders Front over charges that its members committed terrorism. Its leader is already under arrest.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — The hard-line Islamic Defenders Front was outlawed by the Indonesian government on Wednesday and ordered to cease all activities less than two months after its fiery leader, Rizieq Shihab, returned from self-imposed exile and pledged to lead a “moral revolution.”

headline: Alone in a Fancy Hotel Bathroom
abstract: Parents’ solo-vacation fantasies, hopefully realized in 2021.
lead_paragraph: When I’m having trouble falling asleep, I think about a paddle boat ride I took in 2010. My husband and I were on our honeymoon, staying at a hotel in Portugal that was right on the bay. I have a visceral memory of raising my face to the sun, lazily paddling around while the sea breeze gently flowed around me. I recall that moment when I’m tossing and turning in these pandemic times; I felt so relaxed and free then … because I didn’t have kids.

headline: Wounds on Brown Pelicans in California Raise Fears of Animal Cruelty
abstract: In a little over a year, five birds have been treated by International Bird Rescue with severe slashes on their pouches that the organization believes were intentionally inflicted.
lead_paragraph: The first bird appeared in September 2019.

headline: ‘Who Replaces Me?’: An Update
abstract: A Black police officer in Flint, Mich., reflects on what it now means to be part of the force in his hometown.
lead_paragraph: This week, The Daily is revisiting some of our favorite episodes of the year and checking in on what has happened in the time since they first ran.

headline: 5 Dance Picture Books
abstract: Children of all abilities glide from page to stage with the likes of American Ballet Theater and New York City Ballet pros.
lead_paragraph: I WILL DANCEWritten by Nancy Bo FloodIllustrated by Julianna Swaney

headline: Test Your 2020 Knowledge
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: It’s been an eventful year, to say the least. David Leonhardt, who usually writes this newsletter, has created a quiz that tests your knowledge of the year’s biggest stories.

headline: She’s Starring Opposite Tom Hanks. She’d Never Heard of Him.
abstract: Helena Zengel is a giggly, chatty 12-year-old, whose movie roles take her into psychological territory that even adults would find tough.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — When the director Paul Greengrass was gearing up to make his new film, “News of the World,” about a Civil War veteran in 1870s Texas who escorts an orphaned girl to her relatives across the state, he was anticipating one major challenge. “This is the first film I made with a child actor at the heart of it,” he said recently by phone.

headline: She Mocked Men’s Bluster. Then Came the Complaints.
abstract: A stand-up comedian in China suggested that some men had an unwarranted confidence. An attempt to censor her followed.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Yang Li, a comedian, tells jokes about men and their egos.

headline: Watch 8 Classic TV Episodes About New Year’s Eves Gone Awry
abstract: Are your plans feeling particularly lackluster this year? Take heart: These are a reminder that Dec. 31 isn’t always what it’s cracked up to be.
lead_paragraph: At long last, we’ve arrived to the sole silver lining of the 2020 holiday season: a built-in excuse to stay home on Dec. 31 and feel good about it.

headline: What You Get for $3 Million
abstract: A three-bedroom home with a guest cottage in Key West, an 18th-century Dutch Colonial in Brooklyn and a Federal-style townhouse in Alexandria.
lead_paragraph: A three-bedroom home with a guest cottage in Key West, an 18th-century Dutch Colonial in Brooklyn and a Federal-style townhouse in Alexandria.

headline: U.K. Parliament Approves Post-Brexit Trade Deal
abstract: After the House of Commons overwhelmingly endorsed the 1,200-page agreement, the House of Lords also voted in favor of British ratification.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Approval of a trade deal between Britain and the European Union was hurried through the British Parliament in just a day on Wednesday, a decisive but rushed conclusion to a long Brexit story that has divided Britons and convulsed their politics for more than four years.

headline: Yemen Airport Is Attacked as New Government Arrives
abstract: The attack occurred just as a plane carrying several cabinet officials landed. The cabinet’s formation was supposed to be a step toward resolving Yemen’s civil war.
lead_paragraph: AL MUKALLA, Yemen — An attack on an airport in Aden, Yemen, killed at least 20 civilians and wounded dozens more on Wednesday just as a plane carrying members of the country’s newly formed government cabinet was arriving, the Yemeni health minister’s office said.

headline: China and E.U. Leaders Strike Investment Deal, but Political Hurdles Await
abstract: The agreement, which would roll back restrictions on investment, faces some opposition in Europe and objections from the Biden camp.
lead_paragraph: Chinese and European Union leaders agreed on Wednesday to make it easier for companies to operate on each other’s territory, a significant geopolitical victory for China when criticism of its human rights record and handling of the pandemic have left it increasingly isolated.

headline: What We Learned About California in 2020
abstract: Wednesday: The year’s almost over. It’s been illuminating.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: $3 Million Homes in Florida, New York and Virginia
abstract: A three-bedroom home with a guest cottage in Key West, an 18th-century Dutch Colonial in Brooklyn and a Federal-style townhouse in Alexandria.
lead_paragraph: This white clapboard house, at the corner of Southard and William Streets in the heart of Old Town, is being sold with all of its furnishings, down to the pots and pans. It is on Solares Hill, the highest point on Key West, and the structure itself is elevated, reducing the cost of flood insurance. City records date the main building to 1928 and the cottage to 1933, but they could well be older.

headline: From Kobe to LeBron: Tragedy and Triumph in the N.B.A.
abstract: A year that began with the deaths of two N.B.A. icons could not end soon enough, marked by heartache along the way but also small moments worth celebrating now.
lead_paragraph: The longest and possibly saddest year in pro basketball history is almost over. From this world that plays out on hardwood, as with so many other wings of society, there will be few fond farewells to 2020.

headline: Sale of Arctic Drilling Leases Draws an Unusual Taker. It May Be the Only One.
abstract: With a deadline looming and weak interest from oil companies, the state of Alaska may step in and buy leases in the hope of reassigning them later. Some analysts saw that as a long shot.
lead_paragraph: After a three-year push by the Trump administration to open the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska to oil drilling — an effort that culminated in a rush to sell leases before the White House changes hands — in the end the only taker may be the state of Alaska itself.

headline: Views for Miles in Costa Rica
abstract: This mountainside home in Costa Rica, built to maximize views of the Pacific Ocean, is on the market for $1.15 million.
lead_paragraph: This mountainside home in Costa Rica, built to maximize views of the Pacific Ocean, is on the market for $1.15 million.

headline: House Hunting in Costa Rica: A Slice of Oceanside Paradise for $1.1 Million
abstract: Beloved as a haven for tourists, Costa Rica’s housing market has been hit hard in this year of limited travel, with damaging effects rippling out to some, but not all, of its provinces.
lead_paragraph: This modern three-bedroom home sits on a hillside in Dominical, a beach town in Puntarenas province, on the southern Pacific coast of Costa Rica. Built in 2016, the 3,500-square-foot house is oriented to maximize ocean views, with sliding glass walls in every room.

headline: The Bruce Willis Journey From In Demand to On Demand
abstract: An assessment of the actor’s late-career B-movie filmography, including his most recent entry, “Breach.”
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to keep track of Bruce Willis’s filmography, especially since 2015. In recent years, the star’s IMDb page has swollen with a torrent of action productions that drown out the occasional ambitious work like “Motherless Brooklyn” or “Glass.” Mnemonics are useful to keep track of the banal titles: “Hard Kill” followed “First Kill”; “Trauma Center” takes place in … a trauma center. But really, anybody would be forgiven for mixing up “Reprisal” with “Marauders,” or “Acts of Violence” with Willis’s most recent paycheck, “Breach” (available in select theaters and on-demand, which is where most of these movies begin their careers).

headline: From a 1550s Pandemic, a Choral Work Still Casts Its Spell
abstract: We know remarkably little about John Sheppard and his “Media vita.” But it has become a cult favorite of early music.
lead_paragraph: “Media vita” starts low, rising as if from catacombs. The tenors begin, sounding the slow, steady chant that will occupy them for more than 20 minutes. Countertenors come in above them, also rising step by step. Then the highest line enters, then another, another, still another, until all six parts take flight — rich yet somehow fragile, even lonely, and full of fear.

headline: As Aftershocks Rattle Croatia, Quake Recovery Is Slow and Perilous
abstract: Tens of thousands of people have been left homeless after the powerful 6.4 magnitude earthquake that rocked central Croatia, killing seven and injuring dozens.
lead_paragraph: ZADAR, Croatia — After working through the night combing through the ruins of fallen buildings for survivors of a powerful 6.4 magnitude earthquake that rocked central Croatia, the search and rescue operation shifted gears on Wednesday to focus on helping tens of thousands of people left homeless.

headline: Which Digital Thermometer Is Best?
abstract: You asked, and Wirecutter has suggestions.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I was pretty fierce in this space a few days ago, arguing that you need to use a digital thermometer if you want to cook a roast to the state you desire. The internal temperature of your particular cut of meat is the only reliable indicator of its “doneness.” Reliance on the minutes-per-pound at a particular oven temperature is a fool’s errand, dooming cooks either to undercook or overcook their meals.

headline: Looking ahead to 2021
abstract: Also this week: Your New Year’s climate resolutions
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Climate Fwd: newsletter. The New York Times climate team emails readers once a week with stories and insights about climate change. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

headline: Julius Randle Is Causing Something Rare: Excitement for the Knicks
abstract: After the Knicks’ seven consecutive losing seasons, Randle’s strong play is fueling a good start — and hope among fans.
lead_paragraph: You can count the games each N.B.A. team has played so far on a single hand. But since when has a small sample size ever stopped fans, especially Knicks fans, from being excited?

headline: When Is a Comedy Special Also a Corporate Synergy Message?
abstract: Two year-end shows from Amazon and Netflix deliver some laughs, yes, but also serve as veiled ads for the streaming services themselves.
lead_paragraph: At the start of “Death to 2020,” a reporter played by Samuel L. Jackson sits alone in an abandoned office listening to a disembodied voice explain he’s looking back at the past year. “Why would you want to do that?” Jackson responds, with an additional curse for emphasis.

headline: How to Stream New Year’s Eve: 25 Shows From Pop, Jazz and Beyond
abstract: It isn’t too late to make (cheap!) plans to welcome 2021 with music. A host of concerts will be streaming around the globe and major stars will take the stage on TV.
lead_paragraph: THE AVETT BROTHERS If your appetite for sentimentality hasn’t been sated by holiday films, this may be the livestream for you. In their strummy folk-rock vernacular and tidy close harmonies, the brothers Scott and Seth Avett sing earnest songs about love and family. A slew of special guests — including Willie Nelson, Brandi Carlile, Norah Jones and Loudon Wainwright III — will bolster the star power of this New Year’s Eve performance (the 17th edition of an annual Avett tradition). At 8 p.m. Eastern, nugs.tv. Tickets start at $40. (Olivia Horn)

headline: The State of the Virus: 2020 in Review
abstract: How the coronavirus spread across the United States.
lead_paragraph: How the coronavirus spread across the United States.

headline: How Argentina Bucked Tradition in Latin America and Legalized Abortion
abstract: The region, where Roman Catholic and evangelical churches hold sway, has long been unfriendly territory for abortion rights advocates. Argentina in 2020, though, offered a different landscape.
lead_paragraph: Latin America has long been hostile terrain for abortion rights advocates, even in recent decades as legal abortion became accessible in most of Europe, North America and other parts of the world.

headline: 4 Young Adult Crossover Novels
abstract: The latest fiction from Nic Stone, Elizabeth Wein, David Yoon and Arvin Ahmadi.
lead_paragraph: DEAR JUSTYCEBy Nic Stone288 pp. Crown. $18.99.

headline: Let There Be Light, and Art, in the Moynihan Train Hall
abstract: The expansion of Penn Station’s concourse has an acre of glass that lets the sun pour down, and installations by Kehinde Wiley, Stan Douglas and Elmgreen & Dragset. Here’s a first look.
lead_paragraph: Sunlight is not typically associated with the dingy basement vibe that envelops commuters passing through Penn Station.

headline: Norway Landslide Injures 10 and Leaves 10 Missing
abstract: Several homes were destroyed in the landslide about 30 miles northeast of Oslo, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: At least 10 people were injured and 10 people were missing on Wednesday after a landslide in a village about 30 miles northeast of Oslo that Prime Minister Erna Solberg of Norway said was one of the worst in the country’s history.

headline: When Business as Usual Was Turned Upside Down
abstract: A photo retrospective of how the pandemic changed the business world and ruptured the economy in 2020 — creating some winners and, tragically, too many losers.
lead_paragraph: The condition of the global economy and work force is easily measured in data: 82 million people around the world caught the coronavirus; 20 million in the United States were receiving unemployment benefits as of the end of November. But business is about more than data and the movement of capital and the pursuit of profit. This year, as the pandemic crippled the economy, photographers fanned out to document the virus’s toll on stores, restaurants and factories, and the workers they depend on.

headline: Pierre Cardin: He Dressed Jane Jetson and Lady Gaga
abstract: Some observations on the influential designer who made futurism his watchword.
lead_paragraph: The Italian-born Frenchman Pierre Cardin’s surname was perhaps the first French word that many Americans could easily pronounce. People with no inkling of how to utter designer names like Givenchy, with its suppressed “g,” and the sibilant Gallic uptick at the end of Saint Laurent (let alone the impossible Yves) had little difficulty speaking the two syllables and hard consonants of Caar-dan. Lesson: If you plan to become a household name, pick one anybody can say.

headline: Meet Bill Butler, the Godfather of Roller Disco
abstract: He brought dance music to the Empire Rollerdrome in Brooklyn, and taught generations of skaters how to roll, bounce and be jammas.
lead_paragraph: When Grace Jones was strutting around Studio 54 and Donna Summer records were playing at New York clubs, Empire Rollerdrome was hitting its stride in Brooklyn.

headline: Joe Clark, Tough Principal at New Jersey High School, Dies at 82
abstract: Bullhorn in hand, he roamed the hallways as he imposed discipline, expelling “miscreants” and restoring order. Morgan Freeman portrayed him in the film “Lean on Me.”
lead_paragraph: Joe Clark, the imperious disciplinarian principal of a troubled New Jersey high school in the 1980s who gained fame for restoring order as he roamed its hallways with a bullhorn and sometimes a baseball bat, died on Tuesday at his home in Gainesville, Fla. He was 82.

headline: Colorado may have a second case of the more contagious virus variant.
abstract: The newly discovered, more contagious variant of the coronavirus — first seen in Britain — may have been found in a second person in Colorado, state officials said on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The newly discovered, more contagious variant of the coronavirus — first seen in Britain — may have been found in a second person in Colorado, state officials said on Wednesday.

headline: ‘Pieces of a Woman’ Review: A Raw, Ragged Study of a Loss
abstract: Vanessa Kirby gives an intensely physical performance as a woman whose life and marriage are upended by the death of a child.
lead_paragraph: There are two remarkable scenes in “Pieces of a Woman,” though the first — an almost 30-minute, largely unbroken opening shot of a home birth — seems set to divert critical attention from the second.

headline: The World Starts Saying Goodbye, at Long Last, to 2020
abstract: The year that seemed to drag on forever is finally coming to an end.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our New Year’s Eve live coverage

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: China approves one of its coronavirus vaccines.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese government said on Thursday that it had approved a homegrown coronavirus vaccine after an early analysis of clinical trial results showed that it was effective. The announcements sent a positive signal for the global rollout of Chinese vaccines but lacked crucial details.

headline: FAFSA’s Expected Family Contribution Is Going Away. Good Riddance.
abstract: The dollar figure that the federal financial aid form spits out has long left families confused and despondent. And then, there are those great expectations.
lead_paragraph: The Expected Family Contribution — a dreaded and confusing term for parents about to send their children to college — made little sense in the best of times. Now, it’s finally going away.

headline: This Year Was a Disaster. We Hope the Sequel Is Better.
abstract: We streamed, we watched, we worried. We also wondered what the catastrophe called 2020 will mean for movies.
lead_paragraph: The end of December usually brings a flurry of big releases and a blizzard of Oscar speculation. But with the Academy Awards postponed and many theaters shuttered or half-empty, this movie year closes with a shiver of existential anxiety in Hollywood and beyond. In 2020, Netflix expanded its reach, and two of the surviving legacy studios — Warner Bros. and Disney — beefed up their streaming platforms, the latest sign of a shift in business strategy that is likely to outlast the pandemic. As 2021 approaches, our critics examine the film industry in crisis, and wonder what the future might hold.

headline: How the Networks Will Fill Airtime on a Quiet New Year’s Eve
abstract: In a typical year, shots of raucous parties from around the world dominate news programming. This year, the networks had to get more creative.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our New Year’s Eve live coverage

headline: 4 Art Gallery Shows to See Right Now
abstract: On view this week: Analia Saban’s subtly unique prints; Cate Giordano’s tableaus of Henry VIII’s bride; Kim Jones’s gritty assemblage-sculptures; and Harmony Hammond’s textile art.
lead_paragraph: A print, at least usually, isn’t finished when you pull the sheet off the lithograph stone or the copper plate. You have to sign the print, outside the plate mark, and then number it. So each identical print becomes unique outside the artwork’s borders — an antinomy that Analia Saban, an Argentine-artist based in Los Angeles, disturbs and amplifies in “This One,” her clever, subtly difficult recursive series of three black-and-white etchings.

headline: How the Novavax Vaccine Works
abstract: Using a coronavirus protein to train the immune system.
lead_paragraph: Using a coronavirus protein to train the immune system.

headline: How the Sinopharm Vaccine Works
abstract: Using inactivated coronaviruses to train the immune system.
lead_paragraph: Using inactivated coronaviruses to train the immune system.

headline: Colorado May Have Second Case of Coronavirus Variant
abstract: The newly discovered and more contagious variant of the coronavirus, which was first seen in Britain, may have been found in a second person in Colorado after the state and health officials reported its first known case on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The newly discovered and more contagious variant of the coronavirus, which was first seen in Britain, may have been found in a second person in Colorado after the state and health officials reported its first known case on Tuesday.

headline: Finding Solace in Hiking
abstract: A reader considers it a lifeline in dealing with the stresses of today. Also: Do politicians need a college degree?
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Dawn Wells, Mary Ann on ‘Gilligan’s Island,’ Dies at 82
abstract: Her character on the ’60s sitcom radiated all-American wholesomeness and youthful charm. After her TV career cooled, she focused on theater acting.
lead_paragraph: Dawn Wells, the actress who radiated all-American wholesomeness, Midwestern practicality and a youthful naïve charm as the character Mary Ann on the hit 1960s sitcom “Gilligan’s Island,” died on Wednesday at a nursing home in Los Angeles. She was 82.

headline: How to Celebrate New Year’s Eve With Kids
abstract: After nearly 10 months of sheltering in place, you might be out of ideas for a fun family night at home. Here’s how to get the party started.
lead_paragraph: After nearly 10 months of sheltering in place, you might be out of ideas for a fun family night at home. Here’s how to get the party started.

headline: I Miss Dap
abstract: In this year of losses, even the way we greet each other has changed.
lead_paragraph: It’s funny how, in the 10th month of Covid, some of the things I miss most are things I hadn’t thought were missable. I miss the barbershop, for instance, for reasons that would be obvious if you saw me. I used to make weekly trips, but I haven’t been since March. I feel as if I look like a mashup of Frederick Douglass and Chewbacca’s neck. I’m pining for the pomp and circumstance in the process of the cut, the ceremony of the barber raising and snapping the cape before smoothing it on me and fastening it around my neck, the sting and lovely stank of peroxide applied to my fresh hairline and newly speck-free neck. And then the big reveal — the moment when the artisan has finished and spins me in the chair to face the wall of mirrors and witness the masterwork.

headline: Vaccination Challenges, in the U.S. and Abroad
abstract: Readers discuss inoculation missteps in the United States, fears that poorer countries will be left behind and the virus mutation in Britain.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Nearly a Century Later, We’re Still Reading — and Changing Our Minds About — Gatsby
abstract: Our critic considers why F. Scott Fitzgerald’s classic inspires and withstands so much interpretation.
lead_paragraph: I’ve long held to the completely unsupported notion that a protagonist is simpler to write than a truly memorable supporting character. Sometimes just a silhouette — created with a few slashes of the pen, a few charismatic adjectives — seems the more unlikely accomplishment, born out of some surplus wit and energy, some surfeit of love for a fictional world that expresses itself in the desire to animate even its most minor participants.

headline: The Most-Read Food Stories of 2020
abstract: Readers turned to the Food section for advice on quarantine cooking, expiration dates and comfort food — lots of comfort food.
lead_paragraph: Decades from now, when cultural historians sift through the social media posts of 2020, they will tell the pandemic stories of savvy chefs and restaurateurs forced to pivot to meal kits, corner markets and sidewalk cafes as their industry collapsed, seemingly overnight. These historians will note the panic shopping of early March, as Americans rushed to buy N95 masks, toilet paper and Clorox wipes, along with whatever pantry staples they could find, 20-pound bags of flour and industrial-size bricks of active dry yeast included.

headline: Pentagon Sends More B-52s to Middle East to Deter Iranian Attacks on U.S. Troops
abstract: The flights came a week after President Trump warned Tehran following rocket strikes on the U.S. Embassy in Iraq.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two American B-52 bombers flew another show-of-force mission in the Persian Gulf on Wednesday, a week after President Trump warned Iran that he would hold it accountable “if one American is killed” in rocket attacks in Iraq that the administration and military officials blamed on Tehran.

headline: Brexit, Lockdown and a Vaccine: A Head-Spinning Day of Change in U.K.
abstract: Britain put millions more people under severe virus restrictions and approved a new vaccine, while Parliament approved a post-Brexit trade deal with the European Union.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Just before 3 p.m. on Wednesday, British lawmakers voted to ratify the Brexit trade agreement with the European Union, drawing a symbolic end to a debate that has sundered the country for more than four years.

headline: Stimulus Money Should Have Gone to the Jobless, Economists Say
abstract: While lawmakers debate increasing the payments to $2,000, most Americans are expected to save, not spend, their $600 checks.
lead_paragraph: Galen Gilbert knows just what he will do with the check he gets from Washington as part of the pandemic relief package, whatever the amount: put it in the bank.

headline: The Last Week of 2020
abstract: Suggestions for the end of the year.
lead_paragraph: Welcome. It’s the last week of the year, a time when many of us might normally be visiting with family and friends. This year has required some reconfiguring of holiday plans: You might be staying inside, with your usual brood or on your own; you might be working or looking for work; busy or looking for diversion. If you find yourself with the time and inclination to do some reading, there are a bunch of culture and lifestyle stories in The Times that you should check out.

headline: What’s in Our Queue? Lynette Yiadom-Boakye’s Art
abstract: I’m a senior staff editor on the Culture desk, based in London. Here are five things I've been reading and listening to.
lead_paragraph: I’m a senior staff editor on the Culture desk, based in London. Here are five things I've been reading and listening to.

headline: Indian State Ruled by Modi’s Party Bans Islamic Schools
abstract: More than 700 madrasas in Assam will be shut by April, the state’s education minister said. Opposition politicians called the move an attack on Muslims.
lead_paragraph: GUWAHATI, India — An Indian state ruled by Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s Hindu nationalist party on Wednesday passed a law abolishing all Islamic schools, saying they provided substandard education.

headline: U.S. Penalizes Venezuelan Officials Involved in Imprisoning 6 American Oil Executives
abstract: The so-called Citgo 6 were lured to Venezuela for a business meeting in 2017 and have been sentenced to prison on charges of corruption.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration imposed sanctions on Wednesday on two Venezuelan officials for their roles in sending six American oil executives to prison on corruption charges.

headline: 74 of Our Favorite Facts for 2020
abstract: Each day, our editors collect the most interesting, striking or delightful facts to appear in articles throughout the paper. Here are 74 from the past year that were the most revealing.
lead_paragraph: 1. Japan’s legal system has a 99 percent conviction rate.Carlos Ghosn, at Home but Waiting for the Next Move

headline: U.S. Officials Say Covid-19 Vaccination Effort Has Lagged
abstract: “We know that it should be better, and we’re working hard to make it better,” said Moncef Slaoui, a leader of the federal effort to accelerate vaccine development and distribution.
lead_paragraph: The distribution of vaccines in the United States has gotten off to a slower-than-expected start, federal health officials acknowledged in a news conference on Wednesday, though they also voiced confidence that the pace would accelerate in the coming weeks.

headline: Amazon Buys Wondery as Podcasting Race Continues
abstract: The deal, valued at $300 million, is the latest in a string of acquisitions as streaming platforms expand beyond music and video.
lead_paragraph: Amazon is acquiring Wondery, the company behind podcasts such as “Dirty John,” “Dr. Death” and “The Shrink Next Door,” as the race to grab parts of the audio market continues.

headline: Iran Approves Payments for Shooting Down Ukraine Airliner
abstract: Tehran said it will pay $150,000 to the family of each victim, but Ukraine said it expects more, including a thorough investigation.
lead_paragraph: Iran’s Cabinet on Wednesday allocated $150,000 for the families of each of the 176 people killed when Iranian forces shot down a Ukrainian airliner in January, the official IRNA news agency reported.

headline: California Will Offer Financial Incentives to Reopen School Districts
abstract: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California unveiled a $2 billion plan on Wednesday aimed at getting elementary school students back in the classroom safely starting in February, creating incentives of at least $450 per student to a phased-in reopening of classrooms for those who want to return.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California unveiled a $2 billion plan on Wednesday aimed at getting elementary school students back in the classroom safely starting in February, creating incentives of at least $450 per student to a phased-in reopening of classrooms for those who want to return.

headline: In Four Audio Plays, No Stages but Lots of New Voices
abstract: A big-box store, a hotel for transgender women and a dinner party gone awry are some of the places your ears will take you to.
lead_paragraph: When actors can’t gather onstage, they can still make drama with their voices. Our critics review four recent audio plays.

headline: Discovery of Virus Variant in Colorado and California Alarms Scientists
abstract: A more contagious version of the coronavirus may alter the course of the pandemic in the United States, researchers said.
lead_paragraph: A contagious variant of the coronavirus spreading through Britain has left that nation grappling with new lockdowns, curtailed air travel and a surge in infections. Now it has appeared in Colorado and California, threatening to complicate what had seemed a hopeful, if halting, path to recovery from the pandemic.

headline: National Gallery of Art Acquires 40 Works by Black Southern Artists
abstract: The acquisition adds paintings, quilts and sculptures by more than 20 African-American artists, many of them self-taught, into the collection.
lead_paragraph: The National Gallery of Art in Washington has announced the acquisition of 40 works from the Souls Grown Deep Foundation, a nonprofit organization that for the last decade has dedicated itself to promoting the contributions of African-American artists from the South.

headline: Ticketmaster Will Pay $10 Million to Put Songkick Criminal Case to Rest
abstract: The concert giant has agreed to pay the fine to resolve charges that it intruded into the computer system of one of its competitors.
lead_paragraph: Ticketmaster has agreed to pay a $10 million fine to resolve charges that it intruded into the computer system of one of its competitors, prosecutors said on Wednesday, ending a yearslong legal battle over claims that the company illegally interfered in the business of a ticketing start-up called Songkick.

headline: Hawley Answers Trump’s Call for Election Challenge
abstract: The Republican senator said he would object to certifying the Electoral College votes on Jan. 6, a move that is unlikely to alter President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Josh Hawley became the first senator on Wednesday to take up President Trump’s demand that lawmakers challenge the results of the 2020 election, saying he would object to Congress’s certification of the Electoral College results on Jan. 6.

headline: Early Voting Numbers in Georgia Senate Races Put G.O.P. on Edge
abstract: While polls suggest that the state’s crucial runoff elections are up for grabs, Republicans have grown worried about strong turnout in Democratic areas and mixed messages from President Trump.
lead_paragraph: MACON, Ga. — Senator Kelly Loeffler issued a now-familiar warning during a campaign event on Wednesday in Bibb County: If Democrats win the Georgia Senate runoff elections, there will be little left to stem a rising tide of extremist socialism in America.

headline: Stimulus, Virus Variant, Georgia: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Rita Houston, WFUV D.J. Who Lifted Music Careers, Dies at 59
abstract: From a studio in the Bronx, she introduced listeners to artists from a wide range of genres. She was also a mentor to the stars, and a sometime-confidante.
lead_paragraph: Rita Houston, a big-hearted disc jockey with an intoxicating voice who championed artists like Brandi Carlile, Mumford & Sons, Adele, the Indigo Girls and Gomez at the widely followed WFUV-FM in the Bronx, died on Dec. 15 at her home in Valley Cottage, N.Y. She was 59.

headline: As the Pandemic Took Lives, It Also Stole Hopes
abstract: Many of Covid-19’s victims had been entering new chapters in their lives: fatherhood, a career, freedom, citizenship.
lead_paragraph: The scythe of Covid-19 was unsparing as it devastated one nation after another, claiming all  types of people in a death toll now heading toward 2 million.

headline: Death Transformed a Year, and What May Lie Ahead
abstract: As Covid-19 swept the world, the killing of George Floyd galvanized a racial justice movement, and the death of Ruth Bader Ginsburg upended the makeup of the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: Death has rarely so shaped a year as it did in 2020. It swept the world riding the back of the coronavirus. It galvanized a Black Lives Matter movement across the United States and abroad, sending people of all colors into the streets to demand social justice. It altered the ideological makeup of the United States Supreme Court so decisively that the consequences of that shift will assuredly be felt for decades.

headline: Don’t Let the Games Begin
abstract: College athletics can teach the right lesson by insisting that public health is more important than sports.
lead_paragraph: Look no further than the storied Rose Bowl game to understand the National Collegiate Athletic Association’s disingenuous and perilous posturing about the sanctity of its athletics programs while the coronavirus has ravaged the country and college campuses.

headline: This New Year’s Eve, Times Square Will Be Filled With Hope. But Not People.
abstract: Celebrations will be muted as 2020 finally comes to an end, but they will bring much-needed touches of grace.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our New Year’s Eve live coverage]

headline: ‘No Realistic Path’ for Quick Vote on $2,000 Stimulus Checks, McConnell Says
abstract: The Senate leader all but ended any chance of increasing direct payments, despite some Republican support for the effort.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Mitch McConnell effectively killed off any chance that Congress would increase stimulus checks to $2,000 before President Trump leaves office, saying there was “no realistic path” for the Senate to pass a stand-alone bill.

headline: The Bomb That Struck the Heart of Nashville
abstract: I’m thinking of the weight we’ve all been carrying this year, in my city and everywhere else.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — If years were musical genres, 2020 would be a country song — or maybe a blues album, or possibly gospel. It’s hard to know, in the midst of sorrow, exactly which brand of anguish is lodged in the human soul. I do know this, though: It’s been a miserable year here, a year that tore our hearts to pieces even before a bomb reduced a historic part of this city to rubble on Christmas Day.

headline: Closing of Air Traffic Control Center for Virus Cleaning Halts Flights in Dallas
abstract: Covid case at F.A.A. center in Fort Worth leads to ripples of delays and diverted flights across the country.
lead_paragraph: An air traffic control center that serves Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport was closed for several hours on Wednesday for cleaning after an employee tested positive for the coronavirus, grounding flights at one of the world’s busiest hubs.

headline: The Small Colorado Town felt insulated from the Pandemic. Then Came the Coronavirus Variant.
abstract: Simla, Colo., an isolated ranching community, is the site of the first known case in the United States of a new, more infectious variant of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: SIMLA, Colo. — An isolated ranching community on the high plains is the last place its residents expect to be first for anything, especially a new, more infectious variant of the coronavirus. But on Wednesday, state health officials announced that the first known case of the variant in the United States had been confirmed at a nursing home in Simla, Colo.

headline: Critics Say Nashville Police Could Have Done More With Tip About Bomber
abstract: Anthony Warner’s girlfriend told the police last year he was building bombs in his R.V. Police officials said they took their inquiry as far as they could at the time.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — The woman was clearly in distress, sitting on her front porch with a pair of unloaded pistols beside her when the police arrived in August of last year. The weapons belonged to her boyfriend, Anthony Warner, she told the officers, and she wanted them gone. And, she added, Mr. Warner was building bombs inside the R.V. parked at his house.

headline: After Breonna Taylor Case, Louisville Police Face Precarious Next Chapter
abstract: An interim police chief has nearly finished her work, and the city is at a crossroads. Will a department handling one of the nation’s most controversial police shootings win back the city’s trust?
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — The news conference on a Friday afternoon in March was brief and opaque. The Louisville police chief said officers serving a drug warrant at an apartment had been met with gunfire. An officer had been shot and a woman had been killed, the chief said, and a man inside had been charged with trying to murder a police officer.

headline: Forever Is Never
abstract: A third grader reflects on the miserable year of 2020.

headline: 2020: The Year in Visual Stories and Graphics
abstract: Selected Times graphics, visualizations and multimedia stories from the year.
lead_paragraph: Selected Times graphics, visualizations and multimedia stories from the year.

headline: Squirming, Maybe
abstract: David J. Kahn escorts the old year to the door.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — This is the final Wordplay of the year, and what a year it has been for crosswords, which were surely one of the amusements that kept us sane. To celebrate, we invited David J. Kahn into our living room for the most entertaining solving session of the week.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Missouri Senator Says He’ll Join Election Challenge, Dividing the G.O.P.
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, December 31, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “This is a very serious person doing a very unserious thing.”

headline: Corrections: Dec. 31, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Dec. 31, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about a German officer who faces terrorism charges described incorrectly the location of Baustarring, a Bavarian hamlet. It is 250 miles east of Franco A.’s former army base, not 250 miles west.

headline: Trump Was Briefed on Uncorroborated Intelligence About Chinese Bounties
abstract: The unverified intelligence echoes a similar report, deemed credible by the C.I.A. but dismissed by the president, that Russian military agents had offered payments for attacks on Americans in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: President Trump was briefed this month about intelligence reports that China had offered to pay bounties to fighters in Afghanistan who attacked American soldiers there, but the information was uncorroborated and comes months after Mr. Trump dismissed as a “hoax” a C.I.A. assessment that Russia had paid for such attacks.

headline: Minneapolis Police Fatally Shoot Man During Traffic Stop
abstract: It was the first killing by a Minneapolis officer since George Floyd’s death in May. The chief said witnesses indicated that the man had fired first.
lead_paragraph: A Minneapolis police officer killed a man in an exchange of gunfire during a traffic stop on Wednesday evening, the police chief said, the first killing by a member of the department since George Floyd’s death in May. Protesters quickly descended on the snow-covered scene, and city officials begged them not to revive the unrest that left parts of the city aflame in the spring.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: The vote on a long-awaited Brexit deal.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: N.F.L. Week 17 Predictions: Our Picks Against the Spread
abstract: Ten teams will be fighting for seven playoff spots on a final regular-season Sunday when numerous playoff seedings can change.
lead_paragraph: Heading into the final Sunday of the regular season, seven teams have secured playoff spots and 10 others are in contention for seven positions. The key battles will come in the A.FC. South and the N.F.C. East and for the wild-card spots in both conferences, with plenty of seeding yet to be decided as well.

headline: Samuel Little, Serial Killer Who Confessed to 93 Murders, Dies at 80
abstract: At least 50 of those murders were verified by law enforcement officers, according to the F.B.I., which declared Mr. Little the “most prolific” serial killer in U.S. history.
lead_paragraph: Samuel Little, who surpassed even such lethal predators as Ted Bundy and John Wayne Gacy to become the most prolific serial killer in U.S. history while going undetected for decades, died at a Los Angeles-area hospital on Wednesday, California corrections officials said. He was 80.

headline: Working From Bed Is Actually Great
abstract: A perfect metaphor for a year of giving up and giving in.
lead_paragraph: For years, sleep experts have held one piece of common wisdom above all else: that devices have no place in the bedroom.

headline: Siblings Are Killed in I-95 Crash in Florida as Suspect Speeds Wrong Way
abstract: A carjacking suspect fleeing the police drove north in southbound lanes and struck an S.U.V. on Interstate 95 near Daytona Beach.
lead_paragraph: A brother and sister driving back from seeing a display of Christmas lights at Daytona International Speedway in Florida were killed Tuesday night when a man fleeing the police at speeds over 110 m.p.h. drove against traffic on southbound Interstate 95 and struck their S.U.V. head-on, the authorities said.

headline: Ohio offered nursing home workers early dibs on a vaccine. Many said no.
abstract: Although the vast majority of nursing home residents in Ohio are accepting a vaccine for Covid-19, the same cannot be said for the staff in these facilities, Gov. Mike DeWine said on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Although the vast majority of nursing home residents in Ohio are accepting a vaccine for Covid-19, the same cannot be said for the staff in these facilities, Gov. Mike DeWine said on Wednesday.

headline: A beloved Chicago bowling alley gets a pandemic reprieve.
abstract: At first, it seemed as if Southport Lanes in the Lakeview section of Chicago would be yet another sad casualty of 2020.
lead_paragraph: At first, it seemed as if Southport Lanes in the Lakeview section of Chicago would be yet another sad casualty of 2020.

headline: When the virus variant came to a tiny Colorado town.
abstract: Simla, Colo., an isolated ranching community on the high plains, is the last place locals expect to be first for anything, especially a new, more infectious variant of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Simla, Colo., an isolated ranching community on the high plains, is the last place locals expect to be first for anything, especially a new, more infectious variant of the coronavirus.

headline: Fou Ts’ong, Pianist Whose Family Letters Inspired a Generation, Dies at 86
abstract: Driven from China during Mao’s rule, Mr. Fou kept up a correspondence with his father that became a beloved book in the wake of the Cultural Revolution.
lead_paragraph: Fou Ts’ong, a Chinese pianist known for his sensitive interpretations of Chopin, Debussy and Mozart, and whose letters from his father, a noted translator and writer, influenced a generation of Chinese readers, died on Monday at a hospital in London, where he had lived for many years. He was 86.

headline: Your Dog Had the Best Year Ever
abstract: The past 10 months have brought us plague, isolation and economic despair. But all that desolation was strangely good news for some people and trends.
lead_paragraph: The past 10 months have brought us plague, isolation and economic despair. But all that desolation was strangely good news for some people and trends.

headline: In the Cultural Revolution, Ai Weiwei’s Father Burned the Family’s Books
abstract: “It confirmed in me how powerful those words printed on paper, and the images in between, could be.”
lead_paragraph: “It confirmed in me how powerful those words printed on paper, and the images in between, could be,” says the artist and human rights activist, whose new book is “Human Flow: Stories From the Global Refugee Crisis.”

headline: Is Pam Jenoff a Law Professor Moonlighting as a Novelist, or Vice Versa? You Decide
abstract: The prolific author describes her double life as “messy” and “imperfect.” Nevertheless, she publishes a lot of books.
lead_paragraph: IN BRIEF When Pam Jenoff introduces herself to a new group of students at Rutgers Law School, she doesn’t usually talk about what she’s up to outside the classroom.

headline: In Searching Essays, Knausgaard Extols the Freedom and Limitations of Art
abstract: “In the Land of the Cyclops,” the Norwegian author’s first essay collection to be published in English, circles the mysteries of artistic creation, including his own writing process.
lead_paragraph: IN THE LAND OF THE CYCLOPSEssaysBy Karl Ove Knausgaard

headline: Looking for a Westchester House, but No Gardening Please. Which Did They Choose?
abstract: Needing more space and a better setup for their growing family, this couple searched some of Westchester’s homeowners’ associations for a house without the headaches. Here’s what they found.
lead_paragraph: Needing more space and a better setup for their growing family, this couple searched some of Westchester’s homeowners’ associations for a house without the headaches. Here’s what they found.

headline: 2020 Taught Us How to Fix This
abstract: Our current model of social change isn’t working.
lead_paragraph: This is the year that broke the truth. This is the year when millions of Americans — and not just your political opponents — seemed impervious to evidence, willing to believe the most outlandish things if it suited their biases, and eager to develop fervid animosities based on crude stereotypes.

headline: 2020 Was a Test. How Did We Do?
abstract: The pandemic gave us an unwelcome chance to find out what we missed, what we could do without — and how much risk we are willing to take.
lead_paragraph: You don’t need a psychiatrist to tell you it’s been a brutal year. But looking back on 2020, it’s clear we’ve undergone a big psychosocial stress test: Our response to the deadly challenge of Covid-19 helped us discover what we value and who we really are, a mirror held up to humanity.

headline: Fuzzy Slippers for a Frazzled Year
abstract: You should absolutely be wearing shoes at home. Why not make them as cloudlike as possible?
lead_paragraph: Once upon a time, slippers were reserved for the hours spent indoors before and after work. But for the masses working from home this year, dress codes have been transformed — business casual, who? — including footwear. Farewell, heels; hello, fuzzy slides.

headline: News That Can Last a Million Years
abstract: In a year that felt apocalyptic, Martin Kunze has been making plans for the actual end of the world, with some help from The Times.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: The Champagne Toast Takes on Extra Special Meaning
abstract: When my parents first met the man who would become my husband, they ordered a bottle of Piper-Heidsieck and waited for news of a proposal.
lead_paragraph: When my father ordered champagne, it baffled my boyfriend, but not me.

headline: This Is Why Nursing Homes Failed So Badly
abstract: The first coronavirus outbreak in the United States happened in a nursing home in February. Since then, it’s only gotten worse.
lead_paragraph: Eight months into the pandemic, Brendan House, a nursing home in Kalispell, Mont., had not had a single resident test positive for the coronavirus. It was an extraordinary feat, given that 40 percent of the deaths from Covid-19 nationwide had occurred in long-term care facilities.

headline: U.S. Companies to Face China Tariffs as Exclusions Expire
abstract: Many American companies could see their exemptions from President Trump’s China tariffs expire at midnight on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American companies are facing the prospect of higher taxes on some of the products they import from China, as the tariff exclusions that had shielded many businesses from President Trump’s trade war are set to expire at midnight on Thursday.

headline: The Year in Charts
abstract: A tour of the major trends, from Covid-19 spread to political polarization, that affected Americans this year.
lead_paragraph: If 2019 was the Year of Trump, then 2020 was the Year of Covid-19 and Trump. Only the most devastating pandemic in a century could have bumped our loudmouthed president into second place. That is, until Joe Biden also took him down a peg, in a free and fair election with an unambiguous result — except in the world of Trump. And oh yes, all of this occurred during the biggest recession since the Great Depression.

headline: Look but Don’t Touch: Supercars That Have Barely Been Driven
abstract: The power and prestige of cars like a 1990 Lamborghini might compel some owners to take a Sunday drive. But with odometers this low, the investment would take a hit.
lead_paragraph: Supercars hold their value better the less you play with them, much like collectible children’s toys that are worth more when sealed inside the original packaging. But what’s the fun in that?

headline: The Most Popular Real Estate Stories of 2020
abstract: Many of our most-read articles this year sprang from the coronavirus pandemic, whether examining its impact or offering ideas for diversion.
lead_paragraph: As with every other aspect of American life in 2020, the coronavirus pandemic dominated the real estate industry this year — wreaking havoc on markets, shattering our ingrained routines and traditions at home, changing the way we move around, and leaving us with an uneasy awareness that 2021 may be equally unpredictable.

headline: Virus Disrupts College Football Playoffs Even Before Kickoff
abstract: Both semifinals are being played in abnormal circumstances: The Rose Bowl will be in Texas, and the Sugar Bowl will feature teams hit hard by the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: The Sun Bowl, which has been played in El Paso, Texas, every year since 1935, is such a local institution that its organizers were determined to play the game even if teams arrived the day before the New Year’s Eve kickoff and attendance had to be capped at 8,600.

headline: This Is How New Yorkers Will Remember a Year They Can’t Wait to Forget
abstract: “There’s some pieces of normalcy that I don’t really want back,” said one New Yorker. “Our normal wasn’t always ideal.”
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers stand this week as the living footnotes of tomorrow’s textbooks. The year 2020 will be studied by historians, scientists and schoolchildren for generations, and yet, it will be known by many of those who lived through it for the singular moments that arrived behind a pandemic’s deadly waves.

headline: My Joe Biden Story
abstract: In a career as a journalist, I had never encountered a politician like him.
lead_paragraph: As Ben Smith, the media columnist for The Times, suggested a few weeks ago, pretty much every journalist who passed through Washington, D.C., during the past half century knows President-elect Joe Biden and has a story to tell. I’d like to end this strange year, and welcome the new one and the new president, by telling mine.

headline: This Police Union Suspended 8 Members. Seven Are Black.
abstract: The union in a small New Jersey city punished the officers after they expressed support for two chiefs, both of whom are also Black.
lead_paragraph: ENGLEWOOD, N.J. — The tensions within the Englewood Police Department had simmered for months: at disciplinary hearings, during Black Lives Matter marches and in the fallout over no-confidence votes by the officers’ union in the chief and deputy chief.

headline: German Automakers Are Charged Up and Ready to Take on Tesla
abstract: As Tesla completes a factory in Berlin, Mercedes-Benz and Audi are introducing electric cars in bids to defend their dominance of the luxury market.
lead_paragraph: HOCKENHEIM, Germany — The Porsche Taycan rocketed from a standstill so fast that my skull banged against the headrest and my vision went blurry.

headline: 10 Stories of Support in a Year of Obstacles
abstract: Facing challenges wrought by the pandemic, The Fund’s beneficiaries brought help to people and communities.
lead_paragraph: Sheeba Shafaq grew up in Afghanistan watching her grandmother work as a midwife and her father help patients as a plastic surgeon and emergency medical technician. For her, treating people was the ultimate goal.

headline: An Olympic Dream Is Reborn, Despite Fears of Brain Trauma
abstract: A.J. Edelman walked away from the hazards of sledding sports after he competed for Israel in the skeleton at the 2018 Winter Games. Now he is trying again in a bobsled.
lead_paragraph: A.J. Edelman was worried.

headline: 5 Things to Do This New Year’s Weekend
abstract: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience virtually.
lead_paragraph: Since September, the Joyce Theater has been offering a free virtual fall season that is as good as some of its best in-person ones. The secret has been surprise and an avoidance of the usual suspects. If that is a little less true of the latest batch of videos — available through Sunday at joyce.org/joycestream — the variety still provides plenty of spice.

headline: Randall Cunningham Is Back in the N.F.L. … as Raiders Chaplain
abstract: “I want to preach myself into a Super Bowl ring.”
lead_paragraph: Despite his best efforts, Randall Cunningham just can’t retire from football. A former quarterback for the Philadelphia Eagles and Minnesota Vikings, he tried walking away from the game twice, dabbling in a variety of activities to fill the void.

headline: ‘The Other Half of My Soul’: Widows of Covid-19 Bond Over Sudden Loss
abstract: Men have died of the coronavirus in larger numbers than women, leaving untold thousands of spouses suddenly alone. Some have turned to bereavement groups on Facebook.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — One Friday evening, Sandra McGowan-Watts, a 46-year-old doctor from suburban Chicago, opened her laptop, stifled her nerves and told strangers on a Zoom call what had happened to her husband, Steven.

headline: Jobs, Houses and Cows: China’s Costly Drive to Erase Extreme Poverty
abstract: China has spent heavily to help its poorest citizens, an approach that few developing countries can afford and even Beijing may struggle to sustain.
lead_paragraph: JIEYUAN VILLAGE, China — When the Chinese government offered free cows to farmers in Jieyuan, villagers in the remote mountain community were skeptical. They worried officials would ask them to return the cattle later, along with any calves they managed to raise.

headline: Was That a Dropped Call From ET?
abstract: A spooky radio signal showed up after a radio telescope was aimed at the next star over from our sun.
lead_paragraph: Nobody believes it was ET phoning, but radio astronomers admit they don’t have an explanation yet for a beam of radio waves that apparently came from the direction of the star Proxima Centauri.

headline: Vanessa Kirby Has Been Waiting for a Role That Scares Her
abstract: For her first lead in a film, the actress wanted a character as challenging as many of those she’s played onstage. She found it in Kornel Mundruczo’s “Pieces of a Woman.”
